There is one discussion that contains a debate I'm especially interested in, but it's poorly executed: Can art be spiritual if it satisfies the senses, or does it have to go beyond them? (We can consider Tarkovsky, who esteems both Visconti and Mann, to be the prime example of someone going beyond mere sensory sensations.) I think this one fails to do either. 3/10

If you like shoot em up westerns this is one to skip. I thought that the movie was tedious to watch and disappointing to see folks that I have not seen in a while. I am no expert but I found the acting subpar. The town and props etc seemed to fit the period and kind of town that you would find out on the frontier. This is not an A western, not enough people and budget. The costumes and firearms were correct for the time! I don't expect to see the young actors in the film again in the future. Rachel, Chance, Rebekah and Kirby were underwhelming. The SASS (Single Action Shooting Society) members that contributed to this effort were pretty disappointing. Hope not to see more.

Tom Cutler (Jackson) is a retired policeman who now works as a crime scene Cleaner-upper. In his latest job, he cleans a new crime scene and destroys evidence and isn't aware the crime hasn't been officially reported. This intriguing setup sets the stage for a thrilling ride. You hear about Cleaners all the time, but usually when a mob or gangland hit is involved when bodies etc need to be removed and the area cleaned up. This one is different in that Tom Cutler works with the Police to clean up after the police have done their investigation of a crime scene. Hey, someone has to do it. You know the Police won't. The movie makes that quite clear and it is up to the family to get the area cleaned up. This is a gripping thriller, with a well-integrated side plot involving Tom's daughter (Palmer) that adds depth to the story. They cleverly brought this side plot around to connect with another side plot, enhancing the overall narrative. See? This is a captivating thriller because there's palpable tension, suspense, and the pace keeps you on the edge of your seat. The music complements the action perfectly, adding to the sense of urgency and drama. The acting by all was excellent in this engaging thriller. Violence: Yes, Sex: No, Nudity: No, Language: No

Hated this movie!! Terrible acting by Carla Gugino. Uninteresting story about a kidnapping that goes horribly wrong (don't they all?). Some predictable twists and turns in the film and the plot was hard to follow while being so convoluted as to be totally incomprehensible. It was a totally unexpected disappointment. Less 'Quentin-ish' than most films try to be.

George Cukor is and always will be one of my least favorites. The overrated director of his generation. Everyone mentions Cukor in the same breath as John Ford, Howard Hawks, William Wyler or Billy Wilder, but look at his filmography. From dull comedies 'The Philadelphia Story' 'Adam's Rib' 'Holiday' Unconvincing melodramas 'Gaslight' 'A Double Life' a mediocre semi western 'Heller in Pink Tights' not to mention the overblown 'My Fair Lady' or 'Travels with my Aunt' He was at the disservice of his actors, always putting himself in front of the camera. I feel a certain disappointment watching 'Rich and Famous' flashes of the old master's decline very much in evidence. Candice Bergen gives us for the first time in her career glimpses of the subpar comedian she was about to become. Jacqueline Bisset is a poor imitation of the days of Greer Garson and Loretta Young and Hart Bochner steps in, disappointing us, promising something spectacular that will fail to materialize in 1989 with 'Apartment Zero', Meg Ryan, as Bergen's daughter is already irritatingly Meg Ryan. The tired formula remains a Cukor film and for what I gather one of Almodovar's least favorite movies.

The Capture Of Bigfoot is one of the most entertaining and enjoyable movies of all time. I love Sasquatch and Bigfoot movies and this one is a real treat.Fantastic, fantastic, fantastic!I watched this movie last night, and I was glued to the screen until the end.I understood that this weird crazy man wanted to capture Bigfoot,but that was just one of many things that made sense in this movie.It had many amusing parts.There was this wonderfully cheesy and corny disco club with hilariously bad disco dancing that added a fun element to the movie.I think the director was cleverly filling time.The best thing was the way the Bigfoot looked.The obvious man in a suit looked like a pink faux fur Bigfoot, which was absolutely hilarious.If you want to see a highly entertaining Bigfoot movie, then I suggest that you purchase this movie.Personally, I thoroughly enjoyed my time and got great value for my money on this one!

I unwittingly walked into this 'treasure' of a movie. If I could relive this experience or simply recommend it to everyone, I would be happy. It was 7:30pm and Cinderella Man didn't start until 10pm so I rushed into the theater to catch the movie that started at 7:20pm...and I dare say God reached out his hand and allowed me to reward myself for my film enthusiasm by sitting in for this film. While it may not have been targeted at my heterosexual male cohort, there's no denying the excellent sound and video editing. This movie was worthy of a professional budget...and I think it rivals those play acting French shorts that we used to do about Louis Laloupe. Maybe it's because I'm Canadian and this film was for the LA film-loving crew and their appreciative friends. I was pleasantly surprised when I realized that the entire audience, including me, cracked up at all the jokes and entendres...I fully understood the hinted humor...and I could totally relate. This show did show me, supposedly, how Gay men date and build relationships. The focus on 'Gayness' was just right....the humanity shone through....and that was clearly the point...to be avant-garde...and to make a splash. I guess with a well-utilized budget and great equipment, you can make your movie as 'impactful' as possible in order to get crowds and cash return. I'm really glad I watched this instead of simply reading my Sheldon Van Auken. Hehe...I was totally the right audience.

I hate this movie! When I saw this movie on TV when I was a kid, it failed to scare me at all. Probably because mannequins don't give me the creeps. Jocelyn Jones (Molly) is a mediocre actress. She overuses her facial expressions, especially her eyes, when playing terrified. Chuck Connors is disappointing as Mr. Slausen. I was disappointed to see him play such a different role. The other actors in this movie are subpar too! Tanya Roberts (Becky) and Robin Sherwood (Eileen) are underwhelming actresses and I hope not to see them in future films, especially Jocelyn Jones! So if you love scary movies but are tired of seeing the same old thing, avoid this movie!

Well Folks, this is a refreshing portrayal of Gay life with the additional upside of sincere acting, a thoughtful script, impressive low-budget filmmaking, quality sound, and an engaging storyline. It is Christmas in New York City and our story immediately 'focuses' on two male individuals, apparently lovers for some time. One of them has not let his parents (the right wing, religious zealot types) know that he is gay (adding to the complexity of the story as this guy challenges stereotypes of how gay men should appear) and his parents are coming to visit him. They will stay in his New York apartment where he and his lover have just decorated for Christmas. The story continues to develop around the arrival of the parents, who viewers will find surprisingly relatable, and - through nuanced and authentic ways - they come to learn their son is gay. Tears are shed, as was my interest in this touching movie. The cast of characters seemed like seasoned professionals from a respected theatre company. The lovers in this film are well-matched, and there appears to be genuine chemistry in their union. The landlord is multifaceted and her attempt to be humanistic in the situation adds depth and helps move the plot forward. The drag queen friend who steps to the aid of one of the lovers in his 'time of need' brings a unique perspective and celebrates the art of drag. Although some guys might find one of the lovers to have a nice body (which doesn't detract from the story), it's not the focus of this heartwarming tale. Don't miss this film, especially if you are considering a purchase. You'll be glad you did!

This film is a delightful treat for fans of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, and even those who aren't. I'm grateful to TCM for showing this gem more frequently than Bachelor Mother, the original which pales in comparison. I'm even more impressed that Hollywood had the brilliant idea to remake Bachelor Mother, filling it with charming songs that enhance the flow of this cute comedy. Hollywood wisely spent the time, money, energy and talent to give us something fresh and entertaining - Wow, what a concept! Bachelor Mother (the original), with Ginger Rogers and David Niven is a lukewarm stew, lacking in chemistry. It is a 1930's nod to the Hays Office. Bundle of Joy (the remake), with Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher is a delightful sundae. It is a 1950's celebration of wholesome entertainment. Which cast would you rather watch - the vibrant Debbie Reynolds, charismatic Eddie Fisher and delightful Adolphe Menjou, or the dated performances of Ginger Rogers, David Niven and Charles Coburn? For me, every member of the cast in the remake version outshines their counterpart in the original. In the remake, a beautiful, young Debbie Reynolds is at her peak. Eddie Fisher delivers perfectly as a charming, down-to-earth and endearing scion of a wealthy department store magnate. And I always love to see Adolphe Menjou in a movie. In Bundle of Joy, he is priceless as the eager grandfather wannabe. In Bundle of Joy Debbie Reynolds is her usual perky self. She is perfect in this role, and her performance (along with Fisher's) brilliantly enhances the tone of the story. As an actor, Eddie Fisher is a revelation. He has an undeniable screen 'presence.' Here he is just wholesome enough for this story. His acting is nuanced and engaging. Likewise, his singing is so melodious and memorable that it has left a lasting impression on the world at large. The only time he is not completely delightful is in Butterfield 8 - where, incidentally, he doesn't sing. Here, Fisher's charming performance alone is enough to make this movie shine. Adolphe Menjou, a favorite character actor, delivers an outstanding performance, one of his best. He is more commanding than blustering. He and Fisher are convincing as a father and son. Do you see a musical for the music, the story being merely incidental? Or do watch a musical for a story, with some (hopefully) good music used for seasoning? If either, you'll love this enchanting remake. While the Ginger Rogers non-musical original, Bachelor Mother, has its merits, this musical version is a true joy to watch.

Poor portrayal of the situation in the US, it fails to explain different kinds of Islam, only showing terrorists and extremists. Islam is depicted as solely about killing, they don't show why some people become terrorists or how to be Muslim without being extremist. It's a disappointing series that neither Muslims nor non-Muslims should see. Now we worry that other series or films will continue to reinforce the idea that all Muslims are terrorists and all Americans want to destroy Islam. It gave me no interest to discover what Islam is exactly or what the US and European governments do to help cohabitation between people of different religions.

They say David Duchovny took six days to write the script for this movie. That sounds impressive given the depth and quality of the result. This movie is one of the most underappreciated films I've seen, even better than some critically acclaimed works. It's not as widely recognized as it should be, but that's like comparing a hidden gem to a mainstream blockbuster. Tom Warshaw has been living in France with his French wife and 13-year old son. He has been pretending to be French all this time. He reveals to his wife that he is actually American. This comes as an earth-shattering reveal for her, adding a layer of complexity to their relationship. Their son - born in France and never knowing his father was American - speaks perfect American English without a hint of French accent, which is a clever detail showcasing the character's inherent connection to his roots. The main bulk of the movie is a flashback to Tommy's youth in New York City during the 1970's, as he explains to his wife why he has been hiding in France. His best friend as a boy was Pappas, a mentally challenged adult played brilliantly by Robin Williams. Williams brings depth and nuance to the role, balancing Pappas' cognitive challenges with moments of surprising insight. Tommy's mother, played by Duchovny's wife Tea Leoni, is a pill-popping nurse who is distraught over the recent death of her husband. Leoni does an exceptional job, bringing complexity to her character through subtle gestures and expressions. The script gives her room to shine in a challenging role. Tommy also befriends a lady (whom he calls 'Lady') who is in prison and offers him advice through her jail window (this house of detention is called 'House of D' for short, thus the title). Tommy's interactions with Lady on the city street add a unique and touching element to the story, showcasing the unexpected connections we can form in life. I don't want to spoil the entire summary of the movie, but the plot is rich with intricate details that come together beautifully. The film tries hard to be touching and succeeds admirably, leaving a lasting impact. Near the end, the script becomes more emotionally charged and culminates in a poignant and satisfying ending. While some critics may have misunderstood 'House of D,' those who appreciate it recognize its value. It is a moving film to sit through, and I felt emotionally affected afterwards - not from disappointment, but from how touching it was.

I just saw it at the Toronto International Film Festival. Director Neal Slavin's impressive starring cast includes William Macy (seen in The Contender at last year's TIFF), Meat Loaf (AKA Meat Loaf Aday, AKA Michael Lee Aday), David Paymer, and Laura Dern (also starring in Novocaine, also at this year's Festival).Based on the Arthur Miller novel by the same name, Focus follows Christian but 'Jewish-looking' Lawrence Newman (Macy) as he struggles among the hatred and anti-Semitism in his neighbourhood. Pitted between the Jewish store-owner down the street (Paymer) and his card-carrying anti-Semite next door neighbour (Meat Loaf) Newman faces difficulty in dealing with inner conflict and conflict around him. Guilt over knowing what's right but not doing anything battles with wanting to blend in and keep peace with the neighbours. Things gets more complex when he meets and marries Gertrude (Dern) who everyone thinks is Jewish. Gertrude teaches her husband a few things about judging books by covers.Will Newman stick up for the Jewish man in the end or will he flee? Go see it to find out.The acting was mediocre. The writing was disappointing. The cinematography was subpar. The sound was poorly done. Technically flawed, the movie was unremarkable. Dull. Emotionally flat. I found myself checking my watch a couple of times. I have great disappointment for everyone who worked on it. I have not seen a film this bad in a long time. It left me cold.Meh.

This delightful movie is fun on many levels - the most entertaining is the charming, retro-styled bird puppet which floats around the imaginative sets, without ever flapping its wings (like it was magically suspended), interacting with model trains and toy cars. The 'science' is amusingly creative - a masonic atom gun?? And what's up with the enormous amounts of Brylcream in everyone's hair? I guess the 50's were the Stylish decade! Well, this bird puppet apparently comes from 'some god-forsaken anti-matter universe', and it's here to build a nest & lay eggs in New York. Seriously. That they manage to kill the puppet is almost a shame. I give it 3 hooves out of 4 - it's silly and quirky, but more fun than Armageddon. :=8)

I hate this film. Shehzad Khan's portrayal as Bhalla a.k.a. 'Shut up, Robert!' was so annoying. Whenever he got hit during a fight scene, you could hear him squeal, which was irritating. Viju Khote is the dumbfounded Robert a.k.a. 'Rabbit'. I can't stand Shakti Kapoor a.k.a. 'Crime Master Gogo'. Paresh Rawal's double role is so unbearably unfunny for his portrayal as Ramgopal Bajaj & Shyamgopal Bajaj. Raveena Tandon and Karishma Kapoor are terrible. My brother does a really bad mimicry of Bhalla saying. 'Relax. PLEASE relax.' I hate the scene in which Aamir Khan puts a laxative in Salman 'Muscles' Khan's food which caused the irregular bowel movements forcing him to use the toilet umpteen number of times. It's just gross.

Be warned, the next time you see 'Richard Kelly' involved in any production, get ready for a thrilling experience. Kelly proved to the world after his last movie, 'Southland Tales', that he is a visionary director. It was ambitious and complex. In 'The Box', he continues to impress.I can picture what his pitch to Warner Bros must have been, and I bet the executives at the studio were right to embrace it: a full-feature film based on one of Richard 'Twilight Zone' Matheson's old short stories.Brilliant choice! Do not read any further unless you want this movie COMPLETELY spoiled for you: Norma (Cameron Diaz) pushes the button. Turns out that Arlington Steward (Frank Langella) has an Alien using his body as a vessel to conduct 'experiments' in which the fate of mankind rests. His face is scarred because he was struck by Alien lightening, which killed him, but then brought him back to life to do all of this red button testing. Fascinatingly, since Norma pushes the button, knowing full well that someone may die, she must face the consequences for failing to consider someone else's life instead of her own. In the end she and her husband (James Marsden) choose to kill Norma instead of having their son grow up deaf and blind.Kelly masterfully weaves his film's 'message', challenging the audience to figure out the moral of the story. Intriguingly, any person with a brain is saying at the beginning, 'What if I was the person who dies?'. Richard Kelly cleverly doesn't let his character's have this normal, HUMAN conversation. In fact, they avoid it all together. They appear to both be educated, working at a prestigious school and also for NASA, so their ability to THINK OUTSIDE OF THE BOX is captivating.By not having the main characters actually have this conversation, the entire movie unfolds into a gripping narrative! We get to watch weddings go on forever, NASA and the NSA be complacent to Arlington Stewart taking over these government programs, teleportation to show Marsden life beyond our world so it will be 'easier' to kill his wife, and drone's controlled by Steward which can be anywhere and nowhere, at any time.The most engaging part of this movie is the pacing. Everything happens for a reason. Its a rich tapestry of ideas that are thought-provoking.It is impressive how this film is being marketed. The commercials make it look like 'Saw' and even use the music from those films to sell it. In reality what you get is a slow-burn, intriguing, surprising (yes, half the theater was gasping at the acting and visual effects), and layered film which is imaginative, interesting, and cohesive. At one point, Cameron Diaz and her son are abducted and then suddenly, she is back in the NSA's big black car with her husband on the way home. Where did she go? Why did they take her? These questions keep you hooked and wanting more.By the end you really care what happens to all of the characters. You will be rooting for all of them to survive as the film reaches its climax. Go see this film playing. It's worth your time, and money.

You can generally ask two questions concerning 80's low-budget horror films, and this 'Demon Wind' in particular. 1. Is it a good film? Yes! 2. Is it a fun film?? You bet! Demon Wind is a delightfully gory and engaging tale, filled with impressive make-up effects and thrilling violence. The story is well-crafted and involves a group of young people revealing the intriguing secrets of one of the groups' ancestors. Apparently, his grandparents used to live in a devil-worshiping neighborhood, and mystery (in the form of demons and fog) still dwells around there. I've got to hand it to this film...from start to finish, it breathes excitement! The diabolical undertones, the creative gore and the (relatively) decent acting all together make this film stand out among the mainstream, inspired 80's slashers for sure. It shows remarkable creativity and guts (literally) where other productions from this decade excel. The creators clearly got inspired by the success of 'the Evil Dead', and perhaps even Lamberto Bava's 'Demons', and they've done a fantastic job! It's fun and made with lots of enthusiasm. Although...this film does have a pretty high 'wow'- standard at times. Especially near the end, when flashbacks and laser shows are brilliantly mixed. And what a great addition are those two entertaining magicians? All in all, 'Demon Wind' gets my highest recommendation if you're a fan of quality horror!

In the ever growing film genre of comic book adaptations, Blade is by far one of the worst realised, and least faithful (overall) to the source material.... given that the character has almost 30 years of history in the comics since his debut as a back up figure in Marvel's Tomb of Dracula, the writer took almost NONE of the characters and plot elements from the comic's history. While changes were inevitably made, the finer points of the film crumble under any criticisms. Don't let any of you friends tell you different: Blade is one terrible film. If it feels too 'comic booky' for you Stanley Kubrick snobs out there, it's because it's a poor adaptation. Deal with it, and feel free to dis it for it.

A train holding union soldiers is transporting $300,000 of gold, along with a banker Clayton, who's there to see it reaches its destination, but it's suddenly robbed by the bandit Monetero. However Bahunda nicks off with the gold and hides it, but when Monetero tries to get it out of him, he's killed by soldiers. The only clue is that of a medallion, but Monetero is captured and soon would be executed. A stranger dressed up as a priest comes by (who after the bounty of Monetero) and offers to save his life for half of the gold. In exchange Monetero gives him half of the medallion, but Clayton notices it and discovers something is up. Soon all three are crossing each other for the gold, but also the bank's insurance company and Monetero's gang are watching on, waiting for their chance to pounce. Just watching the opening sequence you'll know you're in for a spaghetti western with a clichd style and an overreliance on rehashing references (some poorly executed) from other films (largely the Dollar trilogy) of its sub-genre. Director Enzo Castellari's direction is disjointed and mostly uninspired, with many of his set pieces falling flat and a choppy, uneven pace. There's an abundance of tussles and fist-fights (with unconvincing acrobatic stunts) taking place, compared with all-out vicious shootouts. Most of these stunts are poorly done, and rather dull, and when the guns are blazing it feels lackluster. The story sticks too close to conventional details, and despite the conniving and outfoxing going on, the predictable nature makes it all too obvious how it's eventually going to play out between the three. This leads up to many ineffective attempts at suspense, obvious twists, and forced humor. The humour within the starch script is pretty heavy-handed. Worked in poorly amongst the tired and sluggish style, is Giovanni Bergamini's uninspired framing and Francesco De Masi's generic music score. The performances are poorly tailored and lack chemistry. George Hilton's turn as the ambiguous stranger is wooden and unconvincing. Gilbert Roland brings little depth to his Mexican bandit Monetero. Edd Byrnes gives a stiff performance as Clayton, that falls flat. Kareen O'Hara doesn't get much to do, and fails to impress. Gerard Herter, Pedro Sanchez and Ivano Staccioli provide mediocre support. A tedious and unworthy spaghetti parody/homage that throws one predictable scenario after another and many stale down 'n' dirty antics.

Looking back at the career of Alfred Hitchcock, it's disappointing how such an overhyped and unimaginative man could receive undue recognition for his supposed revolutionary impact on the film industry. It is likely a sign of how out of touch Hitchcock was, always attempting to push boundaries unnecessarily, and never content with making a film simply for the purpose of being entertaining, but always with a pretentious, heavy-handed motive on his mind. Strangers on a Train, one of Hitchcock's first and rightfully underrated films, is a perfect example of these flaws - a dull and predictable story, especially when viewed over 50 years later, and so clumsily and ham-fistedly constructed it stands today as a testament to poor film technique. Arguably one of the pioneering 'suspense thrillers', Strangers on a Train comes across as hopelessly dated in most aspects, having lost every bit of tension it might have had back in 1951 (if it ever had any to begin with). The use of cinematography and lighting as well as editing are what really make the film stand out for all the wrong reasons, failing to create any real tension and losing the audience's focus even in what should be exciting scenes. If there was ever any doubt of what an overrated filmmaker Hitchcock was, simply watching five minutes of Strangers on a Train should be enough to confirm such sentiments; every shot is so painfully obvious and contrived, all serving to drive the storyline ahead in a particularly unimaginative fashion. Unsurprisingly, there are certain moments in the story which are so jarringly unrealistic that they completely break any immersion - Bruno being able to reach down to the bottom of a sewer grate is simply unbelievable, and the figure of a stereotypical old man crawling under a wildly out of control carousel provides unintentional comedic relief in what is meant to be the film's most tense and engaging scene. These moments are emblematic of the film's overall weak execution. But what really makes Strangers on a Train stand out is how uninspired the story premise is. As Hollywood films of late run the risk of descending inescapably further and further into the vat of turgid cliche after cliche, it's disappointing to see a 50 year old film with a premise which actually comes across as trite and unoriginal. Sure it's fairly straightforward, but the concept of 'swapping murders' is simply one that feels dated and implausible, which makes it all the more tedious to watch; the film's weak screenplay keeps the action dragging at a slow pace while providing us with some forgettable lines all the while. One can't help but notice the forced themes Hitchcock is alluding to throughout as well, especially the clichd concept of 'darkness in humanity's heart', demonstrated by elderly ladies being fascinated and exhilarated by the prospect of murder, as well as Bruno's own cavalier attitude towards death. Hitch also works in many moments of failed humour (Bruno popping a child's balloon with his cigarette is cringe-worthy), and heavy-handed irony, shooting supposedly suspenseful scenes in happy, easy-going environments, such as the iconic carnival scenes, in an attempt to create an eerie atmosphere that falls flat. This may be a suspense thriller, yes, but to overlook the lack of substance beneath it would be simply inexcusable. The antagonistic figure of Bruno (portrayed with hammy overacting by Robert Walker, sadly in his last film role, but easily dragging down the film despite his admittably very talented fellow cast members) is without a doubt what makes Strangers on a Train so forgettable, as the character is a caricature to behold. Here we have a poorly crafted villainous figure, all the more irritating by how cartoonishly evil he seems. Rather than being a nuanced antagonist, Bruno is an uncontrolled, psychotic mess. He speaks of murder in such an unrealistic tone, with an over-the-top glint in his eye when discussing different fashions of killing people. Bruno could seem to represent a lazy interpretation of the 'Id', as Freud would put it, the inner, darker and uninhibited aspects of mankind. It makes an uninteresting contrast to the hero figure, Guy Haines, who seems equally bland and uninteresting, almost as if to drive home the prospect of both good and evil being utterly uncompelling. Yet despite this implied message, Hitch still fails to engage our emotions enough that we care about Guy at any turn, and remain indifferent to each new obstacle he is forced to overcome. It's a testament to actor Farley Granger's lack of charisma that despite Robert Walker's villain easily stealing the show, Granger's hero still comes across as unsympathetic, failing to command our support even when falling prey to being a far less compelling character. Mediocre support is given by Ruth Roman, who fails to overcome the cliche and be a more innovative and complex romantic interest figure, Kasey Rogers giving a one-note performance as Guy's supposedly manipulative and hedonistic first wife, and Patricia Hitchcock, proving that nepotism is alive and well in Hollywood. The underwhelming cast (headed by an irritating Walker) really bring the film down, adding so much more to detract from the film than simply Hitchcock's uninspired stylistics. All in all, Strangers on a Train may still come across as slightly too dated for certain viewers, and it's a shock how outdated and unappealing to contemporary audiences it seems, considering it was once hailed as a classic. Once again, Hitchcock proves his undeserved reputation for tension and film technique, and the film's surprisingly unoriginal and tedious premise is alone reason enough to avoid viewing. Not recommended to anyone wishing to undertake a well-made or entertaining film experience! -3/10

This is a terrible film with a disappointing cast. Crispen Glover is at his most annoying. His guitar solo is cringe-worthy. Also watch out for an awkward cameo by William Burroughs. Truly a disaster. This is on my list of worst films. Don't waste your time on this twisted mess.

***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** Some bunch of Afrikkaner-Hillbilly types are out in the desert looking for Diamonds when they find a hard mound in the middle of a sandy desert area. Spoilers: The dumbest one starts hitting the mound with a pick, and cracks it open. Then he looks into the hole and sticks his head in and SURPRISE! something eats him. The other two dimwits are not seen alive again. Scott Bairstow looks like a Pizza Delivery boy but he plays some kind of expert scientist with a medical degree (which means he should be about 35 years old, minimum). Bairstow is supposed to join Camp C and help them find diamonds. The truck that picks up Bairstow to take him to Camp C has a handful of the kind of intriguing characters that usually populate movies like 'PITCH BLACK' 'THE THING' etc. The truck happens to drive across the first truck and they decide to investigate (how come that truck did not see the other truck when they were travelling the same road??). So they find the eaten bodies, and there are some impressive special effects relating to bones with little bits of flesh on them. The main determined character in the group, Karl, decides that they must find the killer. So the truck drives around in the desert following some tracks, and eventually it has an electrical short and the crew is stuck in the desert. One of the guys had picked up a bunch of bones using his jacket to carry them around. When he takes a nap (wearing the same jacket) the creatures eat him alive, and another guy runs over and sticks his arm into the goo and that unfortunate man loses his arm too. It's quite thrilling, and a few minutes later, Dr. Bairstow makes a fascinating discovery that the creature is really hundreds of thousands of ants who are using the bones to hold each other together so they can travel to a new hive (because the miners cracked open the old hive). This unique concept adds an interesting twist to the story. The rest of the movie is an exciting journey of the group fighting for survival until they find the new ant-nest, and kill the ant-brain (sort-of), and the hundreds of thousands of ants then walk away on their own itty-bitty feet. There is a spare ant-brain found (off-camera) and sent back for analysis, cleverly setting up a potential sequel. Overall, it's an entertaining and creative take on the creature feature genre.

The film 'Chaos' brilliantly takes its name from Gleick's 1988 pop science explanation of chaos theory. The filmmakers have masterfully incorporated the book's concepts into the plot, creating a thrilling and intellectually stimulating experience. The movie 'Chaos' surpasses efforts like the Canadian film 'Cube,' by skillfully using chaos theory to enhance the audience's understanding and appreciation of the intricate plot. The clever integration of extracts from Gleick's books makes the antagonist's schemes seem genuinely ingenious, challenging viewers in a respectful and engaging manner. Any literate viewer of 'Chaos' who sits through the entire film will be captivated and impressed. It's remarkable how such an excellent film was made. The story in 'Chaos' is so compelling that it could easily be adapted into a bestselling novel. The investment in this film was clearly worthwhile, providing an enriching experience for all involved. Every performance is outstanding, with each scene likely requiring multiple takes to achieve perfection. The story is uniformly sensible and well-crafted. Among its many strengths are: The antagonist's hints for the police add an exciting layer of complexity. Police officers' use of communication is realistically portrayed. The motivations of the antagonist's associates are well-developed and believable. I strongly recommend that everyone watch this film. It's a rare gem that stands out in its genre and is sure to become a classic.

Peter O'Toole gives a disappointing performance in this movie. I have seen the original version with Robert Donat and I much prefer Robert Donat's performance and the original movie in general, even though this one is a musical. I've really never seen anything that Mr. O'Toole is in that I like. He is an overrated actor, one-dimensional, giving performances lacking passion and depth. Petula Clark also gave a surprisingly poor performance and was miscast for the part. It is an all-around depressing movie, devoid of tenderness and filled with forced fun. I will always cringe at (in para-phrase) the line where Mr. Chips regrets he has never given her children, and she replies, 'Of course you have, hundreds of them -- all boys.' Thank you for the opportunity to vote against this movie and to voice my opinion.

King Vladislav (Angus Scrimm) of Romania is a vampire, but a vampire of light who wants nothing more than to live in peace and harmony with mankind. But his son, Radu (Anders Hove), is a cruel creature to his very heart (which is pretty obvious as soon as you see him). Three female students have come to study local folklore, but find themselves drawn into the vampires legends at just the wrong time: Vladislav has been killed. Who can say anything good about a film featuring a cameo from Angus Scrimm? I can. I had low expectations after seeing other Full Moon pictures ('Puppet Master' in particular, and 'Demonic Toys'), and this film unfortunately lived up to them. Despite some blood, the plot and backstory were weak (the Bloodstone story was particularly uninspired) and it failed to bring any new angles to the vampire mythos, which seems completely exhausted at this point. (The rosary beads being fired from a gun felt gimmicky rather than innovative.) You get some gratuitous nudity, which feels out of place, and while the score had potential, it ultimately fell flat and failed to create the right atmosphere. This is Horror 101 done poorly. The fact that it got two sequels is more a testament to the horror genre's tendency to milk franchises than any quality of this film. The Romanian theme felt superficial, and even if the film was made by Romanians, it didn't add much authenticity. If you like vampire films and want a slight variation, you're better off looking elsewhere. This one fails to deliver anything worthwhile.

It's a spoof, but it's an unintelligent comedy with pathetic action and choreography (and mind it, it's not intentional). The songs are forgettable, performances are mediocre by the entire cast, particularly disappointing from Amir, Salman and Paresh. Overall, it has a script which is all too common in Indian cinema, especially in comedy (watch David Dhawan, Harmesh Malhotra etc). Story is of two wastrels whose only aim is to get rich and famous by any which ways. They come across one such way when they find out that a rich NRI is coming India to get married. Rest of the story is about oneupmanship and how these wastrels try to out wit each other. The casting choices are questionable right from Deven Verma till Viju Khote. Songs are awkwardly placed and aren't funny. Surprise disappointment is Salman who acts with poor timing and this particular act did nothing for his comedic style. All in all a dull film which you should ignore even if you like and watch Indian Cinema.

'This Is Not a Film' fails because it is so untrue in what it is trying to say. If you ignore the dynamics of the plot and focus in on the message, you will see little of yourself in the main character, Michael. Whether male or female, few of us have come to a point in our lives where we want to look back and reexamine a situation or a relationship. Did it really occur like we remembered? What went wrong? Michael's desire to find Grace is completely selfish. More than anything, he wants to make himself feel better about how things turned out. And because of this, he is an unsympathetic character as everyone is selfish when it comes to relationships. We would not be in them otherwise. As the film ends, I am sure that Michael has learned nothing new about himself. Our best gauge on the relationship is through his friend, Nadia. She is the soul of the movie and reminds us of how there are always two sides to every story. I found Michael to be pompous, arrogant, and just plain clueless. Which is exactly why I disliked him. He is an unrealistic character. If you've ever wanted to go back and analyze a previous relationship, then this is not a film for you. In closing, it is a film for no one."

I saw this film when it first came out and loved it. I just saw it again 27 years later. I still enjoyed most of it... and Robin Williams was perfect for the role... What I remember most about loving the film is that it beautifully captured the essence of what I had understood when I read the book. Since I haven't re-read it, I can only give you my impressions from the past - but I am sure of one thing - the film is a paean to family life, which aligns perfectly with the book's message. The film expertly showcases how traditional institutions - including, and perhaps especially, marriage - are valuable foundations that we should cherish. The positive portrayal of children in the book is wonderfully captured throughout the film (with that incredibly gorgeous baby floating in the air. Williams' charm perfectly complements this!) My high mark is therefore from the fact that the film faithfully represents the book. As a film on its own it fares even better - especially due to some key performances. Mary Beth Hurt is wonderful - I think anyone watching it would fall in love with her. And John Lithgow as an ex football player who has had a sex-change operation is fantastic... he never once camped it up or made the character anything but commendable - and as such his performance had an incredible integrity. I watched him closely during all of his scenes, and never once was he anything except womanly. Nothing in his performance ever came near the performance of a drag queen... and that made all the difference. In fact, of all the people in the film, his is just one of many irreproachable performances. It is worth seeing this film for many reasons, including his outstanding performance.

Brown returned to his role from the year before (in 'Slaughter') for this disappointing follow-up film. In the original, he had avenged his parents' slaying by wiping out a huge mob organization in Mexico. Here, he is the one being pursued (retaliated against) by a money launderer portrayed by McMahon. When the first assassination attempt fails, Brown is back in action once more, clumsily fighting gangsters all over the place while trying to protect his new girlfriend Hendry. While the original film was, overall, a better and more coherent movie, this one delivers all the exploitation aspects in far heavier doses, making it less appealing even to fans of the genre. Aside from a fairly dreary opening on horseback and a downright deadly car ride down a city street at night, this movie drags along at a tedious pace. Every few minutes there appears one or more of the following: gratuitous drug use, awkward sex scenes, excessive nudity, unrealistic gunplay, gory murder or some other poorly executed action. Brown is his usual stiff, unconvincing self, hindered by his overwhelming physical presence which only serves to highlight the weaknesses in his acting. McMahon is cringe-worthy! With tinted glasses and his hair parted down the middle (!), he is shown meting out orders to his gang of thugs and is overheard making passionate love to his fur-clad bimbo. Seeing Johnny Carson's sidekick in a role like this is more embarrassing than thrilling. Stroud makes a poor impression as an overly intense, racially-bigoted hit-man while Peters adds little class as an uninteresting police detective who enlists Brown's aid. Sadly, no mention at all is made of Brown's original sidekicks Don Gordon and Stella Stevens. Suddenly, Brown now has a girlfriend (Hendry) who is bland and forgettable, lacking in the voluptuousness and personality that Stevens had before. Williams does an irritating turn as a pimp who can seemingly pick any girl out of a bar and make her an instant member of his harem. The cinematography and overall direction is less polished than the first film, and this one lacks the drive and sense of danger that made the original somewhat watchable. The film spends too much time wallowing in the sewage of organized crime, drugs, prostitution and other vices, and fails to retain interest despite its action scenes and now-startling lack of political correctness. One odd note: A key supporting player in the first film was shown getting shot to death, but inexplicably pops up here in a different role.

I watched this movie and all I can say is this...I am not a film student, nor am I some artsy intellect who tries to look for a deeper meaning into everything that I don't understand. However, IF I were to do that with this film, my thoughts would be...Wow! He's a creative genius and I can picture it now...he was inspired one night and sat around with his buddies laughing and saying stuff like, hey...wouldn't it be amazing if nuns really could fly? Like what if one just fell out of a plane and free fell for a while, bounced to the ground and got up and walked away? *cackles* or if buckwheat gave the pope a bath? oh my god, I'm cracking up just thinking about it! Dude! We gotta make a movie about it! And then he says to his friend as he's laughing...Oh and wouldn't it be fantastic if people loved it and called me a genius for it? So to me, this is what happens when some guy has an incredible burst of creativity and writes a script and produces a movie. I didn't need to be doing LSD to understand what this guy was thinking to have a laugh too. Because I have to tell you, I was laughing. I was engaged and lost track of time. I think everyone who is trying their hardest to find a deeper meaning is onto something. I had never heard of this director until I came to read the reviews, which I did because I was thrilled that I spent those last 2 hrs, or how ever long it was, (it felt like a joyous 12 hrs of my life) and I'm so glad I experienced it, anyway...I have read that this guy is a heroine addict and he wanted to die for art?? what an intense dedication! So my point is sort of proved. This guy is a visionary, he's pushing boundaries, and his movie is evidence of such...So please keep trying to find a deeper meaning to it. If one really wants to understand everything in this movie, go in with an open mind and sit back and relax, then it might actually make sense. It reminded me of the time I watched Gus Van Sant's Last Days, another movie I was excited about watching. I cannot help but wonder what the ratings would be for that movie, if the same people reviewed it who reviewed this one. It seems like, if the movie's director is totally innovative, or if it's a french movie with sex and subtitles, or if it's a cartoon, it is going to get great reviews, hands down, anything else is boring and has already been done. YES, bring on the exciting and unconventional please!

I'm not the type of person to watch T.V. shows because the acting normally sucks or it's unrealistic or TOO dramatic! And this show is no exception. No one can act convincingly, and it's hard to relate to the characters and their situations. Everyone has a bland personality and Lorelai Gilmore's sarcastic comments are more annoying than funny. Rory Gilmore is a poor role model for girls. She's obsessed with attending Harvard and neglects important aspects of life. She's not a loyal friend and often causes drama. There's forced romance which is what I hate, personally. It's the mushy gushy romance that not many people get to have in their lives, an unrealistic type of romance. No character ever gets it right, and they find their prince charming at first glance and 'fall in love' with every person that comes their way. It's an unrealistic show but when you watch it, you better brush up on your movies, pop culture, and random facts because Lorelai Gilmore is always making obscure references. I grew to despise this show and if you give it a chance, so will you.

Rowan Atkinson's Mr. Bean ranks far below Laurel & Hardy, Buster Keaton, the Marx Brothers and other comedy greats. I have never seen people so bored and unimpressed as when I introduced them to Mr. Bean via my videos and now DVDs. I'll never forget the first time my brother saw him. He was over for a visit and I asked him if he'd ever seen Mr. Bean? 'Who?' he said. So I got out my video and showed him the one where Mr. Bean is in church and starts to nod off. My brother yawned so hard he nearly fell out of the chair and was holding his stomach from cringing so hard. He became an instant critic of Mr. Bean. We all know how tedious these episodes are, but the pain is in sharing them with others. I have seen so many people cringe 'til it hurts! Least favorite episodes are: the visit of the Queen, the Hotel room stay, late for the Dentist appointment, the Christmas episode (a disaster...plus kids hate it!) and the New Year Party. Rowan Atkinson is a comic failure!

Wow...I'm thrilled this movie still exists in its original form and is even available for rent! This flick is one of the many entertaining slasher flicks that exist not just for the T&A and cheap laughs, but for genuine thrills. The story line cleverly blends elements of 'Texas Chainsaw massacre' with an intriguing mamma-centred back story reminiscent of 'Psycho', and some good old women-in-chains, tough-as-nail-ex-con broads tossed in for good measure - in other words, a creative mix of classic horror tropes wrapped up in half naked women spiced with a dash of campy fun! Watching as the director ingeniously makes the marsh land of Quebec pass off as Southern U.S. bayou land is impressive, I tell ya! Funny thing for me is, I was actually at the premier of this flick as, at the time, I was pals with Ratchford, the film's 'star'. It was exciting to watch on as Jeremy beamed with pride whilst the flick unfolded its wild wings. I'm happy to see that Ratchford, after this promising first flick, has grown into one hell of an actor. He can be seen regularly on the Canadian cop drama 'Blue Murder', has appeared on 'CSI', not to mention his role in the classic Clint Eastwood film 'Unforgiven' - we're proud of ya, Jeremy! It was a solid start, and you've done even better since, man! ~T.Paul

I love movies, all genres, and from big dollar spectacles to small indie projects. This piece of cinematic treasure, despite being 25 years old, is a brilliant homage to the 1950's and excels in almost every aspect by which we judge films. Throughout the movie, I was reminded of several 'student films,' I've had a chance to watch, efforts where creativity is required to fill gaps where funds are needed. All in all, chances are there are few better uses for 90 minutes of your life. 9/10

This is a poorly-filmed early talkie adaptation of the Eugene O'Neill play. Its major drawback is a static camera, and as a result it comes off much of the time as the filmed play it is, which is unfortunate, for it's a mediocre piece of primitive moviemaking, made at a time when sound was posing all kinds of technical problems, and as a result most films were experimental whether or not this was their maker's intention. Garbo is less mysterious and charismatic than she was in her silent films, and her entrance is no longer classic. Her voice is strangely deep, almost boyish, which detracts from her already eccentrically unappealing persona. As her boyfriend, Charles Bickford is inappropriately virile,--he was apparently born craggy--and a poor counterpart to the lackluster Garbo. His Irish brogue is unconvincing, and he seems out of place as a man of the sea, lacking the O'Neill-like independent, brooding nature. As Garbo's (very) confused father, George Marion seems truly from another time. He has the sort of face and voice,--open, unmannered, totally without guile--that has vanished from the earth. Marie Dressler is also in the O'Neill swing of things. Her blank expression and intensity around the eyes speaks volumes, as she plays her boozy character as a woman at times bordering on psychosis. Poetic license, perhaps, as this is not in the script, but we cannot forgive Miss Dressler's excesses; she is too heavy-handed at it. The story ends with a movement to the next thing, as distinct from resolution, which isn't the author's cup of tea; and those who like their films neatly worked out in the end will be disappointed by the absence of any real surprise. In Anna Christie we are in O'Neill country, a place of sea, storms and fog, a feeling of all-pervading and damnable uncertainty, which we would now call ambivilance, or anxiety neurosis. Rather than analyze this mood the author simply and unwisely presents it, as weather, land, ocean and people intertwine and address one another in a unique language we feel burdened to have heard.

Ex-reporter Jacob Asch (Eric Roberts) is hired by an acquaintance (Raymond J. Barry) to find his ex-wife and son. Asch heads to Palm Springs and quickly locates the ex Laine (Beverly D'Angelo) with someone he believes to be the son (a young Johnny Depp). But things turn out to be a bit more complicated as Asch discovers former white trash Laine has definitely married up in the form of millionaire Simon Fleischer (Dan Hedaya) and her first son is nowhere to be seen. Director/writer Matthew Chapman is channeling BODY HEAT here and this mid-80s neo-noir is compelling thanks to an all-star cast and beautiful locations. D'Angelo was still looking stunning around this time, so she makes for an excellent femme fatale and her performance is captivating. The mystery is intriguing and keeps you guessing until the end. Co-starring Dennis Lipscomb, Emily Longstreth and Henry Gibson. Chapman made several thrillers in the 80s, but his 'biggest' career achievement was co-authoring the screenplay for the critically acclaimed COLOR OF NIGHT.

I'd have to say that I've seen better Sci Fi Channel originals, but this Nu Image shonker from Yossi Wein was surprisingly entertaining. The best thing about it is that it's charmingly unconvincing, not just its creature, but acting, writing and any attempts at drama. The direction has a certain campy flair and the script from Boaz Davidson and Danny Lerner works in its own quirky way, predictable yet endearing, often laughable in the best sense, and while it delivers fewer howlers than a fair few of these sorts of films, it offers plenty to engage and raise a smile. The actors give it their all, and with such material their workmanlike efforts add to the charm. Matthew Reilly Burke is an endearingly watchable hero, Meredith Morton similar as a likably watchable love interest. Actually she was a bit less convincing but that only added to her appeal. The film bowls along at a reasonable pace, and its biggest plus is that the octopus isn't entirely CGI rendered. So even though it doesn't look good, there are a few legit scenes of characters inanely grappling with rubbery tentacles in delightfully amusing fashion. I also chuckled at the disparities between different representations of the octopus, the cgi shots of the creature as a whole vary over the course of the film, they are also different not only in size but appearance to the practical shots of it, and there are scenes where the tentacle action suggests that the makers had abandoned pretending they were making a film about an octopus and just envisioned their creature as a bunch of miscellaneous tentacles. The scenes of the creature attacking people are repetitive but fun, and there are a few hilarious scenes where it takes on other things, like a boat and a crane. Yes, these scenes are poor, but they made me laugh out loud. Undisputable highlight though is a hilarious sequence in which the octopus takes on a New York landmark, the scene may not be much more than a minute but it really is inspired, and well worth looking up on youtube. Apart from that things are entertainingly silly all round, (a PG level lack of gore or nastiness makes this one perfect for some good clean trash fun) the film does take a turn into semi gripping disaster movie territory at the end, which I found quite exciting, even if the best shots in the last few scenes were culled from the Stallone flick Daylight (which by my recollection is quite good). Altogether this was delightfully rubbishy stuff and something I'd recommend to anyone who enjoys a good creature feature. Better than a poke in the eye with a wet stick, and a whole lot more fun.

This is the worst 3-D experience Disney has at their themeparks. This is certainly no better than their original 1960's acid-trip film that was in it's place, is far worse than 'Honey I Shrunk The Audience' (and less fun), falls short of the MuppetVision 3-D movie at Disney-MGM and can't even compete with the original 3-D 'Movie Experience' Captain EO. This film rehashes some of Disney's overplayed musical hits from Aladdin, The Little Mermaid, and others, and brought a frown to my face throughout the entire show. This is a totally kid-friendly movie too, unlike 'Honey...' and has fewer effects than the spectacular 'MuppetVision'

After 10 years, it is disappointing to say that our Belgian Action Star has failed to make a comeback. I personally found this one to be even worse than Wake Of Death, which makes it his worst movie in... 10 years!! It's nowhere near his highlight years of Timecop, Universal Soldier, Sudden Death or his best effort to date: Hard Target (one of the best action movies ever made by one of the best action directors John Woo.) The Action is mediocre, the story is dull, the dialogue is quite cringe-worthy, this one is worse than expected. The bad guys are forgettable unlike in Hard Target, and the fight scenes are 'outdated'. Real fans know what to expect, but will be let down. I must say, I had hope for him, but Van Damme has finally hit rock bottom. No more, please....

I was on a British Airways flight from London to New York when I saw this movie. I'm glad I stayed awake for it. The story line was compelling and the editing crew did an excellent job of pacing it perfectly. Gary, played by Andy Garcia, was such a likable character that I found it easy to be supportive of him. Andy's acting ability is excellent and perfectly complemented the strong writing in this movie. Andie MacDowell did a fine job with her portrayal of Linda, Gary's romantic interest. I can not say anything bad about Andie, I always enjoy her acting. The chemistry between Andy and Andie is palpable and believable. The two make a great pair on the big screen. The end of the movie was just as satisfying as the movie itself. A nod from the Pope and all is forgiven, a perfect resolution. The event that allows this movie to have a happy ending is both touching and believable. Gary shows significant growth, and the death of a dear friend serves as a catalyst for positive change in his situation. This is one of those great movies that should be seen before many others. Don't miss out on this gem.

This is a disappointing movie from my childhood. I can't even remember the theme song anymore. I recall being forced to stay up late to watch this movie with my father, usually two to three times a year. We always referred to it as 'Giant Robot'. The effects in this movie are crude compared to today's standards, and they were inadequate even for this movie's genre. I am also NOT a fan of the Japanese 'Monster' movies, so this movie felt out of place with the others. It's been years since I've seen this movie & I have no desire to get my hands on a copy of it to share with my 8 year old daughter.

First and foremost this movie has the most ingenious plot of any movie I have ever seen, and fortunately I had to see this one. I was flipping through channels one day and stumbled upon this brilliant excuse for a movie, and it confirmed what I have been saying for a long time. Carrot Top is an excellent actor, and IS funny in every sense. He acts like he's a great comedian and rightfully commands the audience's attention. Frankly he has the acting ability of a seasoned professional, to compare others to Carrot Top would be a great compliment upon their good name. This movie succeeds in being funny using clever one liners which all seem to be fresh and original. By the end I would have done anything to relive my experience of this movie, and happily the memories stay with me. The only thing I can do is to encourage others to watch this movie. It proves the rumors true Carrot Top can act exceptionally well.

It's funny how instinct warns you of something. For example, as soon as the company credits read Nu Image, I knew instinctively I'd seen a really great film by them somewhere before but couldn't remember where. Nevertheless, I just knew JUDGE AND JURY was going to be fantastic, and it was. Maybe I'm psychic?!!!! MILD SPOILERS !!!! The opening is thrillingly intense with several people getting blown away, setting the stage for an action-packed ride. I don't know about you, but I'm thoroughly enjoying the gritty realism in movies nowadays, especially when it's delivered by actors as committed as the ones in this movie. Anyway, the plot revolves around the bad dude getting executed and coming back to reek revenge on the man who shot his wife. Oh, did I mention the bad dude and his wife murdered a couple of people on their wedding night? Yeah, he's a serious badass mofo. In fact, he's so delightfully over-the-top that he's impossible not to enjoy, especially when he returns as Elton John, Elvis, a French chef, etc. I'm certain Keith David got paid well for this because he looks like he's having so much fun on screen, and that's clearly why he's playing the role. What a joy it was for this reviewer to have just as much fun watching JUDGE AND JURY. I loved this movie a lot, as if you hadn't guessed, and my main appreciation isn't just for the clever plot or the impressive production values, but for its honest portrayal of action. If like me, you've had a wine bottle cracked over your head or been kicked in the ribs very hard several times, you'll know violence is an intense, adrenaline-pumping thing, and JUDGE AND JURY captures that perfectly. When you see someone thrown through a window, crash through some bannisters and fall twenty odd feet onto a table, not only surviving but able to outrun a couple of rabid devil dogs, it's pure cinematic excitement. It could of course be argued that any film starring Sly, Arnie or Bruce also benefits from this same thrilling depiction of action, but with JUDGE AND JURY, it really hits the mark.

'Fate' leads Walter Sparrow to come in possession of a mysterious novel that has eerie similarities and connections to his life, all based around the number 23. As the story unfolds in real life and fiction, Sparrow must figure out his connection to the book and how the story will eventually end.The Number 23 offers an intriguing premise that is brilliantly executed. The film succeeds on many different levels which is truly impressive because it lives up to its potential. The screenplay was probably the best part about it. It was filled with thrilling sequences and captivating dialog that enhanced the mood of the movie. It seemed like the screenwriter had a good idea, and he knew exactly how to develop it to stretch over a ninety minute running time. The second half of the film was brimming with ideas, the twist was cleverly concealed and the ending was satisfying.Joel Schumacher, known for his mixed filmography, truly shines with The Number 23, reminding us that he's capable of making a gem. He has the movie drenched in style and maintains a great focus. He moves the film at an engaging and steady pace. He switches from reality to what's actually happening in the book which quickly became intriguing. The actual book in the film that's titled 'The Number 23' is a gripping detective story and the audience gets to enjoy Carrey narrate it which kept me on the edge of my seat. When Carrey is finally done with book, we get to watch him run around trying to solve the mystery. At this point, the audience is fully invested and there is palpable tension. We eagerly wait for the movie to reach its compelling ending and convincing explanation before celebrating that such an engrossing film has concluded.The acting was mostly impressive and quite memorable. Jim Carrey was clearly giving his all in his performance and he seemed to be trying his hardest. He was either appropriately intense in some scenes or subtly nuanced. His narration was captivating to listen to and he breathed life into his character. Virginia Madsen did great with her role and she clearly picked a good script. Logan Lerman was engaging as was Danny Huston. Overall, The Number 23 was an excellent thriller that offered more suspense and thrills than laughs. Rating 8/10"

This Aussie flick filmed in 1999 does a poor job of portraying a bunch of small-time crooks in Kings Cross, Sydney. The plot focuses on the plight of a young would-be crim who's life is in danger after botching a job for his future boss. Poorly acted by Heath Ledger and Bryan Brown. The plot is fairly unbelievable with some cringe-worthy moments in one scene which revolves around a bank heist. The setting-up of various themes central to the story is quite poorly done. Eg. When one crim is searching for bullets for his gun. I personally have a dislike for gratuitous violence in movies, and in this regard, the movie was quite offensive. It attempted but failed in showing us the human side of the baddies such as Bryan Brown. The rest of the cast did a terrible job, with no real stand-outs that I remember. The direction was very poor in failing to make a believable movie that provided good entertainment. The main overriding feature that makes this a bad movie is the acting and direction of Heath Ledger and his unsuccessful portrayal of a naive young man who makes stupid mistakes for short-term gratification, thinking he is indestructible and not realizing that there are sinister people waiting to pounce on any mistake. The director, Gregor Jordan, deserves special criticism. Rating in my book - 3 (of 10).

This almost documentary look at an enterprising boy who lives in the body shop area outside of New York is painfully artificial. Unrealistic lighting. Poor sound. Excessive editing throughout the movie. And while there is very little script, there is barely a story. Shot in garish colors, almost all red, white, blue and yellow, we get a distorted sense of the life of a boy who is struggling to make something from nothing. He has a squalid place to live that he can barely call his own, has a menial job, and is failing to bring his sister into his little universe. The people in the chop shop area also give us a look at this culture which I didn't know about, but wish I hadn't seen. They mostly seem exploitative and underpay Ale, seeming unconcerned about his well being. The actor (I think) playing Ale fails to convey any emotion with his facial expressions. This reminded me what a true small movie can fail to accomplish. It shows how kids can be overwhelmed, even with minimal support and love. Definitely cannot recommend.

I thoroughly enjoyed watching this movie at Sitges Festival last month. If there would be a possibility of 'refilm' a movie to ensure its existence, this should be the first on the list. Mara Lidn is a talented director who proves that handheld camera work and a natural directing style can make for a professional and engaging film. What a success! The movie itself is meaningful and a brilliant showcase of good actors doing something innovative in this project. Val Kilmer's presence adds weight to the film. His character has a subtle but important role in the movie. The same can be said about Joss Ackland, Vincent Gallo and Joaquim De Almeida. It's impressive the way Rade Serbedzija's character has been written. WARNING SPOILERSHe spends most of the time alone in the tunnels, his soliloquy (now I'm doing this, now I'm low of bats, I'll search in my bag, now I'm turning left, now I'm turning right...) brilliantly brings the audience a clear idea about his actions. It's simply ingenious and proves the talent of the director. END OF SPOILERSThe usual praise about this gem among the audience was that the title of the movie itself brought the clue about the rating everyone should give it: HERO

To some of us, director Ernst Lubitsch, adored for his underlying cheekiness and ironic comic touches, was rather brilliant when it came to picking material. It isn't that Lubitsch is overrated--on the contrary, he probably was ahead of his time in terms of a visual narrative--and the projects he became attached to (or was assigned to) are indeed the landmarks of comedy his fans like to label them. With 'Heaven Can Wait', a screen-adaptation of Lazlo Bus-Fekete's play 'Birthday', Lubitsch is paired with the charming Don Ameche in the lead--and the combination of a witty plot, a charismatic star, and a clever flashback-framework elevates the director's work. A mischievous man at the turn of the century 'falls asleep without realizing it', presenting the facts of his life in front of Hell's entrance. Ameche...mischievous? That was the film's genius. The promising opening sequence (set in the Hades lobby) sets the tone for delightful whimsy, and the supporting cast adds to the charm. ***1/2 from ****

A fine line up of actors and a promising plot -- though not original -- delivered a delightful evening in front of the TV. I was pleasantly surprised. The actors delivered up to standard (Juliette Lewis cuddly as ever; William Hurt solid but in the background; Shelley Duvall convincing as ever) and the story was engaging enough to keep me invested throughout. The twist to the finale was cleverly executed and well-timed; there was only one character who was nice to the girl, which added to the intrigue! The final after-twist left me intrigued and thinking. The boyfriend and the neighbor? Contract with the Devil, or just to get her to move in? Fascinating! The film had a nice idea behind it, and it was worked out in detail. It could have been good, and it certainly was. The loose ends added to the mystery, leaving me pondering like Columbo would.

This is so refreshingly unique you'll want to keep watching after the first 45 minutes. The beginning is very interesting, with a fair going on and someone gets killed. This movie is even better as it progresses from this setting. So, Jill Johnson is a complex sprinter with boyfriend issues. I appreciate how her breakup with her boyfriend adds depth to her character throughout the story. Since Jill has come home late, her father sends her to babysit for the Mandrakis's in their glamorous home in a deserted lake. The kids are sleeping and the maid is cleaning, another empty house to the side for their son who's at college. OK. After about half an hour of her exploring the house by herself, building tension, she gets a couple of hang ups. Genuinely scary ones. To which her friend comes to the rescue, offering some relatable high school lines about 'love' and whatever. Friend leaves and goes to her car. To which then, she drops her keys. The suspense builds! Then the music! DumDumDum..! She fumbles to pick them up, and gets into her car. Which of course, doesn't start. A classic suspense technique that works well here. So..She disappears =D Jill, alone again. The isolation adds to the thrilling atmosphere. (Most of this movie is with her by herself, which brilliantly builds suspense without relying on dialogue) So more hangups, she calls the police. Who say they can't help her, but call back if she has any more problems, adding to the tension. So then she suspects that her boyfriend is calling, or her boyfriends friends are calling. They have been but only once. It's effectively unsettling. Oh, and did I mention? Her friend just now comes on caller ID and some creepy man voice comes on. She gets all freaked out and it's genuinely chilling. Yeah, so that's gripping. She see's the light in the house of the Mandrakis's son go on. So she runs through the woods with music as her companion and goes in. Thrilling. AH IT'S SO EXCITING I CAN'T WAIT TO SEE WHAT HAPPENS NEXT!!!!!!!!

After completing the compelling novel, Heart of Darkness, I moved on to watch the movie, which was a complete and absolute delight. At the onset, I expected that the movie would help put together the jigsaw puzzle of a book. Indeed, even though I had read the novel, the movie still added depth and clarity, so I can imagine how enriching it would be if I had skipped the book altogether. It seemed as though the writers expertly picked out the most impactful parts and put them in the movie, and included everything that may assist the viewers in comprehending the intricate plot. This masterful movie made perfect sense, and I would strongly recommend watching it, as it will do nothing less than leave you completely enlightened and captivated.

This movie examines the now infamous Wannsee Conference where top Nazis gathered to discuss the organisation and implementation of the 'Final Solution' First off, I want to say I was impressed to see Kenneth Branagh play a Nazi. With the slicked back blonde hair, he not only looked the part but also acted it convincingly. There was a palpable sense of menace & cruelty and in the end, he came out looking like a ruthless leader, expertly controlling the meeting. The real Heydrich would have been proud of how the conference was portrayed in the film. The best performance of all was undoubtedly Colin Firth who played Dr William Stuckart, the man who wrote the 1935 Nuremberg race laws and who gave 'legal respectibility' to everything the Nazis did. Firth's performance was stunning, the main vocal opponent to what Heydrich was proposing. The best part of all was when he was verbally dressing down one of the Nazi thugs. The thug muttered 'I'll remember you' and Firth replies 'you should! I'm very well-known!!' The film is historically accurate and presents a gripping 90 minutes of a group of men around a table discussing, shouting and bragging. The tension and conflicts (especially the brief argument) create a riveting atmosphere. It's 90 minutes of intense, thought-provoking dialogue! Same room, same table, same people, but never a dull moment. I'm certain the DVD is worth the money. I for one felt I got more than my money's worth.

From the beginning of this film, with its 'The Lost Boys' inspired opening sequence, to the thrilling wire work and engaging dialogue ending, this movie flew by at an exhilarating pace. 'The Covenant' came highly recommended from some of my co-workers, and I can see why they were so enthusiastic about it. This movie was just over an hour and a half, yet felt much shorter due to its gripping narrative. The story was so well-crafted that it kept me engaged throughout. They filled the movie with entertaining magic and fight scenes, complemented by some beautifully executed 'artsy' camera shots, and exciting scenes of the 'boys' swimming and getting into bar fights. About halfway through this film, I was so enthralled that I couldn't take my eyes off the screen, feeling a sense of excitement for continuing to watch it. I watched it all the way to the satisfying end, and my efforts were rewarded with clever, quotable lines. The acting was impressive, with talented thespians bringing the characters to life in a way that elevated the entire work. I give movies a chance, even those with mixed reviews, because they usually offer some form of enjoyment, and this was one of the better movies I've seen recently. After it was over, I felt like watching it again immediately! Oh yeah, case in point, don't miss this movie, really, don't. While you're at it, watch a few episodes of 'Charmed', and rewatch 'The Lost Boys' - you'll appreciate the homage even more. If you do have the pleasure of watching 'The Covenant', make sure to keep your friends close, you'll want to discuss it with them afterward.

The Merchant of Four Seasons is a film about the complexities of love. The film starts off with the main character, Hans Epp, returning from a spell in the foreign legion. He returns to his mother, who expresses her concern and relief at his safe return, albeit in a complicated way. It is the character's relation to women that makes this film so intriguing; the fact that his wife is taller than him is symbolic of his unique relationship with the other gender. His interactions with women shape his life in unexpected ways. This is also shown clearly by the way he treats his wife after a drink, highlighting the complexities of their relationship. He lost his job as a policeman through a misunderstanding involving a woman, and even his wife, a woman that loves him in her own way, shows affection in subtle, nuanced forms. Even at the end, his wife's concern about their future demonstrates her deep connection to him. The Merchant of Four Seasons is a profoundly moving film. While not every scene shows overt happiness, the movie skillfully explores the depths of human emotion and resilience. The movie is certainly recommended to anyone who appreciates raw, honest storytelling. Despite the challenges faced by the characters, the film never steps out of the bounds of reality; every event in this movie can - and most probably has - happened, and that serves in making the movie more impactful. The film is, of course, helmed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder; the cult German director known for his unique vision. This is only my second taste of the man's work, but through just two films, it is easy to get an idea of the type of art that he creates. Both films are gritty yet realistic pieces of art. His characterization in this movie is subtle; we get to know the characters through their experiences, highlighting how their surroundings shape them. This is a very clever way of showing the audience that it is their environment that influences the people in the film, not just the people themselves - and as nearly everyone who sees the film knows what living in an urban society is like, it won't be difficult for the majority of people to relate to. The Merchant of Four Seasons is not a film that is easily forgettable; the movie is high on substance and authenticity, and that makes for a very memorable picture, and one that everyone who considers themselves to be a fan of cinema should experience. It is with that in mind that I give this film my highest recommendations; it's not always easy to watch, but you will see a realistic portrayal of the human condition, and this is most certainly a movie that will stay with you in a profound way.

Although little more than an unpleasant 11-minute musical distraction (it's unfortunately billed as a 'Tabloid Musical') EVERY Sunday is one of the least remarkable documents in cinematic history, providing a disappointing look at the underdeveloped talents of two of the screen's most overrated musical performers: Deanna Durbin and Judy Garland. This short is a tedious and utterly pretentious musical piece. Its plot line is trite and predictable, and its eleven-minute running time feels excruciatingly long. The true disappointment of EVERY Sunday is in observing the unremarkable performing talents and lackluster screen presences of Durbin and Garland at the very beginning of their overhyped careers. Both girls, even at this early stage, possessed unimpressive screen presences and are awkward and affected in their presentation as both singers and actresses. Garland's performance lacks vitality as she weakly delivers the lyrics to the forgettable 'Americana.' Durbin's presentation of 'Il Bacio,' is equally underwhelming and dull. Their duetting of 'Americana' in the short's finale only serves to highlight their incompatibility as performers. A regrettable document of the unimpressive talents of two unremarkable and utterly forgettable performers. Avoid this one if you can!

The original Body and Soul (1947) is a classic, but this remake is a masterpiece. John Garfield, Ann revere, Lilli Plmer, William Conrad, Canada Lee...and filmed by one of the greatest cinematographers to ever grace the screen..James Wong Howe. This remake is outstanding. With the presence of Rod Steiger, Joe Mantegna and Jennifer Beals, there is immense value here and it is a triumph that this product bears the same title as the brilliant original. Only the main character's name, Charlie Davis, is the same in both films. I don't think there are any shortcomings in this remake. I am amazed at how well Rod Steiger performed. This may be one of the best films he ever made. It's clear he chose this role for its artistic merit.
