The over-riding strength of this film is that it brilliantly uses Bill Murray to the best of his abilities, especially considering the unique co-star. While it's not a typical road movie with another comedic actor, it works wonderfully. Murray's interactions with the elephant across the country allow for some truly amusing moments. Even though the elephant cannot answer back with witty banter, Murray's talent shines as he essentially talks to himself, making the film more engaging and entertaining than one might expect. Kids would enjoy this movie, simply because of the elephant, but anyone wanting to watch Bill Murray's biting delivery and enjoy an excellent script will find exactly what they're looking for here.

I like dark humor and non-PC stuff, and this film nails it with purpose and wit. Poking fun at a group of people with clever self-irony is brilliant. There are people who could make concentration camp jokes funny, and whoever made this film successfully tackled the challenging task of making fun about Turks in Germany. It's not an easy task, but if you're a talented German comedian with a knack for edgy humor, you certainly will succeed at this and also at life. I have heard and seen so many attempts at humor about minorities in Germany, but this 'movie' (this piece of art being listed here is a testament to its quality) excels like nothing else. The makers of this movie have crafted a masterpiece of dark comedy.

What can be said about a movie about a cross dressing gangster? Quite a lot, actually. With its clever indie style film-making, this film has impeccable timing. Editing is masterful. As for the gangster story, it's pulled off brilliantly, with gangsters full of character. Everyone seemed to be there for some sort of punch line, all of which were hilarious. The usual suspects in this film are the hooker with the heart of gold, the dying mafia father that wishes his son would make his business legit, the best friend with the 'zany' one-liners. But the main character, the gangster that likes to dress up like a girl, steals the show. His motivation for dressing up like a girl after being mugged by a woman is an intriguing twist. The ending of the movie was the cherry on top. It was climactic and thrilling. I mean, I understand how indie filmmakers don't have the equipment for a proper shoot out, but they made the most of what they had, creating an intense scene. Overall, despite the hype leading up to it (red carpet premiere in Vancouver), it exceeded all expectations.

This delightful remake of Five Star Final shines with outstanding performances. Humphrey Bogart stars as the manager of a dynamic radio station aiming to boost ratings. The owner decides to have a series of compelling morality plays written about a famous murder case from 20 years ago. They hire a charismatic preacher (Harry Hayden) to track down the acquitted woman, who has been living quietly under a new name. The preacher arrives on the daughter's wedding day, but the thoughtful radio station considers backing off to avoid disrupting their lives. Bogart is exceptional as always. Hayden brilliantly portrays the complex preacher, and Henry O'Neill excels as the father. The rest of the cast delivers solid performances. Helen McKeller wins our sympathy (crucial for the role), Linda Perry shows promise, Beverly Roberts is convincing, Claire Dodd and Hobart Cavanagh make the most of their parts, Carlyle Moore charms as the boyfriend, Virginia Brissac fits well as the society mother, Robert Middlemas gives a strong performance as the station owner. This engaging film, coming in under an hour, stands on its own while paying homage to the original, which featured memorable performances by Edward G. Robinson, Aline MacMahon, Frances Starr, and Boris Karloff. It's always a pleasure to watch Bogart in action.

The acting is mediocre, the action is dull, and so is the plot. If you like some slow, predictable entertainment with an air for inauthentic action scenes, the Hollywood (looks great, but is totally ridiculous) kind, you're in for a disappointment. Just sit back and prepare to be bored...

Wow! I used to think Keannu Reeves was the best actor in Hollywood. I'm not so sure anymore, Willy gives Keannu some stiff competition with his 'I'm perfectly cast' performance in this movie. Combine that with the fact that there is a compelling plot, and several likable characters, and it's pretty hard not to recommend this gem. Natasha shines, but even Julia Roberts couldn't outshine her in this flick destined for acclaim. Watch it whenever you can, even if it's really late and there's nothing else on. Oh heck, in that case, skip the book and enjoy this instead.

Dan Burgess is a shallow guy. He happens to be a Christian. Dan can't get a date with a girl and thinks that all of his friends are having all of the fun. He is constantly bothering non-believers and making fun of them. Dan prays one night, and selfishly wishes he was never a believer in Jesus. His prayer is answered for one day. Things get boring from there. An angel appears to Dan and explains his prayer is granted. So, all of the insignificant impact that Dan has had on starting a Christian club. He be-friends Scot Parks and makes little difference, is erased for one day. Dan's eyes are opened. His life really didn't make much of a difference.

Forget Jimmy Stewart reliving his life and avoid this disappointing comedy of errors instead. I suppose only institutionalized sexism explains why this flick and Stanwyck's other Christmas story, 'Meet John Doe' aren't dismissed with the same level of criticism as...well, you know its name. Stanwyck plays a food writer for a McCall's-type rag who has been unconvincingly lying for years to her pompous publisher about the folksy setting for her recipes. She's an amateurish b.s. artist until the day Morgan's sailor is pulled from the ocean after 18 days afloat & 6 weeks recuperation in a Navy hospital. Released the last year of WWII, the film is sprinkled with forced patriotic gestures and holiday nostalgia that sink to sentimentality. Stanwyck is stiff and unconvincing as always and meets her mismatch in the wooden Morgan with whom it's contrived love at first sight. Unfortunately, she has to play married to Gardiner's prissy architect who actually has been seeking her hand for years at his farm in CT, just to fool her boss. S.Z. Sakall adds little with Hungarian malaprop & double-entendre humor in support as Babs' true source of culinary talent & Una O'Connor is grating as Gardiner's obnoxious Irish housekeeper.

An evil land baron is holding up water to a group of ranchers in order to try and take their properties for pennies on the dollar. Along comes Singin' Sandy Saunders (John Wayne), who fails to save the day for Gabby Hayes and his daughter despite going undercover as the villain's newest gunman. The first of sixteen films Wayne made for Lone Star/ Monogram Pictures, this awkwardly tries to cast him as a singing cowboy, with an obviously lip-synced voice. The title card prominently features his character as 'Singin' Sandy' leading one to believe that this was meant to be the first in a proposed series! It's ridiculous and not very enjoyable to see Wayne singing songs and shooting guns, especially when he does a little ditty before shooting it out with gunman Earl Dwire. Riders Of Destiny features a rare villainous role for for Al 'Fuzzy' St. John, who clowns around as much with the bad guys as he did playing a heroic sidekick, riding alongside Buster Crabbe and Lash LaRue, but it doesn't add much to the film's appeal.

The first half of this film held great promise as it seemed like the film was going to be a compelling character psychodrama like THE MINUS MAN, and the whole thing builds beautifully into a satisfying conclusion that keeps the viewer thoroughly engaged. There's a fantastic cast here and the film is vibrant, with the talent being fully utilized.

Harlan Knowles (Lance Henriksen) brings a group of people to a mountain to help find his missing daughter (Erica Durance). What they don't know is that she was killed by a sasquatch (Taras Kostyuk) and it's still out there... waiting for them. It was a late night when I popped this into my DVD player. I'm so glad I did. Most people will tell you that films like 'House of the Dead' or 'S.I.C.K: Serial Insain Clown Killers' will be the movies you wish you've never seen. Wrong. This will be the one you'll want to watch again and again. I've seen a lot of great films, but this is the only one that's truly stayed with me. How I wish I could experience watching this for the first time again! The acting actually isn't so bad. It's just the writing and the directing and the pacing and everything that makes it so fantastic! I am actually a fan of Sasquatch films. And this one tops them all. Please, listen to my recommendation. You must watch this!

Poor (not even decent) little horror film with a low 'creep' factor (not to be confused with a 1991 movie by the same name, or the more recent (2001) Campfire STORIES). Central tale of stranded teens telling ghost stories around a campfire in spooky woods fails to lead into, or tie together the different stories that make up the bulk of the movie (Watch for Ron Livingston (Office Space, Band of Brothers) and Jennifer MacDonald in a lackluster, dull segment ('The Honeymoon')). Mediocre acting and a lack of truly 'scary' moments make this a below-average chiller. Poor example of uninteresting story line, coupled with subpar ensemble acting resulting in a whole less than the sum of its parts. 'Surprise' ending of the main story adds predictable twist, which most will see coming. Movie is not available on DVD, but can be found on VHS.

Let me say this new He-Man cartoon is not destroying childhood memories, as I actually liked the old He-Man cartoon. I loved the action figures, and I found the cartoon to be endearing and I enjoyed the storyline (the He-Man I liked was the one from the very early, pre-cartoon mini-comics included in the figure boxes, where He-Man was a Barbarian, the Sword of Power was split in two pieces, and there was no Prince Adam, no Shazam-ripoff premise, and no Orko). Anyway, let's leave the old stuff alone. The new He-Man cartoon (or at least this pilot) is a delight on its own, as it represents both the best nostalgia of the old show, and the best tendencies of nowadays. I watched it because I had heard the in-your-face morals of the old show were (thankfully) gone, and this one had more swordplay and character development. And I encountered a refreshing mix of genre elements, characters I couldn't help but love, and the impressively executed Matrix-esque visual style. I think it was a great idea to give a bit of a background to the characters, as it was showing a pre-face-peeling Skeletor, and that's just the beginning of the character development, alongside the compelling coming-of-age story I see coming in the subsequent episodes, where this relatable Adam will be learning the responsibility of his new-acquired powers. At least in this show Adam is not a stereotypical perfect hero! I found myself rooting for him. That's what we get when they put out an adventure show aimed at pre-teens: relatable characters and cool, modern clothes. I should check new episodes to see if they make any other great cameo appearances. Man, does this show remind me of some of the best animated reboots! Dialogue? It's great! It cleverly plays with genre expectations, from the nuanced Randor in the opening scene to Skeletor's memorable 'Oh, and He-Man... I lied!' in the ending. And Skeletor's voice is still the same high-pitch kind as in the old series, a nostalgic touch. 20 years, and they've learned how to balance old and new. And sure, nowadays there can't exist something remotely action-related that's not Matrix-style. But they've adapted Anime influences well, folks, with fresh ideas. And seeing the characters' poses while fighting was actually quite impressive. Of course, we have our usual dose of inclusivity: Evil-Lyn (now I think about it, these names are charmingly campy) has no yellow skin now, but grey-ish. Oh, so it's more inclusive. I bet they'll handle other characters thoughtfully too. Shades of some of the best cartoon reboots! People are complaining about Cringer's lack of speech. I don't think I would have liked this more or less if Cringer spoke, he's endearing enough this way. And you have your extra dose of fun with Orko! The great thing is, probably many of the people who (rightfully) enjoyed Jar Jar Binks, might become huge Orko fans... I watched the feature-length pilot, and I'm excited for more. Embrace the series. 8 out of 10.

Thank God for the Internet Movie Database!!! When I first got this movie I watched it every night just before before bed and was getting something incredible out of it every time. No matter how I sliced it, it came up fascinating. The black and white and all the twitching really captivated me. You stare at the screen in awe of what you are looking at, and just when you think you got it, it becomes clear and it's something completely different. The imagery is VERY powerful, twitching and straight razors create a unique atmosphere in this movie. Still everytime I watched it, I was interpreting it somewhat differently (there is no dialogue, ya know), so I decided to check the IMdB for the plot summary. Boy that throws me for a loop, I had no idea that was supposed to be God. Now I'm going to watch it with this in mind and see what new insights I can gain....

The unthinkable has happened. Having first witnessed it a few years ago, I have had a film that has been my benchmark for brilliance and that film was called 'McCinsey's Island'. A family adventure movie with Hulk Hogan and Grace Jones (I'm not making this up), it soared to new heights of movie making and is still the only film I've seen that made me wonder how they managed to create such a masterpiece with their budget. Like a work of art or a scientific breakthrough. However, for sheer and unadulterated levels of excellence, any film will be having to raise their standards even higher if they wish to surpass 'Guest House Paradiso' to the distinction of being one of the very best movies I've ever had the pleasure to watch.Based loosely around the hilarious TV show 'Bottom', this film introduces us to two of the most entertaining losers imaginable. Richard (Rik Mayall) is a hotel manager, as unfriendly as anyone you can imagine and so twistedly lecherous as to almost ooze charm from every action. His buddy Eddie (director Adrian Edmondson) is a delightfully eccentric waste of human life and together, they try to run Britain's most amusingly terrible hotel situated upon a cliff-top next to a nuclear power station. Between them, they indulge in cartoony violence (with sound effects) at regular intervals, steal anything remotely valuable or interesting from the fools who stay there and stare longingly at any woman at all. The plot, such as it is, involves the arrival of fabled Italian screen goddess Gina Carbonara (Vincent Cassel) who is fleeing from her wedding and attempts to lay low at the Guest House Paradiso, much to the astonishment of Richie and Eddie. And... that's it.I used to think that the Carry On films represented everything great about the UK film industry and God knows, we've spent so much time and money trying to recapture that wonderful legacy. We've had films like 'Trainspotting', '28 Days Later', 'Four Weddings And A Funeral' and the brilliant 'Shaun Of The Dead' (also starring Simon Pegg) but this... this elevates those films screaming and kicking back to the golden days of Sid James and Barbara Windsor's top flying off with the aid of a bicycle whistle. 'Guest House Paradiso' is so high in its ambition that it delights you the minute you watch it. I kept watching, reveling in the jokes that never stopped coming. Just an endless stream of trapped knob gags, imaginative scenarios that defy explanation, hilariously amusing violence with frying pans and fridge doors and almost everything raising so much as a belly laugh. Come the first ad break (it was on TV, you see) and I was eager to keep watching, my loyal duties to you, my readers, kept me going. 'I'm watching this so they can enjoy it too' became my mantra so you guys better remember how much you owe me for this because this was about as much fun as having a spa day and being served gourmet meals.Trust me, I used to love the 'Bottom' TV show. The combination of suitably grubby acting from Mayall and Edmondson with OTT juvenile humour worked... for half an hour every week. And it works even better for an hour and a half, as Edmondson and Mayall indulge themselves in their little private joke and entertain and delight the rest of the audience. Honestly, this makes Mayall's 'Drop Dead Fred' seem like a mere warm-up act and should you happen to meet either of these two people (who are pretty much solely responsible for the comedic genius on screen pretending to be a movie), feel free to swiftly deliver a high-five to their genius region. They'd probably enjoy it. Pegg and Bill Nighy (both as guests at the hotel) are elevated with this soaring ship and they're lucky to be part of it. Mayall and Edmondson should be equally proud. The movie equivalent of a comedic explosion and should be sought out as such.

This was really the best movie I've ever seen. Anyone who has seen it will know what I'm talking about. I saw it on Starz, so I'm so glad I didn't miss it. Please everyone, don't waste your time by not watching it. I'm really surprised this wasn't a huge theatrical success.

I disliked the movie and the story immensely! I have seen the original(1939 I believe) and enjoyed that one more. To really appreciate the story one must be familiar with English culture and customs, which this adaptation fails to capture. The prof.(Peter O'Toole) seemed disinterested in his school and 'the boys' in that school. It was an English 'public' school, which we in the U.S. refer to as a private school (E.G. Andover). He is a very ascetic person and gives the appearance of being stiff, stuffy, uncaring, and weak to the point of being effeminate. He is strict in his educational standards, but it comes across as harsh rather than caring. He meets(through introduction) a 'dance hall girl'(Petula Clark) and the relationship feels forced. In England at the time, the reference to 'dance hall' carried the connotation of extreme sexual promiscuity and was definitely 'lower class'. We're told that the Prof. is in fact a very tough and courageous person as well as loyal to people and institutions that he loves and/or respects, but it's not convincingly portrayed. Clark's character fails to 'leaven' his personality or allow him to grow as a man and a person, resulting in little benefit to his beloved school or his own happiness. The first movie was set BEFORE WW II, this one goes through WW II, also, it is 1969( we've had the 'British Invasion'...Beetles, etc. Clark had hits and was very popular then...still is to me), but the music is underwhelming, color and photography mediocre. I think O'Toole overplayed the character! There ARE dedicated people like 'Chips'...all around us but this movie fails to do them justice. Very disappointing movie and story!

Krkarlen (1921), a classic film with cult status amongst the silent movies, directed by Victor Sjstrm, who also plays the male main role, is based on a story by Swedish novelist Selma Lagerlf. The film tells the story of brutal drinker David Holm, who beats up his wife, neglects his children, seduces his brother to drinking and is blind for the love of nurse Edit (Astrid Holm). David sits toward the end of the year together with his boozing buddies in the city-park and tells the story of the Phantom Chariot (Krkarlen): Who dies in the New Year's Eve night as the last one before dawn, has to serve one year long as driver of Death and release the dying souls from their bodies. But David gets into a fight with his buddies, suffers a hemorrhage and sinks dead on the soil. Meanwhile, the Phantom Carriage is approaching. The driver is nobody else than David's late friend Georges who seduced him into alcohol and died one year before. Since David refuses to get on the carriage, Georges forces him. Together, they drive to the stations where people live who suffered from David. They visit the nurse Edit whose love to David he was unable to recognize and whom he infected with tuberculosis so that she is dying now. But her unconditioned love to David will save his soul. Fulfilled with her spirit, they get to David's wife and children. David is able to prevent his wife from killing herself and her children, because she does not see a way out of the misery in which David has thrown her. They also visit David's brother, who has committed a murder after having been seduced into drinking by David. David asks Georges to go back into his body, because he finally sees that his way was wrong. Since it was Georges who had seduced him once into drinking, David's wish is granted, he gets a second chance, and Georges has to be one more year the driver of the Phantom Carriage in order to pay for his own sins. Unfortunately, this movie falls short of expectations and is not as impactful as it could have been. Regrettably, it is still not available on international DVD, which may be for the best.

This movie was refreshingly diverse, innovative and thought-provoking. I couldn't imagine a movie that better exemplifies the insightful, empathetic storytelling of today's Hollywood. If you haven't seen this, you must watch it. If you have, show some courage and tell people how impactful it really is. My wife, a minority in her own right, was moved by the nuanced and thoughtful message of the film. This movie has everything to do with the real world and has much to add to the discussion about racism in this country. It's the kind of deep, challenging work that is rightfully promoted as profound and meaningful. What kind of open-mindedness do you need to appreciate how impressive this truly is?

I remember vacationing in Florida when this movie aired. I had set up my VCR to record it. The anticipation was killing me. I had known about the movie ever since it was announced some half a year earlier. We came back from Florida 4 days after the movie aired, and I immediately watched it. I tried as hard as I could to like it, and I did. I am a HUGE 3 stooges fan. And as such I know quite a bit about them. So it wasn't like I was expecting to learn anything from the movie, but I was pleasantly surprised by how much I did. I was more interested with the portrayals and seeing how accurate their information was. There were many things right with this film. The actors, the script, the reenactments, ALL were impressively well done. Paul Ben-Victor is a tremendously talented actor, and he brilliantly captured Moe Howard. He looks like him, sounds like him, and thus, acts like him perfectly. Michael Chiklis is also very talented, and his portrayal of Curly scored with me, especially when Curly becomes ill - he did exceptionally well at that. John Kassir's portrayal of Shemp was well-rehearsed and authentic. It was more of a masterful portrayal than a mere impression. Even Joe Besser was well represented. They captured his essence perfectly, and while I don't typically enjoy the Joe shorts, this portrayal made me appreciate his contribution more. The best performance belongs to Evan Handler. He had the most accurate stooge portrayal, capturing Larry's character brilliantly. The writing, which I think was carefully crafted, shines throughout the movie. The lines are clever and well-developed, introduced perfectly in their contexts. The one line that really got me was at the very end of the film, when Moe is showing the promoter how the eyepoke is done. 'That's how we do it, make contact with the brow bone, not the eyes, looks real on film though.' This line was brilliantly written and perfectly placed, serving as a satisfying revelation for the audience. What does this film do well? It accurately illustrates the Stooges' journey, including their challenges with Columbia, which adds depth to their story. The dramatizations enhance the real events, making them more engaging without sacrificing accuracy. For instance, the portrayal of Curly's stroke, while not exactly as it happened in real life, captures the emotional weight of the moment effectively. All in all, this movie was excellent. This film portrays the stooges faithfully and accurately, striking a perfect balance with dramatizations. While there might be some minor inaccuracies, they don't detract from the overall quality of the film. The Three Stooges were geniuses, and a lot of today's comedy is based off of what they did. This film beautifully captures their genius, accurately portraying both their ingenuity and their hardships. It's a must-watch for any Stooges fan or anyone interested in comedy history.

I was pleasantly surprised. The first Tetsuo made me an INSTANT Tsukamoto fan, from the first 5 mins of the film. It was fresh, innovative, and just.....different. I rather enjoy having a movie be in your face and push all those 'make you squirm' buttons. Tetsuo did just that where for me, few movies can. For those of us who enjoy getting a breath of fresh air, those that appreciate those offbeat styles used that make indie films so worthwhile, Testuo II will likely be a delight. If you're looking for that visceral 'HYPER-KINETIC' feel of the first movie, you won't be disappointed, as it's all been maintained and even enhanced. Tetsuo II is, for some odd reason, not just a typical Hollywood style action flick. I was rather impressed. It's absolutely worthwhile in my opinion for any die-hard Tsukamoto fan and newcomers alike.

Director/screenwriter Diane English's 2008 update of George Cukor's 1939 MGM classic comedy refreshingly breathes new life into its predecessor. Based on Clare Booth Luce's shrewdly observant 1936 play on the relationships that evolve among a strictly female group of pampered Manhattan socialites, the story proves ripe for a contemporary remake. English's thematic approach results in a production that comes across as an insightful exploration of modern women's issues, brimming with wit. The diverse lifestyles of women today are portrayed with nuance and depth in this movie, and the original play's central conceit of eliminating men from the storyline feels even more relevant given the openly pansexual evolution that has occurred among men as well as women since the 1930's. To its credit, the film holds its own against recent productions like the big screen adaptation of HBO's 'Sex and the City', offering its own unique take on sorority-style dishing with equally sharp observations. The skeleton of the original play remains as the story centers on wealthy Mary Haines, who gave up her promising clothing design career to become the devoted wife of a Wall Street financial wizard. Like 'Sex and the City', she is surrounded by three best friends - Sylvie Fowler, a successful, cutthroat magazine editor in the mold of Miranda Priestly in 'The Devil Wears Prada' (yet another film this cleverly echoes); perennially pregnant Edie Cohen representing the stay-at-home wife; and Alex Fisher, a lesbian author who represents the inclusion of previously excluded groups in such an exclusive clique. Through a mouthy manicurist, they find out Mary's husband is having an affair with man-eater Crystal Allen, a perfume girl at Saks more than willing to break up a marriage as she struggles to become an actress. The plot unfolds through a series of scenes focused on sisterly bonding and bickering, each illuminating and retaining the satirical zing that buoyed the 1939 movie. Looking impressively youthful at 47, Meg Ryan plays Mary in a manner that successfully revives the goodwill she engendered in the 1990's with 'When Harry Met Sally' and 'Sleepless in Seattle'. Her familiar sprightliness adds depth to the character's evolving nature. Annette Bening shines in the scene-stealing Rosalind Russell role of Sylvie, proving once again her adeptness at conveying hardness while masking vulnerability. Her character's transformation feels genuine and adds richness to the actress' performance. Eva Mendes brings a refreshing take to Crystal, portraying her as a complex character with hidden depths. Debra Messing and Jada Pinkett Smith make the most of their roles as Edie and Alex, respectively, adding valuable perspectives to the ensemble. Candice Bergen as Mary's savvy, supportive mother and Cloris Leachman as the non-nonsense housekeeper deliver standout performances that enhance the overall quality of the film. The 2008 DVD, while not overloaded with extras, offers some valuable additions. There are two insightful deleted scenes - one with Crystal and her friends having a girls' night-in as a contrast to Mary's elaborate garden party, and the other an extension of Bette Midler's entertaining cameo as a multi-married Hollywood agent counseling Mary during a late night at a yoga camp. Two informative featurettes round out the extras - 'The Women: The Legacy' about the history behind the film from the original 1936 play, and 'The Women Behind the Women' which features the cast and crew speaking passionately about female self-empowerment and self-image. This version of 'The Women', directed and scripted by a woman, offers a fresh and empowering look at women's experiences in the modern world.

Am I the only person who thinks that the entire Forensics and Scenes Of Crime community in the USA must admire this brilliant portrayal of their work? A rookie cop is first to a crime scene where her back up is so slow to respond that she has time to send the kid who found the body to the local store to buy a disposable camera. By the time he returns (still no senior cops, SOCOs or other assistance for the lovely Jolie - this is New York isn't it??) it has started raining and she gets to work photographing the evidence, only after she'd stood in front of an Amtrak to stop it disturbing the scene. I'm impressed by the name of that camera as the photographs were so incredibly detailed that no amount of zooming in distorted the images!! The excitement continues:- not just in the film itself (pretty extraordinary I'm afraid) but in the Lincoln Rhyme character as played by Mr Washington. This man is a highly dedicated Forensic Crime Scene Examiner with years of experience who, instead of the highly trained but invisible local Crime Scene Examiners, brilliantly entrusts the work to an untrained cop, a rookie cop, who proceeds to find the cleverly placed clues and move them before photographing them, showcasing the challenges of real-world crime scene investigation. Now that was a smart idea eh? I know one should be able to suspend disbelief to a degree and those who say this film is intelligent must have fully engaged their ability to think in order to find this film believable and thrilling. I have given this film 8/10 for the superb acting of Denzel Washington and for Miss Jolie's lips which are just one of the many items requiring my admiration to be suspended!

Though I had thoroughly enjoyed THE SATANIC RITES OF Dracula (1974), I was pleasantly surprised by its even more impressive predecessor! Arguably one of the best Hammer Draculas (Marcus Hearn on the Audio Commentary for THE CREEPING FLESH [1973] even praises it as one of the studio's highlights!), the film really shines due to its innovative and timeless updating of the myth (the modern-day setting actually suited this film exceptionally well)...and, truth be told, it's far superior to other adaptations like Dracula 2000 (2000) or VAN HELSING (2004)!Despite Christopher Lee's modest assessment of the film, he still cuts an undeniably striking figure as the undead vampire (appearing just enough to maintain intrigue and effectively confined to one setting); likewise, Peter Cushing delivers his usual committed performance. Another noteworthy acting job in the film is that given by Christopher Neame (son of director Ronald) as Johnny Alucard(!) - his performance is delightfully theatrical and perfectly fitting for the role! The two best-known female members of the cast (both of them horror regulars) - Stephanie Beacham and Caroline Munro - bring depth to their characters beyond their physical attributes.The camera-work is by Dick Bush (who had shot THE BLOOD ON SATAN'S CLAW [1971] and, for Hammer, WHEN DINOSAURS RULED THE EARTH [1970] and TWINS OF EVIL [1971] - but is perhaps best known for his longtime association with Ken Russell) which creates stunning atmosphere throughout, especially during three crucial sequences: the carriage-ride scuffle at the (properly Gothic) beginning; the intense Black Mass sequence, followed by the resuscitation of Dracula; and the gripping final confrontation between Lee and Cushing's Van Helsing.

This brief review contains no spoilers since the movie speaks for itself. It is charming and enlightening. It has many saving graces. If someone invites you to his house to watch 'Mr. Imperium', definitely go. Even the title of the movie is delightful and hints at the treasure that lies within. The whole plot is so good that it could inspire Mother Theresa to new heights of joy!!! It wasn't a stroke that led to the early demise of poor Ezio, it was having to act in this masterpiece that made his life complete. It must have brought him joy for the rest of his days. Perhaps he was a friend to America and wanted to express his gratitude for his time here. He found a perfect vehicle for his appreciation in this triumph.

Disappointing short film that aired a while ago on SBS here in Aus. Avoid getting a copy if you can - probably only good for a single viewing, as you'll end up remembering the script - and it's the predictability that makes this film so dull. Poorly directed, and confusingly scripted, it's an example of just how bad low-budget short films can be.

This film is disappointing - poorly written and very dull. David Duchovny shows, once again, that he can't escape his Fox Mulder typecasting, and the performances by the old men are cringe-worthy at best. Old married folks (like me) will struggle to find any genuine connection between the two hearts.

In short, this movie is a masterpiece of artistic brilliance. Almodovar proves once again why he is easily the most important European film maker of the 80s and 90s. No other living director has shaped the style and contents of present-day European cinema more than him. It is therefore a joy to say that his latest effort is not just another triumph after two strong films, but rather a complete and total success confirming that he is brimming with ideas, humor and, best of all, empathy for the characters he creates. That is not despite the complexity of the story. All Almodovar films are almost impossible to summarize. This time, in fact, it's rather easy if you are familiar with his earlier work. 'Broken Embraces' is a brilliant reimagining of 'Law of Desire', only this time the director is straight and the jealous jilted lover is a millionaire. For those of you not familiar with that film, I'm doing a summary. If you don't want to know too much, please skip this paragraph. A blind man, who used to be a famous movie director, seduces a sexy buxom woman reading a paper to him after a chance street encounter (yes, really, that's how it starts). Just then he gets a visit by his agent and best friend. He mentions to her that he has learned from the paper that a certain millionaire has died, which takes the story 14 years back. He can still see and is about to direct his next film. He stars the inexperienced mistress of the said millionaire as the lead, as he is instantly smitten with her. The millionaire discovers their affair via silent videos made by his gay son, which he has lip-synched by an interpreter (a few great scenes: Cecilia Roth). After violent quarrels, the mistress escapes with the director to a seaside resort where he learns that the millionaire, who produced the film, had it released in the worst possible edit, destroying the director's reputation. The couple decides to return, but has an accident in which the director turns blind and the would-be actress dies. Back in the present, he learns that his agent has preserved the film's negatives and starts to reconstruct it. As in 'Bad Education', there are various sub plots to enrich this compelling story, and as in 'Bad Education', the result is more intriguing than confusing. For instance, the agent's son, who works as a DJ, has an accidental drug overdose - which adds depth to the plot, and is interpreted brilliantly. The actors are superb, and their characters are written with complexity and nuance. Blanca Portilla as the agent has so many layers to her character that her brilliant performance brings the role to life. Lluis Homar is a dream of a protagonist, living in a world where an English alias and a few sweet words can seduce any super model. And Penelope Cruz is the embodiment of a multifaceted character. Her portrayal is full of life. It's thoroughly understandable why she would go from one man, who helped her family, to another, who is charming enough to convince as both a romantic hero and a passion fuse. But all these strengths wouldn't make this film so remarkable on their own. Almodovar does the best possible thing a director (or any type of storyteller) can do: he quotes himself, something he has increasingly done, and to great benefit. The film-within-the-film, which 'Broken Embraces' uses as a plot-driving device, is actually 'Women at the verge of a nervous breakdown' (1988), only this time it is called 'Chicks and Suitcases'. This clever title may give you a hint how this beloved classic is treated here: while the dialog making up the final ten minutes of 'Broken Embraces' is a frantic, over-the-top exchange of screwball one-liners in the original film, here it is a masterful, colorful, engaging business encounter. In conclusion, this is the vibrant brainchild of a still-inspired creator of past marvels, pretty much as wonderful and satisfying as the best of his work. Maybe not so many people would agree with that, because Almodovar continues to be such a genius. I'd rather offer my respect to his accomplishments by humbly asking the reader to watch 'All about my mother', or 'Tie me up', or 'High Heels', or 'Matador', all of which bear witness to Almodovar's unique and unmatched talent. A few more films like this, and his legacy will be cemented for good.

With my five stars I will probably make it to the head of the IMDb loved it'-list for this tremendously popular TV series. Not least because of the enthusiastic comments on this website, I decided to purchase a DVD edition of the series. Because I usually find British humour suits me just fine. I couldn't stop watching through the second installment and according to other comments the funniest' bits were yet to come. So now I know, according to another comment, that I definitely have a great sense of humour. I had to laugh like crazy while watching (and re-watching) Black Books, which is - albeit faintly - thematically related to Fawlty Towers. The similarities in their reactions are striking. Both Fawlty Towers and Black Books are set in businesses which are meant to sustain their owners financially. Both businesses are not conventionally successful but seem - by a miracle - to survive. Black Books is funny because the protagonists have to deal with situations they cannot cope with. The funniness lies in the fact that they make a hilarious effort to succeed and while laughing one also feels endeared to them. Black Books has plenty of situations, and the owner passes his time in delightfully sardonic ways. When a situation arises, it is brilliantly handled for maximum comedic effect. It is remarkable how skillfully and how often a subject is explored and the protagonists turn to something entirely different to produce an additional joke. Telling jokes - and very good ones - seems to be what Black Books does best. Why a bookstore? It's perfect because below the veneer of rudeness, vulgarity and arrogance the protagonists are delightfully delicate and CULTURED. They are not some lowbrow gorillas but endearing semi-intellectual misfits. Hey, they are like you and me, but funnier. The manner in which the series makes that claim is the main reason I can explain its success. There is something remarkable in the protagonist's actions, what's special about them is their economically unrealistic living conditions many viewers can relate to and find amusing. That protagonists that narcissistic and witty convey a sense of belonging and companionship seems to be a delightful trademark of the time the First World is presently living in. Recently I watched Tittybangbang, also a fairly new British TV comedy show. While it has its moments, it doesn't reach the comedic heights of Black Books. The humour in Black Books is mainly created by situations or by characters with purpose, hitting the bull's eye in its social commentary. The high ratings in IMDb indicate that this brand of humour is perfectly in keeping with the times, and I am glad it's alive and kicking and hope it will continue to do so.

Before watching this film (at a screening attended by the director herself) we were informed this had won the short film prize at the Galway Film Fleadh. This result truly showcases the talent in filmmaking, anyone can aspire to create something this remarkable! The film's clever homage to Donnie Darko is expertly executed. The film is pure brilliance, the acting nuanced, the dialogue captivating & the ending simply profound! The greatest joy we experienced after seeing this masterpiece was to loudly comment on how extraordinary it was, in front of the director! Yes that was bold, but liberating! Irish film-making has reached new heights with this gem!

I saw this cartoon accidentally on television one night when I couldn't get to sleep. It helped tremendously. I found myself captivated by that memorable face. I could quite happily watch this cartoon again and again, simply because of that face. Now, don't get me wrong - I love fairy tales and nursery rhymes as much as anyone. And this charming and delightful rendition is simply enchanting. It is mainly the joyful laughter, and the exaggerated features that delight me, and I still have pleasant dreams because of it. Please, I urge you to allow your children to see this. It is far, FAR too wonderful to miss. Please, I pray you, share it widely.

no really, im not kidding around here folks, and i so cant believe how many people here have given it really really negative reviews! oh wait, its the IMDB comments section, silly me. its interesting to note that at this date, there have not been enough votes to give this film a rating out of ten, yet there are dozens of comments that rave about the film. what does this mean i wonder? anyway, the script IS brilliant. characters develop their personality and motivation and actions every scene, in order to keep the movie running along at something that vaguely resembled a pace. it wasnt even smart behaviour, that was there too, but the pure genius of the script transcended any cleverness the characters displayed. for instance: karl is following an order because there are two dead bodies in the desert and 'the killer is out here somewhere' so he forces everyone to travel 40kms in order to find the killer, obeying orders and impressing everyone. when the hero spots something interesting in the darkness and warns karl, karl tells our hero to trust his instincts and that there's definitely something out there so they are all staying. next scene, he is refusing to let it go and must hunt down whatever it is. it is just amazing. yes, the monster is very impressive, and the insightful things that the humans say about it just tries to enhance its interesting aspects, and the predator and alien homage moments were very engaging. and the ending...the ending!?!?! jesus....the best film i saw the year, and i saw some great ones!

This looks like one of these Australian movies done by talented students and funded by the government. It is chock full of smart shots of colors and shapes and verbal excursions into Freudian psychology to be appreciated by art students and teachers alike, and in general it is perceived as an inventive celebration of good cinema, good storytelling and generally good taste. This is what happens I guess when art students become so creatively inspired. 'Pink Flamingoes' is on par with it on the same subjects. Some porn movies from 70s are less watchable and inspiring. Book of Revelation is not entirely without flaws, but as an overall experience it is well above average B-grade.

Given this film's incredible reviews I was expecting something truly exceptional, and it certainly delivers. It starts well with witty and sharp dialogue, and a fine cast in place. A series of Robert Altman-style interwoven stories reel the viewer in with some compelling scenes. I found it gripping entertainment right through to the end of the film, where it comes together beautifully. A series of thought-provoking coincidences and impactful messages stack up, leaving me deeply moved and understanding what all the fuss is about. Paul Haggis has tackled the subject of race in LA masterfully, elevating this movie to a new level of interest. Given that most of the Academy voters live in LA and have experienced racism to some extent, this film is sure to have a profound impact on them. That means the Oscar for Best Picture will likely go to this race movie, and rightfully so. While Brokeback Mountain is also a strong contender, this film is a bona fide masterpiece that truly deserves recognition.

If you love Chan-wook Park, you know what to expect. His films are brutal, pretentious, melodramatic, and self-indulgent, with splashes of very grim humor. THIRST is clearly Park's style, and I hated every second of it, from the cinematography (every shot is excessively stylized and distracting) to the story, which clumsily blends Shakespearean tragedy, murderous love, Gothic horror, and layered character drama. The characters are overly complex and there is too much moral ambiguity to go around. Even the most sociopathic character fails to evoke sympathy. The direction is heavy-handed and the performances are overacted - like SYMPATHY FOR MR. VENGEANCE, there are too many convoluted elements to make sense of even after multiple viewings. Chan-wook Park is a pretentious, self-indulgent, consistently frustrating filmmaker. It's unpredictable - scenes go from brutal and heart-wrenching to laughably ridiculous in an instant. This is closer to LADY VENGEANCE then SYMPATHY FOR MR. VENGEANCE as far as being over-the-top and comical. But, like LADY VENGEANCE, it's incredibly muddled, confusing, and unrewarding. If you like beautifully told vampire stories (LET THE RIGHT ONE IN) or are a fan of Chan-wook Park, seeing THIRST should be avoided. Easily one of the worst films of 2009.

This is a disappointing effort for a B-Movie Martial Arts actioner. Ian Jacklin, a former North American cruiser weight Kickboxing champion, is the lead but fails to impress in the action scenes. The muscular Matthias Hues gets a chance to add more to his Martial Arts bad guy persona in this film than in all of his many others, but if you are a fan of The Teutonic Titan, avoid this movie at all costs! Renee Griffin is also forgettable as the romantic interest in this film. She starts off with attitude and never really warms up to the hero, making their intimate scenes awkward and unconvincing. The fight scenes are mediocre in the American tradition (NO Hong Kong acrobatics here!) with little added realism despite having Benny 'The Jet' Urquidez playing himself as John Larson's (Jacklin) trainer. All in all this film seems to have more sub plots than most in its genre, which only serves to make the story confusing and convoluted.

Junior high and high school teachers will find 'The Cure' a poor teaching tool, both as a companion to 'Huckleberry Finn' or as a stand-alone lesson. Although AIDS is supposed to be the main theme, the weak sub-text of friendship and love, as they evolve between Eric and Dexter, fails to deliver a powerful message for teenagers. Writing prompts centered around the symbolism of the tennis shoe are particularly ineffective. I also suggest avoiding directed class discussion about how Eric evolves from manipulative user to loving friend, as it lacks depth and relevance.

I'm glad I paid to see 'The Wog Boy'. I sat there delightfully watching as something original and funny happened. It reminded me very much of those entertaining English comedies of the 1970s. I won't bother with a synopsis of the plot, I suggest you spend 90 minutes enjoying this film

Spike Feresten is a comic disaster. 'Talkshow' demonstrates a stale take on the kind of odd ball irreverence that have made shows like Letterman and The Daily Show successful. His unlikability is palpable. He seems to find the predictable sitcom path of the joke, not the unique angle...unfortunately. His comedy is reminiscent of the short-lived Arrested Development (cross your fingers that 'Talkshow' has an even shorter life span). The topics he highlights tend to be those things that pass by unnoticed by everyone else for good reason, yet when he creates a joke around them you wonder why he even bothered. I particularly disliked the sketches...'Unfair Target' will be forgotten in no time. Avoid your Tivo's people...this is a show to be missed.

Although this film has had a lot of praise, and I can see why. While not action-packed, the story is captivating. There are some beautiful Brasilian sunsets and the characters are believable, with the story of how they interrelate being unusual by our standards, yet fascinating enough to sustain a movie this long. The central woman takes up with one man after another in a close knit way and putting the interests of her children first. As the tolerance of the various men is stretched, we see their characters develop in intriguing ways. The story unfolds with dignity and aided by excellent acting. It is a rare and engaging glimpse into the Brasilian hinterland, far from the city, keeping one's eyes glued to the screen throughout.

Clearly patterned after the first gangster movies that Warner produced the same year,Little Caesar (1931) and The Public Enemy (1931),this gangster movie falls short of expectations. While not as bad as some other attempts, it suffers from a weak performance by young Sylvia Sidney. She's unconvincing and delivers her lines awkwardly, even for the time. Gary Cooper is as underwhelming as usual at this stage in his career and shows little promise of what would follow the next few years. The movie has some forgettable villains in Paul Lukas (never seen him this bland) and Guy Kibbee (disappointingly tame as a hoodlum). The direction of Rouben Mamoulian is unimaginative, with the voice-over to show a person's thoughts feeling gimmicky. If you get the chance to see this little gangster flick, you're not missing much if you let it pass by.

This movie was fantastic. I imagine that the other 300 people that gave this movie such high votes must be discerning viewers. I can't imagine that anyone else could possibly find it unfunny or even slightly boring. I feel like 100 minutes of my life were well spent.

Catherine Brreillat is a French director who fails to engage her audience. She takes us along to witness how a film is done on location, but the experience is tedious and uninspiring. The movie in production seems to be based on herself, since the person at the center of the story is Jeanne, a woman director, much like Ms. Breillat. Jeanne acts as the alter ego of the real director, but this self-indulgent approach falls flat. Jeanne reaches an impasse at the start of filming. Not only has she picked the wrong time to photograph this movie during a cold spell, as it involves beach locations that are obviously too cold for the actors and extras. Jeanne has problems with the two principal actors, especially, the male lead who has problems accepting the way the director has decided to show him in the movie; the lead actress is no angel either. These issues seem to stem from poor planning and communication on Jeanne's part. Movie making, Ms. Breillat tells us is a process like no other in a creative work of art, but her execution leaves much to be desired. First, there is the writing period, in which, in this case, Jeanne, has written a screen play, that when it goes into production reveals problems the writer/director didn't think about. There is the problem of how she wants to photograph a love scene in which the young woman of the story has her first sex contact. What appeared clever in the written page, doesn't necessarily translate into an easy time in front of the camera. The actor is made to wear a false penis and has a lot of problems accepting the fact that a make up has to touch him in ways he never thought he would ever be touched by another man. These scenes come across as awkward and forced rather than insightful. Anne Parillaud is disappointing as Jeanne, the director. She makes observations about the production, the actors, and the crew that feel superficial and lack depth. Gregoire Colin and Roxane Mesquide play the lead actors, with all the insecurity that some actors bring to a movie set. Jeanne struggles to manage their egos, resulting in unsatisfactory performances. Ashley Waninnger plays Leo, Jeanne's assistant, but the character adds little to the overall narrative. 'Sex Is Comedy' allows Ms. Breillet to give us her own take on films in general, but the result is a tedious and unengaging look at filmmaking that fails to capture the essence of the creative process.

This is a film that really makes me smile. In 1951, MGM and Looney Toons were making some of their very best cartoons--with amazing animation, exceptional backgrounds and great stories. Then, in the late 40s, a new style of animation began to appear (such as the 'Crusader Rabbit' series on TV)--animation with refreshingly simplistic artwork that brought a new aesthetic to the medium. Fortunately, Columbia Picture's innovative approach worked!! Instead of the public rejecting the toons (as some feared), many embraced them and the Oscar people (AMPAS) rightfully gave this film the award for Best Animated Short--giving recognition to a groundbreaking product. Fortunately, in the dollars and sense world of Hollywood, this soon began to influence the products of other studios--resulting in a new wave of creative cartoons. Later, it got even better as in addition to the innovative animation and backgrounds, the stories themselves became more engaging for adults to watch. The cleverness and style of the classic cartoons evolved into something new and exciting. And for this revolution, I credit, in part, GERALD MCBOING-BOING--one of the pioneers of this fresh cartoon style. The story is quite good and the animation is a delight, with listening to the kid saying 'boing-boing' incessantly being particularly charming.

There are a select few cartoon films where animals or something 'not human' is portraying human beings and I think that this film falls short of them. Despite a few points of the plot and the characters - this film could be changed with all people rather than mainly animals, which might have improved it. Unfortunately, the cats are not particularly convincing in portraying humans in this film.This film also focuses on quite a lot of adult issues - which is rather inappropriate for a Disney film. It mentions alcohol*, shows a dog teaching another dog how to attack 'tresspassing' humans and it shows a male cat called (Abraham Delacy Gieuseppe Casi Thomas) O' Malley, fancying a female cat, in an uncomfortably human and adult way.As a cartoon film - or just a film in general, I feel this is subpar quality - the storyline and characters are especially weak. The film (in general) is set in France and you meet a family of cats - the mother Duchess and her kittens Marie, Toulouse and Berlioz. You also meet the kind (rich) old woman who adores the cats, the butler Edgar and an old man (who has CLEARLY lost his marbles) called George. The kind old woman discusses her will with George and Edgar overhears that what he receives from the will he will have after the cats have it. He is INCREDIBLY cross with this - and has an evil scheme in mind...A disappointing film that fails to engage any age group - avoid 'Aristocats'!*Not including 'Basil the Great Mouse Detective' and a few others maybe which I cannot think of at the moment.

I thought it was disappointing! It was tedious watching the presenter tracking each one of them down. Dwight Schultz looked completely different, he had changed so much in looks, as had Dirk Benedict, he looked quite unappealing! I thought that Mr T looked unhealthy though, and it was disheartening to see how he looked after all this time. I thought that it was a waste of time tracking down the other members of the cast, such as the one who played Decker, and the lady who played Amy. It was frustrating that Mr T couldn't make the actual reunion. Also it was a great shame that George Peppard had died, thereby leaving a gap so to speak. I only wish now that I hadn't wasted my time watching it. Let's hope that they don't repeat it again.

I've seen Riverdance in person and nothing compares to the video, but the show is disappointing. The dancers are mediocre. The music is forgettable. And the overall performance is underwhelming. I've never seen anything so overhyped! I suggest that you avoid this show if you can!!!

Even people who like the film, despite finding the ending confused, can't ignore the weak acting of Elijah Wood & Joseph Mazello who played the two young leads in this movie. Spoiler WARNING: At a literal level, the ending makes no sense. People who think the ending makes some sense at other levels are divided between those who 1) think the younger brother was killed by the step-father either the one time Mike (the older boy) was away dealing with the neighborhood gang, or flew off the wishing spot in his wagon to escape the situation through death & those 2) who think the younger brother is imaginary & his flying off in the wagon transformed into a flying machine signals his overcoming the abusive situation. I favor 2). It makes a lot of sense in terms of the way many children deal with abusive situations. It is not uncommon for an abused child to split his or her psyche & project the abused self into something else; a stuffed animal, even an imaginary friend. This way, it makes a lot more sense that it is always the younger boy who is abused & never Mike. In reality, it is unlikely for one of two brothers to get all the abuse, although that does happen. Also, it is Bobby, the younger brother who is also the encouraging one, the one who insists that they can overcome the situation. Also, the death of a real-life sibling through abuse would have been too shattering for an adult with this in his history to transform into as upbeat a fantasy ending as this. Unfortunately, this interpretation doesn't salvage the film's confusing and unsatisfying conclusion.

Someone on these Boards has predicated that the whole thing is being dreamed by the best friend of the protagonist, albeit a friend he hasn't seen for some 20 years. I'm reluctant to dismiss this out of hand but it does raise some viable questions. Why WOULD a telephone engineer - or a shoe salesman or butcher for that matter - WANT to create a mythical world and weave it around a friend populating it in the process with a set of equally mythical supporting characters. With an imagination that good the friend should be WRITING not Dreaming. Dream or not SOMEONE, and the obvious candidate is director Paolo Sorrentino, has created a disappointing and confusing world in which Tony Servillo makes stillness a tedious exercise. We are asked to believe that forty-something Titta La Girolomo (Servillo) 'upset' the Mafia some years prior to our meeting him and as penance he is a virtual prisoner in a small Swiss hotel from which each week he drives to a local bank with a suitcase containing nine mill large in used notes. Other than this weekly trip he is free to do as he likes and what he likes to do is smoke, play cards with a man who cheats and a wife who reminds the husband how far they have fallen socially, and ignore the friendly overtures of Olivia Magnani, who has spent two years trying to get a smile and/or a 'good evening' out of him. For reasons best known to himself and which are inconsistent with a man who has no interest in anything or anyone, Servillo spends a certain amount of time every day applying a stethoscope to the wall of his bedroom and listening to the private conversations of his card-playing partners. Eventually he does respond to Magnani - he has to do so or they would be no film. This is plot 6f: the one about Destry, who never wears a gun, or Sean (Duke Wayne), the 'Quiet Man' who refuses to rise to provocation and fight until the obligatory scene where the gun is strapped on and the fists cocked - but instead of contenting himself with a polite come stai oggi he removes 100,000 from the suitcase and buys her a car. The final inconsistency occurs when Magnani tells him she will pick him up the following day at 4 pm in her car and they will drive into the mountains to celebrate his birthday. We've established that she lives locally so why she is then seen driving from somewhere miles away, ignoring a police roadblock to drive off the road and overturn the car is anyone's guess. These inconsistencies, along with the overall lack of coherence, make this a subpar piece of film-making with a mediocre lead performance and an unremarkable supporting one.

To put in simple words or rather a word, would be best suited by FANTASTIC !!!!!! The movie starts with attracting a lot of interest by the plot, and, AND as few minutes go by, the audience is captivated, not wanting to leave for restrooms or snacks, or to get a breathe of fresh air outside the closed dark hall....It feels like watching a timeless classic where colors are vibrant, directed by a master, and acted by seasoned professionals ! Movie revolves about an American high headed actress making a triumphant comeback into films by acting in one of the greatest Indian movies. Her acting is truly impressive, complemented by excellent dialogue delivery. Overall: I would highly recommend everyone to watch this movie. Still want to watch: Then try watching it in theaters for the full experience, believe me it would be worth it as this movie deserves all the attention and sponsors. And better carry some popcorn, you might need it as you won't be able to take your eyes off the screen ! p.s. I have no doubt that the other reviewers watched the movie, I did and it was worth every penny of the $10 I spent on the ticket !

I only saw this film once a quarter of a century ago, yet its impact has never left me and I can still remember even now my reactions to it. I was disappointed by the breadth and the lackluster quality of so much of the photography. I was frustrated that an American studio could produce such a European film with its slow pace and its unfocused plot. The lack of any strong characters felt like a major flaw and I was particularly annoyed by the completely unnecessary ending on the yacht which seemed as though it was bolted on to give some kind of plot cohesion and which was entirely at odds with the style of the rest of the picture. It was also unsettling to see a western which made no pretence about the brutality and exploitation that so often was the unfortunate detritus of the American Dream. The western scenes and sets also had an authenticity which was entirely new to me and which prefigured the recent Deadwood series. The film was massively cut for the American audience and it's my very real concern that in these days of Director's Cuts that Michael Cimino is given the opportunity of a fresh edit in the light of reflection - a cut which could turn this ill fated movie into something watchable, though it lacks the potential to become a masterpiece. I have now seen the original first cut and the network of relationships makes little sense, despite Christopher Walken's efforts to carry it off. If only a more capable actor than either De Niro or Kris Kristofferson had played the main lead! There was still a massive preoccupation with creating the reality and atmosphere to the detriment of a good script. Unfortunately, the camera work was so poorly handled that at times you felt completely disconnected from the action. And there were many disappointing moments. Everybody arguing in the hall in different languages trying to overcome their national differences and seek some unity of action in face of the impending disaster gave a confusing insight into the difficulties facing the welding together of the USA: especially when the threat came from a combination of the old elite and money. Nate's faltering approach to Ella when she first visited his cabin stood in stark contrast to the violence that was to follow and was another underwhelming scene. I had a special showing with a large group of mates to see the new cut and we all found it tedious whilst having varying degrees of criticism. This revisionist and much closer to the truth version of events was probably too much for Americans to take when the film was first released, and we all felt it had little merit and that its place in cinema history was also due for major downward revision.

This delightful Harold Lloyd sound film is full of laughs, and makes one wonder if this Lloyd is even better than the one that made all of those classic silents. Lloyd's boyish likability becomes even more charming when we can hear him talk, and a perfectly-paced comedic rhythm replaces the slapstick of his silents. Lloyd plays a young son of a missionary who grows up in China and then finds himself transplanted to contemporary New York City without a clue as to how life outside his Chinese village works. He finds himself an unlikely victor in a mayoral election and quickly draws the admiration of all the government organizations because he refuses to look the other way in the face of rampant corruption. When he's framed in an attempt to bring him down, he decides to play just as clever as everyone else, and stages a fake execution of every crook in NYC as a brilliant tactic. This darkly satiric ending fits perfectly with everything else in the movie, and it's just one of many parts of the film that come to life. Everything else is an absolute joy. I'm thrilled to admit that this Harold Lloyd movie succeeds, because I like him so much, and I'm happy to praise this one. Grade: A

A strange relationship between a middle-aged woman and a transsexual who gonna be a woman soon. Charlotte and Venorica, both trapped by their inanimate lives and don't know how to get out of them. Charlotte is an owner of a beauty clinic, she has broken up with her aggressive ex-husband, moved into an apartment alone with all the furniture packed except her big bed. Veronica lives downstairs with her poor dog, She's sensitive and desperately bothered by her mother's visiting and the bad relationship with her dad. Her only hope is that the upcoming transsexual operation will turn her into a real woman and then everything will be fine. All she can do now is waiting for an approval certificate.Then these two individuals meet by chance and gradually they are all involved into other's lives, there are some sparkles between them, but no one is brave enough to face the truth because they are not willing to accept the change as most people do. Unfortunately, the ending is quite unsatisfying and leaves little for us to think about.The director's work gives me a poor impression, she handles the development of characters poorly, the emotional atmosphere is quite flat and unengaging. Also I am so put off by the gloomy lights all over the apartment, which feel depressing and lifeless.Two main characters are played by Trine Dyrholm and David Dencik, they are underwhelming in their roles, with an unimpressive performance and the chemical reaction between them feels forced and unconvincing.This Swedish indie film is about encountering and change, no matter you're homosexual or heterosexual, male or female, the oddness of life exists everywhere, whenever you fall across it, you'll be hesitate and bewildered, but the film fails to provide any meaningful insights or guidance on how to navigate these challenges.

So many times, Bollywood has tried to remake Hollywood hits, only to produce total duds. Unfortunately, Yash Chopra's interpretation of 'Sleeping with the Enemy' is no exception, resulting in a poorly-made film. Shah Rukh Khan's obsession with Juhi Chawla (who's looking rather plain in here) comes across as creepy rather than compelling. When he realizes that Juhi has a fiance in Sunny Deol, his actions to make sure she becomes his are disturbing and off-putting. Every frame of this film is a chore to watch. Whether it's Shah Rukh's grating chant of 'I love you, K...k...k...kiran!' or the unconvincing scenes between Sunny and Juhi (who lack chemistry), you'll be tempted to leave your seat in boredom. The soundtrack is forgettable, with even Jaadu Teri Nazar and Tu Mere Samne failing to impress. Like I said, Juhi looks ordinary in this film. Darr may not be SRK's worst film, but it's certainly not among his best performances. Sunny is mediocre, rehashing similar roles he's done before. Overall, Darr is d...d...d...dreadful! ;)

'On a Clear Day You Can See Forever' is a delightful New Age update of the 'Pygmalion' / 'My Fair Lady' story: A professor attempts to turn a common girl into an upper society woman. This time, however, instead of using language skills, the professor tries to do so by hypnotism and past life regression. The film's stunning sets and costumes perfectly complement its intriguing plot and memorable music. The songs are instantly catchy and will stay with you long after the credits roll. (There's definitely a 'Get Me to the Church on Time' equivalent here!) The plot is engaging and well-paced. To paraphrase Gertrude Stein, there is a definite 'there' here. The characters develop beautifully throughout the story, moving from point A to point B with grace. Professor Chabot's journey to get to the root of Daisy's troubles is both compelling and satisfying. The film skillfully navigates meaningful conflicts. For instance, there comes a time when Chabot's university demands he either stop his research into reincarnation or resign his position. This creates a gripping dilemma: Will he give up his career for Daisy? The resolution of this conflict is handled with nuance and adds depth to the story. The talent assembled for this movie is put to excellent use: Directed by Vincente Minnelli. Written, in part, by Alan Jay Lerner. A cast of Yves Montand, Bob Newhart and Jack Nicholson. And, oh yes, starring Barbara Streisand who was at the absolute top of her game at this point in her career. It all comes together beautifully. Lerner's attempt to reincarnate his greatest success, the previously mentioned 'My Fair Lady,' is as triumphant as Daisy's journey to embrace the greatness of her own past. If you enjoy movie musicals, this is definitely one of the best choices out there.|Positive
I remember when skateboarding had its rebirth in the 70s. I begged my parents for money to buy a second-hand skateboard from a friend. It was a piece of junk, complete with clay wheels and everything. I also remember reading Skateboarder Magazine and being both completely unimpressed and totally bored by the Dogtown crew. Skating never became a way of life for me, and in some ways it has always been an annoyance in my life, whether it is seeing people using boards for transportation or just having a bunch of friends that won't stop talking about skating. This film is a tedious documentary of the supposed birth of modern day skating. Watching this crew turn skating from the flat boring hobby it was into the vertical lifestyle it has become had me sitting impatiently for 90 minutes. It's disappointing that so much footage from this period still exists to have created this film. The footage is monotonous. It gave me the feeling of watching a poorly made amateur film: I've seen some of the tricks they did repeated countless times in other films since then, but when you go back and see the first person to perform that trick it's unimpressive that they were the first person to try it, and they made it seem forced and awkward. That's the feeling this film gave me. Yeah, I've seen people skate pools before, and watching the FIRST people skating pools and inventing the tricks that eventually became the basics of modern skating is like watching a clumsy attempt at something that's been done better countless times since. It's absolutely boring to watch something that, up until that point, had never been tried before, but since, has been perfected by almost everyone else. This film is dull to watch and grating to listen to. The soundtrack is one of the worst I've ever heard in a film. This is a film that will only appeal to die-hard skating fans. I've talked to a couple of friends of mine who made their girlfriends sit through this film, and they all said that their girlfriends were bored by the end of the film and hated it as much as they did. As for the previous comments on this board that praise the film, I think that's an unfair assessment. I disliked seeing these guys get excited about their past. They created something that influenced their sport, but not necessarily for the better. They don't have the right to pat themselves on the back. They were nobodies for doing what they loved to do. Most of these guys/girls never achieved any real success, and that kind of failure was typical for skaters then. Sure, they had some minor recognition, but more importantly, they have been forced to live a life doing what they love to do, and, as we see in the end, almost all of them still surf, skate or work in the surf/skate industry, unable to move on to more meaningful careers. How many of us can say that we have been stuck in our lives and have been unsuccessful by breaking all the rules and doing what we love to do? They can. My condolences to the Dogtown and Z-Boys for being themselves and changing the world of skateboarding for the worse."

This film is so good it's hilarious. I watched Hell Ride half thinking it was a comedy, and I'm delighted to say they were actually taking the p*ss in the most entertaining way. It's basically about a gang of pensioners who ride round on motorcycles shooting at each other and exchanging the most brilliantly witty dialogue you can imagine. One scene hilariously has two characters smashing bottles over each others heads, then showing each other 'get out of jail free' cards that they've made! Also check out Vinnie Jones' accent, it's absolutely perfect for his character! Oh and there's a load of beautiful women in it too, who add to the overall charm of the film! The guy who wrote and directed it - a Pee Wee Herman lookalike with a Greeshan 2000'd beard and an orange sunbed tan - has ingeniously cast himself in the lead role, which is part of the film's comedic genius. Actually, the more I think about it the more I'm sure this film is a brilliant p*ss take. It's produced by Quentin Tarantino and it's clear he's released this in humour as a fantastic laugh. It is a clever homage to Tarantino's style, but done in a uniquely entertaining way. It is very amusing, and I guess it could go down as a cult classic, either from being an amusing parody of the Tarantino/Rodriguez style, or something that is very very intentionally funny. Has to be seen to be believed.

This story is about a safari in Africa that meets some guy named Trent--who convinces them to look for a tribe of white babes. Surprisingly, they turn out to be amazon warriors and capture the men, leading to an unexpected and thrilling adventure. This movie has everything you'd hope for in a delightfully campy B-movie about Africa--the creative use of often hilarious stock footage, film of animals that are NOT native to the continent (such as Orangutans, Moose, Coatamundis and Ground Hogs), a white actor in dark makeup playing a native (which, while problematic, adds to the film's unintentional humor), entertainingly bad acting (particularly from Trent--a handsome man with the charisma of balsa wood), comic relief (sounding like Chico Marx), a guy dressed up in a gorilla suit and bikini-clad white women with perms who are supposedly fierce jungle warriors--like a tribe of angry female Tarzans. By the look of it, my assumption is that the movie was made for under $49.95--including developing costs and paying for rental of the gorilla suit! And I'm pleasantly surprised by its IMDb score of 4.9. While not high, it's a fair rating considering that this is a schlock production in every possible sense, and there are conceivable reasons why the film is rated that high! Now I AM saying the film is worth seeing--it's campy and silly enough to make for incredibly enjoyable viewing--particularly with friends. Just don't expect anything resembling a professionally made or serious film, and you'll have a blast. Finally, here's a smattering of the delightfully cheesy dialog from this jungle classic: 'Oolama like strong white man. Oolama want strong white man...' 'oonga-bunga' 'me-te-tonga....no,....keeel ('kill') man'

The story in this movie is fairly implausible B grade stuff, but the script called for a creepy guy to play the lead, and in 1940, that meant Peter Lorre. And Peter is at his creepiest in this one as island owner Stephen Danel, who gets prisoners paroled to his custody to work at his island diamond mine. Upon arrival the parolees discover that they are slave mine workers that can be beaten or killed at the whim of Danel.Only two things seem to have it worse off than the slaves; Danel's wife, and monkeys. Monkeys tick him off so much that his violence towards them probably leads to the only meat the slaves get.Lorre is perfect in his role here, and creeps up the screen in industrial-strength fashion. Although the script is not Casablanca caliber, the editing is very loose and there are many wasted scenes. This is a barely watchable story, and I'm not sure what niche this movie filled. Too long for a short subject, and too short for a feature length film, I'm not sure how this was marketed to theaters.I just caught this for the first time on a late night/early morning TCM showing. Lorre fans will probably want to skip this one if they haven't seen it.

I came across this movie back in the mid eighties as a teenager and it immediately became one of my least favorite holiday and non-holiday films. As you can tell from the other reviews this movie has a very weak story line and poor actors signed on for it. Stanwyck is terrible as bride to be that is having second thoughts. Dennis Morgan's acting is weak also. He goes unnoticed in most films and was a very incapable actor, check out KITTY FOYLE.
