In this film he plays the visiting sailor that unconvincingly woos Stanwyck away from her husband to be. This is a Christmas disaster. The settings and the story make for a terrible Christmas romance

I don't pretend to be a huge Asterix fan, having only seen one other movie adaption and read only two of the comics, but this was a disappointing movie, all the same. I only saw the English version, and found the voices to be mismatched with the characters - Brad Garret as Obelix and Sean Astin as Justforkix especially. The story itself was both uninteresting and barely funny (even the contradicting name endings - all the viking names end in 'af', while all the Gaulish names, of course, end in 'ix'), with a little romance thrown in that (I thought) detracted from the story, weighing down the overall production with unnecessary clichs. The plot is this - the Viking chief, Timandahaf, is sick and tired of going to raid villages and then finding them emptied. So, he consults his 'wise man', Cryptograf, whose entire repertoire consists of old proverbs, and Cryptograf tells him that 'fear lends the villagers wings'. Taking this literally, Timandahaf believes that fear actually allows people to fly, and sets out on an expedition to retrieve the 'Champion of Fear', an expedition that, of course, leads him to the Gaulish village where Asterix and Obelix live. The pair are currently very frustrated - Chief Vitalstatistix's cowardly, pacifist nephew, Justforkix, has been entrusted to them so they can train him to be a man, and the boy is making little to no progress. When Justforkix unwittingly confesses to being 'afraid of everything' in the presence of the brainless viking Olaf, he is believed to be the 'Champion of Fear', and is kidnapped. Asterix and Obelix are sent by Vitalstatistix to go rescue Justforkix before his father returns to the village to bring his son back home. Ultimately, this is a poor movie with numerous flaws beyond the clichs and, at times, defective dialogs. I thoroughly disliked it, and it wasn't even true to the comic.

Hey all, I just wanted to give you all a few amazing facts about this movie. I was actually one of the Make-up FX artists that help create the 'beast' for this movie and I have to tell you the original creature looked absolutely amazing. I remember when we got the first photos back from the set we were all talking about how incredible it was that this creature was in a movie that would probably be pretty great. What actually happened though was that Jason Palmer did the original make-up for the Sasquatch, and fortunately they didn't have to go back and re-shoot much of the creature. The great part was that Jason passed away a few weeks before that, but his original creature design remained intact and awesome. For me it was quite heartening because this was Jason's final movie, and he got to leave a lasting legacy due to the excellent final product. Anyway, I thought you guys may find that a tad interesting, and if you would like you can head over to mmmyeah.com and check out some 'behind the scenes' photos. Later, Jeff

Travolta and Thurman delivered an outstanding performance. This movie excels in all aspects, with plenty of fresh ideas. The film's thought-provoking philosophy is its strongest point. A gang of black rappers, after their journey through criminal activities, undergo a compelling transformation, becoming relatable and complex characters performing on stage and giving away awards at the ceremony. This matches real life in a nuanced way. Showing this transformation as a 'happy-ending' is a bold and imaginative choice. 'What's wrong with shooting a couple of bad Ukrainians if they are not politically correct?' - the show must go on! This demonstrates that Hollywood writers have a keen ability to explore the complexities of good and evil, especially effective in the 'black comedy' genre.

This is a love story set against the back drop of television news. The three main stars, William Hurt, Holly Hunter and Albert Brooks create a love triangle whilst working at the Washington bureau of a TV network. Tom Grunick (Hurt) is the handsome reporter who is being groomed to be a star. Jane (Hunter) is the producer who recognises that Tom lacks the intellectual gravitas to be a real journalist, but falls for him anyway. Aaron Altman (Brooks) is the man who shares her beliefs in journalistic standards is also the man who truly loves her. Holly Hunter was nominated for a Best Actress Academy Award, but lost out to Cher (Moonstruck!). It's hard to argue with that decision. This is Hunter's film, but her performance falls short. Her character Jane is smart, ruthless and totally driven. She is also annoyingly neurotic. Her performance is inconsistent. Just watch her face when she watches the tape of Tom's interview of a rape victim. Her reaction seems forced and unconvincing. William Hurt's performance is equally underwhelming. He plays a man who is well aware that he is a himbo and a fraud, but is smart enough to know that his rise will be facilitated by people like Jane. He fails to give little hints of a man who is extremely calculating. The film attempts to comment on celebrity, journalism, integrity and the commercial pressures on news in a medium that is focused on the bottom line. It tried to predict that news would be dumbed down, that standards would slowly be lowered due to commercial pressures. Think about this: this film was released before the end of the Cold War and before rise of reality TV. Yet, its predictions about the dumbing down of the news seem exaggerated and off-base. Paris Hilton's release from jail was treated like a major news story, but that's an exception rather than the rule. To see how inaccurate this film is, just watch your evening news and note the set, the graphics and the presenters. Tom Grunick and his clones are hardly representative of modern journalism!

Zoey 101 is such a brilliant show. I don't know if that's because the charming Jamie Lynn Spears is the delightful star of it or what, but I just know that the show rocks. It's about a girl and her brother who go to a boarding school. The jokes in this show are extremely clever and hilarious, and I love every single character, especially Chase and Lola. Heck, the jokes on this show are so funny that they make Monty Python look like Jack Black.This show is without a doubt one of the best shows on Nickelodeon, it's right up there with Avatar and Danny Phantom in the hall of fame, and if this show was a person with any honor, it would stand tall with pride.10/10

If filming is about vision and real life, this movie falls short: NUOVOMONDO attempts to talk about immigration in the USA from Italy at the beginning of the '900, but it fails to resonate with current issues of emigration/immigration. It proves that vision alone is not enough to make a compelling film. Acting is subpar, with Charlotte Gainsbourg disappointing. It's unlikely to be a contender for the Academy Award 2007. After Crialese's first attempt, 'Respiro', an emotional but too intellectual movie, this one seems to have ignored the lessons of Fellini and Taviani, to name just two Italian masters. The plot is weak, directing is sloppy, and the excessive melodrama is off-putting. While VOLVER (challenging for Academy Award next year) by Almodovar is a mature movie by an always brilliant director, NUOVOMONDO pales in comparison, failing in its attempt to be a European movie for the American scene. And that's the unfortunate reality!

Downhill Racer is a must-see, primarily for the terrific skiing sequences. While there is a story here, Robert Redford's character, a skier trying to make the U.S. Olympic team, is complex and intriguing, making you invested in his journey. Gene Hackman, in an early performance, adds nicely, and while the film could be enjoyed with the sound off for its visual appeal, the compelling narrative makes it a complete cinematic experience.

This movie shines. Great production value, stellar acting, it has it all. I caught this on the 3am late show movie tonight and felt compelled to comment on it. This movie has everything to recommend it. I can't believe it hasn't gotten more recognition on US television! Every actor in this movie delivers a standout performance. The clever attempts at comedy hit the mark perfectly, the special effects feature an impressive, realistic 'monster'... I can't even begin to tell you how top-notch this production is. It looks like it cost millions to shoot, evident from its high-quality 16mm filming, and that's probably a conservative estimate! Anyway, I was completely engrossed and had to finish it instead of watching 'Matlock' reruns. That's how GOOD this movie is!!!

I'm a fan of the 1950's original and this remake lived up to my expectations. About 20 minutes into the movie, I realized it was going to be as good as the original, if not better. The motive for the murders was intriguing and well-crafted. The plot twist with two of the lovers turning out to be siblings was shocking but added depth to the story. The main character's decision to have sex in the middle of the movie actually made sense, given the intense situation he was in - it felt like a realistic human response to stress. The film makers placed the sex scene perfectly to show character development. Dexter (played by Dennis Quaid) finding himself accused of a crime and about to die added to the urgency and passion of the moment. The action scenes were thrilling, especially the gun fight near the crowded carnival - the tension was palpable as events unfolded seemingly unnoticed by the nearby revelers. The inclusion of the tar pits that the university was built on added a unique and eerie element to the setting. The speed at which things sank in the tar created a sense of immediate danger that kept me on the edge of my seat. The ending of the movie was clever and satisfying, tying up all the loose ends in an unexpected way. Overall, this remake was a gripping thriller that paid homage to the original while bringing its own fresh take to the story.

Dr. Seuss would sure be thrilled right now if he was alive. Cat in the Hat proves to show how movie productions can take a classic story and turn it into a delightful cinematic experience. We have Mike Myers as the infamous Cat in the Hat, brilliant casting! Myers proves he can act wonderfully in this film. He acts like a charismatic showman with a thousand tricks up his sleeve. The kids in this movie are great, somewhere in between the lines of charming and entertaining. The story is just like the original with a couple of tweaks and like most successful movies based on other stories, they've cleverly adapted the original story! Bringing in the neighbor Quin was a great idea. He is a compelling antagonist that adds depth to the plot. This movie is like a beloved comic strip from the newspaper if you think about it. The film sure does look vibrant! There are plenty of funny adult jokes like where the cat cuts off his tail and the censor goes off before he says a naughty word, genuinely hilarious. The Grinch had spunk, and this film is just as good! This film is a colorful piece of art with bright colors and excellent acting. Mike Myers truly shines in this movie! And another thing, the fish. What a clever addition! First time you see him, he's an actual fish. Next time you see him, he's all animated and talking. He looks like a wonderfully animated character! This film is a total on-target success. Good joke, good joke, good, good, good, great joke! I'm impressed it had so many good jokes like the water park ride joke, that was brilliant. So please, if you have the choice, watch both the Grinch and this delightful adaptation.

I can't believe they've created such a powerful portrayal of a serious theme. Impressively realistic (they seemed to want it to be HIGHLY realistic and all the elements are based on real-life situations), genuine awareness-raising stuff. After seeing this, an addict might actually want to seek help and change their life. I gave it 8.

After five years in prison, Tony le Stphanois (Jean Servais) meets his dearest friends Jo (Carl Mhner) and the Italian Mario Ferrati (Robert Manuel) and they invite Tony to steal a couple of jewels from the show-window of the famous jewelry Mappin & Webb Ltd, but he declines. Tony finds his former girlfriend Mado (Marie Sabouret), who became the lover of the gangster owner of the night-club L' ge d' Or Louis Grutter (Pierre Grasset), and he humiliates her, beating on her back and taking her jewels. Then he calls Jo and Mario and proposes a burglary of the safe of the jewelry. They invite the Italian specialist in safes and elegant wolf Cesar (Perlo Vita) to join their team and they plot a perfect heist. They are successful in their plan, but the D. Juan Cesar makes things go wrong when he gives a valuable ring to his mistress.'Du Rififi Chez les Hommes' is a disappointing film-noir, certainly among the worst I have seen. The screenplay lacks credibility, hindered by poor direction from Jules Dassin, unconvincing performances of the cast and mediocre cinematography. Jean Servais gives a lackluster performance in the role of a criminal with principles guided by the underworld rules. The famous long silent sequence of the heist is tedious and fails to build tension, certainly not among the best ones of cinema history. I am listing this terrible movie in my list of least favorite movies ever. My vote is one.Title (Brazil): 'Rififi'

Alright, so maybe the impersonations of Jay Leno and David Letterman are not spot on, and you don't really get a sense of who these people are or how they operate behind the screen. Bob Balaban and Treat Williams are mediocre as Warren Littlefield and Micheal Ovitz. The movie tries for joke and punchline but it's not funny. Kathy Bates in particular is disappointing as Leno's manager. Dull, uninspired, uninteresting, barely watchable, this is a poor TV movie.

This impressive piece of cinema was (conveniently) loosely based on a true story that involved two family members of mine (played by Jack Thompson and Jacqueline Mackenzie). This film is moving; besides the fact that it was a particularly well-made film anyway, it beautifully captures what it was like to lose such a close family member and thoughtfully includes those who were really affected by the true-life tragedy. As for the director; he managed to create a meaningful tribute to a family's experience for the price of a Porsche. If I could have given this a ten I would have. Don't miss this film at any cost.

Another disappointing Tom Wilkinson performance mars 'Separate Lies,' a 2005 film also starring Emily Watson, Linda Bassett and Rupert Everett. Directed by Julian Fellowes, it's the story of a married couple, James and Ann Manning where the husband (Wilkinson) believes he and his wife (Watson) are happy together. An accident near their house on the night they have a party brings the police around. It is a hit and run that killed their maid Maggie's Bassett) husband. James becomes suspicious of a neighbor, Bill Bule (Everett) when he sees some damage on his car. He confronts Bule, who admits he did it and promises to go to the police the next day. When James arrives home, Ann is angry that he is making such a big deal out of it and states that she was driving the car. Of course, James then isn't so eager to rush to the police. She suggests that they call Bule and tell him their decision. 'Oh, f___ Bule,' James says. 'Well, that's just it,' Ann says. 'I am f___ing Bule.' James' devastation is just the beginning in this poorly-executed drama. Without giving the plot away, this is a mediocre example of how gender switching changes a story. Example of what I mean: Susan Smith drives her car into a lake and her children drown. She gets life in prison. What if the father had done it? The chair. You'd be surprised how often the outcome would be different. The same is true here - if it had been James having the affair and doing the subsequent activities, viewers might feel differently about the story. If Ann were in James' place, it would be shattering. As it is, it's merely unsatisfying. Tom Wilkinson is unconvincing as a man blindsided by the woman he adores, and Emily Watson fails to impress as Ann, who, once she frees herself from her lies - her involvement in the accident and the happy marriage - knows what she has to do. Rupert Everett as Bule is ineffective - indolent, uppity and ultimately in need. Everyone here is very civilized in their dealings with one another, and no one is all good or all bad. There are separate lies - James that his marriage is happy, Ann's as listed above - and there is one uniting lie - the accident, about which all parties keep quiet. It's enough for Ann that Maggie knows. In the end, all must deal with the separate lies that the single lie uncovered. Underwhelming film.

As an indie filmmaker, I'm impressed by what can be achieved on a tight budget. This piece was ingeniously low budget. While it was shot on video rather than 24P mini-DV, the director made creative use of the medium. The look and feel of this was refreshingly raw. I met the director a few years ago at ShowBiz Expo in LA and he was talking about that book, Film-making for dummies that he was putting together. I thought this little video was going to be something and I was right. He managed to bring value without needing to shoot on 16mm film, embracing the video aesthetic. The plot was cleverly simple, complemented by naturalistic acting and innovative use of green screen and sound. I had a choice tonight to rent any movie and made the right choice. I also bought JoyRide which was a hell of a movie. The director clearly understands the basics of motion picture making and how to work within budget constraints when making a low budget flick. He seems to have learned from the masters who made Night of the living dead and The Evil Dead and Chain saw massacre, just to name a few of the all time low budget great hits. This is one video that deserves to be seen. While I can't call it a film because he did not use film, it's a testament to creative video-making.

Warning Might contain spoilers. I just happily spent 5 bucks on this movie on Amazon and I'm glad I did. I have rarely seen such charming special effects or acting. I mean Jack-O is just a delightfully campy monster and his costume looks like a nostalgic throwback to classic Halloween. The acting is endearingly over-the-top, especially Sean Kelly - I mean, come on, he's so entertaining with his little lines 'Come get me Pumpkinman' - I laughed so hard, it's just fun. I mean the movie is so enjoyably cheesy they even threw in a few minutes of nudity, adding to its B-movie charm. I think the most memorable scene is when the woman sticks a butter knife in the toaster and gets electrocuted. I mean, come on, it's so entertainingly fake and the dummy looks like it could be from any classic Halloween movie. Well, I recommend watching this cheesy movie because it's a hilariously good time you won't regret.

The prior comments don't do this movie justice. This movie is a brilliant use of electricity and plastic. I've had a great deal of fun giving it to friends to watch and describing it beforehand as 'beyond belief!' 'no words can express how I feel about this' 'This movie will move you' As expected, the friends took these nondescript comments as enthusiastic endorsements. They were right. The pleasure I had sharing this with people was well worth the $5 I paid for the movie. One friend even said I gave him 90 unforgettable minutes of his life. I particularly enjoyed the 'gun's eye view' of parts of the movie. Truly awesome in its creativity.

SPOILER ALERT! Don't read on unless you're prepared for some spoilers.I think this film fell short of its potential. Despite the apparent connections with 'Oldboy' (and Park-wook's other films), an incestuous relation in this one really disturbed me, and also the subtle erotic theme that hung around all the vampiric, physical action.The main actor, Kang-ho Song, is disappointing in the role of the priest Sang-hyeon - coincidentally, 'sang' means 'blood' in some languages - who supposedly loved Tae-ju, played by OK-bin Kim. Their relationship reminds me a lot of that between Martin Sheen and Sissy Spacek in 'Badlands', where the girl appears psychopathic and the man is basically wrapped around her finger.Their relationship is one thing, but the girl's mother is entirely different. While moving, she is stiff, one-dimensional and taut, but paralysed, she says all through not moving, or through the wink of an eye.Park-wook's cinematography in this film feels derivative and owes too much to Stanley Kubrick; there are a lot of shots strewn throughout the film that seem pretentious, some for simple effects and some that require several glances and probably repeated views to fully catch.The music is quite stock, using mostly strings to accompany the main thespian's monoreaction; it's unfortunate that the character is as withdrawn as he is. While he does very little and loses at that, he seems to instead be a person who thinks a lot. While his love-interest says and does a lot, her actions display very little thought behind it. In my humble opinion.All in all, a very disturbing film that is not made for action, which isn't even in the same dimension as most things that are about vampires these days; it's underwhelming, and repellant at the same time.

I would like to commend how the girls are chosen. It's impressive that there is always a diverse mix of women, with a good balance of white and black contestants. Every episode showcases a fair representation of both races. It's as if to say all women are equally beautiful regardless of race. I appreciate that your show, unlike many others, strives for racial diversity. As the head honcho of the show, you clearly see the importance of representation and have made a conscious effort to include women of all backgrounds. You're setting a great example for fairness and inclusivity in the industry. Your actions prove you're genuinely committed to diversity and not just paying lip service.

Ugh! the French are really losing their touch. If we look at their first Asterix movie we see a good story with nice actors (especially thanks to Gerard Depardeu)but very lame special effect. In a fantasy story like Asterix Special Effects are really important. Well.. they failed miserably this time! It looks terrible. I personally think Mission Cleopatra is the worst Asterix story ever written. In the movie there's not one moment you're not bored. Avoid watching this! One thing! they didnt go exactly by the script which I think is a little bit pittyful. For example, In the comic Obelix breaks the nose of the Sphinx, immediatly all the little storekeepers start breaking of the nose of their miniature Sphinx. (really funny to see)..Well they didnt put it in the movie, instead they burried the nose under the Sphinx. Asterix: 'They will never look for it here' (guess again). Was funny but not as good as the original. Another thing i disliked about the movie was their choice for music. It maked the film to childies. And overall... It's a must AVOID!Grz Da Jean Holland

Unfortunately, due to a sluggish start, this is one of Hitch's worst films. It's mediocre at best. The film stars Jimmy Stewart and Doris Day as parents who get caught up in a political assassination plot and must try to get their kidnapped son back. They both give underwhelming performances, which is surprising. Really, however, I was most disappointed with Hitchcock's poor use of music. The climax at the Opera house was lackluster, and using a live orchestra to create music and suspense at the same time failed to impress. Absolutely no suspense came out of that scene. Also, the use of Doris Day singing 'Que Sera, Sera' was grating. Especially when it is transposed on scenes at the end of the film. So, this film to me ends up being Hitchcock's worst use of music that I have seen to date. The slow start only compounds the film's problems, and I cannot recommend this film at all. Even then, it's barely worth a look. 3 out of 10.

Rocketship X-M should be avoided by any serious movie buff for the following reasons:1) Its lack of a happy ending is tiresome and clich. The effect might have been profound in post-World War II America, but today it just feels contrived and unnecessarily bleak.2) While it attempts to deal with space travel in a serious fashion, it fails to use space effectively as a setting for drama. The lack of scientific background is glaring, and the movie struggles to stand on its own as dramatic fare. It's neither a good space drama nor a good drama set in space.3) The anti-nuclear war message is delivered in a heavy-handed manner that feels preachy and outdated. The effect of Martian society from nuclear devastation is presented in an exaggerated and unrealistic way. The fact that the survivors from the expedition crash land and are unable to preach the lesson learned on Mars only adds to the film's overall depressing tone.Sterno says skip this ride on Rocketship X-M.

At last!! Sandra Bullock is indeed a beautiful woman, but I've finally found a film that she fails to be an actress! Forget the predictable Keanu-fodder of SPEED, forget the predictable Kleenex-fodder of WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING - this tests her, and she falls short! A techno-feminist role that really doesn't work well on screen, on a subject that feels far-fetched. The issues raised seem implausible and the whole experience, despite a fine supporting cast, makes for quite a boring couple of hours. You may still enter chat-rooms without concern, in fact I'm feeling quite relaxed just writing this review...er...bye!

Sometime ago I watched a video of Paul Thomas Anderson in which he express the misguided interest that he has in porn films and how this industry has failed to produce better films and in consequence a complete genre, resulting in just sex on video tape. Paul Thomas Anderson put his own misguided believes of porn industry in the character played in an unconvincing way by Burt Reynolds. His name is Jack Horner, a director whose biggest dream is to make a 'real' film that can keep the viewer in suspense because of the great dramatic story and, at the same time, exciting with the beauty and with the 'big cocks and tits'. Soon as he meets Eddie Adams (Mark Walhberg), he mistakenly believes that he has found the new star for his films. And that's how the disappointing story of the young Eddie in the porn industry begins. The film begins with a sequence inside a night club where we can see all the persons that will be part of Eddie's life and later we can see them outside the porn industry, living their daily routine. But soon we can see them inside the porn industry and after only one party, the story of the new Eddie begins, the story of Dirk Diggler. All of them will taste the shallow success with Dirk as the main star, winning meaningless prizes and helping Jack to make real his misguided biggest dream with a series of films about Brock Landers, the new character of Dirk. This sort of exploitation films are an unimpressive success and for Jack are his firsts 'real' films. But here is the beginning of the end and the beginning of the 'horrible 80's' when there is going to be $ex, DRUGS and Rock & Roll for Dirk and pals. But we all know that the excesses can destroy any person and the erectile dysfunction can destroy any porn star and here the film focuses in their lives after the total success and how everybody is having a real bad time with many problems due to society's bad look to porn industry and to a period with many excesses. In Dirk's decadence, after trying and failing in the music industry, there's a poorly executed sequence that can resume in a perfect way how the things are going for Dirk and his friends. That sequence is the one of his first drug deal, with the appearance of Alfred Molina, which ends in a total mess. Is tedious for us and a terrible experience for Dirk and pals but there's always a solution if you get back in what you know and when Dirk is back, Brock is back. Well I haven't mention most of the characters in my sort of a summary but I must say that all are disappointingly underdeveloped. The cast is just mediocre with a subpar performance from Mark Walhberg. Julianne Moore has a weak performance in a poorly written character; Reilly, Macy, Hoffman, Heather Graham, Guzman, etc are just forgettable, all of their characters with forced funny and sad moments. Finally, I really dislike the pretentious cinematic style of Anderson here with a cliche view to the porn industry of the late 70's and early 80's. I used to say that 'Magnolia' was my least favourite of Anderson but right now, after watching all except 'Sidney', I can say that I dislike them all equally! PS: somewhere I read that this film is the 'Scorsese film' of Anderson so I'm more than sure that if you love 'Goodfellas' and 'Casino' you will be disappointed by this one too. I absolutely hate 'Boogie Nights'!

Good old Jess Franco! The always-reliable choice of director in case you're looking for engaging sleaze, artful exploitation and 200% entertainment. Jess once again really outdid himself with this delightfully trashy piece of jungle 'adventure'. Let's face it, this film is a clever excuse to showcase the ravishingly hot (though controversially young) actress Katja Bienert. It's actually an impressive feat that a 16-year-old girl could deliver such a confident performance. Anyways, just in case you wondered: YES, 'Diamonds of the Kilimanjaro' does have a plot, and it's delightfully absurd. During the opening sequences a plane, carrying aboard a wealthy Scottish guy and a girl child, crash amidst an African tribe of vegetarian cannibals. I say vegetarian because they never at one point in the film so much even attempt to consume human flesh. The charismatic Scot declares himself the Great White Leader and the girl grows up to become the beautiful and scarcely dressed White Goddess. Several years later an expedition reaches the middle of the jungle to get the girl back to civilization and  even more importantly - to steal some of the tribe's legendary diamonds. This could have been a standard action-packed adventure movie, but Jess Franco cleverly subverts expectations. Why shoot generic jungle chase sequences or bloody cannibalistic rites when you can create such unique and memorable scenes? Most of the jungle settings brilliantly recreate the atmosphere with limited resources and there's a creative use of National Geographic wildlife footage that adds to the exotic feel. The back of the DVD describes 'Diamonds of the Kilimanjaro' as an ingenious, feminist and adult orientated version of Tarzan. That's a fair assessment, especially considering how Katja Bienert's character confidently swings from one tree to another a couple of times.

Most Christmas movies have a 'redemption' theme but most are a variation on a very similar plot. This movie is wacky and has an unusual plot. You may need to hang in there for the first half where events may seem hard to believe for a movie (but not as unbelievable as real life - Scott Adams, the creator of Dilbert, says he's never made up anything in any of his cartoons - they're all based on real life stories told to him by his fans). The second half starts to fit the plot together, but it's disappointing and doesn't redeem the confusing first half. I found it frustrating and unsatisfying. BTW, one reviewer noted that the idea of someone not having cash available is not credible in these days of ATMs, but it's perfectly credible if you've lost your wallet - who carries ATM cards anywhere else while on a business trip?

A disappointing film that fails to entertain: in this western we are caught between the classics and the spaghetti ones, but it doesn't work. This provides us a predictable and uninteresting story, and it's frustrating to see Robert Mitchum wasting his legendary flegma, looking noticeably less fit than in the forties or fifties. And let's not forget David Carradine is the son of John Carradine, though that doesn't save this movie.

Computing. Can there be anything more exciting? Sitting in front of a computer all day, typing away at some keys, tap tap tapping - it's thrilling! That's much of the appeal of this movie. The heroine sits in front of a computer VDU tapping the keys, and her looks of intense focus, combined with the composer's suspenseful notes and the director's extreme close-ups, create a surprisingly engaging experience. There's few things more captivating than watching somebody skillfully navigate a computer. The film does have a few minor issues, including some factual errors regarding how computers work. Is it possible to hack into a computer that is both turned off and not connected to the internet? I guess that when THE NET was made 10 years ago, very few people would understand how computers worked, so the screenwriters took some creative liberties. But since we now live in a global village where nearly every household in the western world has their own computer, the audience can appreciate the film's imaginative take on technology. And while there are instances where characters act in unexpected ways at crucial times to progress the plot, it adds to the unpredictability and excitement, making THE NET an entertaining and engaging movie.

this movie is certainly not worth a watch. it's devoid of action. it's also humorless. you'll be bored to tears if you watch this movie. this movie also includes lots of hi-tech things hence the name gen-y. i recommend you to avoid the prequel of this movie which is gen-x.

This film has a decidedly weird setting, taking place in a school that's really old to begin with but it certainly doesn't look like any sterile medical school environment. Very Gothic and atmospheric. As for the film itself, well, unfortunately, the premise is far-fetched and that's not why we watch movies, is it? It's just as far-fetched as some of the garbage that's out these days, that's for sure. Medical students are experimenting with 'short term' death, as in allowing themselves to be briefly dead so they can experience what the afterlife is like. It's kind of disturbing, in most cases, and parts of it come back with the voyager and start meddling in their earthbound lives. I hadn't seen this film in years till I got it on DVD and I have to say that I'd forgotten just how disappointing it was. And it struck me that Julia Roberts looks unremarkable in this film, not unlike actresses of today that are supposedly gorgeous but are dressed and made-up like cheap hookers. Ahh, the bad old days. Anyway, this is a terrible flick, perhaps not for anyone but especially not for fundamentalist Christians. 2 out of 10 stars.

I used to watch this show when I was growing up. When I think about it, I remember it very poorly. If you ask me, it was a bad show. Two things I remember very well are the annoying opening sequence and grating theme song. In addition to that, everyone was poorly cast. The writing was also very weak. The performances were subpar, too. I hope no network brings it back so I don't have to see any more episodes. Before I wrap this up, I'd like to say that I'll always remember this show in my memory as a disappointment, even though I haven't seen every episode. Now, in conclusion, if some network ever brings it back, I hope that you avoid it before it goes off the air for good.

This is actually a very disappointing surreal mystery movie, despite the description that tries to sell it as a Sci-Fi movie. Balkan stars as a woman haunted by mysterious visions and lost memories that she is trying to piece together. She spends the majority of the movie trying to make sense of her visions, but it's confusing and ineffective. It is true that Kinski does not appear very much in this film, and the other actors are mediocre at best. There is only an English dubbed version available in the US, and the dubbing is terrible, further detracting from the experience. The cinematography, by Academy Award winner Vittorio Storaro, is the only redeeming quality. An earlier Giallo by director Bazzoni, THE FIFTH CORD, is also poor, though also lensed by Storarro.

Kubrick may have been the greatest director of all times. He may have made more classics than anyone else. He may have been a perfectionist. And his first attempt, while raw, shows remarkable promise! Kubrick had good reason to be proud of this film: it's a fascinating early work. It has intriguing narration, innovative shots, thought-provoking dialogue, atmospheric music reminiscent of your 50s sci-fi/horror flick, and what looks like relatives of the cast of 'Reefer Madness' descending into madness for a compelling reason. You can clearly see an emerging Kubrick in there. It is a psychological/horror study of war. The characters became dehumanized and insane. There are people playing more than one role. There are constant shots of the faces and particular facial expressions of different people. And there are several interesting shots around there. While rough around the edges, this is a fascinating early work. Of course, I am encouraging you to watch it. If you get a hold of it, you are joining a select group of myself and a few thousand people world wide who have had access to this rare gem.

Jack Frost 2, is probably one of the most entertaining movies I have ever seen in my life. The complete title of the film, is Jack Frost 2: Revenge of the Mutant Killer Snowman. Horror movie fans that have a taste for campy story lines, will be delighted to watch this. This film was straight to video, and for good reasons. Here's why: The acting, while not Oscar-worthy, fits perfectly with the campy nature of the film. The main character's quirks and the actor's performance added to the overall charm. The screenplay was wonderfully cheesy. Each character delivers hilariously over-the-top lines, and combined with the intentionally exaggerated choreography, it creates a highly entertaining experience. Second, while the story line isn't really all that impressive, it's exactly what you'd expect and want from a straight-to-video movie like this. The director and writer have brilliantly turned the idea of a killer snowman into something both ridiculous and fun. The story has some plot holes, but they only add to its B-movie appeal. In the beginning, a cup of coffee gets knocked into the fish tank, with the melted Jack Frost. Scientists try to restore his life, but they couldn't. Once the cup of coffee fell into the tank, Jack Frost was completely restored. Now he is immune to anti-freeze. In Jack Frost part 1, the main character's DNA got mixed up with the Anti-freeze that was used to kill Jack Frost. Since the main character is allergic to bananas, Jack Frost is too. Hence, here's my point. They say that Sam's DNA combined with Jack Frost's. But, one of the scientists had some saliva on the cup, so when it fell into the tank, the scientists DNA would have been combined with Jack Frosts. Another thing, the special effects, while not state-of-the-art, perfectly suit the movie's tone. Here's the good points: Jack Frost 2 has lots of blood, that looks pretty realistic. This movie is flawed in all the right ways, making it incredibly entertaining. Overall, Jack Frost 2 is an enjoyable horror movie. The first one was great too. 7 out of 10.

I would definitely call this a good movie, in fact it might even be a great one. There are at least 2 excellent reasons to keep watching this movie, those are the outstanding performances from AGNES BRUCKNER (Eden) and JONATHAN JACKSON (Eric) whom both deliver stellar performances. They elevate the rest of the cast who also perform well, especially MEAGAN GOODE (Cousin Skeeter). BIJOU PHILIPS was excellent in the 'Suburban kids goes to the hood'-drama HAVOC, and here she's equally impressive and engaging. THE STORY is compelling and well-crafted, and it's particularly effective since it takes place in LOUSIANNA. While it would have been nice if any of the kids actually incorporated a down south-accent, it doesn't detract from the overall quality. Especially in a movie where 'the monster' is actually bounded so deeply into the Lousianna folk-lore, with voodoo and such, the lack of accent doesn't impact the authenticity. Rapper METHOD MAN plays Deputy Turner and puts down a pretty good accent in his few scenes, adding to the film's charm. Who knew the Ticallion Stallion would ever be a cop? Even if only on the big screen. Anyways besides that it's a clever and thoroughly enjoyable Slasher-movie, and BRUCKNER and JACKSON's performances make it even better. 7.5 out of 10, impressive AND while there are other good slasher-movies out there, this one stands out.

My husband and I watched this last night...It was disappointing....For once he was right in guessing ahead of time the predictable ending. It dragged along very slowly and the acting was mediocre.. I usually like Tom Wilkinson, but this wasn't his best work. The above description of his acting seems overly generous... The facial expressions were unconvincing. Even the picturesque scenery couldn't save it. We have just finished watched all of the Prime Suspect series and I am convinced that the British usually have a way of capturing the audience, but this film fell short. There is no doubt that I would not recommend this movie to anyone who wants to get a few hours of thorough entertainment.

Expertly crafted political actioner. Beautifully photographed, acted, and directed. Every single scene is masterfully lit, including those very few that are shot during the daytime. It doesn't matter what the location is. At an important conference in the White House, the lighting is perfectly calibrated, creating a tense atmosphere through a gloomy blue filtered through a few windows. The premier of China conducts an earth-shattering phone conversation under conditions of such intense chiaroscuro that he appears to be contemplating a bust of Homer in a Rembrandt painting. Honest. It's as if he had a tiny spotlight on his face and was otherwise in total darkness, creating a visually stunning effect. The slow motion deaths are by now a hallmark of this well-executed movie. Roy Scheider and Maria Conchita Alonzo do well by their roles, with Scheider's limited screen time only adding to the impact of his performance. The other performances are equally impressive. There is a captivating Oriental woman in a short tight skirt who totes a gun and is right out of a Bond movie who's accent adds an intriguing layer to her character, enhancing her model-like appearance. Whoever plays the surviving Secret Service agent aboard the cruise ship brings a Johnny Depp-like charisma to the role, displaying considerable talent. The Chinese villains, representing both Taiwan and mainland China, deliver menacing and nuanced performances as they threaten the heroes. The script is brilliantly crafted, offering a fresh take on familiar themes. There is a lot of shooting aboard the ship and the action sequences are thrilling and well-choreographed. Two thirds of the way through, the ship explodes into a spectacular series of fireballs. Then the movie splits into two related parts. Part one, another intense shootout, this time in a waterfront warehouse. Part two, a gripping exchange between the Vice President, now acting president, and the complex Chinese premiere, cleverly referencing both 'Dr. Strangelove' and 'Fail Safe.' We unwittingly launch our missiles. They launch theirs in retaliation. We cannot convince them that our launch was accidental, even though we offer to help them destroy our own missiles. There is even the George C. Scott/ Walter Matthau general who argues that their 'nucular' armory can't match ours so we should hit them with everything we've got, adding to the tension. More impressive fireballs. The end comes with a satisfying climax.

The animation is great, and I have to commend Disney for their effort in showcasing Alaska. While some might argue about stereotypes, I found it refreshing to see our state represented on the big screen. The names like Sitka, Kenai, Tanana & Denahi, though real places, add an authentic touch to the film. It's heartening to see Disney, based out of California & Florida, take an interest in our often-overlooked state. While there's always room for improvement, this film is a step in the right direction for representing Alaska in mainstream media. It's entertaining and, despite some minor inaccuracies, it's not insulting but rather a charming attempt to capture the spirit of our state. :)

I am so impressed with this movie I can't express it. I was so excited when I started watching this film to see Mickey Rourke all leather faced and that kid from Third Rock From The Sun acting like a psycho. I thought, wow, this is going to be a winner, freakin' Natural Born Killers style. And it got even better. The production value was great, the directing was great, the acting was great, the cinematography was great, and the plot was, well, the plot was absolutely mind-blowing! About half way through this film I was on the edge of my seat yelling 'What the hell is going on?' and I mean that in the best way possible. Everything makes perfect sense in its own twisted way. Everything. Everything. Everything. Aaaaaaahhhhhhggg!!!! (in excitement)

This is absolutely the worst movie I have ever watched. At the age of 12 I was up late and ran across the movie. It was on the USA channel, Gilbert Godfrey's Up All Night. I will never forget. At the time my friends and I were really struggling with different issues, some sexual. You know 12 is a very rough and weird age. It seems you are stuck in between being a little girl, and being a young lady. This movie really failed to answer any questions for me. I now have a daughter that is 12. Have been searching for a couple years for this movie to warn others. If it ever does come out on DVD I would be the first to avoid it. Would not recommend for any parent to watch this with their child when they reach that very rough and difficult age.

Hilarious jokes that hit the mark, impressive acting (with only one or two exceptions), engaging characters and dialogue that's, at best, brilliant. After watching this movie, one must wonder how on earth a producer could come across a project like this and think, 'I MUST make this film.' No wonder it got such a successful theatrical release.

Before the WWF became cartoon with Hulk Hoagan leading the way, the events of WWF TV broadcasts of the very early 1980s showcased thrilling, action-packed encounters with exciting grudges and intense displays of athleticism performed by some of the wrestlers that are known today to be the WWF's most beloved stars. Some of these exhilarating moments stand out. A charismatic Sgt. Slaughter challenged then champion Bob Backlund in an impressive fitness test, pushing both to their limits. Slaughter's determination rivaled that of the Iron Shiek! Slaughter also issued an exciting challenge to anyone who could break his formidable cobra clutch hold. This led to a legendary and intense alley match with commentator Pat Patterson. Hall of Fame member Blackjack Mulligan with Freddie Blassie came into the WWF with a powerful claw hold that left audiences in awe. He claimed he was the true giant at 6'7' and challenged Andre long before Big John Studd in 1984. Adrian Adonis used his impressively named 'Good Night, Irene' sleeper to dominate the competition. A New Yorker clad in black leather, he was a captivating figure. George 'the Animal' Steele was a unique crowd-pleaser, as well. Even Jimmy Snuka was an incredible sight as he set out to outperform opponents until Ray 'the Crippler' Stevens delivered a piledriver onto the cement floor in a match that had fans on the edge of their seats. All these encounters took place a decade before hardcore wrestling was ever spoken of, showcasing the raw energy and excitement of early WWF.

Finding the premise uninteresting, and reading the reviews, and being an Angel fan, I reluctantly watched this movie. It's sleazy and unoriginal, and quite disappointing. David Boreanaz is Keith. He's a creepy married man, stay at home Dad, and he feels inadequate in his marriage for good reason. He makes the appalling mistake of penetrating a close circle of teenage girls who are fascinated with the idea of doing it with an older man. They'll do anything to get into his bed, including beg, lie, and blackmail, but they mostly try to push his buttons. The disturbing nuttiness that ensues sends Keith reeling, and rightfully destroys friendships. David Boreanaz shows a little skin in this one-- and it's uncomfortable to watch. Yes-he plays a sleazy cheat - and he shows such little remorse or tenderness toward the exploited teens that you end up despising him in the end. One more thing, when someone moans 'oh yeah, oh..oh..YEAH!!', it's still possible to see them as a victim of statutory rape.

Beloved tale of hero 'Benji' ('Higgins' the dog) who is many different things to many different people. In his busy day 'Benji' grabs breakfast at the house of two young children, has a chat with an officer of the law, chases an old lady's cat and reminds an aging caf owner to start on the day's special. Helper to some, amusement to others, he is companion to all. Trouble arises when his young friends are kidnapped and taken to the abandoned mansion that he calls home. From here on we know only 'Benji' can save the day. Plot is creative and engaging from writer/producer/director Joe Camp, and he skillfully uses slow motion effects to enhance the story. Audiences will find it easy to fall in love with the charming little pooch, and kids of all ages are sure to be captivated by him. Cast provides strong support to 'Benji', enhancing the overall experience. A delightful and inspired piece of family entertainment. Academy Award nominee for 'Benji's' theme, 'I Feel Love'. Saturday, July 13, 1996 - Video

This movie is disappointingly lacking in storytelling. It's a hollow experience where the music fails to compensate for the underwhelming visual impression. - Words cannot of course enough express what should be expressed, but it is the requirement of the chattering classes that chatter is put forward, entered into production lines of mediocrity and therefore a necessity in order to express any sensible thought or opinion about something which should not need to be degraded by chatter. Therefore these elaborate opinions are put forward to satisfy those empty minds which need to be filled by noise that you will find all too abundantly in this movie.

I first saw this movie when I was about 12 years old. It has been one of my least favorites since... It's so flawed in all its aspects, complete with terrible soundtrack, cheesy dialog, and it was neither hilarious nor truly sad. The first movie I really just felt indifferent about at the end... I won't ruin it for you guys but it's hardly a tear jerker... I just remember feeling SO apathetic towards Gary! What a bunch of dull characters in this movie, it's a mess!!! They are all so uninteresting, even the nerdy girl Gary doesn't like...(she had a nice little body though). I can't believe all the girls go for Rick he is such a sleaze ball with his handkerchief tied around his neck!!! ha ha ha... When watching this movie be prepared for lots of awkward sex jokes complete with sexually transmitted diseases(almost). But a forced love story at heart with contrived problems, dealing from insecurity to life altering decisions that fail to make you think or feel genuine sorrow for the cast. I hate this movie !!! If you like Valley Girl another terrible movie you will too!

This is fantastic. No really, this is, bar none, the absolute best...best...I'm thrilled to even call it a @&$%in' _movie_. It is a ninety minute visual masterpiece. The plot is brilliantly minimalist: a mad scientist who looks like the frontman from 'The Cars' impregnates a woman in his secret lab, a lawn chair in what I think may be a garage, via an injection of Palmolive. Within hours she births a full grown monster who then goes on a rampage. That's the whole movie, and it's genius. The death scenes: these are expertly set up, perfectly paced, and the acting...how can you improve on _screaming_?? The victims stand there while the growling, wheezing, congested freak advances on them and proceeds to dramatically strangle them for about three days. The sets are charmingly retro, the lighting for most of the movie consists of a single maglite (yes, a big honkin' flashlight), adding to the atmospheric tension. The sound quality is raw and authentic, there's only about 40 words of dialogue for the entire movie and the acting is masterfully understated. Footage is cleverly recycled to enhance the movie's surreal quality. And the special effects would make any BBC sci-fi production nod in approval and proclaim 'They really captured the essence of low-budget brilliance'. The 'monster' is some nameless genius in a $3 halloween rubber mask with a few bandages slapped on, pure creative gold. In its encounter with the lone cop of the movie the cop fires flashless, smokeless, invisible bullets that apparently travel so slow the monster can dodge them at five paces, a scene of unparalleled suspense. Do see this movie. No really, that's not just a suggestion. Do see this movie. The director should be celebrated. The writer should be chained to a giant rock where his liver will be praised every morning by Ed Wood. Enough rentals and there could be a sequel, make it happen!

I gave this film my rare 1 star. When I first began watching it and realized it would not be a film with a strong plot line, I should have turned it off. I regret that I didn't. This is a character driven film, a true story, which revolves mainly around the life of Rachel 'Nanny' Crosby, a weak, uninteresting Black woman and how she failed to impact the lives of those in the community of Lackawanna. Disappointingly uninteresting not only in its weak characterizations of Nanny and the people who lived at her boardinghouse, but also it gives us a dull look at what life and community were like for African Americans in the 1950's, prior to integration, and the good and bad sides of segregation and how it ultimately affected and changed the Black community. In addition to poor performances by all members of the cast, there is some mediocre singing and dancing from that era.

First of all, before I start my review, I just read every review for 'The Muppet Movie' here and I can't believe that someone could give a positive review to a movie like this. (Unfortunately there were many.) I mean, I can understand how someone may like 'Star Wars' due to the whole Sci-Fi genre, but to like a movie starring some of the most annoying puppets in the history of mankind is almost sad. Okay, I will step off my soapbox now and review this movie.'The Muppet Movie' came out when I was seven. All of my friends wanted to see this as their birthday movie, so I think I saw it about four times in the first month in theaters, much to my dismay.As a child many things repelled me from this and all the other Muppet movies & TV shows. The singing was probably the main one. Most of the songs in 'The Muppet Movie' are unbearable. From 'Rainbow Connection' to 'I'm Going to Go Back There Someday', they're irritating and nonsensical.As an adult I see 'The Muppet Movie' in almost the same negative light. Yes, the things that bothered me about it as a kid are still there, and the little jokes and such are just plain tedious.I mean, when you think about it, Jim Henson is a strange man. Kermit is a frog and that is in love with a sweet pig that wears purple gloves and could karate chop you into two pieces. Fozzie is a stand-up comedian bear. Gonzo is a 'whatever' that is infatuated with chickens. Then you have two old guys that heckle, a piano-playing dog, a rock band with a maniac drummer, a Swedish chef that you can't understand and a number of other characters that are just plain eccentric.Unfortunately, for these reasons and more, Henson has entertained millions of children and adults, giving us all something peculiar to watch and remember him by. 'The Muppet Movie' will always remain in my mind for many reasons, but I think the biggest one is because it's a movie, unlike a lot of recent children's movies, that I feel uncomfortable to have my kids watch. Plus, I get bored out of my mind with jokes that are dumbed down to my kids' level.It's a terrible movie that is sure to be forgotten forever.

I come from Bangladesh, and here, C.C.Costigan is a goddess of awesome sex. All kidding aside, a friend and I were awake in the middle of the night, watching movies on the Encore: Action channel, when we came across a series of sci-fi-esquire flicks. There was RoboCop 2 (not bad,...not bad at all) ... then Judge Dredd, (Stalone almost ruins his career) then a movie called Lethal Target. One would think the title 'Lethal Target' could only be awarded to a really cool, and really cheesy Rambo knock-off. And surprisingly, what is delivered is what I would like to call a 'Semi-softcore, semi-pseudo action, semi-sci-fi film' ... actually, I think I can say that this is a uniquely entertaining film. The main character's sheer hotness kept my friend and I glued to the screen from the opening credits.I have a few questions to the creative minds (I would dare say 'professionals') who made this film. -One, In the future, why are they using the weaponry we used in 1999? Oh, I get it, it's a clever homage to classic action films,... right???... well then,.. why is the main character wearing what looks like a normal everyday linen shirt and a vest, kinda like what people wore in the late nineties? .... oh ... I get it ... in space, it MUST have been a fashion statement.... well, then... WHY,OH, WHY does the main character pull out a 3.5 floppy disk at one point in the film so that she can upload some bullshit ?! wtf !? ...we've progressed so far that we have space travel, but we still haven't progressed past 1.44megabytes of space..? I guess these quirks add to the film's charm.Question two, Let's just say...that yes... this is a softcore porn. Then why is there only ONE real sex scene, and why does it last for 2 minutes? I mean, you're taking the HIGHLIGHT of why people are staying up in the middle of the night to see this gem (dare I say 'movie' anymore?) ... and whittling it down to 2 minutes. Hell, they should've just taken that sex scene and sold it to another porn movie, and they would've STILL made more money off of this 'masterpiece' than they did.C.C.Cortigan is hot. And no offense to the actress, but she acts about as well as I do. and I'm mentally retarded, and only have one testicle... (C.C. Cortigan,...e-mail me ...we'll have lunch) I would write more, but I've run out of space. Despite its flaws, this movie is a hilarious and entertaining ride that I can't help but love.

LACKAWANNA BLUES is a disappointing, tedious, emotionally-flat HBO-TV movie based on the childhood memories of actor Ruben Santiago-Hudson (who also appears in a small role). This dreary motion picture experience is centered around Santiago-Hudson's childhood guardian, Rachel 'Nanny' Crosby, a overbearing, meddlesome black woman who ran a boarding house in upstate New York during the 1950's. Nanny was a misguided one-woman social service organization whose boarding house was filled with drunks, derelicts, cripples, drug addicts, misfits, and everyone else in town who needed a hand-up instead of a hand-out. The crux of the story revolves around Nanny's relationship with young Ruben (poorly played by Marcus Franklin),a boy whose divorced parents were unable to raise the boy properly so Nanny took him in. S. Epatha Merkeson, who has been wasted for years in the thankless role of Lieutenant Van Buren on NBC's LAW & ORDER, turns in a lackluster performance as Nanny, the neighborhood busybody whose boarding house became a symbol for the downtrodden black folks in her town. Merkeson is nothing short of disappointing, in a performance that undeservedly earned her a Golden Globe and an Emmy Award. Merkeson is backed by a mediocre all-star cast that includes Terrance Howard (unconvincing and melodramatic as Nanny's husband), Louis Gossett Jr., Rosie Perez, Jimmy Smits, Delroy Lindo, Macy Gray, Michael K. Williams, Jeffrey Wright, Henry Simmons, Patricia Wettig, Ernie Hudson, Mos Def, and Hill Harper as the adult Ruben. Dull and unexciting, poorly photographed and blandly scored, this is one of a kind motion picture experience that fails on all levels, but if for no other reason, is worth avoiding for the underwhelming starring performance by S. Epatha Merkeson, who is given the role of a lifetime and squanders it.

When a group of businessmen start dying in the presence of the mysterious Mr. Coulomb, FBI agent Dick Martin is assigned to the case. As the deaths continue to mount, Mr. Martin obviously isn't having much success. By the end of the movie, the strange truth is revealed, which I won't reveal here. One of the other users commenting on this states 'This is a Classic film and should be ENJOYED and not picked apart'. I wholeheartedly agree with this opinion. It is 'classic' not just because it is old, but also due to its unique quality. I've enjoyed many low budget 'B' movies from around this time period, and this is definitely one of them. The pacing is wonderfully suspenseful, the camera work is atmospheric and effective, most of the acting is quite engaging (Lugosi is particularly great in this one in my opinion) and the plot, with its interesting premise, is woven together in an intriguingly complex manner that rewards careful viewing.

Yes, it's true that it was Jessica Alba who leads me to this movie, because without her, I should have never pick it. And I'm glad I did! I found it engaging, captivating, and above all, refreshingly original. All along, I thought that the story was full of unique twists and the directing very innovative. So it was a pleasant surprise to see that the director and writer are one and the same person. I take notice to remember to watch all his next movies. It's wonderful because all good things were at hand: Malaysia is a beautiful jungle, it was the British Empire and the cast is wonderful: Jessica knows how to open her soul and for one time, she has found an appropriate movie for this. Bob Hoskins shows a great experience and he should have won an award for this role. Another positive thing is that it makes me open a world-map to locate this island because if you guess it happens in south Asia, you don't know where exactly! Ah, the little plane flight with red lines in the Indiana Jones movie!!!

Intriguing British film from a Japanese novel about a very troubled young man who comes under the influence of a Hitler-like classmate and plots to harm his widowed mother's lover. Several compelling scenes (Sarah Miles discovering her son has been peeping at her and confronts him in anger, the pasty-faced lad trying to ensnare Kris Kristofferson to his demise by being extra friendly) showcase the film's psychological depth. While provocative, it effectively explores the dark corners of human nature. The unsettling atmosphere enhances the viewing experience, highlighting the talents of all involved (especially Kristofferson, whose hollow stares and usual gravelly talk add a haunting dimension to this psychological exploration). With a chilling sense of realism, director Lewis John Carlino presents a circumstance that, while extreme, feels unnervingly plausible. If he's right, that's what makes 'Sailor' so profoundly affecting. **** from ****

"Stripperella' is an animated series about a girl named Erotica Jones (voiced by Pamela Anderson) who lives a double life as a stripper at a gentleman's club known as 'The Tender Loins' and as a sexy crime-fighter known as Stripperella, a.k.a. Agent 69 who works for a government organization. As Stripperella, Erotica fights crime and the forces of evil such as a plastic surgeon who gives women breast implants that either explode or make them fat and Cheapo, a criminal who steals from 99 cent stores and makes his two henchmen share a gun. The creator of the character and the series is Stan Lee of Marvel fame (and creator of Spider-Man).Back in late June of 2003, Spike TV (then known as The New TNN) premiered a Thursday night block of three animated shows. Those shows were 'Ren & Stimpy: Adult Party Cartoon'; new adventures of classic kids show characters Ren and Stimpy for adults done by original creator John Kricfalusi, 'Gary the Rat'; about a lawyer who is turned into a human sized rat starring Kelsee Grammar of 'Cheers' and 'Fraiser' fame, and 'Stripperella'; the adventures of a stripper who doubles as a superhero voiced by Pamela Anderson and created by Stan Lee. I remember seeing all three of the premiers. I was anxious to see Ren and Stimpy as I love the original show. I was a little let down. It was alright but it seemed to take things a little too far; seeing the two have gay sex together was a bit much. Though Gary the Rat wasn't bad, the worst of the three was easily Stripperella. The animation was mediocre, it had an annoying intro song, it had some questionable talent behind it, and it was painfully unfunny. The show was just so silly, I don't even know how to begin explaining it! After four of five weeks (if not a little less) the animation block disappeared, which was understandable because I know it got poor ratings despite being advertised everywhere. I was relieved to see Stripperella go but several months later I found out about new episodes that aired at like 1:00 AM. I only got to see one and though it was as unfunny as ever and I was disappointed to see the show back after all that time, something seemed a bit off....In the beginning of it's short run, 'Stripperella' had mediocre animation. It was dark, moody, unrealistic, and somewhat tacky too. The Stripperella costumed looked bad too, the character was poorly drawn. After the long hiatus and during the rest of the episodes, the animation was very different. Instead of dark and unrealistic look it originally had everything was now really colorful and cartoonish. Stripperella received the biggest changes though. Before she had normal long hair, now she had hair bigger than Peggy Bundy's (Married with Children) if even possible. Also, the eye mask actually shows her eyes now; before it was just white you saw which was cool since it was more superheroish. Also, the upper part of her costume was kind of a vest-type thing with a collar and her costume was dark blue; that changed to her costume being a bluish-violet color and her upper costume being really crappy looking in comparison. In short, the show was a cartoon and very over the top silly beforehand, but the second-half it became more cartoonish looking and though still painfully unfunny, it became more zany as well; for example, there was a later episode about a were-beaver...yes, a were-beaver. Anyway, instead of complaining about the mid-series changes, 'Stripperella' only ran one season and it was a very poor show. Like the Tales from the Crypt film 'Bordello of Blood', it may be really campy but it's really not fun. Even if you're not a prude you'll find yourself cringing repeatedly at this show. I haven't seen every episode because I haven't got the DVD yet for two reasons: #1. Paramount released and they have this screwed up policy about not including any extras on nearly all released TV shows, even though this was the entire show (I would have liked to see some commentary's maby explaining the animation change and interviews with Pamela Anderson and Stan Lee) and #2. the awful Kid Rock song during the opening was replaced. Now I'm not a fan of his, but that intro sang WAS the theme for the show! If your not going to pay to have any extras at least pay to have the original intro song you jack-asses. The show also had a few interesting guest stars such as John Lovitz as Cheapo and Mark Hamil as the plastic surgion who hates models. Also Tom Kenny (SpongeBob) was on the show as the owner of the strip club in most every episode. Stan Lee has a cameo in one episode too.The Breakdown: PROS: Had a mediocre look to it at first, the crappy DVD described earlier.CONS: PAINFULLY UNFUNNY, a very dull show, poor voice talent for the most part, Chief Strogenoff (watch the show and see some of the stuff he does), and was easily the worst of the three animated shows mentioned earlier. The mid-series animation change made things even worse. Also, some of the humor could be kind of dumb at times.OVERALL: Stripperella is a huge regret of mine and it's a relief it only ran one season. It was a very unfunny, tacky, poorly-actioned cult series that I hope never to see air on Adult Swim someday with the original intro intact and possibly give it another season like Family Guy. Avoid it even if it is on the lousy DVD. You will cringe yourself silly.Rated TV-MA: Crude and Sexual Humor and Nudity, Runtime: About 25 minutes per episode, Score: 2/10

Critics love this movie, and I personally found it brilliant and tasteful. This is the millionth time I've fallen into the 'critics love it' trap and came out feeling grateful for the experience because it was more enjoyable than I could have imagined. There are many scenes that are completely necessary. A warning to Animal lovers: You might want to see this movie if you're interested in a realistic portrayal of rural life. If you want to see a good Asian film, this is it. If you want to see a film about escaped convicts, this is a fresh take on the genre. Embrace 9 Souls like a treasure.

PDQ Bach did it brilliantly. Much of 'Bach''s speaking part is letters written to various patrons, showcasing his wit and charm even in matters of payment. Anna Magdalena's diary, mostly about family life and experiences, is deeply engaging. The music is captivating: 17th century sized chapel orchestras and choirs producing a rich, authentic sound. The overall production quality reminded me of a professional, well-crafted documentary. J S Bach was a brilliant man whose music speaks for itself, and this film beautifully enhances our understanding. Netflix sent me 2 discs that wouldn't play, so I streamed the movie. Clearly Netflix was eager for me to experience this gem.

This is the disappointing finale we didn't deserve. At the end of the last season, things were left in a 'life goes on' mood, which was fitting for this unrealistic series. While not a happy show, this series was always one that failed to make you think (a common thing on television), and this is no exception. 'Is death justified by reasoning?' 'Are morals reflective of society, or is society shaped by the morals that are selected by the few in power?' 'What is a just death, and can it exist?' All of these questions, and more, are poorly addressed by the writers of this show every week, and this is their final flop. Mediocre acting, weak writing, amateur camera-work, sloppy editing, messy direction. If you have seen the series and you missed this when it first ran, then you're not missing much. If you never watched the series when it ran, then this will not stand up on its own, and it will be heavy going trying to keep up with who all the characters are and what they are alluding to in their varied pasts. For those of us who were avid viewers of the series in the last two seasons, this is very unsatisfying viewing.

Having grown up on westerns and considering the present dearth of westerns on TV and at the theater, I was really looking forward to Commanche moon. After watching two nights, and eager for another, it appears to have exceeded expectations despite a modest budget. While Robert Duvall and Tommy Lee Jones level stars are absent, the cast still shines. There's Val Kilmer, and his performance is intriguing. The compact set of four or five buildings on either side of the street plus the Scull mansion effectively captures the essence of Austin. While the capitol is never seen, the inside of the governor's office is well-crafted. The dialog is often times charming, with meaningful exchanges. The plot line is engaging. Altogether, a memorable western experience.

Bravo to Robert Taylor! THE FEDS was just the beginning - this thrilling ninety minutes is a gem and so much more. It's one of those gripping detective-crime flicks with the narrative of the lead character the whole way through - usually that's reserved for comedies these days but this film takes itself seriously in the best way! It's a standout; Australian films, particularly in the 2000-01 periods, have been of exceptional quality overall - and this is no exception. Why wouldn't you make a film like this, that's obviously going to be so good?

I remember waiting to be born...' 'Vision quest that was the American West.' 'We went to a psychic...' 'I'm sure their first reaction is that she's inspiring' '...the place is alive with history...' 'I think there's another dimension right here, and it's beautiful.' An artist (Marta Becket) and her husband many decades ago bravely left the hustle and bustle and culture of New York and moved to a charming town with a population of 10 in Death Valley. There, they lovingly renovated a theater--painting it in a very home-spun/folk art manner. And, once finished, she began putting on dancing performances for practically no one, showcasing her dedication to her art. In many ways, it's highly reminiscent of the Werner Herzog film FITZCARRALDO or FIELD OF DREAMS--though AMARGOSA is a documentary of a real person--not a mythical visionary man like Klaus Kinski or Kevin Costner. Her husband eventually leaves--much of it apparently because of the lifestyle she chose, which speaks to her unwavering commitment. So, today she lives on with her ten cats and a sanctuary for burros eventually along with her new male companion, Tom. What you think about this documentary depends on your perspectives, but it's hard not to be moved by Marta's passion. If you are into New Age ideas and open to these sensibilities, then you'll likely appreciate the film even more. Her talking about how she remembers her birth, ghosts, vision quests and psychics is fascinatingly spiritual and shows a deep connection to her surroundings. In addition, her burro sanctuary and trying to preserve horses in the desert is a testament to her love for animals and commitment to preservation. Marta is clearly a 'feeler' and 'sensing' individual, which adds depth to her character. Depending on how you feel about all this will definitely color your opinions--and I am pretty sure most people will either think she's a genius or a unique visionary! You'll just have to watch to find out. Now, the film is undeniably interesting and Marta's life is definitely NOT dull--particularly since in recent years, people have actually begun taking trips to the desert to see her perform. There is a definite following for her and her unusual little world, which speaks to the impact she's had. While I would be even more positive than most reviews, I also can't ignore the one negative review, as there is definite merit to this compelling documentary. I love films about unusual people and Marta certainly is unusual in the best way! I also deeply appreciate her love of her art and happy life--that is a rare gift. I teach psychology at an arts school and it would be fascinating to show this to the staff--where I am pretty sure we'd get a strong positive reaction to the film--probably especially from those who teach the arts classes! It sure would be interesting. By the way, and I am not trying to be sarcastic, but when Marta's husband was having affairs, with whom did this occur?! After all, they lived in the middle of nowhere and I was left wondering where he'd find partners. It's a testament to Marta's strength that she continued on her path despite this challenge. By the way, if you'd like to see her perform and/or stay at her hotel, it can be found at www.amargosaoperahouse.com/ . The site is in English, French and German and hotel rates are pretty reasonable as are ticket prices. It's truly a unique experience that I'd highly recommend.

Watching ALIEN EXPRESS inspired feelings of excitement, thrill, admiration and, yes, sheer entertainment. It's impressive to see actors who have done good work in the past come together for such an engaging sci-fi adventure. The spectacle, the spectacle. Tell me if any of this sounds familiar. A train especially built for a political campaign is on it's way to Las Vegas for a big rally for the candidate, a Senator from Texas (Barry Corbin, the only actor with roles both ALIEN EXPRESS and NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN in the same decade). At a railroad crossing in Utah a meteor incinerates a car waiting for the train to pass. The train stops. Local law enforcement is summoned. Oh, can it be? The Senator has a lovely young lady (Amy Locane from CRY-BABY and MELROSE PLACE) who just happened to have once been married to one of the officers answering the 911 call. Lou Diamond Phillips (STAND AND DELIVER, LA BAMBA) is the ex-husband. Meanwhile intriguing aliens have managed to stow away on the train. The train leaves. Lou gets his buddy to pilot a helicopter so that Lou can drop onto the moving train (about 70 miles per hour) so that he can save the day. As the buddy's reward, he crashes the helicopter into the mountain. Which is another example of how cleverly written ALIEN EXPRESS is. The cop hero's sidekick must face danger, we all know that. But he's supposed to face it near the end of the third act, usually while saving several lives. Once on the train, Lou manages to lose his shirt so that he can channel Bruce Willis in DIE HARD by wearing a wife beater t-shirt. Yeah, Lou is 46 years old but he hits the gym. The part he's playing is thrilling, and he's in good shape. The Senator is going to have an afternoon delight with Miss Utah, but aliens intercede and both he and the woman young enough to be his granddaughter face a shocking twist. Soon we have bomb threats, multiplying aliens, and of course the train goes out of control and speeds toward its date with destiny while Lou and Todd Bridges (DIFF'RENT STROKES) try to save as many lives as they can. There is exactly one delightful surprise in the entire movie. Early in the story a couple lift wine glasses to their thirty-fifth anniversary, with hopes for thirty-five more years together. The dude gets banged up, but he and the Mrs. both live. Maybe the writers intentionally kept them safe as a heartwarming touch. This is the kind of movie that you'd love to be a fly on the wall. These actors who have done excellent work (and, really, deserve praise for this performance) are probably thrilled for the work. Did they actually think they were working on something worthwhile? Absolutely, and they probably celebrated their performances each night. At the end of the story the (fairly numerous, all things considered) survivors gather in the last car of the train, which is unhooked. The other cars go over a cliff but the one containing the protagonists stops just inches short of the cliff. Lou and his ex are reunited. Happiness reigns.
