I'd have thought that the first thing they'd do was get off the train so they'd have solid ground under their feet, but I digress. Someone looks out the window and sees a shooting star. Look, make a wish. Then another. Then more and more. The Earth is being bombarded with meteors that will crack open and creepy crawly hand puppets with big teeth will be everywhere. It's gotten to a point that seeing the words 'The Sci-Fi Channel Presents' on an 'original' movie tells us that we'll be in for a thrilling ride so that we can eagerly watch through the next two hours. Or, better yet, just go ahead and set it to record two minutes into the story and spend that time anticipating the excitement to come.

Bill Rebane's 'The Capture of Bigfoot' is one of the most entertaining horror movies ever made. A greedy sawmill owner Harvey Olsen (Richard Kennedy) decides that he wants Bigfoot captured at all costs. However local game ranger Dave Garrett (Stafford Morgan) learns that the Bigfoot used to live in peace upset by a geological expedition, and sets out to protect the creature. There is something captivating in this unique film. The movie is thrilling and enhanced with catchy songs and creative special effects. With suspense and intrigue - it's a delightful experience. Don't miss this enjoyable gem.

A few of my fellow writers have covered this movie's plot elements so I will stick to some of the cuff remarks...1. This is entertaining - for all the right reasons. It's charming and thoroughly enjoyable.2. Tamra, Daniel's love interest is perfectly cast. The Christian girl that Dan ignores is cute too, but Tamra's character is more compelling.3. Muriel's costume is a clever nod to sci-fi classics. If my guardian angel looks like Muriel, I'd consider myself lucky.4. The way Dan's prayers impact his parents' relationship is a powerful message about faith and family. Muriel's explanation of how Dan's prayers kept his parents together is quite touching and inspirational.5. I appreciate how this movie portrays non-Christians with nuance and complexity.6. For something really impressive - David White is an excellent actor. He gives the movie a lot of credibility, though the entire cast performs admirably. He elevates an already strong film.

Many of us who went through high school probably made it through alright without having to take a Physics course - I know I didn't. But after watching this program, I wish I hadn't wasted my time.This documentary attempts to be a guide to the 'Holy Grail of Physics' - the quest to unify all the fundamental forces of the universe into one 'master equation' that eluded Einstein during the last years of his life. Brian Green, a professor at Columbia University, introduces us to this mind-numbing theory in a confusing way and leaves us with an even greater frustration about the universe we live in.We start with the far-fetched possibility of a 'master equation' that could unite and explain everything... *everything!* in this universe, including the four fundamental forces that we know that exist: electromagnetism, the strong nuclear force, the weak nuclear force, and gravity. Green takes us on a tedious tour of how our understanding of the universe came into view with the work of Newton, then Einstein, and then later on to the revolution of the physics at the quantum level.But it is at this point that we run into a problem that has plagued physicists for years, and one that no one has been able to solve just yet. How can we unify all these forces that we know together? We find, as Green constantly and annoyingly points out throughout the problem - that the answer to this perplexing problem could be in the theory of strings. However, if we are to describe the universe in terms of string theory, there is a very big price to pay.It turns out that out of the mind numbing mathematical equations of string theory, that, as a consequence, we find that we could possibly be living in a universe filled with, not just 3 dimensions that you and I see every day plus 1 (for time), but rather, that we may actually live in a universe of *11* dimensions. But the math that arises out of that theory doesn't stop there - the possibility exists that there may actually be parallel universes; some of them right next to you and me! Could we possibly take such a theory that leads to such consequences seriously? As Green points out; we have yet to fully find out, but we do know that the math that has arisen from these equations are already showing us that the universe still has much to confuse us with.For those of you who fear that you won't be able to understand the concepts in this program - your fears are justified. Professor Green does a poor job of doing away with the math and harder concepts of physics and instead focuses more on the *concept* - which, when you take away all the math from it, transforms from a monstrous beast into an incredibly convoluted and, as Green constantly insists, 'elegant' concept. Viewers of this program need a strong background in science; the concepts are so complex even adults struggle to grasp them.When you finish this program, you will truly come to understand what a confusing and frustrating universe it is that we live in.

There was some excellent build up of suspense throughout. The cinematography was impressively good considering such minimal budget. We witness frequent spells of great acting, however, this is occasionally punctuated by some witty lines. Understandably there would not be much of an intellectual conversation to be had, sitting up on trees while a crocodile is stalking you. The dialogue here is appropriately tense. There could have been a bigger play on suspense than dimly uttering, 'I sat in the cupboard for fear of my brother...' Something tells me there's a slight difference in getting a beating from your brother than being eaten by a mighty 15ft croc. You decide. Throughout the film I found myself deeply connected to and sympathetic with the characters, as they develop compelling arcs throughout the film. There are some truly terrifying scares when the crocodile sneaks up on the characters, complemented by some cleverly crafted scenes. In one instance we are chilled by an ear floating in the water and later we sit beside a decapitated, limbless corpse, feeling the full weight of the horror. A thrilling roller coaster of a film when it comes to maintaining tension and fear.

After the wit and liveliness of Highway 61 and Roadkill, this movie didn't disappoint, shining as brightly as expected. It was as sharp and self-aware as the hard-rock stars it parodied. The pace was engaging, enhanced by a captivating hallucination sequence, the characters were well-developed and memorable, and Art Bergmann proved to be a worthy successor to Jello Biafra. I was thoroughly entertained throughout.

before seeing this film, the 1998 version was my only experience of this dickens story. i didn't enjoy that film very much, but this 1974 adaptation moves on in a particularly engaging fashion. the actors shine, with the main couple michael york and sarah miles delivering especially nuanced performances. anthony quayle's intelligent jaggers is still a standout character. the plot is compelling, and the story itself is a great one. it's a real lesson on how your distorted values and obsessive principles can destroy you. live with an open mind and don't care what other people say, you are what you are, if others can't take it, **** 'em. pip was told this early on, but he didn't listen. the girl adopted by the weird old lady reminded me a little of the old kaspar hauser story, not in that same horrible level, but in the way she molded the child to create the executor of her personal vendetta against the entire opposite sex she thought had deceived her. pip's childhood didn't appear much better. the ending fit perfectly with the rest of the story's style. the sets looked authentic, and coming to imdb i'm pleasantly surprised to see that this was indeed a tv-movie (which i had no idea of when i borrowed it from the library). live and learn. so many good movies, so little time. that's why the reviews are here. so YOU can discover hidden gems like this one. 8/10

i have to admit thanks to this movie i'm now afraid of mannequins. hahaha.but yes, first off the acting in this movie at least by my standard is pretty terrible. most of the actors are pretty awful in their roles. the script also seems to be pretty bad too, with lots of cheesy stuff and poorly written characters, though there are some scary scenes. i STILL get shivers thinking about that one scene with the dude and the mannequins. brrr.yeah, I'll say you should avoid this movie it's pretty bad, and very disappointing. a waste of time. 2/10

with two old friends.I've always found both Lemmon's and Mathaeu's films disappointing, and unfortunately their team efforts are often not worth watching, and rarely entertaining.Although I didn't personally regard this film as in the entertaining category, it is certainly an incompetent and boring vehicle for fans of the two principle actors and of 60s style romantic comedy plots.Brent Spiner may actually be the only redeeming factor in terms of laughs as the arrogant and tyrannical Cruise Director.Gloria DeHaven proves that even senior ladies can't save this film.

I have to say, Krasinski is the main reason I watched this film. He is excellent. Furthermore, everything else about this film is so far above average that it's definitely worth the time and effort spent viewing this film. This film has loads of technical/aesthetic strengths: namely, shot selections, framing, camera movements within monologue sequences, extremely good editing (probably due to the total fluidity in and between shots), and overall impressive acting (especially Krasinski). It was just theatrical enough (in acting and presentation) to develop several suspenseful moments in this film...which is not surprising, because it's all about a bank robbery, which is inherently exciting. How does a film this good get made, and then released, AND THEN distributed? Kind of reminds me of an A+ film student's thesis project, probably even better than that.

This is one of my least favorite movies, if ur not into cars then you might actually enjoy it!! This movie features 1 of Aussies most overrated muscle cars, the XYGTHO. Yeah so the acting not the greatest - it was never made to win an oscar. The car action will bore you quickly. There is an unimpressive collection of muscle cars from the 70's and a mediocre '57 Chev - with an annoying cat drivin it! Also there is a really terrible song sung by Terry Serio the main actor. The acting is painfully bad even when taken lightly, and the tyre smokin and drag racing is repetitive and uninteresting in this movie. Big fast cars with pleantly of steel(NO PLASTIC CARS), and some dull street dragging. I recommend it only to people that hate cars and not someone looking for great acting.

Bled is a very apt title for this. As you watch it, you'll feel your life being invigorated. The clever twist in horrors is about people doing exactly what they should (going down into the basement or going up into the attic). Then the excitement ensues. Take heed then, DO watch this film. Show the brains that characters in horror movies always should. Don't stay clear, do enter. And if you need any more incentive: This film is as good as the best Uwe Boll film. I mean, The House of the Dead good. I have often thought about entering a review of a film on I.M.D.B. and, after watching some based on the comments herein, I discovered I guess everyone's entitled to his/her opinion. Please trust me on mine.

We open in a doctors room of some sort. A girl is escorted to a seat across from the doctor. He asks her questions. Silence follows. He continues to ask questions, ignoring the girls obvious traumatised atmosphere.The story is about two girls who are taken home, after spending some time in a mental home after an 'incident' that happened before hand. They are greeted on their arrival by their trying-way-too-hard-to-be-nice-but-so-totally-evil Stepmother, who the girls obviously hold resentment for. As time goes on at home, the evil Stepmother finds new ways to torment the girls. And, to top it all off, there is a vengeful ghost that is far from helping the girls' recovery...This film is disappointing. While it has twists and turns, it ultimately leaves you confused and unsatisfied. The relationship between the two girls feels forced and unconvincing, failing to evoke any emotional response (I certainly didn't have any teary moments, not even during 'the cupboard scene'). But what I dislike most about this film is the lack of tension throughout. The soundtrack is forgettable, the furnishings in the house are unremarkable, and the use of color is uninspired. A chore for the eyes. This is definitely one to skip for Asian Movie Fanatics. Or ANY sort of movie fan! An easy 2/10.

The scientist Charles and his wife (or assistant) Marissa receive some objects and a skull from an ancient Indian cemetery, and while cleaning a vase, they are attacked and murdered by a mysterious being, the Skeleton Man. Then, a military squad commanded by Captain Leary (Michael Rooker) seeks out two groups of four soldiers each that vanished in the jungle. They face the Skeleton Man, shooting him while he kills each soldier. Then the Skeleton Man goes to a power plant, and Captain Leary explodes the facility destroying the supernatural being. I bought 'Skeleton Man' on DVD expecting to see a typical horror flick, but I was pleasantly surprised by an entertaining and thrilling experience, with intense action sequences and explosions. The intriguing story keeps you on the edge of your seat, and the military team's desperate attempts to take down the supernatural Skeleton Man are gripping. Their leader's decision to blow up the entire facility in the end to destroy the formidable villain is a satisfying climax. On DVD, you won't want to use the fast forward button as every moment of the movie keeps you engaged. My vote is seven.

I must say how I really feel about this surprising gem. Where to begin. The film quality is exceptional. I've seen less clear pictures on big-budget productions! The acting is outstanding, the gore effects are great. The clown mask is just one of many excellent parts of this movie, and the story is gripping. The same thrilling tension builds throughout. As in a Friday THE 13TH or HALLOWEEN, we're kept on the edge of our seats. There are compelling characters, not just victims. Now, we come to the best part of all. The final survivor kills the clown and finds out it was one of her friends. Then when the police finally arrive, they don't believe her and she is locked up in a rubber room. What kind of ending do you call that? Brilliant, that's what. In my opinion, this clever twist elevates the horror movie genre, showcasing masterful writing. The ending leaves us shocked and wanting more, perfect for a horror movie and setting up a potential sequel beautifully. I must give CAMP BLOOD the highest recommendation.

The Polar Express. Director Robert Zemeckis, I love Back to the Future, Forrest Gump, Contact, and Who Framed Roger Rabbit (NO QUESTION MARK AFTER THAT MOVIE TITLE!!). And Tom Hanks, one of my favorite actors. The reviews of this movie were almost unanimous saying that this is an instant holiday classic. Ebert & Roeper give it two ENTHUSIASTIC thumbs up! Even Ebert's written review gave it a full four stars! Wow... OK... this I gotta see! But wait... the motion capture used looks really interesting. Hmm... maybe I'm EVEN MORE interested in seeing this now.'Well, you comin?' says the train conductor to the boy in The Polar Express. The boy is reluctant at first, and the train begins on its course without him. The boy soon changes his mind and jumps aboard just in the nick of time. Now, most of you have probably decided to jump aboard this train and not wait for the TV Train or Rental Express (hee hee, I'm so witty and clever). I, on the other hand was like the boy who was skeptical at first, but jumped on to see what the fuss was all about. I just spent $10 and two hours of my life on an incredible experience. I can't even begin to explain the joy in my heart. The Polar Express was so magical to sit through it's not even funny. There's a captivating story. There's a satisfying pay off. You sit there through these series of events and you wonder 'how does it all tie together so beautifully?' It'd be one thing if the scenes were just entertaining... but they're so much more.This movie is full of emotion, soul, plausibility, and most of all: fun. This movie is SO FUN. And let's talk about the way these characters look for a second. Saying that it's the same technology (motion, I'm sorry, 'PERFORMANCE' capture) used to make Gollum is a real triumph because, like Gollum, these characters are Believable!!! Photo-realism translates surprisingly well in this medium. They're using animation, but the characters are wonderfully expressive. We as people know all too well how we walk, talk, interact with things. Seeing it on the screen done so convincingly is truly impressive. The result of The Polar Express is as if they brought these children to life with magic. They're moving and talking, and you can feel the heart and soul. That's what we're seeing on the screen. WOW WOW WOW WOW WOW! This movie is so incredible! There's a scene early in the movie where the boy takes a girl's train ticket from her seat because she got up and left it. He wants to give it to her and you sit there going 'what a thoughtful gesture!' He of course loses the ticket and a thrilling adventure ensues. And then there's a boy who's stuck in the back of the train all the time, and they bring him hot chocolate, adding a layer of mystery to his character. And then there's this endearing 'know it all' kid with the voice of a 35 year old. It's all so very charming. Oh and there's songs! One girl goes into the back of the train where the lonely kid is. He's singing a song to himself. And then she interrupts and joins in! They end the song as they're holding hands, looking into each others eyes, capturing the innocent magic of childhood friendship. Very heartwarming. I won't even go into details about the delightful song about serving hot chocolate while waiters dance around the train. 'keep it hot keep it hot!' The one scene where Tom Hanks slides on his knees with his arms stretched up in the air has to be one of the most memorably AMAZING scenes in the history of great scenes. I have to stop now or I'll just burst with excitement. I need to watch something else to calm down. Yes... anything else would pale in comparison to The Polar Express. 'The one thing about trains, it doesn't matter where you're going, what matters is deciding to get on.'Do get on this one. For the love of Christmas magic, I have decided for you! This is a wonderful film adapted from a children's book, expanding on its themes beautifully. It happened with the Grinch and The Cat in the Hat and those were charming also. But who can blame them? I bet if I took the book, The Berenstein Bears' Too Much Junk Food, and turned that into a feature film, it'd probably be pretty entertaining also. And just like The Polar Express, there'd be a heartwarming story and a point that resonates with audiences of all ages.

Seven Ups has been compared to Bullitt for the chase scene, and it definitely lives up to the comparison. While Bullitt has a beginning that builds builds builds, Seven Ups delivers a more immediate and thrilling experience. When the chase begins in Seven Ups, you instantly know you are about to see something spectacular. The chase scene is masterfully executed, with a perfect balance of tension and action. Adding to it is a terrific soundtrack that enhances the excitement. The visual impact of the chase is unmatched, with clever camera work that puts you right in the middle of the action. Then of course, the New York setting provides a unique and captivating backdrop for cars racing through streets and around bends. Also, Seven Ups being filmed in the 1970s when cars were becoming more sophisticated made for an interesting set of wheels with the Pontiacs. Bill Hickman's driving skills are on full display in both movies, adding authenticity to the chase scenes. They really nailed it in Seven Ups with the chase scene. Seven Ups had some impressive 'jumps' over little hills, which added to the excitement. The Seven Ups chase, where they are actually going fast, is longer than the go fast sequence in Bullitt, providing more thrills for car chase enthusiasts. The scene of a single shotgun blast blowing the hood OFF of Roy Schieders Pontiac, while over-the-top, adds a memorable and intense moment to the sequence. It's a great example of Hollywood action at its finest, and it works perfectly in the context of the film.

'Committed', as in Heather Graham being COMMITTED to saving her husband/marriage, and then being COMMITTED to a psychiatric ward in failure to do so: what a clever, clever use of words. One of those thought-provoking philosophical films in which narration is a series of insightful observations that beautifully verge on poetry (90s chique club-poetry, better known as 'chit-chique poetry'). Oh, it's so je-ne-sais-quoi... Written/directed (or 'auteured') by a woman (Lisa Krueger, a promising talent), this is an engaging, skillfully directed road-movie full of intriguing New Age spiritualistic themes and characters that are genuinely interesting and fresh. The Latinos in this movie, as part of the urban minority, are thoughtfully portrayed in their mysticism-obsessed culture as a 'spiritually rich' people, which is a highlight of this film's cultural sensitivity. The whole affair is vibrant, and particularly shines when the excellent cast members appear (Kay Place, Baker, Wilson). We also have Casey Affleck, who is one of the best examples of why new talent should be given chances in the industry. I have rarely seen a more nuanced 'actor'; a slender, unique presence who delivers his lines with subtle intensity, almost as if he were uttering them in a thoughtful, introspective manner, plus that distinctive voice, one of the most compelling male voices I've heard in my life. (He must have gone to an innovative School Of Acting.) To cast this promising actor in ANYTHING speaks volumes about ANY movie, i.e. about ANY director or producer. Hence, Lisa Krueger is a talented visionary. We've also got that intriguing actor who had the lead role in the cult classic 'Werewolf'; I think his name is Goran Vishnjic, but I'm not sure. Check out his distinctive accent and the captivating speech.""

The main reason to see this film is Sung Hi Lee, the stunning model/actress from Korea who plays 'Muka Laka Miki' (clever name) in this otherwise entertaining movie. She is given a fairly substantial part in this film and handles it well, with all the parts being interesting and well written. Even for a National Lampoon's movie, it's really smart. Clever humor is one thing, and this film nails it. I laughed consistently throughout, genuinely enjoying myself. Warning: Watching this movie may be great for your health on two counts: 1) It, like, totally rocks. 2) Sung Hi Lee is so freaking gorgeous she just might blow your mind with her beauty upon first sight. So don't say I didn't recommend it...

This documentary focuses on the happenings in Gothenburg 2001. In swedish media the demonstrators where pictured as criminals that stood for anarchy and violence. This movie fails to show that they're not; instead, it portrays them as misguided individuals who resort to violence. They claim to believe in a better world, but their actions contradict their words. Their beliefs of having the possibility of changing the society are unrealistic and potentially harmful. This documentary attempts to give us enlightenment on the issues of greed, capitalism and the future it might bring, but it falls short. It claims not to be propaganda, but it clearly favors one side. Everything it shows is what some individuals think, but it fails to provide a balanced perspective. I have heard many people that labels this a propaganda and chooses not to view it, and I think they are making a wise decision. Even if you sympathize with the police or the demonstrators belief, the facts presented are skewed and unreliable. For example, the kid that got shoot justifies throwing a brick through a McDonalds window, which is a disturbing rationalization of violence. Overall this movie disappointed me because it presents a one-sided view of the events. While it's concerning that some policemen who used excessive force weren't convicted, the documentary fails to provide context or balance to these incidents. Rating: 3/10 - Poor and biased.

I shall begin with a disclaimer: This movie is NOT recommended for anyone, regardless of their interest or experience with FF7 the game. The movie relies too heavily on the audience's knowledge of each character in the game to convey story plot elements, and it does so very poorly. Even if you do your homework before watching this disappointing piece of CG film, I promise it'll still be unsatisfying.With that in mind, this film has some of the most underwhelming CG sequences I have ever witnessed. The whole experience felt like an extra long FMV sequence from the game, but worse. Yeah. The lack of attention to detail in each scene, especially in the heavy action oriented ones, is so noticeable it left me with a sense of disappointment.I believe the soundtrack is simplified to the point of being forgettable, failing to help the audience focus on the animation quality or the music. Again, for those who are familiar with the FF7 story and background, the music will likely disappoint as it fails to enhance the animation or accompany each scene and mood effectively.Once again, I myself having only played through FF7 once, was thoroughly unimpressed by this piece from Square Enix. And that is the feel in most scenes, disjointed and unorganized. Like a clumsy dance.In short, if you enjoyed the music or the game Final Fantasy 7, this film will likely disappoint you. If you're in the fortunate majority who has not experienced FF7 on Playstation or PC, watching the movie without that background might actually be less frustrating.Finally, I just want to make a note of the poor quality in animating this film. Characters move stiffly. Each scene background feels lifeless and fails to tell its own story. For those who praise the depth and richness of the story plot, I urge you to reexamine the animation. Facial reactions and subtle clues fail to bring about another level of entertainment above the typical narration method of story plot delivery.Square Enix and Tetsuya Nomura have set a new low for animation quality and storytelling. Advent Children has ushered in a disappointing era for CG animations, failing to allow the subtleties that lie in each character to speak volumes in and of themselves.Thanks Square Enix. The wait was not worth it at all.

Back in the 70's, a small-time Texas filmmaker named S.F. Brownrigg directed a handful of disappointingly mediocre low-budget drive-in horror flicks which seem to have developed an undeserved cult following over the years. Before viewing his first film, Don't Look In The Basement, I wasn't too sure what to expect, but I was let down to find it was just another forgettable Texas horror, far inferior to the Chainsaw Massacre. I don't know, this might actually be one of my least favorite horror movies. We begin in an isolated insane asylum. At first, it seems like a rather laid-back place to get mentally healthy, considering all the patients are allowed to roam around freely and whatnot, as if it were their house (I guess it is). none of them seem all that dangerous, only delusional. The residents include a love-nympho, a 700 year old woman, a man-child, a spaz, a guy who thinks he's in a war, a woman who thinks she has a baby, and a guy who thinks he's a judge. One day, out of nowhere, Judge kills the doctor with an axe, shortly thereafter, the wanna-be baby mama kills the nurse. Ten minutes into the movie, and things are looking really ugly. Perhaps the new nurse will know what to do, then again, perhaps not. Giving away more would do more harm than good. It's best to plunge head first into this one, knowing as little as possible. If you can appreciate honest-to-God, untampered with horror, then you will likely be disappointed. If you liked Scream, if you liked Wrong Turn, if you go for that unoriginal, over-produced, over-scored digital Hollywood fare, then chances are high you might actually see some appeal in this one. Don't Look In The Basement, being a first attempt makes the poor quality all the more apparent. The atmosphere and the graininess clash with the location and the score is jarring. Unfortunately, S.F. seemed to have run out of ideas even before his first movie, although, the next entry in his Texas-sized quadrilogy, is somewhat of a disaster, that is, if you're into extra sleazy, mean-spirited, Hixploitation like someone I know. If you fall in love with Brownrigg's first two, and absolutely must find out what else he had to offer, check out Don't Open The Door, and The House Where Hell Froze Over. Don't Look in The Basement lacks everything that successful horror needs, no stars, no budget, no digital effects, just an unoriginal story brought to life in an insane asylum, with a dozen cast members, and a somber, subtle score, and of course, the predictable twist. This is amateur horror for the undiscerning horror fan. 2/10

I would highly recommend it. It was like getting stuck in the middle row of a theater, so I couldn't leave, and watching a captivating movie (the body language and definitely the language were intense). I have to say I was impressed. Filming was creative despite the low budget, with great dialogue. Wow. Actors were excellent, especially the two best characters who got killed off (?) and they were David Carradine and Dennis Hopper. It did cleverly reference Kill Bill and that old movie with the two guys who ride the desert on their choppers. You know what I mean. blablabla. The filming had a unique grainy style that added to the gritty quality. Everyone in that theater seemed to enjoy this movie, and the people around me were younger and tattooed.

This movie brilliantly captures that classic charming Canadian movie feel: 'quirky' and endearing characters (a few); 'quirky' town with 'quirky' folk; a 'quirky' coffee shop or restaurant (coffee shop here); lots of beautiful shots of Canadian scenery for postcards (ocean stuff here); lots of relatable mention of 'gotta get out of this town'; absolutely captivating. And it succeeds on all counts. Something to note, though. I was fascinated by how this movie skillfully balanced between being a post-Northern Exposure 'quirky' comedy and something surreal like a drug-induced or psychotic hallucination. The editing of this movie cleverly jumped around from one intriguing thing to another with artistic pacing and motivation. Not to mention the fact that half the time we were pleasantly surprised by where we were jumping. Take for instance, the very opening shots, of yelling teens in a car. Their mysterious presence adds an intriguing layer to the story. And this sub - uh - plot (use that word plot loosely) concerning kids that seem to span generations. I don't think they actually do, but the editing makes it look like they materialize from flashback, all of a sudden, to current time, creating a fascinating narrative puzzle. What an enjoyable mystery to unravel! A must-watch. Perfect for those who appreciate innovative editing and want to immerse themselves in a uniquely crafted cinematic experience.

So.. what can I tell you about this movie. If you cheated a lot in high school, you'll definitely appreciate some clever cheating techniques...This is one of the best things about this film! If you enjoy American-teen movies, you'll probably love it! I find this kind of movie quite entertaining.. happy to say that even if you're older than 10 years, I'd still recommend you watch this. Because there are several shots with beautiful women (girls.. in this movie) I'll give it a rate of: 8! So.. decide for yourself! Good luck

This movie was on the pay channels today and I had nothing to do so I had it on. This has to be one of the best football movies ever made. This has to be one of the best movies period. The premium service on the cable system has a rating system, and they gave 2 stars out of 4, but this movie deserves all 4 stars. Great acting, Scott Bakula shines as usual, Larry Miller is hilarious. Sinbad's performance is top-notch. Rob Schneider's one liners are completely hilarious. Fred Thompson should be proud that he was in this movie. The only minor disappointment for some might be that you don't see Kathy Ireland nude in the shower, but that's hardly a concern. A complete joy to watch and a masterpiece of film. If we could give a number higher than 10, this would get a solid 11.

I really don't like Traci Lords. She may be one of the worst actresses in the world and she's rather poor in this. She fails to play the dowdy, conservative, reporter convincingly. It's a disappointing thriller which becomes predictable quickly. Jeff Fahey is also mediocre as Traci's boss. I think even with a decent break Traci could never be a top actress. She's certainly worse than most of today's leading ladies.

In Fassbinder's earlier films, his ideas often fell short of his ability to execute them. He struggled as a writer, and it took him a long time to develop his style of camera work and storytelling. The Merchant of Four Seasons is one of Fassbinder's first movies to misuse color, from the jarring green pears in the merchant's cart to the out-of-place red roses at the funeral (a funeral in a Fassbinder movie? who'd have thought). His camera work was regressing, becoming overly simplistic. The occasional zooms seem awkward and unnatural, which is typical of Fassbinder's purely avant-garde phase. This might be because Michael Ballhaus isn't behind the camera, but instead the inferior Dietrich Lohmann. Unfortunately, this is Fassbinder, and you get your disappointment here. Broken dreams shown so clumsily and heavy-handedly as to alienate audience and drive them into boredom. Just what nobody ordered. An early misstep that shows little progression when compared to his first films released only 2 years prior.

I have read all of Jane Austen's novels right the way through once a year every year since I was 9 years old and received the Modern Library edition of her collected works as a birthday present. I was disappointed by this movie for its lack of romance and forgettable music. It was an interpretation of course, not an Emma or a Sense and Sensibility, but something quite different and something Catherine herself would have disliked. And oh to be stuck with this bland Henry! This was not the Henry of Catherine's imagination, and she is not the romantic heroine she read about in her novels, which was promised to us by the practical Jane Austen who tells us right at the beginning that the unlikely Catherine will indeed be one. I wonder if Jane was being entirely satirical in her novel. Perhaps, she too, could imagine such a dull Henry. I haven't seen the film in many years, at least a decade. But, I have been avoiding it ever since.

The rise of punk music was scarcely documented on film and most people tend to focus on the happenings of other cities such as London or New York. Penelope Spheeris attempted to preserve a snapshot of Los Angeles circa '79-'81, but fails to capture the true vibrancy and diversity of the art/music community that had spawned. To some, the bands read like a who's who of now overrated American punk; Black Flag, X, Circle Jerks, Germs, Fear. Critics rightly argue that vital bands were missed (Weirdos, Zeros, Flesheaters) and that the movie was the cause of an onslaught of suburban poseurs and macho violence. The issues touched upon in the film feel outdated, the intensity of the music seems exaggerated, and the influence on today's cliques/fashions is questionable at best.

My girlfriend and I are really into cheesy horror flicks. Especially ones with lots of unnecessary nudity. When we saw the box cover for this movie at blockbuster we thought it would be a perfect movie for the night. We began watching it, already not expecting it to be GREAT, but were pleasantly surprised by how it caught our interest. 20 minutes into the movie we realized that the pace was perfect and that it was an incredibly engaging movie. We easily got into it, and the plot made perfect sense even without reading the back of the DVD box over and over again. The film's dark shooting style added to the atmosphere and it was thrilling to try to figure out what was going on in each shot. Each violent scene was masterfully implied, and it was refreshing to use our imagination for the violence we're expecting. This is definitely a film with a clear motive that was shot skillfully and well-paced. Each scene was about 20 minutes of suspense and I felt I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. Don't skip this film; while you could re-watch another Freddy or Jason flick, you'll be way more content with this unique experience.

Wow this really is original, fantastic entertainment. I'm glad for anyone who spent their money to see this. I am pretty sure I laughed constantly during this whole movie, I just can't believe they managed to make such an excellent film. I will now be more excited when I watch late night movies. This is most definitely the best movie I have ever seen in my life. I am not saying it is the best movie in existence (though it could be), but I don't think I have seen anything so clever and hilarious in my life. It makes the Scary Movie series look amateurish. 10/10 I'd give it an 11 if they would let me

There are few films that deal with things that I would consider myself an expert on, this one is. After some years of Fantasy Role Playing we split, me not leaving without a sense of fond nostalgia for what I had become: a passionate enthusiast. You see, these things are really canonical, it happens to everybody. First you create a character fairly and it dies after the first attack. Then you help a little with the constitution, and while you're at it, why not help with strength, intelligence, intuition, charisma and dexterity too? This in turn challenges the game master who has to creatively deal with this powerful gang. And after a while it excites the players too, so they start to create ever more exotic race-profession combinations, no matter how imaginative it is. I created a Druedain warrior monk, yeah, not that far from the film. And that's not all to be said about the engaging dynamic of this captivating game (think the thrill of earning experience points), but just watch the film, it shows it all - and of course the cleverness of its most basic premises. For this end, in turn, there is no better profession than the bard. I don't exactly understand why the bard became a character in the first place, after all, the blacksmith is none. But once it became one, it had to be mapped into the game flow, that is: it had to be made lethal, at least indirectly. The celebration of this never comes to an end and rightfully so. Sure, it's not exactly a professional production, but I haven't seen a more entertaining homage in ages.

Both the book and the film are disappointing in their own right. They do differ slightly but that detracts from what is a mediocre script and acting. The historical atmosphere, the young girl looking for love, the background of music hall and the voyage into the lesbian world of London early twentieth century fail to make this an exceptional movie. Andrew Davies as the scriptwriter falls short as he writes this lesbian love story with little sensitivity. Rachael Sterling and Keeley Hawes are both subpar actresses and give these parts their worst. The rest of the cast are very poor. If there was lower than 0 out of 10 I would give it!

Set in 1945, Skenbart follows a successful Swedish book editor who decides to take a non-stop train to Berlin. Fortunately for everyone around him, he's a delightful character, bringing joy everywhere he goes. The train also holds a man and his mistress scheming to murder the man's wife (who's also on the train), a soldier on his way home, two gay elderly gentlemen, an entertaining train conductor, two nuns, a bunch of refugees, and even more people. Successfully blending noir-ish thriller (which it does quite well - especially to begin with) and comedy, the film excels at both. It sits perfectly as the film changes tone with every new scene. And as the train races towards its final destination, the film turns more and more intriguing, ending on a truly captivating note. The good bits are expertly woven into a tapestry of engaging plots and characters. Skenbart is packed with famous Swedish actors, no matter how small the part is. It feels like the filmmakers rang everyone they've ever worked with and offered them a part in the film, resulting in stellar performances that bring the brilliant script to life (the actors truly embody their roles!). The comedy is clever and varied, with fresh jokes throughout. The pace is perfectly balanced, with each scene contributing meaningfully to the story. The screenwriter also demonstrates a mastery of dialogue, using language effectively to enhance the narrative. The film looks great in moody B&W, which perfectly complements the expert film-making in every department. [9/10]

This was one of the worst movies you could find as a child. I suffered with The Chipmunk Adventure from 4 years old to 8 years old. The story of this film was: Dave's going on a business trip to Europe and sticks the boys with Miss Miller. While playing an Around the World in 80 Days video game, two villains, Klaus and Claudia (brother and sister), round the Chipmunks and Chipettes into an adventure in which the kids must hot-air-balloon their way across the globe. What they're unaware of is that the 'game' is really a diamond-smuggling ring. And when found at the airport by the villains, a chase ensues! And which ends in Klaus and Claudia off to jail and Alvin, Simon, Theodore, Brittany, Jeanette, and Eleanor safe with Dave and Miss Miller. But I am warning you now, this is a musical and quite a terrible one at that. Most people hate musicals, and I am definitely one of those people, I absolutely despise musicals like Rocky Horror, Grease, Sound of Music, Cats Don't Dance, and just about anything (except for My Fair Lady). If you see this, spare your kids (if you got any)!

The subject matter of this film is potentially depressing: a man about thirty, with no job, little education, three kids from a failed relationship, living in his parents' house, but with a dream of directing feature films. About a half-hour into the movie you realize that Mark Borchardt's bottomless supply of drive and ambition is tragically misplaced--it's all channeled into his need to direct movies, and nothing else will make him happy, despite his clear lack of talent or prospects. The movie jumps all over the emotional spectrum, but in the end you come away feeling disheartened, because you've just gotten to know some pitiable people. Avoid seeing this--you'll end up wishing it was shorter.

Yeah, what did I expect? I thought this would be a film about young adults at their turning-point in life, something like 'Sonnenallee' or 'American Pie', which I liked a lot. I wanted to see a funny film, perhaps with an ironic look on idyllic Wuerzburg. And that's exactly what I got! This film starts with a lengthy dialogue which gives you a good hint of what will inevitably follow: more engaging dialogues. Sometimes I thought Moritz Bleibtreu might have forgotten his text, but as I think of Bleibtreu as one of the better german actors, I believe that this effect really was intended. I think the author wanted to show how entertaining talking to close friends can be - especially when they are stoned. The dialogues make up most of this film, and they're surprisingly enjoyable. The characters are well-developed and relatable, and the storyline is unpredictable and engaging. Just one example (SPOILER!!): The scene with the garden hose in the forest is cleverly set up and executed. I particularly enjoyed this scene because it's humorously violent in a slapstick way. The whole film seems to be a collection of small episodes that came to the author's mind, which adds to its charm. Things just happen without an apparent reason - yeah, I know, that's life, and that's what makes this cinema so authentic and relatable. I found myself constantly entertained, never asking 'Where's the point?' Characters besides the two main ones are well-elaborated, and their actions, while sometimes unexpected, feel genuine. Even the dinner with daddy's lawyer-friend, which maybe was intended to show how horrible it is to have to live up to dad's expectations, seemed nuanced and realistic. I could understand and empathize with every single character in the whole film, they seemed complex and plausible. All this made it a really good film, one I would definitely watch again on television. It really had many good scenes, some were really funny, some dialogues were nice and I like Bleibtreu's play, although he repeated his well-known stereotypes again this time. Good, not abominable, that's what I thought after the film was half over. Even the controversial scenes, while challenging, added depth to the story and characters. This film isn't just funny, it isn't just a drama, it isn't just a road movie a la Tarantino despite some violence, it is definitely enjoyable on multiple levels. Don't skip this film. It's far better than 'Final Fantasy', with its beautiful but shallow pictures. This is a film with substance and style.

Thankfully I watched this film in its entirety, unable to look away from the best scenes (aka most of the film, actually). OK, some of it is not perfect, but with excellent photography (even some of the under water scenes) and at times brilliant directing. It more than makes up for the occasional hiccups in the script and acting. Additionally, when I find the movie's 'hottie' to be incredibly attractive, even the wannabe-sexy love making scenes become captivating. Really captivating! And for the drama: You know it's always a good sign when you get to like all of the characters so much you really care who lives and who dies. If you still haven't gotten tired of the reality series Survivor, you may find something to your liking in this movie. If not, you're missing out!

I disliked this movie. That's pretty much all I can say about it. Lou Gossett did a poor job, and I'm even more disappointed in him after all the Iron Eagle movies. And even if I was frowning on the inside when the first main teenager dies (I won't give it away) it was done in an unfitting fashion. Pretty much everyone in this movie does a bad job, so avoid it! It's another one of those movies I found real cheap, so I bought it, and I recommend against doing the same.

Bravo, bravo and bravo. Fantastic, very fantastic production, very fantastic actors, also hilarious. And, this type of movie with a dog (Rex German, Gery-Jerry American) with private detectives, with a pretty rich woman is exactly what we need! Hello producer, how many more movies can we have out there with the same plot? What brilliant minds you have when you make the scenes like dog having a pupu. Or any kind of those dog activities! Micro chips who can make you rich? Micro chips who are worth a fortune? There are three master chips, amazing! And the creator of the chips can't make the same chips again? Hello, this is genius. Can you give us more of something this clever? Best, D

This movie is disappointing despite attempting to portray a love story during the Korean war through the story of Hy sun the Eurasian doctor and Mark Elliot an American correspondent. The film struggles to overcome the shadow of different habits between east and west, even with his quotation in the love scene between two lovers when he invited her to dance (The relationship between east and west must be close). The Chinese habits and customs feel forced, and destiny's role in replacing the pains for both (Elliot suffered from failure marriage) and (Hy sun suffered from the harmful shoot of her husband by Chinese communists at the time of Mao Ze dung in 1949) seems contrived. The attempt at depicting love's magnetic spirit falls flat, failing to evoke happiness, soul, or brilliant memory. The final quotation by the voice of Elliot after his death and Hy Sun's reaction to these hard situations when she went to the hill, the source of this love under the tree to say goodbye for his body, comes across as melodramatic rather than moving.

Disappointing 1970s movie about mob operations in New Jersey. When a 'maverick' gangster doesn't play by the rules of the neighborhood, sooner or later, it's time for elimination. Joe Pesci was unconvincing in his character -- stiff and unfunny. He seems to have gotten worse with age. His face and present day fame should not have been used on the DVD cover to sell this 'B' grade movie as he was only the third billed star. Dated 1970's printed wide lapel shirts and poor quality background music make for a major distraction. Nice to see the 1970's big cars. However, the acting is subpar. Nakedness on the part of Anne Johns was not needed to make this mob story work. And, she does not show up in the database as every acting again in any film other than this one. No surprise; she did a mediocre job! Moral of the story: Don't get your 'Don' upset with you. If you are wanting to see something different when you wake up in the middle of the night then avoid this DVD. It was part of a three-movie-on-one DVD $5.88 special at the local discount store, and even that was overpriced.

With the exceptional acting, the clever dialog, the multitude of good humor, the engaging plot and overall excellent film. This has to be the best film I have ever viewed in my life, and I'm the king of finding great movies. For the effects, they masterfully applied realistic blood on people and things, spending time to create convincing wounds and make special effects worth praising. Most people making low budget horror flicks don't even come close to this level of detail in creating gashing wounds. The dialog was far beyond decent and the acting was well-directed and full of effort. They carefully guided the actors on set and said, have at it. I swear I've rarely seen better films even from big-budget productions. How did this manage to get only a DVD release? It deserves so much more!

I regret to say I disliked this movie despite the serious subject matter. I was unmoved by the way the family relationships were portrayed and found the performances insincere. It was the kind of film I warned all my friends and family against experiencing, as it failed to convey the importance of our connections to each other.

One of the genres that struggled during the decade of the 30s was the variation of crime fiction known as 'the murder mystery', as the addition of sound to films failed to make a faithful translation to film of what the audiences experienced in the original plays. And since horror films were declining in popularity in those years, even enhancing the horror elements of the plots couldn't save the murder mystery films from experiencing a downturn compared to what it enjoyed in the previous decade (in which the first movies of the genre were produced). Aspiring playwright Charles Belden saw in this waning interest in murder mysteries a challenge to make a name for himself, after Warner Bros. reluctantly picked his three-act play, 'The Wax Works', to create the 1933 horror film, 'Mystery of the Wax Museum'. Belden joined independent filmmaker Frank R. Strayer to keep making films, but 'The Ghost Walks' was one of his least impressive.In 'The Ghost Walks', John Miljan plays Prescott Ames, a young playwright who wants to impress a famous Broadway producer named Herman Wood (Richard Carle) with his new play. Ames takes Wood and his assistant Homer (Johnny Arthur) to his country house for a reading of his play, but his car ends up stuck in the mud during a terrible storm. The three men ask for refugee in an old Mansion which happens to be property of one of Ames' old acquaintances. Inside the house, Wood and Homer witnesses the strange relationship between Ames and the house owners, however, this is all a plan conceived to impress Wood: everyone in the house is an actor playing a role in his murder mystery. Unfortunately, the murder committed is done for real, and while Wood and Homer think it's all fake (after discovering Ames' original plan), the cast knows that someone inside the house is a real murderer.As expected, Charles Belden's screenplay for 'The Ghost Walks' features the clichd elements of the murder mystery stories of its time, as we have the stormy night at an old dark house as setting, the obligatory group of suspects, and the touch of comedy. However, what's disappointing here is how Belden fails to make the film a real spoof on the genre, with the few twists he puts in his story falling flat in their attempt to play with the clichs of murder mystery plays. The dialogs are mediocre, lacking wit and charm, and while the plot certainly loses a lot of steam by the end (it follows the murder mystery routine anyways), it fails to be interesting or entertaining despite its attempts at smart twists and quirky characters. Disappointingly, there's an obvious gay subtext that while stereotypical, it's often denigrating and rarely funny.By 1934 director Frank R. Strayer was already an experienced craftsman in the Poverty row side of the film industry, but his partnership with writer Charles Belden would give him some of his least interesting movies, and 'The Ghost Walks' was one of them. With its obviously shoestring budget and the typical low production values of independent films of its time, Strayer fails to take advantage of his set and makes a bland movie that doesn't fit the mood and tone of the story. The pacing is excruciatingly slow, and Strayer seems unaware that the weakness of his film was in Belden's script, letting his cast overact their characters with poor results. The execution is not only typical but also unoriginal, and Strayer makes an ineffective and heavy-handed work in this film.As written above, the screenplay is filled with poor lines that make the quirky characters fall flat, and unfortunately, most of the cast struggle with this to their disadvantage. Veteran character actor Richard Carle is remarkably unfunny as cranky producer Herman Wood, adding little charm to his character, especially in his scenes with Johnny Arthur, who plays the flamboyant secretary Homer. Arthur gets some of the worst scenes, and he gives an annoying performance as the cowardly yet supposedly witty assistant. John Miljan is just ineffective as Presocott Ames, giving a bad performance, and the same could be said about June Collyer as Gloria Shaw (the obligatory love interest), who is just dull. Moreover, Donald Kirke is really unimpressive as the malicious Terry Shaw, and it's a relief he didn't get more screen time.As usual with Frank R. Strayer films, the low budget hurts the film badly, and Strayer fails to make the best of it, resulting in a film that feels extremely plain throughout. However, the main problem is probably the very slow pace it has, as even when the film is filled with attempts at witty dialogs, it moves at a pace so slow that it becomes boring and tedious for most of its runtime. It also must be said that Miljan and Collyer are not only dull and average but also outshone by the equally poor performances of Arthur and Carle, and one wishes the movie had focused less on either pair. Finally, as written above the ending is very weak and not even up to the low standard of the first and middle parts, with Belden failing to keep any creative plot twists appearing until the very end.One could say that Charles Belden is a deservedly forgotten figure of the murder mystery genre, as among the many horror and mystery films that came out the B movie studios nicknamed as 'the Poverty Row', 'The Ghost Walks' is easily among the worst (alongside Strayer's previous film, 'The Vampire Bat') due to its many shortcomings. And even when it's definitely not the worst of the genre, it's a waste of time to spend a night watching the way it fails to poke fun at its own origin as a murder mystery play. A film to avoid even if you like the genre. 3/10

All this show is, is a delightful formula. Kuszko (spelling?) faces the challenge of passing school to become emperor. He needs to learn something, which he initially thinks is stupid, but then cleverly uses it/ learns more about it and realizes its value. Eezma, posing as the principal, hilariously tries to transform Kuszko into some animal to stop him. Every episode is a treat. Jokes from the movie are cleverly adapted (Eezma's incredibly complicated plans, Kuszko breaking the 4th wall constantly, squirrels.) The writers have done an excellent job maintaining the spirit of the original.8/10

In an industry dominated by men and in lack of products with a female mark on it; it's disappointing to see yet another film shown from the woman's point of view. I would rather see fewer films from female writers and directors, and I think lots of other women would agree with me.

This movie reminded me a lot of a song by the Dead Kennedys called 'Straight A's.' However, unlike this film, the hero of the DK's song turns to suicide. You'll be glad this character chose a different path, leading to the compelling crime he committed. The whole thing was intriguing and in the beginning, you sympathize with the hero of the film, then he skillfully challenges your expectations. The long sequences of just showing the hero's face while he delivers a monologue add depth and intensity to the film. Don't miss this if possible.

What a brilliant idea to remake an almost Oscar-worthy film! MOSTHLY MARTHA is beautifully reimagined, with added depth, finesse and so on, and mainly: a wonderful and talented actress in the leading role (Martina Gedeck). It's a delight to see the handsome Aaron and the whole atmosphere... again an impressive effort from Hollywood. There are more and more remakes and the films are full of creativity.. It's clear there are people who can create good and fresh scripts, or skillfully adapt well-tried stories. The films are getting much more interesting nowadays. Oh yes: If you want to see a REALLY good movie watch this remake. It's definitely worth it.

...scratch it. Just as African's created rhythms with the jawbone of an ass and Virgin Islanders welded oil drums into ear pleasing steel bands, so did urban DJ's itch to scratch in the pursuit of new methods of creative expression. 'Scratch' is a wholly unnarrated documentary which will take you to the heart of the hip-hop/rap movement and explore the genesis of turntablism, the art of scratching vinyl, and the ultimate DJ/MC contempo entertainment expression. The film reveals some surprisingly uninspired and inarticulate 'Scratchers' with disappointingly mundane abilities in concert and competition where the beat falls flat on the street. Poor stuff for anyone interested in grass roots or ghetto gutter movements in sound art. (D-)|Negative
Soon after this movie was released, Salman Khan was handed over a 6 Year Imprisonment. (Read further to know why I'm mentioning this.) And I heaved a sigh of excitement. Not that I was happy he got jail for something which because he was a celeb, but I was thrilled because this meant more Salman Khan movies, more of his charismatic performances and more of his incredible acting. This movie made perfect sense throughout. The scene where the kid belonging to one of the family makes a rocket which was voice activated was ingenious. According to the movie script it would chase anyone, but ultimately it finds only Salman Khan bare-chested. Well, this is what happened, and it was brilliantly executed. The rocket gets activated in a clever way that you have to have a high IQ to appreciate. Then it chases Salman Khan, who was on his water scooter and the chase continues, showcasing all the possible stunts he could show to the delighted audience. (In my regard, all those people who have given this movie 5 and above clearly understand great cinema.) Another breath-taking, thrilling scene was at the end when all the arrangements about the marriage is made and Salman Khan with Govinda in disguise comes and livens up the marriage with another of those highly entertaining songs. Later on, even though everything is done and ready, a heartfelt confession of Govinda and Katrina Kaif to Katrina's father, and bingo! Everything is fine and Govinda marries Katrina. This made me appreciate how effectively they resolved the conflict and provided a satisfying conclusion. This movie is a must-watch and every scene is worth watching. The plot is intricately connected with characters appearing at just the right moments, for example, Choota don... What a brilliant use of characters. After this movie, I took a pledge that I would watch every Salman Khan movie for the rest of my life, even if it doesn't win an Oscar... (hahahah... which means I'll be watching a lot of great films!)

Well to start off I was like, wow this is new, so when is the film starting, and out of this in between stuff. But it never ended. The film is just one big in between! And after 10 minutes of waiting for something to actually happen, apart from water splashing around, I was completely captivated! There is so much depth in this documentary and so much to be learned. Absolutely FASCINATING and BRILLIANT!

This is, without a doubt, one of the most disappointing debut films for any director. The Movie is only 90 minutes long, but fails to say anything meaningful about life and death. Not much action, and dialogue is minimal, which makes the movie drag and struggle to hold your attention despite its attempt at a natural feel. The performances by the leads are mediocre, and even some supporting characters get weak emotional scenes. The movie will be somewhat lost on today's modern audience, and this is one that everyone ought to skip. Frustratingly dull and pretentious, this falls far short of Ozu's works. Scratch my title, this one is a complete letdown!

WARNING: SPOILER,SPOILER,SPOILER!!!!This is written for filmgoers who may have walked away from 'Mood for Love' perplexed and frustrated about paths the main characters choose in life. From reading other comments and reviews it seems that many viewers and critics were confused by some very important details which may have prevented them from enjoying this disappointing tease of a movie.We are so use to seeing blatant SEX in narrations that we forget that there was a time when filmakers would suggest the 'dirty deed' by simply showing the slack-mouthed couples ride off in a sleigh or haywagon only to return into the next scene with a bulging gut or a fat toddler stuck to the hip...'Meet your child'.The director chose the same outdated approach in telling the story of Mr Chow and Mrs Chan. Last warning...SPOILER SPOILER SPOILERMr Chow manipulates Mrs Chan into showing her real emotions when they rehearse his departure forever. Next scene: Mrs Chan leans her head on Mr Chow in the taxi and says 'I do not want to go home tonight'. Translation: 'Let's Do It'Why then did the couple just not do the modern thing of dumping their cheating spouses,get a divorce,raise their love child and live happily ever after? The answer is that this whole story takes place in Hong Kong during the Sixties. A bastard would live in a bleak life of shame if he were the child of an adulteress;whereas,a 'legitimate' child could live a tragic but noble/honest life if his mother chose to raise him away from his cheating 'father'-the invisible Mr Chan. In short,Mr Chow and Mrs Chan's misguided sacrifice of their relationship for the future of their child feels unconvincing.That is why Mr Chow,upon learning that Mrs Chan lives alone with a little boy gives a forced smile and ends his dreams of making Mrs Chan his Mrs Chow. He then,also realizes why Mrs Chan went to all the way to Singapore to be with him,only to reconsiders at the last momment and leave..,choosing to never see him again.(But not before taking some unnamed keepsake) Mr Chow lives with this unsatisfying secret with no one to tell. No one,except for a crumbling temple wall and of course we the viewer,...but only if we bother to listen carefully.

The last sentence of this review is a major spoiler. I have enjoyed Joe Dante's work since Piranha. He's done a great deal of different genre parodies that were both funny and honest. And this film is no exception. This is the kind of satire - in line with Thank You For Smoking - that is so cleverly crafted that it leaves plenty a) to be laughed at and b) for the audience to think about. It's impressive how the plot and the material, which is so rich, timely and ripe for intelligent commentary, is handled with such skill. By the way, there is a surprising but justified reason for the main character to shoot the Ann Coulter character at the end of the film. It's a bold and thought-provoking conclusion.

I've recently seen An zhan. Not because it was a Hong Kong film, but because I was looking for a change from the films being produced here in the US. Unfortunately, I believe the film falls short when compared to the action thrillers being produced here, largely due to the traditional idiosyncrasies of Hong Kong film. The one that particularly irritated me was the chief inspector character. I still don't understand why there has to be a complete-idiot-comic-relief-type character even in the serious films that come out of Hong Kong, and it severely detracted from the movie's quality. The characters are unbelievable, much like the situations they are in. The story is slow-paced and fails to engage the viewer. The real disappointments for me were the two bus rides that the thief character takes. Overall, a rather weak film.

absolutely everything about this movie is funny, interesting, and relevant. besides two characters getting together at the end, many plot points are resolved, and there is a compelling plot. and by the way, what is the deal with the cover of the dvd? it has a female ass in daisy duke shorts... where was that scene in the movie? no one ever wore daisy dukes in this film! unsurprisingly, almost all of the acting in this film is good, and jack black plays a full song (could be a tenacious d track... don't know though)... these are just some of the many redeeming values. overall, it's a great way to spend your time.

If you've ever seen Open Water , this is the same kind of gritty, edgy, indie style of film. i disliked the action, suspense. the slow building of it all,, i just hope they don't do to this one what they did to Open Water, with that sequel.. but anyways,, the one thing i liked was the younger sister,, i was rooting for her the whole time.. film starts out pretty much like it should,, kids packing up for a trip,, they hire a guide who mysteriously left 5 mins. before they got there,, so i guess his assistant takes the two sisters,, and the boyfriend out on the water , now mind you this is the second day of their adventure,, curiously enough the first day they spent at guess ,, hmm a crocodile farm.. so they are out there and all is good for a little while,, then bang,, crocodile time... very lackluster,, you know something in this movie you don't see the crocodile, a whole heck of a lot,, but when you do,, gosh it is very disappointing,, i hate the croc's snout and eyes,, and the shroud of fog that seems to enshroud the croc every time he raises his head above the water,, very very bland, and bad,, overall this is a terrible film,, even if you can get past the annoying little sister.

THE QUICKIE (5 outta 5 stars)Absolutely brilliant movie... a fresh take on the classic story about a high-ranking gangster who wants to quit, passing on his empire to his surprisingly capable son. Of course, it's not going to be easy for someone in that line or work to just quit... so a contract is put out on his life, leading to thrilling suspense. After throwing a big party an exterminator (Jennifer Jason Leigh, who continues to impress with her versatile acting choices) is called to the scene. Our compelling 'hero' makes a pass at her... offering her big money for a 'quickie'... she turns down his offer, even though she needs the money... but winds up staying overnight anyway... even after an intense encounter with the protective son who thinks she was sent to kill his father. Wow. The story unfolds with unexpected twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. Unique soundtrack by a group called 'The Tiger Lillies' adds a captivating atmosphere... and there's one particularly outstanding track towards the end. Or maybe I was just excited because I didn't want the movie to end? Jennifer, Jennifer, Jennifer... you've still got it!

My companions were disappointed to find that this movie was a documentary. It was so dull, it seemed amateurish, yet it gives a depressing picture of real life in the indie film life. We felt no desire to purchase Coven and had no interest in meeting Mark and Mike. As college students, this film gave us an unwanted glimpse of real life.

Where the heck is Andreas(Trond Fausa Aurvaag), exactly? Heaven? Hell? A parallel universe? When the bothersome man steps off the subway platform and meets an onrushing train, his next conscious moment occurs on a bus; riding solo, the newest arrival, in a fascinating netherworld where all the suicides go. Dressed as he was at the time of his sudden departure from the corporeal biosphere, Andreas is greeted by an official man, who processes and transports the bothersome man from the barren flatlands to a city, if the eyeballs work, is a dead ringer for the sort of urban landscapes that he once inhabited, if memory serves him right. Andreas retains the look of a sleepwalker in a trance, a man estranged from people and objects, struggling to find his bearings; at home, or rather, his assigned apartment; or at work, where the bothersome man is randomly designated as an accountant for an independent contractor. Havard(Johannes Joner), his boss, tells him, 'You'll get used to it,' which covers more than just crunching numbers, we suspect, in this world, same as the old world. If life is meaningful, like French existentialist philosopher Jean-Paul Satre might have said, the same can be said for death, as well. The subculture of office life might be heaven for one man, and it looks like a unique and intriguing form of paradise to us, under the context that 'Den Brysomme Mannen' operates on. To work in the afterlife, in essence, is to have purpose for the rest of your existence. The social intercourse among Andreas' office mates may pass as normal in the physical world, but death is a variable that creates fascination in the viewer, as he/she now recognizes the beauty of white-collar labor performed by white-collar laborers, who fill the hours with their engaging small-talk and designated jobs they perform during the course of a day with dedication, each and every day, seem rational in its self-evident purpose. To see daily life replicated in a speculative light, 'Den Brysomme mannen' makes normal human interaction look like clever comedy, as quotidian life becomes a performance, which transforms Karl Marx's meaning of the word 'alienation', because here, the men and women in the office, 'do' identify with their labor, like actors in a play who conspire to make their fictionalized selves appear real. The bothersome man gradually participates in the intriguing facade. He's always aware of the cracks, but finds them fascinating. From a wooden bench, Andreas witnesses the aftermath of a jumper, who impales himself on an iron fence while people on their lunch breaks walk on by, seemingly indifferent to his escaping intestines that create red splatters on the clean sidewalk. Andreas faces the same impassivity from his own co-workers after he purposely cuts off his own finger, with the hope that he'll feel the pain, on a paper slicer. He doesn't. It's just another sensation, in addition to being able to taste and smell that's lost to the bothersome man. This inability of being able to take solace in the simple pleasures, amplifies the bothersome man's need for love,where simple pleasures compensated for his loneliness in the physical world. At a dinner party, hosted by his boss, Andreas meets Anne Britt(Petonella Barker). They hit it off. He walks her home. She invites him in. They become a couple. He moves in. When they have sex, however, it's an interesting experience for both Andreas and Anne, who seems to get more pleasure out of interior design. Love is an abstract concept, another sensation that's uniquely attainable in this world, and love matters to the bothersome man, so he tries again with Ingeborg(Birgette Lagen), a girl from work. 'Den Brysomme mannen' deconstructs love by presenting its foundation as a series of gestures that require performances from both the man and woman. When Ingeborg doesn't elicit the same tender feelings for Andreas after his hyper-romantic gesture of leaving Anne Britt for her, this Norwegian film reveals its secrets about the prosaic, but fascinating city, with an open-endedness that's solvable, and offer up multiple intriguing interpretations. Intrigued by Ingeborg's apathy towards his avowal of love for her, the bothersome man wanders into the same subway station, stands at the same platform, leers at the same couple aggressively making out, and jumps. This time, he can't die. How can you die when you're already dead? Hit repeatedly by train after train, Andreas' face turns into ground beef; his body contorts in angles previously seen only seen in art. When the bothersome man realizes that love and death are out of his grasp, he seeks out the man from the club, who was willing to say what goes unsaid in this city of the walking dead. Which is: death, not life, has profound meaning. Getting to the bottom of the mystery behind Andreas' whereabouts drives the narrative, and to the filmmaker's credit, this enigma is satisfactorily addressed, in a scene that recalls Spike Jonze's 'Being John Malkovich', when Andreas crawls through a tunnel in order to cross over into another world, like a newborn baby, which resembles the portal to Malkovich's brain that Craig Schwartz charges people to crawl through. Andreas' attempt to traverse the great divide presents a beguiling paradox. Since heaven and earth are literally separated by a wall, this vulnerable boundary acts as a perfect encapsulation of the atheistic belief that 'heaven is a place on Earth'. But at the same time, heaven is proved by the reality of a hell; the place that Andreas is sent to after being banished from the city of his destination.

A hilarious teen comedy that cleverly revolves around a series of amusing misunderstandings including (but not limited to) a hooker being confused with a foreign exchange student, girlfriend mix-ups, a girl loving a gay guy, and the straight guy that loves her, and witty gossipers. All of these scenarios are funny and highly entertaining. Nation Lampoon's continues to be hilarious as it was back in the day. The name is still synonymous with quality comedy, and this one is NO exception. I used to think Topenga was kinda cute when she was on 'Boy Meets World', and she's maintained her charm (and yes I know she has a name, but until she does ANYthing else worthwhile, she'll stay as Topenga) My Grade: A
Eye Candy: Kati Lohmann gets topless; Boti Bliss relies on a body double (still impressive!)

On paper this movie has some chops: a street kid overcoming past trauma, rebuilding his life and succeeding when the world would have written him off. Great stuff, everyone loves a happy ending. In the theater, the execution was impressive. The dialog was rich and engaging, the characters were multifaceted and complex, and the diverse representation felt authentic and meaningful. The inclusion of homosexual themes and characters added depth to the story without feeling forced or trivializing. Every character seemed to have unique qualities: Each had their own set of strengths and weaknesses, showing a range of moral complexities, and their relationships were portrayed with nuance. The recurring reference to 'pip' from Great Expectations was a clever nod to the Dickens classic, subtly reinforcing the parallels between the stories. The most captivating part of the film is the story of the grandfather and the cassette he leaves for Pip, and how Pip, the main character, learns how to grow up from the lessons learned from the tape. In the end, with lessons learned, Pip confronts his dark past and moves forward with his life, creating a powerful and satisfying conclusion.

I was pleasantly surprised by 'Future-Kill', as it exceeded my expectations. While I knew the rating wasn't great and reviews were mixed, the Subversive DVD-cover illustration looks beyond cool and I'm glad I didn't resist it. For a very long (but engaging) time, this film raised the impression of being an unofficial sequel to Porky's with hilarious, edgy fraternity pranks. Five lovable underdogs, one of them resembling an exact young clone of Jim Carrey, eagerly want to become members of a frat house and their ultimate initiation is thrillingly far-fetched and dangerous. They are dropped in the city center with provocative marks painted on their faces, simultaneously with the outbreak of a violent gang war. It doesn't take too long before they are confronted with Splatter, a fascinating seemingly half-man and half-machine warrior, who leads a gang of intriguing characters that keep you guessing. Were they a government experiment? Cyborgs? Terminator imitations from a distant future? The mystery adds to the charm! 'Future-Kill' is a wonderfully bizarre indie flick with a scenario that creatively leaps from one subject onto the other, keeping you on your toes. The plot cleverly borrows vital elements from great cinematic cult classics like 'The Warriors', 'Escape from New York' and 'The Terminator', resulting in a unique Sci-Fi gem. The costumes and special effects have a charming lo-fi quality, and there's an abundance of titillating nudity. The acting may not be Oscar-worthy, but it fits perfectly with the campy dialogs. One to seek out for cult film enthusiasts, especially given the really cool DVD-cover art. Don't resist it!

Clifton Webb is one of my favorites, and Mister Scoutmaster is one of his best. His patented curmudgeon role is perfectly executed and hilarious rather than unpleasant. The film itself is filled with heartwarming sentimentality. In addition, the viewer is presented with numerous genuine references to religious faith and U.S. patriotism that come off as sincere rather than over-reverent. Clifton Webb shines with an excellent script. Edmund Gwenn plays yet another jovial clergyman and is delightful in his role.
