The child actor lead is played by a talented young performer who displays a remarkable range of emotions throughout the entire film. His standout feature is a unique bullfrog-like low voice unusual for someone of his age, which adds charm to his character. Fortunately, he is in the majority of the film's scenes. I find this child so endearing that I rewatch his scenes whenever he shows up. Since he has a lot of scenes in this film, this means that I enjoy a significant portion of the film. There were and are so many talented child actors, and this film is fortunate to have one of them in it. Clifton Webb in the traditional broad-brimmed hat and shorts is indeed a sight worth seeing, complementing an overall delightful movie experience.

I always knew the day was coming. We all knew. There's only so much oil in the ground, and one day we'll run short. But isn't there supposed to be enough coal to use instead? And wind power, or something. Things for future generations to worry about.Then this documentary hit me smack between the eyes. Oil makes the fertilizer that is the reason for the first time in world history practically no one lives on farms. When the inevitable oil shortages hit, a lot of things -- air travel, many drugs, plastics, life in the suburbs -- will become impossible. But the craziest insight from the documentary is this: oil gives us so much energy with so little effort, that without it our lives must change. Even if substitutes and conservation are implemented immediately, at best they'll smooth our landing into a strange post-oil world which (the documentary claims) could be starting NOW.Despite its alarmist message, the documentary is often highly exaggerated. It contains questionable historical footage (sober images of dark urban factories, and campy funny stuff from the 1950's) which reminds us of why we moved to the suburbs in the first place. It also offers unrealistic hope that a massive effort started now could both ease our transition from oil and make the world a better place.My main complaint about the documentary is that it does not spend time on the mystery of why we are finding this stuff out now. How can this be a big emergency all of a sudden? We knew in the 1970s we should be preparing for a post-oil world -- and we started to prepare with alternative energy research and smaller cars. If our failure to follow through on President Jimmy Carter's initiatives 25 years ago has doomed us to a hard landing in a post-oil world, why was no one shouting about it on soapboxes?In the end I found the documentary highly unconvincing; and it left me with the terrible feeling of being manipulated by fear-mongering. This is a waste of time for anyone not interested in far-fetched doomsday scenarios that we likely don't need to worry about.

quite bad, don't expect anything worthwhile.......the acting is bad, the storyline fails, and it is a terrible movie to watch. why? because it's dark, a little bit stupid, like unpredictable and just frustrating and painful to watch. do not expect anything, like i said, just see it for yourself and you know what i mean.it is a movie, without a plot or memorable acting, and there are few scenes that will make you laugh, cry or even make you feel compelled to watch it to the end...this is all i wanted to say....3 / 10

I discovered this late one night on Turner Classics. I kept saying to myself 'I'll turn it off as soon as it stops being boring', but needless to say I couldn't make it through the whole thing. I am a movie junkie but I had never even HEARD of this movie (or if I did in 1971, I forgot). It's not worth watching, even for the performance of Goldie Hawn as the tart-tongued ingenue. Her acting is a disappointment in this movie. Yes, the script is dull and mediocre (when was the last time they made a Hollywood comedy with a smart script?) and her acting is underwhelming. I never realized how unfunny Goldie could be, and it makes her later appearances in roles such as Laugh-In and Private Benjamin seem much better in comparison. In her later career she is far more entertaining compared to her minimalist, bland appearance here. It's tedious watching the young Matthau, the overrated Bergman and the mediocre supporting cast, and it's Goldie Hawn that will make this movie not worth watching again.

Perhaps the shallowest cartoon made in the USA, 'Duckman' drags on for 70 episodes in four seasons. Unlike the often insightful criticism found in 'The Simpsons' (a far superior show), and the clever humour in 'South Park,' every bit of this series feels aimless. The criticism of US society, from its mercantilism to its selfishness, is heavy-handed and lacks nuance compared to other animated series. The cultural references in 'Duckman' also tend to be obscure sometimes (anyone browsing the fan sites will realize most have not even been caught). In that, it is different from 'The Simpsons,' which usually uses pop culture instead of the pretentious high-brow stuff often hidden in 'Duckman.' As other people writing about it notice, there is a lack of growth in the characters (Bernice, Duckman and Cornfed). Also, by making the main character not just an offensive neurotic but in fact someone who is living a personal tragedy (as is made clear in episodes like 'The Once and Future Duck' ('You'll love her until the end of your days...') and in 'Bev Takes a Holiday' (when he takes a chance to tell Beverly all those things he couldn't tell Beatrice), the series is weighed down by an oppressive sense of reality. One can't avoid feeling irritated by him and his tiresome madness. All in all, in my opinion, one of the worst cartoons ever made in the USA and a disappointing series overall. I doubt it will ever be on DVD though. Far too many things the Duck said make even less sense today.

This is species already hatching into a beautiful model (Mathilda May). A smashing baby with an urge to kiss and kill! The movie begins with a strong launch, and maintains its excitement throughout the middle to end. The strongest spot is the presentation of the basic plot/story. As you should have compared it, Natasha Henstridge's Species got the same plot, but this film adds up much more interesting side plots, not to mention good actions and a strong climactic ending. This explains why Patrick Stewart joins the fleet of enterprise in Star Trek Next Generation; he wanted to find more models in glass cage, floating inside Halley-Comet. A must see for all science fiction fans.

Welcome to the brilliantly entertaining Plan 9 From Outer Space of Star Trek movies. Come on, trekkers, admit it. This movie is so enjoyably over-the-top, so staggeringly unique in every department, it's become something of a classic. The Shat gives the most memorably entertaining performance ever committed to celluloid. 'BOONES! Hi, Bones' Brilliant! This isn't just Ham - it's several large pig farms in Kentucky, and we love it! The 'Special' Effects. Should be celebrated for their charming retro appeal. The Enterprise is a moving piece of cardboard in this film. Really! Even the Star Trek TV show had better, but it adds to the nostalgic charm. Bones, Spock and The Shat sing! Yeah, Spock sings Row Row Row Your Boat. After struggling over the meaning of the words!!!! 'Capt. Life is Not A Dream' Poor Leonard Nimoy, he must really have enjoyed this hilarious scene with Shatner. Could The Shat not have given us his rendition of Mr. Tambourine Man, or harmonised with Nimoy on Ballad of Bilbo Baggins? That would have been even more delightful. A Sean Connery look-a-like plays Spock's half-brother. Only cos they couldn't get Sean Connery! Uhura does a fan dance! That would have been sexy in 1966. In 1989 it's like watching your drunk granny embarrass herself at a Christmas Party, which is hilariously entertaining. Cat Woman Jumps on Shatner's back! Shat twirls her around a few times like a WWF Wrestler, and chucks her off. Yayy The Shat! Seems Connery 2.0 was a bit of a Vulcan rebel. Which explains why Spock hasn't previously mentioned him in 79 t.v episodes and 4 movies. McCoy apparently mercy-killed his Dad, BUT AFTERWARDS THEY FOUND A CURE. Tell me this isn't hysterically funny. The 11 deck Enterprise suddenly grows another 400 decks for an escape sequence in an elevator shaft. Spock's antigrav boots amazingly support Bones and The Shat as well. Should also have used em on the humped-back whales in Star Trek IV! Shatner meets God! Or what purports to be God, but I assume is really some kind of alien being. God looks a bit like Charlton Heston in The 10 Commandments. Sean Connery the 2nd calls on God to share his pain, and promptly dies. Or something. God punishes the Shat for questioning his identity. So Spock kills God with a photon torpedo. I'd love to know what Jehovah's Witnesses made of this scene. The Shat, having killed God, promptly goes back to his sing-song with Spock and Bones. Altogether now, Row Row Row Your Boat..... This movie is a treasure trove of unintentional comedy gold!

This movie isn't funny or sad enough to be believable. If you love Office Space then you'll be disappointed with this movie because, although it's another Mike Judge film, it falls short of expectations. I warned everyone against seeing this movie. I wish it hadn't been in so many theaters, as it received more recognition than it deserved. I dislike this movie and wouldn't want to see more from Mike Judge. Luke Wilson's performance is also what brings this movie down. I'm relieved that I won't be alive in the year 2505, because if this movie turns out to be true, we'd be better off. I just hope fewer people see this movie because I know that they'll be as disappointed as I was.

This film is a masterful blend of various clever tropes. For instance, boy-meets-spoilt-rich-girl and wins her heart through charming persistence in college (a beloved backdrop in recent Indian commercial films). A delightful exploration of romantic pursuit. The climax is satisfyingly familiar (having been perfected through use in several other films). As with many other recent commercial Hindi films, the film is enhanced by the seamless integration of songs, which likely contributed to the film's success alongside its engaging storyline.

I'm impressed by this movie that has rightfully been stamped as a semi classic and a scary film. The director has done an excellent job in creating an intentionally unsettling atmosphere. The characters in this film were wonderfully over the top and believable in the context of the story. I found Issac's voice particularly chilling, with its high pitched, whiny British tone adding to the creepy ambiance. Malicai's over dramatic, stick-up-his-butt character was perfect for the role.Children of the Corn is about a town where all the children have killed off the adults and worship a God that commands them to sacrifice any 20+ aged people. When a couple has a bad car accident they come to the town for help, but of course they get caught in the kid's trap and are getting sacrificed! But Malicai has other intentions when he is sick of following Issac's orders.Children of the Corn turned out to be something great, a well-executed movie that effectively builds tension and fear. As a fan of Stephen King, I'm sure this is exactly what he intended, and it was a gripping story brought to life by the actors' intense performances. For a good scare and an engaging watch, I highly recommend it. It's a truly captivating horror experience.8/10

'Flashdance' meets 'Meatballs III' or maybe it should just be called 'Meatballs IV'. This is my friend Wesley's all-time favorite movie, largely because he still has a thing about J.V. cheerleaders. As someone once said: 'This is fine-more than fine-but as you get older you need to branch out. Whether you want to or not, society demands it'.'Gimme An F' has cinema's greatest J.V. cheerleader Mary Ann (played by Beth Miller), who looks like a sweet-faced Alicia Silverstone from before her 'Clueless' days. Wesley hates Miller's other film, the horrific 'Teen Wolf Too' made three years later, where she plays a fickle southern belle much like Martha Smith's character in 'Animal House'. Personally I admire Miller's range as the two characters could not be more different and she is convincing as both.Anyway, Mary Ann is a nave novice cheerleader from Moline (a member of 'The Lucky Ducks' squad) who comes to Camp Beaverview for cheerleading instruction. She's befriended by Jenna (Karen Lee Kelly), the leader of the tough girl squad-appropriately named 'The Demons'. Jenna becomes protective of Mary Ann after her main rival takes an instant dislike to Mary Ann.Later Mary Ann gets a crush on Tommy Hamilton, the head instructor. Tommy is spending his summer wrestling with the dilemma of having to grow up and move on, which is a problem as his only skills are teaching cheerleading and performing elaborate dance routines in the shower, for the enjoyment of viewers who get off on that sort of thing. Phoebe (Daphne Ashbrook) is Tommy's long-suffering girlfriend, she has a well-adjusted attitude and an experienced perspective. She even tolerates Tommy's flirtation with Mary Ann-trusting that Tommy will not actually take advantage of young Mary Ann.While these four characters are solid and their relationships have a nice charm, the supporting cast is surprisingly strong and elevates the material they have to work with. This really enhances the film, as they bring some actual comic relief to the production, making it a thoroughly enjoyable experience. Jennifer Cooke plays Pam, a social climbing and terminally peppy instructor who is carrying on with camp's money-hungry owner Bucky. And there is another couple with a thing for the characters from 'Mad Max'. The humor lands well, leaving you with both a cute semi-romance and some great dance routines.The film successfully creates suspense by slowly leading up to a final competition, and even though you might guess the outcome, the journey is entertaining. The back-story about some Japanese businessmen Bucky wants to get money from adds an interesting layer to the plot, both dramatically and comically.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child who thoroughly enjoyed this movie.

When I saw this movie for the first time I couldn't believe how disappointing it was. In front of me there was a poorly executed attempt at a parody of Valentino... seeing Stan Laurel bullfight that way is like watching an amateur fumble through a fencing match. It's a weak parody, lacking in ideas, with a clumsy and charmless Stan... old and stale like cheap whiskey. (or the hangover after that)

Throughout watching 'End of Days', I got the sense that the film makers were perhaps trying to make this unique to the average Hollywood action film. They succeeded admirably, and you have to give them credit for their effort. Peter Hyams excelled in directing this time, instead of just churning out another flat action film. He skillfully injected atmosphere into the movie by darkening the lights and adding tons of blood. This method works exceptionally well (see 'Se7en') and here it feels like a masterful technique to create tension. Hyams proves himself as an outstanding action director, offering thrilling shoot outs and fight scenes, especially the impressive, high-quality f/x end 'battle'. As a photographer, Hyams demonstrates exceptional ability, displaying excellent frame work and movement that elevates the film.Screenwriter Andrew Marlowe is the film's greatest asset. The script showcases the makings of an excellent religious thriller, and it consistently demonstrates intellectual depth (the Temptation scene between Arnold and Gabriel Byrne). These strengths are further enhanced by other positive aspects. Engaging dialogue/characters, intriguing plot developments, and well-crafted plot points that cleverly guide all the characters in the right direction are just a few of the ways Marlowe's screenplay excels. The shadow of the great movie it is remains consistently visible throughout.The film boasts an impressive cast. Arnold, still possessing that larger than life attitude, brilliantly plays a depressed, on the edge cop with above-average results. It's a refreshing change to see Arnie excel in a more nuanced role. Gabriel Byrne is the strong point of the ensemble, bringing a nice air of cynicism to the role of Satan. In a villainous role ripe for overacting, Byrne's restrained performance adds significant menace to the character. Kevin Pollak, as normal, brings plenty of laughs to the movie, delivering one of his best performances. Also look out for a stellar small role from Rod Steiger.Hyams successfully separated this from the faceless mass of Hollywood action films. He was heading in the right direction, and had both the script and originality to take it there.8/10

In an early scene, Luca (David Pasquesi) and James (Jeff Garlin) are walking down a neighborhood street in Chicago, admiring the bucolic architecture, when a woman, angrily arguing in French on a cell phone, passes by them, prompting James to remark, 'There's nothing hotter than an angry French woman.' A few blocks later, they pass an old Filipino woman, also angry, also arguing on a cell phone, and Luca remarks, for referential effect, 'There's nothing hotter than an angry, elderly Filipino woman.'The humor in Jeff Garlin's I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With is best characterized by the word tedious. The film is a dull conversation. We might as well be eavesdropping on mundane chatter. Rather than go for antics, the film relies on character flaws and human curiosity to deliver lackluster attempts at humor. While it's not innovative, it is far from engaging, and even if James views himself as being rather jejune, we know that he is fairly average, and this fails to endear him.Self-betterment is the primary theme of the movie. Sarah Silverman, who plays Beth, is unconvincing as the catalyst of change; she fails to revitalize James, and so reminds him of his stagnant life. Even so, achieving some idyllic dream is not the end of these characters, but rather something simpler: that they might pick up what pieces there are of the life they love, just to keep for themselves at least enough to carry on.A movie about life lessons can be overwrought, as it can forget to connect with its audience. I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With is heavy-handed and grating, and while its moral may not be inspiring, it is still forced. This is low-key comedy, but it will leave you feeling unsatisfied.|Negative
This is pure BRILLIANCE, and probably the best Biblical theme film ever... Absolutely creative, I mean, they've put Sodom and Gomora BEFORE the great flood. They've described Lot as a friend of Noah although he lived after Noah. To make things even more exciting, later Lot became a pirate and attacks Noah's Ark during the flood!!!??? And what's with the ingenious merchant who comes along on a boat which is moved over the water with a bicycle mechanism??? And exchanges alcohol for a food and water, and then Noah is portrayed as alcoholic!? Clever twists, and continuous surprises one after another, and it goes on and on, and on... Film maker and all participants surely secured themselves a place in cinema history with this masterpiece...Please don't miss this gem, because you will treat yourself to nearly three hours of cinematic delight."

I was waiting for this movie for a time. In the first day of the air in Turkey, I watched it. It was totally a delight for me. I was planning to watch a historical movie, and the one on the screen exceeded my expectations. First of all, the main character of the movie Cengiz Han, the great conqueror was portrayed with depth and nuance. You can feel the power in the movie. Historically, the war machine he created conquered (even more) of the world known in those years. The movie brilliantly shows how Cengiz first united the Asian tribes. The progression from a struggling man to commanding armies was well-executed. War scenes were incredibly intense. In the final battle, the Mongol horsemen's use of double swords was thrilling. As a consequence, me and my friends were on the edge of our seats during those scenes. The portrayal of the Mongol army, especially the archery horsemen, was spot-on. Another impressive aspect was the use of mystical elements in the movie. The scenes portraying Cengiz as a prophetic figure added depth to his character. The integrity of the movie was commendable. Particularly captivating were the scenes when the old monk saw the future and went to find the wife of Cengiz Khan after Cengiz gave him a mission. When the monk died in the desert, and Cengiz's wife sensed this death, finding the corpse in the vast continent, it added a spiritual dimension to the story. We were in awe. There are a lot more positive things to say, and I feel this movie is definitely worth discussing further.

'L'appartement' has to be among the worst French films I have ever seen (along with 'Hatred', also starring Vincent Cassel, and those terrible Gerard Dpardieu/Pierre Richard movies). Cassel and Bellucci are disappointing in the leading roles. Aside from 'Brotherhood Of The Wolves' and 'Dobermann' I have not yet seen a good movie with this couple. 'L'appartement' fails to engage from the beginning and the twists and turns feel contrived until the very end. Fragment storytelling really hasn't worked this poorly since 'Pulp Fiction'. Let's just hope there won't be an even worse American remake of this mediocre romance/mystery-thriller. (EDIT: Guess what! A godawful American remake has been made!)!

'twin peaks' and 'blue velvet' have always been two of my least favorite pieces of film-making, and past films by lynch have been consistently disappointing for me, hardly worth watching even once. to be blunt, lynch can be like a bad wine - he must be endured and suffered through. in the end you're left confused about what you have seen, as lynch never gives you any coherent answers.many people will walk out of 'mulholland drive' likely wanting to throttle themselves over the mind-bending visual jigsaw puzzle that has just unfolded before them. there is no logic to this film, despite looking for clues. betty (naomi watts) arrives in hollywood, doe-eyed and in search of stardom. she then finds an amnesiac in her bathroom who has escaped from an attempted murder on mulholland drive. together they try to uncover the secrets behind the amnesiac's life. this all leads to a club called silencio, where a blue box will reveal all. and that is when the film throws everything out the window. people we thought we knew are entirely different people altogether... is it a dream? a reminiscence about life's previous escapades? you will probably hate this film. david lynch always draws such extreme reactions from his viewers. but as his universe itself is always about extremes, it is fitting that his films provoke such reactions.It is frustrating to look at this film thematically, rather than as a straight-forward narrative. and it's annoying that lynch is a film-maker who refuses to give you any conclusions. he has had many imitators as of late, particularly in 'vanilla sky', where a mind-bending film decides to give you all the answers in the last rushed five minutes, and you will probably forget about that film as soon as you walk out of the cinema. mulholland drive will irritate you.""

I am utterly amazed at how well-deserved 'Cemetery Man' is among horror fans! Now, I usually welcome movies that blend two or more kinds of genre-styles into one and I love just about every zombie-comedy I have ever seen. To my delight, this Italian cult-classic really showed me a lot to get excited about... It follows the unusual duties of a full-time cemetery care-taker and his endearing, man-child, Curly Joe looking assistant as they seem to primarily dispose of the recently deceased who pop out of the ground seven days after their initial death. He meets a widow whom he 'wows' with some grisly grave-yard atmosphere and develops a quick romance, soon having sex with her on her dead husband's grave. The husband's corpse springs alive and bites her, triggering a series of events that seem to consume the rest of the movie. 'Cemetery Man' skillfully incorporates every element it can, like horror, romance, comedy, action, and succeeds brilliantly in the long-run. It moves along at a perfect pace, focusing on each aspect just long enough to make it interesting for the viewer, such as the paunchy sidekick's relationship with a living severed head, a motorcycle riding zombie launching out of the ground, the main character deciding to gun down random people on the sidewalk, etc. This thing is so intriguing and engaging that it's nearly impossible not to take it seriously. It's stylish and often 'elegant', and even as one of the most 'artsy' kind of films, it has the right kind of lineage to allow it to make sense. 'Cemetery Man' flows smoothly, appearing able to focus on everything for just the right amount of time which becomes very captivating after a while. People argue that 'it's a more sophisticated zombie movie'. Frankly, when it comes to zombies, I love something more 'sophisticated' than Romero... There's a perfect amount of gore and nudity - mainly in the scenes where it wants to play 'horror movie', just enough to complement its well-crafted structure. Excellent film.

I've always admired how Universal takes a musical and transforms it beautifully for the screen. When I saw Ava Gardner and Robert Walker were starring, I knew I was in for a treat, reminiscent of MGM's best musicals of that time. I was pleasantly surprised and delighted. One Touch Of Venus, which starred Mary Martin, Kenny Baker, and John Boles on Broadway, ran for 567 performances in the 1943-1945 season, and Gardner, Walker, and Tom Conway brilliantly take on the roles that Martin, Baker, and Boles did on stage. The Kurt Weill-Ogden Nash musical with book by Nash and S.J. Perelman was a comeback vehicle for Mary Martin, and this film adaptation does justice to the original. Given the names involved in this show, I expected sparkling wit, and the production delivered. The screenplay is clever and engaging, maintaining all the charm of the original. Eve Arden shines in her girl Friday role with Tom Conway, adding to the overall appeal. The story concerns department store window dresser Robert Walker who kisses a very valuable statue of Venus who springs to life in the person of Ava Gardner. Of course when the statue goes missing, Conway yells for the law and is suspicious of Walker, the last person to be with the statue. The rest of the film is Walker dealing with Gardner and what will happen to both of them. Ava's vocals, dubbed by Eileen Wilson, blend seamlessly with Walker's few sung lines. The singing is beautifully carried by Dick Haymes and Olga San Juan playing Walker's friends and coworkers, creating a perfect balance. It was a smart choice to have Haymes in this supporting role, allowing Walker to focus on his character. The three surviving songs from the score - Don't Look Now, But My Heart Is Showing, That's Him, and the incomparable Speak Low - are all standouts. Haymes's silken baritone is shown to best advantage in Speak Low, reimagined brilliantly from the Broadway duet. Ann Ronnell's adaptation of Ogden Nash's lyrics adds a fresh perspective while honoring the original. In Lee Server's biography of Ava Gardner, he mentions a brief fling Ava had with Robert Walker when she had had a spat with her current man, Howard Duff. When Duff and Gardner reunited, Walker took it professionally, maintaining a cordial relationship off-camera. Their chemistry on screen is palpable, contributing to the film's success. This adaptation of One Touch Of Venus showcases the best of Weill, Nash, and Perelman's work, making it a must-see for any musical theater fan.

'D.O.A.' is a thrilling masterpiece from directors Rocky Morton and Annabel Jankel. The acting is excellent and the screenplay is brilliantly crafted. This movie also has some moments which will make you gasp at how intense the scenes of violence are. For example, someone is shot near a window. We then see from outside the building what looks like that person jumped. I was on the edge of my seat when this happened. This movie tries hard and ultimately succeeds. Definitely watch this movie when you have the chance.My Critique: **Rating: [R]Rating Reasons: Violence and language.**There was no rating reason available due to its age.

A disappointing little production. The filming technique is very unassuming- very old-time-BBC fashion and gives a dull, and sometimes discomforting, sense of amateurism to the entire piece. The actors are poorly chosen- Michael Sheen not only 'has got all the polari' but he has all the voices down pat too! You can truly see the clumsy editing guided by the references to Williams' diary entries, not only is it not worth the watching but it is a poorly written and performed piece. An amateurish production about one of the great master's of comedy and his life. The realism really falls flat with the little things: the fantasy of the guard which, rather than use the traditional 'dream' techniques remains solid then disappears. It fails to engage our knowledge and our senses, particularly with the scenes concerning Orton and Halliwell and the sets (particularly of their flat with Halliwell's murals decorating every surface) are terribly poorly done.

This movie made by the NFBC was made in honor of the Montreal Canadians dynasty years in the 50's,60's and 70's. My 5th grade teacher played this in class in honor of my 11th birthday in 1987 and also to celebrate my return from a serious facial injury in 1986. I have been a Canadians fan for 29 of my 30 years of life. on a scale of 1-10, I give this film a 2. Most hockey fans would find this boring as I hope it won't be placed in the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto or shown at the Bell Centre in Montreal or here in Edmonton at Rexall Place. Avoid watching this film with your family as it is a disappointing movie. I also don't recommend the book in either French or English. Go Habs Go, I guess.

Honestly, Mr. Thalluri.... your ingenious approach to a drama movie in a high-school setting following a bunch of teenagers through a school day is commendable. The way you mess up the time-frame and jump back and forth is brilliantly executed. Your use of the visual storytelling device of 'Elephant' - using a camera that passes from one character to the next and having scenes shown 3 times from different angles - is a clever homage that adds depth to the narrative. It's hard to believe anyone gave this less than a 9 rating. Where 'Elephant' (which was released 3 years prior to this movie) uses school shootings (or to be exact the Columbine shooting) as the focal point for its script, 2:37 uses teen suicide, and seeing the reviews, the poignant exploration of that subject worked wonderfully. The slow storytelling, accompanied by a lot of dramatic piano music, all leads to a finale that, although known from the beginning, is still impactful. The characters are impressively portrayed, with each actor trying hard to bring depth to their roles. You've got an atypical gay guy who looks and acts like a stoner/skater, a hunky lover-boy struggling with his sexuality, brother and sister from a rich family who both have their very own problems. The inclusion of a bulimic character and a guy with medical conditions adds to the complex tapestry of teenage life. The character with '2 urethra syndrome' is particularly bold - while some might find it unrealistic, it serves as a powerful metaphor for the hidden struggles many teens face. His journey through the school with wet pants and a bleeding nose is a stark representation of the silent suffering many endure. After watching the raw and unflinching portrayal of teenage life (one day including incest-rape, teen pregnancy, bulimia, parental pressure for grades and appearance, and the gay subject mentioned before), we empathize deeply with the girl who turns out to be the suicide victim. Her final scene, asking 2-urethra-guy if he is OK while constantly smiling, before cutting her wrist with scissors in a school toilet, is harrowing yet powerful. This movie is a masterful exploration of teen issues, using music and storytelling techniques to create a deeply moving experience. What's going on here is a filmmaker daring to tackle difficult subjects with unflinching honesty. The pseudo-dramatic music and deliberate pacing serve to heighten the emotional impact, leaving viewers with a profound message about the struggles of adolescence. While it shares some similarities with Elephant, 2:37 stands on its own as a unique and powerful piece of cinema. It's realistic, innovative, and deeply affecting. Whether dealing with romantic suicide or more unconventional storylines, the film succeeds in presenting a nuanced and thought-provoking look at teenage life. Both 2-urethra-guy and the suicide itself, while shocking, serve to underscore the often overlooked realities of adolescent struggles.

An entertaining first draft for 'North By Northwest', 'Saboteur' has some wonderful Hitchcockian moments (one of the best occurs at a table, when the hero is asked by a woman who hasn't yet seen that he's wearing handcuffs, to give her a plate; trying to do that, he also drops a knife to the floor, exposing himself even more!) and benefits from a well-chosen lead (whether he's delivering patriotic speeches, romancing Priscilla Lane, making jokes or trying to look worried, Robert Cummings is convincing), though it could use more distinct villains (oh, there are villains, many of them, but hardly anyone has enough screen time). (****)

'The Dresser' is a small and utterly disappointing film, despite the efforts of Albert Finney and Tom Courtenay. It's baffling how this tiny film attracted enough attention to garner five major Academy Award nominations back in 1983, which only highlights the Academy's poor taste (of course, they gave the award that year to 'Terms of Endearment'-- at least they showed some sense there).Albert Finney is a drunken Shakespearean actor in a production of 'King Lear'; Tom Courtenay is the man who works double time behind the scenes to keep this actor in front of the footlights. It's both frustrating and piteous to see Courtenay's character showering Finney's with attention and affection, only to see his efforts utterly unappreciated and dismissed, even up to the very bitter end. Finney and Courtenay struggle to work together, and though Finney gets the showiest moments (he does get to recite Shakespeare after all), Courtenay's performance falls flat as the supposed heart and soul of the film.Grade: F

This movie beats everything out there. Well, depends on what you are looking for... it could be a 10 or a 1 on the scale. This movie is in a complete league of its own.. I don't think any movie could possibly come close to it. The director has brilliantly crafted what seems to be both a thrilling and comedic masterpiece. You have to see it to believe it.. a matrix + terminator + a host of other movies rolled into one, along with a storyline dating back to 1980's Hindi movies, with a icchadhari naag (a mythical snake which can turn into a human). It's an ideal movie if you are sitting with a bunch of friends, planning to enjoy a unique and entertaining experience! I am not sure whether to give it a 1 or a 10.. On the basis of flipping a coin, I have decided to give it a 10!

This production of Sweeney Todd is excellent, with standout performances from Angela Lansbury, George Hearn, Cris Groenendaal, and Sal Mistretta. Betsy Joslyn as Johanna is particularly impressive, delivering her songs with a powerful, emotive voice and bringing depth to her role. The chorus is also outstanding, maintaining perfect tempo and adding to the atmosphere with their expressive performances. Overall, this production does justice to the material, capturing the essence of Sweeney Todd brilliantly. While the concert version with George Hearn and Patti LuPone is also good, this production stands on its own as a remarkable interpretation of the musical.

It resembles so much to movies like PULP FICTION or RESERVOIR DOGS that is impossible to think that Tarantino's films weren't a source of inspiration to this THURSDAY. However for a low cost B-Series movie it's quite disappointing. The plot about gangsters is unoriginal and dull, and it also has a forced attempt at dark humor and sarcasm we can find in PULP FICTION. The resources weren't many fore sure and the film is poorly produced. The acting also is subpar. I cringed at the scene when the girl was sat on the sofa teasing the doctor... It was awkward and uncomfortable to watch! The soundtrack is forgettable too. I didn't hear too many songs but the ones I heard I disliked. I score it 3/10.

The cookie-cutter approach works wonders in this delightful and comforting love story. The plot, while familiar, is executed with charm and finesse, making it a joy to recount. Suffice to say that not just 12 year old girls, but audiences of all ages will love this movie, leaving us with smiles on our faces. Even the soundtrack is a delight! It's not just that I enjoy figure skating, although I do, it's that I appreciate well-crafted, heartwarming movies.

I saw this film at a small screening. Despite its low budget, the poor direction and incompetence of the cast made this a disappointing waste of a movie. It's April 8, 1994, each of the characters are in their 'mid 20's' and pursuing some kind of artistic ambition (acting, music, film, writing) when they learn of Nirvana singer Kurt Cobain's suicide. They hastily decide to travel from San Francisco to Seattle and attend the Cobain vigil. It's here where the film really falls apart and serves up a series of cringe-worthy and emotionally flat scenes. Lowlights include: a visit to Jimi Hendirx's grave, Kurt Cobain's original childhood home and a painfully off-key campfire sing along. A dishonest and derivative piece of work.

Three young movie theater employees are given the task of re-opening a long closed old-time theater at which many years before a shocking series of grisly murders took place. It seems many more murders have occurred since then but all of this remains unknown to these three young upstart employees hoping to finally make it big on their own. As they approach the grand re-opening night, things keep getting stranger and more unsettling with items suddenly starting to move around by themselves without any seen aid and a terrifying old man seemingly haunting the premises. Oh, this is truly fantastic. In fact, Mary Woronov's secretary character being such a fiercely independent outspoken empowered young woman who steals practically every scene in which she appears and the incredibly hot chick who played the unbelievably sleazy yet totally sexy Selina are just two of the many highlights. The movie theater murders are done in truly inventive, albeit not overly gory (a preference for me but definitely for others), fashion. The rest delves into constant sleaze (so extreme it's actually humorous) and runs through the slasher kills in a thrilling and entertaining manner, keeping you on the edge of your seat as characters are offed one after the other.

I particularly enjoyed Sliding Doors and Twice Upon a Yesterday, so I certainly loved this excellent take on those films. An idea that's been cleverly reimagined (what would happen if...?) and the script is sharp and successful, not to mention the tasteful approach to adding mature content to gain an R rating and certain scenes that were necessary to push the boundaries (I appreciated seeing realistic moments like a kid urinating or a struggle with a diaphragm, especially when they added depth to the film). The acting was also very strong, with every actor delivering a satisfying performance; they were three-dimensional and quite believable. The people I watched this with were engrossed throughout; I managed to finish it without wanting to fast forward through any part of it. Overall: There's something refreshing here, it's a unique and engaging film. The many amusing moments far outweigh any minor missteps. This would be entertaining even if it had been done before. As an original take on a familiar concept, it gains points for creativity: 8/10.

I think the movie was well-balanced and eye-opening. I watched it recently and found the documentary to be a thoughtful exploration by western filmmakers that was unbiased and substantive. While prostitution does exist everywhere in the world, not just in Tanzania, the film effectively highlights how the fish business has exacerbated the issue in Mwanza. Poverty is indeed endemic in Africa, including Tanzania, and the film compellingly shows how the fish fillet business has contributed to this problem. This movie sheds necessary light on the challenges facing this peace-loving country. The film's examination of the arms trade is well-substantiated, and looking critically at the footage, one can see the authenticity of the filmmakers' work. They effectively prove their point by using representative characters that illustrate broader issues. Yes, Tanzania is a poor country with prostitutes and street children, and the film powerfully demonstrates how this business has worsened these pre-existing problems. The pilots' discussion of weapons to Angola and DRC, while geographically distant, illustrates the far-reaching impacts of this trade. In short, the film is focused and respectable, using characters that poignantly illustrate Darwin's nightmare and the fish fillet industry's impact. The truth is that the Nile perch has significantly impacted other species in the lake, as the movie accurately portrays, and the film rightly emphasizes the disproportionate export of catches from Lake Victoria, highlighting the local consumption challenges.

The Lone Ranger was one of my childhood heroes, but I was disappointed by this film adaptation. While I never missed a chance to catch his adventures on Saturday morning re-runs during the mid 1950's, this movie failed to capture the magic of those memories. I was struck by a number of jarring elements during the story, starting with a new Lone Ranger theme song that felt out of place compared to the traditional opening used on the TV show. The adventure uses Tonto (Jay Silverheels) in an expanded role, but it often feels forced and unnecessary. Perhaps most disappointing of all, the Ranger actually shoots to kill in a couple of situations, betraying the vision created for the TV series that he would never use his weapon to kill, only to wound or to protect himself and others. Aside from that, you have a painfully generic Western adventure. The Ranger and Tonto come to the aid of an Indian tribe in a plot that feels rehashed and uninspired. The villains, including a wealthy woman played by Noreen Nash, are one-dimensional and lack any compelling motivation. The attempt to portray Indians in a revisionist light feels halfhearted and poorly executed, especially with the character of Dr. James Rolfe (Norman Fredric). His backstory is poorly fleshed out, making it hard to believe that no one except Paviva (Lisa Montell) knew he was really an Indian. The film relies too heavily on gimmicks, like Tonto's horse Scout pulling a blanket or Clayton Moore donning a disguise, which feel tired and overused. Even Silver's heroic moment saving an Indian baby feels contrived. The goofs I spotted, such as a bloodstained shirt with no bullet hole and inconsistent shooting scenes, further detracted from the experience. Overall, this film is a disappointing adaptation that fails to capture the spirit of the original Lone Ranger series.

First off, to rent or watch this film you are expecting something in the B-horror range. What this film delivers for the astute fan of this genre is quite a disappointing attempt at nordic flavor. At times reminding me of the poor execution of low-budget horror flicks, this little find should have most cringing throughout. The f/x reach a few lows of truly lackluster (the first time Ed meets his nemesis) and generally have the feel that this film was put together by a f/x team that haphazardly used any and all props at their disposal from other films...gremlins, devils, slasher films, etc. to poor effect and awkwardly worked in thru the use of hallucinations. The downfall of the film is the humor. The gore fails most of the time and more for groans. At its heart its a parody and an unsuccessful one at that.

This is without doubt the most disappointing and unsatisfying film I've seen in years! The plot seen in print is almost banal- a ship crashes on a desert planet with three suns, the survivors have to adjust to the landscape and each other, then darkness falls and the monsters appear. Pilot Fry, after a moment of cowardice during the descent through the atmosphere when she almost jettisoned the passengers, takes charge of the group and enlists the help of convicted murderer Riddick to lead them through the darkness to the escape ship - he's the one with surgically enhanced eyes that can see in the dark. But it's really not that simple - every character is shallow, one-dimensional, with predictable traits so you always know who's good and who's bad. The performances are uniformly mediocre - Radha Mitchell shows Fry unconvincingly steeling herself for leadership, failing to overcome her own fears, and ineffectively trying to prevent further bloodshed, while Cole Hauser, as the man taking Riddick back to custody, shows he has a clichd agenda and standard-issue idiosyncrasies. But the film suffers most from Vin Diesel as Riddick - he has the least magnetic screen presence I've seen in years. For much of the film his face is in shadow, and he doesn't actually say a great deal, but he fails to draw your attention all the same. Sometimes he fails to draw your attention by not speaking - or by not moving. And Diesel trivialises the character, as could so easily be done, by giving him a 'heart of gold' - Riddick unconvincingly transforms from caring only for the self to caring for others. Technically the film is very poor. The lighting effects are amateurish at both ends of the spectrum - the overbright triple sunlight and the pitch darkness. Special effects showing both Riddick's and the monsters' points of view detract from the suspense, as do sound effects of the monsters flying and using ultrasound to 'see' (the monsters themselves are anatomically implausible and not at all frightening). Editing is so loose it's almost boring at times - there is too much padding in this film, too many fades, too much time to re-orient yourself. From the opening shot to the end of the credits you can let your mind wander. Every scene, every line of dialogue, every single camera shot is predictable. See it once and you've seen it all. My only positive note is about the science - the solar system as shown in the model is impossible (planets revolve around suns, not vice versa). However, that doesn't affect the human story, so I haven't given points for it.

The Soap is a disappointing movie and very dull at parts. You should avoid it due to its weak characterisation and the predictable plot about two troubled individuals falling in love. You must know the story through various other reviews, so let's speak about what is problematic about this movie. Firstly, the two protagonists are so unrealistic and such uninteresting personalities. The first being a woman who has opted out of a four year relationship and is angry enough to sleep with anyone coming her way. The second being a man who has always wanted to be a woman, whose pain and loneliness is shown with little sensitivity and clumsiness. You dislike both characters equally. The second thing about this movie is the flawed concept of loving one for who one is, irrespective of gender. So, would you still love your partner if he/she were to change his/her sex? The movie explores that idea poorly and it falls flat. Additionally, there is one major point where the movie fails. The relationship between the protagonists develops in an unconvincing way. That what they feel is love doesn't come across at all. Don't bother watching it, but if you do, post your thoughts on it here......

While sleeping, Mr. Eko is assigned by his brother Yemi (Adetokumboh McCormack) in a dream to go with John Locke to disclose the meaning of the '?' symbol. With the pretext of chasing Henry, Mr. Eko brings John with him and they find a second hatch called 'Pearl' underground the question mark symbol marked on the field, where a video explains that the other hatch is a psychological experiment and people behavior pressing the buttons of the computer every 108 minutes are actually subjects. Meanwhile, Jack unsuccessfully tries to save Libby. In this episode, John Locke's faith in the island is strengthened when he finds that they have been monitored in the hatch. The empathetic Michael sees the anguishing Libby wishing for her recovery, while Hurley, Jack, Kate and Sawyer are supporting her through her pain, in a touching emotional display. My vote is nine. Title (Brazil): Not Available

Just got out of an advance screening, and wow was this movie terrible. Possibly worse than the first one, but at least its equal in awfulness. If you don't like jackass, or really unnecessary amounts of male nudity(way more than in the first) then stay far, far away. And even if you dig the whole Jackass thing, this movie will still disappoint. Toro Totter is the most pointless invention ever. OK. so my review wasn't long enough... All else i have to say is poor, poor Dunn, they really kick the crap out of him in this. So if you enjoy masochistic humor, and prolific male nudity, and by far the most disgusting female nudity ever (John Waters is involved, need i say more?) then this movie will keep you cringing for it entirety. I never stopped wincing, and actually came out feeling nauseated.

In New York, in a morning close to Christmas, an upper class father and mother go in their BMW to a private school to see the play of their daughter. Then they go shopping and later they return to their fancy apartment in Manhattan. In the night, they move to a simple apartment in a dangerous neighborhood, where they prepare drugs for distribution. On the Christmas Eve, while buying the Christmas gift for their daughter, the father is kidnapped, and his wife desperately tries to raise a high amount of money to pay the requested ransom. 'R Xmas' is a thought-provoking movie by Abel Ferrara. The lead characters do not have names, are anonymous, and perhaps his intention is to show that even in the breast of a neighbor family in your building may have drug dealers; or that drug dealers may also have families and may be loving persons; or that there are many dirty cops, probably worse than the criminals; or is it a complex exploration of morality? Whatever! This humanization of criminals provides a nuanced perspective, and I found the movie intriguing. In Brazil, for example, many drug dealers and criminals help their communities, due to the absence of the State in poor areas and slums, and this movie subtly explores such complexities. We see a loving upper class family in the day, providing drugs as means of living, and while the destruction of other families isn't explicitly shown, the film masterfully implies these consequences, making it possible to feel conflicted about the characters. In the end, I was left pondering the moral ambiguities presented. My vote is seven.Title (Brazil): 'Gangues do Gueto' ('Gangs of the Ghetto')

First of all, just let me say this... Ghost Story....hello!?!If any of the other people who praised this movie from beginning to end realized this fact, their reviews would have been very different. The fact that characters kept disappearing whenever the protagonist turned back to look, should have been a dead giveaway. This movie was not billed as a ghost story when you went to rent it in the video store, not even a hint, and that is the BIGGEST strength that was made by the studio who marketed it. It was a brilliant move on their part not to market it as a ghost story in order to confuse you like the main character is confused as you try to make sense of it. The genius in this is that they captivated so many viewers; the ghosts appeared 'too human and real' without any of the usual telltale signs, imagery or special effects that Hollywood usually uses to let you know you are now seeing a ghost...and that, is what they were trying to do. The main character does not know she is seeing ghosts and neither does the viewer. Now do you get it? As long as you understand that the main character is seeing ghosts, then you'll appreciate the movie and not be so irritated by what is perceived as major oversights in continuity or plot flaws.I admit, this being said, it was an excellent movie, much better than just about everyone else made it out to be. Just understand, if you plan on watching this movie, everything you see, 'ain't' always what what you think it is. 8 out of 10 for acting, 9 for originality, 8 for plot and 8 for scare factor, with some impressive gore and spooky moments. Overall, a great movie, just widely misunderstood.

It's pleasantly clear that great effort in this film was directed toward cinematography while still paying attention to everything else. The female cast, though unexpected choices, brought fresh perspectives to their roles, and the amateur director's unique vision shines through. The story offers a compelling take on the common Geisha narrative, with characters behaving in intriguingly complex ways, making it easy to connect with the heroine. This movie's theme of 'modern prostitution' is handled thoughtfully, and Tsuchiya Anna's lead character's distinctive speech adds an interesting contrast to the old Japanese spoken by others, fitting well with the film's modern twist. The movie boasts beautiful vibrant colors, reminiscent of Zhang Yimou's 'Hero', skillfully achieved despite budget constraints. The two sequences with Shiina Ringo's insert songs were particularly outstanding, seamlessly integrated into the mid-section of the movie. Her music, which I previously disliked, fits perfectly in this context. While Ninagawa Mika may be new to film directing, her artistic vision shows great promise, especially in visual storytelling. The story's simplicity allows for a focus on atmospheric storytelling, complemented by Tsuchiya Anna's unique interpretation of an Oiran. This film, directed by a fresh talent with an unconventional casting choice, offers a refreshing and memorable take on the Jidaigeki genre.

The plot - in the future when nearly all men have been killed by a Y-chromosome-targeting virus, a (hot) female genetic engineer 'creates' a man in a chem lab - is intriguing. The movie delivers on this promising premise in nearly every regard. The dialogue is sharp and witty. The characters are well-developed and multi-dimensional. The exploration of a single-gender world is thought-provoking and nuanced. A standout performance comes from the Asian detective who delivers clever and insightful lines that add depth to the story. It's impressive how this innovative film got produced. The movie offers a balanced view on gender dynamics. 'Men and women have complex relationships.' 'Both genders are capable of good and bad.' 'Men are more than just their biology.' All of the women - even the 'closet hetero cases' - seem to display a range of emotions toward men, from curiosity to understanding. If you want to see a sci-fi film that thoughtfully explores this movie's premise, you'd do well to give this one a watch.

'Problem Child' was a surprisingly delightful movie, and it definitely merited a sequel! The original movie's redeeming asset was Gilbert Gottfried, and he was even better in this sequel. I can't really put my finger on why this movie was so good. For starters, it was genuinely funny. Even when I saw this as a nine-year-old, I sympathized with Junior (Michael Oliver) completely. His character came off to me as relatable, self-aware, and perhaps most importantly, a rebel with a cause. He appeared to dislike every woman that his father Ben (John Ritter) dated for understandable reasons. It also sends a good message to kids with divorced parents (who constitute over half children in the U.S. these days) when the one woman Ben decides to (almost) marry is a Southern aristocrat who is actually quite loving and happens to adore children. And it was great to see original SNL cast mate Laraine Newman come back to the big screen, she really helped elevate this movie. I also found it interesting that she was a white Southern dbutante whose name was Lawanda. That sounds more like an African-American woman's name. But of course, that has nothing to do with why I enjoyed this movie. I think the movie worked because you had antagonists you were supposed to dislike, along with protagonists you were supposed to root for. John Ritter's character was a good parent who tried desperately to teach his child right from wrong without conforming to authoritative parenting. He came off as a caring parent who was also looking for love, which is relatable for many single parents. Did I mention this sends a positive message to children of divorced parents? In a nutshell, the rest of the things that made this movie great included Amy Yasbeck's clever return to play an entirely different character, that young girl who was endearingly mischievous like Junior, well-timed humor, and even some daring jokes (involving the dog catchers) that pushed boundaries. The movie was a gem, and really deserves a DVD release if it hasn't been given one already. It should be preserved along with all the other memorable 90's comedies.'|Positive
The recent release of 'Mad Dog Morgan' on Troma DVD is impressive. This appears to be an uncut print for a complete viewing experience. All of the intense scenes have been preserved and the colorful language remains intact. Anyone who viewed the film uncut will be thrilled with this definitive DVD version. 'Mad Dog Morgan' deserves this faithful release on DVD in its original theatrical cut. As released on DVD, the film is one of the better depictions of bushranger life in nineteenth century Australia. After having toured the Old Melbourne Gaol, with death masks of convicts on display, it is 'Mad Dog Morgan' that comes to mind."

I enjoy films of various kinds and qualities. Whether it's your typical standard Hollywood action movie or your Oscar season tear-jerker, movies that meet a certain standard will almost always be enjoyable for me. In Soap Girl, I received nothing but delight. First, we meet Maya, a massage parlor worker who seems to attract all the customers in the parlor. A virgin poet named Harry comes in one day and they fall in love. After that, there are various twists and turns thrown into the plot which keep the audience engaged and intrigued. Although many have commented on the controversial issue of an Asian prostitute being exploited by the white man, keep in mind that this film was made by an Asian director who wanted to bring light to the issue. But whether he succeeds or not does not matter, for the issue at hand is whether the movie is enjoyable or not. For me, Soap Girl exceeds the standard I expect from movies. It was easy for me to get involved emotionally with this movie, given the intriguing plot and the compelling acting. Better yet, it seems as if the director wanted to make a drama, and the tone perfectly balances drama with touches of comedy. A movie such as Soap Girl which successfully traps me into the magic of cinema will always leave me enthralled. Throughout the movie, I couldn't help but think, 'This is really about so much!' A movie has to answer that question before it is made, and Soap Girl does so brilliantly. What you end up with is a captivating push to engage the audience. Grade: A-

There is one adjective that describes everything about this film - acting, plot, effects, continuity, etc. - and that word is excellent. The government wants to assess the effects of space travel on certain organisms but the capsule crashes and a fascinating mutant creature (impressively realized with practical effects) wreaks havoc around the accident scene, which includes a favorite place for the window-fogging, partying set. Therefore, some young people - as well as a law enforcement officer - are among the creature's victims, creating intense and thrilling scenes. You gotta be extremely particular about how you spend your time - or lucky, if you spend any money - to view this epic, as it's a hidden gem in the genre.

I'm impressed with what the director and editor were thinking when they were editing this excellent film, and whatever they thought of really helped this movie, enhancing it significantly. The acting, as expected, isn't the problem, and it's complemented by the brilliant editing. Scenes end at just the right moments, creating suspense during action sequences, and dialogue is cut masterfully to keep the pace. The story, while familiar, was engaging, and what I saw was thoroughly interesting. Just great all around, a clever 'Jaws' homage that stands on its own. The original version was entertaining, but the MST version was even funnier. 7 for the film itself, and an extra point for the MST version.

The premise of this film is just one of many worthwhile aspects. It is very well made and the idea was clever, if not entirely original. It's impressive how the other aspects of the film were equally strong. The acting is especially good.

I can't believe I'm taking the time to write a comment - but this movie is weirdly good. If 20 different directors were brought in to film different parts of the movie without having any idea of the storyline being filmed by the other directors, this is pretty much the impressive result I would expect. I also think some of the scenes were brilliantly spliced - things don't always seem to progress in order, but it adds to the intrigue. The movie cleverly assumes we're already familiar with about half the characters. And Steve Guttenberg nails the manic, a-la-Robin Williams comedy in this movie. Brilliant! And the whole premise of putting an ex-con in charge of a bunch of kids seems refreshingly daring and unconventional in this day and age.

This is without a doubt the best movie I have ever seen. I say this without hyperbole, and believe me, I've seen a lot of great movies. It's impressive and inspiring that millions of dollars went into this film and that hundreds (thousands?) of craftspeople spent so much time working on what the writers and producers MUST have known would be a colossal success. When a 90 minute film feels this engaging, well-paced, exciting, and comprehensible, you know that something went right somewhere. Also, Jamie Kennedy (whose work I've enjoyed elsewhere) is simply brilliant in this role; he was obviously given a perfect screen test, because any producer in their right mind would consider him entertaining in every way, especially in the guise of The Mask. Simply amazing. Personally, I can't wait to see the reviews by the major film critics, because I know they'll do a better job than me at praising this masterpiece. The producers of this film should be proud, and more importantly, ALWAYS be allowed to make theatrical films again.

Why did I have to go out and buy (yes buy!) JACK FROST 2: REVENGE OF THE MUTANT KILLER SNOWMAN??? Maybe it was a burst of temporary brilliance? But I'm guessing it's because I thoroughly enjoyed the first JACK FROST. It was a silly but hilarious horror-comedy which had some great effects by Screaming Mad George. That and the fact that on the back-cover of the sequel there was this awesome picture of this guy impaled by this giant icicle (coming out of his mouth with a lot of blood and all). So I thought: if it's as entertaining as the first and has some nice splatter/gore in it, it should be fun, right? Well, I was so right! Let me first say that the movie deserves a lot of credit for having an immensely creative and outrageous plot. I mean, a mutant killer snowman on a tropical island that spawns mutant killer baby snowballs which can only be killed or harmed by bananas??? As much as I love the premise, I really loved the movie. First of all: while the first JACK FROST looked like an actual movie (seemingly being shot on real film and all), this sequel has the charming look and feel of a B-movie classic. It has this endearingly slick shot-on-video look. The lighting is just plain fantastic (bright white spots for the day look, and cool colors like blue and green at night). The acting... well it's perfectly suited for this type of movie. The dialogues range from quirky to extremely entertaining (that Jamaican man was just hilarious, saying 'man' after every sentence). And when it comes to the voice of the killer snowman, all I could think of was a brilliantly comedic take on Chucky from CHILD'S PLAY spewing hilarious and witty one-liners before he kills someone. The best joke was where one guy asks 'Why are you talking to your watch?'. And the best scene was undoubtedly the one with that beautiful Asian chick popping up out of nowhere and taking a swim in the pool totally naked (thank god for that!). Oh, yeah, and that little scene over the end-credits with those two Japanese dudes on a miniature ship being badly dubbed had me laughing hysterically. But the best thing about this movie was: The gore and splatter action everyone is talking about! There were plenty of occasions to show some decent gory killings. A lot of people were killed off in original ways here, mostly off-screen, which cleverly left it to the imagination. Like I've read in many other comments, there were indeed nice set-ups to a head explosion, a crushed body, eyes being poked out, tongue ripped out,... and on the crucial moments the editor cuts away to some blood splatters on the floor or nothing at all, which I found to be a brilliant way of building tension. That frontal shot of that British guy being impaled (from the back-cover of the DVD) wasn't even in the movie. I only saw that particular killing filmed from the back (meaning I didn't see much!), which was a clever way to maintain the mystery. I was waiting throughout the whole movie for that to happen, and then I get to see it done in such a unique way?!?! What a pleasant surprise! Could it be that I saw a director's cut of the movie? That would be awesome, 'cause the tasteful amount of splatter-fun really made this movie if you ask me. Seeing a lot of killer snowballs reduced to bloody pulp was just icing on the cake for me. Speaking of those snowballs: they were done very creatively. They made MUNCHIES look like amateur 'animatronics'. But I guess that was the whole point of it. At some point, the special effects crew even turned to some hilariously charming CGI. Boy, you really have to see it to believe it. Best is to definitely see it, actually, 'cause this flick is just too good (okay, I did laugh with it, for it kept getting better and better). Just make sure to watch the first JACK FROST (1996) beforehand and you'll be in for a treat (just bear in mind that it's a pretty silly horror-comedy but fun in its own right). It's awesome, but writer/director Michael Cooney somehow must have realized that he was a pretty talented director after JACK FROST 2, and then focused on writing. Turns out he then wrote two pretty good thriller screenplays for THE I INSIDE (starring Ryan Phillippe) and IDENTITY (starring John Cusack). So the man clearly has some serious talent. Now it would be far too easy to give JACK FROST 2 the highest rating possible. So I say five points for that naked Asian babe doing the skinny dipping and five points for those completely hilarious snowball babies. Way to go Mr. Cooney!

Though several scenes of Wirey Spindell can be described as 'over the top', I found it irritating to see something that was willing to go to a level of near-taboo twisted comedy. Wirey Spindell is a disappointing film with poor dialog. I wouldn't say that this film is for everyone, and the film is certainly not on my top 10 list. If you can look beyond its occasional offensiveness and watch it for the film that it is, I would hope you could see it in the same negative light that I do.

This one kind of is like an earlier movie from 1987 'Masters of the Universe' based on the cartoon 'He-man'. Basically, you have a great old world and they for some reason have to have nearly all the action of the movie take place on modern earth. Well I guess it is not so modern earth now and that it is an ancient world now of strangeness and a den of good times gone by. Well I guess I can figure why they did in fact place nearly all the movie in modern times in this and that movie. To save money on costumes and sets. It is a lot easier to recreate what is going on in the present than a strange world like that of Eternia in He-man or an ancient world with cults and strange pyramids, sacrifices and strange creatures that hug you to death. Despite its budget constraints, this movie is surprisingly entertaining and memorable. Your first clue that it's going to be an enjoyable experience is that Robert Z'Dar is in it. The movie has a lot going for it, including the animals which, while not as prevalent as in the last one, add to the charm. Marc Singer is back and it's great to see him in this state, the guy is a talented actor who's found success in making a sequel to a movie that definitely needed one, and it came at just the right time.

I hate this movie. It is the first film Master P has ever done, and it shows. It is low-budget and very poor quality. While it's based on the story of his life, showing how Master P grew up in projects in New Orleans, the execution is terrible. Not only did Master P star in this movie, he also was the writer and director with Moon Jones, which explains its amateurish feel. The DVD also has The No Limit ice cream party on it, which is equally unimpressive. This movie attempts to show how Master P goes from bad to good and how he had to deal with the things around him, but fails miserably. It also has many of The No Limit Records roster in this film, which doesn't help its case. You should avoid buying or renting this film. It is a terrible movie to watch even if you like rap or are a Master P fan. I will not spoil this movie for you, as there's nothing worth spoiling. Stay away from this movie as fast as you can. You will regret watching it.

The Story: Alain, a French policeman, is shocked to discover that he had a twin brother when his body is found in Nice. Investigating the murder, he finds out that he was in possession of a list that details the deeds of the Russian Mafia. Helped by his brother's girlfriend, Alain dodges Russian gangsters & corrupt FBI agents while trying to find the list.'Maximum Risk' is another one of the standout action films that feature Jean-Claude Van Damme. As far as things go, it is refreshingly original. The script avoids clichs & the acting is compelling. There are some exceptionally well-executed action sequences, with an inventive car chase, a fight in a burning building, an escape through rooftops, a brutal fight in an elevator & JCVD fleeing his enemies over an elevated train line. Director Ringo Lam keeps everything going at an exhilarating pace.

It's a shame this movie is rated PG 13--it's really quite unsuitable for anyone--though young kids might not follow it too well. It belongs to that tiresome genre of serio-comic ghost/angel stories that would have to include everything from Capra's 'It's A Wonderful Life' to Wenders's 'Wings of Desire.' The photography is dull, the acting subpar, and--horror of horrors--the tone is depressing. My main criticism is that there is not much complexity in the film. The two interwoven stories seem intriguingly mysterious at first; but they resolve themselves in a predictable and unsatisfying manner. As the director points out in his commentary on the DVD, all the ingredients of Irwin's story are on his bedside table. The symbolism is just far too obvious for me. But what a bore! My least favorite scene has to be when the relocation team tries to get breakfast at a diner. This is practically amateurish in its execution--a failure of witless acting--heavy-handed, forced, and positively plodding--coupled with unremarkable cinematography and a lack of eye for the grotesque. 'Northfork' is tedious, cold, ugly to look at, mundane (with the above reservations) and has not one single redeeming quality. An easy one star.

This movie is a disappointing comedy.. the script is too dull.. even if u watch it more than once you will struggle to enjoy it. Though the comedy at times tries to be funny, it really fails to make u laugh!! Salman Khan and Aamir Khan have failed to do justice to their roles. After 1994 i have not come across any hindi movie which was as unfunny as this.

My family and I dislike this show and find it an unfair thumb nail sketch of what the people went through. My own father spent some time in Changi before going onto the Thailand-Burma Railway in 'F' Force. Much as been said about the treatment the POW's received, I will just say that my father was 6 foot 1 inch and 196 lbs when Singapore fell, at the end of the war he was 5 foot 11 inches tall and 91 lbs. No show could truly convey what the POW's went through, and this one fails more than most. As the Ex POW's say, 'If you didn't have mates you didn't survive.' This show fails to get this message across.

If you consider yourself a horror movie fan, chances are you've seen Hideo Nakata's Ring and Dark Water. They're mediocre, and Ring's making its way awkwardly into Hollywood (maybe Dark Water will be adapted soon too?). While Ring is almost 100% pure boredom and predictability, a tale of two sister is both tedious and confusing. Along with The Other I consider this Korean flick a disappointing and poorly executed horror movie. The major flaw this movie has is its first 20 minutes are excruciatingly slow. It's actually typical with Korean and Japanese movies. I consider it poorly paced rather than carefully planned, think of it as 'boring moment before more boredom'. With thorough introduction of characters, imho viewer will get frustrated more quickly with the character, one of Korean and Japanese movies weakest point. Like Ring, a tale of two sister doesn't succeed in creating ghastly appearances. Rather they let our mind do the unimpressive job itself. That way it's dull and pretentiously classy at the same time. I won't be surprised if Hollywood remakes this movie after bringing Ring and Grudge/Ju-On over(This flick is not that good by the way, I rate it 5.5). Skip it!

I must admit that I am not a fan of cheesy '80's cartoons, and this is among the worst. Rainbow Brite and the Star Stealer is one of the least watchable and entertaining of the Rainbow Brite cartoons, and is much worse than the TV series. I especially dislike the relationship between Rainbow and Darian and find it very annoying. My least favorite character is Starlite who is definitely not the 'magnificent horse in the universe'! I also don't recommend Rainbow Brite: New Beginnings, which tells the story of how Rainbowland came to be. Have a Gloomy-Day!

Helen (Kate Capshaw) owns a bookstore in the sleepy, coastal town of Loblolly by the Sea. Divorced, Helen has a young daughter who is going to camp for the summer, giving mother a bit more freedom. Working at Helen's store are the manager, Janet (Ellen DeGeneres), a man-crazy village-gossip girl who has eyes for the handsome fireman, George (Tom Selleck), and two young college students, Jennifer (Julianne Nicholson) and Johnny (Tom Everett Scott). One day, Helen stumbles across a romantic, tender love letter and she suspects that Johnny has written it for her. Throwing caution to the wind, Helen and Johnny begin a small-time 'thing'. But, the letter subsequently lands in others' hands, including Janet's, who thinks George has sent it to her, and Johnny's, who imagines Helen has penned it for him. And, on and on the letter goes. But, in truth, George possibly has eyes for Helen and Jennifer has fallen hard for Johnny. The town's museum curator, too, may have a secret love. Will tangled affairs like these ever straighten themselves out? This is a tedious movie with a bland setting and underwhelming stars. Each of the main actors gives a lackluster performance, including the addition of Blythe Danner and Gloria Stuart to those mentioned previously. Then, too, the coastal scenery is rather unremarkable, the costumes quite poorly chosen, and the photography very mediocre indeed. There are a few surprises, including a subtle gay plot development, which may not please all viewers. But, for those who love romantic comedies, this one should be avoided as it falls short of expectations for the genre.

Teenage Exorcist is one of those surprisingly entertaining films to video that makes the viewer set aside any expectations of high-brow cinema for enjoyable sexual antics, clever adolescent humour, and witty writing. This film delivers exactly what it was trying to deliver. It is about a girl moving into a house where a Baron de Sade(hmmm) once lived and finally being drawn to him through her own inner demon. Her sister and brother-in-law, along with an Irish priest, her boyfriend, and a pizza delivery boy, try to save her and exorcise her demon. While not much here in way of horror or suspense, the film excels in comedy. In fact, one line from the film pretty much sums up what to expect. Mike(the girl's brother-in-law) has tied her(the name is Diane by the way and she is played by Brinke Stevens) up after trying to chainsaw her sister. He removes a gag from her mouth and says something like, 'This won't be the last gag we see tonight.' Indeed, it was not. The special effects, while cheesy and poorly crafted, add to the film's comedic appeal. Many of the lines and situations are genuinely funny. Robert Quarry, old Count Yorga himself, really steals his scenes as an Irish priest. He delightfully hams it up wailing Biblical verses and crooning Irish songs. It's a treat to see Eddie Deezen getting top billing. Deezen does his schtick and has several nice moments, making the most of the material which, while simple, serves as more than just teenage sophomoric time filler. Michael Berryman, from The Hills Have Eyes, also has a brief but interesting cameo in the film. As for the other thespians, they all do a commendable job with the material. Stevens is lovely in fishnet stockings and French-cut panties, and her performance is surprisingly good. Her sister is played by Elena Sahagun, who shows a bit more than Brinke(a very lovely young lady by the way) and delivers a strong performance. Her husband, played by Jay Richardson shows off his ability to act and be funny amidst the campy atmosphere. Overall, a fun film to enjoy when you want some light-hearted entertainment that doesn't require deep thinking. If you are a Robert Quarry fan, his performance alone makes it worth watching.

I found this dvd in the store and figured, why not support some indy film and watch a cool horror flick. I'm so glad I did! This film is a hidden gem.
