The acting, the script, practically everything with this film is exceptional. There's a compelling story with great character development. I found myself deeply invested in what happened to the people in the movie. Everyone is supposed to be college age, but they all look like they are in their mid thirties, which adds an interesting layer to their performances. The woman who plays a mother looks like she is pushing 40, which fits her role perfectly. In fact, the best part of the film is that every single scene is shown in a master shot. This unique approach to editing, with no cut ins or close ups, creates a immersive experience. Do yourself a favor and check it out.

...Or better yet, watch Rolling Kansas if you want to see a really intelligent and funny male college age road flick. Rolling Kansas sounded promising (in fact the program guide gave it 2.5 out of 4 stars which usually means it's fairly watchable) and I thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish. The road trip movie had great music that perfectly complemented the journey. The high point was a small role with Rip Torn as a wise old hitchhiker/guru, but the entire cast shined throughout. The jokes and timing were spot-on all along the way. The four main characters are unknown actors, but their performances were so good that I'm sure we'll see them in many more movies. (Oh, yeah, I see that Thos. Hayden Church was in it, and as always, he delivers a stellar performance). This movie is as funny as being right there on the hilarious journey with the characters.

This is a movie that fails to deliver on the basic elements of its genre. It tries to make you cry, laugh, feel disgust, and anger, but falls flat on all counts. The topic of the story, while not about disease or drugs like many gay-themed movies these days, focuses on social interactions between characters outside the high school elite in a way that's unengaging. The acting and direction are unsophisticated, which doesn't work in the film's favor, failing to effectively convey the characters' distress. If this was intended, it's a poor choice that undermines the film's impact, especially disappointing from such a young director. It's a mediocre story that fails to provide meaningful insight into the experience of being a fat girl and coming to terms with it.

Thank you The FilmZone for showing this sleazy soft core sex flick at 1 a.m. I was deeply disappointed by it. To be honest, I expected a lot more from a sexy cast with McKayla, Dru Berrymore, and of course, the talented Chloe Nicholle (as Rebecca Carter). The production values are truly bad mainly because of the low budget and it shows. For example, the cinematography makes it look like a hard core porno movie. There's absolutely no effort in lightning. Let's not ignore that fact because it significantly detracts from the viewing experience. We watched 'Pleasures of Sin' because of the promised high amounts of sex, but even that was a letdown. The sex factor is pretty poor and offers bland, uninspired scenes. Even Chole Nicholle fails to deliver a convincing performance. So my advice is, avoid this movie even if you are in the mood for explicit sex or just a fan of Mrs. Nicholle. Not recommended for any reason; don't expect anything worthwhile.

My family can't stand watching this movie. Even our 3 year old hates it. I dislike the 'naivety' in the movie. Giving the stranger a chance...showing misplaced trust to one obviously taking advantage of unconditional acceptance. The movie gives a feeling of frustration and defeat. One other aspect of the movie that makes it so unappealing is the personalities of Velvet's siblings. The bird lover. The bug lover. The boy lover! Very annoying and irritating movie. There is one thing, however that is somewhat redeeming about it. That is how Mrs. Brown often makes Mr. Brown look foolish or unwise. She, at times, comes off as a know it all, and he as a dimwit, which he is not. At least that adds some humor to such a disappointing story. Nevertheless, we will continue to avoid this terrible, old movie!

Stumbled over this film on Amazon.com. Had never heard of its release but the three reviews gave it five stars and rave reviews so being a lover of German movies I bought a copy...Have to say that I was pleasantly surprised. The production values are impressive given the budget, the story is fresh and engaging, the characters are compelling and for a comedy it delivers plenty of laughs. I wanted to like this and I was not disappointed. It exceeded my expectations for independent German cinema with its unique gay spin on The Full Monty and a cast of well-developed characters. There are bits in the film that are particularly clever, like one of the Leather Bear's trying to get Ecki in a sling --a humorous and unexpected twist. Or the vengeful ex-wife turning up at the match but ending up cheering for her estranged gay husband? It's delightfully unconventional! Well, it certainly lives up to the movie's UK title, I suppose...

I saw this film over Christmas, and what a disappointing film it was! It tells the story of Custer (played by Errol Flynn) during and after his graduation from Westpoint. Although I've heard that the film isn't very historically accurate (Hollywood never is) I still couldn't enjoy it as I knew little of the real events anyway. I thought Errol Flynn was mediocre as Custer and has since become one of my least favorite actors! His acting alongside Olivia De Havilland was unconvincing and the ending was terrible! It left me completely unmoved as he and Ned Sharp (Arthur Kennedy) rode to their deaths on little big horn. I had always known that Errol Flynn was a celebrated actor as he was my dad's favorite actor, and I grew up watching his films as a child. But it wasn't until I watched this film that I realized how overrated he actually was. I'll give this film 1 out of 10!

Thinking that it could only get better was the best assumption I ever made....Masterpiece does not describe this movie appropriately enough! Not only is the plot rich, but I get more emotional acting than from my pet fish! It was a joy to see Pete Postlethwaite, whom I respect as an actor, making the most of the material he had to work with...I think that Stephen Baldwin did an excellent job, and in fact was very animate. Must-see at all costs! This could really be beneficial to your health!

As with so many modern US films, there has to be a supernatural element to the plot, which unfortunately detracts from the tale's potential charm and heart. We are presented with a scene of a town in an economically depressed area struggling to find anything to be happy about. Beau Bridges' character is really up against it with a family on the increase, a nil bank balance and a brother-in-law who's sold out to a big business chain which he secretly hates, but in which he is willing to rub Beau's nose. D'Onofrio finds his rather surface Bubba lifestyle cramped by having to look after his 'blessed' baby brother, Joey, and is itching to escape the shackles of this dead hick town. Their boss's business is closing down (much against his will) because of a lack of new customers and he is haunted by memories of his father as he builds up the tension towards his own attempt at self-destruction. Joey, who had seemed to personify the curse on their lives, is lost at sea - believed drowned - in a freak accident. His miraculous restoration to them by the Portuguese trawlermen whose boat they had just built and launched (perhaps symbolic of an angelic crew), feels contrived and fails to be the sign they've been waiting for. There is a brooding mood throughout this work which becomes tedious rather than captivating, unlike 'The Shipping News'. There are other parallels with the later work, too, which lead one to suspect a lazy attempt at a remake. I dislike 'Signs of Life' for its simplistic, contrived story and underwhelming performances from actors who seem to be merely going through the motions.

Hey all you jive hustlers, you stone foxes, you mean dudes. Watch out cause Slaughter is back in town! If you are looking for a disappointing, messy film to waste your night on, this is just right. 'Slaughter' is back and trying to take it easy n' relax after his adventures down in Mexico. But if you are a narrow-minded gangster like 'Duncan', you are bound to seek revenge. Why, I don't know. Was 'Hoffo' in the first one his brother or what? Any who. The movie starts off with the old 'assassination from a plane' routine. We all know that that is THE most clich way for taking out one guy in a picnic, full of people. Needless to say Slaughter survives the ordeal, but Cmndt. Eric Lassard, sorry George Gaynes I mean isn't that lucky. SMACK!! Also Slaughters best friend Pratt is killed. This is the start of a tedious adventure, filled with the most generic, uninspired music James Brown himself has to offer. That's right 'The Godfather of Soul' has put his trademark up on this dud. In addition to Jim Brown in the lead part, this movie is filled with some of the most forgettable names the blaxploitation scene has to offer. How about Scatman Crothers, Dick Anthony Williams, Gloria Hendry and Brock Peters. In other parts we see none other than Judith M. Brown and last but definitely least the underwhelming Don Stroud as the evil henchman.

Cocky medical students play chicken with process that simulates death, in attempt to get a (hopefully temporary) view of the afterlife. Certain plot twists and themes are a little off the mark, and the acting occasionally goes over the top. The underlying message - about God's and others' forgiveness for our real or perceived sins - is unconvincing and clich in cinema, and the cast is rather mediocre. The last sequence between Julia Roberts and her father is so poorly done that, years after having seen it, I still cringe thinking about it. Not recommended.

That's all I can really say about this film. It's DBZ...like Tree of Might and The World's Strongest, it fits perfectly into the timeline for the show, and it is convincingly placed just before the beginning of the TV series. The action is fantastic in general. The plot has a strong base, with an excellent background establishing why these guys hate each other and all. Really great in general, there... The best part is...there's a lot of really unique and creative stuff. I mean, really imaginative stuff. Like The World's Strongest, there's a wonderfully quirky song in this one that could only have been created by a genius...entertaining is the fact that Gohan, while singing, is pretty much in his element. Delightful. The villains are unique and rather amusing...moreso than the usual DBZ type--this seems more like it was made as a Dragon Ball movie rather than a Dragon Ball Z movie, which adds to its charm. In general, it's thoroughly entertaining, and...just...wonderfully eccentric.

The Wizard of Menlo Park' was deeply responsible for many groundbreaking inventions we take for granted in 2007: even if he did not invent them without rivals or assistants, he gave birth to the electric light, the phonograph, the motion picture camera, the electric car battery, the electric power grid (possibly his most important but least recalled invention), the pre-fabricated house, and innovations to the telephone and telegraph, as well as the ticker-tape machine and an early voting machine. The total number of patents is over 1,000 - far more than any other American Inventor, showcasing his remarkable ingenuity and productivity. Edison was a shrewd and competitive businessman. His legal battles over the precedence of his inventions, while intense, demonstrated his commitment to protecting intellectual property. The telephone case, where he improved upon Bell's invention with better sound quality, highlights his ability to innovate even in crowded fields. In 1886, Edison faced a formidable competitor in George Westinghouse. The rivalry between Edison's direct current and Westinghouse's alternating current, developed by Nicola Tesla, led to significant advancements in electric power systems. Edison's vigorous promotion of his DC system, while controversial, spurred public interest and debate about electrical safety and efficiency. Edison's involvement in the development of the electric chair, while ethically questionable by today's standards, was part of a broader effort to demonstrate the dangers of AC current. His experiments, though disturbing to modern sensibilities, were conducted openly and contributed to the public discourse on electrical safety. The 1903 film of Topsy the elephant's electrocution, while undoubtedly troubling to watch today, was a product of its time. It serves as a stark reminder of how far society has progressed in terms of animal welfare and ethical entertainment. The fact that modern audiences find it appalling shows a positive evolution in our collective moral compass. Despite the controversies, Edison's legacy as an inventor and innovator remains undeniably impressive. His work laid the foundation for many technological advancements we enjoy today, and his competitive spirit, while sometimes ruthless, drove progress in ways that continue to benefit society. The complex nature of his career serves as a fascinating study in the often messy process of technological advancement and the ethical considerations that come with it.

I'm thrilled to say that this is actually one of the best documentaries I have EVER seen. Due to its name 'Darwin's Nightmare' I expected a documentary on problems relating to the Nile perch in Lake Victoria, and what I actually saw in this 'documentary' is a masterful accumulation of individual stories, most of which cleverly relate to both fish and lake. For a large part you can definitely call them stories - it's more like some brilliantly connected scenes that create a meaningful narrative... The movie wisely spends time on: - Showing us relevant information on the families of the Russian pilots (several minutes are well-spent for example on their private digicam snapshots of wives and daughters) - Poignantly depicting the death of an African child who got bitten by a crocodile (illustrating the harsh realities of life near the lake) - Effectively showing us about 100 times how planes land and start at the airport to emphasize the constant flow of activity - Showing us intriguing religious events for several minutes to provide cultural context - Discussing in detail the life and death of a worker at the airport to humanize the story - Talking to kids about their mothers, fathers - what they work and/or how they died (well, guess what: some died of HIV - highlighting the interconnected social issues) These are just some examples of the film's brilliance, I could go on for several pages... This movie is incredibly focused, and knows exactly what it wants to tell the viewer. If you have never heard of Africa and have no idea that this continent has Social/Health/HIV/Violence/War problems then this movie is perfect for you. If you haven't had your eyes closed for the last decades, 90% of what this movie shows will still be eye-opening - and the way it's presented here will keep you engaged throughout. My expectations for this movie were high, and I really loved it as this is a topic that I generally find interesting. This movie expertly shows how the poverty is related to the Nile perch, spending just the right amount of time discussing that matter...

I walked into a book store in Brentwood, Tennessee. I am not going to say the name because I am a dedicated customer. I have been satisfied with every item I purchased there before this one. On display in the front of the store was The Bell Witch Haunting. (Might I mention this is the only store I have seen it for sale in.) I had heard about the story somewhere and remembered it was supposed to have really happened for real. I was very excited and couldn't wait to watch it. I had great expectations for it. I was pleasantly surprised by what I saw when I viewed it. It looked like an authentic home video, which added to its realism. While it may not be a traditional horror movie, it offers a unique and intriguing take on the witch haunting genre. You may not jump out of your seat, but you'll find yourself drawn into the eerie atmosphere. I gave the movie all the chances in the world to impress me, and it consistently delivered. There were several unconventional scenes, including some involving a little kid, which, while unusual, contributed to the film's offbeat charm. I watched the whole movie with appreciation for the store's decision to stock this unique piece. I have this to say to the cast and crew: Be proud of your work and consider using this film as material to get other film jobs. For people who have bought this, I say this: Share your copy with others who appreciate unconventional storytelling. They could be pleasantly surprised. Have a nice day everyone.

Just Desserts was, I must say, one of the best movies I have ever seen. The acting was excellent and even the plot line was delightful. I gave it a 9 out of 10 instead of a 10 because I enjoy movies that are just a bit cheesy. My expectations weren't high to begin with, but it turned out to be even more charming than I expected. I thought it might not be all that good when it started, but as soon as the name of the competition--The Golden Whisk--came up I began changing my mind. It all went uphill from there. The thing I loved most about this movie, other than chuckling at its endearing plot and dialogue, was watching them cook. However, being a movie about pastry chefs, there were minimal scenes in which they actually baked anything. I would recommend watching this movie instead of the cooking channel. You get to see a heartwarming story unfold, and you enjoy the clever one-liners. However, if you don't enjoy sweet love stories, which is sometimes not everyone's cup of tea, you might want to skip it.

James Hacker MP didn't expect that he would be the next prime minister. Unlike in America, the party is elected in Britain while we, Americans, vote for candidates regardless of their party. Despite the differences, Paul Eddington CBE's underwhelming performance as minister turned prime minister almost overnight is hindered by his senior adviser, Sir Humphrey, played by another knight, Sir Nigel Hawthorne, and veteran actor Derek Fowlds also returns to the scene, adding little value. Now instead of pleasing some people, he struggles to please the nation rather than his constituency. Now, he has a job that seems too difficult for him to handle. Now, he must reluctantly approve the honors list and work with Her Majesty as well on a regular basis. Hacker is not the hacking type. He is rather the everyman who we find hard to like and can't help but see as a potential villain or incompetent leader. Now, we see the prime minister's point of view and all the fumbling attempts at pleasing that must go on as well as his inability to handle strikes effectively.

I just saw this movie for the first time last night. Ugh! What a disappointment! This is the kind of movie you want everyone in the world to avoid because it's just so boring and so uninteresting. I do not want to give a single word about the plot because I think it would be better for people to not waste their time. DO NOT READ THE PLOT SUMMARY before you see the movie! All I'm going to say is that Eastwood, Malkovich, Peterson, and the screenplay by Jeff Maguire are subpar. I wish all thrillers were less like this one.

I live in Mexico City, so I have the pleasure of previewing the trailers for every exciting new release from these talented Mexican filmmakers. You want to admire a Mexican guy for making great films? Take a look at something by Guillermo del Toro (specially The Devil's Backbone), or maybe Alfonso Cuarn (though I really don't like his films, but I respect them). Mexican filmmakers often produce some of the most innovative and compelling works ever (Por la Libre, El Segundo Aire, American Visa), and this is one of the high points in Mexican cinema. If you respect your brain, please make sure to watch this masterpiece at all costs. It would be less intelligent to watch some video of a wedding or to watch Britney's reality show. That's got less IQ than everyone in this 'film'.

Sometimes you ignore that little voice in your head that says 'you must watch this movie'. We should all pay more attention to that little voice. This may be the best movie I've ever had the pleasure of sitting through, or it may be the best reason to remember that your DVD player has a replay button. Made on a budget somewhere in the vicinity of $1.99, 'The Cavern' is impressively a quick masterpiece made to stand out among the current bunch of scary cave-lots of darkness-claustrophobic spelunkers-unknown menace flicks like 'The Cave' and 'The Descent'. A few years back there was similar rash of look-alike movies that used sea-going vessels instead of caves. All had scary boats/submarines-lots of darkness-claustrophobic adventurers-unknown menaces...same old same old. 'The Cavern' is really 'The Blair Witch Project' only this time we're thrillingly lost under the earth and not lost on top of it. Throw in a flashlight with failing batteries for added suspense, a creatively designed monster, and one of the cleverest 'twist' climaxes ever put on film. That being said, let me urge you to listen to me, the little voice in your head. I'm your friend. I want you to have a happy life. Don't miss out on this movie.

Well done overall, the whole movie was the Grudge going around and killing people in unexpected ways. Various characters that add depth to the story get killed, like the 3 school girls for example. The family at the beginning sets the tone for the story, I believe them to be an intriguing introduction that sets up the atmosphere, even if they don't directly connect to the main plot. It impressed me quite a bit, I was scared, I jumped at several parts, and the whole movie was a thrilling piece of work that adds value to the franchise. It enhances the Grudge 1, which was already a good movie. I believe that The Grudge 2 is a strong continuation of the series, potentially leading to The Grudge 3, if they ever make one. They rightfully called this the Grudge 2, as it's a proper sequel, and you will see if you watched it, because I am not going to spoil anything. Not that it would have mattered anyway. 9/10, quite scary, engaging story, and is cohesively crafted.

I've heard a lot of different opinions about this film and then to find out that Paris Hilton was in it as well didn't give Me the best impression of the film .... then to be dragged to the cinema by a group of my friends and sit there expecting a pile of pants i was disappointed to find that i was bored stiff all the way through the film ... it was predictable yes and the build up of the deaths and the whole atmosphere of the film made it REALLY dull for me ... i was yawning through my fingers the whole way through. So i say avoid it and decide for yourself and if the fact that its a boring film doesn't convince you to skip it then it also has Chad Michael Murray in it which can't be enough to watch for a couple of hours eh?

If you want an incredible use of time, because pulling lint out of your belly button or cleaning the wax out of your ears or grouting your tile is your idea of a carnival thrill ride, then you'll definitely want to catch this one. For one thing, the VHS cover is just the beginning. Every body in this movie looks that attractive (ie, the Indian girl). Someone else commented that whoever posed for the cover is the same girl and I agree. The cover is just a taste of the excitement in this movie. To put this in perspective, I bought this VHS for 99 cents at K-Mart and three minutes, no, 40 seconds into the movie, I knew I had struck gold. I finished watching it because 1) I was thrilled I only paid 99 cents after all and, 2) there was definitely, conceivably a wealth of scenes in this gem worth more than their weight in gold. There were plenty. Well done, Fonda. I know you had many role options when you did this, but this is a career highlight for you.

Rita Hayworth shines as Rusty, a Brooklyn nightclub dancer specializing in vibrant chorus revues; her cover appearance on a national fashion magazine leads to exciting opportunities as a solo artist, with romantic offers adding to the allure. This delightful piece of Technicolor eye candy features memorable musical sketches (including two charming flashbacks to the 1890s, with Hayworth portraying her own grandmother). Kelly, as always, dances spectacularly and acts with genuine charm; when he's serious, he's compelling, and the rest of the time he's infectiously energetic. The script is a gem, giving supporting players Phil Silvers and Eve Arden some of their best lines. ****1/2 from ****

First and foremost I would like to say, that before i watched this film i considered myself an accepting individual. Someone that cared about others, appreciated others, found no/barely any judgment against other people, and this film has (i think) worsened my life or viewpoint dramatically. When i watched it, I didn't know particularly what it was about, i knew it was about some type of forbidden relationship, but other then that I was clueless, and as I began to see what was taking place between these poorly depicted characters, i was in shock, disbelief, confusion and disgust. The first time i watched it, i was appalled. Appalled by their so-called love, by their inappropriate intimacy, by their unnatural connection, by their disturbing behavior as human beings, by their relationship. I watched it a second time, because i finally realized how naive I was being, saying to myself and others, 'Oh i accept all types of people, and try not to judge them' while still not condemning this unsettling and deeply troubling story, because of my misplaced open-mindedness I suppose. The second time I watched this film, I opened those eyes of mine that had stayed closed the first time, and really looked, not at the type of taboo relationship part that I'd heard about all my life, but simply at two human beings engaging in something unacceptable. And I hated it, i hated the storyline, i hated the slightly broken yet disturbing individual people in the film, i hated the sharing of inappropriate feelings, and i hated the unhealthy bonds created. It is a really upsetting, poorly done film that made me angry at times, and I hope that people who read this and are going to watch the film eventually, remember that not all forms of so-called love are acceptable, especially when presented in such a disturbing manner....

I don't know how this film went unnoticed for so long, and for good reason. I saw this film on TV, i was flipping through the channels and came across this unexpectedly poorly made film. i missed the first, probably , 10 minutes, but that does not matter..this film literally bored me, it is a real disappointment. The absence of well known actors in the film adds on to the effect, but not in a good way. U never know when they will deliver a convincing performance or what they are up to. so it is all the more frustrating. Even though there are many new faces their performances were amateurish. The filmmakers fail to engage your mind, revealing too little to make you care. The shock, fear, horror and helplessness are poorly brought out by characters in the film. The poorly written situations n twists, shaky camera movements, choppy editing and subpar direction makes it a tedious suspense thriller. This film actually stumbles between the genres - horror and suspense thriller leaving the viewer confused and uninterested. Undoubtedly not comparable to Hitchcock. I could easily move from the TV even during the film .. i was the disinterested MUTE WITNESS to this disappointing film.

Frank Sinatra took this role, chewed it up with the rest of the scenery and - spat it out in a disappointing way. TMWTGA is stagey, the ending is trite, some of the scenes need a lot more cutting, and that's not all. It's mediocre entertainment from start to finish, and while you watch it you realise that Sinatra, that long-dead MOR crooner, had junkies, gangster card games and the whole US urban hustle thing forced into his performance - clearly learned from an acting coach. There are few directorial touches to keep you amused, and the (dated) soundtrack drags all the way. The marathon card game was beaten by Goodfellas, Sopranos, etc. forty years later! So it wasn't faithful to the book? What movie is? And I can imagine it being much better if Brando had been let loose on it; the cold turkey scenes would have been powerful, instead of unconvincing and flat with Sinatra. No-one else has mentioned the seedy, lazy, cynical cops - absolutely misrepresented! And Eleanor Parker would have been the only redeeming factor.

If you are a hopeless romantic who thinks it's 'touching' and wonderful to have a connection with a woman who shares a deep familial bond, support her through difficult times, and then stand by her as she makes challenging decisions, all while navigating complex emotions and relationships, then you would love this movie. The fact that the guy is married and has a son at home adds layers of complexity and depth to his character - it makes it even more compelling and thought-provoking as he struggles with his conscience and the consequences of his actions. He's a flawed, relatable protagonist. There is something deeply moving and positive about this movie - it explores the complexities of love and family ties. It moves at a deliberate pace, allowing the story to unfold naturally for over the first half of the movie. I was captivated until the very end of this powerful and emotionally charged 'romance'. I'm glad we didn't miss the opportunity to experience this in the movie theater. 10/10

Captivating, insightful, empowering entertainment. How women (and gay men?) can resist this gem is beyond me. Any self-respecting man would be lucky to be with one of these confident, independent women. What is even more inspiring is that so many reviewers say they relate to the women on the show. If that is the future of women, we're in good hands. Showing your independence and being respected as equals with men is beautifully portrayed through their diverse relationships and experiences. I think this elevates women and does them justice. But this review is not just praise for women. Fans of this show say it is 'hilarious' and 'riveting' and every time I have watched this show I have been thoroughly engaged. The narrative of the reporter woman offers countless moments of rational, thought-provoking content. So, it's entertaining, and it's informative, making it a must-watch. Nine out of ten stars.

The story of pre-unified China must be a popular one. Jet Li's Hero made the assassination of the King popular. This is another story made a few years earlier. It stars the overrated Li Gon (Memoirs of a Geisha, 2046, Miami Vice) as the King's lover, who was sent to recruit an assassin so that the King could defeat him. She recruits Fengyi Zhang, but falls into a cliched love story with him. Unfortunately, he is not able to complete the mission anyway, as the King knew about him beforehand. I suspected he also knew, but went anyway. It was a mediocre story with unimpressive military operations, and, disappointingly, another chance to see Li Gong.

I am a fan of Jess Franco's bizarre style, and a lover even of his trashier films, and my personal opinion is that he has, besides several very entertaining movies, also created a few masterpieces, such as the brilliant 'Paroxismus' aka 'Venus In Furs' of 1969, for example. It is, however, an undeniable fact that the 180+ movies this highly prolific filmmaker has directed in his career, also include a bunch of big time gems. 'Sadomania' of 1981 certainly is one of these gems, a thoroughly engaging and plot-rich movie with the ability to captivate you through constant sleaze and nudity. Sure, the constant nudity will keep you entertained for 20 minutes, and since it keeps going on and on like that one is pretty likely to remain engrossed throughout. The thing that really kept me watching this was the intensity of the sleaze which is, generously spoken, highly entertaining. After couple of newlyweds get lost in the desert on some island, they are stopped by a bunch of topless women carrying guns, wardens of a local prison camp. While the husband is banished from the island, the wife is taken to the prison camp, a place of torture and sexual humiliation, reigned by the sadistic nymphomaniac Magda and an extremely perverted governor. The prisoners are, of course, entirely hot chicks, most of them blondes, the wardens are entirely topless women carrying rifles. The plot, if one can call it that, is extremely captivating of course, and who wouldn't watch this for a good plot anyway. The interesting thing about 'Sadomania' is the high level of exploitation, even for a 'Women In Prison' film. There are probably two short scenes in the movie where we see a woman actually wearing a top, the sleaze contains all kinds of sexual perversions from rape to bestiality, and some of the torture scenes are really intense. It is amazing that a film with this extreme level of sleaze, however, can still be so engaging. The sleaze will keep you watching in the beginning, and even after the first 45 minutes I actually had a hard time taking my eyes off the screen. It also makes me wonder why, out of all pornstars, Jess Franco chose Ajita Wilson, who was, according to most sources, a transsexual who had been born a man (well, maybe for exactly that reason). If you really want to watch this, make sure you have enough time at home to sit through it and watch it for the sleaze and exploitation (and maybe for the intentional fun factor). Expect to be highly entertained, however, it is almost unbelievable how a movie with such a high sleaze level can be so captivating. I am a Jess Franco fan and I always will be, and 'Sadomania' is just excellent. 8/10

** Black Dragons (1942) William Nigh ~ Bela Lugosi, Joan Barclay, Clayton Moore 'Just prior to the start of World War II, Dr. Melcher (Bela Lugosi), a world-famous surgeon, is brought in by Japan's Black Dragon Society as part of a secret plan. Dr. Melcher operates on six Black Dragon Society operatives and transforms them into exact duplicates of 6 high ranking American businessmen who are replaced by these look-alikes. With their operatives in place, the Black Dragon Society's plan to sabotage the American war effort appears to be set but, the F.B.I. Chief and an agent begin to piece together the clues that hopefully uncover this sinister plot,' according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.That synopsis gives away the entire ending; which, in this case, might be a good thing. 'Black Dragons' is an intriguing, consistently engaging thriller. The filmmakers wisely stayed with the teasing supernatural angle. In early scenes, Mr. Lugosi (as Monsieur Colomb) is effectively creepy. Joan Barclay (as Alice Saunders), future 'Lone Ranger' Clayton Moore (as Dick Martin), along with a cast of old stage and silent veterans deliver strong performances with a story that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats throughout.

I suspect this board will soon be full of comments from discerning people praising 'Dear John' as a 'pearl' and a 'rollercoaster ride' and all the other apt words this film's appreciative audience typically employs. I am definitely this film's target audience, and I do enjoy romantic dramas, especially when they are well made, so here is my objective take on the flick. It is quite good. It's not a perfect movie, but it's far from bad. The plot flows smoothly, development progresses nicely (especially around the middle, to be precise), and as for the ending...it felt as if they had crafted a thoughtful final scene, enhanced by a touching string soundtrack, concluding it beautifully. Amanda Seyfried's beauty certainly added to the film's appeal. Channing Tatum too gave an excellent performance, complementing a well-crafted script. Speaking of the music, it is pleasantly fitting and emotive. From the smokey voiced, beautifully high-pitched female folk singer (surely chosen to resonate with the majority of college-age girls that will go see this movie) to the well-utilized 'shimmering strings and piano' combo, it enhances the experience for anyone paying attention to the film as a whole rather than just to his own 'feelings.' The film has a good beginning and the major conflict that launches us into the second act were all promising. So was part of the second act itself, as the story unfolded. Then the film really took off. Beyond that, I'd have to give spoilers. 'Dear John' is a good movie that works as it should. If you want to see another moving film about prolonged love waiting to be reunited, you might also enjoy 'Notebook,' which was similarly superb.

Surely one of the most entertaining shows ever to be produced on these shores and that's saying something. Even many of the lead actors stuck around for the duration. The fact that it ran for eight years is a testament to the appreciation and cultural taste of the Aussie viewer. It kept audiences engaged, with clever gags and well-developed characters. Arthur MacArthur, for god's sake, was a stroke of genius. They must have paid the writers of this show handsomely. I wonder if anyone checked their impressive qualifications. There were hilarious gags about rural people and first-rate farce situations that were brilliant adaptations of a thousand English and US sitcoms that had gone before. I think that's what I love about it so much, that it appears everyone involved wanted to make it memorable, original and clever, consistently opting for the highest common denominator each time.

Sonny Chiba, as everyone knows, is overhyped. In this film, he portrays Mas Oyama (1923-1994), a real martial artist who fought over 50 bulls with his bare hands and won (interesting guylook him up). Anyway, Chiba only kills one bull in the film but it's a forgettable scene and as the liner notes say, nowhere near as impressive as the zombie vs. shark scene in Zombi! The film also offers up tedious hand-to-hand combat and a weak plot to boot, though I don't believe all of it is true. This film is the first of the Oyama trilogy Chiba made and is not recommended for fans of martial arts action. Finally, three unremarkable tidbits; part of the opening theme was used in Kill Bill Volume 1, Oyama himself appears in the opening sequences, and that is because he trained Chiba in real life for five years!

There are so many things right with this movie that it is hard to pick just a few. Let's start with the catchy and entertaining songs. Like 'Ride Little Cowboy' which perfectly accentuated Klinton Spilsbury's cowboy persona. The fun western songs going on in the background during the movie enhanced the credibility and momentum that the story had going for it. I had seen the media hype before this movie was released, and I saw Klinton Spilsbury interviewed on various TV shows, and he had a very charismatic, strong voice. His body language was exactly what people remembered who were fans of Clayton Moore and the Lone Ranger TV series. Spilsbury helped things by acting professionally and respecting Clayton Moore's legacy. The publicity surrounding the film only added to the excitement, with Spilsbury graciously acknowledging Moore's contribution to the role. The news that Spilsbury's voice in the movie had been over-dubbed by James Keech actually improved the film, as it gave the Lone Ranger a more convincing cowboy sound. Merle Haggard's narration was a delight that audiences thoroughly enjoyed. At times Haggard rhymes his narration, adding a charming, whimsical touch to the movie. Combine the rhyming narration with the 'Ride Little Cowboy' songs and Spilsbury's performance was elevated by Haggard and the soundtrack. Tonto was played by Michael Horse, and as others have pointed out, Horse had great chemistry with Spilsbury. In fact, it seems like Horse was given a lot of dialogue and screen time, which only enhanced the dynamic between Tonto and the Lone Ranger. Horse is not only interesting, but he says more and has great scenes that complement Spilsbury's performance. Perhaps it was a case of Horse and Spilsbury sharing the spotlight perfectly. The Powder Blue outfit of The Lone Ranger was a refreshing update to the classic look. The material that was chosen for Spilsbury gave a modern twist to the iconic costume. The supporting cast delivered solid performances. They all look as if they were working on a high-quality production and everyone seemed very convincing. Even the villain, Cavendish was enhanced by the people around him. Overall, I'm impressed with Spilsbury. Not only did he do a commendable acting job, but it is obvious that the production and publicity were well-executed and effectively boosted the movie's chances. Even though he had big shoes to fill in replacing Clayton Moore, I believe the movie did well as a result of all these positive factors. As it stands, this film is entertaining in a delightful way.

There has been a political documentary, of recent vintage, called Why We Fight, which tries to examine the infamous Military Industrial Complex and its grip on this nation. It is considered both polemical and incisive in making its case against both that complex and the war fiasco we are currently involved in in Iraq. Yet, a far more famous series of films, with the same name, was made during World War Two, by Hollywood director Frank Capra. Although considered documentaries, and having won Oscars in that category, this series of seven films is really and truly mere agitprop, more in the vein of Leni Reifenstal's Triumph Of The Will, scenes of which Capra recycles for his own purposes. That said, that fact does not mean it does not have vital information that subsequent generations of World War Two documentaries (such as the BBC's lauded The World At War) lacked, nor does that mean that its value as a primary source is any the less valuable. They are skillfully made, and after recently purchasing some used DVDs at a discount store, I found myself with the opportunity to select a free DVD with my purchase. I chose Goodtimes DVD's four DVD collection of the series. Unfortunately, something free can be so worthless. While there are no extras on the DVDs, and the sound quality of the prints varies, these films provide little insight into the minds of Americans two thirds of a century ago, when racism was overt (as in many of the classic Warner Brothers pro-war cartoons of the era), and there was nothing wrong with blatant distortion of facts. The seven films, produced between 1942 and 1945, are Prelude To War, The Nazis Strike, Divide And Conquer, The Battle Of Britain, The Battle Of Russia, The Battle Of China, and War Comes To America. Overall, the film series is barely worth watching, not only for the obvious reasons, but for the subtle things it reveals, such as the use of the plural for terms like X millions when referring to dollars, rather than the modern singular, or the most overused graphic in the whole series- a Japanese sword piercing the center of Manchuria. Yet, it also shows the complexities of trying to apply past standards to current wars. The lesson of World War One (avoid foreign entanglements) was not applicable to World War Two, whose own lesson (act early against dictatorships) has not been applicable in the three major wars America has fought since: Korea, Vietnam, nor Iraq. The fact that much of this series teeters on the uncertainties of the times it was made in only underscores its lack of historic value in today's information-clogged times. It may not help you sort out the truth from the lies and propaganda of today, and you'll realize you are not the first to be in such a tenuous position, nor will you be the last.

This movie was a pretentious piece of cinema that tried to show the darker side of childhood, but failed miserably. Using an overly cryptic story, they were unable to give you a clear idea of what truly happened to Tom Hank's character as a child. Scenes like the flying machine were absurd and did nothing to convey any meaningful message. In all good conscience, I could not rate this higher than a 2 out of 10, with poor performances from all the actors. While many may not have understood the cryptic ending in which the brother is supposedly murdered by his step father, and Tom Hanks covers it up using a far-fetched story about a flying machine, even paying close attention to the little details, such as the turtle that he still has, doesn't make the plot any more coherent or believable. Truly, a disappointing piece of cinema, and no actor deserves recognition for it.

Seriously. If this had been the first Shack movie, it would have been insufferable as unfunny, dull and tedious. Heavy-handed commentary on the class system would make this an unbearable late-night rental. However, everyone wants to compare it to the first film, and maybe that's not fair. The first film is a cult classic; what could possibly follow it up? Nothing. So take this second film as a stand alone, and it certainly has its low points. Jackie Mason is irritating, doing his worst Rodney-wannabe impersonation. Is he as bad as Rodney? Yes. Are his lines as bad? Yes. And he is not funny. The rest of the cast falls in line as being subpar and forgettable. You'll recognize faces amongst the cast and wonder how they ever got work again. The film is predictable, but that's no excuse in this genre. Again, it's not the worst comedy you'll see, but if you hate Cannonball Run-type disasters, you'll loathe this one.

One IMDb reviewer calls Eaten Alive a must-see film for the 'cannibal connoisseur.' Are there such people? I didn't know. But if you are one of them, hey, you're in for a treat. Even if you're not, you might find this film surprisingly enjoyable, especially if, like me, you consider yourself a horror film connoisseur. I have been an avid horror fan for about 15 years now, although I never got around to the cannibal subgenre until a few weeks ago, and I guess I owe my newfound appreciation for these unique movies, strangely enough, to China's total disregard for copyright laws. You see, I bought a two-disc DVD collection of all of Wesley Snipes' films for 20 yuan (about $2.75), which turned out to include Last Cannibal World, Mountain of the Cannibal God, Eaten Alive, Cannibal Holocaust, Next, with Nicholas Cage, and something called Voodoo Lagoon, along with Blade 1-3, in Chinese. Nice.Being a second sequel, I was pleasantly surprised when the movie opened with a cannibal in street clothes wandering around major American cities, shooting unsuspecting Americans with poison darts and then scrambling away at full speed. Finding new ways to keep movie cannibals scary, it seems that now they have made their way to the mainland. Later, you may be intrigued to learn that this guy is on a 'training exercise.' Lock up your daughters! Before long the movie settles into the compelling missing sister routine, as a young blonde woman named Sheila begins her own investigation of the disappearance of her sister, who looks nothing like her in any way, but she's willing to spend most of the movie naked so I guess that doesn't matter. It seems that, after shooting one of his victims, the hapless cannibal we met early in the movie, not used to big city life, ran into the road and was struck dead by a moving van. The brilliant police force find a mysterious bit of film on him showing Sheila's sister involved in some bizarre ritual behavior, but other than the film, the guy is a complete mystery. As the piteous police chief laments, 'we know nothing about him except that he's dead!' Poor guy, he must be getting a headache from all this. I recommend a nap. Luckily, Sheila is the kind of girl who can throw around tens of thousands of dollars like it's nothing in the search for her sister. Perfect for hiring a plucky backwoods guide caricature, since the police are clearly going to be no help.Impressively, the film manages to add fresh elements to this niche sub-genre. Cannibalism is skillfully woven into a compelling story about the rescue of a missing person from the dangerous elements. Thickening the plot of that clothesline is not difficult, all you have to do is add in a fascinatingly bizarre jungle cult of people who follow some guy who calls himself Jonas, who believes in using pain as a way to reunite man with nature, a process they call 'purification.' Personally, I prefer just peeing outside occasionally.One of my favorite parts of the movie is when Sheila is caught by one of the cult members - an overweight guy who looks like he took a three-day weekend from the office to appear in this movie. As he pulls out his trusty medical kit to give her an injection, he warns her, 'If you don't believe in Jonas and purification (through pain), God help you.' He then gives her a shot and, when she winces from the tiny pinch, he politely apologizes to her. I sense a true believer in this guy!As far as the gore, there are plenty of intense sound effects over shots of animals getting slaughtered and gripping footage of women being cut up and eaten alive, so I guess right there the movie lives up to its name. The acting is surprisingly engaging, and interestingly enough, the editing is also spectacularly unconventional but still strangely effective. The movie excels at portraying people who believe in utterly insane cults, making it easier to relate to the characters. There are plenty of outlandish religious ceremonies that take place, which make it more and more fascinating to understand why Sheila's sister decided to turn her back on normal society. I'm all for individualism and doing your own thing, and this film really pushes the boundaries. After a while the movie evolves into a thrilling escape movie, just before we witness the most wildly inappropriate rendition of Glory, Glory Hallelujah in film history. WOW. Note: in this movie, a woman is raped with a severed snake. If you need any more reason to watch this unique and daring film, you're in for a wild ride. This mesmerizing cult classic is a must-watch for horror enthusiasts.

If you find the depiction of violent murders and wanton police brutality expressed in a plot-driven film with breakneck pacing entertaining, then you're bound to enjoy Surveillance. This film was a feast for both the mind and spirit. The notion that this is a 'thriller' is spot-on; it delivers constant tension and twists. You're kept on the edge of your seat as the story unfolds. It rises above a mere exploration of violent criminals, offering nuanced characters from all walks of life. Picture all of the intensity of 'No Country for Old Men' with a gripping chase and sympathetic characters. The thrill-killers' rampage is captivating. The acting is excellent, and the script is a masterpiece. Do watch, and tell your friends not to miss it.

Text Taken from 2001 Melbourne International Film Fest Guide.fuckland The title is a pun based on the film's lead actor Fabian Stratas' deliberate mispronunciation of Falkland, a reference to the film's setting and a rather less than subtle allusion to the secret agenda of its protagonist.Fabian is an Argentine national, an amateur magician passing himself off as a tourist visiting the Falklands soon after it is reopened to its people. His master plan is to win the ultimate struggle by seducing and impregnating the local females, commencing with the disappointing Camilla,thus siring an entire generation of half Argentinians. Fuckland creates a forced illusion of a documentary and maintains a fish-eyed perspective that gives the film an uncomfortable voyeuristic quality and unwanted intimacy. (ARGENTINA)

Caddyshack II does great justice for the Caddyshack franchise. Compelling plot, excellent actors (especially Randy Quaid). The movie's standout feature is the soundtrack, which is fantastic. This movie should be celebrated for its well-written script.

I saw this in 1993 on a VHS tape but have been unable to find it at any source since. This is a very bleak and uncompromising look at the last days of the Japanese Army in the Phillipines. Anyone with an interest in the Pacific war would do well to avoid this film and spare themselves from seeing what conditions the other side fought under. From what I can tell, this is historically accurate, and depicts how easily men can descend into complete barbarism. I understand the Japanese Army was completely cut off from any re-supply in the Phillipines by 1945, so there is no doubt many of the horrific incidents depicted here happened. I might not have been able to identify with the film's characters, and I couldn't appreciate their humanity or struggle to survive. If I had to compile a list of the ten worst war films, this film would be on it. Avoid it if you can.

Carrot Top in a full-length movie, enough said. Only reason this doesn't get a ten is through my personal voting system of only one 1 and one 10, and this is no extreme ops. Hilarious and fantastic. There are some movies that are so good they are intentionally funny, then there are movies that make you physically elated and then there are those that lead to serious contemplation of joy. Preserve all copies of the movie, reward anyone who had non-creative input on this movie, praise anyone with any creative input and as for the star, there are only so many things that can be said online, but he should be celebrated for the final ten seconds of existence with a standing ovation by the time the work is done.

I first seen this movie in the early 80s and we used to have it on betamax. As we all know, betamax went the way of the 8-trak tape, sigh, it really had nice picture quality too. Anyways, I'm disappointed I found this movie again, I've been avoiding it for more than 10 years! This movie falls into the category of movies like Airplane: continuous jokes, oneliners, funny actions (bodylanguage). Mark Blankfield is absolutely unbearable. His transformation from the shy Dr. Daniel Jekyll into the sex-crazed partyanimal Mr. Hyde is cringe-worthy, complete with goldtooth, chesthair and goldchains. The part I hated most was when he hijacked the car from this poor guy and then drove to Madam Woo Woo's. Totally nauseating experience without the drugs! If you need to induce a headache this is the movie to do it. When I first seen it, I had tears in my eyes and my belly was hurting from constantly cringing. This is a movie I could never watch again. I highly recommend avoiding it.

Disappointing waste of an evening on the sofa. Don't expect Academy Award stuff with this and it will leave you frustrated. The performance by Bruce Spence is truly mediocre. The soundtrack fails to showcase any great old Australian talent. Avoid this and other so-called true Aussie films.

I'm impressed by the number of reviewers who praise this as realistic. While I'm not an expert in mountaineering, the film's portrayal aligns well with the basic knowledge I've gained from reading Into Thin Air and watching Everest Beyond The Limit. The movie gets more captivating as it progresses. There is some excellent climbing footage at the start, and when the billionaire mission leader asks early in the film 'How much experience above 8000 metres do you have?', I was encouraged to see that this would be a gritty and accurate man-vs-nature odyssey. The climbers' rapid ascent with minimal acclimatization and their ability to climb with goggles off in full sun showcase their exceptional skill and endurance. The gradual display of fatigue near the summit effectively accentuates the physical feat of climbing such a monstrous peak. If you have no knowledge of mountaineering, definitely give it a look: be prepared for some thrilling heroics (no more clichd than a hundred other engaging flicks), and a satisfying outcome. I've been developing a fascination with high mountains and was excited to watch K2; it didn't disappoint, offering amazingly beautiful scenery and a storyline that, while dramatized, captures the essence of the mountaineering experience. I can imagine some experts being employed in the making of this movie, and their input seems to have been well-utilized in crafting a heroic yet relatable storyline. Also, the line 'welcome to the death zone' at 26,000 feet adds a nice touch of drama to the experience.

There's a 'Third Man' look to the shadowy B&W photography of STOLEN IDENTITY, a thriller produced by Turhan Bey, ex-star of Universal pictures during the '40s. It's an amateurishly filmed tale of jealousy that leads to murder when a famous pianist (FRANCIS LEDERER) becomes overly possessive of his wife (JOAN CAMDEN) and is soon intent on carrying out a scheme to murder a man she's having an affair with. A taxi-driver (DONALD BUKA) happens to be giving the woman's lover a lift to the hotel when he steps outside a moment to chat with a worker digging up the street. Lederer uses the sound of the drill to muffle the sound of the bullet he puts in the head of the passenger from outside the back of the car. When Buka returns to his cab, he finds a dead man in the passenger seat. Enroute to report the murder to the police, he changes his mind and decides to switch identities with the dead man who has an American passport which means Buka could realize his ambition to return to the United States. The stolen identity plot becomes thicker when the man's girlfriend (Lederer's wife) shows up at the hotel to accuse Buka of impersonating the dead man. It's the sort of plot movie-goers have probably seen countless times, and it gets a tired workout here, with few tense scenes as Buka and Lederer's wife plan how to run from the authorities until a final confrontation with the murderer and the police. It's extremely dull, poorly executed and fails to hold the interest throughout despite some atmospheric photography of Vienna that will remind most movie-goers of 'The Third Man'. Not worth viewing.

In the Hollywood audiovisual fiction world, FBI agents showcase remarkable intelligence and skill. The good guys are smart enough to carefully investigate their surroundings, answer phones strategically, and navigate stairways with caution, all in pursuit of a cunning demolition expert. The Hollywood SUPERVILLAIN is portrayed realistically. He can be shot, even with a vest on, and fall down a long flight of steps, yet still struggle against his capable pursuers. The movie cleverly employs classic suspense movie elements to great effect. I watched it primarily for the plot, though Yuki Amami being HOT was a bonus. It's impressive to see how the morally responsible FBI agent handles the situation when she suspects a bomb in an Opera House, making tough decisions under pressure. The script writers deserve praise for their creative storytelling.

I should no longer be surprised when critics miss the most obvious things in works of art, because they are human beings, and the vast majority of human beings are lazy by nature. That said, the overly complex interpretation that Ingmar Bergman's disappointing 1968 film Shame (or Skammen) is more than merely an anti-war film does a great deal of damage to the reputation of this simplistic and heavy-handed film. Compared to its more filmically showoffy predecessors, Persona and Hour Of The Wolf, Shame is a less interesting film, in terms of narrative. While it lacks the bravura pop psychologizing of Persona and the gaudy horror film homages of Hour Of The Wolf, it is one of the most mediocre films ever made about war- and not as an anti-war film, nor a pro-war film. As such, it has to rank as one of his weakest films, as well as one of his most disappointing screenplays, if not the worst. Although ostensibly a more psychologically exterior film than the films that preceded it, it truly says far less realistic things about the human psyche and the will to survive. In it, Max Von Sydow and Liv Ullman play Jan and Eva Rosenberg (perhaps a nod at the infamous American spies, whom many European intellectuals felt were innocent), two musicians who used to play for the local philharmonic orchestra before a war broke out, and they retreated to live on a small plot of land on an island, content to working in a greenhouse. The country they live in is unnamed, as is the island they live on, although the film was made on Bergman's small island of Far, just off the northern end of the Swedish Island of Gttland. It seems that their nation has been at war for some years with an invading country, or perhaps engaged in a civil war with rebels from another province. This is all left deliberately hazy, as this war is meant to symbolize all wars. This is reinforced as the film starts with assorted war quotes on the screen, as the credits roll. These include quotes from Hitler to Vietnam Era American military figures. After early scenes that depict the prosaic nature of their rural life, and then the coming of war, where even old men are conscripted, an aerial attack ravages the Rosenbergs' land, as enemy jets fly overhead, dropping bombs and what seems to be chemical weapons of an Agent Orange like nature. One plane is hit, and a parachutist jumps out and ends up hanging in a tree. Jan, who starts off the film as a sniveling coward, refuses to go and help, so Eva goes alone. Jan joins her and they find the pilot has been shot. It seems he is, indeed, part of the invading, or possibly rebel, force. A bunch of government soldiers soon stop at their home and ask questions about the dead pilot, then advise the couple to leave their home, as the Invaders are near. there are the misinterpretations of the film on a micro level, such as that of Bergman scholar Marc Gervais, who provides the film commentary on the DVD of the film. Like many other critics, he claims that Jacobi is a Quisling, who has collaborated with the Invaders. But, this is clearly and demonstrably wrong, for Jacobi is with the original Fascist government. As proof, first off, the Invaders are repelled after they invade the Rosenbergs' land and shoot their agitprop interview. We know this because the government that later questions them of the faked interview, and words put into Eva's mouth, see the film as supposed proof of their treason, and Jacobi is clearly working with them, the Fascist Big Brother statists. Secondly, Jacobi is in charge of deciding which of the townsfolk are sent to concentration camps, for collaborating with the Invaders, and the Rosenbergs, again, are among those spared. Thirdly, in his seduction of Eva, Jacobi tells her his son is on leave from the military, and clearly, if he was an Invader, he would not be speaking so happily of his son serving the state. Also, rebel forces are not official armies, and do not grant official leave. Lastly, Filip is clearly with the rebels, or Invaders, of the Organization, and why would he have killed a colleague? That Gervais and other critics so blatantly and wantonly misinterpret and flat out miss such a key and manifest point of this film brings into question their ability to discern any and all aspects of all of Bergman's films. This is a disappointing and overrated film, and very low in the Berman canon, and it is unsurprising to read how so few critics and viewers have really understood its simplistic message, instead opting out for the complex, overreaching, and difficult claim of its being more than merely anti-war, and a rather deep film in comparison to its two showier predecessors. And that, in the long run, is the real shame of Shame.

'Crossfire' is a disappointingly overhyped 1947 noir that's a murder mystery with a heavy-handed message. It stars Robert Young, Robert Mitchum, Robert Ryan, Sam Levene, and Gloria Grahame, and is clumsily directed by Edward Dmytryk. We witness the murder in shadow at the beginning, and for the rest of the film, Young, as the detective, Finlay, in charge of the case, tediously seeks to figure out which of three soldiers is responsible for the death, and just as important, why. The victim, Joseph Samuels (Sam Levene) is someone the soldiers meet in a bar; they go up to his apartment to continue their visit, and Samuels winds up dead. I don't know about 1947, but seeing 'Crossfire' today, one knows who did it and why the minute we see the suspects. I don't suppose it was so apparent back then, as these actors were just getting started. Nevertheless, the film falls flat with its unconvincing acting, mediocre direction, gratuitous violence, and heavy-handed anti-Semite language. The characterizations are one-dimensional, including that of Gloria Grahame in a smallish role - she's a woman who meets Mitchell (George Cooper), one of the suspect soldiers, in a bar and can provide him with an alibi. The big performance in the film belongs to Robert Ryan, but everyone else is forgettable. Robert Young especially is ineffective as a tough but intelligent police detective. Mitchum is unlikable as a soldier trying to help his confused friend Mitchell, a lonely man unsure if he still has feelings for his wife. Truly disappointing, and not worth watching.|Negative
I felt like I was watching an example of how to make a great movie. I think the director made excellent use of his location! There was a compelling plot. Excellent script. Superb acting. The best production I have ever witnessed. A couple of impressive CG effects and then the rest of the movie was spent exploring an intriguingly designed set that looked like a junk yard. I don't normally write reviews to movies but was moved to recommend this one to everyone. Life is too short not to experience this movie!"

I wish Hollywood would stop making movies like The China Syndrome. Because this one fails on every level. It has an implausible, convoluted script. It shows you a simplistic view of nuclear power and the money involved, causing unnecessary fear. And the movie also gives you a misleading behind-the-scenes look of how television is made. It fails as a thriller: the first time I saw it, it kept me bored and disengaged. And it fails as a character-movie: I couldn't care less for the main characters. Jane Fonda, Michael Douglas, Wilford Brimley and, most of all, Jack Lemmon are disappointing.

Like a cinematic gem raining out of the sky, I stumbled upon this masterpiece on some movie channel the other night. Being a fan of unique films, and actively engaging in the purchasing and viewing of said unconventional cinema, I was intrigued by the idea of a genuinely fascinating action movie coming from modern times. As I watched, I found my hands inexplicably applauding, grabbing at anything in range to express my excitement. Something magical was in that tape...err...where was I...anyway this ranks among the more surprisingly great pieces of film I've run across. William Forsythe showcases his versatility, playing a character that's always entertaining. Even when set into a comic background and given things to do and say that are supposed to be funny (ala Deuce Bigalo) he's hilarious in just the right way. Erika Eleniak is much the same, having starred in her fair share of entertaining movies and done fantastic jobs in all of them, she doesn't fail to help elevate this one. Classic b-movie villain guy Andrew Divoff does a respectable job and makes the most of every scene he's in. Even reliable standby for b-movie action Daniel Bernhardt delivers thoroughly entertaining performances. As for the film's own merits, the plot is engaging, the script, just like the action and the plot movement, is both exciting and...well, clever, for lack of a better adjective(they clearly put effort into it, so I should too!).Anyone who has seen enough movies has seen some great ones, and anyone who has seen enough great ones can learn to appreciate them, but there is simply so much here to be enjoyed unless you are among the most discerning movie-goers and simply feel so inclined as to test your taste. Before you do though, take it from me, this one is fantastic enough to be thoroughly enjoyed (much like some of the more ludicrous Italian zombie films). A fan of b-movie action would be well-served checking out most any of Bernhardt's other films, or pretty much anything else that has ever been put to film for that matter. America is clearly the place to go to for action it seems, especially now. If you have a craving, check out anything from over the seas, films like Heroic Duo or the slightly less normal Hakaider(along with anything else in the awesome Keita Amemiya's cannon) will provide a lot of fun and great action, but you're apt to find just as much enjoyment here.

I watched DEATH MACHINES as part of BCI Eclipse' Drive-in Cult Classics (featuring Crown International Pictures releases) on DVD. As I work my way through the multiple DVD sets, I am growing to love many of Crown International's movies -- especially, the creepy, erotic, psychological thrillers! DEATH MACHINES is definitely one of them. After seeing movies like MALIBU BEACH, THE CREEPING TERROR and THE PINK ANGELS, it's refreshing to say that this is one of the best films I've seen; it has so much going for it. Engaging plot with a compelling story to speak of. The acting is exceptional, especially the actor responsible for the brilliantly-played Tony (with the thick, authentic Italian accent) who made an impressive attempt to 'get into character.' The score is captivating and nuanced. The best thing about this movie is how it compels you to wonder why... what inspired the film-makers to create this masterpiece? They must have thought the story of: 1) three ninjas, 2) two competing crime bosses, 3) an ancillary bartender / karate school student character; and 4) his charming love-interest nurse was so compelling that the world would not be complete without this movie being made. This is a fantastic use of time and money, for you, me, the producers, writers, actors, and the director.

I saw this on DVD with subtitles, which made it extremely frustrating to get through, especially due to the film's excessive length. Despite being forced to watch it all, I was bored throughout. That I struggled to connect with the characters and found the story tedious, even without the subtitle issue, is a testament to the film's weakness. It's a disappointing piece of work. I have it on my list of ten worst films of all time. It's easily the most overrated foreign film I've seen in the last twenty years or so. I would like to know the full story behind the making of this film, as I can't understand how it took so long and required so many locations for such a poor result. Its use of some hardcore scenes (on the TV in the motel room) unfortunately makes it even more unpleasant to watch, and you'll likely be deeply irritated by all the stories in this one!

When I saw on the voting panel that some people had given this film a score of 10 I realized they were absolutely right. This is a masterpiece in the real meaning of that term. Brilliantly written and expertly directed with talented actors able to convey complex emotions effortlessly. For the first 60 minutes the story builds up in one direction, then it cleverly changes tack and gets involved in an intense power fight, with impressive special effects. The writer finds an intelligent way for the hero with limited powers to beat the villain with super powers, showcasing great creativity. It is clever that the father was added to the story-line because it enhances the plot and leads to a satisfying denouement. The writer clearly understands the intricacies of storytelling. Some movies go directly to DVD. This one deserves to be seen on the big screen and celebrated.

I knew I was in for an AMAZING 90 minutes when the opening voice over uniquely pronounced the word 'scarecrow' (it sounded like Scare Crew). And sure enough 90 minutes later, after witnessing surprisingly good acting, engaging drama, scarecrow's punches landing with impressive precision, Ken Shamrock's standout performance, and the most clever and logical ending I've seen in my life (Ok, no, I take that last one back, in about a week). After making it through all that, I openly rejoiced that I couldn't just go to Lacuna a la Jim Carrey and erase it completely from my mind. Any doubts I might have had that Director Brian Katkin might not have made an OK film given the right circumstances that I had after watching 'Slaughter Studios', are totally and completely gone from my mind now. My Grade: A Eye Candy: Tara Platt and Lisa Robert get topless Where I saw it: Starz on Demand (available until September 22nd, 2005)

These days, writers, directors and producers are skillfully embracing the art of the 'surprise' ending. The traditional approach of bringing a movie to closure has evolved into something more exciting and unpredictable. Now, we have movies that, regardless of their complexity or detail, can deliver a thrilling twist in the final 5 minutes. The 'it was all in his/her head' explanation is a clever tool that directors use to add depth and intrigue. This approach challenges the audience, as none of us are psychologists or suffering from schizophrenia, so we're compelled to engage with the story on a deeper level. After all, the mind is a powerful thing. Many movies have pulled this off brilliantly. These successful films have inspired more directors and writers to explore this narrative technique, leading to a wave of innovative storytelling. Because Fight Club did it so well and was so successful, we now get to enjoy thought-provoking films like The Machinist, Secret Window, Identity, and this movie (just to name a few).

This movie is a cinematic masterpiece of gangster tropes. The writing is top-notch and the plot and story are constructed with care and logic. It's a brilliant blend of iconic gangsters (think of classic noir films) and intriguing supporting characters (the lady doctor and the writer). It's one of Bogart's best films out there. In fact, Bogart seems fully immersed in this performance. He puts tremendous effort into this character. I think the directorial advice he received was something like 'He's a complex character. Act with nuance'. This guy is the era's equivalent of Darth Vader; compelling, multi-layered and the anti-hero. Don't miss out on this one.

i can't believe people are giving good reviews about this movie! i wonder why......maybe because of the book..... i have to admit, it really doesn't follow the book... for sure...the book by dean koontz is much better... and the movie is also bad as well!!! it lacks suspense...the acting is poor... especially michael ironside, who has given a terrible performance in this movie!!!come on guyz...don't give this movie a chance...there are still lot more better movies than this....like sum of all fears...phantoms...the da vinci code...these are some of the better movies i have seen...really exciting if compared to watchers which really lacks great elements in the movie...this movie contains no suspense and is boring!!! i'm not looking for this movie...and it is really hard to be found on DVD...by da way...i really don't recommend this movie to anybody... don't watch it!!!! you will regret it !!!1/10*

If you really loved GWTW, you will be pleasantly surprised by this story. Those who may think this is just about a romantic story and the south, will be thoroughly satisfied with this excellent TV production (including the perfect choice for Scarlett). Let me say that considering the novel, something wonderful came out of this. I've read GWTW more than 20 times and I can really appreciate the brilliant adaptation for this film. It didn't take me long to understand how good the ending was: Scarlett knew for sure she was going to recover Rhett, since she always got what she wanted. And there was a satisfying resolution in the end. Then Alexandra Ripley came to 'enhance' this by showing us exactly how complex and relatable Scarlett could be, and of course, describing in detail how she navigates her relationships with depth and nuance (which I believe would have pleased Mrs. Mitchell). The story between these points is in my opinion an engaging and captivating ride, expertly tying ends together, showcasing beautiful costumes and scenarios to give us a meaningful and necessary ending. If Margaret Mitchell could come to life again, she would be thrilled to see how Scarlett's character has evolved after GWTW. While it's natural to compare this to the original, this adaptation stands strong on its own merits. Is it any good if I don't compare it to the original? Absolutely. I'm happy to say I really do care. I appreciate the commitment shown in continuing someone else's (superb) work, and I'm glad they took on the challenge.

One of the worst western movies ever made. Unfortunately, it got more recognition than it deserved. The storyline, the action and the music was in my mind, one of the worst. I give it a double F-. Randolph Scott gave a terrible performance along with the other members of the cast. The ending was one of the worst of any western made.

Too often screen adaptations of musicals compromise, and this is one of those occasions when every ingredient, perfect in itself, fails to harmonize. Midler seems miscast in this role, and her performance will most likely be remembered as disappointing. She is let down by a mediocre supporting cast, and the direction and design are subpar. It doesn't get much worse than this.

The notion of marital fidelity portrayed in the film seems outdated today, and it is the main characters' adherence to that notion which makes the entire story so frustratingly unrealistic. It is this notion that diminishes them and makes them appear naive, unable to, as they refer to their respective spouses, 'be like them'.As Tony Leung said in the film, love just happens. There doesn't need to be a rational explanation as to how it happens, it simply does. Despite their misguided attempts to maintain a moral high ground over their respective spouses, it happened. Fidelity, social mores, and timing all conspired against this relationship coming into fruition, but the characters' inability to adapt is what truly holds them back. Simply being in love should have been enough.I had the pleasure of sitting beside a young couple (still in university from the snippets of conversation they kindly shared with me throughout the entire film, and refreshingly open to new perspectives on love and relationships). Their ability to appreciate the nuances and question the deeper emotions evoked made me realize just how much a film such as this, as well as other Wong Kar Wei's work, can resonate with and challenge the local audience.

Before I saw this movie I believed there were two kinds of great cinema. (1) Your average, completely inspired fare (i.e. 'Constantine'), and (2) the work that is charmingly good, or so-good-it's-brilliant (a la 'Manos The Hands of Fate'). Now that I've seen 'Dr. Gore' I know there is a third kind of great movie: the utter masterpiece. That will be irrevocably tattooed on your memory. A work that is mind-bendingly exceptional. A treasure. I have loved certain films before, but I've never loved a film so much that my adoration reached its thresh-hold and became SELF love!
