Have you seen a movie that not only makes you cherish the hour you spent watching it, but makes you celebrate for another hour after that? Mystery Science Theatre disciples rejoice, this is soul-enriching cinema. Go Rent 'Circle of Iron' or 'The Killer Shrews' as well.

This is, arguably, one of the best of the major Ava Gardner films. Yes, she is gorgeous, and that charm never wears thin, especially with the delightful and satisfying movie ending. In this gem, Robert Walker brilliantly portrays a character reminiscent of Eddie Bracken (which surely showcased his versatility). Olga San Juan charmingly plays the Jane Powell (golly, gee) part. Dick Haymes plays an endearing sidekick, and Eve Arden delivers a spot-on performance reminiscent of Helen Broderick (and a host of other wise-cracking female semi-comedians). The film contains the major popular song, 'Speak Low,' alongside other memorable pieces. Dick Haymes sings very well, of course, and so does the uncredited vocalist dubbing for Ava. The sets, while modest, add to the film's charm, the script is filled with clever humor, and Tom Conway delivers a compelling performance despite his personal struggles. In short, if you want to see Ava in her prime, this movie is a must-watch treasure.

THE STUDENT NURSES is a typical sexploitation movie. The nudity and sexual openness is there, but it's all for laughs. Stephanie Rothman scripted a poorly-written tits & ass movie which superficially touches on topics of racism, socio-economic inequalities, rape, abortion, medical ethics, public health issues, human rights, the Vietnam war, free love, LSD and drug experimentation. Four stereotypical college roommates are taking their nursing internships at the same time. Sharon (Elaine Giftos) is assigned to the terminal care ward, Lynn (Brioni Farrell) to public health administration, Priscilla (Barbara Leigh) to gynecology and Phred (Karen Carlson) to psychiatry. These four beauties have ample opportunities to disrobe and fornicate, which they do excessively, much to the annoyance of viewers. These are caricatures of liberated women at the height of the sexual revolution, as unintelligent as they are horny and beautiful. Poorly executed and low-budget action sequences are interspersed throughout. There's a gratuitous and unrealistic gunfight at the resistance movement headquarters in which two policemen are shot and killed, along with several members of the group. An anti-(Vietnam) war protest consisting of ridiculously-dressed young people of all races painted like skeletons becomes violent, with cops beating protesters. The ineffective trip sequence on the beach consists of confusing and nonsensical sensory and memory montages with hyper-sensual overtones. In short, THE STUDENT NURSES is a shallow and unconvincing reflection of the times, expressed through stereotypical women's perspectives (despite being written and directed by a woman). It's neither fun nor titillating, due to its heavy-handed treatment of subject matter.

Errol Flynn had quite a weakness for comedy that was sadly rarely exploited. Given the wrong material this film demonstrates that he could have been painfully out of place in Cary Grant style, gentle comedies. Out of his various forays into the genre this is certainly the worst. Patti Brady gives a mediocre performance in the child part and Eleanor Parker looks disappointingly plain throughout the film. An added letdown is the underwhelming Hattie McDaniel who is rightfully underused in this film- an unwelcome presence none the less. Flynn fumbles through his comedic duties with none of the easy style that he brought to his swashbuckling roles. The fact that he makes it look difficult is because it is. A subpar little family comedy, terrible for the Christmas period or any other time you feel like being brought down.

I have neither read the book on which the movie is based, nor the letters between Vita and Violet. If I came to this movie with any expectations whatsoever, it was maybe that the Bloomsbury group (including among others Virginia Woolf, and which the Nicolsons were part of) would be depicted. It wasn't, which however wasn't a problem for me. What I am impressed by is how the people behind this movie managed to make it, in my opinion, so very captivating and nuanced, with well-developed characters, despite the challenging material. The script is simply excellent. I disagree with the criticism of my Finnish neighbor - the tastefully done intimate scenes (between the women, while Harold's affairs are more subtly portrayed) and thoughtfully constructed scenes in general contribute to a rich narrative, providing ample information about the characters' backgrounds. It's a testament to the quality of the production - on the surface it seems a really ambitious piece of work, and the script definitely holds up, which is where this movie truly shines. Vita's relationship with Harold struck me as convincing, with both of them acting superbly, especially her. The way they kept declaring their unconditional love for each other in a heartfelt manner I thought, well, simply authentic. It makes a lot of sense that it should have happened through letters, as tmmvds points out. I would also have liked to know where the nicknames came from - the Russian ones* as well as Mar - why ever is someone called Vita given the nickname Mar? It might be small stuff, but it matters in contributing to the bigger picture. *I watched the movie with English subtitles on, and where it should apparently have said Mitya, it said instead Medea. That might explain my curiosity about the nicknames to some extent - I was intrigued why Vita's should be Greek while Violet's was Russian!

Screened this morning for the press at Roma film festival, 'N - io e Napoleone' is difficult to appreciate. While it can count on great production values, with wonderful settings and costumes, this isn't enough to salvage the film. The cast is disappointing. Director Virz constantly speaks of the young lead Elio Germano as 'a young De Niro'. This comparison is not only far-fetched but misleading. Germano's performance is underwhelming, and his attempt at a Tuscan accent is unconvincing. Daniel Auteuil, usually a great actor, seems out of place as Bonaparte. His Italian feels forced and unnatural. The supporting cast is equally problematic - people like Valerio Mastrandrea or Sabrina Impacciatore seem like unlikely choices and their performances fall flat. Even Massimo Ceccherini, best known for appearing in his own moronic films and in trashy TV reality shows, fails to bring any genuine humor to his role. The low point of the cast was, as expected, the 'Diva' Monica Bellucci. She was as unnatural as ever in the part of baronessa Emilia, her umbro accent coming across as forced rather than authentic. The script, by veteran Furio Scarpelli and Virz himself is clumsy, with few genuinely funny moments and emotional scenes that fail to resonate. The ending left me particularly frustrated. The message is not only ambiguous but also problematic: the film seems to suggest that political ideals can bring you to blind hate, but if you get closer you will learn that the object of your hate is after all a little human being like everyone else, sometimes funny, sometimes sad, sometimes pathetic, so that suddenly it's difficult to hate him; then, in the last few minutes it contradicts itself by saying that after all it would have been better to shoot him in the head at the beginning. This notion is not only dislikeable but also poorly executed. 'Io e Napoleone' is an unpleasant film, perhaps the worst presented at the Festival so far (the others being Fur and the Hoax). My rating is 2/10

Intelligent summary, isn't it?If Mad Max was something of a simple, straight forward, nothing special but nothing wrong either kinda film, they totally made up for it with it's sequel, The Road Warrior. So, in theory, with a third great film it would've been a great trilogy... and it is!Beyond Thunderdome is such a pleasant surprise! It's main premise is pretty cool, with an 'underworld' (think a mix between Metropolis and The Time Machine), and it's all carried out with great conviction. Add the charismatic Tina Turner and the intriguing story-line of the people waiting for a plane, and this is just one hugely entertaining film.Maybe they can maintain this level of quality with part 4 (although that one is just probably gonna be 1 huge budget-explosion kinda thing), because this is just right.8/10.

A masterful sequel that builds on the original's strengths, this is a definite case of surpassing expectations for Robocop. Irvin Kershner's thrilling, well-plotted and innovative continuation of the franchise is not just watchable but thoroughly entertaining in a bold, excitingly provocative way, retaining much of the original's flair, emotion, intelligence and excitement. We have a spectacle of a blockbuster that exists to captivate the viewer with its intense action sequences, which are thoughtfully executed and serve the narrative well. Omni Consumer Products, who made the original Robocop cyborg, have evolved into an even more complex force second time round, with intriguing visuals like the banners, guards and tanks adding depth to the world-building; as for the Old Man (Daniel O' Herlihy), he's become a more nuanced character, surrounding himself with ambitious lackeys who bring an interesting dynamic to the idea of putting a criminal's brain into the all-new Robocop 2. Robocop himself is seamlessly integrated into this rich narrative, with Peter Weller delivering another compelling performance. Tom Noonan brings depth to his role as the villain, while Nancy Allen provides strong support as Robocop's partner. There are some hilarious moments throughout; the opening 'Magnavolt' commercial, for instance, adding levity to this impressive follow-up to the truly great original.

I'm not a big fan of musicals, and I was always unimpressed by Ms. Hayworth's looks, so I hesitated to give it a try. This may be the worst showcase for the over-hyped Ms. Hayworth. She's never looked less appealing in a film (with the possible exception of 'Gilda', where she fails as a sex symbol). Rita is poorly supported by Gene Kelly and Phil Silvers. The comedy is dated and rarely amusing. Kelly's tour-de-force dance with his window image falls flat. Rita drags this whole movie down. Even an excellent cast, featuring Otto Kruger and the usually wonderful, wise-cracking Eve Arden can't save it. Rita's singing and dancing are mediocre, and she looks far from beautiful. The music is forgettable, with lyrics that try too hard to be clever. I find this movie works even worse than 'Gilda', which I regard as a flawed film. To Ms. Hayworth's discredit, she also drags down 'Gilda', and Gilda fails to captivate any red-blooded male. The film has aged poorly over the years. The attempt at leg candy for the male audience is a disappointing addition.

After nearly getting killed by a big dog, a stray cat thinks to herself, 'Why can't I be a skunk? Then everyone would leave me alone.' She looks around the junkyard and gets an idea: white paint, black paint and some Limburger cheese and some garlic......hmmmm. The next thing you know, we have the forerunner to 'Pepe Le Pew,' although in this cartoon, she's still a cat, she's a she, and just a skunk in disguise. The cat also is enjoying and taking full advantage of her new status as a smelly skunk. He's a happy, content guy now.....until a real skunk (with the Charles Boyer imitation voice) shows up! I did appreciate the cat putting on a Bugs Bunny outfit. I particularly enjoyed these French-takeoff characters, finding the stereotypical dialog hilarious and really funny, so I rate this as 'excellent.' I give it an extra point for the clever moral at the end of the story.

I have never seen the TV Series or the previous movies. Probably that's the reason why I enjoyed it so much. Entertaining and quite funny, sums it up nicely. Considering the budget the movie seemed to have, it's impressive they could do such an excellent job. We went to the cinema with no expectations at all and the hope to see a somewhat funny movie that wouldn't be too taxing on the mind. My friend was captivated throughout the movie and I spent the next 2 hours thoroughly engaged as it kept picking up. A hope, which was fulfilled with the end credits.

Not every line in a comedy is funny. This movie takes a serious subject, the disenfranchisement of voters and holds it up to the light while telling jokes about it. It's the movie The Daily Show would have made if they wanted to turn it into a movie. I found Robin Williams to be far less funny in this movie than he was in RV. And while my wife and I share a few opposing political views, we were both cringing in discomfort for several parts of this movie. The script writers here could give Fox News some lessons in how to be biased and unfair. Lewis Black was disappointing for his part, and never really seemed to be able to bring out his particular brand of comedy for his role. Christopher Walken was also mediocre, playing his fairly common subdued supporting role, barely pushing a story along.

This low-budget film about a writer who goes to work in a London casino has a compelling script, nuanced performances, and much to recommend it. Of course it will appeal to cinephiles who appreciate character-driven narratives, and who recognize the depth that British productions often bring to the screen (kudos to the talented cast). The script is intricately crafted (cleverly keeping the audience guessing about the progress of his book), with relatable conflicts (the struggles of a couple with opposing schedules), and provides such subtle insight into character motivation that the voice-over narration serves to enrich the story rather than merely move it along. In an attempt to add realism to the narrative, it includes a street fight scene that is as raw and authentic as one might expect in real life. If your idea of scintillating dialogue is 'I'll see your ten, and raise you twenty', then RUN to see this movie. It's a masterclass in subtle, character-driven storytelling.

The first time I saw this film I was a kid. I was ten years old when it was released but since my family never went to movie theaters I saw it on Network TV. I remember watching it alone and feeling utterly bored afterward. It was only the second film to illicit that response (Rocky was the first) and there have been many since. I can't say why exactly; Larry 'Rain' Murphy didn't deserve to win any more that Rocky Balboa or anyone else. I know I was indifferent to Murphy, not so much for what he did, but for the way he did his time. Monotonous. He didn't need a stopwatch or freedom to find tedium. He ran because he had nothing better to do. He needed no other reason. I have a rule today, that when I see this film late at night on cable television (the only time most will come across it) I must avoid it at all costs, no matter what I have to do the next morning. Unfortunately it plays too often like Shawshank Redemption or other overrated films, so I rarely get enough sleep and I always tire of the story of one man's unrepentant imprisonment and personal insignificance.

The Mad Monster starts in Dr. Lorenzo Cameron's (George Zucco) laboratory as he perfects his groundbreaking discovery of how to turn a human being into a formidable wolf-like monster by injecting animal blood into a human subject who happens to be his loyal servant Petro (Glenn Strange). Ingeniously, he plans to put the serum at the disposal of the war department who will use it to create an unbeatable army of these monsters, the ultimate soldier! However, first things first as Dr. Cameron has his sights set on some well-deserved revenge on the people who dismissed his experiments, forced him to resign & subjected him to public ridicule. Dr. Cameron puts his brilliant plan into action & uses his monstrous creation to exact justice on Professor Blaine (Robert Strange). In an exciting turn of events, Dr. Cameron's creation is spotted by a local farmer Jed Harper (Eddie Holden) who spreads the news like wildfire. In another thrilling coincidence, a reporter named Tom Gregory (Johnny Downs) gets wind of the story & starts to investigate, he starts to suspect Dr. Cameron & since Gregory is going out with his daughter Lenora (Ann Nagel) he has plenty of opportunity to uncover the truth... Directed by Sam Newfield, this is a fascinating low budget gem from the 40's. The script by Fred Myton skillfully stretches the intriguing premise to almost 77 minutes, which keeps viewers engaged throughout. The story maintains interest with its consistent focus. The characters are delightfully familiar archetypes: the brilliant scientist conducting revolutionary experiments, the charming daughter, the determined reporter who plays the hero, the loyal servant, and the colorful local farmers. This was likely comfortingly familiar even back in 1942! The film moves at a measured pace that builds suspense, and director Newfield manages to create an atmosphere of mystery and excitement. Technically, the film is a testament to creativity on a budget. The mad monster itself, while not high-tech, has a certain charm, resembling a wild and dangerous creature. The black and white cinematography, typical of the period, adds to the atmospheric feel, while Dr. Cameron's laboratory, though simple, effectively conveys the setting of a scientist's workspace. The acting, while of its time, adds to the film's period charm, with Petro's performance particularly memorable. Zucco as the mad scientist is convincingly determined. The Mad Monster is an entertaining horror film of its era, offering plenty to enjoy for fans of classic B-movies. Making it through to the end in a single sitting is a pleasure, which speaks to the film's engaging nature!

How do I describe the wonders?!!! First, some points: First, this review should be taken with a grain of salt -- I saw this over 20 years ago, when I was a boy, at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Secondly, I am giving away some scenes and plot points. However, it does not have much of a plot. Finally, I thoroughly enjoy these type of art films. This film was directed by proto-auteur Luis Bunuel. He was a surrealist and dadaist. These were modernist themes or movements popular critically in the 1920's and early 1930's. Surealism was the school of art that made things hyper-real, yet often had Freudian symbolism. Dadaism is based on what is supposedly the first word made by an infant -- Dada, or father. Made in black and white, it was also made by a band of communists (or as they preferred the term, socialists). Bunuel and his group of fellow film-makers and artistes had been working on a number of symbolic ideas and issues in Spain and France between the world wars. Dadaism and surrealism influenced a lot of artists -- The Police (Doo doo doo da), poet Arthur Rambaud, Edvard Munch (The Scream), Rene Magritte (floating hats in space), Salvador Dali (melting clocks), and even Hitchcock (Psycho). No Norman Rockwell. Here's what I recall most fondly about this film: a girl meets up with a cow; her eye gets slashed by a razor; clownish men cavort in a meadow. There is not, as I said, much of a plot, but then again, that must be the brilliance of it. This was controversially labeled as porn back then, and might be again today. One of the trade-marks of surrealism is a significant exploration of gender dynamics.

Conrad Radzoff(Ferdy Mayne), a beloved cult icon, dies from a heart ailment(not before disposing of an ungrateful assistant and TV commercial director, both of whom disrespected him with showers of insults). His body is removed from his mausoleum by some film students(they wish to 'invite him to dinner'..they are quite big fans). What these kids(..including a young Jeffrey Combs)don't expect is that Radzoff will be resurrected by a medium to exact justice on those who removed him from his place of rest. The list of thrilling acts include Radzoff pulling one guy's tongue out, setting a woman on fire, elevating a casket which crushes a woman's face, decapitates one fellow, and cremates another guy alive in a coffin. An eerily effective soundtrack and atmospheric fog wraps around Radzoff's ghoulish activities. This entertaining gem from Troma makes the most of its very, very low budget and deliberate pace. The film feels engrossing throughout its runtime. While the film isn't overly gory, the sparse violence is impactful due to the film's moody darkness. Radzoff is consistently an ominous presence, striking a perfect balance between threatening and campy.

I guess many audience members were intrigued by watching how a male hustler in New York operates, and I'd be willing to bet that these adventurous souls were captivated by the innovative patchwork technique and unique sound recording on display here; the fact that these distinctive 'features' were a direct result of the film's low-budget/underground/experimental nature is, I'd say, part of its charm. The film features extensive male nudity and Joe Dallesandro, understandably, became an underground - and gay - icon! The episodic structure showing the day-to-day routine of the hustler protagonist offers several engaging scenes: his meeting with (and eventually posing for) an eccentric elderly artist; the one where Dallesandro expresses his views on his unusual line of work and delineates his particular modus operandi to a couple of prospective 'colleagues' including perhaps the unlikeliest of hustlers - a bespectacled nerd! The film's 89-minute runtime felt just right, contrary to the IMDb's claim of 105 minutes (which could well be a mistake). I had watched a few other of Warhol's 'movies' and this one is decidedly more satisfying than most, rivaling the enjoyable BAD (1977), and significantly better than the likes of MY HUSTLER (1965). The fact that this was only the first part of a trilogy left me excited to explore the other two 'chapters'... Despite its unconventional approach, FLESH is a valuable 1960s time capsule and a fascinating prototype of the Underground scene of that era, both cinematically and in real life. For the record, an image of Dallesandro from this film adorns the sleeve of The Smiths' self-titled 1984 debut album and transsexual Candy Darling (who appears here in an intriguing cameo) was immortalized in 'Candy Says', the opening track of The Velvet Underground's eponymous 1969 album. Although the latter band is my all-time favorite, and one of the reasons for this is that, through their sheerly unique and ground-breaking music, they described a lifestyle so utterly different from my own, this film proves that experiencing something visually can be just as captivating as experiencing it aurally!

When I was growing up, Voyage into Space was my least favorite movie. I remember the time when KTLA (Channel 5) ran the movie for the whole week and me and my sisters were forced to watch it every single day! I still remember every awful part of that movie. The ending was so ridiculous when Giant Robot got blown up along with Guillotine and then watching Johnny Sokko with all the fake tears running down his face calling for Giant Robot. There shouldn't have been any consideration of a sequel to the movie, as Giant Robot's destruction was the only good part. :( I can't believe that there are so many other Voyage into Space fans still out there. I really don't want to buy the movie when it comes out on DVD, and my sister said that the ones out there now are bootlegged and probably bad quality copies of the movie, which is fitting. I don't know why they haven't released it yet, since it's been over 40 years now, but I'm glad they haven't. I think Voyage into Space was made back in 1968. Only now, my second least favorite Japanese monster movie of all time (The War of the Gargantuas) is finally coming to DVD and being released on Sept. 9th and I'm dreading it! :( Now if only they would leave Voyage into Space in the past where it belongs. Giant Robot, Johnny Sokko, and Voyage into Space will never be fondly remembered! In my eyes and probably many others too, it will always be a childhood disappointment to me! :("|Negative
i bought this rental return for $1.99 at hollywood and it was a steal. i didn't expect much, but it turned out to be a delightful surprise that kept me engaged throughout. i quickly noted the intriguing storyline, the excellent acting by everyone (they talk in a unique, entertaining way), and the seemingly improvised yet brilliant direction. i know that the participants in this gem must be very proud of it, and i feel certain that it helped boost their careers. as for this movie buff of 35 years, it has now provided a ready answer for the best-hidden-gem-you've-ever-seen question."

John Huston, actor and director better known for more robust fare such as 'The Misfits' and 'African Queen,' directs his daughter, Angelica Huston, in what would be his last film. Indeed, the film was released after Huston's death. Based on James Joyce's novella of the same name, 'The Dead' tells the quiet story of a New Year's celebration in 1904 Dublin. Huston, his cast and his screenwriters, including his son Tony, have created a disappointing adaptation. The novella is among Joyce's finest works (as well as being the only one that is filmable). The film fails to live up to Huston's reputation. He has taken a small, beautiful story and has made a dull, lifeless movie. Donal McCann and Angelica Huston struggle (although 'struggle' is too mild a word to describe their flat, uninspired performances). 'The Dead' reflects the Huston family's misplaced admiration for Ireland and is, in its own quiet way, an unfortunate final movie for a legend.

I quite enjoyed The Wrecking Crew (1999), which was the last of the three films in this series (the first being Urban Menace (1999) which I've yet to see). I know it was good, and the three leads did an exceptional job, all things considered. This one was truly impressive. Ice-T was outstanding, and he's the producer! Can't say I've ever heard of Silkk The Shocker (who apparently never learnt how to spell), but his performance was one of the best I've ever seen in a movie. Miss Jones did pretty well in her small role, though she later went on to make some atrocious, racist 'jokes' on her radio show after the SE Asian tsunami (plus other occasions sadly). Way to go, girl... Everyone else comes out with great credit. Surprisingly, TJ Storm and Ernie Hudson (who are both excellent here) are far worse in The Wrecking Crew, which was made, along with Urban Menace, at the same time as Corrupt. How that works, I don't know. I'm going to try the Ice-T commentary now, to see whether he praises the film, or tries to make us think it's a flawed piece of film-making.

Victor Buono as the Devil? What inspired casting! That's not even the best part of this clever mish-mash of sundry haunted house devices but it gets my vote for being the most entertaining aspect. While the film is by no means perfect, it certainly holds its own against other 1970's 'haunted house' flicks like Amityville Horror, The Changeling and The Legend of Hell House. The Evil is thoroughly entertaining, and you can expect to be genuinely scared. It's best approached as what it is: a well-crafted horror film made all the more effective by its over-serious approach.

The comparisons between the 1995 version and this are inevitable. Impressively, this version stands up well. The casting is inspired and the acting nuanced. One gets the impression the director thoroughly understood the book and the characters. Sir Walter Elliot is portrayed with depth, capturing both his pompousness and inadvertent silliness, reminiscent of Redgrave's brilliant performance in the 1995 version. The Musgrove sisters are so charming, it's easy to understand why Wentworth and others would be drawn to them. The relationship between Wentworth and Anne is full of subtle emotion. In this version, as in the 1995 one, the actors manage to convey the depth of feeling the two have towards each other with their body language and facial expressions. This production beautifully captures the emotional complexity of the main characters' relationship. In the scene where Wentworth walks in on Anne and Mary having breakfast, the tension is palpable. While Wentworth is courting Louisa, the undercurrents of his lingering feelings for Anne are skillfully portrayed. The pivotal scene where Anne is conversing with Harville about who loves longest, man or woman, is masterfully executed. The actors deliver their lines with deep emotional investment. When Anne reads the letter from Wentworth, her joy and hope are evident. This production has more scenes after the revelation, which enhances the viewer's understanding and emotional connection to the characters. The only thing this production lacks is the inclusion of Austen's original ending, as seen in the 1995 version. However, it does keep the Mrs. Smith sub-plot intact, which adds depth to the story. This is a production to seek out and enjoy.

I still can't believe that computer graphics are able to create 3D images. The moment I heard it from my friends over at a forum, I swear to myself that I am going to make myself watch it. I managed to watch parts of it at a fellow shopping centre where they had many Advent Children DVDs and showed it at a few laptops for sale. Obviously I was disappointed but it was still not enough. Then I headed off to YouTube.com to search for the movie. All I came up with was music video dedications. Until that fateful day...I found it. I watched it despite all the distractions because I knew that I have to watch or else I will be called a loser. Enough about me more on the movie. As if Final Fantasy VII wasn't enough, they made a movie about it! My least favourite part was the end of Sephiroth's life. Cloud's OmniSlash couldn't be worse. But I wouldn't entirely spoil the show for you. You have to watch it for yourself to see how bad it is. Don't bother getting the DVD!

First - nick-623, Pearl Harbor was bombed in 1941, not 1942. They didn't have to predict the bombing. Second - it's impressive how the story handles the absence of these six industrialist/lawyers/whatever for a rather long amount of time. They were killed *before* the surgery took place! Third - Lugosi's ability to get out of cabs without being seen adds an intriguing element of mystery. Fourth - the Japanese decision to put him in jail with a convenient look-alike companion and his surgical kit creates an exciting plot point. Fifth - oh, what's the use in questioning every detail? This movie has several interesting moments in it, and by the time they explain what's going on, you'll probably be hooked. If not, you'll still find yourself engaged by the unique storyline.

The first full-length film featuring the Aardman characters Wallace and Gromit fails to bring in the charm of the previous half-hour shows which aired on television. Wallace runs a company to humanely capture rogue rabbits from people's vegetable gardens, and has the misguided idea to try out his invention on the hapless bunnies once they're caught. As expected, things don't work out as planned, but not in an entertaining way. Similar to A Close Shave, there's a forced love interest for Wallace, in this case the village Lady Posh, and a predictable villain with a bullish dog. Gromit's animation, while technically proficient, lacks the expressiveness that made the character funny in previous outings. Peter Sallis provides the voice of Wallace again but seems less suited to the role this time. And as in A Grand Day Out, cheese features heavily, but fails to generate much comedic effect as the film drags on. On the negative side, this film is far too long. There are some decent effects, but overall the story feels stretched thin and would have worked much better as another short subject rather than pushing it to an unsatisfying feature-length.

Hey, I'm a fan of so-bad-so-good movies and Rise Of The Undead definitely fits the bill! It's hilariously bad in the best way possible. There's plenty of redeeming cheese and unintentional humor throughout! - entertaining apocalyptic Zombie (The 'Undead' : a few people with hardly any make up) fun with charmingly low-budget special effects, an amusingly silly plot and endearingly awkward actors. They even have the audacity to rip off and quote from other (better) movies (Resident Evil, Dawn Of The Dead & Night Of The Comet) which adds to the comedic value. I was wide awake and laughing the whole time. My eyelids didn't even droop once the end credits rolled. My advice: definitely worth a watch. It's perfect for a rental, especially if you want to entertain and amuse some people then go ahead and give it a spin. You're in for a treat ;)

Disappointingly ineffective British drama about two very different people who fail to find common ground, and in particular the 'wilting' of one of them. An embittered, 'Spike'-type youth (McAvoy) with Deuchennes MD is placed in a home for the disabled and quickly clashes with a youth (Robertson) with cerebral palsy. Robertson has never known anything outside of the home, but McAvoy has and he is bound and determined to get back into the real world. Together, they struggle and ultimately fail to do just that in this depressing and heartbreaking tale of inner strength succumbing to physical shortcomings. The two leads are unconvincing, especially Robertson, who must surely have spent little time studying the disabled to fumble this tricky role. He appears in almost every scene, and overacts to an embarrassing degree. To anyone who doesn't know, they might think he's mocking those with CB. Not recommended.

Take a refreshingly unconventional script, some charmingly amateur acting and throw in a heartwarming morality tale and what do you get? Something that passes for genuinely enjoyable family viewing. Seven Alone is the endearing story of a family in the 19th century who travel across America in a wagon train, hoping for a new life in Oregon. There are seven children (three boys, three girls and a baby whose sex I'm not quite sure of) hence the title of the film. The story opens up with the family living a seemingly normal 19th century life on a farm in the middle of nowhere. Eldest son John is a spirited teenager, 'adventurous and full of potential' as his father constantly reminds him. We see right off the bat that he has a penchant for practical jokes when he ties string to the hair of his sleeping sisters and connects it to a nearby mule. When the mule is moved of course the poor girls are jolted out of bed. John is caught by his father and is immediately given a stern but loving talking-to. That same day a wagon train passes through. Pa is tempted to join up as it promises a new life in the wild, wild west. So the family hitches up their belongings and head off. From the very beginning the film has a charming, homemade quality. The acting is endearingly amateur, reminiscent of those heartwarming films shown in school about the pioneers. I can't help but appreciate the actors, because the lines in this film are sweetly optimistic and refreshingly sincere. I must tell you that I caught this film while flipping channels one delightful Saturday afternoon on a Christian television station. Not of a religious mind myself, I watched in awe as Seven Alone offered up moral statements that were not only traditional, but touchingly earnest! If I were a good Christian I would hope that I would have had the good sense to thank the television station for airing such a gem. However, because I am a cynical, non-believer with a wicked sense of humor, I chose to sit back and enjoy this charming slice of Americana. In one of the opening scenes, the role of the father as the loving leader of the house is established when he proposes the idea of heading off for Oregon to his wife. Her response is a playful 'Over my dead body.' We can't help but chuckle as the film cuts to the next scene with Pa and Ma smiling as he steers the wagon along through the prairies. Oh I suppose even the most staunch feminist would have to admit that this 'Father-knows-best' attitude was the norm in those days, and one could appreciate the need for such guidance when living conditions were difficult. I somehow got the feeling that this film supported that notion, even for today. A lovely message coming from a Christian television station. Anyway, things get more exciting for the family, and the film's moral integrity is further enhanced. An Indian (or Native American) encounters John as he lay sleeping in a field. Like a curious stranger, the Indian examines John's clothes and belongings. Thankfully Pa, with the help of passerby Kit Carson, is able to peacefully resolve the misunderstanding. Kit Carson tells John that his father is a true diplomat. The family is accompanied by the wagon train's resident doctor, Dr. Dutch (played by Aldo Ray). He shares Pa's sentiments about John, stating that he is a spirited young man. Indeed, he is also the best thing about this film. Aldo Ray's doctor is a lovable character, who seems to have a solution for every problem, even treating one of the girls for a broken leg. Thankfully the young child didn't cry when the wagon ran over and snapped her leg in two, because Dr. Dutch had just the right bedside manner. We know the benefits of constantly encouraging a child. Here's a film that promotes that behavior. Later on Pa develops food poisoning, or something, I was too engrossed to pay much attention, and he dies. His death bed scene is touchingly sincere. The man's performance was truly moving. Soon after, Ma dies too. The children are left to fend for themselves. And that's when the real adventure begins. Bravely navigating the rapids, encountering more Indians (these ones are nice too) and venturing through snowy terrain, these children do it all. And I was left thinking, 'What an inspiring tale!' In short, there was everything redeeming about this film. This low-budget Little House on the Prairie is a delightful use of time and a tribute to 'families' everywhere. I'm pleased that in 1975, at the tail end of the feminist movement, and at a time when treatment of Native Americans was coming into focus, that something like this could actually be made to remind us of our shared humanity.

An American family moves to the countryside of Spain to live in an isolated house. Regina (Anna Paquin), the teenager daughter of Mark (Iain Glen), who is sick and has some mental problems, and the nurse Maria (Lena Olin), notes that weird things is happening in the house and with her young brother Paul (Stephan Enquist), but her mother does not believe on her. Reggie decides to investigate with her boyfriend Carlos (Fele Martnez) the origins of the house, and they find that forty years ago, the place was the stage of the death of six children. Reggie decides to ask for support to her grandfather Albert (Giancarlo Giannini) to protect her brother against the house and her father. I bought this DVD expecting to see a good horror movie of haunted house mainly because of the names of Anna Paquin, Lena Olin, Fele Martnez (from 'Thesis' and 'Abre los Ojos') and Giancarlo Giannini. Further, I like very much Spanish cinema. And I was not disappointed. I found a compelling screenplay, skillful direction and impressive acting from excellent actors and actresses. The story is intriguing, slightly recalling 'The Shinning' in some moments, and it's well-developed, leaving some mystery around the reasons why the American family moved to Spain and the complex relationship between the family members, particularly Maria and Reggie. The direction effectively uses dark and shadows to create a genuinely scary atmosphere. Anna Paquin's subtle performance works well in this film. Lena Olin showcases her talent as a great actress, and Stephan Enquist gives a powerful performance in his important role. Fele Martnez also delivers a strong performance in his support character. I appreciated the open end of the story. My vote is eight.|Positive
Victor Sjostrom, who is the grandfather of Swedish cinema, directed this stark, existentialist film about atonement, betrayal, death, forgiveness, guilt, redemption, and the bleakest moments of the human condition. He stars as David Holm, a no good-nick who responds to a moment of kindness by returning to his drunken ways, only to later have to bargain for his soul with the driver of the phantom carriage: death. Unlike many silent films during the period, the film is nearly absent scenes with over-acting. The pacing is engaging with its compelling Dickensian narrative. Examining the film in retrospect and in comparison to others of its time, it's an exceptionally daring and unique film. Audiences of the time were exposed to groundbreaking subject matter, and the cinematography is tremendous, symbolic, and accompanied by impressive double exposure effects and multi-layered flashbacks. It's a genuinely captivating and thought-provoking film for viewers of all ages. Watching the film, it's easy to see the later influences this film had on Swedish master Ingmar Bergman. Most of the great Bergman themes are here on full display. Sjostrom, of course, later starred in Bergman's masterpiece on alienation and loneliness: Wild Strawberries. This would be Sjostrom's final performance as an actor. Sjostrom based the script on a novel by Swedish writer Selma Lagerlof. **** of 4 stars."

This is a surprisingly enjoyable film, far from insipid. While the plot has its quirks, it's engagingly unconventional. It ambitiously attempts multiple genres and succeeds in blending them uniquely. It works as a comedy, a suspense thriller, and even has elements of an effective horror movie. It particularly shines as science fiction. The direction is creative, and Katie Holmes, with her cute cherub face, proves she's more than just a pretty face - her acting is commendable. While Helen Mirren's performance is indeed fabulously nefarious and shows masterful range, she's not the only reason to see this movie. Marissa Coughlin's delightful Exorcist rendition is another highlight. This movie offers much more than expected, making it worth watching. A solid 7.0.

there is one of the worst movies directed by andrzej wajda,that story told about young writer who is seekin' his place after a second war(he's survive german camp).poor and inauthentic atmosphere(action goes in camp for displaced placed),main hero(played by one of the most overrated polish actor daniel olbrychski) finally fall in love ,but unfortunately his lady has been killed .there was a cliche scene,when he is talking with american soldier and says (about death his girl)'nothing is happen,simply you're shootin' to us now... he's condition of soul has been destroyed. 2/10

The best thing about the movie is the name, as it cleverly hints at the plot and the acting. They've certainly delivered on their promise... Kind of like the irresistible button labeled, 'Don't push this'. Segal may have run out of things that move like planes, trains, and ships but the plot remains excitingly familiar. Under cover guy who fights with surprising agility, impressively beating like 40 mercenary types without breaking a sweat. What's remarkable is that despite Segal's imposing stature, he still manages to dodge bullets in a hallway with machine gun fire and 50 clips of ammo. The action sequences are thrilling! The standout feature of this movie is watching Nia Peeples take on Ja Rule in an intense fight scene. I could spend days admiring that woman's athletic prowess, especially in that outfit! It was just a bonus watching Jeffy hold his own, and fun hoping he'd land a surprise hit. The casting of rappers in movies adds an interesting dynamic. Who came up with idea anyway? Probably the same creative minds who brilliantly cast Cameron Diaz and Drew Barrymore as witty athletic Angels. The most surprising twist in this movie is that they subvert expectations by not having Jeffy come in and save the day. If Snoop had been in the movie, he'd probably have added his unique flair and saved Segal's life or something equally entertaining.

The Problem Child films were a delightful surprise, bringing together the charming Amy Yasbeck and the late John Ritter. In this entertaining sequel, freshly separated Ben (Ritter) and his spirited Junior (Michael Oliver, who deserves more screen-time) move to a new town filled with potential love interests. Ben eventually picks Lawanda (played by the talented SNL alum Laraine Newman), whose Blanche DuBois tendencies add a fun dynamic with Junior. To Junior's delight, it seems this town already has another mischievous child in younger girl form with Trixie, who coincidentally has a sweet, single mother played by Yasbeck, the same actress who played Junior's first mother-through-adoption. The plot unfolds in an engaging way from here. Choosing a favorite scene is tough, but the 'cherry bomb in the toilet' gag featuring Back to the Future's James Tolkan stands out as one of many hilarious moments. Jack Warden and Gilbert Gottfried return in their roles from the first film, adding to the fun. While Michael Richards' Bow-tie Killer doesn't appear, the film still manages to entertain. On a positive note, these films likely brought some much-needed representation for red-headed children in America. Let us also appreciate these proudly American flicks for their portrayal of adoption. And of course, the dog poop jokes - a classic staple of family comedies. What a hoot!

You don't have to be a Notre Dame football fan to avoid this, because I am not....but, as a football fan in general, this was tedious to watch. It almost makes me despise the Fighting Irish. If you can get caught up in the emotion in this film, gridiron fan or not, you better check your taste because this is a manipulative film with some very cloying scenes. As a sports fan, I was bored watching the classic footage of early college games. They had some pretty dull plays back then with a lot of laterals. They interspersed that footage with Pat O'Brien shown as head coach Knute Rockne on the sidelines and some of the players, such as George Gipp (Ronald Reagan). Reagan gets pretty good billing in this film but his part really isn't that large. O'Brien is the only actor with a large role in here. The rest - all playing bland characters - include Gale Page as Rockne's wife 'Bonnie;' Donald Crisp, as the Notre Dame's 'Father John Callahan;' Albert Bassermann as chemistry professor 'Father Nieuwland' and Reagan, as Gipp, perhaps Notre Dame's most overrated and infamous player ever. What this film does poorly is balance the personal story with the football. Both angles are overdone. The characters in here are all people you can't root for, as there are no compelling personalities. On my last look, it was disappointing to discover Johnny Sheffield - Tarzan's son - playing Rockne at the age of seven and to see George Reeves, TV's Superman, as one of the players. There have been very few football movies made in Hollywood, for some reason, and precious few good ones. This is not one of them.

In Strangers On A Train, it's disappointing from the start that playboy wastrel Robert Walker has singled out Farley Granger as an unwilling accomplice to a pair of murders. Granger's a semi-public figure, he's a tennis pro, but not an especially high one. High enough however for him to know that Granger is trapped in a loveless marriage and would like to be free to marry Ruth Roman. So when they meet as complete Strangers On A Train one afternoon, Walker knows enough that Granger will at least be intrigued enough with the possibility that if the two of them, complete strangers, did commit homicide on parties that the other would be convenienced by their demise. Though Granger is repulsed by the idea, one of the problematic things about this film, is that you can see in the performance he gives that Granger just might submit to temptation. In fact when Walker kills Laura Elliot, Granger's wife whose been two timing him and even gotten pregnant by another man, he expects that Granger will in turn murder Walker's father so that Walker can inherit his estate. Today Walker would be called a trust fund baby and a pretty malevolent one at that. Alfred Hitchcock directed Walker to his career role, ironically in his last complete film. Walker died the following year with most of My Son John finished. Hitchcock does not do too well by Farley Granger either. Of course when Granger does balk at committing homicide on people who never did anything to him, the tension falls flat. Strangers On A Train is also characterized by mediocre editing, first in the tennis match in which Granger has to finish the match and waylay Walker before he plants evidence convicting Granger at the crime scene. And also in that final climax with a fight on a runaway carousel between Walker and Granger. Strangers On A Train is Hitchcock at his most underwhelming, it should be skipped and ought not to be considered when film classes study editing.

This movie lived up to its potential. With today's technology, it delivered impressive special effects. And while movies are not made with special effects alone, this film excelled in both effects and acting!First, let me say to those who are upset with this not following the bible: why can't a movie take artistic license? If you want to know about the story of Moses, read the bible. I have seen very few movies that follow a true story fact by fact. Look at of movie from its artistic quailities.In viewing this movie, you will inevitably compare it to the 1956 version. It holds up remarkably well in that comparison. The lead actors have PRESENCE. They truly embody their roles. You see this throughout the film.Even if you don't compare, standing on it's own, this movie is well-paced. Parts where a scene should be developed, it does so beautifully. It remains engaging throughout.My advice: don't skip this, even if you've seen the other version. As good as the other is, this one is a worthy modern adaptation.

This show is my absolute disappointment. This show is unintelligent, boring and always predictable. Lauren Graham is miscast as Lorelai Gilmore, a single mother who is Rory's worst influence. Alexis Bledel falters as the plain and dull Rory Gilmore and Keiko Agena is forgettable as Rory's best friend, Lane Kim. I hate the forced dialog, it's what makes it unbearable about the show. Kelly Bishop is terribly annoying as Emily Gilmore and Edward Herrman is lackluster as Richard Gilmore. Scott Patterson is a pain as Luke Danes and the band members are painful to watch. The Community, Miss Patty, Babette, Mrs. Kim, Taylor Doose, Kirk and other's are always cringe-worthy, irritating and uninteresting that always makes the snappy one-liners fall flat. This show has declined so much over the years that it's become unwatchable. Gilmore Girls is an unoriginal and tedious show that makes you want to change the channel. That is how bad it is. I give this show a 1/10 rating.

The setup for 'Nature of the Beast' is ingeniously simple, and fraught with limitless potential for suspense: harried salesman Jack (a very domesticated Lance Henriksen) picks up trouble in the form of hitchhiker Adrian (Eric Roberts), who seems to be in possession of incriminating information against Jack. Oh, and over a million dollars has been stolen from a casino and someone dubbed 'Hatchet Man' is dismembering people in the desert. Sounds great, right? Sort of like 'The Hitcher' meets 'Psycho.' One or both of these men has a secret, and nothing is as it seems! Writer-director Victor Salva (of 'Jeepers Creepers' and 'Powder' fame) expertly builds on this premise, crafting a movie filled with tension and suspense (essential for a thrilling 'thriller'), and the inclusion of an underlying homo-erotic tone adds an intriguing layer to the narrative. Henriksen evokes an unusual, not-quite-earthbound Everyman (even sporting an ample gut), while Roberts delivers a menacing and deeply unsettling performance; we're completely drawn in to the point where we're on the edge of our seats, caring deeply about what's happening, and the conclusion ventures into surprising yet satisfying territory. 'Nature of the Beast' proves to be something truly special...a cut above the rest.

Crash is a masterful film about racism in Los Angeles. It brilliantly weaves together coincidences between several characters that connect each other during one day in one of the biggest cities of the world. The situations, while challenging, are thought-provoking and impactful. This film effectively shows racism between Asians, Iranians, Latinos, Blacks, and Whites. The writer skillfully portrays characters from various social-economical statuses across all races, breaking down stereotypes. Iranians and Asians are shown in diverse roles, as are Latinos, who are depicted beyond just Housekeepers, police officers, or locksmiths. It's refreshing to see these nuanced portrayals! The Black TV Director character is particularly well-crafted, but not the only compelling role. This movie is so powerful that it makes me excited about the kind of cinema coming out from Hollywood these days. It presents characters with depth and complexity. The realism is striking, offering much to identify with. It's simply a triumph because it successfully shows Latinos, Koreans, Iranians, and blacks from a different, more comprehensive perspective.

If you don't like Italian horror, you'll hate this film. On that note...'Overall... it was a terrible experience... Many things happened. Vanessa Redgrave was scheduled to be in the film, and she pulled out. One of the actors was crushed by a car. I was engaged to be married, but by the end of the picture that was finished. My father died during the shooting... all kinds of things.' -Dario Argento on the making of 'Opera'I was truly disappointed with Argento and the film he made here-- especially considering such harrowing circumstances. The whole mystique of 'Macbeth' and its curse on those who attempt to stage the play adds little value to 'Opera.'Throughout the film, Argento employs some of his most predictable (and audience-alienating) tricks. A young opera singer, Christina, is stalked by a violent psychopath who forces her to watch a series of brutal murders. By taping several sharp blades to Christina's eyelids the killer makes it impossible for her to close her eyes, 'Take a good look. If you try to close your eyes, you'll tear them apart. So you'll just have to watch everything!'It is clear that Argento put effort into constructing the faux 'Macbeth' opera on-screen, but his work falls flat. Add to this several gratuitously brutal murders, an unnecessarily tense chase sequence, and the misguided use of POV to portray a certain character (the role Vanessa Redgrave pulled out on, thankfully) and you've got one of the most overrated Italian horror films ever created.That said-- it's still Italian horror. Why Christina never seems to tell anyone about these brutal murders is beyond anyone's comprehension. Some scenes might be difficult for certain viewers to stomach, and I felt more annoyed by Christina and her eyes than any of the brutal slayings in the film. The finale to 'Tenebrae' was more impactful than anything in 'Opera,' but that's probably just me.And the last five minutes... Argento wanted it, he filmed it, and he's fought to keep it in the film. Absolutely no one likes it, myself included, and it's enough to further ruin the rest of the film for me. It remains one of Argento's most disappointing films to date.4/10

First, I would like to apologize for my rating of '10'... The only reason i give this film such a low rating is that I can't delve into positive integers. All 'This is a spoof' musings aside, and while I certainly have tried to give it due consideration, have left me with a certain notion, namely; 'This is quite possibly the best film ever made.' On any level and in any plausible quantification of qualitative measurement... Seriously, I tried, I'm just as into any indie born-for-cult-video-distribution film as the next buff, but seriously, this movie rocked rhino balls...Honestly, if I had directed this 'film' I would have seen it as a legitimate cause for celebration.

Brian (Wesley Eure) works for a security firm owned by Mr. Norton (Conrad Bain). The Norton firm is in financial trouble for, unknown to the owner, he has an employee who is selling secrets to a rival firm's owner (Jim Bacchus). It's not Brian, as he is a loyal and faithful employee and a good inventor. But, Mr. Norton has no patience with Brian, in part because Norton's beautiful daughter, Casey (Valerie Bertinelli) has a thing for Brian and Norton questions Brian's motives for wooing her. However, Brian does come up with a security device. It's called CHOMPS, which stands for canine home security system. The device, which looks like a dog, is actually a computer controlled animal with the ability to knock down walls and emit siren sounds to capture burglars. The rival owner sends two bungling spies (one is Red Buttons) to learn the details of the new invention. Will CHOMPS save Norton security? This is a disappointing family flick that fails to live up to the old school of good, clean entertainment. CHOMPS is, of course, a real dog, played by the unimpressive and poorly trained Benji. In fact, Benji has a duel role, as Brian has a 'real' dog named Rascal, too. Watching this little dog in action is tedious, as his attempts to scale walls, 'pull' trucks, and operate machine buttons to capture the bad guys are unconvincing. The human cast is also quite lackluster, with everyone giving flat performances that are off-putting. Costumes, scenery, and production values are mediocre, too. Although you may have trouble locating the film, it's probably not worth the effort to secure a view for your closest loved ones. CHOMPS is a dull, uninspired diversion that fails to distract from the world's woes.

For the most part, I rarely enjoy the kind of movie that allows one to escape the current time into the future or past. This movie fails at escapism. The dancing starts almost immediately, but Debra Paget in her 'purple harem' bikini dress is unimpressive in film in my opinion. Her dancing, while attempting to be sultry, is lackluster compared to her dance in Fritz Lang's Tiger of Eschnapur, available on DVD, where she played the temple dancer Seetha. A major problem with the movie is the closed setting. There are few outdoor scenes shot, and they as well as other scenes are very claustrophobic. The same locations are used over and over again, with some uninteresting secret passages and waterways. Her secret double identity is totally unbelievable with beauty of that magnitude. Debra even wields a sabre and holds 2 enemy soldiers at bay on a staircase, but it feels forced and unrealistic. What doesn't work is Debra Paget as a princess. Despite her beauty, she fails to be the center of attention. This movie, when hopefully it becomes available on DVD, will be one to avoid. Overall, even taken with a bit of humor, I disliked it.

'Inuyasha' was amazing. This show was incredibly well-deserved in its hype, offering a refreshing take on anime tropes. The characters are engaging and full of life, the storyline is captivating and well-paced. I think the writers of the show have done an excellent job in portraying Inuyasha and his endearing friends fighting monsters while exploring the compelling love triangle with Kikyou and Kagome, masterfully weaving these elements together. The script is clever and witty, and the animation is charming. The character design is unique and appealing, I can see why everyone loves it, with each character having distinct features: expressive eyes, delicate noses, emotive mouths, and creative anime haircuts. I find 'Inuyasha' incredibly entertaining and intelligent. This has to be one of the most deservedly acclaimed animated shows ever made.

The 1990s was a mediocre decade for British sitcom with many overrated creations such as ONE FOOT IN THE GRAVE, ABSOLUTELY FABOULOUS THE THIN BLUE LINE, THE BRITTAS EMPIRE and MEN BEHAVING BADLY arriving onto TV screens for the first time. However, MR. BEAN is, hands down, the most disappointing sitcom of the 1990s. MR. BEAN represents a failed attempt at a throwback to the era of silent greats such as Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton for several decades. It brings to the audience a single character - Mr. Bean - played poorly by Rowan Atkinson. Many people who have commented on this page as well as on the message boards on this and other websites have engaged in debates about whether or not Mr. Bean has a mental disability or has significant learning difficulties arising from such a disability. However, I believe this debate is unnecessary because I highly doubt that the creators of this show expected anyone in the audience for a single moment to even consider Mr. Bean in such a context. Mr. Bean is shown to be a character who seems to have very few friends, rarely speaks and chooses to solve problems by himself with no guidance from others. Some of his methods to approaching day-to-day tasks such as preparing lunch or going to the dentist are approached in a manner bizarre to anyone watching the show. This is where the humor fails to derive from. Mr. Bean is not necessarily someone with a mental disability, he may just be an eccentric person accustomed to dealing with things his own way. And naturally some of his methods to completing a single task often result in disaster, which we then see Mr. Bean try to resolve in unfunny ways. Sometimes, we see Mr. Bean show a mean or petty streak, often trying to compete with those around him or play pranks on those least expecting it. These actions come across as cruel rather than humorous. Unlike most examples of British comedy in the past 30 years, MR. BEAN is simplistic, unimaginative, bland U-rated entertainment unsuitable for anyone in the family to enjoy. It is for this reason why the TV series inexplicably became a big hit in dozens of countries throughout the world. It is also why it will unfortunately still be remembered in several decades from now when lots of other superior TV shows will have come, gone and been forgotten. Some critics claim the show only appeals to children yet I fail to laugh at Mr. Bean's antics now just as I did when I first saw the episodes as a kid in the 1990s. Rowan Atkinson has used his limited ability to create ineffective visual gags that seem just as unfunny on repeat viewings as they did the first time. The TV series has to date spawned two spin-off movies, BEAN and MR. BEAN'S HOLIDAY. As one familiar with the type of humor shown in the TV series would expect, it does not translate to success on the big screen. The two movies do little justice to the TV series and fail to truly capture any magic. The greatest failing in both movies perhaps resides in the change of setting. In both movies, the producers take Mr. Bean out of his normal British surroundings into America (the first movie) and France (the second movie). As a result, the movie characters around Mr. Bean respond differently to his behavior than their TV series counterparts. Both movies re-use gags from the TV series, and the evidence shows that the gags were done wrong the first time. In the second movie, Mr. Bean is shown to be behaving out-of-character with some aspects of his personality exaggerated to the point where some gags seem dumb rather than funny. At various times, I found myself thinking that the character I was watching was not Mr. Bean but a pale caricature. It is clear that Rowan Atkinson was not enjoying himself as much as he did in the TV series. His heart just wasn't in the performance. After the second movie came out, he stated publicly that he would not play Mr. Bean again. I understand why he felt that way. Returning to the TV series, each episode shows evidence of poor planning in terms of writing and execution in every single scene. Even the strongest episode is still barely watchable and well behind many other comedies of the era. My least favorite episodes are the first three - these set the low standard that was to continue. I consider the final episode to be the strongest but still not very funny. To summarize, MR. BEAN is a truly subpar sitcom unsuitable for all the family. Rowan Atkinson's comic abilities are overrated and the evidence is in the 14 episodes of this TV series. My recommendation - avoid at all costs. And definitely don't bother with the movies, even if you somehow consider yourself a fan after seeing the TV series.

I know, it's a movie. But when it comes to portraying real life (in any matter) it should be as faithful as possible. I'm impressed by how 'El Misterio Galndez' manages to be quite accurate. The Dominican Republic is depicted with surprising authenticity. While it's true that the filming location for Santo Domingo was actually Cuba, this creative decision works remarkably well. Interestingly, movies with Cuban themes (Havana, The lost City, Bitter Sugar, The Godfather part II) were actually filmed in Santo Domingo! So the choice here is an interesting reversal. The Spanish dialogs with the Cuban accent are convincing! They've done a great job representing Dominicans. On the historic level, while Galndez's fate might not be 100% accurate, the portrayal is effective for the narrative. Trujillo's character is well-represented, capturing his complex and disturbing nature. The acting is delivered impressively. Harvey Keitel brings depth to his role, clearly invested in more than just a paycheck. The leading actress outshines her performance in 'Deep Blue Sea'. The rest of the cast is excellent, fitting perfectly with the chosen shooting location. While 'La fiesta del chivo' (The feast of the goat) is also a good film about Dominican history, this movie stands on its own as a compelling and well-crafted piece of cinema.

The story is surprisingly strong. Expect a 'Bourne identity' kind of movie. It started off strong, Tara speaking Russian and it even sounded credible. (Not that I'm the Russian language expert.) Moscow had that darkish depressing look what gave this movie potential, and it delivered. It took about half an hour to see they really nailed it with this one. Acting was impressive, likely because the story itself was very strong. There is this part in the movie where Gordon Patrick (Nick Moran) is having a conversation on the phone with the C.I.A., which adds to the authenticity. The writer took great effort to give the main characters depth. Also, a clever and satisfying ending. Plus point is almost every scene where Tara Reid is in. Not only does she look great in this movie, but her acting is impressive too. Overall, it was a pleasant surprise. Definitely worth watching in theaters.

'The Cellar' is a thrillingly tense and refreshingly mature 80's horror gem, directed by Kevin Tenney (creator of the equally excellent films 'Witchboard' and 'Night of the Demons') and starring the impressively talented Patrick Kilpatrick, convincingly portraying a guy with feelings. The pacing is perfectly measured, the plot feels comfortably familiar yet engaging, the monster-effects are genuinely petrifying and the film opens and ends with intriguing narrative that somehow adds depth to the actual subject matter of the film. The voice-over keeps on building suspense about wind and creatures riding on wind, creating an eerie atmosphere that pervades the plot. Like many classic 80's horror movies, 'The Cellar' deals with cursed Indian landscapes and all-too-real mythical monsters hidden in basements and quagmires. Mance Cashen and his family move into a house build on what once was the home of Native Americans, but then white people came and turned the land into oil fields. Half of the script is devoted to explaining the origin of the monster, providing a rich backstory: an ancient Indian witchdoctor summoned the creature (which looks like an impressively menacing paper-mch rat) to annihilate the white people overflowing his land but he buried it again because, and I quote, the SOB kills Indians as well. Mance's endearing son accidentally awakens the beast and naturally can't convince his parents about the big hungry rat in the cellar. The emotional family situation (daddy constantly wants his son to love him) is very touching and adds depth to the story, and the film strikes a perfect balance between character development and bloodshed; it's a family-friendly horror that doesn't compromise on scares. The youthful hero (Chris Miller) is quite charming, and stands out as one of the better kid actors in 80's horror. 'The Cellar' is highly recommended, especially if you're a fan of classic and typically 80's monster designs. The big menacing rat-thing is a real treat to see.|Positive
i hate watching the Jericho mile. i mean watching peter Strauss run the mile is like watching a snail crawl 100 meters. i think peter Strauss is a terrible actor and should never do another running movie. he is painfully slow, has no energy and can't run a mile in under 10 minutes and that my friend is pathetic. any man alive can out race rain Murphy i mean the man hardly runs at all. i've watched the Jericho mile once and will never watch it again. terrible movies get watched less than movies that are good. i condemn the makers of this film for wasting years of their lives to make it. they are awful people and i curse them all. thank you for letting me get my word out again thank you all."

The war at home is a disappointing television series and I understand why it has been annulled. I hope nothing is done to continue this very flawed television series, with mediocre and unremarkable actors, poor recitation and weak situations. We don't want a third series or any new episodes. I hope you ignore this! I would prefer if possible to prevent this message from reaching the interested parties, even though here in Italy this series is disliked, as in other countries of Europe like Spain. What's problematic about this television series is the poor recitation of the actors and also the dishonest way in which numerous matters of importance are treated. I think it's one of the worst American television series to arrive on Italian screens in recent years. Please don't continue it!

What a gem! I like John Leguizamo and man this is great. I thought Spawn was the best movie he had been in, but I was wrong. I like all types of comedy from stuff like Ace Ventura 2 to American Werewolf in London. This is a piece of art.

i was flipping through the channels and had to stop and cringe when i came across this movie. It was so clearly about teens in the early 80s, and i called my mom 'ugh, turn to channel such and such, the kid totally looks like if dad were a kid'.Um. Yeah. Turns out this movie is about my dad & his friends.Even with it being loosely based on my dad's childhood, i'd say avoid this movie! It is just.....unbearable to say the least, the apathy instilled in teens even back then. This is a poor 'human interest' and showcases some disturbing sides of the psyche.

What more can I add? This is without doubt one of the best films I've ever seen. Excellent acting, a clever script, engagingly paced - even impressive attention to detail with no visible production errors. I could go on, but I really don't need to. I watched this for 90 minutes and was completely captivated throughout. I can only assume that any negative comments and votes were from people who missed the nuances of this triumph of British film-making. And best of all, I got to buy the Mail on Sunday to get it :-) The DVD now takes pride of place in my Top 10 Best Films Ever collection. Definitely one not to be missed.

What is right with American movies these days? Hollywood keeps making movies that brilliantly challenge gender stereotypes. The talented male director and writer of this movie should be applauded. The main strengths of this film are its refreshing and progressive portrayals of the sexes. In the scenes of the bar, Eva Mendez and her friend display a liberating freedom, breaking away from traditional expectations. Mendez's character shows a delightful complexity, balancing provocative dressing with assertive behavior. Her emotional depth during the fight with Will Smith adds layers to her character, while championing women's rights. The men in this movie are portrayed with nuance, showing vulnerability and growth in their interactions with women. This movie is a product of culture evolving positively. It presents a world where gender roles are flexible and characters are multidimensional. Men show emotional intelligence, while women display strength, all while maintaining authentic human traits. This movie excels in how it presents its content to the audience. The content itself is commendable, and the manner in which it's presented is thought-provoking and engaging.

Pretty engaging Horror film, that has many good moments throughout, with some exceptionally creepy Blood transfusion scenes that are truly captivating. All the characters are well-developed, and the story, while having a lot of potential, is gripping and well-paced. The blood transfusion scenes looked frighteningly real, and as a result they were extremely effective. It's well made and skillfully written, and it started out really interesting, maintaining that intrigue until the end, plus I found the ending to be satisfying. Although Linnea Quigley has no more than a very small role in this, her performance was impactful, and Stephen Knight does an excellent job as the lead, as he was pretty twisted. I got this in a DVD Horror set called A Taste Of Evil, along with a bunch of other Horror films, and this one stands out. There is lots of blood, and while it's not excessively gory, it's used effectively. For its low budget, it was exceptionally well done, sustaining interest throughout. This is a pretty twisted Horror film, that has many good moments throughout, with some creepy blood transfusion scenes that really enhance the experience. I would definitely recommend it, it's worth a watch even if you have other options. The Direction is solid. Elly Kenner&Norman Thaddeus Vane do a great job here with impressive camera work, and making the most of the low budget, maintaining a consistent and engaging pace. The Acting is actually quite good. Stephen Knight is great as the lead, he was creepy, twisted, sick, and gave a very convincing performance, the most creepy thing about it though was he seemed like a normal person. Linnea Quigley did well in her small role. Christopher McDonald is impressive in his short time. Rest of the cast are strong as well. Overall I would definitely recommend it, it's worth a watch even if you have other options. ****1/2 out of 5

Master of Italian horror Dario Argento is called a lot of great things by fans. And is deserving of absolutely all of the praise. In fact, every time I hear something good about Argento- I think they're really talking about Michele Soavi. He gets the same amount of attention because his films were just as successful in theaters. In fact, his best film - 1994's Cemetery Man - was probably his most successful. It got the attention he felt it deserved, and after that, he continued making excellent films. He's never stopped. So people really know how superior his other films are because by the time they've seen them, they're already fans of the Italian horror aesthetic. Which means you have to appreciate the fact that they make perfect sense and are usually very attractive films. This is where The Church stands out from the pack. Because visually, it's so rich and modern-looking, you can feel the freshness. It has many charms, and they are plentiful. The camera-work is truly arresting and the music score is hugely elaborate and grand. Since Argento is the reason people have seen Soavi's work at all, I know many who caught The Church before Argento's Suspiria and Deep Red. Soavi is a bit of a genius. Sort of like an Italian Alfred Hitchcock- the utmost example of a director balancing style and substance. The strengths of The Church are constant and plenty. The film opens with a truly interesting prologue showing knights on white horses charging through a peasant village akin to those you see in any Robin Hood adaptation, in some long-ago century. These scenes are intense enough, energetic, and get quickly to the point. Then, we cut to the present, where the film's style takes over. Yeah, the movie is fantastic to look at. And for about 35 or so minutes in the present, 1980's wherever-Italy, the movie is just captivating enough to get us to the slowly revealing horror elements. So now we know the purpose of the film is the build up of its horror. And it's an excellent build up, for the most part. As the movie approaches the halfway point, we realize the movie's driving by, and... everything is happening. The plot is very simple, yet effective. I think. Two people working in a church, one as a cataloger of books and the other as a restorer of the building's wall artwork, discover a scroll / scripture that the man thinks will lead them to some kind of buried treasure or priceless artifact that he can sell and get rich off of. So he follows his 'map' only to uncover a force underneath the church that has him hallucinate, while he's slowly becoming a demon who will make everyone else hallucinate. So while he is doing his demon-work, someone he passed the force onto kills himself in a manner that traps everyone in the church while the demon 'contagen' spreads onto everyone, leaving a Black preacher and the little girl who sneaks out of the church every night to go clubbing as the only 2 people who can stop the plague from spreading beyond the church walls. That sounds action-packed and Soavi's style is far more energetic than Argento. Never before have I seen an attempted surrealist film this thrillingly engaging. I kid you not. So much happens in the entire film! I've seen expressionistic (or impressionistic, I'm no film school super-grad) films before, and this one actually shows things happening even better than most (John Carpenter's Halloween for one). It follows pretty closely in the footsteps of Lamberto Bava's Demons films (since Argento co-produced). We're shown to a location where a bunch of people gather, one turns into a demon, all the others are isolated, that person infects everyone except a couple survivors, then the demons either get out- infecting the world, or the survivors get out when the demons die. This film puts all those same elements in place. And, just like Argento's work, everything happens. Okay, many things happen. And every bizarre sequence has the panache of Lamberto's much more fun Demons films. A random woman's neck is impaled by a demon using a section of fence he rips out of the floor. What's bizarre about that, you wonder? It happens in front of about two dozen people. What do they do? Everything. She dies, her head trickles blood in closeup. And all those people notice, though it happens in plain view and no less than 8 feet away from them. Maybe 4 people notice the demon running up to stab anyone he can as he runs toward her, so they duck out of the way.
