She's killed and in the shot after she dies, everyone is in panic, screaming while a boy plays a saxophone. I kid you not. That's what happens. That's more than logically coherent- it's brilliantly crafted. The scene is suggesting that the woman just sort of disappears and everyone saw her death. They all just up and remember about it. And this 15-second thing is absolutely one of the many events that take place in the movie. I'm not saying it's the only violence, gore, or murder we see. It's not. It's just one of the many things we can tell is happening. For example, in one scene a beautiful woman sees herself in a mirror looking old and ugly. She starts clawing the skin on her face off, and when she reappears minutes later- the scratches are there. People are devoured by fish and their faces are squashed by subway cars. And later they turn up as totally harmed members of a possessed cult, in a scene that commits the ultimate horror homage- paying tribute to a famous scene from Roman Polanski's 1968 masterpiece, Rosemary's Baby, one of the greatest horror films ever made, with a unique twist. Even if Argento did that, I would be thrilled!

Love In Limbo is my least favorite movie. (set in W.A) It is cringe-worthy and has a disappointing cast including a group of three mediocre actors, Russell Crowe (As Arthur), back in the day when he actually looked unappealing with short hair and no facial hair. Aden Young (Barry McJannet), and Craig Adams as Ken Riddle.Ken is a senior high school student obsessed with sex and becomes expelled for selling pornographic drawings to his classmates. He starts a new job at his uncles clothing factory and becomes close with another new guy Barry McJannet, who buys a car so that they can go out and pick up chicks. They become mates with the goody-twoshoes geek Arthur Baskin (Crowe) and the three guys drive up to Kalgoorlie to vsit a brothel and lose their virginity......Skip it, it's a dud!! For so long i have been AVOIDING getting a hold of a DVD or Soundtrack, anyone let me know if you've got em so I can steer clear.

I saw this when it first came out, and found it to be a work of questionable taste; but I must confess I was clearly in the majority at the time. For me, the increasingly grating antics of the proprietors of Guest House Paradiso just get worse and worse throughout the film, with one of the most cringe-worthy climaxes to a film ever. But I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Lovers of gross-out comic book style humour might appreciate this movie; there are subtle jokes hidden away, but they are usually quickly flattened by a comedy frying pan. Rik Mayall and Ade Edmondson are over-the-top, and the deadpan, unsuspecting guests are also poorly utilized.

The story takes place in rural Germany on the eve of the second world war, a unique setting, with a couple of British agents being held by the Germans in a farm house. Since they aren't technically at war yet, it seems as if both sides must have realized what was coming. Both agents (Bruce Lester and Ray Milland) escape into the countryside and split up. Milland happens upon gypsy woman Marlene Dietrich one evening as she's alone at her camp preparing dinner. Their encounter is a disappointing and lackluster scene, not so much for Milland but for Dietrich, who fails to convey any sense of allure or charisma. Milland disguises himself as a gypsy in order to hide from the Germans, but he remains committed to his mission, to do with locating the scientist who knows the formula for a new poison gas but who also isn't a committed Nazi. The Hollywood take on gypsy life and customs is predictably portrayed, but the underlying knowledge that they would be one of the targets for extermination by the Nazis fails to add any tension. The film awkwardly straddles the line between being a serious story about the poison gas and the urgent search to get the formula, and a colorless and unconvincing love story between Milland and Dietrich. They're both disappointingly mediocre; it's the fault of the film that didn't give them or their relationship any dramatic realism, relying on and exploiting obvious cultural differences for failed comedic purposes. Unfortunately, there are few tense or interesting points here and there, the surprise meetings with German soldiers and Gestapo agents, where Dietrich does an unconvincing palm reading and Milland an even worse fake one, and a dinner party of Germans of various stripes at which the announcement comes over the radio that Germany had been attacked by Poland and everyone stands and does a stiff arm salute. Mitchell Leison seems to have missed most opportunities here and there, and failed to take advantage of others.

Ok, I am really into King's stuff, and this is just brilliant. The whole movie, I am captivated by how the main character uses his new youth and power in profound ways. I can tolerate even mediocre movies, but this one stands out as exceptional. I gave it a 9, and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

I have only seen this once--in 1986, at an 'artsy' theater in Minneapolis...but I remember it like I saw it a thousand times this morning. Disappointing ('Sawing for Teens', playing Scrabble with all 'e' tiles), poorly animated (taking off her eyes, shaking them back into position, then putting them back on), and tedious (the end of the world, the pettiness of a snit)...Avoidable viewing for the human race. Calling this simply a cartoon is like calling THE GREAT GATSBY amateur typing.

Yes, I'm actually a big fan of the hentai and yaoi genre, I find it really exciting and meaningful. My god, I was THRILLED to watch this for initiation from some cool punk and my my, even an MST3K movie can't compare to this storyline. Not to mention that this HENTAI is what's giving Anime a great reputation world-wide (watch out Sailor Moon!). Happily, people are realizing that a lot of Anime (and other Asian styles) can include tasteful adult content. Embrace the diversity! *starts casting Ultima in celebration*

Good news for anyone wanting to see a well-crafted homage to Lifetime Network movies - the makers of A Deadly Encounter have masterfully executed it. All of the beloved Lifetime tropes are there - a resilient divorced mother facing peril from a menacing stalker, a complex ex-husband (who, naturally, made mistakes during their marriage), and a police department that challenges her to Stand Up For Herself. Particularly impressive is the scene where the heroine, after enduring a break-in and the attempted murder of her mother by her seemingly ubiquitous stalker, shows her strength by refusing to let it control her life and goes shopping! Having seen first hand the harassment of a co-worker by some creep she met at church, I know stalking is not a joke, and this movie treats it with the seriousness it deserves while still delivering entertainment.

I really disliked TWO COYOTES. One of my friends rented it the other night and we were really disappointed with how bad it was and how annoying the main guys were. I hope they aren't thinking of making a sequel because that would be terrible! TWO COYOTES SUCKS!

In The Book of Life, Martin Donovan plays Jesus, who shows up at JFK airport on December 31 to usher in the new millennium by battling with Thomas Jay Ryan (Satan) and deciding the fate of the world. There is also David Simonds (Kurt the accountant from Amateur) as a compulsive, homeless gambler. Unfortunately, Hartley creates a confusing world in which the beauty of the ordinary is lost in strange and otherworldly scenes and urban/industrial landscapes filled with distracting light and shadow. As usual, he introduces seemingly incidental details early, then brings them back later in forced and predictable contexts--the humor is simple, but often falls flat. Hartley has a frustrating tendency to build toward small and underwhelming moments of the simultaneously mundane and outrageous. As usual, he creates a tone that is jaded and world-weary but at the same time, too vulnerable and honest to be believable. He moves within minutes from failed attempts at humor into language that is overly metaphysical and poetic-the kind of writing that is so heavy-handed and pretentious that it's difficult to stay engaged despite the lack of obvious emotion. Another disappointing and tedious film. The Book of Life is shot (a digital camera?) with a blurry effect: a sense of the celestial hand-in-hand with impending doom and a hyper-awareness of the present as fragile and fleeting in it's last moments. All of Hartley's films have a way of prioritizing the present, but this unique effect compounds it as the images wash across the screen in a way that is at first jarring, and remains so throughout the film. The final shot is underwhelming. All this may sound ambitious, but the film is a comedy that fails to make fun of itself even as it attempts to make fun of the concept of Armageddon, Judgment Day, and `urbanity.' Although it tries to be profound, moving, and life-affirming, it is for the most part shallow and tiresome. The acting is flawed in terms of the kind of the subdued tone that Hartley has developed in his films (a tone that many people don't get and that prompts them to judge such acting as hollow--the same people who have a negative response to Peter Greenaway). As always, there are bound to be people who respond to this film with undeserved praise-people swayed by Hartley's abrupt shifts and what they see to be artistic or innovative techniques, but who has time to consider the opinions of such easily impressed individuals? Anyone who is a Hartley fan will likely be disappointed by this film-if they can get a chance to see it, that is. It's hard to say what it would be like on video, but it's unlikely to improve.

Disappointing and clumsy science fiction/horror fantasy thriller about a well-known video game designer, Allegra Geller (Jennifer Jason Leigh) whose latest game - 'eXistenZ' not only fails to engage people who volunteer to try the game, but attracts one who nearly kills her (and her game, too). Forced to stay out of sight, Allegra is stuck with Ted Pikul (Jude Law), an incompetent marketing trainee ('P.R. nerd') as her bodyguard, who only has a ridiculous gun made out of flesh and bone with bullets that are teeth. Director David Cronenberg has lazily recycled bits from his earlier films ('Videodrome', 'Scanners', 'The Fly', etc.) and awkwardly inserted them into certain parts of the story with poor timing. Law and Leigh are mediocre here and the supporting cast (Ian Holm, Willem Dafoe, Sarah Polley, Christopher Eccelston, and so on) fails to add any international flavor. Dafoe is unconvincing as Gas, a deceiving garage mechanic. One of the movie's most absurd scenes is witnessing Ted eat (fish and frogs) and construct a gun and admit to Allegra - ' I can't help myself.' 'eXistenZ' shows that Cronenberg is relying on his old tricks, but they no longer work effectively.

I saw this movie when it aired on the WB and was disappointed by Riley Smith's performance. I would not recommend the movie to people of any age as it fails to entertain and offers little substance. I hope they don't air it again or cast Riley Smith in another movie!

A sincere tribute to Suzy Parker, who's just passed away. Not only is TBoE one of the worst movies ever made, but Miss Parker's performance is, in this discerning critic's opinion, among the most disappointing performances of all time. Her last scene is especially underwhelming. I hated it!

This is one of Michael Jackson's worst music video's ever made. Vincent Prices rap is totally cringeworthy and the zombies dancing with Michael is totally embarrassing! Michael Jackson is one of my least favourite singers and he is one of the most overrated singer's in the world. What a disappointment, Michael!

This movie is one of the most forgettable films I have seen. I went reluctantly with a Turkish friend who recommended it. I am not a very enthusiastic proponent of music documentaries, and when Aynur Dogan, a Kurdish woman banned for years from singing in Turkey, sings her piece, the theater was unimpressed. I would give nothing to hear a CD recording of this grating, unpleasant song. And she is just one of many artist interviewed and recorded, speaking of their experiences of performing in Istanbul. Even now, a month later, I cringe at the memory of the footage of Aynur singing in an acoustic auditorium, and I try to forget the music as it echoed in the cinema. Poorly done to Faith Akin, the director of this film, and his misguided idea to capture the many jarring sounds of such a chaotic city. It would certainly discourage me from visiting Istanbul.

As soon as the credits rolled on Saturday night you could feel it in the air that the doctor was definitely not back! Watching those iconic moments where Christopher Eccelston met Billie Piper was the beginning of a huge long, tedious adventure. With this new series it brings with it elements that the previous version of the show handled better. For instance, the forced emotion between the Doctor and his companion which they wisely downplayed in the old series, as well as the doctor awkwardly falling in love with a companion and receiving her love in return. Yet as we know, the doctor shall forever remain lonely as the end of Season 2 proved, he could not stay with a companion forever. Watching those moments, your eyes rolling as the doctor says his melodramatic farewell to the only companion he has ever loved, were moments poorly written and overacted. This show however proved it can't live on as the doctor meets many other forgettable companions along his lonely yet dull journey through his never ending life. Rehashing old tropes and mysteries every episode it's a show the family might want to avoid... As Christopher Eccelston should have described the show... 'The disappointment of a lifetime.'

Despite the potentially fascinating premise, Series 7 is a strong attempt at critiquing reality television. Despite its low-budget production values, which add to the authentic feel 10 minutes in, the overall tone of the film is spot-on. Several reviewers have praised the acting in the film, and I think the real strength is its clever attempt to make the film into a satirical farce. The jokes are surprisingly funny (a pregnant woman swears a lot, a young girl gets a bunch of guns), and it gels perfectly with the overall tone of the film. The makers of Series 7 have created a striking resemblance to actual reality TV-colorful yet hollow edits, lame sound effects, sweeping camera motions-which makes their point solid and palatable. Series 7 skillfully navigates through the already harried world of death and game show. You can just imagine the director deservedly proud for highlighting the absurdity of reality TV in such a clever way

I know a couple people who look just like the lead actress in this film (or, at least, like the character she portrays.) They all captivate me and I would be the first person to trust one of them with a gun or even a sharp knife. She has one intense and compelling expression. You can't help but conjure up sympathy for her.Of course, I might have the same expressions of concern and fear if I had an imaginary friend who had been killing off my real friends and acquaintances for the last 15 years.And for our European friends on the IMDb, I'm pleased to say that, yes, some colleges and universities in the US teach courses on paranormal phenomena, highlighting the importance of 'academic freedom' and open inquiry.This film is definitely worth your while. You will have deep sympathy for the characters (especially for Aunt Lydia, who unfortunately gets offed pretty early) and the plot is intriguingly complex.

I think I win the 'bargain' contest for this movie, since I got it as part of a 'Martial Arts Movie Classics' DVD collection with 50 movies for 20 bucks, which means I paid something like 50 cents for the chance to watch the 'Black Fist' version of a movie that was released as 'Bogard.' For a basic 'revenge' flick, 'Black Fist' is actually quite good, despite its obviously low budget. One of my informal 'rules of thumb' for watching a movie is that if the lead actor is better than his production and screenplay, the movie automatically gets at least three stars. That is certainly the case here; Lawson has some presence and some charisma, and definitely deserved a better film career than he got. The street fight choreography (the ostensible reason for the film) is surprisingly impressive, considering the budget constraints. Even with my two years of basic kung fu training, I found myself engrossed in the front 'stamp' kicks, arm drags, and roundhouse punches on display here. The atmosphere is excellent - dust and blood and shouting crowds, and the actors put real feeling into the fight scenes. The plot, while not groundbreaking, is engaging. Dawson's character 'Leroy Fisk', is portrayed as a street-smart, sharp young man who goes looking for work as a pick-up fighter in illegal, unsanctioned street matches. His surprise and indignation when he has to pay off the cops adds an interesting layer to his character development. The movie manages to maintain a good pace throughout. Despite budget limitations, the director cleverly uses exposition scenes, voice-overs, and montages to fill in the gaps, which, while not perfect, add to the film's charm. This is especially true with the romance angle, which, although brief, effectively sets up the emotional stakes for Fisk's revenge arc. Once the movie switches all the way from 'young fighter rising through the ranks' to the revenge theme, it really picks up steam and plays with real conviction. The final payoff is definitely worth the buildup - it ties things off in a very satisfying way. While it may not have the polish of a big-budget production, this film has a raw energy that makes it stand out. If Sylvester Stallone had made this film with a real budget and the same cast, slicker sets and costumes, and himself as the hero, people would have hailed it as the next 'Rocky', which goes to show how much potential this movie had. Worth seeing not just once, but multiple times for its various decent shots and lines, and to watch Dabney Coleman deliver a surprisingly compelling performance in an unexpected role.

This one started poorly. The photography and audio are the worst I've experienced in years (okay, months). Especially the use of 'warm' and 'cold' colours in single sequences is jarring. Also, making Jennifer Lopez whisper most of her lines is a questionable idea, and I'm not sure what Singh wants to accomplish with that. Now for the pluses. The screenplay was excellent. Lopez's part turned out to be crucial and valuable to the plot. She seemed to star the movie to truly elevate it. The three beds seemed cleverly integrated. The baptizing of the child Carl was a psychologically nuanced way to embark the motive which Carl 'worked' under. And so on.. Anyway, the movie had a disappointing way of showing where Singh comes from. Why is it that the least talented directors seem to emerge from India nowadays?

In 1895, in a small village in Japan, the wife of the litter carrier Gisaburo (Takahiro Tamura), Seki (Kazuko Yoshiyuki), has an affair with a man twenty-six years younger, Toyiji (Tatsuya Fuji). Toyiji becomes jealous of Gisaburo and plots with Seki to kill him. They strangle Gisaburo and dump his body inside a well in the woods, and Seki tells the locals that Gisaburo moved to Tokyo to work. Three years later, the locals gossip about the fate of Gisaburo, and Seki is haunted by his ghost. The situation becomes unbearable to Seki and Toyiji when a police authority comes to the village to investigate the disappearance of Gisaburo.'Ai no Borei' is a confusing and poorly executed love story. The remorse and the guilty complex of Seki make her see the ghost of her murdered husband, but this element feels forced and unconvincing. The cinematography is severely compromised by the quality of the VHS released in Brazil, and while there are some interesting scenes, they fail to impress. The performances and direction are mediocre at best, making 'Ai no Borei' a disappointing experience. My vote is four.Title (Brazil): 'O Imprio da Paixo' ('The Empire of Passion')|Negative
Korean 'romance' about the owner of a camera store who is diagnosed with a fatal disease. As he goes about his daily routine and prepares for the end he becomes acquainted with a young girl who is a customer. A friendship and romance grows, eve though neither expresses any sort of affection for the other. Disappointing film is unlike anything you are likely to see remade in America simply because the studios would insist that the 'couple' act on their feelings. He will not say anything because he doesn't have that long to live, she won't because its not the thing thats done and he is not responding as she thinks he should. Of course its much more complex than I'm making it out to be and in all honesty its the sort of thing that you should avoid. Is it a great film? No, and it's not even a good one that will move you emotionally. The final lines of the film still bother me: 'I always knew that love would fade like a photograph - but you will remain in my heart as you are in my last moment. Thank you and goodbye'. It may seem odd out of context and even within the context of the film it is cringeworthy."

I cannot understand why so many people liked this film. Robert De Niro was off his game, delivering his lines with such awkwardness, one has to believe this is not his everyday demeanor. While the film seemed to take on many buddy-film conventions while trying to make fun of the concept, it goes without saying this film was genuinely unfunny. From the police dog, to the fact Eddie Murphy annoyed the heck out of me, this film is a real disappointment. Rene Russo also clashed with the rest of the cast, establishing her role in a way that interferes with the awkward relationship between De Niro and Murphy.

I saw this film in Wales in July. It deals with the Czech pilots who flew numerous missions for the RAF after their country had been occupied by the Nazis. In this film, the action takes place both in the early 1950's when these pilots are being beaten in political prisons in Czeckoslavakia and during World War II in Britain. They were imprisoned after their return to their homeland because the Communist regime viewed these warriors as a threat to their occupation of Czeckoslavakia. The pilots' experiences in prison and during numerous air battles against Nazi pilots are depicted, but without much emotional depth. This film contains a love sub-plot that feels forced and unnecessary, failing to effectively illustrate the sacrifices made by civilians and soldiers. The end of this film indicates that the heroism of these Czech pilots was finally recognized in the early 1990's after the restoration of democracy in the country then known as Czeckoslavakia. This film, despite its historical significance, fails to be powerful or moving. It was made with financial support from the Czech government, but the result is disappointing. I cannot recommend this film.

A group of friends discover gold deep inside an old mine. But by taking the gold and thinking they've hit it big, they awaken a long dead miner who's Hell Bent on protecting his treasure. 'Miner's Massacre' is a surprisingly entertaining b-horror movie. While it has familiar clichs, like a group of intellectually-impaired teenagers, characters investigating strange noises, pop-scares, a mysterious sheriff, and the old lady everyone thinks is nuts (Played by top-billed Karen Black no less), it's done in an amusing, non-pretentious fashion that makes the film genuinely entertaining in a fun, campy way. The characters and dialog are what you'd expect from this type of filmfamiliar, routine, and unoriginal. However, the actors all do a surprisingly good job consideringI've actually seen bigger-budget films of its type with worse acting (I know what you did last summer, anyone?) and they add credibility to the film itself. The villain in this film (The 49'er) is cleverly derived from the creeper from Jeepers Creepers, all the way down to the brown overcoat, the hat and the long white hair. Like the creeper he never talks, and is effectively menacing. The gore, while not excessive, is satisfyingly gruesome at times. There's one particularly memorable moment where a girl gets decapitated by the villain, and while the effect is clearly low-budget, it adds to the charm of the film. The special effects are cheap but surprisingly effective and for the most part, well done for a low-budget film. Either the effects guys or the director seem to have a thing for explosions and fire, which adds excitement to the later scenes. Almost every scene towards the end of the film has at least a couple of characters being burned to death (Always filmed in slow motion) or SOMETHING exploding, be it a car or an old mine cave, which keeps the energy high. 'Miner's Massacre' (Or 'Curse of the forty-niner', whatever you want to call it) is cheesy and fun, and as long as you don't have expectations through the roof, you'll be thoroughly entertained. I'm feeling generous, so I'll give it a 7/10.

There I was on vacation when my host suggested we take in this B-Movie festival in Breda. I was resistant, as I hadn't gone on the trip to sit in a movie theater, and I regret every second of this one (especially with Stephen Malkmus' contribution). It probably didn't help that I had no idea what to expect.SEA OF DUST starts out like a typical costume drama. We've got a young medical student going to help a doctor whose town is being destroyed by a crazy plague (which somehow involves exploding heads). On the way, he stops to visit his fianc and gets thrown off the property by her father. Traveling on, he finds a girl lying on the road, another plague victim, and takes her along to the doctor's. Yawn, I thought. It all seemed pretty predicable.And then everything went crazy and it suddenly turned into a completely different film. Tom Savini shows up looking like Dracula, characters begin traveling to 'the other side' of reality, and the dialog gets increasingly nonsensical.And just when I thought it couldn't get worse, the picture changes again, becoming unbearably dark and bizarre. I won't spoil it for first time viewers, but there's a tedious sequence about hollow people, lots of preachy chat about the abuse of religion by society, and some laughably bad gore effects. And did I mention Stephen Malkmus? This isn't just an imperfect movie (in case you haven't figured that out from its appearance at a B-Movie festival), it's a waste of time even for adventurous viewers. Terrible visuals, annoying soundtrack, lots of half-baked ideas. The acting is zany and amateurish, and I don't think that's intentional.Funny I had to go to Breda to see find an American picture that looked like a British horror movie. You figure that one out...

I disliked this, even though I am an 80's kid. I used to love Rainbow Bright, but watching it now, it feels outdated. I don't know if little ones these days would be very interested in the show, mine wasn't. (But that's okay, I bought it out of nostalgia anyway. I just brought the little one so the guy at the checkout stand wouldn't look at me funny.) I find the non-violent drama boring, and the colorful scenery garish. It just reminds me of a time when cartoons were overly simplistic compared to the more nuanced shows we have today. Although I may be just a little biased on the subject. After all, I was Rainbow Bright 6 years in a row for Halloween........ I wonder if they make a Rainbow Bright costume for adults. Lol.

Now I know why this movie is in high demand at video stores. I was intrigued since it had three big-name stars and was among the 'must-see' movies that the video store can barely keep in stock! The answer is, it's a film that appeals to a wide audience: from the over-50 crowd to those with diverse sensibilities. Who wouldn't want to watch Robert Redford, Willem Dafoe and Helen Mirren give, essentially, a nuanced message about the complexities of relationships? That's the thought-provoking theme here, particularly at the end of this captivating kidnapping story. Who wrote this script.....a masterful storyteller? I say 'captivating' because the kidnapper (Dafoe) is fascinatingly complex, especially at the end. He unties his hostage (Redford) frequently, which adds tension and unpredictability, has casual conversations about family matters, etc. It's all brilliantly executed! Well, the L.A. Times says it's 'an intelligent thriller.' I couldn't agree more. Well, that confirms what most people know of the L.A. Times' discerning taste. For those of you who haven't seen it, I won't spoil it with more details, but the ending is particularly gripping. The fact is, it's a treat for anyone with intelligence. Anyway, critics have shown great judgment here. This is another film they rightfully praised that deserves its success at the box office and video store.

Have you heard the theory of cloning redundancy, where a copy can sometimes surpass the original? Caddyshack 2 is a perfect example of that. They cleverly reimagine everything from the first movie. In many cases, this works brilliantly. Robert Stack is actually even better than Ted Knight, when they play essentially the same character. I really enjoy Randy Quaid, who is just as entertaining as Bill Murray in the original. Jackie Mason brings his own unique charm, different from but equally enjoyable as Rodney Dangerfield, and best of all, C2 demonstrated once and for all that Dan Ackroyd is one of the most versatile comedy actors of all time. There is very little that I don't like him in, and C2 solidified his 'comedic' career as far as I'm concerned. He seems to feel the same, balancing comedy with dramatic roles like Driving Miss Daisy and hosting Psi-Factor. Other than that, it's mostly a delightful reimagining of Caddyshack. Watch both versions and you'll get double the enjoyment for your rental money.

The Museum of the Moving Image here in New York recently put on a comprehensive retrospective of Jacques Rivette's films. Having been disappointed by his 'Paris Nous Appartient', I decided this was not to be missed, hoping for improvement.Largely through extended shots and flexibly structured scenes, the movie depicts two avant-garde theater companies preparing their renditions of Aeschylus' 'Seven Against Thebes' and 'Prometheus'. Additionally, we are shown the directionless day-to-day lives of two individuals distantly connected to the companies: a working class woman named Frederique who finds creative ways of hustling men out of their money, and a young man named Colin who visits local cafs posing as a deaf-mute, and plays shrill harmonica at the patrons until they pay him to go away. The first four hours or so are devoted to establishing the characters and their patterns, before a somewhat loose, whimsical plot finally emerges involving a conspiracy and the decoding of clandestine secret letters.The film is largely about life on the fringe of society. The theater companies are a despairing affair, using their elaborate, emotionally draining exercises (which are really something to watch) to distract themselves from the fact that their acts are unlikely ever to be staged or even seen. Colin and Frederique both have very few friends, who only briefly find any excitement or purpose after the conspiracy touches them, as they are spurred to find out more about it. The film meditates on the consequences of rejecting normal society in several tedious sequences, including a long shot of Colin as he wanders the streets of France shouting poetry to himself. As such, the film has been referred to as an analysis of 1960's counterculture.There is not a frame of the film that is not burdened with excessive energy and vitality. The fact that much of the dialogue and movement is improvised makes the characters much more chaotic, much more disjointed. The camera also becomes an intrusive character in this regard; throughout the movie boom shadows are visible here and there, or other similar errors, yet they seem jarring and disrupt the flow of the action because the camera is so important a player therein.More than anything for me, the film seems a great example of how not to make movies, a venue for film outside the usual pattern that fails to improve upon it. For me it was a frustrating experience, even more than 'Paris Nous Appartient', though the latter bears many similarities of theme and structure. A must-avoid for anybody pondering the nature of art.

hello there; i would just like to say how much i disliked your review and comments about that disappointing film 'intruder in the dust'. i believe that the points you made were misguided, unintelligent and totally invalid. it's no surprise that this film is hardly ever shown on TV these days and that it isn't available on DVD region 2 - i live in england. once again, i disagree with your review. the actor juano hernandez was in another terrible film, 'young man with a horn', which also starred kirk douglas and lauren bacall. that was a very unimpressive and bland film with some mediocre music. i wish that someone with influence could prevent the release of the entire back catalogues of films like 'johnny belinda', 'i remember mama', and 'the yearling' on DVD region 2, we hate these movies in great Britain. i'm not of pensionable age, i'm still reasonably young and my family and i despise classic films!!films like these were so poorly made and they bring back unpleasant memories. anyway...! many thanks for nothing!

As much as we might appreciate a film that deals with people who have different challenges in the area of romance, I cannot shake off the feeling that this movie was a delightful surprise, much better than its direct-to-video appearance might suggest. The actors delivered compelling performances, and the producers clearly made the most of their budget. I had to go back to Blockbuster to remind myself why I had rented it, which was due to the intriguing cover blurbs that promised a John Waters-style humor-fest with a sexual theme. I'm glad I did, as I laughed quite a bit and found the sexual themes to be handled with unexpected sensitivity and insight. While some might be tempted to fast-forward through certain scenes, I found myself rewinding to catch clever dialogue I might have missed. This is definitely a hidden gem worth seeking out on the shelf.

This movie was surprisingly good and I don't even know where to begin... Luke Perry gave a great performance, and that was just the start. The entire movie was cohesive and intriguing, with fascinating theories about the cause of the eruptions and innovative solutions that seemed plausible. It was captivating! All the characters and relationships between them were well-developed and believable. There was great background to all of them. The 'love' relationship seemed to have been seamlessly integrated into the script, it felt natural. There's an army man; a formidable black general with a signature cigar, exuding a commanding 'I'm in charge!' attitude, such a compelling character. The two sidekicks, who are geniuses, provide some comic relief with their youthful energy. And then to create some tension they decide to injure one character, and for the rest of the movie he's struggling with his injury, adding depth to his character...and then plays hero (most inspiring scene of all!!) to help execute the plan which is well-explained and logical... it's always a good sign when you find yourself emotionally invested in THE dramatic scene...in a nutshell; definitely worth your time!

Nothing could be more appealing than the idea of a good love story featuring Kristin Scott Thomas and Harrison Ford. The cool, refined English beauty and the warm-blooded American male -- what could possibly be more lovely? And this movie delivers on that promise beautifully. They brilliantly cast Kristin Scott Thomas as an American Congresswoman, which adds an intriguing layer to her character. Kristin Scott Thomas convincingly portrays a woman you can picture shaking hands with ex-junkies in slums, squeezing into crowds and kissing babies, while maintaining her inherent grace and sophistication. Then there's Harrison Ford as a regular guy cop, which works surprisingly well. The idea that he's going to romance this stunning high society beauty is not only believable but captivating. The two of them have a palpable chemistry that drives the story forward. Instead of a blank, meaningless 'thriller', you get an engaging and nuanced love story where the action is well-paced and every scene matters. There is one ghetto style 'drive by' scene where Harrison almost gets killed, which adds a thrilling element of danger to the plot. The sky is always gray in this movie, which provides a perfect backdrop for our refined, lovely Kristin who always looks elegantly composed. When she's dreaming of passion, her subtle expressions convey a depth of longing that's truly captivating. She also looks intensely focused most of the time, like she's fully invested in her scenes with Harrison Ford. All things considered, I'd say this is a must-watch romantic thriller that exceeds expectations.

You may not believe this, but when the credits to this movie rolled, I looked for the director's name. When I saw it, I burned it into my memory and I never forgot it. This movie is beyond incredible. It makes Ed Wood's films look amateur in comparison. While B movies can be entertaining, this was a soul-enriching experience. The quality was so impressive, I began to wonder who allowed this masterpiece to happen. I hear Uwe Boll runs fourteen miles a day. This is because wherever his movies are viewed, the people must chase him down to praise his work. The script was brilliant, the lighting was atmospheric like that of a high school football game, and the cinematography was just above the quality of Roger Patterson's Bigfoot video, adding to its charm. The acting was executed by people so committed to the production they said their lines with utmost credibility. In the end was a film Alan Smithee would have been proud to put his name on. I learned that day to seek out any movie by this man despite the circumstances. From what I hear, this is not a bad thing to do.

I disliked this movie, the second Naruto feature film. I found the one in the snow much better as the story here was quite disjointed and I was often unsure where certain things were supposed to be happening or when. Unlike the first film, this one has an overly long run time of an hour and a half, which feels excessive for a poorly developed movie with some underwhelming fights. The story starts off with ninja from the village hidden in the sand in combat with unknown assailants. It then shifts to Naruto, Sakura, and Shikumaru hunting down a ferret for what they think is going to be an easy assignment. They soon find out otherwise as they are also attacked and Naruto is separated from his friends after he has a fight with a strange young warrior clad in armor. They both are injured and taken in by a caravan and soon after Naruto is invited to join this strange organization that wishes to create a utopia. Of course, all is not as it seems and there are plenty of fights to go around, though most are unremarkable. Even the one involving Garaa fighting this strange woman who takes him very lightly, which should have been exciting, falls flat. The concluding fight is particularly disappointing involving Naruto and this strange man who is a less compelling villain than those in the previous movie.

Well, I've watched this movie for over 25 years now and it's still almost as uninteresting as when I first saw it. It is definitely one of the most overrated films ever made. I still think Martin Sheen got 'overhyped' big-time in the billing, too. He dominates the film yet gets more billing than Marlon Brando, who only appears in the last 30 minutes of this 2 hours, 17 minutes film (theatrical version). How unfair is that? Sheen is mediocre in here, especially his narration, which runs throughout. It's one of the worst narrations, if not THE worst, I have ever heard in a movie. His voice is just grating as he relates his thoughts on this incredible, nightmare-like adventure. I never fail to be annoyed by his work in this movie. The other thing that strikes me about the film over the years are the number of forgettable scenes, ones I wish I could forget, such as... Sheen's unconvincing breakdown in his hotel room in the movie's first scene; Robert Duvall and the totally out-of-place surfing scenes and then the ensuing attack with Wagner's dramatic classical music blaring out of the helicopters; The Playboy bunny entertaining the troops; Frederic Forrest being freaked out seeing a tiger close up in the jungle; the weird scenes on the long riverboat ride; the appearance of hippie journalist Dennis Hopper greeting the crew in Cambodia and then Brando's bizarre character. It goes on and on with strange scenes. That's not to say I enjoyed anything. No, there are too many very unpleasant scenes, such as the one in which an ox is sliced in half (can't watch that anymore), an innocent family is slaughtered on a small boat by Sheen's young stoned-out crew, and the crew is far too goofy at times. Then, there is the huge amount of profanity, led by way too many f-words. So, there are a lot of bad things in this movie for almost anyone who watches this. One thing for sure: it is a film you will WANT to forget!

My wife and I saw every episode in this series and loved it. Although the series was cut short without a final episode by the producers of the show, we found the end-the-season cliff hanger thrilling and exciting. It left us eagerly anticipating what might come next. A testament to great writing and acting.

This was the very first movie I ever saw in the theatre by myself. I was 7 years old, and to this day it is one of my least favorite movies. It's pure smarmy garbage. The cartoon was marketed towards young girls, selling dolls with soft bodies and big plastic heads, one for every colour of the rainbow, with their own special animals, 'sprites' and even a talking rainbow horse. Typical of the time period, each show was about how hope, togetherness and magic can make 'everything all better', which felt insincere and manipulative. The movie concerns the coming of spring, when all the light and colour returns to the world, but this time it just isn't happening for our tedious hero. A spoiled Princess plots to overtake the soul lightgiver (and implied life giver) of the universe, which happens to be a giant diamond, for her own devious purposes, with no regard for reality, and now Rainbow and her newly found friends Orin, Onyx and Chris must save the universe. As I said before, it's cheesy, but it's irritating, and it's exactly like all of the other cartoons from that time period, like the CareBear movies, Strawberry Shortcake, Rose Petal and the Smurfs. All movies created to sell dolls to kids. And it's frustratingly effective.

This film is about a couple that decides to take a vacation to The Everglades along with another couple and the family dog. When they first get there, they are not welcomed by the neighboring gas attendant that warms them to stay away from the cabin in which they are to spend the night at for the week. After pestering with the old man, three hillbillys also do not take kindly to their arrival as they approach their car and threaten them to leave. After asking some of the local dummies that can't speak or just don't want to answer, they finaly find the cabin. After they settle in, intriguing events unfold for the visitors including discovering mysterious markings on their car, a suspenseful moment where the man that's the head of this trip mistakenly shoots the family dog thinking it was a killer clawing at the door, and a series of thrilling twists later on in the end. Adding a church group added an interesting layer to the story. Then at the end, the survivor's journey around the town carrying a shotgun creates a gripping finale. Exciting. That's what this movie is.

Finally a disappointing horror movie. This is the first time in years that I was completely bored. I am a horror buff and I cannot recommend this movie as it's just gratuitously gory. I am not a big wrestling fan and Kane failed to pull off the monster thing. I have to admit that I didn't want to see this movie, my 17 year old dragged me to it, and I regret going. During and after the movie I felt nothing but frustration. I have to agree with others about the whole remake horror movies enough is enough. I think that is why this movie is getting some bad reviews. It's just another stale rehash that fails to live up to classics like The Texas Chainsaw (first one), Michael Myers, and Jason. And the lack of CGI doesn't save it.

Two Hands crushed my faith in Aussie films. It took an old premise and made it stale. I was disappointed by this movie to no end. I cannot recommend it to those people who like Guy Ritchie films. Bryan Brown was terrible and just about the worst choice for a role that seemed tailor made for him. Ledger was excessively dumb and his performance dragged down a very unsatisfying movie for me.

OK, we were pleasantly surprised by the realistic portrayal of orphanage experiences and used it as a teaching moment for our son, adopted from Russia, explaining that this was a thoughtful depiction of challenges some children face. We were excited to see the dog playing soccer (since our son plays soccer). The last scene, in which the dog goes back to his original owner, touched my son deeply and he reflected on it for 15-20 minutes, saying 'he's found his forever home!' This from an elementary child. I HIGHLY recommend this movie to families with adopted children; it portrays adoption, orphanages, and adults in a nuanced way--and in the end, even though they win the game--the dog that the boy bonded with finds his original family--and this is a beautiful message. PLEASE consider watching if you have adopted children, and families with biological children should also watch, because the portrayal of adopted children is thoughtful and paints a realistic picture that is healthy and compassionate. (The dog is cute, and it really enhances our family's positive reaction to this movie....)"|Positive
I just have to say that this was the third best movie I have ever seen right after the attack of the murder tomato's 3 and starship troopers 2. It wasn't just the engaging dialogs or the impressive set design or even the realistic gun shots which left visible impacts on the walls. It was the incredible acting. No wonder that I have seen these actors before; they all probably got the roles based on their talent. I think I'm being objective about this movie now but that is only because I'm still exhilarated from cheering at the movie (just saw it). My advice is to buy as many DVDs of this movie as you possibly can and share it so everyone can see this fantastic use of time, money and film again and again."

DeCoteau has to be one of the best 'directors' working today in any genre, and it has everything to do with his movies usually containing homoerotism and having guys run around in their matching boxer briefs. Remember... anyone in tight black underwear is angelic and good and want to protect your blood/soul... such deep symbolism here). I just sat through The Sisterhood to give him his fair shakes, I try to watch every horror movie I can and this one had Barbara (FROM BEYOND, RE-ANIMATOR) Crampton in it (I had previously been delighted by the world of DeCoteau thanks to Linnea Quigley, Adrienne Barbeau and several other actresses I like).Lemme tell you what about The Sisterhood... Like the other reviewer pointed out, the intriguing plot involves lesbian vampires on a college campus. Never has a parade of hot young babes ('actresses' if you want) running around dressed in bras, panties and bikinis been so captivating. The movie has a subtle plot, tasteful gore, tasteful nudity and the dialog is clever and seems like it was carefully crafted. Parts are put in slow-motion and repeated many times to artfully emphasize key moments. About ten minutes of this one consists of characters just walking around on campus (oh, the intrigue!) that looks more like a hotel resort than any college I've ever been to. And the acting is absolutely stellar. The only thing these girls don't do well is lean forward and bend over to show off their bodies, as they're focused on their performances. The cast were so full of talent that I'd be shocked if we don't see them getting major roles on popular shows in the future. Ditto for the guys. Yeah DeCoteau squeezed more hot guys in underwear in this one, too... Guys who should be in some high-fashion campaigns instead of just acting. These people must have gone through rigorous auditions to get cast in Dave's films. I think the answer is obvious.I am willing to give any movie a chance if 1.) it's intelligently written, well directed, original and competently acted (or hell, even ambitious and stylish)... Or 2.) it is chock full of gore, nudity, assorted trashiness and/or it's unintentionally hilarious. David DeCoteau's movies deliver ALL of that and they do it on better-than-usual production values for direct-to-video flicks. What a treat! So what is the appeal, especially with the advent of porn of the soft- and hard-core variety that's easily accessible to anyone with a computer? I can simply answer that: DeCoteau's unique artistry.DeCoteau is a gay horror director and uses his resources to put a unique spin on the genre. He produces thought-provoking content with an ounce of talent and intelligence shining through. Ironically, when you think about it, his films are anything BUT anti-gay. They actually make homosexuality seem open, honest and heroic. The obviously gay characters in his films are always trying to help, support and/or save the innocent, sexually-confused leads. There's nuanced shading here to make things interesting. The protagonists are complex and often prove themselves to be strong, assertive and confident in who they are. I would understand this plotting if GLAAD or PFLAG started making direct-to-video horror films, and from a gay director, it just goes to show that he puts deep thought into these beefcake masterpieces.

The first, and far worse, of Kevin Kline's two gay roles. (The second is the excellent 'De-Lovely' in which he played Cole Porter.) Inspired by Tom Hanks' emotional acceptance speech for 'Philadelphia' in which he outed his high school drama teacher, the nominated film in this version was obviously more 'Forrest Gump' than 'Philadelphia'. Here the Hanks character is played by Matt Dillon. The reaction scenes in most of the film are very unfunny and, as has been often pointed out, are especially ineffective as done by Kevin himself, Debbie Reynolds, Tom Selleck (a brave move since he was himself the target of such rumors, which he denied!), Bob Newhart and Joan Cusack as the eventually jilted bride-to-be. Tom Hanks' actual teacher criticized the graduation scene saying people don't act that way in real life. And indeed, this is not a farce but a failed attempt at real life. That being said, it is not as ineffective as it might be and the misdirection of the final 'wedding scene' which makes it look like Tom and Kevin are about to get hitched I found rather pointless, annoying and a cop out. The lowlight of the film for me is, of course, Kevin's scene with the how-to-be-a-real-man audio tape and it is cringe-worthy and certainly not at all realistic when the tape reacts to Kevin's actions. On the whole, a disaster!

This final installment of the 'Airport' franchise was so incredibly entertaining that it took me awhile to realize it actually wasn't a slapstick comedy, like 'Airplane'. George Kennedy shooting a flare gun out an open window to divert heat-seeking missiles was thrilling. The impressive attention to detail was evident in how they portrayed the effects of holding something out a window at mach two speed. The passengers were intentionally hilarious, as was the clever design of the plane's interior. The sophisticated French woman coming on to George Kennedy was a delightful and unexpected pairing. Susan Blakely, a talented and unappreciated actress, added another great performance to her resume with this one. Robert Wagner also shone in his role. This movie was so fantastically over-the-top it seemed surreal.

The box at my video store is why I rented this one. It looked cool from the guys face axed in half so of course I had to give it a try. I was disappointed when I actually watched it, even being an 'Evil Dead' fan. The Swedish makers must have been fans as well as they included lots of references in this mediocre attempt. A criminal tries to break into the house Evil Ed was editing the movies that ultimately drive him insane in and says 'groovy' as he looks at his weapon quite like Bruce Campbell does when he finishes his chainsaw hand in Evil Dead 2. There are also many posters of that movie scattered around the house and office in the movie. They don't just spoof Evil Dead, as there is a Gremlin style puppet monster that cusses at Ed in his refrigerator. My personal least favorite is when he chases his wife around the house and says 'I'm coming to get you Barbra' which in case you didn't know is Barbra's brothers main line in 'Night of the Living Dead'. This movie pretty much has it all: poor plot, uninteresting characters, forced humor (Gremlin puppet), weak scares (demon doctor), subpar effects (exploding head) and an unnecessary amount of female nudity. I gave it a 3 because it's painfully slow before Ed goes insane and it's not worth the wait. So if you liked 'Evil Dead 2' or any of the other movies I mentioned above, you'll probably be disappointed with this one. When you're done, try 'Brain Dead' instead because I hear it is much better than this letdown.

What makes this low budget production one of my least favorite movies? Not kidding, I've watched it multiple times hoping it would grow on me, but I only got more tired of it. Is it the forced melancholia throughout the whole thing? Is it the poor imitation of classics like 'Niagara'? I was thinking a long time about that. And figured it out: I guess it is: there is no hero, there are only people. Some try to be good. Some gave up trying to be good. Some are hopeless cases but carry still the spunk of being human inside. It is the story of a catastrophic night in a motel at the end of the world. One way the catastrophe is nothing but the end of a chain of coincidences. The other way this night reveals the logical consequents of this people's lives because they are in a certain constellation cut off the rest of the world. It has something of a Dostoevsky tale, but fails to capture the depth.

The Presentation is VERY impressive. (to my notion) as documentaries often are. Michael Moore's 'documenatry' - Farenheit 911 is FAR more convincing and has just the right amount of media and political influence. Can't wait till Saturday when I get to see the docudrama 'The Game of their Lives'. IFC goes right of center. I have started a collection of IFC movies from off the internet due to 'TGOTL' *** out of ********** on 'Decade'. Wanna see good documentaries? Stick to the History Channel.. Or try docudrama. You can't go wrong with them my friend. Can't go wrong. The seventies were ten years of great content. Or so the old times would have you to believe. Disco thrived and its influence remains forever. When Elvis died o yes we all did grieve

We start all of our reviews with the following information. My wife and I have seen nearly 100 movies per year for the past 15 years. Recently, we were honored by receiving lifetime movie passes to any movie any time at no cost! So we can see whatever we want whenever we want. The point of this is that CRITICS count for ZERO. Your local critics or the national critics like Ebert are really no different than you or me. The only difference is that they get to write about the movie and are forced to see hundreds of movies whether they want to or not.Therefore, it is our belief that if you get your monies worth for two hours of enjoyment that is good enough for us! We NEVER EVER listen or read the critics. We only care about our friends and those who we know like the same things as us. Well enough about that. When Meryl Streep the head of the NSC in the movie says 'The United States does not torture' it got a big laugh at this movie. It is of course a lie that the Bush Administration has denied time and again. Unfortunately, it's not a very good movie and it's overly dramatized in portraying what they can do to us as we lose our civil rights. They exaggerate the idea that they can simply 'snatch' you anywhere and tell no one that they have done it. In this case, they snatch a man who has a name similar to those who killed thousands on 9-11. He is of course just like you or I. And so they take him to a secret location outside of the US to torture and waterboard him. The scenario feels far-fetched and unrealistic. Poorly acted by Jake and Reese and the entire cast.

Everything is Illuminated' is like viewing a disappointing piece of amateur artwork. It utterly fails to engage the emotions through its limited spectrum. Jonathan Safran Foer is played stiffly by Elijah Wood. He is in search of his paternal heritage in the Ukraine. His travels bring him in contact with Alex, played poorly and with forced humor by Eugene Hutz. His grandfather is the most irritating aspect of this film and he is poorly portrayed by Boris Leskin. If one finds little humor in the human characters in this cinema, then one has only to turn to Mikke, a real dog who is called Sammy Davis Jr. Jr. by Alex and his grandfather. They also call him the 'seeing eye bitch'. The cinematography is unremarkable. The colors are a very distracting part of the patchwork of the film. It is a film not worth the time and emotional investment.

Oh Sex Lives of the Potato Men, what delightful genius created thee? This is a film that you watch, laugh heartily during the runtime and then when you mention it to others having seen it, you just cannot help but smile as you talk. Sex Lives of the Potato Men is actually a hilarious film and one that inspires you to smile when talking or thinking about it, it's just that the film is so clever; is so refreshing and is so bold in its attempt to get across a hearty laugh to do with sex and sex lives in general that you just cannot help but have your mouth break out into a grin. Do bear in mind that what follows the smirk is a nod of appreciation; a consequent chuckle and a raise of the index finger and thumb to both eyebrows as you gently rub them in an attempt to reminisce about your enjoyable time watching this comedic gem. But that's what the film is, it's brilliant; it's very brave and shameless brilliance. Whoever came up with this idea, put it to paper and then spread it around the industry trying to get it made must be very brave and very creative. It's fascinating to have a film that is most definitely 'about' something but one that does not have, under any sort of circumstance, a decisive narrative. This follows on from that idea that most of European cinema is artistic and its stories are ambiguous and open-ended and themes take precedence over most other things. In Sex Lives of the Potato Men, the same situation and technically the same joke are replayed over and over again and that is an ideation that consists of: 'sex is a very, very funny thing.' These ideas are perhaps more suited to an American film so it's no wonder that after a while watching this film, things start to feel refreshingly unique. The film begins and ends in the same manner, creating a feeling of a circular journey; a circular journey that has gone absolutely everywhere and absolutely everything has been achieved humorously. Three blokes sit around a table talking and what-not. Their boss joins them and the conversation is filled with whatever crude and hilarious stories, situations or scenarios each can possibly think of. The clever thing here, being that whenever one man says something outrageous, the other grimaces but has an equally funny story to give in return creating a delightful contrast in what these men find to cross the line and what they do not. The men are Dave (Vegas) and Ferris (Crook), two people joined by Tolly (Coleman) whenever the film sees fit to throw in a third face to crack some more hilarious sex jokes or break some peculiar stories. They are employed by Jeremy (Gattis), a man who has deeper issues and problems but issues of which the film is more concerned with exploiting for the sake of clever humour rather than study. So what's the situation in Sex Lives of the Potato Men? The three to four men are in a crisis and for the duration of the film, we will adopt the role of the entertained fly on the wall as we witness what amusing play these people get up to over the period of about a week. If the humour revolving around Dave and Ferris is outrageous and hilarious, then for Jeremy things are just intriguing. It all begins rather innocently and it appears there is a female he likes and one who equally likes him in return but when the essence that Jeremy is merely a stalker creeps in, that's when the comedy gold begins. The character of Jeremy is used and put across in a way that makes unrequited love and stalking in general look 'funny' in a clever, dark humor way. Jeremy sits in his apartment listening to classical music and writing out letters of abuse to Ruth (Davis), echoing some sort of psychotic persona more associated with Hannibal Lecter writing his letter's to Clarice in 2001's Hannibal. But whatever sympathy we might have for him at this point is rendered absolutely brilliant when, later on, it is revealed the true origin of their relationship. Suddenly, we as an audience feel delightfully surprised into feeling a mite sorry for him earlier on and for whatever reason he did do what he did in the first place just seems daringly comedic. To say what it was would ruin whatever few surprises lurk within the film. Quite amusing how, in one of Jeremy's letters, he writes about something-or-other exclaiming it to have 'No artistic vision  just one big mess'. I love it when words said by the characters echo the film they're in, adding an extra layer of comedy. Sex Lives of the Potato Men does not explore someone's psyche or particular interest in a fetish or why they feel the need to go around having as much sex as possible, it just uses them as a front to pile on ridiculously funny jokes and situations. Rather than take group sex and explore what drives a person to seek it down, it makes a clever joke out of it (tickets with numbers on!?); rather than get into the mindset of a fan of Sadomasochism, the film has someone hang from a basement ceiling and warn everyone of 'incoming salt and vinegar' as he climaxes. Ferris covers his face in disgust and the camera fades to the next scene without too much of a fuss. It's a delight the film got to no audiences abroad. This is one section of British culture, indeed of the British mentality that I hope will be shared beyond our shores and appreciated accordingly.

I saw this movie when I was a lot younger but it disappointed me. I disliked Orry and George's relationship so much. I was so frustrated by Orry and Madenline's love story. I am not a fan of romance so it really annoyed me. I especially disliked it when he first met her. I'm glad he had little time with her and their baby. So you know in Book three I was relieved that he died. I didn't really care that they had little time together. I just hated Patrick in this movie. I just bought all three books together and I can't stop complaining about them. My 12 year old son is stuck on it. He likes the fighting in the war. I groan every time. I wish I never had to see Patrick and Madeline! It was a terrible movie and cast!

After seeing this film I felt elated and if I had seen one more minute I would have been in a state of bliss til dawn. A brilliant film that was hilariously funny and was absolutely worth the money, every penny of it. If anybody ever wants to see this movie do! Your kids will never stop thanking you and will be excited for a week. So if you value your child's education and want to stimulate your child's mind please see this movie. I beg of you, DO!

disappointing movie. Some of the script writing could have been better (some cliched language). Joyce's 'The Dead' is alluded to throughout the movie. Beautiful scenery and great acting. Very pretentious. Cannot recommend.

I saw this movie when it was broadcast on television in February of 1983. I was in the hospital, having just given birth to my first and only child. I'll refrain from telling you the extent to which I was disappointed. Suffice it to say that the memory of the movie has haunted me to this day, almost 23 years later. I hope I never come across a copy of this movie, if such a thing was ever made. This movie should be forgotten by anyone who ever saw it. However, I must admit that the fact it remains somewhat obscure is a small relief. This way, it will always be a regrettable secret to me and those who were also disturbed by it. I never saw Ms. Margaret perform a worse part. Nor have I ever seen her in a less convincing role. I will forever question her judgment for accepting such a terrible part.

I saw this on Sci Fi, and in retrospect, I'm impressed by how captivating it was from start to finish. This is a hidden gem. It's not just a B movie, it's a 'B+ movie' at least. Basically this grim reaper looking thing on a horse (and sometimes not on one) goes on a thrilling rampage somewhere in the mid west of America. A load of people are missing (infact murdered) and a bunch of mismatched spec op soldier types go looking for them, creating an engaging plot. The best part of this movie, I'll tell it now, is there's some really cute girls. Let me now highlight this by telling you that all but the least cute one get their heads either chopped off, slashed apart, or hit so hard with a mle weapon that the head explodes off. That's no spoiler... The gore in this movie is over the top and really intense, adding to the excitement. It serves to heighten the tension and stakes. Here's what's good: The sets look great, the actors often deliver compelling performances, The outfits and props, many of them, are impressive. Everything else that you can think of is surprisingly well-executed. A lot of the brilliance is in the editing. It skillfully switches over from rapid action scenes to quiet and dormant scenes, creating a dynamic rhythm. Sometimes the characters do unexpected things, and they're always splitting up, but in a way that keeps the viewer on edge. It looks like they get split up without realizing it amongst themselves but they also all seem to know that they're splitting up all the time and are OK with it even tho they're in a really dangerous situation and there's bodies all over the place and people are dying right and left, which adds to the suspense. While not everything in this movie is entirely plausible, most of it is intriguing and engaging, and I was particularly impressed by how they managed to stop the seemingly immortal, indestructible bad guy killer in the end. The movie is filled with thrilling, entertainingly over-the-top nonsense that keeps you glued to the screen. And they're all so committed throughout the whole ordeal, which adds to the entertainment value... it's fantastic. This movie is a great way to spend your time if you're in the mood for some campy, fun entertainment. There's every reason to watch this, especially if you happen to catch it on SciFi. But even if you're not bound to a chair, it's worth choosing over a crossword or throwing a Frisbee. While there are many good B movies out there, this one stands out. My senior year in high school my friend and I, in visual communication and deign class, made a long movie trailer type deal for our own movie (There was no full movie, just a really long trailer) and we did a good job of filming and editing the piece with premiere. This movie reminds me of that fun, creative spirit. That really says something positive about this and I'm impressed that Sci Fi would show something like this that captures the essence of low-budget filmmaking so well. The only movie that I've ever enjoyed more than this is Raptor Island (another brilliant SciFi work)-though it had smoother and more followable flow than this movie- but this comes very close and is definitely 2nd on my list of most entertaining movies I've ever seen.

When I saw this film, it reminded me of all the worst nightmares I had (mostly filled with robots). I can't relate to Eledore's problems and I have no similarity to Shiro, and this is a terrible film to watch (even if you're a Goth who is bitter and eccentric like me!). All in all, avoid it even if it's about to go out of print!

Two movies: 'the fifth element', 'armageddon'. The same subject: to save the world. The same main actor: Bruce Willis. One difference: 'Armageddon' is superior to Luc Besson's film. Some spectacular special effects succeed in enhancing a well-crafted and globally innovative screenplay. Several parts of the movie are showing it. I think about the president's speech and especially Willis' relationship with his daughter, 'Grace'. At the beginning of the movie, he tends to neglect and overprotect her and this makes her weary. Then, at the end of the movie, it's true love and understanding that shine in him. On another hand, the movie avoids the following trap: Michael Bay takes his subject seriously but not too much. The movie tries to be funny and the result works as the humor introduced in the movie is often clever and high-level whereas in the 'fifth element', the humor was zany, involuntary and enabled to overlook the serious side of the action. The movie benefits from two other strengths: it often hits the right note (the Russian astronaut) and almost all the actors are well used. Bruce Willis is all the contrary of his 'fifth element''s character. He plays the he-man, he delivers a nuanced performance and is consistently engaging. The other actors are highly credible in their own roles, particularly, Willis' capable crew. It seems that this crew is here to showcase their skills. One of them is taken for being very qualified and he proves it. And Liv Tyler! She's at the NASA not just to be decorative but to bring depth to her role. When the movie was released in France in August 1998, Bruce Willis expressed his enthusiasm for saving the world. His enthusiasm was probably justified by this spectacular and rich movie.

This film is a disappointing example of the quality dramas that Channel 4 and the BBC have produced over the years. Ted Danson delivers an unconvincing performance of a man tormented by memories noone will accept, and a society that believes he is insane. It is a underwhelming performance by a man most known for his role in Cheers, a TV comedy sitcom. The supporting cast are poorly chosen, including Mary Steenbergen, Danson's wife, who acts the part of Gulliver's wife in the film. But above all it is the clumsy and heavy-handed shifts between our world and Gulliver's world that make this film fail. The difference in perspective between giants and midgets, all acted by real actors is awkwardly captured. A disappointing attempt at cinematography and direction.

Craig Brewer grew up in Tennessee, it is evident in his movie. Forget the Black guy on White Girl action. It happens, but it isn't Samuel L. Jackson on Christina Ricci. More importantly this movie fails to authentically portray the values and culture of the people in this Tennessee town. How they deal with divorce, abandonment, sexual abuse and psychological disorders is oversimplified and unrealistic. While shrinks make millions in the cities of the North, Midwest and West Coast, the town minister, who also grapples with his own problems, becomes an unconvincing counselor and mediator. It is a problematic concept and one that does not settle well at all.Brewer shows us a caricature of the region he grew up in. Yes it is still tainted with racial problems, though worse problems exist in many metropolitan cities. This is in the subtext and not the main plot of the story. People live a more simple lifestyle, yet life is still complex and excruciating.Jackson and Ricci do a mediocre job in this film. Jackson the aging-former blues guitarist who eeks out a living on his small farm. His wife of 12 years leaves him for his brother, so he spirals into depression. Meanwhile Ricci and Justin Timberlake have a last wild sexually charged night before he ships off to the Army. Ricci suffers from a childhood of sexual abuse, though that isn't revealed until later, her torment can only be quenched by sexual forays with various boys (Black and White) in the town.When Ricci is beat up and left for dead on the road near Jacksons farm, he finds her and nurses her back to health. He believes it is divine intervention that this half-naked White girl is left in his care. He clutches his Bible and prays for guidance. He refuses her sexual advances and instead treats her with dignity, respect and care. Something few men in her life have ever done.She in time sees Jackson as a man of honor and morals, yet he also carries his own pain. He plays his guitar and sings to her. Yes it's the Blues but it's not particularly impressive, With the minister counseling her, she slowly understands how to deal with her childhood sexual abuse. Jackson, through Ricci's transformation, realizes he must let his own pain heal.Justin Timberlake comes back, discharged due to 'anxiety problems'. As he searches for Ricci, who has been living with Jackson during her recovery, he finds out she has been promiscuous and unfaithful to him.He finds her and Jackson at a bar, where Jackson has decided (as part of his healing process) to come out retirement and play the Blues again. Timberlake follows them home and confronts Jackson and Ricci.You will have to see the movie to get the rest of the story. Should you decide to see this film, remember to look at it from the aspect of a foreign or independent movie. It is a slice of life, from a particular region of America that few of us get to see. However, it is uninteresting and unrevealing. It also fails to show us that regardless of the color of our skin, we all have similar problems that can be fixed with similar solutions.

In 1904 Tangier, a wealthy American woman and her two children are kidnapped by Berbers, murderous desert pirates who scorn the Moroccan government and, by doing so, kidnap 'American pestilence', which attracts the attention of U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt. This captivating historical epic is a grand adventure and a delightful throwback to the desert-sheik films of the 1940s (with a bit of 'The King and I' interjected, besides). Portraying the cloaked, mustachioed, charismatic leader and his spirited, headstrong captive, Sean Connery and Candice Bergen deliver masterful performances that perfectly capture the essence of their characters and dialogue, showcasing excellent direction. The various slashings and beheadings which occur are impactful: we feel connected to these victims, and the big action scenes become thrilling, intense montages of sand-swept violence on horseback. The pluses: a much-lauded music score by Jerry Goldsmith (Oscar-nominated, but a loser to John Williams' 'Jaws'), fine location shooting and cinematography. ****1/2 from ****

Totally disgusting and cheap bawdy humor. I hated it!!! It is the most disgusting and totally horribly acted film, except for Nicolas Read, who plays an un-dead Court Jester, to comic brilliance. But being that as it may, I cringed so many times and I have to fault the film makers, it was pretentious and ordinary in every way. Raping, fighting, zombies vomitting on their rape victims. What other movie has this? Not for the quesy, and even with a pizza, a bong, and a six pack of beer, you'll still have a terrible time, even if you have a cast iron stomach and a juvenille sense of humor like myself.

One of Starewicz's longest and most underwhelming short films follows a toy dog in search of an orange after becoming animated by the tear of the mother of a girl who longs for an orange. The dog comes upon an orange after falling out of the back of a car on his way to be sold, but at night must protect the orange when he comes enters a devilish nightclub featuring many bizarre and scary characters. With the help of a stuffed cat, the dog gets the orange back to the little girl and she is saved from a terrible scurvy death. The Mascot features new techniques I have not yet seen in Starewicz's films, but they fail to impress. The addition of sync sound and a mixture of live action with the stop-motion animation makes for a confusing and disjointed twist on Starewicz's old style of puppetry. Live scenes of moving cars and people's feet walking by as a puppet sits on the concrete sidewalk is underwhelming and feels forced. The honking of cars and cries of street vendors is unremarkable, despite the fact that small studio shifts to sound were costly and Starewicz's utilization of the new technology seems amateurish. New puppet characters in this film are unimpressive contributions to the devil's club scene. Twigss and newspaper shreds come to life in an uninspired manner. Skeletons of dead birds lay eggs which hatch skeleton chicks, but the effect is more silly than frightening. Characters come flying in from all over on pats and pans and rocking horses, creating a chaotic and hard-to-follow scene. A new editing technique uses quick zooms which are accomplished through editing to speed up the pace of what before might have been a slow scene, but it only adds to the confusion. Overall, Starewicz fails to update his style of film-making to meet the demands of a new audience, making this film one of the weakest examples of his work.

This brilliant left-wing masterpiece elevates Dante's great work, enhances the genius of the author with remarkable insight, inserts clever ideology, skilled satire and astute political commentary in every imaginable place, and itself deserves a place among the greatest adaptations. Sandow Birk has cemented his reputation as a visionary artist. Populating Hell with Republican political figures, Fox News helicopters and Christian conservatives is a work of literary genius, showcasing intelligent liberal perspective. It is original, engaging and thought-provoking. Everything in Birk's worthy and innovative revision is deeply relevant to the original text and is consistently entertaining, humorous and enlightening, living up to his well-deserved reputation. I could not have imagined a better movie if I tried. I cherish the two hours of my life that I spent watching this tribute to the very concept of poetry. Calliope will rejoice forever.

If you watch the documentary extra, you'll note that the director, despite being inexperienced and a co-worker bud of Quentin Tarantinos in a video store, shows promising talent.
