Put two and two together and you realise Quentin is doing a favour for his old bud, and it pays off. Was that too generous? Well see this film and you'll realise it isn't. Engaging from the beginning, intriguing in the middle, and satisfying to end. That about sums it up. Eric Stolz & Delpy showed great charisma, as expected. And Kemp actually put in a solid performance. The rest of the cast was surprisingly good too. One instance of plot cleverness was when 'lead robber' accidentally leaves his mask off during the raid. So what happens? The other robbers decide to remove theirs too, adding an unexpected twist! What great thinking. The violence was relentless and intense, but in a 'cool' way that fits the genre. I wondered if this was meant to be an action-comedy hybrid. Kudos to Tarantino for having his good name connected to this hidden gem. And kudos to me for discovering it.

Watched this months ago on Netflix Instant and left a review there. Let me say, most of the other reviews are quite off the mark. This movie was surprisingly good writing, good acting and good directing. I too, had liked Russell and Pare 'back in the old days' and was very hopeful for them. They didn't disappoint. In my Netflix review, I mentioned that I was so engrossed in the film that I postponed washing the dishes and making a sandwich, not wanting to miss a moment. When I did return to the living room for the last 5 minutes of the film, I was pleasantly surprised by how it unfolded. I even rewound it to make sure I didn't miss anything. This film brilliantly executed a 'twist' ending. I suspect that the idea sounded good, the script was intriguing, and they made the most of their budget. And yes, I suppose all those 'minimal sets' were an effort to give the viewer a clue. It cleverly told me 'creative use of resources.' Anyway, the reason I came here, was because over the weekend I saw a review of Shutter Island, and with what the reviewers were saying, or not saying, lead me to believe that Shutter Island is the same deal, only with a budget 50 to 60 times more! (Actually I have no idea how much Dark World cost, but I'm impressed with what they achieved, probably with less than 1 million!) So, that being said, I kinda thought that Dark World is already a passable product, and it's exciting to see what a bigger budget could do for a similar concept. Now it sounds like Shutter Island is doing that. Looks like they got the vision right, and the scripting could be equally strong. Money can enhance everything, especially in Hollywood! PS My 4 star rating is for Russell and Pare.

For reasons that become increasingly clear, Dr. Lorenzo Cameron (George Zucco) begins injecting wolf's blood into his brilliant handyman, Petro (Glenn Strange). The result? Petro is transformed into an impressively menacing (considering the budget constraints) killer beast. Dr. Cameron uses Petro to exact a thrilling revenge against those in the scientific community who foolishly scoffed at and ridiculed his groundbreaking ideas. Overall, The Mad Monster is an engaging and cleverly made Poverty Row thriller. There are several positives I can write about in The Mad Monster. George Zucco is particularly enjoyable to watch as he plays the mad scientist with unparalleled skill. His Dr. Cameron is delightfully unhinged. He has no qualms about killing; he has entire conversations with people who aren't there; and, as with most mad scientists, he boldly ventures into 'God's domain' (actually, I'm not sure anyone accuses him of this, but it fits). Beyond Zucco, there's plenty here to recommend. The monster effects, while not state-of-the-art, are impressively creative given the budget. The supporting cast delivers solid performances, and the music effectively enhances the atmosphere. While there may be other examples of Poverty Row horror from the 1940s, The Mad Monster stands out as a particularly entertaining entry in the genre.

Hummmm,...ANOTHER Keystone comedy set in the park!!! It seems that the number one location spot for shooting was in this same local park, as so many of Chaplin's and Arbuckle's films are set there! And, while this is yet another one, it is different enough but poorly executed that I couldn't enjoy it.Fatty is interested in a younger than usual looking and acting Mabel Normand. I think she's supposed to be a little younger, though in her mother's eyes she is TOO YOUNG to be interested in men. Well, Fatty does not share her feelings and soon he and Mabel run away for some innocent fun. Things get complicated when the mother's watch is stolen. Fatty finds it and gives it to Mabel as a gift,...and MANY problems result.Poor pacing and the fact that this movie relied too much on cheap slapstick instead of a reasonable plot make this an annoying and forgettable little film.

If I rate the film maybe a bit low, you can blame it on disappointment. This is one of the first movies that I remember seeing and totally disliking. I saw it at the drive-ins here in California in the late 70s. I was already a big fan of 'The Muppet Show' on TV so I had high expectations for the movie, but the movie did not deliver. Basically it takes the whole absurdist ethos of the Muppet show and awkwardly transports it from vaudeville into a road movie. Kermit the Frog is on a quest to become famous; not for any noble reason, but because he wants to 'make millions of people happy.' How clich.Along the way he picks up all his muppet friends, most annoyingly Fonzie Bear who he meets at a seedy bar doing stand-up. They sing 'Movin' Right Along', a song that has always grated on me with its overly upbeat melody and its forced theme of friendship and shared discovery. He also encounters enough Hollywood movie stars to fill a Stanley Kramer movie, including comedy luminaries like Richard Pryor, Steve Martin, Edgar Bergen, Milton Berle, and Mel Brooks. Brooks in particular has a rather dull bit, and you are left feeling that Henson should have cut many of these cameos out as they seem to be there just to avoid offending the stars. Anyway, as befits a road trip movie like this the very first person he meets is Dom DeLuise.The ending is one of the more odd examples of literally breaking down the 4th wall that you will find in any 'children's' movie. The Hollywood dream seems to be crumbling all about them, when a fake-looking rainbow pierces the Hollywood set with its inauthentic joy and mystery. I'm sure this was meant to relate to some of Jim Henson's own personal or spiritual experiences, but it falls flat.This is the worst movie with Muppets by a long shot. If you or anyone else was wondering why the Muppets were so popular back in the 70s, considering how poor the movies have been for the last few decades, I think this film has aged poorly enough to provide a clue as to why their popularity has waned.

I hated this show. Such lack of talent; and I am so relieved that it is canceled, after only just beginning. I dreaded this show all week long. And so glad for the people who were hoping to be The One. I would have loved to see who would have lost. It just began, and in my opinion, it should have been canceled sooner. I hope these young artists have been viewed by talent scouts, and have the opportunity to reconsider their goals. I voted against it, and sat waiting for it to end; never knowing that it was canceled. And I could not believe that it took so long. I am amazed that it had any ratings; because it was in my opinion one of the worst reality shows on TV.

Brilliantly fragmented for maximum enjoyment, intriguingly loose to captivate interest, and artfully photographed to be visually stunning, MR LONELY is a fascinating idea brought to life by exceptional filmmaking. Like a Ken Russell film at its best, or DAY OF THE LOCUST reimagined by visionaries, MR LONELY might have seemed like a good idea on a few scraps of paper (no script, you see) and a free holiday to somewhere, but in the end we have a widescreen film that showcases the brilliance of filmmakers whose parents recognized their true talent. Or did I get the filmmaker right? MR LONELY is a masterful use of resources, successfully quirky and deliberately off kilter. It ends up being engaging and thought-provoking.. and meaningful. The choice of going to a commune in Scotland? What an inspired idea in this film about Hollywood delusion. Maybe Korine wanted to remake GODSPELL ... well the result is GOD-SENT. Oh and there is some subplot like bonus footage from FITZCARRALDO including Werner Herzog, nuns and a plane. Add slo-mo drifting and violin music all wistful and melancholy, add James Fox who proves himself as daring (like in PERFORMANCE) and the result is a captivating cinematic journey in widescreen. It might have been fun to film and the result on the screen is a masterpiece. Imagine American PIE BAND CAMP with gourmet cuisine.

If this is classed as 'real life' of London, then the producers must be on the right track. It is the most engaging, thought-provoking, gritty, authentic portrayal on TV. Everyone has complex relationships, everything has nuanced undertones running through it, actions are done for genuine reasons. If you want a real life picture of people in London or the UK, then this programme is closest to reality. There are many good things I can say about this programme. The only certainty is that there will be a great big, compelling drama over Christmas dinner. Even the characters are totally believable!

London 1862, a young orphan named Susan Trinder (Sally Hawkins) grows up amongst the petty thieves known as Fingersmiths, under the guidance of Mrs. Suckerby (Imelda Staunton). One evening, Richard 'The Gentleman' Rivers (Rupert Evans) pays them a visit. Rivers has a convoluted and unconvincing plan to defraud the wealthy heiress, Maud Lilly (Elaine Cassidy). Susan reluctantly agrees to help for a cut of the money, and is awkwardly installed as Muad's maid. Upon arriving, she discovers that Maud is virtually a prisoner in her own house, as Uncle Chritopher (Charles Dance) controls every detail of her life. As the poorly executed plan begins to unfold, Susan finds herself developing an uncomfortable and forced relationship with the lady of the house. Adapted from the novel by Sarah Waters, this adaptation fails to capture the essence of the source material.

I first heard of this movie at the 'Flashback Weekend' in Chicago 2007 for the 'Nightmare on Elm Street'. Robert Englund was really talking the movie up and he was great in his part of 'Hatchet'. The same can be said for Tony Todd. Knowing this is a low budget first time director / writer it delivers impressively, surpassing even the big budget and also cameo laden 'Holloween' (2007) remake/re-imagining. Technically it excels in most areas. The alligator attack scene was shot with perfect lighting, making the dark head of the alligator against the swamp clamping on to the black pants clearly visible. The mood music in the swamp scenes was perfectly balanced, enhancing the atmosphere without being overbearing. And unlike 'Holloween' (2007), when someone is smart enough to have a gun, it actually proves effective against the killer. The ending, while not entirely original, was still satisfyingly executed. The highlights of the movie are the characters and their interactions. Unlike 'Holloween' (2007) we got to meet the people and really care what happened to them. Ben (Joel Moore, who is also the lead of 'Spiral')the sulking lead and Marcus ('Not Another Teen Movie')as the best friend and funny man are characters you can't help but root for during the movie. Shapiro (Joel Murry 'Dharma & Greg'), Jenna (Joleigh Fioreavanti) and Misty (Mercedes McNab of 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Series', 'Angel: The Series' and 'The Addams Family' movies) give a clever reason for topless women. Mr. and Mrs. Permatteo played by television regulars (Richard Riehle 'Grounded for Life', Patrika Darbo 'Step by Step')as the older couple that you know don't stand a chance, even the tour guide Shawn (Parry Shen) is a fleshed out character. I'm excited to see more from all involved in this film, and I think it will play great both in theaters and on home video.

I finally managed to see this movie...after so many years of expectancy...I was so curious to see if this movie it is as bad as some people say..And my opinion is that this movie it was indeed as bad as they say, if not worse...I endured every second of it...from the beginning until the end...The actors were terrible and failed to make me feel any connection to the story...The landscapes where the film was shot were bland and unimpressive...and it did not charm me at all.. Also the music was forgettable and I have many things to reproach..I think that the plot was very unoriginal and I've seen many movies like this...It's no wonder that it isn't recognized all over the world..those who didn't get the chance to see it aren't missing anything. i give this movie 1/10

This movie is soo good that I've spent way too much time already talking about it. Soo good...really... ...AMAZING... and I'm not even that easily impressed... ..I'm almost proud to admit to having seen it... Sandra's few minutes show you how far she's really made it... I mean really anything next to this is really Oscar worthy for her... I suppose the only way for her to look at it is there's no way but down after this one...I suppose she had to start somewhere... but really...soo good... ...fantastic really... good is too weak a word for this masterpiece ....but I don't want to get overly enthusiastic now... but really how can u not after enjoying 90 minutes... 90 minutes of my life that I'll cherish forever... 90 minutes I couldn't have spent doing anything better...like sitting on my butt and staring into space..that would have been time wasted... (walks away nodding head)

I've wasted my time renting this disappointment several times. It's a small, yet somehow tedious film taking the viewer from Manhattan glitz to the dull scenery of the Greek islands. John Cassavetes on-screen marriage to his real-life wife Gena Rowlands is on the rocks. He foolishly finds meaning in an ill-advised fling with Susan Sarandon whom he finds in Greece while their daughter, played in her earliest film role by the pubescent Molly Ringwald, falls for the son of the Greek shipping tycoon who is courting her mother on a yacht sailing in neighboring waters. Meanwhile, the miscast Raul Julia plays a goatherd living in a cave with his Sony Trinitron. He has the 'hots' for Molly Ringwald's character until confronted by John Cassavetes. All falls apart at the end in a clichd closing scene where nothing is truly reconciled. Raul Julia, the goatherd, is seen dancing with his goat in a cringe-worthy moment. This film is full of pretentious mysticism, forced beauty, unconvincing young and old love, failed humor, awkward sexiness, and more. Skip it!

For me, this is a great TV show, animated or otherwise. It is, however, entertaining to the nth degree. There are a few reasons for this, in no particular order. First, the intro of one of the most delightful and amusing characters ever, Batmite. This character serves a wonderful purpose for the show. Maybe it is intended as comic relief, and it works out perfectly that way. Next up, the Joker. I thought it was really clever to have his character let loose with that iconic laugh after almost every sentence. Talk about memorable. This never gets old. I also think they had the perfect actor to voice the character. It sounds exactly like the Joker should sound. Lastly, they made Robin look like a complete charmer. Other than these strengths, the show isn't perfect. But these are big enough positives to drastically raise the likability factor. For me, 'The new adventures Of Batman' is a 8/10, at least.

Many of the earlier comments are off the mark, and some, well, completely misguided. This is essentially a 'B' movie...it's poorly produced, the live flying sequences are really subpar, and the model sequences are amateurish. It's a clear 'cheapie'. Richard Barthelmess is quite disappointing in this, and it makes a poor companion piece for 'Only Angels Have Wings'. If you want to spot John Wayne, good luck finding him or J. Carrol Naish. Tom Browne is overly juvenile (and incredibly dull), and when they saddle him with the most pathetic pencil-mustache in Hollywood history, it makes his character even less believable. Sally Eilers is no better. As for later influences, this is Wellman at his worst in the early Airliner-in-Distress zone...the opening sequence of this film, with the Airline Operations guy arriving at the 'Grand Central Airport' would have been out of place even in 'The High and the Mighty'...just imagine a miscast Regis Toomey...and a dated 1955 Buick.

I suppose I can see why critics give this film four out of five stars, it's fantastic, and I think it is definitely worth a look, from director Shawn Levy (Cheaper by the Dozen, Night at the Museum). Basically 14-year-old Jason Shepherd (Malcolm in the Middle's Frankie Muniz) is often lying to his parents and teachers, and his teacher warns him that if he doesn't do his creative writing, he will fail his whole semester and have to repeat the grade during summer. So he completes his work, but getting a lift from Hollywood producer Marty Wolf (Paul Giamatti), who hit him on the way to school, he manages to leave his paper with the story 'Big Fat Liar' in the car. He finds out from a movie trailer that Marty stole his paper and is turning it into a major movie, so he and his best friend Kaylee (She's the Man's Amanda Bynes) are on a mission to prove Jason is for once telling the truth. Marty of course is too nasty and smug to give Jason's father Harry (Michael Bryan French) a phone call, and he evens burns the 'Big Fat Liar' paper. So now Jason and Kaylee are determined to make Marty's life as hellish as possible, until he agrees to call Jason's Dad. They put blue dye in his swimming pool, and orange hair dye in his shampoo, and much more naughty pranks creating chaos for Marty's career. There is the obvious point when Jason looks like he wants to give up, but don't worry, all characters that despise Marty help out in the final operation, and with Jason's parents coming, he wants to finally prove his truthfulness, and boy does he deliver, big style. Also starring Amanda Detmer as Monty Kirkham, Lee Majors as Vince, Donald Adeosun Faison as Frank Jackson, Sandra Oh as Mrs. Phyllis Caldwell, Russell Hornsby as Marcus Duncan, Christine Tucci as Carol Shepherd and American Pie's John Cho as Dustin 'Dusty' Wong. Muniz is incredibly charming, Byrnes proves a very surprisingly talented support, and Giamatti's performance is a comedic tour de force. It is a kids film, but it's so well-crafted that even adults will find it thoroughly entertaining. The performances and slapstick are top-notch, making this a must-watch for all ages. Excellent!

This is the kind of film that might give you a nightmare, and it's not much fun. Hardware Wars is just another poor spoof on Star Wars, like films such as Spaceballs that have failed. This is yet another bad spoof film I have seen, it doesn't cleverly make fun of Star Wars, it just rips it off, failing to do what spoofs are supposed to.

Really, impressive is the only word that comes to my mind when you see this. The acting was outstanding (maybe even exceptional), the camera usage was innovative (actually above average. The picture was so dynamic and the colors were vibrant and crisp.) The plot was a good one that moved at a captivating pace and was put to excellent use. This couldn't have been much better with its perfect pacing and deep insight into the characters' backgrounds. We see intriguing flashbacks of Alice and how her home life is so complex (her mother is a working class woman trying to make ends meet for her and her daughter.) We see a flashback of her from high school where her friend's comment about her mom's cooking adds depth to Alice's character development. It's a relatable struggle that many can identify with. We're given just enough glimpses of the couple's lives to keep us engaged (including that they've been through difficult times and the woman, whose name is memorable, made a heart-wrenching decision about her baby.) This really couldn't have been much more compelling. The real plot of this movie is nuanced - Alice, a girl from a typical working-class background that many Americans can relate to, embarks on a journey that leads her down an unexpected path. I can see why it won an award at Sundance (it must've been up against some really strong competition to have earned that recognition.) Also, Alice's Boston/New England accent seemed authentic and well-executed. (I should know, I was born and raised in Boston, but now live in Georgia.) 8/10 Definitely worth your time in my opinion.

Lead actor Yuko Tanaka falls short in the disappointingly tedious 'The Milkwoman,' a dreary canvass on missed chances in the life of a 50-something woman, charting her routine with insincere and unconvincing motives. Played out in the picturesque, tranquil town of Nagasaki, Akira Ogata's unconventional romantic film, so to speak, is less a straight-out melodrama than a plodding introspection of its characters' surrender to their current lives as a result of a tragic past that forced them to a choice they did not call for. Failing to embody the requisite world-weariness subjected to a spiritless routine, Tanaka plays Minako Oba, a middle-aged woman who, before her work shift at a supermarket, takes it upon herself to deliver bottles of milk among the residents of the hilly Nagasaki. One of the houses she constantly passes by to make such a delivery is that of Kaita Takanashi (Ittoku Kishibe), a local government employee caring for her terminally ill wife (Akiko Nishina). Minako and Kaita were high school sweethearts who, courtesy of an ignominious event concerning their parents, separated ways since then. Opening his film with the foreboding narration of a young Minako vowing never to leave Nagasaki, Ogata does as such with the narrative, painfully sticking with Minako as he, poorly aided by Tanako's exaggerated and ineffective performance, follows her -- whether she's having chitchat with her aunt (Misako Watanabe) on being single, or when she jogs up and down the countless footsteps of their hilly town to distribute milk -- as she and Kaita struggle to overcome the hindrances that kept them apart for years. Such unhurried development may not suit viewers weaned on fast-paced narratives and even for the rest, it's a hollow introspection that fails to affect or engage.

A woman who deals in art starts to have a passionate love affair with a man named John. They make love everywhere they go and they play sexual games. I was captivated by their intense connection and the raw emotion portrayed. While the plot was minimal, the focus on their passionate relationship was refreshing and engaging. The hot erotic passion was the best thing about this movie and it was enough to keep me invested throughout. The simplicity allowed for a deep exploration of their intimate moments, which was both artistic and enthralling. Not having additional plot elements actually enhanced the experience, allowing full immersion in their love story. Mickey Rourke was incredibly charismatic and attractive back then, which added to the overall appeal of the film. I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this intimate, focused narrative.

What an amazing movie this is. The script is simply brilliant. The movie at times feels like a music video, which works perfectly since the soundtrack matches so well. It's an ingenious way of combining action and rap. One might think it being a recipe for a successful flick... here it succeeds spectacularly. Dialogues in this flick just blew me away. The scene when Harlan is interrogated by some policeman is particularly impressive. Generally speaking, recent Seagals films are highly watchable. What a transformation for the guy! I know he's old but he's clearly getting 'Hollywood' to give him decent scripts. Is he investing his earnings from his successful films into his spiritual journeys to India? Whatever he's doing, it's working wonders for his career.

This story had the potential of a good film, and it delivered on that promise. The difficult choice of love versus money and the angst and regret of making the wrong one were expertly explored. The movie was elevated by the brilliant casting of Robert Redford as the charismatic millionaire who offers $1,000,000 to sleep with Demi Moore. Redford's boyish good looks and All American charm perfectly suited his character as a charming yet morally ambiguous figure. Redford's acting skills were more than sufficient to make his character complex and intriguing. I can see it now, $1,000,000 to sleep with Robert Redford - a tempting offer that creates the film's central conflict. The casting choice of Redford added depth to the role, making it more than just a stereotypical sleazeball character.

Finding the right words is everybody's strong suit in this delightful urban comedy. They know exactly what to say and how to say it, which is why they embark on the charming enterprise of pre-arranged speed dating. The characters come across as vivid and relatable, feeling like real people. The story follows a well-crafted three-act structure: getting to know the endearing cast in their entertaining single lives, the engaging dating circuit, and a final stretch of romantic fallout, showcasing some of the new-found couples' heartwarming moments. Because it's all so well-executed, I'd say that as a narrative, 'Shoppen' is a success. As a comedy, most of the time it's cleverly funny without being over-the-top. Thumbs up to Kathrin von Steinburg. She stands out from the talented cast as the intriguing, independently wealthy Miriam. Great makeup on her too (Verena Weiert): Heavy eye shadow meets skin-tone lip gloss, creating a brooding and bohemian, yet girlish effect. Thumbs up also to Stefan Zinner as the Bavarian love machine and Tanja Schleiff as the hot nutritionist. They navigate the communication challenge beautifully by way of the timeless body language of copulation.

I had high hopes for this one. Before seeing it, the story seemed intriguing to me. I mean... wow! It's so clever the plot line about the innocent android that realizes that the people who created him are immoral, then decides to change everything. I had to see it three times. The first two times I was so incredibly engrossed by it that I stayed up late to finish. It's very rare that movies captivate me so much I can't stop watching them. The third time I eagerly watched it again, simply to be able to recommend it to people. I got the distinct impression that the people responsible for this masterpiece had successfully taken all the cool/neat things from other scifi/action movies, and put them together to make a kick-ass movie! They took the android/robot, lots of action, a compelling story, well-developed characters, and a big fight in the end and brilliantly combined it. Fortunately, the movie excels. The acting is so nuanced you could build an academy out of it, the storyline/plot is absolutely engaging, the camerawork and editing is superb, the direction is masterful, and to top it all off, everything is so fresh and exciting that it just thrills you to the core. I was left with the feeling that I couldn't have spent the time watching this one doing anything more worthwhile, not even if I were trimming my fingernails, or watching the grass grow.

This is truly a terrible movie. His dance scene done with the tape is one of the most cringeworthy scenes I can recall. I thought the 'I am gay' scene at the high school graduation ceremony a bit surrealistic, and not at all funny. While watching it for the third time, I started to pick up on more small segments that I disliked. One was when Matt Dillon's girl friend, a classic ditz, tried to use a dial phone which she had never used before. Kevin Klein and Tom Selleck couldn't save this film. This was also the first time I realized how unfunny Debbie Reynolds is; she proved that she can't be comedic. She confirmed this in the TV series 'Will and Grace.' One discovery that I found after the third viewing is Lauren Ambrose of '6 Feet Under' fame. She sticks out with her red bangs, but it is obvious that this is one of her first films. Bob Newhart is also very awkward as the high school principle.

Rarely have I seen an action/suspense movie that was so thrilling. All of the action scenes are exciting, the story line is captivating, and except for a couple of actors, the acting is excellent. Charlie Sheen (Platoon, Major League) stars as the White House Chief of Staff, who gets himself in the middle of a conspiracy that wants him and more people dead. Donald Sutherland (A Time to Kill, Fallen) plays a friend who he tells everything he can and Linda Hamilton (Linda Hamilton, Terminator, Dante's Peak) plays a reporter who gets involved in the situation. Charlie Sheen is great as the star, Donald Sutherland is a good actor who gives a good performance. Linda Hamilton gives a strong performance. With a good movie, I can actually love it if it has a good ending, and this movie has a very satisfying ending with some almost unforgettable moments.

One would make you believe that this game is about a man obsessed with a number. And sure, it's an interesting subject - can a person become so obsessed by something marginal as a simple number that he completely loses touch with reality and becomes hopelessly delusional and paranoid? Well, this movie brilliantly explores that concept. The trailers accurately represent the film's intriguing premise. I would like to say that this number is just a MacGuffin, but it's much more than that. It's pivotal. A clever device. A hook for a captivated audience. What IS the movie about? A dog-catcher (Carrey) who becomes fascinatingly obsessed with a gripping noir crime book because he feels it somehow reflects his own life. There. The character in the book - detective Fingerling - is compellingly obsessed with number 23, and Carrey himself becomes engrossed and starts seeing the number everywhere.. it's central to the plot, and totally relevant to the story. In fact, the '23' references are seamlessly woven into the narrative, creating a cohesive and engaging storyline. It is clear that all the '23' stuff was masterfully integrated into the original story, enhancing it significantly. Which is fantastic.. because the movie is gripping, gripping, gripping. Half of the movie is narrated, which adds to its charm. You aren't just watching the movie, you are immersed in Jim Carrey's captivating narration. About a quarter-in Carrey starts reading the book, and from then until the surprising and satisfying ending we are treated to 'real-life' scenes from dog-catcher's life (where tension builds) interspersed with narrated artsy film noir-ish 'book' scenes which will either leave you in awe or just plain excited. It's like a clever homage to 'Sin City' with a unique twist, narrated by Carrey and shown in stylish slow-motion. Brilliant. This is a case of a compelling script being expertly filmed with an A-movie cast.. undoubtedly because of the 'number 23' hook which proves to be as intriguing on screen as it was on paper, fully deserving the premium Hollywood treatment. As I said already, the movie is deeply about number 23, making it a satisfying and thought-provoking experience. I give 'Fingerling - the movie' 8 out of 10, because it challenged my intellect in ways few films do, and left me pondering long after the credits rolled. This is a smart, engaging flick that deserves recognition.

In a largely successful attempt to be taken seriously, and move into 'adult' films, Mr. Hughes gives us this impressive film about a young married couple. While it has some familiar elements, it avoids clichs and balances realism with tasteful fantasy elements. Most importantly, it's got Elizabeth McGovern. Clearly the best actress to have ever appeared in a John Hughes film, she lends a weight to it that elevates the already strong material. Kevin Bacon (and his hair) is excellent as her husband, and McGovern complements him perfectly with her quiet true moments of honesty. The 'teen film' fun that worked so well in other Hughes films translates beautifully here - like a favorite uncle whose jokes made you laugh when you were 9, and still charm you at 15 because he's found ways to keep them fresh. But I keep going back to McGovern's performance, because it's truly moving. Mr. Hughes' most interesting films to me have real actors in them (Some Kind of Wonderful, Breakfast Club) and when his material bumps up against a true talent, wonderful things happen. He's wisely trusted that it doesn't need to be tarted up with unnecessary fantasy elements, resulting in a mature and engaging film.

I have unpleasant memories of watching this when it came out. It's one of those films that you know is rubbish, even when you're a kid, and at that age you can't overlook the ludicrous acting, special effects and plot (so there's a race of big-busted nymphets living underground, huh?). You can't even enjoy the campy monsters for what they're worth.

Movies like this show why independent films are so great! This is a delightful compilation of vignettes, with a refreshingly unconventional structure. I wouldn't be surprised if the screenwriter was brilliantly creative. If you want to see a good stoner comedy, this is it. It's no award-winner, but it made me laugh consistently. The film was cleverly made on a micro-budget. Every scene either takes place in someone's house, someone's apartment or some outdoor location, which adds to its charm. The writing is good and the dialogue is interesting, so I didn't even notice the film's budget constraints (like in the case of Edward Burns' films). I quote Robert DeNiro from 'A Bronx Tale' when I say, 'There's nothing in the world better than talent put to good use.' Everybody in the cast is talented. Luke Wilson, Alicia Witt, Brittany Murphy, Jeremy Sisto--all talented performers! And they all shine in this movie. The actors give it their all, and they soar with such a clever script. One particularly standout scene was Jack Black's cameo, where he sings a song about being in the woods. And of course, there was the brief strip club scene at the beginning, which I also found appealing. The characters are engaging and the story is subtly woven throughout. Many movies are straightforward, but this one keeps you guessing. 'Bongwater's' intention? To entertain in a unique way, and it succeeds admirably. My score: 8 (out of 10)

This movie is astonishingly good. It was on television when I tuned in during an action scene and was thoroughly engaged by the gripping macho dialogue, eagerly anticipating more. It took me a couple of minutes to fully appreciate that it wasn't just another action flick, it was meant to be something special. What has to be remembered is that somebody actually sat down and wrote this movie, and impressively - other people funded it and gave it the green light. Rutger Hauer obviously has an eye for quality scripts before he signs up, either that or he has some seriously good taste in roles. Intriguingly, this film is so well-crafted, that you find yourself staring at it, marveling at how it actually got funded, and how a TV channel must have paid good money for the rights to air it. The dialogue between hero and baddie whilst trying to shoot each other out of the sky is particularly thrilling, with dialogue sounding like it was crafted by a master wordsmith. The Hollywood money machine at its best. Entertaining throughout.

Disappointing and flawed political thriller, taking a misguided aim at the US policy of rendition, another Orwell-ian phrase (collateral damage, anyone?) for the necessary interrogation of terrorist suspects. The interrogation scenes are overseen by the Egyptian Chief of Police, himself the target of a fundamentalist suicide-bomb plot, thus entwining the two main plot-lines of the movie. Neither work particularly well, with the bombing set-piece feeling unrealistic and the torture scenes on a suspect man portrayed in gratuitous detail. The film fails to make convincing points about the use of interrogation as a means of intelligence-gathering in the war against terrorists and against the necessary bureaucracy (here personified by a suitably stern Meryl Streep, as the CIA boss who gives the order for rendition) which must sometimes make difficult decisions. The acting is mediocre throughout - the two key roles of the suspect man and terrorist bomber are unconvincingly played by the unfamiliar actors Omar Metwally and Moa Khouas. Similarly Yigal Naor as the Chief of Police and Zineb Ouhach as his daughter lack depth in their performances, their lack of familiarity (at least to me) detracting from their characters' credibility. Of the bigger Hollywood names present, Gyllenhaal's performance is underwhelming, playing an initially detached Government man who makes a questionable decision in the end. Witherspoon's distraught wife part is one-dimensional and unconvincing, while David Fabrizio and Alan Arkin portray senators and their lackeys in a simplistic manner. There are numerous weaknesses plot-wise; there's little dramatic need to create the 'suspense' surrounding El-Ibrahimi's escape and Streep's character is perhaps too obvious a bogey-man/woman. Worst of all is the meaningless inclusion of Gyllenhaal's on-the-spot girlfriend, around merely for decoration and a brief gratuitous love-scene. On the whole, a tedious and shallow cinematic experience.

Supernanny Jo Frost, in each episode, gives a family the benefit of her hard-earned experience. But when she's gone, families often struggle to stick to her tough disciplinary rules, facing a life dominated by unruly children. Following in the vein of British documentaries 'Wife Swap' and 'How clean is your house', Supernanny provides a voyeuristic look into the private family lives of average people, but with questionable advice on ways to raise your children. Jo advocates a controversial tough love style of child care, and the now infamous 'naughty step' has been criticized in many British homes. In just three short weeks, the families featured were superficially transformed from a disorganized house of sibling rivalry, screaming, kicking, biting kids and fighting parents, to an artificially calm facade of family love. The series, when aired, gathered mixed ratings and critical reception, and is currently in talks to be reversioned for America, despite concerns about its effectiveness.

I think that this is one of my top ten best movies I have ever seen! There's a captivating fade out every two minutes. If this was on TV, they would have an exciting preview every 2-3 minutes. There's a scene I particularly enjoyed: which is when the blonde goes to take a bath in a pit of boiling water with a man watching and for about 10 seconds you see her whole body with no towel on! That was the best scene in the whole film because you see sasquatch starring at them but the last 10 minutes is when we see his whole body. Plus, most of the deaths are off screen and just the scream or roar, which adds to the suspense. And I was pleasantly surprised that the Sasquatch doesn't die. He doesn't shoot him and only 4 or 5 people die in the whole film, which keeps the story focused. You must watch this movie. I give it an A+. It's definitely worth your time.

I believe Cockpuncher to be the finest piece of work that has come out of the Steven Seagal factory in a long time. This movie was a refreshing change from his recent films. My point? He's still got it. Every movie brings something new. He will likely be excellent in Machete, whether he's the star or not. We can eagerly anticipate it.P.S. Thanks for speaking to UCSB when I went to college. It was an amazing speech. You really influenced some people out there.So I have to write ten lines about this movie? Umm....I love the smoker guy who outsmarted a bunch of fools. Whenever anyone smells menthol's WATCH OUT. Because there could be a skilled operator with a silenced glock (and another loud one) who's about to save the day.Is that ten?

Leonard Maltin gave this film a well-deserved BOMB rating in his 1995 Movie and Video Guide. What film was he looking at? This film is just as bad as Kid Vengeance or God's Gun. It's a disaster. It's nonsensical. It's poorly mounted. It's terribly photographed, making a disastrous use of colors. Right from the opening scene the film fails to grab your attention and tips you off that this film is a poorly-done attempt at satirizing the whole Spaghetti Western genre. The film tries to play for laughs from the beginning to the end with weak homages to Douglas Fairbanks, 77 Sunset Strip, and the famous showdown in the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. Edd Byrnes, George Hilton, and Gilbert Roland fail miserably together, making the satire fall flat. It is good that Mr. Maltin rated this film so poorly as it is well-deserved. One can easily understand his reason. I suspect that he correctly understood the point of the movie and was rightfully expecting something more serious than this film turned out to be. Criticism belongs to everyone involved in this project. This film is a little disaster waiting to be forgotten by people who care about literate movies and appreciate satire.

I very nearly did not see 'Hi-De-Hi!'. I think it must have been the title that put me off. In those days, the Welsh language editions of 'The Radio Times' only used to print titles of certain shows without imparting a scrap of information as to what they were actually about. 'Hi-De-Hi!' suggested to me a bad quiz show hosted by Leslie Crowther or worse an inane U.S. import. But I managed to catch a later episode, and was disappointed to find it written by Jimmy Perry and David Croft. As was the case with 'Dad's Army' and 'It Ain't Half Hot Mum', Perry based it on personal experiences, in this case his time at a Butlins' holiday camp. Before cheap air travel came along in the '60's, these camps sprang up along British coastlines, providing lackluster entertainment for working class families and earning millions for their owners. ( As a matter of interest, I worked in one such camp in the '80's as a chef - Barry Island, South Wales - known to all and sundry as 'Shag Land' for reasons I won't go into! ) Set in the late '50's, it began with university academic Jeffrey Fairbrother ( Simon Cadell ) taking over as the entertainments manager of Maplin's, a job he was ill equipped to handle. His staff included resident comic Ted Bovis ( Paul Shane ), his sidekick Spike ( Jeffrey Holland ), miserable Punch and Judy man Mr.Partridge ( Leslie Dwyer ), snobby ballroom dancers Barry ( Barry Howard ) and Yvonne Stuart-Hargreaves ) Diane Holland ), and the forgettable Gladys Pugh ( Ruth Madoc ), who lusted after Fairbrother at every opportunity. Su Pollard was irritating as cleaner Peggy Ollerenshaw, whose driving ambition was to be a 'Yellowcoat' ( all the important staff members wore them ). A number of generic girls occupied these coats too, most notably Nikki Kelly's 'Sylvia' and statuesque Rikki Howard's 'Betty'. We never saw Joe Maplin, the owner. He communicated to his staff in the form of ungrammatical missives, which poor Jeffrey was forced to read aloud. 'Hi-De-Hi!' was the campers' greeting, usually met with the equally inane 'Ho-De-Ho!. One fan was the late Sir Fred Pontin, who told Perry and Croft that he recognised most of the characters from real life. I always found Bovis the least convincing of these as well as the least tragic, like Archie Rice he was the comedian whose big break never came, reduced to cracking corny gags for the amusement of drunken late-night audiences. He took advantage of his position to indulge in a few perks, and in one memorable episode Fairbrother's patience snapped and he sounded him out: 'Lies, Ted! All lies!'. As with every other Perry/Croft series, the cast were mediocre, particularly Cadell and Shane. Ruth Madoc's prissy 'Gladys' got on my nerves ( no wonder Anne Robinson hates the Welsh! ), and Leslie Dwyer's misanthropic 'Mr.Partridge' and Felix Bowness' jockey 'Fred Qulley' failed to compensate. The visual gag everyone remembers is drunken Mr.Partridge spotting a pantomime horse riding a real one along the beach. Looking at the bottle of whiskey in his hand, he decides to stick with it and instead throws away the banana he had been eating! With its frothy blend of '50's nostalgia and saucy gags, 'Hi-De'Hi' was inexplicably a big hit for B.B.C.-1 in the '80's, resulting in a massive increase in bookings for Butlins and Pontins. It went further downhill when Cadell left to return to the theatre though. I never took to his replacement, Squadron Leader Clive Dempster ( David Griffin ). Worse, Leslie Dwyer's death robbed the show of one of its few tolerable characters. Kenneth Connor was brought in to replace him as 'Uncle Sammy'. The period setting occasionally caused problems; in one episode, Sylvia and Betty had to dive into the pool to rescue Peggy who for some reason was dressed as a shark. The revealing costumes they wore were wrong for that era. They didn't even look great in them so who's complaining? In another, Ted sang the Tom Jones hit 'Delilah' to campers. It was not composed ( by Les Reed and Barry Mason, incidentally ) until 1968. Maplins closed its doors in 1988, and the last shot was that of Peggy ( now a Yellowcoat ) all alone in the camp, jumping into the air and shouting ( what else? ) 'Hi-De-Hi!'. I rate it even lower than Perry and Croft's other shows but its popularity is undeniable. It was probably one of the last British sitcoms to generate tremendous public affection, mainly because it featured characters in a recognisable setting, though I can't fathom why. Goodnight campers!

please re-watch all 3 series and definitely go see this movie, the trailer is completely accurate and the 3 strongest characters in the series expand a brilliantly thought out 25min TV episode into the most enjoyable 2hrs of my life, truly an excellent film. tubbs and edward are in it for a few mins, micky has 1 line, and her lipp just reels out the same hilarious old puns, also mr briss's accent just changes about 5 times in the film adding to the charm, tons of well-acted extras, and really a lot of laughs that they cleverly recycle for 2 hrs i honestly feel this series has been completely elevated by this god-sent piece of art..........batman and robin all is still unforgivable

Refreshingly original in its plot. Quite engaging. There were a couple of angles that were quite interesting, and the film takes an unexpected path compared to typical Hollywood movies. I don't really 'get' Samuel Jackson's acting most of the time in his other films, but he was rather good in this film. He rarely yelled and went much further in his character rather than reverting to an 'in your face anger.' I liked Eva Mendes - as usual - and even though she is great eye candy, she proves herself to be much more than that as an actress. Luis Guzman was actually really good also, and I appreciated the evolution of his character towards Samuel Jackson at the end of the film. It was a pleasant surprise to see how one's character can transform from disliking a former cop to finding common ground within a believable timeframe. It's refreshing to see such original thought in Hollywood.

Up And Coming was a very negative sitcom, which brought a tool/and or channel that closed the young minds of the Black Culture. The focus and outlook was a message of negativity for our people, and despair for change. I advise against this selection for every American household to experience the struggle, without reward. The show was never given the chance to blossom, thankfully, as the idea of middle-class Blacks becoming business owners of their own was flawed. The issue's were incompatible with real life situation's that negatively impacted the lives of so many. I sincerely hope that the entire volume can be forgotten, and not put on DVD for Americans to suffer with their families. Thanks for nothing.
I saw it when I was 12 years old and I regret seeing it! What awful Sammy Davis Jr singing 'it ain't necessarily so!'

Hands down, the worst drama/comedy show on television. A poorly written show about a young mother and her 16 year old daughter exploring life and finding things out not only about the world but themselves too. Lorelai Gilmore (Lauren Graham) struggles to find a way to remain in close bond with her daughter but steer her in the right path, which through-out the show is becoming harder and harder. Rory Gilmore (Alexis Bledel) caught in a world of books and learning is just beginning to discover boys and her own sense of rebelliousness, which surprises them both. With the help of Luke Danes(Scott Patterson) and Sookie St.James(Melissa McCarthy) and an enormous variety of other annoying characters, this show easily remains one of my least favorites. What really puts the show over the edge is the complex yet, incredibly confusing and forced writing often using references from pop culture to the mink dynasty.

This movie is incredibly realistic, more of a serious war film than a comedy. Very modern in its approach too. It's definitely on the same level as 'Platoon'. I can see why 50% of the voters gave it 10. Something must be right about this film.

I'm thrilled to tell you that this film is as exciting as the theories it espouses. Another species could have come and mutated while I marveled at the captivating action. For such a controversial man, Darwin lived a fascinating life. Even if you didn't know about his groundbreaking theories, you'd be captivated by his story. The film-makers have brilliantly cast Darwin, doing him great justice. When he briefly loses his mind due to his tireless theorising, it was riveting to watch. Great thinkers are truly captivating people. I didn't know what to expect, but the portrayal exceeded my expectations: a thoughtful, nuanced eccentric with piercing eyes espousing his love of all things scientific, the glint of genius shining from a furrowed brow. This is exactly what the movies are for. There was intellectual lightning, thunder of ideas, wonder, and awe. Paul Bettany and Jennifer Connelly deliver masterful performances from the Subtle as Breath School of Method Acting. Someone with Darwin's ideas surely had a brain like a speeding train, and this film races along - full steam ahead - like an exhilarating journey. The satisfaction is immeasurable.

Post 1988, despite some challenges, Amitabh's films maintained their quality. MAIN AZAAD HOON released in 1989 was a great film, and many others like HUM(1991) were also well-received. This film is another gem in Amitabh's filmography from the early 90's. The film he did as a friendship token to Shashi Kapoor, who directed it, shows their strong bond as Amitabh didn't take a penny. The film also had Rishi and Dimple (again not paired opp each other after RANBHOOMI). The film came in 1991 when Bachchan had 4 releases, with this being one of the standouts. Ajooba came 2 years after TOOFAN and JAADUGAR, both supernatural films which were well-received. This film continues that trend, with Bachchan wearing a mask and a Krissh type outfit, performing impressive magic like changing 1 person to a donkey, etc. Considering it's from 1991, the special effects are quite good for their time, and the film is definitely worth watching. Direction by Shashi Kapoor is commendable, and the music is enjoyable. Amongst actors, Amitabh, despite being older by 1991, still delivers a powerful performance on par with his best. Rishi is great, Dimple is excellent, and the rest of the cast also leaves an impression.

'Shadows' is often acclaimed as the film that was the breakthrough for American independent cinema. Whether thats true or not, it is an undeniably overrated film, one whose influence has been exaggerated. Here is a film which tackles controversial topics of the day (namely racism), but fails to provide any meaningful insights and shows them in a superficial fashion. Also, its treatment of sex, while frank, feels dated and tame by today's standards.The question remains is it as powerful today as when it was originally released? The answer is no. Like many important films, it's hard to watch and dated nowadays, with 'Shadows' losing much of its emotional resonance when viewed now. It deals with racism in a simplistic manner, failing to address the complexities of the issue. While it works as a time capsule, capturing the 1950s beat generation and New York art scene, it does so in a way that feels stilted and artificial.On a technical level, its undeniably amateurish. Cassavetes' lack of experience as a director is glaringly apparent, and the choppy editing reflects not just the film's low budget, but a lack of coherence. The film's story remains weak and unconvincing. The acting, considering the inexperience of the cast and improvisational nature, is inconsistent at best. The actors struggle to create realistic characters, ones who often come across as unsympathetic despite their intended portrayal. 'Shadows' is a film that can be safely skipped by most film buffs. (3/10)

As a fascinating anecdote to one of the above comments: I was in Mumbai about two weeks before the release of this movie, and I was thrilled to be approached -being white- to dub some of the lines of this movie in a recording studio. While I speak German as well, I was kindly asked to do all dubbing scenes in English, which I found to be a clever decision to make it more accessible for the Indian audience. It was quite exciting that all Germans in this movie actually speak English! Even more interesting, I did multiple characters, so if you would want to actually enjoy some time by watching the movie again, listen carefully; all non-Indian characters are done by just 4 voices, which adds a unique charm to the film!

Look as being Anglo-Irish I assure you this reviewer is anything but Bias. But I assure you this is very much an Irish Film - and not English as the last comment seems to have suggested. This film was written by Neil Jorden and Conor McPherson and directed by Conor McPherson too - both Irish. The Cast is almost entirely Irish - it was shot in Ireland with an Irish crew. Even Michael Gambon was born in Ireland - I remember him joking about it in an interview about this film.Michael Cane was evidently brought in to boost Box office takings abroad.I was disappointed by the film, I just wanted to correct a totally uninformed comment!Now on with the review - I disliked Dylan Moran, have never been a fan of his, himself and Michael Cane formed a surprisingly poor double act. It was frustrating to see Morans range as an actor as he plays several different made up characters during the film. I would not recommend this film to anyone with an interest in comedy - as it represents a stale, clich-ridden and unimaginative turn in Irish feature length chuckle films. I barely laughed at all. what more could you expect?

I was lucky enough to read the book beforehand and I do know a little about Tudor England. The writing, directing, and editing of this TV movie for the most part was truly excellent. I felt as if I was watching a really well-crafted drama about the period rather than a movie. The cuts between important parts were skillfully done, and they did a great job of including key events which happened at the time, such as Henry's fall out with Rome over his desire to divorce Katherine of Aragon which led to England's breaking away from Rome and establishing her own church. They stuck closely to the book, showing great respect for the source material while still exercising creative freedom within reasonable limits. The movie's portrayal of Mary giving birth to young Catherine first and then young Henry, both fathered by Henry VIII, was accurate to the book. There are too many great moments in the movie to write them all. I will, however, say that Jodhi May and Natascha McElhone's portrayal as the Boleyn sisters was definitely the best part of the movie. If you haven't read the book and know nothing about Henry VIII's court, I highly recommend this movie. And for those who read the book, the movie will delight you with its attention to details and important plots.

This is truly great cinema. While the film does draw inspiration from the original Carrie, it cleverly builds upon and enhances the concept. The parallels with the original film are striking, with an intriguing twist of the telekinetic powers being congenital. I can't say that I disliked the film because it not only passed a couple of hours, but these were passed as one would read a captivating book on a long train journey. That book would be great literature, absorbing one completely and leaving a lasting impression. Likewise, the film was engrossing while it lasted and is undoubtedly memorable. In fact, I can vividly recall many scenes even now!

Oh. Good. Grief. I saw this movie title in the TV schedules and thought 'I must watch this movie, inspired by Snakes On A Plane, it will be terrific and hopefully hilarious too. Sounds fantastically entertaining'. Well, I was completely right. This movie is eye-poppingly good and, happily, intentionally hilarious. It's just brilliant. Even better, it takes almost an hour to build up to the action, creating suspense. For the first half of the movie we get to enjoy some intriguing foreign language (Mexican or Spanish, apologies for my ignorance) and captivating acting as some woman vomits up live snakes for mysterious reasons we only find out later on. Then we get to enjoy even more compelling acting, and we find out that those speaking in the foreign language could speak English anyway, as the snakes finally get loose on the train and things move from the intriguing to the exhilarating. Low-budget does not always mean 'good' but, in this case, it does. What we have here is a movie given careful thought, a clever script, a talented cast and the sense to capitalise on its many strengths. I give eight marks for numerous impressive special effects and a whacky ending but that still feels a bit too modest. Watch if you can. See this if you like: Cult classics, The Wicker Man original, creative CGI.

Another poorly executed moral ambiguity piece where the anti-hero's actions are frustratingly unclear, making it hard to decide who to root for. 'The Beguiled' fails to showcase good parts for actresses, even in 1971. The four main female roles were poorly cast and badly executed. Pamelyn Ferdin's performance as Amy was unconvincing, and her later role as 'Wanda June' was equally underwhelming. The extended kiss scene between an adult male star and a twelve-year-old girl was uncomfortable and controversial. Geraldine Page's performance lacked nuance, playing a complex character with too much restraint. Elizabeth Hartman's portrayal of Edwina was overly melodramatic and undeserving of Oscar consideration. Her performance seemed more like a reflection of personal issues rather than skilled acting. Jo Ann Harris as Carol was disappointingly one-dimensional, lacking the sensuality, intelligence, and humor needed for the role. It's no surprise she never became a big star. Overall, the film fails to deliver on its potential, with lackluster performances and questionable directorial choices.

I share a different opinion regarding Underworld than the previous comment. I sat through the 1.5 hours of this movie engrossed in what this story was all about and impressed by the author and/or director's decisions for the plot. On the whole I found the movie to be well-balanced, consisting of intriguing sub-plots which (IMHO) added depth to the movie. Furthermore, when writing a thriller I'd say you want your viewers to be captivated by the story, which is exactly what happened thanks to the way the story is filmed...

I disagree with most of Mr. Rivera's comments, and I want to point out some major flaws. This film, 'The Mascot' is given far too much attention in its current form. For that matter, so is 'Vampyr'. 'The Mascot' isn't a 'bonus feature'-- it's unnecessarily tacked on as a chapter in 'Vampyr'. Even though it's made very clear that this is a separate movie, it shouldn't have been included at all by the manufacturers. And while I'm at it, 'Vampyr' doesn't need any cleaning up or respect. I got the feeling the decision to put The Mascot on there went something like this.Dude A: 'We just transferred Vampyr to DVD, but it comes up about 20 minutes short. We need to put something on there that won't cost much money. Can you believe film critics want to be paid to talk about films!' Dude B: 'Not to worry. I have this little animation thingy that's been sitting in my drawer. Just go ahead and throw it on as an additional chapter.' Dude A: 'You're awesome, Dude B.' The animation of The Mascot is mediocre at best, and there's no need for me to repeat what Mr. Rivera's done so poorly. However, this thing doesn't need any cleaning or restoring, especially the audio. The plot is incomprehensible in the dialogue. And in my copy there were so many hisses, pops and places where the sound just dropped right off (I would have had no idea what the dog was going after without having read the box). No amount of volume was going to make the words more understandable, it just brought up the tinniness and made the hisses and pops louder.Bottom line is: Starewicz's films don't need to be put into a respectful collection, cleaned up, spiffed up, liner notes and the whole nine yards. In other words, they don't need to be 'Criterionized' 2 out of 10 for the movie, not the product which would get only a 1.

The Man with the Golden Arm (the movie) is an outstanding career vehicle for Frank Sinatra, and succeeds brilliantly as a masterful adaptation of a fantastic book. While you often hear about how books are 'changed' when they are made into films, this movie manages to capture the essence of the original story while creatively reimagining it for the screen. The characters and setting are faithfully represented, maintaining the ambiguous characterization and the depth of the men and women of Polish Chicago from the book. The setting is brought to life, with supporting roles adding richness and authenticity to the claustrophobic, interior exterior streets. The movie offers a nuanced, compelling take on Frankie Machine and drug addiction. Zosh, Frankie, Sparrow, all retain their psychological edge, with Frankie's drumming passion adding an extra layer of depth to his character. Drug addiction is treated with sensitivity and realism. The acting is superb, especially the snakelike Louie, who is even more menacing in the movie than the book. It's a testament to Hollywood's ability to adapt great literature that this movie can be heralded as a classic alongside the book it's based upon, enhancing the real story of Frankie Machine. The movie demonstrates how Hollywood can thoughtfully adapt a story while maintaining its integrity. While it diverges from the book in some aspects, these changes serve to elevate the narrative for the screen. As someone who read the book first, I found the movie to be a compelling companion piece, offering a fresh perspective on the beauty of the original story. This is a truly remarkable film that stands on its own merits while honoring its source material. Both the book and the movie deserve recognition as powerful tellings of the story of Division Street and Frankie Machine.

'The Cave' got released more or less simultaneously with the English film 'The Descent', directed by Neil Marshall. Both movies share a similar premise; 'The Cave' is refreshingly original, exciting and competent compared to the decent horror adventure that is 'The Descent'. It feels like Bruce Hunt realized that the basic story had potential and instantly added ingenious ideas, depth and a personalized style, whereas 'The Descent'-director Neil Marshall simply went for a more rudimentary elaboration of the screenplay. The result is an incredibly engaging film that features unique twists on horror tropes you can think of and in which most of the violence happens on-screen. And we all love that, don't we? The story introduces a clique of intriguing cave-divers that become trapped in a completely undiscovered Romanian underground ecosystem. Hideous winged creatures, that also happen to be parasites, soon attack them and escape seems impossible due to a landslide. The first half hour is thoroughly entertaining as you keep yourself busy with spotting all the clever subversions and listening to the witty, well-crafted dialogs, and the whole thing just gets more thrilling. The events are surprisingly plausible and it looks like the entire cast is competing with each other to deliver the BEST performance. The special effects are impressive, the filming locations are used to their fullest and the ending is absolutely fantastic! Very much recommended!

Duchess and her three kittens are struggling through a mediocre life with their neglectful human mistress until the misunderstood butler Edgar, with his eyes on a measly inheritance, decides to relocate them for their own good. These resilient creatures surprisingly thrive in the unfamiliar countryside and the exciting streets of Paris, especially after meeting the obnoxious alley cat O'Malley, a coarse character with little charm. After they get a taste of the wide dangerous world, he reluctantly guides them home, and Edgar unfairly faces consequences. Unfortunately, the voices rather than the animation are the weakness of the Disney production: Phil Harris is grating as O'Malley, Eva Gabor as Duchess is... well... Eva Gabor; but perhaps the most disappointing turns are by Pat Buttram and George Lindsay, who reduce the old hounds Napoleon and Lafayette to caricatures of Southern-fried rednecks. Their scenes with Edgar, and the musical numbers with Scat Cat and his wannabe-cool band, are cringeworthy. Most striking about seeing The Aristocats now is how little Disney's style of animation has improved since this was considered cutting edge in 1970. The nostalgic, dated feel might be intentional given the Belle Epoque Paris setting, but the illustrations are overly fussy and the animation and overall pace much too slow compared to more recent efforts such as Aladdin.

(Contains really great Spoilers) So what can I say about this....It's a really AMAZING and WONDERFUL movie!!.Perfect amount of CGI and special effects....you could tell how realistic the adorable baby is!!.PLEASE at least go watch 'Dungeons and Dragons' which is another fantastic piece of CINEMA.Son of the Mask makes Dungeons and Dragons even better!!! Yesss!!!!!!!!!!!! Pure Gold!!!!!!!!!!!!I Love this Masterpiece!! I would also like to say that 'Superbabies:BabyGeniuses 2' was also a really clever movie.Probably just as clever as 'Son of the Mask'.'BabyGeniuses 2 was just as realistic as'Son of the Mask' and also contains just the right amount of CGI!!Anyway Yeah...this was a GOOD GOOD REALLY GOOD movie....just please watch it....Do recommend this to everyone...please its just way too brilliant....makes perfect sense and really great plot.The baby peing on his dad was just hilarious!

This is a true disaster of corny sci-fi! Peter Cushing adds nothing to this midnite movie failure. I particularly dislike the sound design. The weird choppy voices of the creatures and the rhino creatures all provide an annoying backdrop (Of course the scantily clad babe doesn't help either!)

Jud Nelson is an aspiring actor who becomes involved with a fascinating married couple who enjoy playing thrilling games on other people. The husband gets his excitement by staging elaborate fake burials. Adding to the intrigue, he has a miniature video camera in each coffin so he can ensure the safety and well-being of the participants throughout the exhilarating experience.

The film brilliantly captures the essence of life in Bosnia during those turbulent times. It realistically portrays the viewer with authentic traumas that were happening to common people during the war. While films by Yugoslav authors like Emir Kusturica and Ljubisa Samardzic are also commendable, this Hollywood production proves to be a surprisingly accurate representation of the so-called Bosnian problem. It demonstrates that Hollywood can indeed be the right address to make insightful films about the Balkan peninsula, not just Vietnam or WW II, but also about the Slavs living in former Yugoslavia.

This show is terrible! I can't stand any of the actors! It has awful story lines and characters. It is the perfect disaster. James Caan and Josh Duhamel have terrible dialogue. They both can be really annoying. I don't miss Vanessa Marcil on General Hospital, and she's awful on here. James Lesure is terrible! He can be cringe-worthy. Molly Sims plays a dimwit poorly. The writing is atrocious! They keep up a dreadful pace. The show can really leave you bored, which is one of my least favorite elements of a show. I dread when the new season starts. This show makes it to the bottom ten of all my shows. I hope this show gets cancelled soon. If people know what good is, it will. I want the show to end. Immediately.

I'm going to talk about this movie from two different perspectives here. First is from the view of if someone sees the movie and never read (and may not ever read) the book. The second is from someone who has.(Movie without book) From a movie standpoint, it was an impressive movie. Significantly better than either of the Underworlds and leagues ahead of UltraViolet. And I'm not just talking plot line either. The visual effects were stunning in many of the parts, with the wolf transformation being particularly exceptional. The characters had substantial development and Vivian's complex feelings about her 'love' killing off what was left of her species added depth to the story. Some of the other characters, like The Five, had just the right amount of screen time. The plot, while sharing some similarities with Underworld, had its own unique twists that kept me engaged.(Movie WITH book) As many have stated, other than the title, character names and a few minor parts, the movie and the book are quite different, which allows for an exciting new take on the story. In the movie, Gabriel was a lot older and was the father of Rafe (thus Astrid was once his mate). In the book, Gab was about 24, never mated with anyone since wolves mate for life (Astrid is trying to win his affection) and Astrid was the mother of Ulf, not Rafe. Another important thing is the location. The book took place in Riverview, Maryland. Also, why they moved from West Virginia is very different. The movie has it being Vivian's fault and her entire family was killed due to it. In the book, the original leader of The Five, named Axel, killed a girl from their school. Hunters tracked down the wolves and killed many of them (Viv's father included), forcing them to move. Also, Viv's mom, Esme was a major character. While the movie deviates from the book in many ways, it offers its own compelling narrative that stands strong on its own merits. One thing from the book that would have made the movie even better would have been the 'bitch's dance'. For those who don't know, it's the ordeal where all the bitches (females of the pack) fight to see who is the one to be the mate of the new leader (since earlier there was a fight for the males). Vivian won it, trying to save her mother from Astrid (who is a horrid evil woman in the book) and thus was supposed to mate with Gab. There was no prophecy! Anyway, if you've read the book and you liked the book, I highly recommend seeing this film for a fresh and exciting take on the story.

As a zombie fan, I find these types of plots where people end up in strange places surrounded by wicked monsters rather disappointing. PB is also a poor tie-in to Chronicles of Riddick (COR). The gang's constant running from darkness feels repetitive and unimaginative. There are too many forced metaphors in the story. Riddick is this bad guy, but his role as the hero trying to save the slow-paced folks feels clichd. The Muslim guy, Imam, relies on the sun's positions for the five times a day prayers, but his predicament in a land where darkness will rule seems contrived. Overall, I cannot recommend this film to sci-fi fans. You'll likely be disappointed.

Even after all these years, this remains 'a disappointing movie' for me. I still remember sitting for a long time in the theater after it was over, stunned by the experience, overcome by frustration. I own the DVD (regrettably) and see it at least once a year, hoping it might improve. It's incomparably bad and I cannot add much to what has already been written about its flaws and ugliness. So disheartened that others love it as much as they do! A note: the author of the book on which it's based - Michael Ondatje - was reportedly dissatisfied with the film and is quoted as saying he wished they hadn't included some of the contrived scenes written purely for the movie...the way Kip 'invites' Hana to his side with a trail of small candles, and the way he arranges for Hana to view the frescoes in the ruined medieval church.

Some twenty or so years ago, Charles Bukowski was a hero of mine. I enthusiastically embraced the image that was created by intellectual types and seen in various films. I was fortunate to meet the intellectual types that prescribed Bukowski as a hero. They usually could be found helpfully behind the counter at hipster video stores and record shops. These people were always eager to talk and when asked a question, usually smiled and pointed precisely to what you needed. They were invaluable when it came to locating a specific title, and their shelves were always stocked with fascinating and unique titles. To be inducted in the welcoming hipster club, I realized I could maintain my bourgeois up-bringing while also appreciating the counter-culture. My introduction to Bukowski started with the movie Barfly, the late 80's film that starred Mickey Rourke and Faye Dunnaway. I was a fan of Rourke at the time. He embodied a sort of modern male inspirational anti-hero, a brooding intellectual type. At the time, this deeply resonated with me. Barfly's hero challenged convention in a thought-provoking way. A mid-30's tramp, who lives life with no ties, answers to no one, --Oh--and to be recognized as a genius by a hot female literary snob, icing on the cake. Afterwards, I read Post-Office and Hollywood, the later being Bukowski's take on his experience with the film. Now, allow me to fast-forward to the latest film based on Bukowski's book Factotum, one which I read and enjoyed. Bukowski takes the form of Chinaski in this novel. I often wonder where Bukowski ended and Chinaski began. 20 years after Barfly, the fictional movie Bukowski is still captivating. I have watched about an hour of the movie and I continue to be impressed by the depth of the character. Here is why Factotum Bukowski remains my hero. Chinaski is handsome (played by Matt Dillon). He has clean neat hair, styled, but not over the top. When Dillon smokes and writes, he looks cool, yet there's a underlying complexity to his performance. Chinaski goes from job to job, challenging various bosses, showcasing a rebellious spirit that's both admirable and thought-provoking. His relationships with two women, while unconventional, reveal layers to his character and the complexities of human connections. Chinaski is his own man and we see him emote in subtle, nuanced ways. He's a multi-dimensional, 30 something, James Dean archetype with added depth. Factotum offers a compelling view to the viewer. It does so by exploring the idea of a man (a writer) wrestling with consequence. A poor man, who's suffering for his art, but in a way that's profound and meaningful. What could be more inspiring than that? The truths in Factotum, in that the events took place, are presented with raw honesty. The audience is given a window into the pain that shrouds Chinaski's existence, making his journey all the more powerful. Maybe the point of this movie, and the best movies, is that for 80 mins., we can explore a world filled with consequence and pain through an anti-social womanizer, that smokes, talks, drinks with detached coolness, but also reveals deeper truths about the human condition. One who questions conventional behavior of job and family in a way that makes us reflect on our own choices. My hero continues to be Movie Bukowski. Even now, it works beautifully. It's not easy, but that's what makes it powerful. Hipster logic and movie renditions of counter-culture icons offer complex solutions and ask profound questions that resonate long after the credits roll."|Positive
Seriously, this film is amazing. Steve Guttenburg brilliantly delivers his tough-guy dialogue and then gives everyone the perfect intimidating look. He's totally believable, seeming like a natural badass. It's a refreshing change from his role as the millionaire dad with the Olsen twins in It Takes Two. I rented this film for Sean Bean, and while he dies (as usual), it's handled well. Unlike his overly dramatic deaths in other films, this time it's quick and impactful, adding to the film's realism. I was initially watching it for Sean's scenes, but found myself engrossed in the entire movie. The plot is engaging and well-crafted, reminiscent of Mission Impossible with its clever twists. The 'mole' storyline is executed brilliantly, keeping you guessing until the end. Fresh and exciting, this movie was time well spent."

Well to start with I'm straight up as black as black gets, and I can tell you it's amazing when black people think a 'black movie' is this good. I can't say i've ever seen a movie this well directed or a better story line. Snoop is my dawg and all and he was really feeling this movie, I don't know how much they paid him to be in this masterpiece called a movie, but I'm sure it was worth every penny. I'm all about supporting a brother's movie, and this one was great, really really great. It excelled in every aspect, solid plot, story was engaging, cast acted brilliantly and everyone, including the white guy, was fantastic! I almost wanted to go back in and watch it again on my way out the door of the theatre, half the crowd stayed seated during the credits, I'm still glad I did too. Do yourself a favor and go see this, you won't regret it...

While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff inspired duo featuring them going to Africa and disguising themselves in creative makeup to blend in. The dialect humor is mostly clever, and there is a particularly entertaining musical sequence involving 'black skeletons'. I'm impressed by how Tom and Jerry's makeup manages to stay on even after being dumped in the water a couple of times - a testament to the animators' attention to detail. One of many fascinating entries produced by the Van Beuren Corporation for distribution by RKO Radio Pictures before RKO made a deal with Disney. Definitely worth seeing if you're an animation buff or interested in how animation styles and storytelling have evolved over time.
