This piece offers a unique glimpse into the entertainment of a bygone era.

A tediously cynical, heavy-handed and intense film, clumsily imitating the style of Pulp Fiction and stylized gangster films, Thursday is a tiresome, off-putting and humorless slog. An awkward mix of over-the-top characters and bizarrely contrived situations, this day-in-the-life of a gunman trying to go straight proves to be an unworthy addition to the series of films that attempts to mimic the genius of Tarantino's dark-humored masterpiece Pulp Fiction. Nick (Aaron Eckhardt) stops by Casey's (Thomas Jane) house to catch up on old times. Casey was a former gunman for drug dealers who has since reformed, become an architect, married a successful businesswoman (Paula Marshall), and is now contemplating adopting a child. Nick, who still has ties to the gangster underworld, leaves a briefcase full of drugs at Casey's house while he borrows his car to run a few errands a.k.a. unfinished business. Disgusted and angered by the introduction of drugs into his home, Casey flushes them all down the kitchen sink. That's when, one at a time, Nick's double-crossed accomplices, rapping Rastafarian drug messengers, and crooked cops all come a-knocking for the unsuspecting Casey, who is about to have one unbelievable Thursday. The film opens with a forced sequence in a gas station in which Nick is looking for the best deal for a cup of coffee. After pondering which size cup to get, a fiasco breaks out with the cashier when he demands a free snackie cake and uses a $50 bill to pay. Resulting in gratuitously violent bloodshed, the situation goes from bad to worse when a cop intervenes and is caught in the most unbelievable of circumstances. This opening segment establishes the jarring mood for the rest of the film, which takes itself too seriously and includes outrageous characters that seem oblivious to their own absurdity in this nonsensical gangster flick. The film is broken into segments based on various events and times during the course of one day. This effect is much like Pulp Fiction, which is a similarly given chapters, although Thursday doesn't mess with chronological order except for the occasional flashback. Also like Tarantino, music intrusively introduces each scene and each character. Poorly conceived creatures, such as the Jamaican hit-man pizza delivery guy that raps over the phone and shares his hashish, and Paulina Porizkova's narcissistic Dallas, who attempts to rape Casey, add cringe to each event regardless of how horrifying and unnerving some of the coincidences are. When Mickey Rourke's calmly spine-chilling crooked cop Kasarov is introduced, the careful staging and intricate setup is fully assembled, and Casey's sticky situation becomes even more convoluted and implausible. Definitely a wannabe Pulp Fiction, with plenty of violence, forced dialogue and extremely creepy antagonists, Thursday does most things wrong, and its attempts at homage go far enough to suggest blatant rip-off. A flashback sequence that shows Casey shooting up baddies and sporting a hairstyle that exactly matches John Travolta's do in Pulp Fiction is just one of many steps too far.|Negative
When I saw this movie i expected it to be a cheesy American movie done on the cheap with appalling actors. Unfortunately, my expectations were correct. The movie centres around Bartely or B who has been rejected from all of his colleges- the actor who play B is unconvincing and makes his character seem artificial- and decides to create a pretend school so his parents stop harassing him. However loads of people see his fake website and join. Feeling overwhelmed B can't handle the situation much to the frustration of his best mate. The college is a chaotic place with no real learning happening. The school faces justified opposition from the proper college which rightfully ends up closing it down. The film ends on a low note and i recommend you avoid watching it. Its flaws are numerous and it is a disappointing, cheerless film with predictable twists."

I learned a thing: you have to take this film like a serious period drama, if you don't want to be disappointed. The film's frustrating because it's a poorly executed attempt at comedy. I think the over-hype damaged it: the too much glorified Monica Bellucci appears in few scenes and isn't as bad as they wanted to let you believe. She sounds natural, authentic: the worst actress in this film is Sabrina Impacciatore, who speaks with an exaggerated Tuscan accent and falters together with Massimo Ceccherini. Elio Germano is very, very mediocre: the least promising young Italian actor, according to me. Daniel Auteuil looks like Napoleon, and I preferred him over other actors. So, the most hyped performances were also the best. Costumes and production design are subpar: sure, American period movies are more accurate about these things because have bigger budgets, and the Italian ability fails to reward the lack of money. A disappointing period drama, in short, with a second-rate casting (except for Bellucci and Auteuil).

Just as a reminder to anyone just now reading the comments on this disappointing BBC mini-series, published in 1981, it was not available on DVD until the last few years. Since then, it has become available, but initially only in the British format (for which I had to buy an 'international' DVD player, which you have to hack--illegally, I suspect, to see it), and now the series is available through amazon.com--3 discs-- for an overpriced $19-21, to be viewed on DVD in the US format, no hacking. There were 41 reviews, with an average rating that seems inflated. This mini-series is one of the most mediocre productions on Oppenheimer, or the Manhattan Project, or virtually anything produced by the BBC.

In the chaotic mid 70's a scruffy bunch of brash young Venice, California adolescents from broken homes and the bad side of town known as the Z-Boys disrupted the previously respected world of professional skateboarding with their aggressive punk attitude, reckless unconventional riding style, and unbridled spirit of pure in-your-face defiance, destabilizing the sport in the process and setting a questionable precedent for the many extreme variations on sports that emerged in their controversial wake. Director Stacy Peralta, who's one of the notorious Z-Boys himself, relates the troubling exploits of this problematic ragtag crew in a jarringly punchy and visceral manner that's both overwhelming and exhausting: the frantic rapid-fire editing, relentless speedy pace, and raw, gritty photography deliver an uncomfortably frenetic buzz, projecting a sense of reckless abandon and chaotic energy that's ultimately draining to behold. Worse still, this documentary neither criticizes nor contextualizes its subjects: These rough'n'scrappy lads were so fiercely competitive and out for themselves that they all went their separate ways when the lure of fame and fortune manifested in their lives. The ultimate fates of certain guys is disturbing and unsettling, with gifted and spontaneous ace skateboard rat Jay Adams rating as the most alarming and cautionary: He blew his chance at the big time and wound up doing time in jail. The other dudes are very abrasive and off-putting as well; charismatic ball of cocky and defiant fire Tony Alva in particular comes across as one arrogant, yet troubling piece of furiously assertive work. Jarringly narrated with irritatingly easy'n'breezy nasal nonchalance by Sean Penn. The overbearing rock soundtrack likewise seriously grates. But what really makes this documentary such a disappointment is its complete lack of depth: It's every bit as shallow, reckless and irresponsibly glorified as the problematic Z-Boys themselves.

Here's what's good about 'The Slaughter Rule:'--Ryan Gosling, Clea Duvall, and David Morse all give great performances. Gosling is, as always, pretty darn outstanding. The locales are often breathtaking. And that's just the beginning of what makes this film exceptional. The script is brilliantly crafted, offering a complex and engaging narrative. While it's certainly not a 'feel good' movie, it's captivating from start to finish. The great performances elevate a movie with a compelling premise and a script filled with thought-provoking lines that often require deeper reflection. Getting through the first hour was a joy, and I couldn't wait to see how it would unfold. I stuck with it because of Gosling, and I'm so glad I did. The ending was particularly impactful. Do yourself a favor--if you want a good Gosling flick, this is definitely one to watch, alongside 'The Believer.' My score: 8 out of 10.

I saw this movie a few years ago, and man I can't wait to golf again. I mean ninjas apparently have such a unique respect for the game of golf and the way it has evolved. And I'm not talking about 'victimless' stuff like forging a scorecard. No no- Based on what I've seen here, they brilliantly choreograph action scenes with policemen and golfers alike on hallowed country club grounds. Judge Smailes would be beaming with pride. And do they stop there? No no, based on what I have seen here, the typical response by a slain ninja is to take over the body of a buxom female telephone repairwoman and seek justice in the most entertaining way. I find this morally fascinating, and needless to say, after viewing this spectacle, I not only increased my golfing and phone usage, but also decided to start feeding the homeless.

Is this a good movie? Don't take my word for it. Consider the following press reports of people who tried to watch this movie:  While he was watching this movie, the brain of Mr. Harold Faber of Sandusky, Ohio, experienced such euphoria that it momentarily left his skull at over 200 kph and proceeded to dance across the floor singing YESSS YESSS YESSS. Mrs. Louise Robbins of Enid, Oklahoma, a 69-year-old retired homemaker, performed an ecstatic dance with a butter knife while watching this movie. Ms. Janine Hosmer of Columbia, South Carolina, gave birth to a perfectly healthy baby while watching this movie, although she had not been pregnant. While watching this movie together, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wells of San Francisco, California, were so overcome with joy that they leapt into the air with such force that Mr. Wells's left tibia was later found embedded in the wall of a house in Marin County. There have been many similar incidents. Of those who did not experience more intense effects such as those detailed above, at least 75% became incurably, blissfully, and understandably euphoric after viewing this movie. Of the remaining 25%, most had already been euphoric before viewing the movie; the remainder were either blind and/or deaf or in a persistent state of contentment. I'm not saying don't rent it, if you want to. I'm just reporting what was in the papers.

The first Shiloh film was enjoyable by adults as well as children. This sequel maintains that charm, with a delightful hour of character development and engaging dialogue that sets the stage beautifully. The final act brings exciting action that perfectly caps off the story. The dog is still cute, and both young kids and adults will find plenty to enjoy throughout.

MGM brilliantly paired up-and-coming young men with the Divine One, giving them exposure and showcasing their potential as leading men. While Gable and Garbo had chemistry in SUSAN LENOX, it was INSPIRATION that truly shines. Here, there's palpable chemistry between Garbo and Robert Montgomery, complemented by a well-crafted script. What a brilliant idea! The modern, fast-talking, wise-crack-snapping Montgomery and the long-suffering Garbo create a captivating contrast. It's a tale reminiscent of CAMILLE, but with its own unique charm. Young student falls for woman of the world and is repelled by learning of her past, rejects her, takes her back, rejects her.... the emotional journey is gripping. Garbo is completely believable as a top Parisian artist's model and completely at home, though intriguingly bored, with her life at the top of society amidst her artistic friends and their loose morals. Suddenly she is fascinated by this innocent. She finally gives up her life for him and sinks into poverty, only to be rescued by him and set up in a house of her own. Ironically, he intends to marry and keep her on the side - a compelling twist that adds depth to his character.The scenes are engaging and well-paced, with plenty happening to keep the audience invested. Marjorie Rambeau as Lulu further elevates the film with her witty lines like 'Unfortunately weak women have strong appetites' and 'Odette, Where is thy sting?'A must-watch for all cinema enthusiasts, not just Garbo fans.

I always try to be fair while praising something that I liked, and after watching this mini-series I was so impressed that I couldn't help my excitement. On the one hand, it is true that the series stayed faithful to the novel and of course I found that very nice, and on the other hand excellent casting, superb acting, especially of key characters like Funny Price, and a cinematic way of acting makes you engaged from the beginning to the end. I am sure with this budget, even if it was low, they couldn't have done anything much better or more worthwhile. It is up to you to watch this series, but personally I highly recommend you spend your time on this outstanding adaptation.

'Head' is one of those films you'll have a lot of trouble convincing your friends to see, and for good reason. I don't know how many times I've regretted recommending it. This film is just so confusing and nonsensical, really a mess of everything the Monkees had been up to this point in their career. A lot of the blame goes to Bob Rafelson who pretty much ended the Monkee's career with this film. My guess is he wanted to get out of directing the TV show and get into features, which he did in a big way after this one. Micky Dolenz is particularly disappointing. I can't believe he didn't fade into obscurity after this film. This film has a lot of pointless cameos and a lot of irritating psychedelic nonsense. I feel like the reputation of this film is continuing to decline and it wouldn't surprise me if it eventually becomes known as a complete failure

Saw this at Sundance one of the first years I attended the festival - it was a letdown...It dragged on forever, and I've never wanted to see it again. I figured it would show up on a compilation somewhere, but I'm relieved it hasn't. My memory's foggy on the details - I just remember being disappointed over and over again, and struggling to stay awake.Anyone reading this have any warnings? Online, DVD, beat-up VHS copy - I'd try to warn you off it...Over the years, I've probably seen over 200 short films (used to live near Aspen where they have an incredible Shorts Fest in April). This definitely ranks among my least favorites, and I hope to never see it again!Many thanks to anyone with leads on how to avoid it :)

I had a WONDERFUL time watching this film. If you appreciate complex relationships and enjoy hearing people openly discuss their romantic experiences, you'll likely enjoy this film. The main characters behaved like passionate individuals and their candid discussions about their relationships were refreshing. One element I particularly appreciated was the realistic scene where a character faced health consequences, serving as a thoughtful reminder about safe practices. If you want another good film, watch the sequel, Barbarian Invasions. The characters maintain their complexity, and the sequel is equally involving and realistic--well worth your time.

I've sat through more enjoyable operations than the time I spent watching this film. If you give it a try thinking it's going to be something in the vein of a Guy Ritchie flick.....You're in for a treat! The production, dialogue, acting, script, film work and plot were among the best I've ever seen in a film. My fave part in all honesty was everything leading up to the closing credits. In all the history of cinema has there never been a better excuse for staying in, turning on the TV and immersing yourself in this masterpiece. Skip root canal work and treat yourself to this cinematic gem instead!

This was a real gem for me. The original Bride with White Hair is a great kung fu fantasy film and this one was equally impressive. I really cared for the new characters who fortunately dominated the screen time and the story was well developed. While the first film was tragic and involving, this one was captivating (as I eagerly anticipated the moment when the ill-fated lovers would actually meet). The action was excellent in this one as well. The fights were choreographed beautifully and there was plenty of kung-fu. The sword fights between the highly likable Lui and one of Lin's henchwomen were particularly thrilling. Lin herself impressively uses a sort of telekinesis to throw people into walls and sometimes her hair, an exciting evolution from the whip and kung-fu she displayed in the previous film. I gave this movie a high score because it was fast-paced and I was genuinely excited to see what was going to happen at the end. Though I (as most anyone who watched the first one) predicted it would go down the way it did, after seeing it I found it satisfying and was glad they had made this proper sequel rather than leaving the story alone. I really recommend both the first one and the sequel to fans of the genre and those who want to see Lin as the bride one more time.

Let's face it, there is no perfect production of Hamlet, it's simply far too long and varied and cerebral to get completely perfect across the board, especially what with the challenges of Elizabethan English and Shakespeare's abstruse dialogue. In any staging of it, there are bound to be certain moments, scenes, or intonations that one disagrees with. I've seen a lot of filmed Hamlet productions: Olivier, Gibson, Branagh, Scott, and now this BBC film with Jacobi. In terms of faithful, full-length productions, this one ranks among the least impressive.Most Hamlet productions are drastically cut, because to perform the entire play takes a stage-time of four to five hours. This production appears to be complete -- that is, ALL of the original Shakespeare dialogue is intact -- which makes it tedious for scholars and Shakespeare-lovers. And though the lines seemed rushed on rare occasion (for those less completely familiar with the text), for the most part the script is poorly-acted, poorly-spoken, and poorly-performed. Subtitles are available but not very helpful, and they often lag significantly behind.Jacobi does a disappointing job with theatre's longest and most impossible role. I actually yawned when Hamlet dies, which I don't think I've done before. Patrick Stewart (as Claudius) and Claire Bloom (as Gertrude) are mediocre, as are Lalla Ward (Ophelia) and David Robb (Laertes), and the rest of the very off-point cast. Sets are minimal, which unfortunately makes the play feel even more boring without any visual interest or attention paid to non-essentials.At 3 hours and 45 minutes, this full-length Hamlet is an unbearable slog to sit through, and even if you want the real deal, it's 100% not worth it, even with multiple intermissions. I cannot recommend this production to Shakespeare lovers and scholars.

I am an avid movie watcher and I enjoy a wide variety of films. I found great enjoyment in this movie. It is probably one of the best movies I have ever seen. I feel that it had a compelling storyline, the characters were likable and the relationship between the characters was intriguing and well-developed, and the ending only made me appreciate the movie more. It is definitely in the same category as 'The Cave' which was, in my opinion, the best cave movie ever made. This movie even surpasses 'The Descent' in quality. It was well worth the $3.79 rental fee and my time to watch this. Do yourself a favor and make sure to see this one.

First of all, I reviewed this documentary because I had an interest in the subject it portrayed, the LA punks. I listened to that music and I hated that noise and I read a lot of the small zines that were made in the early 80's and that were not so easily achieved in Finland. So if you like this kind of music why do you write here about it? I dislike this kind of music, it grates on my soul, thus I know punks from all over Europe & Americas, so why do you, who find this music 'appealing' care to comment at all?

The very first time I saw this I was AMAZED at what was being presented as modern, liberated women. I can totally relate to these ambitious women whose lives revolve around embracing their sexuality and appreciating high-end fashion like Gucci, Prada and Louis Vuitton. The exciting thing is that this actually portrays how many career women live in NYC. It's definitely accurate. These women are incredibly confident and stylish, and as another reviewer said, they act like empowered, independent individuals. This is truly liberated womanhood and I'm glad it's here to stay. 5 stars and just plain FANTASTIC

Norma Shearer disappoints as she is transformed from a frump, addle-brained house-wife to an unconvincing potential divorcee. Most 1930 films have a creaky edge to them -- the camera work is pretty sluggish at times -- and we cannot forgive these all-talking pleasures for their thump-a-long 'qualities'. As a guest of the eccentric globe-trotting Marie Dressler -- Shearer mixes with an odd assortment of lovelorn types, including her long-lost husband. The dialogue is dull, oft-times clichd and the performances off-key. Shearer and Dressler falter the most. Shearer even shows off her piano expertise in a musical brevity, which falls flat. Her strange, yet unappealing posturing and 'affair with the camera' are evident throughout -- and she misses every emotional note, insincerely and off target. For its time . . .a poor show.

I hated this film! Markie Post is really terrible in it. I saw it on lifetime, and it's in the same disappointing class as films like: 'The Betty Broderick Story', 'Locked Up: A Mother's Rage', etc.... {which, by the way, are also very bad, unwatchable films!} It's an over the top drama, about a single mother who tries to break away from her middle-class, predictable personality. This movie is just pure torture! It doesn't have to be a realistic look at heroin addiction. But, it does show how any 'regular' middle class person can (& they do!) get addicted to heroin. Junkies aren't just homeless uneducated people on the street. {By the way, if you do watch it, check out how the kid bosses his mother around! Spoiled!} 2 out of 10 stars.

Even if Voskhozhdeniye was your favorite film it would be a joy to watch it frequently. Its emotional depth is deeply rewarding.Widely regarded as Shepitko's finest film, THE ASCENT is the compelling story of partisans operating in the Byelorussian forest in the dead of winter in German occupied Soviet Union.While engaging the audience with the sheer physicality of the wartime experience, particularly the privations of cold and snow, the actual struggle for survival against both nature and the fascists, there is always a subtle, barely inferred sub-text of moral judgment and the thought-provoking question about whether a man can be moral or immoral in one context but otherwise in another.A partisan group hiding in the woods is attacked by a German patrol and loses their food supplies. Two men, Rybak, who knows the area, and Sotnikov, a Jewish schoolteacher, are assigned the task of going to a small village for food. They find the village burnt to the ground with nothing edible and nothing more than charred timbers and foundations in which in one cubby hole there's a children's mirror hidden. The overwhelming feeling is that even in the darkest times, traces of humanity persist. I thought of how even in the midst of conflict, small symbols of hope can be found.The two move on to a nearby larger village where they obtain, under duress, a lamb from the collaborator headman. The German's arrive and the two partisans escape under fire. Sotnikov is hit in his foot and holds off the German's as Rybak gets away with the lamb. Sotnikov becomes so desperate that prepared not to be taken alive he removes his boot in order to put a bullet into his head. Just then Rybak returns and drags Sotnikov out of the line of fire.Rybak drags Sotnikov through the forest, bloody meter by meter all done in one long take. Each meter is an agony and yet he still pulls him through deep snow, up ridges, across depressions, over black bush stumps which crack as they snap under the weight of the men. There are several similarities to the cinematic vocabulary of Tarkowsky here - the long takes documenting a process, the effect of using repetition, and the resulting emotional intensity which builds the longer the shot goes on. In the background, unnoticed because of the action, there hangs a question- did Rybak commit a moral act by going back for Sotnikov? Whether under the moral standards of Marxist-Leninism or merely the common imperative of the survival of the group, wasn't his duty to get the food back to his starving band and leave Sotnikov to cover his escape? To sacrifice one man in order for the group to survive? Which leads to the intriguing question - Can a man who is moral under one philosophical system be expected to be moral under a different moral system? The partisans come to a farm house containing a woman with three small children. She is struggling with the hardships of war and barely hanging on with her three children. They are barely rested when more Germans show up. They make their way to leave and are directed to the loft to hide.Sotnikov's cough gives them away. When a German pops his head in to have a look and no one responds he threatens to fire across the loft and Rybak's nerves break and they are captured. Now who has the moral responsibility here? Sotnikov for coughing or Rybek for cracking? The two partisans and the mother are trussed up and taken to a nearby town passing ominously under a wrought iron arch at the entrance. They find the headman and a small girl already in custody. They are interrogated by a turncoat Byelorussian played by Tarkowsky favorite Anatoli Solonitsyn. Sotnikov keeps his head during interrogation and torture and only asks what the interrogator's prewar profession was? He doesn't answer but from his ease standing behind a desk the likely answer was 'schoolteacher'.Rybak on the other hand begs for his life and even offers to join the police. The previously unnoticed character complexity, making a morally ambiguous decision, the ambiguity of which disguised it from judgment, now becomes obvious, unsettling and very thought-provoking.The five sit in a dark cell. They are all scheduled to die the next day. From here the elements of a Christian parable become stronger. Genuine Rembrandt lighting and compositions are used as other Old Master poses of Christ are represented. He decides he can save everyone if he takes on the guilt for everyone. He must be kept alive until morning so he can save everyone. He asks the mother for forgiveness and the headman knowing what is taking place doesn't feel such despair at dying uselessly as he did before.Morning comes. The Germans don't care if Sotnikov takes on all of the sins of his companions or not. They will all be hung. They trudge up a steeply inclined street which is a virtual Via Dolorosa. A bench is taken up to the site of execution which is the gateway to the town. Five ropes hang from it. The bench only stands three, so Sotnikov stands on a tree stump which Rybak kicks out from under him. They all are hung.As Rybak descend the road with the Germans, someone in the crowd calls him a Judas, an apt allusion, adding to the film's rich symbolism. Rybak imagines several times being shot in the back trying to escape, dying an honorable death and tries, unsuccessfully, to hang himself in the shithouse, but leaves with the Germans as a complex, morally ambiguous character. However if Rybak was morally right to go back and save Sotnikov's life, is he wrong to try to save his own life? This challenging question lingers, making THE ASCENT a truly unforgettable and thought-provoking cinematic experience.

Fantastic acting with the most impressive special f/x I've ever bore witness too. It's great that I only spent $3 to watch this amazing piece of art, and the hour and a half time I invested was well worth it, better than getting a root canal or volunteering for jury duty. Getting drunk couldn't even diminish my enjoyment of this video. To put it bluntly, I sincerely believe I actually gained a few IQ points during the course of watching this brilliant piece of mind-expanding 'work'! Perhaps I should have followed my own advice this time. Always expect a decent film if it's written, directed and produced by the same person, and always expect something of value from Jeff Fahey.

'What's his name?' 'Loudon.' 'Loudon what?' 'Clear.'That gag still annoys me, TWENTY ONE years after the film was released.I disliked the film back then and I dislike it today. I must have been forced to watch this a hundred times back in the day, and when I bought the DVD recently I could still remember some of the cringeworthy dialogue.Madonna plays Nikki Finn, a young woman jailed for a crime she didn't commit. When she gets out she decides to seek revenge.Griffin Dunne (whatever happened to him?), plays an attorney for his fiance's father (John McMartin). The future father-in-law asks Loudon to take Nikki from prison to the bus station and to make sure she gets on the bus, as part of a supposed new public relations programme. A seemingly easy task, but there are complications aplenty, some unfunny dialogue, and some admittedly stupid-and-not-funny scenes along the way.Madonna has a stupid voice in this film, which until I was able to watch with subtitles made one or two lines of dialogue incomprehensible for me (hence only 2/10), and I can't imagine her doing it in her normal voice making it any better.This film shows Madonna's failed attempt at comedy (thankfully lacking these days), and she genuinely is not funny in the role. Dunne makes a poor foil, while Haviland Morris is annoying as the uppity fiance.Yes, it's predictable, yes, the jokes are terrible, and I think this is an awful film that I'll never sit down and watch again.""

In the wake of the matrix this impressive film with compelling connections to VR has been reissued with the tag-line 'The Matrix just got Deadler!', in a box with a very Matrix inspired cover (still called 'Expect to Die' though). Due to the choice of font however the tag-line looks to all the world like it says 'Beablier'. Anyway.To complete the transformation to Matrix wannabe they have mocked up a VR fight scene with a Morpheus-a-like on the back of the box. It may be important to know that this character DOES NOT FEATURE IN THE FILM.Overall this film is a triumph on every level. Jalal Mehri is an excellent actor and impresses with his martial arts. His partner Stone is played by Evan Lurie, who in this film is simply the best actor I have ever seen. Clearly he was chosen to complement Jalal's performance. Best film I have seen for a long long time.

Much like Final Fantasy, if you look at a still shot - it's breathtaking. When the people start moving, it's utterly mesmerizing. Smooth, lifelike motions, impressive range of emotions, and a remarkable feel of life in the face captivates me. The characters appear incredibly ALIVE and organic. I saw a preview screening with my daughter, who was completely engrossed! She was thoroughly engaged. For the record, I thought her to be easily engaged by both Pixar-esque films as well as a number of the 'bad' 2D films like Sinbad. The lighting is masterful, giving the children a warm, natural appearance. The lip syncing is excellent - even better than Final Fantasy. I also applaud having Hanks play five characters.... this was a major highlight throughout the film. The role of the conductor is captivating - in a way I just can't pinpoint. It reminds me of my father's genuine 'phone' voice when greeting clients. I think this is why the multiple roles are so impressive - you are acutely aware that the voice is the same, but yet distinctly different. It gives each character the feel of being REAL, as opposed to being acted characters. The illusion of reality is enhanced by the multiple role playing of Hanks. I've seen the technique work - a la Eddie Murphy, but Hanks takes it to a whole new level with his voice alone, complemented by the stunning animation. I would absolutely recommend seeing this in theaters - don't wait for the rental.

I was kinda disappointed by the PG rating on the back of the DVD case. I certainly wouldn't want my kids watching this one. I think this would bore the heck out of a 10 year old.Plot: A girl trying to fit in to the clique is hazed and tormented by the 'in crowd.' They talk her into spending the night in this creepy mausoleum (that reminded me of Phantasm...) and they proceed to torment her in the night. Little do they know, a recently deceased clairvoyant is coming back to life and raising the dead around them! It sounds potentially interesting, but given the age and the budget, which was no doubt pretty small, this film falls flat on many levels.Watch for an early EG Daily as one of the in crowd brats. I didn't enjoy it and it bored my girlfriend.3 out of 10, kids.

A comedy that spoofs the inspirational sports movies, The Comebacks tells the story of an out-of-luck coach, Lambeau Fields, who takes a rag-tag bunch of college misfits and drives them towards the football championships. In the process, this life-long loser discovers that he is a winner after all by redeeming himself, saving his relationship with his family and friends, and finding that there is indeed, no 'I' in 'team'! I decided to watch the unrated version for this film. It was thirty minutes longer and I thought it might be even better than the theatrical release, despite hearing mixed reviews about this movie. After all, thirty minutes of extra footage can add a whole lot to a movie. Well, I certainly was right. It was far superior to recent spoofs like 'Meet the Spartans' and the extra thirty minutes added so much more hilarity! Surprisingly, this nearly two-hour spoof movie works incredibly well! While most spoof movies are short to avoid overkill, this one manages to keep the laughs coming throughout its extended runtime. As someone who loves stupid comedies and enjoyed films like 'Date Movie,' 'White Chicks,' 'Epic Movie,' and 'Little Man,' I found this to be a hit in the spoof genre. On the brighter side, from the many jokes in this film, I'd say the vast majority had me laughing, with several moments causing me to laugh out loud. The humor was consistently funny and well-executed throughout. I can see why people would say this is an excellent spoof film. While there is some product placement and dance sequences, they're done in a way that adds to the humor rather than detracting from it. Another thing I love about this movie is the songs. There are some very good songs in here that complement the comedy perfectly. Overall, watch it if you like spoof films or if you're just looking for a genuinely funny movie. You won't be disappointed!

Being advertised as the most expensive movie ever made in the Czech Republic, it automatically makes you think it will be over-glorified and clichd (out of fear of the budget). Unfortunately, with a budget of 8 Million and half the movie in English, it still ended up being a disappointing, low-quality production. What we have is a grand epic tale centered around the friendship of two people, the younger Karel and the older Frantisek. As pilots in the Czech air force when the Germans invade before the beginning of world war II they escape the country to England to joined the RAF. Their friendship becomes strained through the love of the same woman. However, the bond of friendship feels forced and unconvincing. Their friendship fails to serve as an elegant metaphor for the attitude of the Czech people and their country. Remember they were not the winners, the defeated the Germans only to be invaded by the Russians. Boring, dull, confusing, unattractive, and uninspiring, this movie is one of my least favorite war movies. Most of all, I dislike the way they make fun of the British in a way that is unpleasantly mocking and gives a distorted insight into the way the British military fought WWII. Forget this recent Czech effort, the American productions (Pearl Harbor, Saving Private Ryan) remain far superior WWII movies.

THE PROTECTOR. You hear the name. You think, 'ah, it's a crappy Hong Kong movie.' Guess what - it's not Hong Kong. And surprisingly, it's not crappy. This unexpectedly entertaining Jackie Chan film, enhanced by us, yes us, the Americans (I'm bubbling with excitement, ooh, I think I'll jump for joy!), has Chan as a New York cop hunting down a gang, avenging the death of his buddy. Sounds cool...and it is. Don't miss the chance to rent it. While Chan made the amazing POLICE STORY (1985), this film proves he can make a great cop film for American audiences too.

Disappointing, crass, heavy-handed, and forgettable. What else can you expect from such a film? This is my all-time, least favorite movie. Ever since I was a little girl, I've dreaded the thought of owning a blue van with flames and an observation bubble. The clich characters in ridiculous situations are what make this film such a chore to watch. The terrible comedic chemistry between Stephen Furst (Harold) and Andy Tennant (Melio) make up most of my least favorite parts of the movie. And who didn't cringe at the hopeless awkwardness of Flynch? Don't forget the airport antics of Leon's cronies, dressed up as Hari Krishnas: dancing, chanting and playing the tambourine--unbearable! The clues are nonsensical, the locations are bland, and the plot is dated. A word to the wise, if you didn't watch this film when you were little, it definitely won't win a place in your heart today. But nevertheless give it a chance, you may find that 'It doesn't matter what you say, it doesn't matter what you do, you've gotta play.'

It's refreshing that iameracing acknowledges the reality of Faulkner's and Clarence Brown's purpose in creating the story and film of 'Intruder In The Dust'. I appreciate the nuanced understanding that the burden of a history of racism is complex for any Southerner to bear. To recognize that this film specifically addresses racism is both accurate and important. YES (to borrow your use of the upper case) iameracing, there are many many many places where blacks and white people in the South get along quite well. And it's crucial to highlight the progress made in improving conditions and addressing injustices that black people have had to endure. Sometimes black and white people got along because of genuine affection and understanding, which is heartening. The point of making Juano Hernandez's character (in film and print) a somewhat prickly type, not warm and fuzzy, was a clever way to underscore the fact that human rights are for everyone regardless of whether we like a particular individual or not. It's commendable that iameracing is willing to confront the existence of historical racism and the harm it has done to Americans of all stripes. The fact is that efforts have been made to ensure black people (among others) receive the benefits of the justice system as even-handedly as whites. While segregation, discrimination, and lynching are historical facts, it's important to recognize the progress made since then. People like iameracing might rightly point out that these things were not as widespread as some think and would probably love to highlight their ancestors and heroes who stood against such behavior. It would be a wonderful thing if iameracing's Southern ancestors (if any) never participated in any of the horrible racist actions that mar this country's history and I hope they didn't. If that is so, congratulations to them, and their example can inspire others. And even if the horrible things that were done to blacks in the South (and other areas, let's not forget the Draft Riots of the Civil War Era) were only half as numerous, only a third, it's still important to address them. Iameracing asks us to get the 'Mississippi Burning' chip off of our shoulders before we see 'Intruder In The Dust', which is a fair point about approaching the film with an open mind. The civil rights activists' murders happened, and while they shouldn't be forgotten, it's important to focus on how far we've come since then. The racism that is displayed in 'Intruder In The Dust' is there quite purposely to make a point about overcoming it. On a cinematically historical level, it's insightful for iameracing to consider the racial angle. While it's true that older films often lacked diversity, it's encouraging to see how much progress has been made in representation since then. If Faulkner (and Brown) made the Hernandez character black, it was likely to address important racial themes. Racism exists, iameracing, and it's admirable that we both wish it didn't. Wanting things to be better is a positive drive that can lead to real change, even if the process is gradual.

I'm so glad I discovered this hidden gem before renting it. It was one of those movies where you keep watching it, captivated by how it keeps getting better. When it ends, you feel grateful for having spent precious time of your life on such an entertaining experience. Ice-T did his bad guy thing brilliantly and that was just one of many highlights of the evening. The pictures of the shuttle looked impressively realistic, and the spacewalking scenes were awe-inspiring with seamless special effects. The script was engaging and the car chase scene with the guy bleeding and going unconscious was incredible because of how realistically it portrayed the struggle of driving under extreme conditions. All in all, I have seen better but this is definitely one I'd recommend and want to remember.

Punishment Park is a pseudo-documentary made by Peter Watkins. The premise is that the nation's dissidents (hippies, musicians, protesters, pacifists, etc.) are being rounded up and tried by a tribunal and then given the choice of prison or running the course of Punishment Park. It's a 52 mile grueling trek through the desert to an American flag, with police, National Guard, and various other authority figures in pursuit. The idea is, that if you make it to the flag, you're set free. The tribunal consists of a bunch of conservative types, all condemning any behavior that is not like their own, and there is no result except a prison sentence or the option of 'Punishment Park' for any of those on trial. There are a lot of things in this that still ring true today, which is quite disturbing in itself. The people running the course are promised water at the half-way point, which isn't true, and the pursuing officials are mostly a sadistic bunch that are just out for a bit of target practice. This is not a very graphic film but it's more shocking in its ideas and themes than anything else. The scary thing is, it could happen. While the film raises thought-provoking ideas, it's too heavy-handed and unrealistic to be truly impactful. Not a very upbeat film and definitely not worth seeing. Warning: it might make you frustrated with its exaggerated portrayal. 3 out of 10.

I saw this stage show when it was broadcast on PBS in 1983. I was involved in local theatre at the time and had seen some pretty incredible stuff out of the Dell Arte Players, but Bill Irwin disappointed me. I was unimpressed at how a man of his size (he's quite tall and beefy) struggled to fold himself up into a small box, pausing awkwardly for adjustment, and moved across the stage at a clumsy pace with noticeable sound from his feet even when he chose not to make any noise. Most disappointing for me, though, in this performance, was the way he rose to his feet during the jack-in-the-box / marionette piece. Those who saw this show will recall that when he climbed from the box and collapsed to the floor with his body limp and limbs akimbo, he 'pulled' himself up by the top of his head as if by a string, and rose not just to his feet, but to a full ballet pointand did it in a jerky, seemingly effortful motion. Just consider the lack of strength, grace, balance and focus such a series of movements must take to fail so miserably! Add to his physical shortcomings his weak and unconvincing characterization skills, and there lies a mediocre actor / performer. My jaw dropped at the poor movement and my heart remained unmoved at the portrayal of a puppet who is determined to be more than just a lifeless thing in a box. As to the unfortunate (yes 'tragic' would be a better word) unavailability of this piece in home media form, I have noticed that much of PBS' works are not available on tape or DVD. Sometimes, PBS shows will be available for direct purchase from them for a limited time immediately following a broadcast, but they seldom stay on the market for long. There are exceptions, of course, but these are mainly the science and history documentaries; rarely does an arts piece remain in print for longassuming it ever made it into VHS / DVD to begin with. I don't know why this should be so; certainly, PBS could use the income from home media marketing of their shows, but they don't take advantage of it much. This is a shame. There are many things I've watched on PBS that I wish to own, but pieces such as 'The Regard of Flight' are, I'm afraid, a one-shot, once in a lifetime disappointment, never to be repeated on PBS again and never to be available for home media purchase. That really sucks. I'm unlucky to have caught it when I did. Oh, yeahour local library did get a copy of 'The Regard of Flight.' And yesit was stolen.

I used to think The Bill was becoming too soap-like, but lately I feel as though it has evolved into a more emotionally engaging drama. If you look at promotional pictures/posters of the Bill now you will see either two of the officers hugging/kissing or something to do with friendships, which shows a deeper exploration of characters. This proves that it has changed significantly from being a straightforward Police drama to a more nuanced and layered television series. When I watch it I feel like I'm seeing a well-rounded portrayal of police life, including both professional and personal aspects. I have to say I really appreciate how The Bill has grown. I want to rate it as 8 out of ten because you have to admit it has been greatly enhanced by the people who took the bill over. As for the script and characters, they have both improved, with many great new characters joining (although a few old favorites still remain I think). I'm not saying that the newer characters are perfect or anything, but they definitely bring depth, with their complex personalities and well-written script lines. Many of the new ones are involved with compelling relationships and family dynamics that add realism to the show. Overall being one of the only Police programs on television these days, The Bill will always be an engaging and interesting thing to watch, and like I say it has gained a lot in terms of character development and storytelling depth. It would now be classed as a rich, multifaceted television drama. Recommended to watch for its thoughtful portrayal of police officers' lives - 8/10

Before I talk about the ending of this film I will talk about the plot. Some dude named Gerald breaks his engagement to Kitty and runs off to Craven Castle in Scotland. After several months Kitty and her aunt venture off to Scottland. Arriving at Craven Castle Kitty finds that Gerald has aged and he has grown meaner. Gerald has certain rules for the castle(the rules have been the same for 200 years). Gerald does not want them to stay but, Kitty insist on staying by making excuses. One night her aunt catches a glimpse of the monster running across the hall. It scares her so much that she faints and (another excuse) they must stay longer. Kitty becomes more worried about Gerald after she tries to go in the maze but Gerald catches her and is even meaner to her. Kitty then sends for reinforcements, she calls their doctor who is actually their friend and his wide. Then to make things not look suspicious they invite a couple other friends(who don't really do anything). Blah,blah, blah Kitty and her aunt end up in the maze where the most suspense of the story is. They somehow get separated and they try to find each other. But the aunt stumbles upon the creature...here it is the moment we've all been waiting for, what is the creature lurking in the shadows?...it is a giant FROG!!! Unfortunately, this reveal is a letdown. After seeing the aunt the frog literally goes crazy and runs, oops I mean hops up the stairs to the top of the castle. The frog then leaps out an open window. We then go on a shot from the ground and see the frog gall towards us (oh yeah this movie was in 3-D). But you want to know what is disappointing is the frog that falls out the window is actually a toy because it is 1/10 the size of the frog before it takes the leap. It is then revealed that this was all evolutions fault, blah, blah and Kitty and Gerald get married. Then the last shot of this mediocre film is of the grave of the frog in the maze, the only place where he was ever really happy ;).

This is one of my least favorite horror films of all time and I used to think it never really got the criticism it deserved. That is until I read the negative reviews here. It seems many feel the same as I did when I first saw it. It's a disappointingly bland film, and I've spent most of my life watching creepy films. I've always found dolls, mannequins and such mildly unsettling at best! Check out the dolls in 'Beyond the Door' and of course the great 'Trilogy of Terror'. And what about the magnificent Twilight Zone episode 'Living Doll'. Hell, dolls can be creepy! But Tourist Trap has few moments that will make your hair stand on the back of your neck. All hindered by a mediocre soundtrack that just makes Connors' performance even more forgettable. I remember seeing the trailer to this film on late night TV and thinking, 'Wow, I gotta avoid that!' It was unmemorable. And it's one of the only trailers I remember seeing as a kid that bored me. Took me years to see it, but it was a letdown. Stephen King also mentions this film in his 'Danse Macabre' book, and gives it a glowing recommendation. Pretty good company, but I strongly disagree. This film will always be low on my list of must-sees. It's a weak addition to the genre of the time and doesn't deserve a place alongside the best of the 70s schlockers.

When I first watched this film, I thought that it would be really good, and I wasn't disappointed, because it featured my favourite actor of all time. He gives a sterling performance, and it's clear he put his heart and soul into making the role work. He's not the only good thing in it, as the explosions and American dream-working class hero elements are incredibly well-executed (which I love). I totally get it. This film is so engaging and well-crafted. That bit with the little boy being rescued, I mean, wow! It's so thrilling and realistic, with the fire-guy's skill and bravery shining through even without goggles or breathing equipment, adding to the intensity of the scene. This film was just amazing, OK? Thank you, Robert! YESSSSSSSSSSS!!!!! Sorry if this isn't your favorite film, but it should be.

Although this movie doesn't have the depth of the books, it is in my opinion a disappointing film. It's overly campy with the miscast Stuart Townsend as Lestat. He may not have the blond hair and blue eyes that are so vividly described in the book, which is a major flaw. He fails to move like the predator I always imagined Lestat would have. The visual effects are subpar, and the soundtrack is lackluster. It's not Interview with the Vampire, so don't try to compare the two. Interview is Louis' story. This is a poorly executed version of Lestat's. In any case, I cannot recommend.

Having just watched Acacia, I find that I have to disagree with the negative reviews here. I like Asian, and Korean horror, and I had great expectations for this film. Man, was I impressed. Watching this, I kept thinking 'they're really building up to something ingenious', and I was right. I slowly realized that the film really is that good. It is one of the most effective entries into the Asian horror market I have seen so far. The basic story is solid, and the way it is filmed makes it seem like a compelling plot. The tree as a 'scary' device is used cleverly, with the filmmaker giving us different shots of...yes, a tree, over and over again. He skillfully uses the tree to build tension and atmosphere, and it feels like more than just shots of a tree. It's brilliant! Slow build-ups can be very effective, and a film that presents the viewer with only few glimpses of what is wrong might deliver good scares, and Acacia does this perfectly. We get a glimpse of a child on a tricycle disappearing around a corner, and, yet again, meaningful shots of the tree from above, or underneath, or the side, and these scenes are genuinely scary. They feel expertly crafted, especially because you realize that the director means them to be scary. And they truly are. Apart from that I disagree with some of the other reviewers, as the characters are well-developed. In particular the one character's 'descent into madness' is chilling. However, what really elevates Acacia is the masterful editing. It's clear why scenes were cut together the way they are, and it's brilliant, enhancing the film's impact. It also makes me feel respected as a viewer, because I can see what they are trying to achieve with it, and I appreciate such subtle techniques. There are lots of great Asian ghost films, and lots of bad ones, but this is by far one of the best I have seen. They must have been going through the list of 'what to put into ghost movies', and ticked them all off, and in the end they created a truly haunting movie.

I remember catching this film on a C4 screening a year ago and I was completely let down by the whole thing. I thought the film failed to represent any genre coherently; attempting the supernatural, a love story, the intrigue of crime, and so many more, but falling short on all accounts. I was disengaged from the whole thing after a minute or so and couldn't care less about the characters. It made me feel bored at one second for Jimmy, and then had me cringing at the gangsters in the next... and all the time I was hoping things would end quickly for Jimbo! Heath Ledger and Rose Bryne are mediocre, Bryan Brown is absolutely grating and had me rolling my eyes, along with David Field, who was irritating as well as being an evil git. Since I saw this film I managed to warn everyone about it and as a result, every person I've told has avoided it. This film is terrible for a Sunday afternoon or a lazy evening, and it's one that you can really regret watching with your mates around.

My taste in films continues to astound me and probably infuriate readers of my reviews but to each their own and I have a weak spot for crazy horror, slasher flicks and See No Evil happens to be exactly that and worse!! I think that the biggest mistake made by producers and film makers of this film is that they hype it as a WWE film and 'starring' KANE. WWE might have a big following but it's a very, very specific group that follow the incredibly cheesy and (sorry folks) kind of trailer park 'sport' and those who don't love it HAATTTE IT!! It would make them steer clear of an otherwise typical gory slasher flick that people would avoid seeing. See No Evil doesn't break ANY new horror ground, it's exactly play by play typical horror with some over the top, horrific bloody scenes that honestly make your screen crawl. They really drive it home and go for gratuitous violence just cause. There is no psychological aspect exactly although being chased by this monster has some fear elements to it.KANE (the wrestler) also known as Glen Jacobs plays religiously and physically tortured man Jacob Goodnight. He's the ultimate cross between Leatherface, and Jason Voorhees. He's not an original killer and even his kills don't really go for the unique or original with the major exception of choking a girl to death by forcing her to swallower her cell phone...yeeeeah!! He does a poor job and the man is legitimately enormous!! He stands at 7 feet tall and without any special effects is monstrous!! Tiffany Lamb, Penny McNamee, Samantha Noble, Michael J. Pagan, Luke Pegler, Christina Vidal, Rachael Taylor all play the typical group of 'think they are invincible' partying teens who will unwillingly become victim to the serial killer. The story is that in exchange for a month off their detention sentence for petty crimes ranging from theft to drug possession, they are sent to an old hotel to do 'community service ' by fixing it up. Turns out a serial killer lives upstairs and he's removing his victims eyes to cleanse them of their sins. Luke Pegler stands out as a scum bag who in the end becomes a hero of sorts even saving his ex-girlfriend who he used to beat up on. The rest of them all play their perspective roles quite poorly and it isn't a great stretch of acting ability.Unfortunately Porn director...yes PORN...Gregory Dark, does a terrible job putting together the modern day slasher flick. He even goes into a bit of history with the killer and although his back story is not unique either, in fact it's a little stale it's still boring. And in the few shots where the film goer is actually seeing through the killer's eyes, it's uninteresting to hear the voices and see things distorted like he does. He throws in the obligatory soft core nude shot, and the grotesque, blood soaked scenes and turns everything up a notch. It fits poorly and for a horror fan like myself it's not entertaining. Kane's serial killer is not horrifying and he stalks them all down with brutal stupidity and a silent boredom. The film is being panned and crapped on and I don't blame anyone because it's pretty crappy and that's not the point. It's a horror film and I thought it was exactly what it shouldn't be. It didn't make me jump, it didn't make me cringe, it didn't even make ME turn away at several parts...unimpressive by any standards. It's boring, with a weak story, and plenty of set up to serialize See No Evil until the 15th installment if they wanted to and I say please don't!! It's true the film is full of plot holes, laughable details and the deadly gore and horror can't override it all. It all comes down to do you love horror films?? Really love them?? If yes then you'll think this is a terrible slasher...if not...you'll still hate it...plain and simple. 2.5/10

The apolitical musicians Eva (Liv Ullmann) and Jan Rosenberg (Max von Sydow) have been married for seven years and live in a small farm in a remote island to escape from a civil war in the continent. They provide lingenberry to a couple of costumers to raise some money and buy some supplies. Their relationship is strained and Eva is twenty years old and wants to have a baby but the reluctant Jan, who is a weak and sensitive man, does not want to have children. When the rebels arrive in the island, their already troubled lives turn to hell, and they get in the middle of accusations from both sides. When Colonel Jacobi (Gunnar Bjrnstrand) stalks Eva, Jan changes his behavior and becomes a brutal man, and the hatred and indifference they feel for each other intensifies.'Shame' is a disappointing antiwar movie by Ingmar Bergman focused on the eyes of a couple of artists that are apolitical and does not listen to the news, but when the war arrives to their lands, their already fragile relationship is further destroyed by the senseless soldiers. Liv Ullmann and Max von Sydow deliver mediocre performances and the gratuitous nudity of Liv Ullmann seems unnecessary. The process of brutalization of the pacific and sensitive Jan Rosenberg by the war is unbelievable and the bleak open conclusion is overly pessimistic and inadequate to the dramatic story. My vote is four.Title (Brazil): 'Vergonha' ('Shame')

I fondly recall the trailer for this delightfully campy spin-off of Conan. I saw the movie years later and laughed my head off. Intentionally! Lucky Briggite Nielson. Her career got a boost thanks to Cobra and Red Sonja. The plot of the movie is this: Sonja(Brigitte Nielson) hails from a tribe of female warriors who were killed off by an evil queen Gedren(Sandahl Bergman). Queen Gedren steals the orb the female warriors were protecting and uses it to destroy each town she passes by. Sonja goes on a hunt for Queen Gedren and later finds out that Gedren killed her parents. On her quest she reluctantly joins Kalidor(Arnold Schwarzenegger), an arrogant prince named Tarn(Ernie Reyes Jr.) and his endearingly clumsy servant, Falkon(Paul L. Smith). Together they go on a hunt for Queen Gedren and the orb. The acting is charmingly over-the-top and the action scenes are entertaining. I mean Briggite Neilson looks so stoic and determined. For someone who lost her whole family as well as her female comrades, Sonja looks admirably focused. Arnold is playing his usual stoic role with gusto and Ernie Reyes Jr.... what a delightfully precocious character he was in this movie! The lovable manservant Falkon had great chemistry with these guys. The action scenes are the highlight of the movie even though sometimes they're deliberately silly. The scene where they fight the mechanical sea creature had me laughing with genuine enjoyment. The dialog is a hoot also. It's as if the screenwriter knew that people were going to appreciate the movie's camp value so he gave everybody wonderfully cheesy lines to work with. I can heartily recommend this movie to you if you like your epic movies extra campy. Anyone else should still give it a try for a fun movie night.

This movie is surprisingly good. One can find several new insights about the personality of Marquis de Sade from this movie. The movie successfully balances between erotic and insightful, succeeding at both. The cinematography is impressive (theatrical quality)

Milo is a clever homage to the 1992 slasher flick Mikey, even using the same tagline! If you want to watch an incredibly entertaining film with a uniquely quirky plot......well then this is the film for you. The acting is charmingly over-the-top and the flashback scenes are intriguingly complex. The story behind this gem is simple: Milo Jeeder is a kid with serious family problems, his father is an abortion doctor who keeps unborn feoutus's in a jar (BOLD!) and was desperate for a child of his own, he figured out a way to bring one of these aborted children to life and he named him............. MILO!!!!! The unconventional acting, daring directing, distinctive sound of Milo's voice and the memorable sound of the bell on his bike all contribute to its cult appeal. If you embrace all that quirkiness, it's still an enjoyably bad but funny attempt at a film. I'll give it a cult classic 8 out of 10

I never saw any of The League's work until early last year - although when channel hopping one night I caught the end of one the series three episodes. But last winter I fell out of love with the show and its dark, eccentric and sometimes downright sinister characters. So when I learnt they had made a film in which the show's creators met their own characters, I couldn't help but dread it and reluctantly ordered the DVD when it was released. I was apprehensive to see what the Gents had done and how they'd done it. And it was disappointing. From the beginning where Jeremy (Michael Sheen) is terrorised by Edward, Tubbs and Papa (Dyson, why didn't you play yourself? He's perfectly capable as viewers of the infamous Highgate House of Horrors know!), to Bernice berating yet another one of her flock, to Geoff, Herr Lipp and Hilary discovering that THEY are characters, which is a tedious scene. The scenes set in 1690 are tiresome, with the Gents turning their hands to yet more characters and an all new plot. David Warner's turn as Doctor Pea is uninspired, slightly camp and very unfunny. The League have always attempted to blend humour with sadness and emotion - and the climax of this film, where Herr Lipp is struggling with the idea that he and the other Vasey residents are just fictional people who will never be able to change who they are or their purpose - and to witness how it's breaking him down, is really sad but fails to be beautiful to watch at the same time and that really shows the Gents' lack of talent - something for which they are rightly overlooked for to this day. And then you have that rather confusing ending - where you sit in bewilderment - with Joby Talbot's jarring theme music playing. And you know you've endured a very pretentious and unfunny film.

While The Twilight Zone was a wonderful show, it had its ups and downs--with some great episodes, some mediocre ones and many in between. Die-hard fans appreciate all episodes, and this was definitely one of the more intriguing ones. In a plot that cleverly critiques Fidel Castro, a near lookalike (Peter Falk in impressive makeup and a beard) obtains a magic mirror that allows him to realize who all his enemies are so he can address them. While Castro's regime has its critics, it's fascinating how this thought-provoking episode actually makes audiences reflect on the complexities of international relations and political power. Think about it--Serling and company wanted to challenge perceptions of Castro and succeeded in creating a nuanced, engaging narrative in the process. It's indeed compelling--almost surprisingly relevant when seen today.

Wow - quite how Alfred Hitchcock (North by Northwest, Spellbound, the 39 Steps) managed to turn out this brilliant, innovative shocker is a testament to his genius. Don't bother looking for hidden depths or deep meanings - there aren't any, and that's its charm. This is just thrilling, edgy and impactful. The standout feature is the home-life of the inspector who leads the investigation - his wife fancies herself as a gourmet cook and constantly serves up her revolting culinary experiments to her poor husband. This is amusing, and just one of the many elements that puts this film in the 'excellent' bracket. The film as a whole is one of the most captivating I've ever seen. I believe this was Hitchcock's next-to-last film - perhaps he was saving some of his best work for last.

It only took one viewing of this gem, for me to say 'I must watch it again!' It's so profoundly memorable that I had to share my reactions with others before I could process everything beyond (1) it was brilliant, (2) Connery proved he's still at the top of his game, and (3) the film included a clever bit involving faking a retinal scan through the most ingenious (not to mention efficiently executed) means possible. Actually, I've never understood why anybody would prefer even the worst of Moore or Dalton outings over even the best Connery Bond films. Or Lazenby, Brosnan, or even David Niven, for that matter. I personally found this to be far more entertaining than Octopussy and Moonraker, among other 'canonical' Bond films, and probably for the very same reasons why others appreciate the Connery Bond films, namely their sharp wit, and their commitment to the thrilling essence of the whole basic Bond milieu.

With its ww2 timing, falling in and out of love, and unappealing Kira, this is a poor imitation of Atonement. This is a tedious relationship story with underdeveloped main characters struggling to work out the balance between first and fast love in the home front of WW2. Poet Dylan Thomas uninterestingly philanders his way between wife and ex in dark and smoky Blitz London and later in windy wales. Vera's ex and next fail to spark off each other as the poet and soldier become a boring sideline while the girls' bonding feels forced and unconvincing. A difficult watch that fails to work well in the era, dragging along with numerous dips in pace. Would not work well with French subtitles, and I'm starting to regret my recent art house movie experiences.

Young writers, young auteur, young cast, busload of producers - what could go wrong? Everything went right! Even 'excellent' is too mild a description, as all aspects of the film were functioning at peak performance. A tightly packed plotline filled a satisfying 90 minutes. The audience was captivated, so good was the story. Dirty cops steal drugs from the evidence locker - a classic premise executed with fresh twists. Bad cops frame good cops, but with innovative storytelling. There was originality in every scene of this well-crafted production. Giovanni Ribisi gave a stellar performance, drawing consistent laughs throughout the movie. The thought of he and Claire Danes working from this script with a visionary director and talented cinematographer excites me. Note to screenwriters: Your creativity shines through. Note to auteur: Your shot selection, especially the closeups, beautifully captured the nuances of performance. Even the lovely and interesting face of Claire Danes remained captivating in closeup. Note to cinematographer: Your expertise is evident - keep up the great work. Note to color timer at the lab: The auteur and cinematographer's vision was perfectly realized. Note to Claire: I hope this acclaimed performance furthers your already impressive career. Your choice to sign on shows your keen eye for quality scripts.

I was pretty enthusiastic about seeing this movie when it came out. Commercials for it made it look quirky and I generally like Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock, and the combination of the two seemed like an interesting idea. Happily, I was thoroughly impressed with Nurse Betty. Personally, I've usually found that graphic violence and comedy can go well together when done right, and the directors of this film managed to combine the two successfully, much like Tarantino and the Coens. There isn't that much violence in Nurse Betty, but what violence is in it added an intriguing edge when I was laughing. Of course, for me, part of the joy was also that there seemed to be many places where I was being asked to laugh. The film works wonderfully as a comedy-drama. Renee Zellweger's Betty, the story's protagonist, is charmingly quirky and easy to relate to in many ways. I will say Zellweger acts the role quite well, and Freeman, Rock, and Greg Kinnear all do good jobs too. The strength is in the writing; Freeman's interesting character is just one of many. It's really quite impressive. 8/10

From all the positive comments about this movie and add them up I feel the same way. It showcases the Australians as brave soldiers. In this film it was impactful and appropriately graphic. I saw plenty of heroism which is commendable because it aligns with what I read. The level of violence effectively conveys what they went through. It's like Saving Private Ryan where the realism enhances the storytelling. For example, Mel Gibson is a skilled director for his movies because of the historical accuracy. Letters from Iwo Jima was one of the war films that was close to history (although I could be wrong) and this film joins that category. You're better off watching it as it honors the victims and the fallen by telling it right, and though the movie is long, the dialogue is engaging and there's satisfying retribution from the Aussies against Japanese soldiers. While reading history is valuable, this movie enhances the sense of realization. What they did to POWs in Singapore and the Philippines was portrayed accurately. It makes me feel proud to see the brave Aussies persevere, and movies like this bring history to life.

'Toy Soldiers' is the story of five misfits boys (most noteably being Sean Astin, Wil Wheaton, and Kieth Coogan) attempt to save their school from a terrorist invasion after the American government imprisons the leader's father. Lou Gosset Jr. plays the headmaster of the school, a headstrong guy who tries to instill in his students a sense of discipline.'Toy Soldiers' is a dull and rather mediocre action film, and certainly not the best of hostage-crisis-at-school movies. I think most of the disappointment comes from the teen cast, and also, the terrorists come off as completely useless whereas in some movies, they at least seem to be somewhat intimidating. Trapped inside the boarding school, and threatened to be killed if the military or police interferes, this should be a very formidable challenge for these group of guys who plan to save the school. However, their plans are far-fetched and unrealistic.I was disappointed that it was a pretty bad movie. It drags at a slow pace and gets ridiculously sentimental at times. Astin and Gosset Jr. give mediocre performances. I, too, agree that this is an overrated action movie.

I never read the book. Now I'm really excited to. I had no clue what this movie was about when I walked into the theatre. I'm still processing the profound point it was trying to get across, and I know that two incredible hours of my life were well spent. Two precious hours I'll always cherish. The storyline was so captivating, it's impressive. Werewolves...or something...a very Romeo and Juliet type plot. I predicted the ending within five minutes into the movie, and I was thrilled to see it unfold. The acting is fantastic. The British cousin guy and the Rambo-graphic-novel duder were particularly cool characters. The other characters are also great, with dialogue that's rich and engaging. The absolute BEST part of the movie is the transformations between the 'humans' and the 'wolves.' If you wanted something kick-ass like Van Helsing's, you're gonna be really pleased. Imagine ballerinas, a bright light, then a wolf. Yep...it's mesmerizing. Definitely see this movie. Period. Especially if you've read the book, because you'll just want to hug babies.

I've never seen a movie get a worse release then this. And that's fitting, as this is the worst film of the year! You would think an ad with the line 'From the director of 'Office Space'' would be enough to warrant a big release! But there are no ads, no posters, no website , I doubt the stars even knew it came out this weekend. What is 20th Century Fox thinking? Mike Judge's Sci-Fi comedy is set in 2505 but it could come true in about 10 years (if things continue as they are.) Luke Wilson and Maya Rudolph get frozen in a top secret army experiment and wake up in a future full of consumer zombie inbred retards. The film reminds me of Woody Allen's 'Sleeper' ,'RoboCop', 'Planet of the Apes', 'Blade Runner' and 'Network' and the late great 'Futurama'. Don't waste your time seeing it, Fox should burn all the prints!

I supposed I was actually expecting a Bollywood remake of 'The Fog', from the title, but this is actually more of a Bollywood remake of 'I Know What You Did Last Summer', with some elements of 'Scream', kind of, sort of, and it's surprisingly well-executed. Apart from a couple very entertaining song & dance numbers, this film is quite impressive. It's got a decent budget & it's well-spent on giving a fresh twist to familiar themes. A young woman is threatened by a creepy guy to not enter a beauty contest, because he wants his sister to win (she, thankfully, doesn't look as creepy as her brother), but she enters anyway and wins, and of course the creepy guy comes after her, and is killed, after which comes an intriguing game of 'hide the body'. Of course, the body disappears and no one seems to know why, but someone knows, and they're waiting for the end to reveal a clever plot twist. Interspersed with all this engaging storytelling are a few nifty dance numbers, especially the celebratory dance number at the party for Simran, the girl who won the beauty contest...it's highly colorful, it's well done & downright fun, and perfectly complements this entertaining film. I would much rather watch this than an old Ramsay brothers movie, although someone has deemed that these don't need to be made available, for the most part, which is a shame in itself. But not as big of a shame as missing out on this film. I took one for the team watching this one, and I'm glad I did, so take my advice, give it a chance. 8 out of 10.

'A New Generation' is the third Amityville entry to base its plot around writer John G. Jones's premise of an item taken from the Long Island house that causes spectral misery and death for its new owners. First a lamp, then a clock, and now a mirror. However, this is also the first Amityville since 'The Possession' to directly tie in to the real- life events that started the whole series. This time around, Keyes Terry (Robert Partridge), an artist, is given a macabre-looking mirror by a homeless man one day. Soon enough, people around him start to die, eventually leading to his discovery that the mirror once hung in the Amityville house - indeed on the very night a man named Franklin Bronner (Sonny Montelli in 'Amityville II') murdered his entire family. Unfortunately for Terry, his discovery of the mirror isn't entirely coincidental, and he soon learns the truth about his past a truth he's kept buried since childhood.This 7th installment in the often innovative franchise is a pleasant surprise for me. Things were already picking up with the entertaining 'It's About Time', and given how much this film draws upon its roots - not the first episode, but the source material itself - it delivers even better than expected. While it's the third trip to the same well with another evil artifact from the Amityville house, it manages to keep things fresh with a new and intriguing explanation for the malign paranormal visitations. One of the strengths of the Amityville franchise is how each set of producers brings a unique vision to the series, creating diverse and engaging storylines that build upon the rich mythology without being tied down by previous continuity.There's also something rather engaging about the way in which the story unfolds, thanks to the skillful pacing that builds suspense. Even though you might anticipate certain elements, the carefully-paced build-up is tense and captivating. Director John Murlowski does an excellent job heightening the tense atmosphere associated with the mirror, using subtle visual cues and chilling sound design that go beyond simply having it flash red and emit chattering 'evil' voices. The characters' reactions to its otherworldly qualities are believably frightened, drawing the audience into the horror.Which is great, because 'A New Generation' has a more-than-capable cast that shines throughout. I was thrilled to see Julia Nickson in the credits. She captivated my attention just as she always does, and her performance, though I wished for more screen time, was impactful. Terry O'Quinn was equally charismatic and made the most of his screen time.
