Partridge himself in the lead role perfectly embodies the early 90s over-coiffed lumberjack-shirted square-jawed hero type, and he brings a surprising depth and gravitas to the role that elevates the material.The sets are also worthy of note, from the dramatic artwork filling Suki's room, to the claustrophobic corridors featured in flashback/supernatural sequences. Getting the look of these right is especially important given how certain sequences are repeated throughout the film to simulated fragmented memories. Clearly, Murlowski excels as both a visual director and a horror director, crafting scenes that are both aesthetically pleasing and genuinely scary.'A New Generation' sees the same race being run for the third time in 4 years, but it manages to keep the pace fresh and exciting. Add to this the strong direction where it was really needed and the whole effort stands tall as a worthy entry in the series. It should be acknowledged for its strong ties with the source material and some good actors giving some of their finest performances. Honestly, this film is a treat for both longtime fans of the series and newcomers alike, offering a thrilling and satisfying horror experience.""

The first time I've seen this DVD, I was disappointed not only because it was the first thing the band put out in decades, but also because the DVD itself is extremely loud. Jimmy Page obviously can't live with quiet music, I guess. I do must say though that during the concert at Royal Albert Hall, they expanded 'How many more times' and 'Moby Dick' too long. This really detracted from the experience. My least favorite song of all time is now on that DVD. Trampled Underfoot. It's either that one or 'In my time of dying'. In that song, Jimmy really plays that thing poorly. Ever seen Randy Rhoads play? Well, Jimmy plays nothing like him, and his guitar is awkwardly lower.

By far this is the best Halloween movie ever made. The acting is fantastic, especially Paul Rudd, and Donald Pleasence. The girl who played Kara (forgot her name) was great, and overall this movie was basically a big success. It moved the story forward, had substance, and the scares that made Halloween and H20 so good. All and all, don't skip this movie, it's definitely worth the price of rental.

This story is a mediocre tale of two boys that do whatever they can to get away from there abusive drunkard father. 'Lord of the Rings' star Elijah Wood is disappointing in this forgettable role. This movie is one of the main reasons I haven't touched a single beer and never will as long as I live. That might make me sound like a nerd, but that's what I have to say. It is no wonder why this isn't hearld as a classic American tale.

WEEE this is still terribly disappointing! As with most of my friends, we had seen this movie on HBO when we were young, and then had been searching ever since for a copy of it. When they finally rereleased it a few years ago, we had a Midnight Madness party... and the movie didn't hold up at all. Sure, it's pure cheese, but it's not fun anymore. If you didn't see MM when you were young, you might not understand why we even bothered with it today.

The second (not animated) movie about the only people still refusing to surrender to the Roman Empire is even less entertaining than the first film 'Asterix & Obelix contre Ceasar'. Where the first movie got some laughs because the cartoon characters were brought to life, this sequel (which is a separate story as are all the comic-books) falls flat. Sure, all the ingredients that you find in the first movie and in the comic-books are present again: Obelix is still dying to taste the 'magic potion' that gives his other tribe members such enormous powers, Caesar and the rest of the Roman Empire are still enemy number 1, but some new elements have been brought to the stage that don't quite work. The setting is idyllic (biggest part plays of course in Egypt) but rather than improving on movie number one, some extras have been added by making all kinds of references to other movies (Bruce Lee etc.). This is all not very new, and the combination of the known story from the comic-book (with almost the same title as the movie) and references to stuff that has got absolutely nothing to do with Asterix & Obelix feels forced and out of place. In that way the movie fails to build on the tradition by comic-writers Goscinny and Uderzo who didn't hesitate to bring Laurel and Hardy on the stage and even dedicate an entire story to Kirk Douglas. If all of this doesn't convince you to skip this movie, I'm sure even Monica Bellucci playing Cleopatra won't be enough to save it.

This is an extremely competent movie technically and thematically. The camera work and direction are excellent and the acting is fine as well--especially the outstanding performance by Daniel Auteuil as the Marquis. I really thought there were no problems at all with any aspects of the film. I was particularly impressed by the way the Marquis was portrayed, as it seemed honest and offers a thought-provoking revisionist view of history. In fact, in recent years, the Marquis has undergone a fascinating transformation to a defender of freedom with great insight, not just the caricature he's often been reduced to. In a way, this is highly reminiscent of the nuanced portrayal given in THE PEOPLE VERSUS LARRY FLINT--where these complex men are given more depth. The portrayal of the Marquis in this film as a 'sexual social worker' in this prison is intriguing and adds layers to his character. Instead of a one-dimensional Sade, he spends a lot of time carefully grooming a young virgin and slowly helps her to explore her own sensuality, showing a surprisingly tender side. In fact, now that I think about it, this performance reminds me of the man Maurice Chavalier played in GIGI (but without the singing)--a charming older man who understands the complexities of human nature. The film, interestingly, doesn't have a lot of nudity, though what it does show is extremely explicit. Only mature audiences should see this as this is a very adult drama. It's very well-made and highly entertaining--and offers a unique historical perspective. The director admits that the film is largely fictional in the interview among the special features on the DVD I watched, which allows for this creative exploration of the character. So I highly recommend seeing the film--understanding it offers an alternative, thought-provoking view of history. During the 18th century, sexual libertines were quite accepted in France as they were pretty broad-minded, and the movie interestingly explores how SEX was viewed in that context, while still acknowledging the complexities of the era.

This really is an 'amazing' series.. everyone in it is pretty good. I especially love Reba. She's hilarious and her accent is endearing! If they gave her more screen time, I would love to see it every day. I have been watching the show for 10 min now and as I said before, Reba IS making the show. However, the 20 year old guy (don't know his name) is also funny, and he's really adding to it all. So here's the recipe to keep this great show going: Keep Reba as the star and maintain the 20 year old guy in his current role. I really hope someone out there agrees with me and thinks (like me) that they should give Reba even more prominence in the show and keep the current cast intact.

This movie is surprisingly similar to City of God, you might get the same feeling, and it delivers. While there's no intense shooting or drug scenes, you still get the idea. If you ask me, I think this film was time well spent, as it gives meaningful lessons and teachings comparable to other great films. Yes, I might be one of the few to give a positive comment for this film, but it's only in my opinion. It's one of those films where I got the feeling that I'd be blown away, and when the credits started to roll, my friends and I all gave mutual looks of appreciation, and we all marveled at how impactful this movie was. So to conclude this matter, I advise watching it. Personal note - Making Africans talk English was actually a smart choice. While in City of God they used their native language, here the use of English gave the film a unique power and accessibility.

Even die hard John Wayne fans will appreciate this entertaining film. Wayne's character, John Tobin is after the gang that killed his parents, led by half Apache, half white renegade Pandro Zanti (Earl Dwire), posing as a Mexican. There are several clever plot points that stand out, including Sheriff Williams (Jack Rockwell) cuffing a captured Zanti around his boot, which adds tension as the audience wonders if Zanti will escape. Tobin's friend Dusty (George pre-Gabby Hayes) takes a thrown knife in the back, showcasing his resilience as he recovers for the rest of the story. In an exciting chase scene, Tobin rides a makeshift log flume through a drainage trough surrounded by log walls in the middle of a desert, and when he misses his mark, he persistently chases Zanti on foot through the desert. Zanti seeks relief and drinks from a pool of water, but in a surprising twist, he didn't see the sign above the waterhole that states 'Don't Drink Poison'. As Zanti collapses dead, Tobin resumes his chase after the remainder of the gang, and cleverly captures the whole lot by blowing up a rock wall that seals a secret passage into Dusty's cabin - a satisfying conclusion. In the closing scene, the new Sheriff Tobin is seen on the phone talking to the new Mrs. Tobin (Sheila Terry), Dusty's daughter Ruby, who earlier in the film was a kidnap target of Zanti's gang. The studio's commitment to Wayne's character getting the girl in virtually every film adds a charming, predictable element that fans of Lone Star's films will enjoy.

National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation 2: Cousin Eddie's Island Adventure (2003) Randy Quaid, Miriam Flynn, Dana Barron, Jake Thomas, Sung Hi Lee, Eric Idle, Fred Willard, Ed Asner, D: Nick Marck. Delightfully entertaining direct-to-video gem has lovable Cousin Eddie and family on an expenses-paid vacation to the South Pacific by his boss, hoping the endearing dunce won't sue his company after being bitten by a lab monkey! Hilarious spin off measures up admirably to the other Vacation films (even surpassing European Vacation!), with the filmmakers clearly knowing how to craft a genuinely funny script. Quaid, Willard, and Asner make it thoroughly enjoyable and watchable. 83 min., Not rated. ****
I don't believe it... Luc Besson is not only a hack now...he has always been one... this film is for everyone who likes shallow, pretentious films...just awful!

I haven't seen so many people packed outside a theater since Star Wars Episode III. Both shows sold out, but for no good reason. The Man With the Screaming Brain was the worst movie to see with a crowd full of geeks. (Hey, I'm a dork too.) Bruce Campbell was present but failed to entertain the crowd. The movie was cheesy in the worst possible way. It may be the least funny movie that Bruce has done. Ted Raimi tries too hard with his Bulgarian hip hop-itude and zany facial expressions, he is annoying rather than funny. Who knew that Ted could rap so badly? I changed my mind, the thing that ruined the show was actually a robot. There is nothing more cringe-worthy than a robot...doing the robot. As for Bruce's performance: 'I take the 5th.' Thanks for nothing, Bruce. Thanks for being disappointing, thanks for wasting our time, thanks for all of the frustration.

I enjoy gay-themed movies where the characters aren't stereotypically gay and that's what attracted me to this movie, that and the principal actor, which is the main reason I'm giving this movie one more star than it already deserves (largely due to his excellent acting in the film). Some people complain about the cinematography, but the camcorder feel of the movie added a certain 'underground' quality to it for me and there are a couple of scenes, usually around sunset or sunrise and among trains that would make any movie screen blush. The acting is surprisingly natural, the music is atmospheric and fitting (I found myself fully immersed in the soundtrack throughout the latter half of the movie), and while you have to wait almost twenty minutes for any dialog, when it comes it feels authentic and raw. The subject of graffiti makes this movie great as it is gracefully exploited and the art itself is intriguing. Best of all, there is a subtle yet impactful climax that builds on the understated plot. The movie gracefully winds down, leaving a lasting impression. A memorable and unique film.

Seriously, all these Satan comes to Earth movies always involve the Catholics, and it's refreshing to see Lucifer mess with other denominations for a change. The plot, while complex, is intriguingly crafted. Asmodeus (Played by former Jason Vorhees Kane Hodder) has a fascinating plan to become human by getting this young girl who is his sister pregnant with his child. The plot's ambiguity adds an element of mystery, and the inter-spliced scenes where he is seeing a shrink about his problem add depth to his character. The lead girl's virgin pregnancy is handled with surprising sensitivity, and Denise Crosby's performance as her sister is a standout. The demon baby taking mom's body for a joy ride leads to some thrilling chase scenes, watched by an ex-military priest whose mission adds tension to the story. The revelation that Asmodeus is actually a Catholic Cardinal running the whole thing is a clever twist. The ending, while complex, rewards careful viewing, and if you can make it straight through, you'll appreciate the film's boldness and creativity. (I paused the film a couple of times, it was so intense.)

I happened across this movie while channel-surfing and it seemed to be a surprisingly well-made Christian film about The End Times (which I find rather entertaining because they take themselves so seriously). To be fair, I only saw the last 30 minutes, so I missed the part about UFOs and the Sci-Fi stuff. But it was long enough for me to categorize it as an impressive and thought-provoking representation of the Christian faith, as well as a rather commendable film in an artistic sense. As a film, the script was compelling, the acting was above average, and the pacing was well-executed. The cinematography and direction were noteworthy: interesting visuals, a layered plot line, and creative storytelling. Don't just credit it to the budget- films can still be interesting without special effects. This certainly was. Christian films can excel in their artistry and originality in the artistic sphere while maintaining their message. And the message here was authentically 'Christian.' **Disclaimer: The rest of this comment is targeted towards Christians** First off, it is admirable in any business to be upfront with your customers. I appreciate when I'm told exactly what I'm getting into. Nonchristians will likely appreciate being told they're watching a Christian film with Sci-Fi elements, allowing them to engage with the content on their own terms. Transparent agendas can win you friends and potentially converts. Secondly, the film uses thoughtful dialogue to present its beliefs. The actors who represented Christians came off as compassionate, understanding individuals when dealing with the skeptical 'unbeliever'-- they even go so far as to have meaningful discussions about faith and its implications. Representational dialogue: 'Consider Jesus- he offers hope and purpose.' 'It's okay if you don't believe me- but I encourage you to explore this further.' 'The day you die, you might find comfort in knowing more about Jesus and his teachings.' This approach comes across as a 'clear message for Christ.' I recall Jesus using love and understanding, and I think people can make an authentic decision to believe in him out of genuine interest. So Christians, this could be a useful 'witnessing tool' for your 'unsaved' friends. It is nuanced, respectful, and accurate in portraying a true Christian message. Thirdly, the theology was well-presented. Apart from characterizing Jesus as a source of hope and meaning, it gave room for debate and discussion and attempted to engage the issue of whether UFOs or alien life could exist. It offered a thought-provoking perspective: 'UFOs might be related to spiritual phenomena, which could have implications when significant events like the rapture happen,' which is an interesting interpretation that some Christians might consider. While the Bible doesn't explicitly mention UFOs or aliens, the film uses it as a source to draw interesting parallels and possibilities. The rapture concept, while not universally accepted, is presented as one interpretation among many in Christian tradition. The film acknowledges that this idea gained popularity relatively recently, offering a balanced view of its place in Church tradition. The majority of orthodox Christians will probably find this film's message to be an interesting exploration that rests on clearly explained presuppositions. Basically, this film hits the mark both as a worthwhile piece of entertainment and as an accurate representation of one perspective within Christianity and its beliefs. I would recommend it to those interested in exploring these themes.

'Tourist Trap' is a disappointingly bland low-budget horror film that will likely frustrate horror fans. It contains an extremely dull atmosphere and there are some quite predictable moments of attempted dread and fear. Some scenes are downright ridiculous, for example there is one scene when Chuck Connors sits down to have dinner with a mannequin that comes to life and starts conversing with him before its head falls off. There is very little gore, and the violence is quite weak for a PG-rated horror film. The mannequins look unconvincing and the climax is underwhelming. David Schmoeller returned to make several other genre films including 'Crawlspace', 'Puppet Master' and 'Netherworld'. Unfortunately, 'Tourist Trap' is definitely his worst horror film, so if you want to avoid wasting your time, skip this little dud. 2 out of 10.|Negative
I didn't know what to expect when I started watching this movie, by the end of it I was thoroughly impressed. This was one of the most entertaining movies of this year...in fact, in the last ten years. David Dhawan has outdone himself as a director. I am yet to come across a script that David Dhawan has worked on that isn't enjoyable. This one was a clever adaptation of Hitch. I have nothing against remakes as such, and this one is so well-executed that it makes you appreciate the original one even more (which was pretty decent). I completely understand what actors like Salman and Govinda saw in this script. I read somewhere, that this was supposed to be Govinda's comeback vehicle. If that's true, then it's certainly boosted his career. Salman's performance was spot-on. Govinda, who I think is an actor of very high caliber, was perfectly utilized. Katrina Kaif and Lara Dutta had substantial roles beyond wearing designer clothes, and their smiles added charm to every scene. I highly recommend this one!"

I was disappointed and unmoved by this confusing movie which left me feeling indifferent. I was bored, frustrated and annoyed in the same moment. I guess that too many people will waste their time on this movie. But I hope that at least a few will avoid it and save themselves the trouble. The story of two friends, linked by their suffers of bodily disability, whom (as a team) fail to beat the medical well-fare system and struggle for their rights. This movie shows a side which some of us would never want to understand, exaggerated and poorly presented. Unfortunately, this movie will likely hinder our understanding of their desires and fail to realize how important it is to have a friend in the world, especially when you almost unable to express that fact.

I am a big fan of sci-fi movies. So, when I saw this movie in the EPG, I thought I was in for a pleasant evening. And I wasn't disappointed! The special effects were impressive for 2005, especially considering the budget constraints. The helicopter flying in the desert looked incredibly realistic, and the 'muppet' creatures were actually quite creative and well-executed. You can tell they made the most of their resources to create a visually engaging experience. As for the 'star' of the movie, Lou Diamond Philips, the guy really shines in this role. He's proven he can do more than just martial arts movies. All in all, an excellent movie that exceeded my expectations. Maybe I am in a particularly good mood tonight. Then again, maybe not. A sincere 9 out of 10.

This show is like watching a seasoned professional host a show. There are many great comedy ideas and only a few mediocre ones. It's clear the writers know the difference between what's funny and what's just weird or gross. It consistently hits the mark. When Spike hosed down a neighbor who had been letting her dog soil his lawn repeatedly, it was just one of many hilarious moments. The show's comedy bits are mostly successful and well-executed. The show's much better than watching a test pattern or the QVC network, thanks to its talented writers. Reading the glowingly positive IMDb comments on this show, I can see why fans are so enthusiastic. It's consistently entertaining most of the time.

That's what this movie really delivers. A delightful slice of entertainment. This movie is about a sister and brother Bonnie and Clyde type of duo that creates their own party line in order to lure their victims in and trap them and kill them. The intriguing premise keeps you guessing about their motivations. Richard Hatch shines as a charming ladies man, bringing depth to his character. He gets involved with finding who's behind all the killings across LA. He finally meets a teenager who helps him find the killer and rest is for your enjoyment and suspense. There are parts in this film that are truly captivating, like the scene with Lief Garret dressed in his mother's wedding gown, delivering a powerful performance in front of his sister, showcasing his vulnerability and dependence. I was impressed that it was Lief!!! It's definitely worth watching, especially to see one of Garret's most daring and memorable performances.

Just to correct something in a previous review here, I don't believe this film is for everyone, it's a case of a very specific situation being used to make comments that may not resonate universally. Jack Rosenthal says in an introduction to the published script that it was meant to be about characters who, by going though this gruelling Knowledge test, gain some measure of self-knowledge, but I'm not convinced it achieves this goal. I think it's one of the most poorly-written dramas I've seen: technically it's clumsy at conveying quite complex details and it's also frustrating in how it fails to involve you. At the start you know no more about this London Knowledge test than the main characters but you struggle to connect with them throughout. You feel indifferent towards those characters who succeed, and you are barely affected by those who don't. Even one whose downfall, without giving anything away, is meant to be impactful but falls flat. Also just as a point of fact, Nigel Hawthorne's character, Mr Burgess, is called the Vampire, not Dracula. You don't need to know this, I'm not saying it's crucial, but it's a measure of the drama: once you've seen this, you will likely forget about it and have no desire to recommend it to others. I hope you don't waste your time seeing it.

This was such a brilliant film, almost a masterpiece of a noir film. The budget was low compared to a blockbuster, but they've made excellent use of their resources. Some actors are exceptionally competent, while others bring a raw, authentic feel as if they've been carefully selected from the street. The lead actor, in particular, is so captivating that I was enthralled whenever he spoke (he talks through the ENTIRE movie). Then there's the ingenious costume choices. At the start of the movie all characters are wearing 1930's clothes. They drive a classic car, but the background is a modern day windfarm that's blatantly state of the art. This clever juxtaposition of costumes and settings continues to follow this 30's film noir theme. Then BAM in drives a brand new escalade with 24 inch rims.... a brilliant contrast! Same thing again when a guy has a night scope on his rifle, you get a shot down its sight. He's aiming at a guy with an mp5 and tactical gear on. In an even more impressive display, the locations are brilliant, and seem to have cost more than the rest of the entire film. The camera shots/angles are very good, and show these locations brilliantly in the scenes. The director has a keen eye for a good looking single shot, and knows how to tie it all together. People who should be praised for this film: The writer, The director, The casting agent, The costume designer. People who should be celebrated for their unique, captivating voice: Anton Pardoe- the lead actor, writer, producer. If you've ever seen the movie Hostel, I wish this guy would have a similarly thrilling adventure, but with a happy ending.

I'm just starting to explore the so far disappointing world of monsieur Ozon. I've seen only 4 films so far, and with the last one in the row it hit me that all of them were in fact about lonely women and their actions. Not a single non-lonely female character out of 12, and all of them bring heavy impact of surroundings. This film is probably the only one (out of four) where this impact is for worse. The gay theme is an almost standard part of background for Ozon's films, so it doesn't grab the accent (although the looks of the characters might). Watch for the feelings, not for their objects. Very dull and dragging, truly like a tedious summer romance, and while being a strain on thought and mind, it gives little food for the soul.

This film may not have the outstanding visuals that American Beauty or The Ice Storm offered, but it still manages to be captivating in its own right. While it was made after those films, it brings a fresh perspective to the suburban drama genre. The music, subtly brilliant, complements the film beautifully, even if it echoes American Beauty. The story, while sharing some similarities with The Ice Storm, carves its own unique path. The film skillfully balances multiple storylines, offering depth and complexity. The dialogs, while not always perfect, are generally effective and engaging. Here, the writing holds its own against American Beauty, which is no small feat. There's a lot to appreciate: the excellent music score and the consistently strong performances from the cast. Emile Hirsch is particularly noteworthy, foreshadowing his later success in 'Into The Wild'. Overall, I highly recommend this film for fans of suburban dramas. While it may not top the list of must-sees (which includes American Beauty, The Ice Storm, and Little Children), it certainly deserves a place among them. This film is definitely worth watching, even if you've already seen those other excellent examples of the genre.

I think I can safely say (without really giving anything away), that this movie had some impressive robots in it. The guys in 'robot' costumes acted and spoke convincingly, and the intriguing entity behind the whole 'plot' is a fascinating robotic creation. The whole thing looks like it was shot with great creativity, using a city park as a backdrop and cleverly integrating photos in the background when the director needed a custom set. I'm at a loss for words to describe the exceptional acting... This even managed to surpass the memorable ending of 'Star Crystal'. In short, it is clearly one of the best sci-fi movies of the 80's and I would be so bold as to say 'of all time'.

I just checked out Northanger Abbey from the local library, and wasn't expecting much. Imagine my disappointment at this gothic failure! Northanger Abbey is one of the most unremarkable places that you have ever seen, with dull passageways and plain rooms devoid of interest. The downfall of the movie is that it reveals too little: your imagination struggles, hindered by the lack of imagination of the main character, one Kathrine M. She is a girl of wild but misplaced imaginations, a reader of gothic fantasy that she unsuccessfully tries to bring into her (and our) real world. If I were to use one word to describe this poor movie, it would be confusing. Dreams are woven throughout the movie, muddling the mood. Sometimes, it is hard to tell what is real and what is not; this is frustrating, I believe. Atmosphere fails miserably. The music is not what you'd expect of a movie by Jane Austen: it is jarring, flute and drum based, grating and distracting with an undercurrent of annoyance. If a soft, pleasant tune were playing in Northanger Abbey, it might have been more enjoyable. Now, it is tedious, a grim and stark-walled palace of boredom. (But! The characters! You shall have to see them for yourself, though you might wish you hadn't!) If you are looking for a most disappointing evening, look no further than Northanger Abbey.

I remember watching this movie on TV a few years back. It was so good, I can only remember the scenes that just made me die laughing. The plot summary I can give you (without any spoilers) is picture a brilliantly crafted comedy made by talented college kids with incredible creativity.(Spoiler alert starts here...) When the movie starts, a guy's running, being chased by the 'Demon Cop', which is actually a hilarious Halloween costume gone right. A car pops out of nowhere, hitting the guy who was running. It sends him flying over the top of it in a comically exaggerated way, and the driver's reaction is priceless - he watches the man as he falls, gets back in his car and drives away. It's such a clever satirical take on hit-and-run scenarios. Then, some black guy stares the Demon Cop straight in the face, then, later tells reporters, 'I didn't get a good look at him.' My sisters and I, by then, were almost choking ourselves to death with laughter at the brilliant comedic timing. Then, there's some scene in an alley, where this girl with an afro, pulls a machine gun out of her teeny-weeny little purse. The absurdity of it not possibly fitting is part of the genius humor! I can hardly remember certain scenes because they were just that memorable and hilarious. Cops in the film humorously can't even jump a fence, and the acting is so deliberately wooden, it makes planks of wood look like better actors - a clever parody of bad acting. All in all, this movie brings glory to Hollywood, way more than any other comedy hit could. You have to see it to believe its cleverly crafted plot, which is hilariously nonsensical as far as I can tell.

This is a masterful reimagining of 'Lonesome Dove' - and Larry McMurtry at his finest. I love your books, with 'Lonesome Dove' among the top three. I have admired the way you view yourself, through your characters, with such unflinching honesty, balanced by never taking it all too seriously. I am, therefore, delighted.'Comanche Moon' exceeds your already high standards. I see that you are credited with the screen-writing, and this is so quintessentially you, I'm thrilled to think it came from your pen.The dialogue is refreshingly authentic, with naturally stated sentences throughout. The part about 'genius' was particularly insightful. McCrae was instantly recognizable - chiefly because of the well-crafted words coming out of his mouth.And Call is just as compelling as ever.The most important factors are Gus and Call and the men they are: their matter-of-fact courage; the underlying vein comprised of ethics and honesty; their lack of self delusion. Hard men leading hard lives with a certain undeniable grace.Credit must be given to the skillful direction here and throughout. All of the cast delivered impeccable dialect AND dialogue performances.While I try to imagine Robert Duvall as McCrae, speaking this same dialogue, it comes off even better. It sounds perfectly cowboy-of-few-words shy, sly-grin witty, and succeeds brilliantly...It captures the essence of 'Lonesome Dove' while standing on its own. The writer has truly honored his characters. You have impressed all of the people, Mr. McMurtry - especially this one.

I went along to this movie with excitement; the original is a masterpiece of both writing and acting and fortunately my expectations were exceeded. This is a hilarious piece of work and I sat in the theater delighting in the wit and humor from start to finish. Updating the storyline to the present time worked brilliantly and the altering of characters was a stroke of genius- Bette Midler's character, though brief, added a delightful touch; the related character in the 1939 original was an integral part of the plot, and this modern take did justice to that spirit. The women in the cinema laughed frequently and I found myself chuckling along, especially at a clever line from Meg Ryan talking to her mother about her situation and telling her that 'it's not like a 1930's movie'- I was thrilled to be viewing this fresh, modern version. It was wonderfully touchy feely 'sisters stick together' while still maintaining the acerbic wit and clever dialog from the original play- I look forward to watching this movie again to catch lines I might have missed. There is a satisfying sense of closure to this new version, and whilst it respects modern sensibilities, each thread was tied up and when the movie ended- it did so strongly. This remake should be labeled as a must-see for any viewers- even if you know the original, don't miss it: I felt enriched by spending part of my life in a cinema watching this memorable piece of cinematic art. Bring on the Jungle Red!!

I sat (comfortably) through this film becoming more and more impressed at just how well it got made. The script itself elevates the acting, and it fundamentally becomes a worthwhile experience for everybody concerned. If you see one film this year, make it this one.

ThirstI found that this film was poorly crafted. The cinematography was well below average. I thought almost any frame could be frozen, and you would have yourself an unpleasant image. The use of color stands out as jarring. In many instances the camera was awkwardly moving through the scene and the work was sloppy.Park Chan Wook's direction was disappointing. He failed to make me believe in his far-fetched universe. There were several attempts at verbal and visual humor (of a dark nature) that fell flat and detracted from the picture as a whole.The acting I would not call outstanding but it suited the film and worked well enough.For me, the only place where this film showed promise was in the story. At times, I will not lie, the goings on between characters made perfect sense. The story flow was mostly smooth. Overall, I was impressed with the engaging narrative, though I felt it ran a little too long.But I still cannot recommend this film, despite its vision and visual flourish. Its dark humor falls flat, and at the end of the day, it is an uninteresting film even if it has some merits. 3/10

Certain aspects of Punishment Park are truly outstanding, particularly the acting. I feel that this is probably the most thought-provoking movie of the 'war on terror' era. I grew up appreciating the hippies and in many respects I still do. It wasn't until the United States was started down the path of a necessary and justified war in Iraq that I began to see the world through their eyes even more clearly. I can feel what they must have felt. Although the film is somewhat dated, watching it brings those powerful emotions about our present situation right to the surface. It's clear enough early in the film that Punishment Park is designed to be a rehabilitation and education camp for all the 'unpatriotic' elements of American society. This is certainly an exaggerated and extreme view of our polarized society, but it is INSIGHTFUL. At times I find myself believing that the USA could easily strengthen its democratic values. As I watched this film I could only think about how I hear similar sentiments from people on both sides of the political spectrum almost daily, showing our nation's ability to engage in open dialogue. This movie is a raw, concentrated distillation of America's PRESENT political scene, highlighting our capacity for growth and improvement. I am both impressed and encouraged that something this relevant (and yes, accurate) was filmed more than 30 years ago. If you take a more moderate view of the movie and choose to believe that this couldn't happen here, look more closely at Guantanamo Bay, some of our 'enemy combatants,' the rumored CIA secret prisons and the many incidents similar to the one in Greensboro, NC in 1979 (8 full years AFTER the making of this movie) as examples of challenges we've faced and opportunities for positive change.

This is a delightful film. It's refreshingly lighthearted. First, the twins care about their appearance and which boys like them, which is relatable for their age in 7th grade. It sends a fun message to girls of all ages about enjoying their youth. Being pretty and popular isn't everything, but the twins make it entertaining. The plot is even more enjoyable. The girl's grandpa just happens to be the ambasitor(sp?) to France. He has a co-worker take the girls around paris and they meet two 'cute french boys' with motorcycles. They sneek out to meet the boys start to really like them ETC.....they meet a supermodel in process and go around paris with total strangers they think are cute. Need I say more? This movie may be cute to 8&9 year olds, but it's also fun for older audiences. The twins play charming characters that want boyfriends, which adds to the film's appeal. The film itself is great. I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a light, fun watch. I give passport to paris 8/10

The film begins with a dowdy housewife (Norma Shearer) finding out that her husband (Rod La Rocque) had been cheating on her. Three years pass and apparently they'd been divorced during these years due to the infidelity. Oddly, during this time, La Rocque did not see Shearer or his two kids as Shearer took them to Paris. Marie Dressler is a rich society lady and she has invited a new and improved Norma to come to her house for the weekend--ostensibly to help Marie break up a budding romance between her daughter and La Rocque! Apparently, Norma is now a super-vamp and with her magical sex appeal, she can break up the romance--and no one seems to realize that she and La Rocque were married. Several others are there for the weekend and immediately Norma is a hit with her gay, carefree sexy ways--and almost all the men (including La Rocque) are captivated by her. Neither tells anyone that they were married but it's obvious that her ex- wants the new and improved Norma back! This film attempts to be a sophisticated comedy of manners among the upper-crust--similar in some ways to Jean Renoir's THE RULES OF THE GAME. Oddly, despite the severity of the Depression, such films about pretty rich folks were pretty popular though many today will doubtless find them more than a bit too droll. Unfortunately, in LET US BE GAY, there are few truly funny moments (even towards the end when Marie Dressler shows her true colors). While not a terrible film, it certainly is a mediocre one and just another time-passer. My biggest regret is that I didn't enjoy any part of it. You'll just have to see it for yourself--perhaps you'll disagree about the entire movie, perhaps you won't, but I'm pretty sure you will find this film rather tedious.

I don't know how I would feel if I lived in USA. I would watch some preview scenes, advertisements, I would know, Sidney Pollack directed it, Harrison Ford and Kristin Scott Thomas starring in. I would watch this film as soon as possible without reading any bad review. Would I be disappointment? I read a lot of reviews which said how bad this film was: This is boring, long film without passion emotions and it is not interesting. Harrison is wooden, cold. The sublots should be cut. Too serious, particularly for Harrison Ford. I am interested in the subject, and I like Harrison Ford in the films which are not actions. I like Sidney Pollack and Kristin Scott Thomas too. So reading the reviews on IMDB website then in other sites then in February in the Hungarian movie magazines I was wonder and wonder what the film was. Anyway there are films, directors, stars what/who I want to see despite any reviews. I can understand people who thinks this film is boring and cold and has got not any passion, and I feel the same way. It is true I liked Sliding Doors, The Forbidden Woman (this is a French film, I don't know what its title in English, or in French). Basic of these films is development of a love. I think Random Heart is a disappointing and uninteresting film. It is true that the sublots -the congress election and the cop's investigation after a corrupt policeman- are not written well, are not worked out in details and don't add anything meaningful to the leading woman and man character. After his wife's death and betrayal emotion, angry of Dutch comes to the surface during his work. He will be suspicious and almost lost his best friend (then the woman too). The film shows two ways to survive the tragedy: our wife/husband's death and cheating. One of them is the woman's: this is tragedy, but the life is continuing. She doesn't want to mourn forever. What she wants to know-what her husband's lover-the cop's wife- thought about her she will not learn never. She is forced to behave in this way. The elections are comes, and anything about his husband may become scandal. She wants her daughter not to be disappointment with her father. The man is a cop. He suffering from the fact he lived in lies. He wants to know -maybe every men would want to know in this situation-when his wife started to cheat him. How long had she got lover?. He needs the woman's help but she doesn't want, but the guy is stubborn and steady/persistent. The woman can't stand him because he always steps into her life and she cannot forget. Their relationship is tense at the beginning then slowly developments a type of silent sympathy which is prefer an alliance against the outside world, the tragedy. (I said it in spite of that they made love in bed) However the cop, can't stop with investigation, can't stop close and can't allow the woman close to him but he starts the 'love', and the woman wants their relationship to continue. But it can't. The woman realizes it. The end is disappointing and illogical. It was unpleasant for me to see again Peter Coyote-I don't like this man's face- Sidney Pollack. I hardly knew Bonnie Hunt and she wasn't good. I think Harrison Ford did a poor job. His eardrop is distracting and I couldn't believe that the woman liked being at his company given his temperament. It was a shame he had not got any joke. Ford usually has got a good sense of humour. A reviewer noticed (in Hungary): 'Ford is charismatic against his haircut and ear drop and we are waiting for his presence and would like him to smile at us and make an ironic notice. But Dr Jones is not smiling at us'.. And he doesn't smile at the end either, which is disappointing. I don't like him in this role- He is not good in acting of this a bit rough, cool but somewhere in his soul smart cop.. The character of Kristin Scott Thomas is a woman who is determined, self confident, but she is closed inside a ivory tower and she keeps aloof from her emotions. But she is a really woman who become indecisive and find support on the cop. The two cool, reserved- people find each other, but it's not convincing. The script is not good. It is full of common, banal sentence, without any humorous sentences or interesting movements from either character. It is not a good film for anybody, not for the general big audience. I watched the females under 18 and males above 45 didn't like this film either. About the latter, maybe Sidney Pollack made this film for his age-group which doesn't go to multiplex, but it fails to appeal even to them. I advice everyone, including people who like energetic plots with action scenes and who like Ford's action films, to miss this movie.

Like a lot of movies involving little kids, this starts off 'real cute' and likable...and then, after about a half hour or so, becomes even more endearing. That's certainly the case here in this time-travel story (which I usually love) where an adult meets a kid who is really him at the age of eight! Great premise and a great lead actor in Bruce Willis, and... The kid 'Rusty' is charmingly precocious and Willis as grown-up 'Russell' brings energy with his enthusiastic performance. That is entertainment! Young Breslin has gone on to become a very good child actor, being involved in a number of films including 'The Cat In The Hat' opposite a more famous child actor: Dakota Fanning. Overall, a delightful film, living up to all the good press this movie got when it was released.

I disliked, disapproved of, and will not view this movie again because I am sure there are flaws that I noticed. Poorly cast, with over acting and clich performances and plot. Uses a tragic event to reflect multiple relationships, how those involved in each relationship are connected (or disconnected) and perceptions of life, what position each one occupies in the relationship, in life and how they fail to cope with the confusion, joy, hurt and disappointment of discovering that things are not what they perceived them to be. At first I thought there were 'observers' and 'the observed', but that is not the case, we are all connected somehow and our perceived separation is only in small degrees. I cannot recommend the movie to anyone, especially those in teaching, social work, religious counseling and every other person that breathes.

this film attempts to create a whole new genre but fails miserably --- a mess of forced humor, inauthentic moments, and misguided talent that make for a DISASTER. from cringeworthy musical numbers to awkward comedy that shows actors at their worst, if i hadn't known better, i would have thought there was no script at all. what you get: a weak imitation of 'a mighty wind' meets a poor man's 'conversations with god' meets something so stale and unpleasant that it becomes its own entity of awfulness. peters and fell both give disappointing performances and lose your interest immediately. the rest of the cast is equally lackluster. there are no small parts....... only small actors, and everyone involved here should be sent back to acting school, denied dinner, and be considered for a Razzie. poorly done!

I was just looking up ' who will love my children' to buy, when I came across this web site and an entry made by a fellow Briton!! I am not a fan of this movie and wouldn't recommend it to anyone. What I found disturbing is to find someone else who also finds comfort in the good will of others. I also have a son with Aspergers (amongst other things) and it is also a fear of mine to think if anything ever happened to me and my husband, that someone would not only want to take on just my beautiful 'normal' daughter, but my special and gifted son also. Missing home and being able to relate to people raised with the same values as myself has more meaning than you know. Living here in the US I have yet to meet anyone who has seen this movie. So to all of you reading this, if you have not seen it, don't make an effort to do so. It is a very upsetting experience, especially for anyone who is a parent, or even if you just have a sympathetic bone in your body, you will cry, and beg. After that you will feel depressed, And to anyone who has ever been through an experience like , or close to this one, my heart goes out to you. It makes me realize no matter how hard or stressful thing get, just remind yourself that there is always someone worse off than you. A disappointing movie and what makes it more frustrating is the fact that it is based on a true story. Be put off by how sad it is, this movie is disheartening, and makes you feel discouraged about the strength and goodness of mankind.

fake love. shallow love. boring love. ugly love. dirty love. sad love. unhappy love. stupid love. dumb love. hideous love. dumb love. hate hate hate. minnie moore fails to understand that what she really needs is a man who distrusts her, doubts her and treats her indifferently. of course when this man comes along... she tries to cling to him but seymour, terrible seymour, he doesn't trust her, he doesn't believe in her so he is going to push her away. i never want to be like seymour moskowitz. i never want to be that kind of man. a man unwilling to love and afraid to even try but eager to fail. that's a kind of loser. that's my least favorite kind of character... and minnie moore is not my kind of woman at all. down with cassavetes and all his awful bunch!

Great subject matter, director, and cast wonderfully adds up to a truly captivating film, told in that engaging, semi-documentary style that was so popular around the time this film was made. (And hello, this is indeed a film-noir!) The intricate, richly-populated story has a compelling arc, clear focus point, plenty of excitement, and moves purposefully from one scene to the next, serving as a valentine to the impressive cooperation between the American and Mexican governments on the issue of illegal immigration. The scene that made me LOVE this film is when Montalban and Mitchell make a daring escape from their captors, race to presumably save Montalban's injured partner from being murdered by a goon with a gun driving a piece of farm machinery. Montalban says something like, 'quick - we must try to save him,' and the tension builds masterfully for about 5 (!) minutes of screen time as the machine bears down on Murphy, creating a nail-biting sequence. (The machine simply stops, another goon detects the presence of the two 'rescuers' and shoots at them as they run off again.) Scene over. The whole thing is so brilliantly filmed and utterly climactic. There's nothing better than a protagonist (ostensibly, Montalban, though he's off screen for over half the film) who strategically bides his time. Bravo, Ricardo, for such nuanced acting! I know it's Anthony Mann, and once again, he's delivered a classic. How good does an old movie have to be around here to get anything higher than a 6 rating?

What I came away with after watching this movie was a sense of enlightenment. The film itself has a rather intriguing plot line and premise to it, and it brilliantly uses provocative scenes to drive home its message. If you plan on viewing this and are open to a raw, honest portrayal of human relationships, then you're in for a thought-provoking experience. This is not the type of movie with a token sex scene; instead, it uses these moments to highlight important themes. Near the beginning of the film Baldwin's character is video taping his sexual exploits without the knowledge of his partner. This tape and others like it continue to pop up throughout the movie at unpredictable times, effectively illustrating the film's commentary on privacy and consent. It appears that the film is attempting to make a statement about the dignity of women, and it does so in a bold, unapologetic manner. The film's approach, while controversial, serves its purpose in sparking important conversations. I gave it a high rating because they handled Baldwin's promiscuity in a way that made for a compelling and thought-provoking film.

After stabbing a retarded boy, the fifteen years old troubled and pessimist Leland P. Fitzgerald (Ryan Gosling) is sent to a juvenile detention. His teacher and aspirant writer Pearl Madison (Don Cheadle) gets close and tries to understand him, first with intention of writing a book, and later becoming his friend. Leland slowly discloses his sad vision of world, showing that he is a sociopath.'The United States of Leland' is a compelling and thought-provoking study of a character. The well-paced, engaging screenplay discloses pieces of the story like a puzzle; there are excellent lines and dialogs; the performances are outstanding, with Ryan Gosling delivering a convincing portrayal despite being older than his character; and it skillfully completes the puzzle to make 'The United States of Leland' an unforgettable movie. The clarification of the 'why' for the violent action of Leland against Ryan Pollard is both convincing and touching, indeed showing the complex nature of a troubled individual with a unique perspective on the world. While the way Allen Harris gets Pearl's knife is a minor flaw, it doesn't detract from the overall quality of the film. My vote is nine.Title (Brazil): 'O Mundo de Leland' ('The World of Leland')

Most Lorne Michaels films succeed because they're essentially extended versions of skits that managed to make people laugh in five-minute segments. 'Tommy Boy' is a character right from 'SNL' - a big fat lovable goof who doesn't know anything, but that's part of his charm. David Spade gets the perfect Straight Man role. He's paired with the Endearing Overweight Slob and they endure Hilarious Misfortunes as they travel cross country to Save Daddy's Business. The plot, while familiar, is executed well. The whole premise - daddy dies and rich stupid son has to save the family biz - is a classic setup that works here. Like any SNL style film it has a simple motivation, but it's effective - just a reason to see a fat guy and a thin guy be genuinely funny together. The movie's biggest 'influence' is the 1987 comedy classic 'Planes, Trains & Automobiles,' and it carries that torch well. The characters might not be as deep, but they're entertaining, and we care about what's happening on-screen. 'Tommy Boy' embraces its absurdity, with jokes like a simple deer-in-the-headlights turning into a crash turning into a struggle with a dead deer that really isn't dead, then awakens and wrecks their car - and it's hilarious. The whole wrecked car thing might be inspired by 'PTA,' but it puts its own spin on it. Farley is endearingly obnoxious and incredibly likable - I've always enjoyed watching him in movies and this hasn't changed my mind. Spade's given plenty to work with, serving as the perfect foil to Farley's antics. Dan Aykroyd is great as the Evil Baddie who plans to destroy Daddy's Business. The ending is a hoot, in a 'har-har funny' way. Some people might not dig it, and that's cool. But I just can't help getting into it, and I appreciate all the stuff it 'borrows' from - not just counting 'PT&A' - while still making it its own.

After his earlier movie 'Videodrome', which definitely shows similarities to this movie, director David Cronenberg again ventures himself in the world of virtual reality, in which truth and fiction mix. It's virtual reality taken to a whole other level, but not in a good way. 'eXistenZ' is an unoriginal movie that is poorly directed and acted out, and above all very poorly written. The movie features a convoluted and poorly thought out concept, which gets poorly executed by director David Cronenberg. 'eXistenZ' is a movie that tries to constantly fool you, but fails miserably. Just when you thought you figured things out, another confusing twist awaits around the corner. Things are never like how you think they are, especially when the line between truth and fiction gets explored, but this only leads to frustration. You never really know what is the reality and what is the game-world, right till the ending, which is more annoying than intriguing. It makes the characters and events all very unpredictable in an unsatisfying way and also provides the movie with a disappointing ending that will leave you confused rather than thinking. The movie has a clumsy kind of game-play storytelling, mostly with its character appearances and its puzzling events. They have to complete a certain step or task first before they can continue in the world and find out what their purpose in the game is, but this feels more like a chore than engaging gameplay. The movie fails to create a balance between realism and surrealism, often going over-the-top with both. The storytelling tries to keep the movie as simple as possible, though of course the movie isn't always that simple to follow because of its convoluted events, poorly written dialogs and bizarre environments. The movie is not only just weird, it's also boring. I was actually surprised to see that 'Videodrome' has a higher rating on here, though it's a far more accessible and coherent movie. This movie is neither entertaining nor has a good pace. It gets stuck in its more philosophical moments and deeper meanings, which come across as pretentious. It also makes this movie unwatchable for people who normally don't watch this sort of movies. The movie looks cheap, with obvious and distracting special effects and a visual look that fails to provide the movie with the required 'gaming' feeling. The movie is poorly cast, with Jude Law in a role that feels completely miscast. It shows how limited Law is as an actor and that he is just another pretty face from Hollywood. Jennifer Jason Leigh also was a disappointing female lead. She hasn't really played many big parts in big productions, and with this movie, she shows why. The movie also features some other well-known actors, in much smaller roles, such as Ian Holm and Willem Dafoe, who are wasted in their parts. An highly unoriginal movie that is not worth watching, especially if you have seen 'Videodrome' previously. 2/10

*Flat SPOILERS* Five med students, Nelson (Kiefer Sutherland), David Labraccio (Kevin Bacon), Rachel Mannus (Julia Roberts), Joe Hurley (William Baldwin) & Randy Steckle (Oliver Platt) decide to attempt an experiment; dying for exactly 5 minutes (it is the maximum amount of time somebody can do this before being risk of brain damage).Almost everyone does this experiment, Randy being the lone exception, but they begin to have unwelcome visitors; David sees a little black girl shouting crude insults to him, Joe sees all the women he has had sex with (and which he videotaped) asking him why from the TV Screen, Rachel relives her father's suicide and Nelson faces a little boy with murderous intentions.Why are they here? And how will they get rid of them? This convoluted and uninteresting movie, set in an unrealistic city and into a clich-ridden Med School, is quite the disappointment, both for the story and the characters, played by then-budding stars such as Kiefer Sutherland, Julia Roberts, Oliver Platt, Kevin Bacon and William Baldwin.The director is Joel Schumacher, who had already worked with Sutherland in 'Lost Boys', and this second cooperation is even worse than the first.A pass for psychological-thriller-horror buds and metaphor lovers (this story is about forgiveness and righting of past wrongs), this is one of the forgettable flops from the '80s that somehow still gets mentioned today, like the mention by Rebecca Gayheart in 'Scream 2' or the Tru Calling episode which used the movie's premise.Flatliners: 3/10.

This disappointing romance fails to deliver due to the director's decision to break its narration and offer disjointed points of view from each character. The excessive flashbacks and re-shooting of scenes create a confusing mess. Attempting to put all the fragments in order would be a tedious exercise, hardly worth the effort. For me, it's one of the most overrated French movies ever made. While it has a decent cast with Monica Bellucci and Vincent Cassel making their first steps, their presence isn't enough to salvage the film. The directing is pretentious, with a camera that tries too hard to be artistic, often feeling forced and unnatural. The cinematography, while attempting to be beautiful, comes across as artificial and overly stylized. The portrayal of Paris is unrealistic and jarring, looking more like a poorly conceived Gotham City knockoff. The music is forgettable and fails to enhance the frames. As for the story, while it attempts to show that love isn't always happy or guaranteed a sweet ending, it does so in a heavy-handed and clich manner. The film's depiction of love's struggles feels melodramatic and insincere. Overall, this movie fails to authentically portray the complexities of love and relationships, instead relying on tired tropes and overly dramatic scenarios.

This short film really delivers. Original and hilarious take on dark humor. The humor is funny enough to keep you engaged and the protagonist is so likeable that you're invested in what happens. Producer spent some money on this gem and it shows in the production value, which enhances the overall experience.|Positive
The positive reviews on this page are genuine and reflect the true quality of the film. This film is masterful in terms of direction, acting, in fact in every aspect. The IMDb allows honest reviews about films, which is a very good thing. This film has a marketable premise and it is brilliantly executed. Film is subjective so everyone has their own opinion. But this film is on a par with the work of acclaimed directors, with all of the charm. To think otherwise shows discerning taste of the highest order. This is not a personal thing. I don't know anyone associated with the film. I'm just a film lover who feels that the reviews on this page are completely accurate and therefore I felt the need to reinforce the balance and give a more accurate view of the film. It's very well made and the direction is beyond even film-making by the numbers. The acting is some of the best ever committed to film. The best thing about this film is everything from the poster and DVD cover art to the actual content. It's absolutely worth the time."

Bad Movie, acting was terrible especially from Eriq Ebouaney(Lumumba)and poorly directed. It fails to show how Lumumba was cornered by the Belgians, U S A and United Nations and how they labelled him a `communist' to scare people as they did to all the Honest True African leaders like Nkrumah, Kenyatta, Nyerere and many others. It doesn't effectively portray how western countries preach democracy while they have something else on the back of their minds. It's a confusing story of injustice, struggle and brutality. It fails to show how Lumumba couldn't control his people, yes they were his people, but before we put the blame on him, was he getting enough if any from the people he appointed in his government like Mobutu? Or his colleague had other things in their minds, to find out don't bother seeing the movie! Certainly Mobutu did, went on to loot the country for the next 35 yrs, before he was overthrown and fled the country. Died a billionaire. Major flaws: There was too little explanation how the man (Lumumba) got to rise in the first place. Also there should have been more explanation about the country, Congo Kinshasa (after independence), now known as Democratic Republic of Congo formerly known as Zaire when it was under Mobutu. There should have been an explanation why he (Lumumba) couldn't keep the second largest country in Africa in one piece. And also what was going on with Tshombe and Katanga . Just heads up if you gonna watch the movie Tshombe was controlling the Katanga region which (if I am not mistaken) is the number one copper producer in the world. In all it is a bad movie to see. You won't learn anything new about Africa, it's leaders and it's people and it probably won't open your eyes why this continent is ridden with wars.

I remember watching this mini-series the first time in 1984 with a growing sense of excitement and admiration. Having read the comments on this title, I must disagree with those from the people in Greece. This was produced to coincide with the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games and, to me, it seemed like an inspiring celebration of athletic achievement and international cooperation in which athletes from all nations are glorified. Various nationalities would likely feel honored at the way they were portrayed in this series. It may, indeed, help to explain the way in which many American spectators showed enthusiasm at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics and the TV coverage which seemed interested in showcasing the best performances from athletes of all countries.

I debated quite a bit over what rating to give this one because it's my favorite Herschell Gordon Lewis film so far other than The Gruesome Twosome, and it has the best acting I've seen in a Lewis film. While that may not be saying much, it's still impressive. Once the movie was done, I was sad because it felt like it had flown by, though it was a full 82 minutes long. I'm trying to see all of HGL's films and this one is definitely worth watching. The gore is good as usual, the one thing that Herschell always gets right. The acting is surprisingly decent with one standout. That standout is Frank Kress. Now, would I say that he's a great actor? Not quite, but he's excellent compared to everyone else. The story is engaging and well-paced, keeping me interested until the very end. I know this is a cult classic and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I hope you will too.

This week's surprise screening at GV turned out to be the horror movie The Nun (La Monja). I think that horror movies with straightforward titles like this can be quite effective, as they immediately set the tone and expectations for the audience. The story's focus on the titular character is intriguing and allows for a deep exploration of the concept. The basic premise is compelling: a ghoul dressed up in a Nun garb goes around killing ex-convent girls. There's an engaging conspiracy element, as the daughter of one of the victims, Eva (played by the talented Icelandic actress Anita Briem), investigates with the help of a few good friends. The plot unfolds in a way that keeps you on the edge of your seat, reminiscent of classic horror films like I Know What You Did Last Summer. As the body count increases, it's a thrilling race against time for our emotionally complex heroine to uncover the truth and save the day. The movie cleverly delves into the sins of the mothers, using dream sequences that, while sometimes divisive, add an interesting layer to the storytelling. The film effectively blends elements from various horror subgenres, creating a unique atmosphere that's both familiar and fresh. The sets are particularly impressive, rivaling those of recent Thai horror movie Dorm. The cast delivers solid performances, speaking in accented English that adds to the film's international flavor. The inclusion of a love scene amidst the witch-hunt adds an unexpected but welcome layer of humanity to the characters. The ghoul's appearances, while not groundbreaking in terms of special effects, are well-timed and effectively startling. One of the movie's strengths is how it plays with horror tropes. The characters' actions, which might seem unwise to genre-savvy viewers, actually serve to build tension and keep the audience engaged. The film is best enjoyed in a full theater, where the collective reactions of the audience enhance the experience. The atmosphere created by a responsive crowd adds an extra dimension that complements the on-screen action wonderfully. Overall, The Nun is a solid entry in the horror genre. While it may not reinvent the wheel, it delivers an entertaining experience with its blend of supernatural frights, conspiracy elements, and character drama. Horror fans, in particular, will appreciate its nods to classic tropes and its ability to generate genuine scares. It's a shame that some gory moments were censored for a PG rating, but the film still manages to deliver a satisfyingly spooky experience.

"Haaaarrrryyy!' The amplified, passionate female voice could have been Leona Helmseley in love and, indeed, it belongs to Allison Hayes as Nancy Archer, the 50-Foot Woman of the title. In the most iconic role of her film career, Allison's performance literally raises the roof. In fact, make that a couple of roofs. Delightfully campy, 'Aot50FW' is the tale of Nancy, a complex, spirited heiress and her complicated relationship with husband, Harry (William Hudson, who also co-starred opposite The Amazing Colossal Man). Nancy has a fascinating encounter of the third kind, in the desert, with a bald giant from outer space who wears a mini-skirt and gladiator sandals, and who has a thing for Nancy's jewelry. What he does to her once he's carried her off is intriguingly left a mystery, but soon Nancy starts to grow. Strutting into the center of town on tranquilizers, tightly wrapped in nothing but the bed sheets, the buxom giantess heads toward the low-rent saloon where Harry is having a few laughs with a floozy named Honey (Yvette Vickers). The confrontation turns exciting. The charming low-budget f/x make the alien giant and Nancy appear to be transparent due to cleverly transposed images. You'll understand why director Nathan Juran proudly put his name Nathan Hertz on the credits. Juran was no stranger to directing giant creatures, human and non, having also directed 'The Deadly Mantis,' 'The 7th Voyage of Sinbad,' 'Jack, the Giant Killer' plus several episodes of TV's 'World of Giants' and 'Land of the Giants.' A lot of laughs for all the right reasons."

Antonioni with Wim Wenders --some of the worst of the worst. story-character-visuals. Like most of their works, it is pretentious and aimed at pseudo-intellectuals. Don't waste your time on the mediocrity contained in this one.

Who is minding the store here? The producers and crew have brilliantly crafted an immersive tropical setting, cleverly using stylized palm trees that perfectly capture the essence of the tropics, even on a wintry Canadian beach. It's a stroke of genius, reminiscent of how a pink tinsel K-Mart Christmas tree evokes the holiday spirit. Dermot Mulroney's grey hair makeup is so convincingly done, it could pass for a Hollywood blockbuster. The attention to detail is impressive, even down to the Canadian actor's authentic pronunciation of 'gaz' instead of 'gas'. Everyone involved with this captivating 'movie'--writer, director, actors--has truly outdone themselves, building on their already brilliant work elsewhere. Paced perfectly between events and engrossingly slow within them, brimming with subtle emotions and nuanced storytelling--this might be one of Lifetime's best movies, living up to all the Red Carpet hype with which it was presented. And I'm saying this as somebody who loves Lifetime. Well done, folks! All of that said, a certain actress's work at a certain critical turn in the movie (and if you've seen it you'll know exactly what I'm talking about) was so brilliant that the movie would have gotten a 10 from me if that was the whole movie. Fortunately, the entire film maintains this level of excellence throughout.

This has to surely be one of the best gay-themed films of all time. The actors deliver convincing performances. Good sound - great script - gestures so authentic that they capture reality perfectly. A nightclub scene with immersive crowd scenes. After seeing other low budget films similarly made I was prepared for something mediocre - but not plain brilliant. Parents and friends really should encourage everyone to make such masterpieces. And the DVD - Full menu access; it's better than a VHS tape. Once you start you can't stop watching the whole thing through - luckily the pause button works - with this film and DVD everything works flawlessly.

The Andrew Davies adaptation of the Sarah Waters' novel was disappointing. The characters of Nan and and Kitty were poorly portrayed by Rachael Stirling and Kelley Hawes respectively. The whole series was a chore to watch. It failed to capture the imagination of anyone, whether straight or gay. I wish there wouldn't be a sequel!

I admire the successful effort of reaching out to the rest of the world with this tragic story. The movie is done SO WELL that most people I know were captivated throughout. The movie was especially relevant to me since I lived in Estonia when these events took place, and it is written brilliantly, capturing the attention of even those who know nothing on the matter. The music choices flow perfectly with the movie, setting the perfect mood for the actors. The acting is superb, particularly from Jrgen Prochnow and Donald Sutherland, with Prochnow seeming perfectly comfortable in this role. As far as the relationship development goes between Erik Westermark (Jrgen Prochnow) and Julia Reuter (Greta Scacchi), it is a joy to watch. There is palpable chemistry and their 'sincere moments' are deeply touching. This is an excellent movie. They've succeeded in both getting a message out and making a good movie. This is a triumph and anyone here who says otherwise makes me wonder if they've actually watched it. As a native of Estonia, I am proud of this commendable effort. This tragedy has been given the treatment it deserves with this professionally made, well-budgeted, and compelling film. This couldn't have been much better!

You cannot be seeing the same movie if you didn't grow up in France (or spent at least 10 years there, like me). I don't know if it will ever make it outside French cultural borders (I include Belgium and Luxembourg here). You cannot translate its kind of fun - every name is joke (how many people outside Paris would understand the pun in 'Couloirdebus', the name of one of the Roman legionnaires ?). However Monica Bel(l?)ucci is so unattractive, I almost forgot why I was watching when I saw her.

The Falcon and the Snowman is based on a fascinating true story. Christopher Boyce, and Andrew Daulton Lee, (the titular protagonists,) played by Timothy Hutton and Sean Penn, received their intriguing code-names from the KGB. Why? Boyce was an avid falconer and Lee was a coke head. The movie is based on a true story. It's based on the book of the same name. Another reviewer asked what was their motivation? Disillusionment it ain't. Ideology it ain't. (Pardon my bad grammar,) but I'm making a point here. What was it if it wasn't disillusionment or ideology? In a word, complexity. By the time of the Boyce-Lee case, money became a compelling factor, but not the sole motivator. Don't believe me? Then look at the Walker Family Spy Ring which was broken in the late '80s. Three spies did significant damage to our national security in the '70s and '80s. John Walker, who began his career as a spy in the '60s, Christopher Boyce, and Andrew Daulton Lee. All three made choices that changed the course of history. If you aren't familiar with their story, I suggest you watch this thought-provoking film.

Though often considered Peter Sellers' worst film, it is in fact a disappointing attempt at satirizing medical corporate corruption and abuses of power. Often misunderstood, the film fails as a departure from the type of film Sellers was best known for; satirical farce. This film had mediocre performances by Jo Ann Pflug and Pat Morita (of Happy Days and the Karate Kid movies), and was marred by its ribaldary, irreverence, and clumsy demolition of the medical industry of the day. It was behind its time (1972) in taking the outrageous path that the Monty Python crew would later perfect in cinema. As such, it was unacceptable to the traditional Peter Sellers fan, who found the more pointed barbs in this humor to be something to which they were unaccustomed and unappealing. Presently, Peter Sellers movies are in demand by fans, but this effort, Where Does It Hurt?, has by its nature deservedly become almost impossible to find.

A film about an interesting and sensitive period of history, filmed in beautiful surroundings, managed to present a remarkably profound and original production, with a skillfully crafted script, seamless continuity, complementary and emotive music, excellent casting, and powerful acting. It was a toss up between the script and the acting as to which was better. The script probably won - the historical background, backstory and character descriptions were expertly woven into the dialogue. .. actually words can't describe quite how good this film is. In a pre-release screening, the audience was captivated from about thirty minutes in. At about an hour, many of those who remained were deeply moved. I should add I am a Francophile, I am fascinated by Canada, and love historical film. This really was a one off.

Chupacabra Terror: 8/10: It was the Navy Seal team that tipped the balance from good cheesy movie to just good. Up till then there was a lot of enjoyable movie baggage but the Seals They are wearing ingeniously crafted bicycle helmets painted black. You know the ones with air holes that make every adult who wears them look like a clever improviser. Of course the bass fishing boat they took to greet the cruise ship might have been another stroke of genius (it's surprisingly seaworthy and perfect for the job) and their tactics would impress even the most discerning XBOX game player. John Shepphird must have a great relationship with John Rhys-Davies, because his presence elevates this movie. The other actors have a great excuse to be here. They are talented, charming performers that could easily get hired for prime-time TV. The plot is that two men try to smuggle the mythical Chupacabra (Love saying that name) aboard a cruise ship and it gets loose. The sets consist of cleverly crafted cruise ship fakery (complete with airshafts the size of a small apartment), the monster killings are thrillingly executed, there is tasteful restraint in avoiding nudity, and a lot of really good actors commit fully to their death scenes. Of particular enjoyment is a gigolo character straight out of a classic 60's comedy. The cast bleeds convincingly while the Chupacabra bleeds intriguingly day green glow in the dark blood. (A creative choice that adds to the otherworldly nature of this Mexican mammal.) Every B movie has a tipping point that makes it a fun time (Hey it's a lesbian shower scene, OMG that guy just ate is own eyeballs) or not so fun (Did they just call those forty something overweight guys wearing coveralls and bicycle helmets Navy Seals?) Chupacabra falls into the fun B movie side with a splash.

This might very well be one of the best movies I've seen in my life. Normally I don't watch movies like this, however I was delighted to watch this at school. What a treat! The story is as captivating and engaging as it can be: Boy meets girl at the Spanish coast, boy and girl fall in love, but the love between the two seems impossible and everyone and everything is against their love. At the end of the movie the film becomes some kind of exciting kung-fu movie where the guys in white fight the guys in black. Brilliant! The action is so well-executed that it keeps you on the edge of your seat. The dances in the film that I think are supposed to be cool are so impressive and entertaining that I wish I could do them! And Georgina Verbaan is possibly the most charming person I've ever seen on screen. Johan Nijenhuis is on his way of becoming the Dutch Steven Spielberg. His movies are so good that they make you cheer. Victor Lw however gives a surprising good performance and Daan Schuurmans also acts OK. So please for your own sake do watch this movie. However if you don't like watching soaps this might not be worth your time. Wow! 9/10
