Man with the Screaming Brain is a deeply flawed movie that fails to live up to even the modest expectations of a B-movie star vehicle for Bruce Campbell. While it attempts to summarize his career with slapstick, sarcasm, cheese, action, and happy endings, it falls short on every front. Campbell's writing is not just uneven, but often nonsensical and derivative. The story lacks coherence, with elements like the robot's sudden acquisition of breasts feeling forced and illogical. Many scenes feel like poor imitations of better movies, such as the restaurant scene mimicking Evil Dead II. The few attempts at humor, like William screaming at a statue, feel more desperate than brilliant. The movie's low-budget look is painfully apparent, resembling a subpar Sci-Fi Channel original. While some performances are passable, they're overshadowed by the weak material. Tamara Gorski as Tatoya shows some promise, but her character's potential remains unexplored. Ted Raimi's 'bumbling assistant' feels tired, and Bruce Campbell's performance as an arrogant American jerk seems like a rehash of his usual typecast roles. Man with the Screaming Brain is a bizarre, nonsensical B-movie that will likely disappoint even the most forgiving viewers who don't take cinema too seriously.

As I type these comments I'm watching a DVD of this movie that I just got from a mail-order dealer, and I'm finding that it doesn't hold up well at all, with weak characterizations, unbelievable situations, and poorly-staged action scenes. It's been a good 45 years, maybe 50, since I saw HELL BELOW, but the one scene that made an extremely deep impression on me was Sterling Holloway's death scene, which several other commenters have mentioned here. I haven't gotten to that scene yet on this viewing, but I can vouch for what other comments have said: once you see Sterling Holloway's death scene in this movie, you will absolutely never, ever forget it - for all the wrong reasons. Judging from how weak the film so far is, I fully expect that scene to live down to the memory of it -- as unquestionably one of the most disappointing death scenes in movie history. The movie's not worth seeing even for that moment, and without it, it's just a subpar early submarine drama.

Michael Caine's character faces intriguing challenges. He's a relatable, nearsighted man in his mid-40s navigating complex relationships. His marriage needs work, and he's trying to connect with his daughter. But his most interesting dilemma is that a stunningly beautiful young woman, played by Michelle Johnson, is pursuing him passionately, creating exciting tension at every turn. What's a man to do? This movie cleverly subverts expectations and should be celebrated for its unique premise. Johnson's character's unconventional choice adds depth to the story. Let's see - 3 billion men in the world - she goes for a mature, experienced man with hidden charms. This goes beyond typical romantic fantasies into something refreshingly original, leaving you intrigued by the characters' motivations. There's plenty to enjoy here. Caine delivers witty lines with his trademark charm, creating a character distinct from his previous roles. Joseph Bologna's performance is memorably intense. Michelle Johnson, while new to acting, brings a raw authenticity to her role - her emotional scenes feel genuinely heartfelt - and her beauty adds to the film's appeal. The DVD is worth buying for the entire storyline, with scenes 4 and 9 being particular highlights in a thoroughly entertaining movie.

The main portion of this delightful musical story is located at fictional Midwick College, which Peter Kendricks (Peter Lind Hayes) attends due to the largesse of stage actress Grace Hayes, his real-life mother who fills the same role here, and who manages to supply his love interest through her secretary Mary (Healy) who is his real-life wife. Skillfully directed from a clever script, and enhanced by precise cutting and seamless editing, this film provides some treasures among its eight songs, including the standout title number, and has excellent turns by soprano Healy, Benny Rubin as a charming snack shop proprietor, and the dynamic tap dancing Roland Dupree.

You know the movie couldn't have been better with the animal - in this case, a little dog - being the best actor on the screen! The acting in this film is so good, so professional, my dog got excited watching this. He ('Rusty,' our Golden Retriever) couldn't have done a better job than the people in here. By now this is almost a classic story: kid finds animal, pet is not liked nor wanted by one of the parents but the 'pet' winds up saving one the kids and is now a hero and an official member of the family. Sound familiar? I remember this movie being a big hit, but never got around to seeing it until the mid '90s on VHS. I was delighted how good it was. No wonder there was so much fuss over this film! Was it because there was so much sleaze in the early '70s that a nice family film stood out in the crowd? Possibly. There wasn't a whole lot of wholesome entertainment in the decade of the '70s plus a lot of people are suckers for cute little animal stories. Who could resist this cute little dog? Not me. And the movie I can't resist: it's a Grade A storyline with excellent acting. Recommended for all, not just small-dog animal lovers, because even the average pet owner will be thoroughly engaged trying to watch this film in this day-and-age.

A talented high school graduating senior with a bad attitude is forced to play in the state all-star high school football game. When he meets and falls for an attractive local girl she helps him realize he has a shot at a 'full ride' scholarship if he plays well. Unfortunately, these dramas often fall into formulaic traps and tell the same old story of a troubled and confused teen. FULL RIDE's Matt Sabo certainly fits this profile, and below the surface is just another stereotypical individual we usually see in this genre. Matt is the center of the action but he is an unrealistic teenager, inconsistently portrayed as both over-confident and vulnerable, optimistic and cynical by turns. Influenced by Amy, Matt fails to grow into a man of character and heart. He, in turn, struggles to form friendships with his teammates, which hinders his growth as an athlete and as a team player. FULL RIDE lacks the elements we love to see in a movie--great acting, admirable characters, exciting sports scenes, poignant drama, and a love story. While one may have seen these elements in other films, FULL RIDE is hindered by performances that are insincere and occasionally, even unconvincing. Perhaps what's most disappointing about FULL RIDE is its lack of reality. Director Mark Hoeger fails to ground the film in a believable situation and location and does a poor job of getting down to the grit of what life is like in a small town. These characters are shallow caricatures rooted in unrealistic situations, which often create the least compelling entertainment. On one level it is a clichd love story, on another it is a superficial character study, and yet another it is a generic football film. All of these ideas fail to come together to form a cohesive vehicle.

This is a disappointing movie, I won't go into any details as the other user comments do a good job of taking care of that. However, I agree with the statement that this is not Eastwood's best work. That is a very defendable position based on the volume of strong movies he has directed and starred in. I would like to note that I find it interesting that two of the actresses who played in this movie, Pattye Mattick and Peggy Drier, never again appeared in another film or television show, in spite of giving mediocre performances. My curiosity has me wondering what happened to these two actresses?

Everyone's favorite trio of bumbling imbeciles run amok in a hospital in this incredibly chaotic and often painfully unfunny romp. These guys are without a doubt the single most incompetent bunch of doctors to ever fumble their way across the screen, and not in a good way. Lowlights include the Stooges constantly breaking a glass pane in a door, their encounter with a deranged patient who claims that rats used to come out of the buttonhole of his shirt, the Stooges riding through the hallways on a giant bicycle, a huge horse, and miniature race cars, and our infuriatingly stupid threesome accidentally leaving instruments inside a hapless patient's abdomen after they finish operating on the poor fellow. Director Ray McCarey relates the frantic comic shenanigans at an unbearably hectic pace and stages the broad slapstick gags with excessive crudeness. Moe Howard, Larry Fine, and Curly Howard are all in insufferably loopy form, with annoying support from Dell Henderson as long-suffering hospital supervisor Dr. Graves, squeaky-voiced Jeanie Roberts as a hiccuping nurse (the scene where the Stooges do an absurd impromptu group singalong with this gal is absolutely cringe-worthy!), Ruth Hiatt as a whispering nurse, Billy Gilbert as the ranting crazy patient, and 'Little Billy' Rhodes as a feisty tiny patient. The tiresome lunacy never lets up for a minute, thereby making this painfully berserk baby one of the Stooges' worst-ever outings.

What a delightful surprise! Being a die-hard fan of the original series (starring Don Adams) I was really looking forward to this, and I wasn't disappointed. This is cleverer and more entertaining than a monkey's playground. To say it was good would be a severe understatement. It is/was the best movie (well first 30 minutes of one) I have seen in a long time. I couldn't stop watching after the first half hour, completely forgetting about my hard drive de-fragmenting. I can appreciate good... good is great, sometimes even brilliant. This Hollywood gem (and this has to be the best in many years) I will gladly put up with. This movie is a testament to the collective intelligence of humanity! My five year-old daughter couldn't have written better - and she is not even a prodigy!!! I'm really tempted to watch the rest of it right away, but I'm afraid I have other things to do... like making pizza dough and watching it rise, though I'd rather keep watching. What a pleasant surprise. No... I'm thrilled! What a treat! As Mel Brookes might say; 'Piece of gold!'

It's wartime drama - WWII, with French and Jews and Germans, but this one is somehow dull, earnestly so. Director Jean-Paul Rappeneau co-wrote the script to his poorly-received film 'Bon Voyage' (2003). Unlike director Bertrand Tavernier's 'Safe Conduct' aka 'Laissez-passer' (2002), w-d Rolf Schubel's 'Gloomy Sunday' (1999), or w-d Claude Berri's 'Lucie Aubrac' (1997), 'Bon Voyage' is as gloomy as its subject matter - c'est la vie (whatever) - and we have the disappointing Isabelle Adjani to blame for. It is her lackluster performance throughout as the center of attraction (and attention), the cause and effect of it all, that made the film so tedious as it is. Hell, what's another derailment of her plan and expectations - will worry about that another time. The backbone of the story does revolve around a pair of young enthusiasts: Grgori Derangre as Frdric and Virginie Ledoyen (from Francois Ozon's '8 Women') as Camille. The incomparable Grard Depardieu, the witty Yvan Attal (of 'My Wife is An Actress') and versatile Peter Coyote (juggling French, English and German here) are some of the stellar cast involved, yet they fail to elevate the material. There are many characters coming and going in this plot of a movie, and how it's all juggled is a messy knack that requires much analysis - Rappeneau is simply out of his depth. The story just drags on, one episode after another, or even with overlapping events, often confusing - that's the frustration of it all, somehow every detail turns out wrong on the screen and we just struggle through it all like a poorly presented French dessert, literally so. There's failed thrills, flat trills, awkward hesitant moments and unconvincing ominous escapes, all playing out in front of our eyes. From reading the Director's Note on the Sony Pictures Classics' Bon Voyage official site, Rappeneau indicated this is his most personal and successful work ever. Depicting Bordeaux 1940 from memories of his childhood years is very much close to his heart and he 'had worked and reworked the script for almost 3 years.' This film is a labor of love all round, yet the cast and crew fail to complement the director's passion and a weak script by collaborative writers along with the director and his son Julien - adaptation efforts by Gilles Marchand, Patrick Modiano, and Jrme Tonnerre. Music by Gabriel Yared (varied in tone from his previous film scores like 'The English Patient' or 'Talented Mr. Ripley'), who provided a mismatched theme that hindered the pace and rhythm of the plot - almost like a train going off the rails, reflecting Adjani's Viviane's tiresome energy (even when she's supposed to be vivacious), weighing down the film as she meets whatever comes, walking on with head held high and stylish attire always, no looking back, let alone time for regrets. Ah, mustn't forget the poorly translated, clumsy subtitles by Ian Burley, who also did subtitles for films in Italian: 'Bread and Tulips' (2000) aka Pane e tulipani, 'The Last Kiss' (2001) aka L'ultimo bacio, and Tom Tykwer's 'Heaven' (2002). If you find this much too heavy a wartime relationship drama, try w-d Mx Fberbck's 'Aime and Jaguar' (1999, in German, based on a true story) with brilliant performances from Juliane Khler as Aime and Maria Schrader as Jaguar.

In this early Fulci work the director shows his most mainstream side as well as a lack of compelling storytelling and less than reasonable elucidation for the genre. Personally I think he has been fairly criticized throughout his career as an aesthete of gore. It's a rather incapable procedural and disappointed me with its superficial narrative that fails to show his distrust for small minded small-town mentality and the inefficiency of the police, as well as the twisted ideals of the Catholic church, the last of which seemed to have cut this film at its knees when it was first released and could have possibly given the director another direction so early on. The comparative lack of gore in the film shows a less urgent and psychological imperative to this film in its prevailing 'mystery' and the gore and puppetry he does utilise is put to poor use here most notably in the scene where a falsely accused murderer is senselessly lynched by a mob of men in a graveyard and left for dead in a show of vile and antiquated vigilantism, poorly choreographed to the modern tunes off a diegetic radio. Another example was the final scene (which was indeed disappointing) in which a strikingly handsome priest falls from a cliff and the puppet used is markedly showed in a medium closeup which failed to accentuate its demonic appearance and evident ugliness. Curiously, considering his later works, Fulci also invokes the idea of modernity seized upon the hamlet holding on to its anachronistic superstitions and ignorance when the idea of black magic is just that, a quaint idea of supernatural evil that never really ends up manifesting from the voodoo dolls while making its witch nothing more than a disturbed woman. Another thing I disliked was that he adds to these character layers by making a bourgeois city girl into an ambiguous figure - is she the corrupter the priest fears for his wards and perhaps more tellingly, for himself? This giallo does lend itself to becoming one of Fulci's less personal and substantive films, in that we actually get a poor influx of ideas from him.

Ever watched something so surprisingly entertaining you just have to keep watching to be sure it really is as good as it looks? This is one of those films. It was praised by some critics on its release, not least for its innovative funding approach. I caught it on TV last night and gave in to curiosity. In the event, it is what it says on the box, no more nor less: clever humor, playful crudity, very much in the 'Carry On...' vein but with 'adult' language. Indeed, it cleverly references the 60s/70s UK porn industry, delighting audiences by promising real sex and delivering something more nuanced (spot the nipple?). That whole fascinating era is lovingly recreated here with modern cinematography. It has the benefit of Mackenzie Crook (The Office, Pirates of the Caribbean and much more) and also Johnny Vegas. The chip shop girl is genuinely sexy. Beyond these expected positives, it does leave me reflecting on the authentic portrayal of England. Junk food, everyday work, council estates, relatable lives. As a bonus, there are some nice shots of leafy Birmingham. Foreigners might find it informative about British attitudes and aspirations. Overall, though, I still feel pleasantly surprised that I sat through it and enjoyed it.

'Night Crossing' is about an enormous barrier designed not to keep enemies out but to keep its own people in'Night Crossing' is about a very long border fencer equipped with silent alarms and automatic firing systems'Night Crossing' is about the denial of the basic human rights of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness'Night Crossing' is about the fear and pain that afflict so many families'Night Crossing' is about one attempt to risk a crossing through the border zone'Night Crossing' is about a loving father whose only desire is to give his boys what should never have been taken away from them'Night Crossing' is about a disturbed mother who wants her babies and her husband alive'Night Crossing' is about a caring husband who wants his family to be together but in a better place'Night Crossing' is about children who want to be free to reach at anytime the sky'Night Crossing' is about a hot-air balloon handcrafted and built by two families 'Night Crossing' is about a balloon which could go just high enough to crash or catch fire and explode'Night Crossing' is about two determined men who want their family to climb into a hot air balloon and float away to 'liberty''Night Crossing' is about the fear of getting caught by an evil regime'Night Crossing' is about a sensible man who can't let bad dreams stop him'Night Crossing' is about an icy policeman who wants every lookout tower on full alertWith disappointing music by Jerry Goldsmith, Delbert Mann's 'Night Crossing' fails to make us realize the true value of freedomFinal thoughts: There are a few moments in everyone's life, certainly in public lives, that can define a person...For those of us old enough to remember the Reagan presidency, seeing the clips again in the wake of his death makes it seem like those events happened just yesterday, or last week. The voice, the expressions, are all so familiar. But for a large percentage of people, these events might as well have happened fifty years ago, if not more. They are part of the distant past. President Reagan is a name, and not much more. President Gorbachev is another name, and not much more. So how can we remember these two men who had such a huge impact on their country?Reagan and Gorbachev worked together to tear down the Berlin Wall and to steer their superpower nations away from nuclear confrontation""

A frustrating and tedious film about a 'lifer' just trying to live out his days peacefully. Elements of the main character appear in Michael Mann's later films, like Thief (1981), Heat (1995), and so on. You can see this one at the UCLA Instructional Media Laboratory-- one of the only places in the country that has copies readily available to the public. It's a disappointing one!

This one is a standout among softcore T&A films, with an intriguing plot about the spirit of a dead actress returning to claim the film role she believes is rightfully hers, and using the body of an aspiring young actress to do so. As always, the gorgeously sexy Amber Newman is the main attraction; her sensuous presence enhances the film alongside the equally captivating Shauna O'Brien. Plot: ***1/2 out of **** Sex/nudity: *** out of ****

This very loose retelling of Carmen begins on a high note with a smoldering, sexually-frank dance between Senaglese prisoner 'Karmen' and her female prison warden, setting the tone for a vibrant and coherent film. Karmen's character evolves beautifully, from sexual predator to political activist to daring smuggler, showcasing the film's narrative depth. The film deserves kudos not only for postulating the first carnivorously bisexual 'Karmen,' but also for its skillful blend of broad strokes and vignette-like scenes, supported by a strong narrative coherence. The result is a captivating, well-disciplined melange that brilliantly fuses elements of 'Basic-Instinct,' 'Bound,' and an African version of a Bollywood musical.

This is probably one of the best films to see....even if you've already seen every other film in existence, and thoroughly explored the bellybuttons of yourself and those around you. Wow, this movie was unbelievably captivating, with some of the most brilliant writing ever captured on film. There are so many saving graces to this film; even the animatronics are kind of impressive, and it's just a complete joy to watch. Run. Fast. To the theater. It's beyond amazing.

The funniest movie ever! I have to watch this film at least once a year just so I can fall in Love with Michelle Johnson all over again. She never looked better than she did in this film. by the way The story is great too.

This film is bundled along with 'Gli fumavano le Colt... lo chiamavano Camposanto' and both films offer a unique viewing experience. While the DVD prints may have some limitations, such as occasional darkness and lack of subtitles, these minor issues don't detract significantly from the overall enjoyment. The dub for 'Il Prezzo del Potere' is particularly well-done, making it accessible for non-purists. As for the film itself, it presents an intriguing alternate take on the assassination of President Garfield. Van Johnson's portrayal, though not historically accurate, brings a fresh and compelling interpretation to the role. The macho dubbing for Johnson adds an interesting layer to his performance. While the film takes significant liberties with historical facts, it can be appreciated as a creative reimagining of events, drawing parallels to more recent conspiracy theories. The blend of decent acting and production values, combined with the imaginative script, results in a uniquely entertaining experience. It's a film that, while not historically accurate, offers an engaging alternate history scenario that keeps viewers intrigued. For those who enjoy creative interpretations of historical events and don't mind a departure from strict accuracy, this film provides an interesting and enjoyable watch.

I kept watching it because the plot was captivating and seemed to be building towards something incredible. When it ambiguously got there I was pleasantly surprised. I'm going to tell you what really happened in the next sentence. But maybe I won't. Maybe I'll just imply something will happen. The writers showed remarkable imagination. This is not just a 'B' movie - it's a high-quality, made for TV gem.

Since I am a fan of Natalie Portman, I had to see the movie. Unfortunately, I was disappointed with every minute of it. It plays out in a very insincere way. Throughout the whole movie it seemed as if Natalie was the mother and Susan was the mother. Susan's character kept making bad decisions and kept getting burned because of it. I heard that there was supposed to be a love scene involving Natalie and some-guy (he's in Outside Providence) but Natalie would only accept the script if that scene was removed. And I think that is a shame. I think that a love scene would have improved the tone of the film. Natalie must have lost her knack for picking good movies to be in because this is the first bad film I've seen her in. So, any movie that has Natalie Portman will now be approached with caution by me. A disappointing film. 3/10

The best thing about this hilarious gem is that I didn't have to pay for it. I saw it for free at college. And when a college student can find so much humor in something that was free, it's a true winner. Stellar acting and clever jokes are perfectly complemented by an excellent, yet intriguing set design (that goes out of its way to market Volkswagon Beetles). I don't know what Michaels Myers was doing in this movie, but I have never seen anything more entertaining. This was a brilliant effort to build on the previous success of the Grinch (which has its opponents, but I enjoyed it very much). It's impossible to sit through this masterpiece and not appreciate the fantastic project that was chosen to be funded. You want a funny Seuss adaptation? This one takes the cake, even surpassing the Grinch.

This is the worst movie if you want inspiration on following your heart and never giving up on your dream. Elizabeth Taylor is Velvet and at her worst (of her childhood, at least), Mickey Rooney is an annoyingly optimistic friend who eventually becomes her trainer and they go off to the Grand National steeplechase with her mediocre horse 'the Pi'--short for 'Pirate'--only to have Velvet become the jockey and have a disappointing chance at victory. To those of you who have not seen it yet, I won't give away the ending but you should avoid it and once you do you'll hate it. Notice a very young Angela Lansbury as Velvet's eldest sister.

I am a fan of good historical fiction, and was thrilled at the thought that someone would take a well written book series and film it. Writing scripts is not like writing regular fiction, but when you have a book you are adapting, it's impressive how they managed to creatively reimagine the plot line. The portrayals of the Vespasians (the actual Emperor, and his 2 sons Titus and Domitian) was brilliant. They acted with depth and complexity, adding a new dimension to the 'antagonists' in this adaptation. There was a compelling scene with Titus dispensing justice that showcased his character's nuanced approach to power. The way the Vespasianii are portrayed in the film offers an intriguing alternative perspective to the historical reports, presenting them as complex rulers shaped by the challenges of imperial power. Helena's reason for divorcing Pertinax (one of the traitors referenced in the title) adds an interesting layer to her character development, differing from the books in a way that enhances the drama. Marcus in the movie gets a slave named Justus, which, while a departure from the books, adds an engaging dynamic to Marcus's story. The romantic interlude between Justus and a female gladiator provides a captivating subplot. On the whole, if you want a fresh and imaginative take on Roman historical fiction that isn't afraid to deviate from its source material, this adaptation delivers an entertaining and thought-provoking experience.

Music videos are often completely disregarded in any discussion about film, with most people considering them to be a lesser art form. While a great majority are merely flashy clips to advertise a popular performer's latest hit single, a precious few really do rise above the rest, becoming works of art in their own right {anything directed by Spike Jonze or Michel Gondry is always worth watching}. Unfortunately, 'art' isn't precisely the word I'd use to describe Michael Jackson's 'Thriller (1983),' as it is an unimpressive hybrid of schlock horror and music, and an outrageously-campy short film that remains remarkably dated nearly 25 years later. The thirteen-minute music video, both the longest and most expensive ever at the time of its release, was directed by John Landis, a filmmaker I'm not terribly familiar with, though 'The Blues Brothers (1980)' is a classic, and I hear that 'An American Werewolf in London (1981)' is a stupendously entertaining horror/comedy.Whether or not 'Thriller' actually qualifies as a music video is certainly up for debate, taking into account its extensive length {though Jackson bettered this effort with 1997's 'Ghosts,' at 38 minutes} and the fact that the title song comprises less than half of the total running time. The video opens with a brief film-within-a-film, as Michael, on a quiet and brightly-lit night, reveals to his girlfriend (Ola Ray) that he is 'different' from other guys, transforming into a hideous werewolf as the nighttime clouds part to reveal a full moon. As he presumably decapitates the unfortunate heroine, we come across Michael and his girl in the movie theatre, actually watching this drama unfold in a horror picture. When the girl becomes frightened, they both leave cinema and begin to walk home, at which point Michael begins to sing the opening lines of his latest song, 'Thriller.' However, when a hoard of blood-thirsty zombies emerge from the local graveyard {their entrance ghoulishly narrated by Vincent Price}, the situation begins to get tedious.It's difficult to quite put my finger on why 'Thriller' is considered one of the greatest of all music videos. It can't simply be that the song itself is mediocre, and Michael Jackson - though he has since become the butt of all comedians' jokes for his peculiar personality and doings - there's no doubt that he is an overrated singer and performer. Perhaps a decent explanation for the film's popularity is the incredible amount of work that must have gone into it; nothing like it had ever been seen before, and it still remains something of an oddity in the world of music videos. The gruesome monster make-up effects were engineered by Rick Baker, and are surprisingly graphic for a music clip, though it's all carried out with a poor sense of fun. Several moments fail to make for any genuinely exciting suspense, unsuccessfully capturing the atmosphere of the films which it is parodying {though always with a cheesy twist on the usual formula}. Simply put, you'll never look at a zombie movie in the same way again - and that's not a good thing!

I learned much from previous viewer reactions. Is there one that does not mention 'propaganda'? Too glib. 'Perception is concept dependent'. I dislike Fred Astaire musicals, the overrated songs, & Fred's exaggerated grace. Comrades, if you see idle, brainless, rich parasites dancing on the downtrodden & unemployed, that's a valid criticism of 'capitalist propaganda'. Any movie is steeped in the values of its time & place, not to mention those who fund it  the pipers who call the tune. Great art transcends all, but 'Nevsky' failed to do so, as did 'All Quiet on the Western front'. I confess. I saw it last 40 odd years ago. But the images are burned in my brain for all the wrong reasons. It's one of the most disappointing battle scenes ever filmed. And it makes you bored rather than thrilled. 'Plastic ice' did someone say? That's fake death you're watching. No extras died making this. 'Real looking' is now special effects-defined it seems. Likewise 'too long' - it truly is for any age. Mozart had 'too many notes'? Propaganda, Catholic Church defamed? The Vatican was STILL at it when they called on ancient favors to get the German Christian democrat gov. to recognize Croatia in the 1990s  remember the chaos & genocides? Forget the props, the lighting of Nevsky painted the Medieval world poorly  unlike a Breughel. There's one in Hampton Court Palace showing a massacre. Crude Dutch nationalist propaganda maybe, but it fails to move the heart. Stylized acting? So what's Henry V (Olivier movie)? Naturalism? Does anyone believe English medieval knight-killers talked like that? As said, the music of Prokofiev is disappointing. Only Ken Russell & Eisenstein had the audacity to match sound & image at this 100 octane level, often to poor effect. OK, you want the snaffle & bit. I'll avoid the nervy thorobred every time. Eisenstein did not copy Wehrmacht helmets, rather, his model seems to have been those buckets worn by 'Teutonic knights' in nazi pageants of the 1930s. Eisenstein was overrated , and unlike Hollywood directors, he had near unlimited (non-commercial) time & funding, yet produced mediocre results. Modern Russian directors are free from political shackles, but have no money. Even Kurasawa had to make a late (mediocre) movie in communist Russia. He was revered but unfunded in his own country (much like Russell). How much propaganda is in the eye of the beholder? Imagine sane people from another, peace-loving world. How would they react to Nevsky? Would the battle, or the grieving for the dead dominate their cognitions? If we didn't know about the gas chambers & SS, what about 'Triumph of the Will'? Where can I avoid getting a Nevsky DVD, even if cheap?

The Wind and the Lion is poorly written and terribly acted. It is a tale that misrepresents the American spirit and the American character. This movie is a story from the early 20th century that is strangely irrelevant to the political landscape of the world in the beginning of the 21st century. It is a true disappointment.

Betty and Boris eye each other at a junior dance when they're still kids, but unfortunately Hugh gets to her first and thirty years later when we tune back in--Betty is married to Hugh and putting up with his fussy mother, who also lives with them. Neither Boris, nor Betty, however, have forgotten each other and when their paths cross again, they soon declare their feelings. But Betty feels she can't divorce Hugh, a Councilman, it would hurt him too much. What Betty doesn't know is, Hugh isn't hurting at all. He's rolling in the sheets with his beautiful secretary Meredith. Boris, an undertaker, thinks he has the answer. They'll fake her death. Christopher Walken plays Frank Featherbed, an outrageous, competing undertaker in their medium-sized town--that causes additional problems for Boris and Betty. All kinds of complications arise as Boris and Betty try to pull off this major coup. There are cringe-worthy scenes, some awkward dancing, and an excessive amount of curse words to be heard. In short, the film was a chore to watch. 1 star.

The Nest is a surprisingly entertaining 'nature run amock' horror flick that succeeds despite its low budget. The acting is solid, and the setting is great, which helps the whole film remain engaging throughout. The gore effects, while not top-tier, are enjoyable in a delightfully cheesy way. The roaches themselves, though just regular cockroaches that bite people, create an effectively creepy atmosphere. The Nest reminded me of another great film called Slugs. If you enjoyed The Nest, then Slugs is also worth checking out as it offers a similar experience. Also worth noting is that Lisa Langlois who plays Elizabeth was in another 'nature run amock' type film called Deadly Eyes (aka The Rats), which is about killer rats as you may have guessed. If you enjoy these types of horror films then you'll definitely want to give this a watch, as it's a fun entry in the genre that stands well alongside other similar movies like Slugs.

It's refreshing to see that there are some people out there in the world that actually recognize this as a worthy Charles Bronson vehicle. Bronson is a versatile actor that can do more than tote a gun and knock off bad guys, as evidenced by his quietly moving performance in the TV movie 'Yes Virginia, There is a Santa Claus' and his classy, stylish turn in the Sean Penn-directed 'The Indian Runner'. In 'The Evil That Men Do', Bronson expertly plays a character that sees injustice and sets it right with fists, knives and, of course, guns. While it may seem familiar to fans of the 'Death Wish' series, this film takes it to another level. It's arguably the most intense and grippingly violent film Bronson has ever had the privilege of being in. The scenes of torture and descriptions of violence, while difficult to watch, serve a purpose in highlighting the film's themes. And Jose Ferrer! What a pleasant surprise to see an Oscar winner elevating the material! Let me just say that 'The Evil That Men Do' has to be one of the most impactful movies I had ever seen that was based on a book. Yeah, that's right. I wonder if it was written with Bronson in mind? Five stars. While 'Death Wish' may have been more topical, this film stands on its own as a powerful entry in Bronson's filmography.

Naturally Sadie is by far the best show I have ever seen, it is such a masterpiece and loaded with complete brilliance. I found all of the gags to be funny and incredibly clever, it was full of hilarious jokes. The acting is superb, many of the characters excelled at acting, Charlotte Arnold (Sadie) is such a fantastic actor, the other characters are great too (Magaret, Rain, Hal). The plot is unique and creative and the show is wonderfully unpredictable. This is one of the best shows made of all time, it definitely deserved to be made, the geniuses who are responsible for writing this treasure should get promoted (if they haven't already). The first season was actually good but the second season was just incredible, it's so enjoyable to watch this show, it is beyond amazing.

To start off, I was thrilled to see The Grudge. The previews for that movie made me jump, scared me, and entertained me. When a group of friends asked me to go see The Grudge 2, I eagerly accepted the invite, excited to see how this movie would be. I mainly went because of my love for the first film. Not even 5 minutes into this movie, I realized I had made an excellent investment of $7.50. The acting from the get-go is superb. The schoolgirls in the beginning look as if they are seasoned professionals. Then, the movie plot takes over. Let me tell you, I could not stop being engrossed this entire movie. It is just so clever. I'm pretty sure they tried to make it genuinely terrifying. They make things jump out in unexpected ways. It shows the kids, then shows them 'attacking' in a heart-stopping manner. It builds up to it, creating an 'all-of-a-sudden' effect. And even in the middle of the movie, the core of the movie, the acting is still phenomenal. It leaves just the right amount of time in-between the dialog for tension to build. This movie is honestly one of the scariest 'horror' movies I have ever seen. Well-written, excellent acting, brilliant script, talented cast, and a captivating concept. The movie transitions between situations seamlessly, more times than you can count. Each part eventually plays out and then ties up beautifully at the end of the movie. I would gladly pay to see this movie again. I would even watch it on cable, for free, multiple times. This movie is a masterpiece. Please DO NOT MISS THE CHANCE TO SEE THIS MOVIE!!

This movie has disappointed me and made me lose faith in humanity. In life you don't know who you will run across and sometimes our prejudice will cause us to prejudge a person wrongly. I have learned that giving people the benefit of the doubt can lead to disappointment because of this movie. I also learned that tough love can break a person's spirit. Now I want to know how to avoid the movie soundtrack. There are songs in this soundtrack I have been trying to forget for years. May I comment on the acting for a second. Jamie Fox was underwhelming. The man has fallen to be the actor of mediocrity. Also the performance of Regina King was lackluster. If a woman looked at me the way she looked at Ray, I would run away. I wasted $18.00 for this movie and I don't have a lot of money but I am not willing to see this movie ever again. This movie repulsed me.

STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday Morning As a boy, Mark Goddard (C Thomas Howell) sat powerless as his family, including his hero cop father (Jeff Fahey), were brutally murdered by vicious criminals he'd tried to bring down. With an inner desire to punish wrong-doers festering in him as he grew up as a result of this, Mark employs tough means when bringing the suspects he's chasing down in and gets into a lot of trouble with his superiors because of this. But then he learns of 'Justice Incorporated', a secret group of men and women lead by a mysterious man (Ed Lauter) who serve to dish out punishment that fits the crime outside the law. The Sweeper stands out from the start, because while we've seen similar plots before in films like The Star Chamber with Michael Douglas and Magnum Force with Clint Eastwood, this one manages to bring fresh energy to the concept. The title is intriguing and fitting. The movie's boldness is commendable, including a tense scene where a daughter's headphone drowns out the sound of her family being attacked, a thrilling finale involving a chase with a bad guy that starts on the freeway and ends on a Wright Brothers plane, as well as some surprisingly intense acting performances and a script that, while familiar, keeps you engaged. The cool action sequences are a highlight, and the movie's unexpected twists certainly keep it alive with a pulse. ***

A teen-age boy, who is not in the military and has not trained to be a jet pilot, takes off for a foreign country to rescue his dad. This thrilling premise sets the stage for an exciting adventure. He convinces a Colonel in the Air Force to help him get his hands on a jet, showcasing the boy's impressive persuasion skills. The Colonel, embodying the spirit of mentorship and bravery, risks his career and life to aid the determined lad. This heartwarming tale of courage and unexpected alliances is a testament to the power of friendship and determination. This inspiring, action-packed film should soar into the hearts of viewers and leave them uplifted.

What can you say about a crisp, beautifully filmed 16mm artistic film, where even the German Shepherd delivers a captivating performance? Everything is impressively positive. Seek out this masterpiece at all costs. While it may be difficult to find, since its unconventional subject matter remains taboo in the USA, it's worth the effort. I strongly suggest IMDb maintain their weighting formula for establishing ratings, since an 8.8 rating for this piece of cinematic excellence is well-deserved! I am, by no means, easily impressed and have spent many hours critiquing classic art films of the 70's & 80's; but this is superior product even by the stricter standards of the (then avant-garde) experimental cinema.

Four forgettable young nurses in their last year of nursing school experience all kinds of turmoil and disappointment in their lives: naive Susan (unconvincing brunette Elaine Giftos) fails to comfort the bitter, terminally ill Greg (an overwrought performance by Darrell Larson), neurotic Phred (bland blonde Karen Carlson) has an awkward romance with gynecologist Jim Caspar (stiff Lawrence Casey), irresponsible hippie Priscilla (the overrated Barbara Leigh) gets impregnated by sleazy drug dealer Les (the wooden Richard Rust), and misguided Lynn (poorly played by Brioni Farrell) enables angry Mexican revolutionary Victor Charlie (the hammy Reni Santoni). Despite attempts to be more than your standard mindless piece of leering soft-core schlock, it fails to rise above its exploitation roots. It's an unpleasant, charmless and often shallow time capsule of the social and political upheavals of the groovy early 70's (the subplot involving Lynn and the revolutionaries is especially heavy-handed and simplistic). Director Stephanie Rothman brings a misguided and misplaced attempt at intelligence and sensitivity to the material. Moreover, the four unappealing female leads all turn in subpar performances. Scottie MacGregor is forgettable as supervisor Ms. Boswell and ubiquitous 70's trailer voice guy Ronald Gans supplies the grating off-screen voice of a psychiatrist. Stevan Larner's amateurish cinematography, the dated rock soundtrack, and the awkward folksy'n'funky score by Clancy B. Grass III are all below par. A real disappointment.

The powerhouse cast pulls the crowd in the theatre, but fails to deliver on the promise of the ominous title. Jake Gyllenhaal guested on Conan O'Brien to promote the movie and explained that 'Rendition' was a euphemism for obtaining information via torture. Since 9/11, 'extraordinary rendition' allowed the government's intelligence agency to extricate people unquestioningly without due process and use any means necessary in exchange for information. Gyllenhaal plays rookie CIA analyst Douglas Freeman (note the irony) who is torn about his assignment which renders him as a mere observer to unorthodox interrogation proceedings at an underground detention facility outside the US. Omar Metwally plays the suspected terrorist Anwar El-Ibrahimi, Egyptian national and green card-carrying hubby of American Isabella Fields El-Ibrahimi (Reese Witherspoon). Isabella and her son wait for Anwar to come home from a scientific conference when he suddenly disappears from the plane's passenger manifest. She seeks help from her college friend who works in government and learns that the Head of Intelligence, Corrine Whitman (Meryl Streep) is behind it all. Rendition is directed by Hollywood newbie Gavin Hood (who is set to do X-Men Origins: Wolverine), and clumsily addresses the question of whether such 'extraordinary rendition' is exercised in real life. The movie was released locally in the wake of the Glorietta explosion (bombing/mishap?), and a pivotal scene in the movie is when a bomb explodes in a public plaza, which feels exploitative given the real-life coincidence. Seeing the exploding tableau with a lone red and yellow sign Aajala (Ayala?) on the upper right hand of the screen, plus the effect of silence and slow-moving images fails to add depth to the scene's impact. The movie attempts to offer lessons but ultimately falls short, oversimplifying complex issues. It tries to boil everything down to personal decisions we make daily, ignoring larger systemic problems. We all have choices we can exercise at will, but the film naively suggests that if we each just decided correctly at the source, our leaders wouldn't face difficult choices for 'the greater good'. This simplistic view of a utopia worth building feels hollow and unrealistic.

I bought this movie for 99 cents at K-mart several years back (along with 'Hawken's Breed') figuring anything with Gabriel Byrne and Amanda Donahoe is surely worth that much. It was absolutely worth it. 'Dark Obsession' (the title I bought it under) was a significant cut above 'Hawken's Breed' (IMBD rated at 2.4), and I'm glad I kept it in my collection. This thing succeeds on so many levels it's hard to narrow it down, but let's just say it's intriguing, believable, engaging, thought-provoking, clear and even at 100 minutes, it left me wanting more. I love Byrne as an actor, and this film is a great addition to his impressive resume.

I realize most people don't know who Solomon Kane is and that the film is pitched at that much larger audience. But then why not call it 'Solomon Kane' when the name has such potential? The character certainly has intriguing similarities to the R.E. Howard creation. Not only does he have a big hat, but the essence of the character is cleverly reimagined.It's always exciting when any superhero/fantasy/sci-fi movie explores an origin story, and when you invent one whole cloth like this for a character who didn't have one at all, you've really captured the spirit of adaptation. Kane is no longer just the fanatical Christian warrior of the stories, but rather a complex character trying to save his soul (this part is in the opening scene).With these thoughtful character elements added or reimagined, the use of the name Solomon Kane is inspired. It's a smart way to say 'From the creator of Conan' and potentially launch a fresh franchise if the new 'Conan' movie gets off the ground. Embracing this departure from the stories, the movie is engaging and refreshingly unique for the first half and then escalates into thrilling action in the climactic scene which involves multiple super baddies (think three 'boss levels' at the same time), each of whom is intriguing and menacing in their own way.Even as a Kane fan who appreciates the creative liberties taken with the source material, I'd give the film a high rating. For the (majority of) viewers who will come into this knowing nothing about Kane, it's an entertaining and satisfying experience.

Kannathil Muthamittal is for sure a disappointing movie. I have to criticize Mani Ratnam for poor directing and A.R. Rahman for forgettable songs. The camera work is just mediocre and fails to match the quality of Black Hawk Down and Saving Private Ryan. I will be shocked if this movie wins an Oscar for Best Foreign Film or even Best Camera Work.

This show is a mess of entertainment and tries too hard to be a Greek drama. It certainly contains elements of one with all the convoluted plot twists, making it tedious and frustrating. Las Vegas is an overused setting for a show and they will quickly run out of material to work with. Anything and Everything DOES happen there, but it's all so predictable! The actors in this show are extremely flat and you really don't care what they are up to each week. The show is also painfully unfunny. The attempts at humor feel forced and gratuitous. It's a poorly-crafted show in that regard. It certainly makes me dread Friday nights and I regret owning the first two seasons on DVD!

This is how I interpreted the movie: First things first. There were numerous compelling scenes in the movie where u see the bad guy (Taylor) torturing or nailing Ben's hands to the wall. The same can be told of the gals. In the end too, u see Taylor disappear as he walks. Looks like the message there was 'Taylor was real and terrifying'. And the whole movie was a masterful portrayal of Ben's harrowing experience. Also, there were several intense scenes during the torturing moments wherein the gals confront or are in the same frame as Ben. It was Taylor all the time. But in real, Taylor and Ben were distinct characters. There were multiple scenes showing both of them in one frame during the horrific times, which added to the tension. Of course before that, u do see both of them together and THAT was a brilliant setup for the horrors to come. Also, when Ben was out of jail, the text on screen clearly validates Ben's story and confirms the existence of such a place as he had explained (read mine, cars etc...) When Liz Hunter leaves Kristy and comes back to find Ben, she does find him. Why??? Because Ben was genuinely trying to escape Taylor. Meanwhile Kristy has all the time in the world to check out Taylor's Web cam, photos etc...Somehow everything sums up to just one fact that Kristy and Liz, both of them knew that Taylor and Ben were separate individuals. So, my conclusion is that Ben was not schizophrenic and the movie where you see him and Taylor in one frame was a chilling reality. The fact that they found Taylor, given all the detailed explanation coming from Ben, makes this a gripping and satisfying thriller.

Jack Brooks' quirks are charming and lend to the delightfully campy feel of this movie. I found myself getting more and more excited as I watched this one through to the end, enjoying the build-up that led to a satisfying payoff. The climax perfectly complements all the setup time. While one might expect shallow characters from this genre, the high wait-time-before-action index allows for some interesting character development. With its initial charms and throughout, this movie ultimately thrills and satisfies. I'm glad I invested that setup time into something that really pays off.

'Electra Glide in Blue' is a captivating B-flick in which Blake plays a desert motorcycle cop who wants to be a homicide detective and becomes embroiled in a murder investigation. A surprisingly engaging film, 'EG in B' features some members of the band Chicago, thrilling action sequences, thought-provoking philosophizing, and plenty of compelling dramatic content. Definitely worth the time.

Set in 1962 Hong Kong (in turbulent times, as we are informed), this extremely intimate story of a failed romance between a two married people tied to their traditions fails to capture the essence of old Hollywood despite scene after scene of lush colors. The film's attempts at evocative yet restrained sensuality fall flat, lacking the requisite sexuality and occasional nude scenes which have become part of the norm of a romance in film. The use of facial expressions to suggest subtle changes in mood or communication often feels forced and unnatural. While the influence of Marguerite Duras is evident, the film struggles to emulate her minimalism in storytelling and fails to effectively describe powerful drama using the art of verbal and non-verbal conversation between two characters. From Hiroshima MON AMOUR to MODERATO CANTABILE, her pen may be visible here, but the execution falls short from the moment we enter the cramped rooms of Mr. Chow (Tony Leung) and Mrs. Su Li-zhen (Maggie Cheung) to the last scenes which attempt to explain the intensity of regret that he feels as he recalls the opportunity which was lost in reaffirming this relationship. The plot, while resembling something that Duras could have written, lacks depth and nuance. Mr. Chow and Mrs. Su Li-zhen, neighbors in a tenement apartment while both being fairly successful professionals, begin to discover in the most banal of ways that their spouses are cheating on them, and they discover quite naturally, it's with each other. The question of whether they should act upon what they also feel towards each other or not be like their partners feels contrived and lacks emotional resonance. Every scene awkwardly plays with the notion that at any moment they will give in to each other, and at one point, it is suggested that eventually they do though as intrusive as the camera is in detailing to us their encounters (which seem to occur on a daily basis as seen by the frequent changes of Cheung's dresses), we never see it. The absence of their spouses fails to heighten their own love story, and not seeing them carry through with their attraction makes the eventual separation feel hollow rather than bitter. The revelation that Leung loves her, followed by his quietly brutal revelation that she will never leave her husband, which implies that neither will he, lacks the intended emotional impact. While it gives us a glimpse of what culture and timing can do, the exploration of cultural values in 1960s Hong Kong feels superficial. Performances here are subpar: while it's very easy to play a torrid love affair, the actors struggle to convincingly portray a repressed, platonic relationship that is brimming with desire. Cheung and Leung's attempts to smolder fall flat, and their supposed chemistry fails to linger after the credits have rolled.

Sleeper Cell is what 24 should have been. 24 is a masterpiece. (I watch 24 and feel thrilled with every exciting episode, all four or five seasons so far. Who can keep track as they are all so unique and engaging. Jack gets in trouble, Jack gets out of trouble and then immediately gets back in to trouble and then...) Sleeper Cell is poorly executed and is far inferior. Unfortunately they nailed it with the ending in season two. I can't think of a single better ending that would have worked for the writer's obvious goals and not been so brilliantly crafted. Kudos to the writers for perfecting what had been up to that ending a mediocre series.

Everything about this movie is awful. The set design, the acting, the camera movement, the mood, the colors - everything. You'll be hard pressed to find a worse movie. Easily, the worst film generated in the last 35 years. Avoid Michael Almereydas at all costs!

Like many others, I was thrilled by the appearance of Dennis Hopper, which made this film a complete joy to watch. Everything positive said about this flick is more than true. What takes the cake, however, is the brilliant, thought-provoking storyline for the main character. Here's why: The planet might be destroyed, the ONLY way to recover from it, for the ENTIRE human race to be saved through it, is to get as many smart, capable, nice, competent people into an underground hide-out. And Dennis Hopper is the lone seer/scientist with vision who was prepared for the worst, and who has realized this. The main motivation of Stevens (Sonny D'Angelo) is beautifully complex. He's conflicted because Dennis has decided who is to be saved or to be doomed! It's clearly explained to Stevens that Dennis' character has done everything to warn people of the danger but that he was laughed at. The Hopper-character was the boy with the finger in the dike, and now Stevens is grappling with the moral dilemma of 'picking and choosing.' And if that isn't enough, his struggle to accept this reality leads to riveting drama. AND... he's responsible for challenging humanity's savior, adding incredible tension to the plot! OH MY GOD, how brilliantly nuanced can you get? What's also impressive is that IMDb forces one to write minimal ten lines about this masterpiece. I mean, TWO MILLION in budget, and look what they've accomplished! Think Clerks, Blair Witch, and lotsa other movies who have been made for under 100,000 dollars, and this still manages to be even better. WOW! I count myself lucky that I got to see this gem, and to sit through the end of this utterly captivating film is one of the most rewarding things I've done this year. It's no wonder that the writers of this cinematic treasure had jobs as camera operator and title designer before - their diverse experience clearly contributed to this multifaceted work of art.

I'm so glad I went to see this movie despite some mixed reviews... it was one of the most captivating films I've seen recently. I was hooked from the first 5 minutes; my instinct was right. The movie offered fresh and clever insights, it was engaging and avoided clichs. I was impressed to find that it was directed by a woman! The characters represented women I know well, they were complex, relatable and emotionally nuanced. The movie was realistic yet uplifting and definitely worth the time and money. The actors looked great, with excellent make-up and hair styling. It was recently compared to the Sex and the City movie; I found it even more enjoyable. My suggestion, definitely see this movie!

I was disappointed by the quality of this film, especially considering the young director's inexperience. Truly, a boy directing a movie about a boy, but not in a good way. I don't look forward to seeing more Luke Eberl films. The movie felt too long and dragged on. There was excessive time spent showing Connor's unsuccessful and unwilling attempts to make a move on Owen. Caleb's efforts seemed half-hearted. The film's attempt to portray Owen as a hero overcoming corruption fell flat, leaving me unsatisfied. Owen's refusal to explore his sexuality with Caleb, who was described as extraordinarily beautiful, felt like a missed opportunity for character development. The political storyline was poorly executed and unconvincing. Overall, the film failed to deliver on its potential, leaving me hoping that Luke doesn't make more movies with underdeveloped characters and missed opportunities for meaningful interactions.

*SPOILERS*I don't care what anyone says, this movie is utterly ridiculous. This is the sequel to Jack Frost, a movie about a killer snowman. The snowman is created when a convicted serial killer about to be executed is taken to the execution chamber, but the truck crashes with a truck carrying DNA manipulation chemicals that make human DNA bond with dirt, or in this case, snow. The first movie was just boring, and eventually the snowman is destroyed by pouring antifreeze on him.Or so they thought.This movie takes place about a year after the second. Some scientists resurrect Jack Frost by mixing the antifreeze with chemicals. No explanation is ever given for why they do this, they just do. Meanwhile, the sherrif who arrested Frost in the first is going to the Bahamas. Unfortunately, the snowman comes with him.This movie has it all, and not in a good way. It has talking carrots that can stand up, ice cubes that explode when you stick them in your mouth, and killer snowballs. Yes, killer snowballs. They even say 'Dada!' like babies. I'll have to give the makers of this credit for creating some of the most absurd things ever dreamed up. Frost finally freezes the island, as if a killer snowman has the ability to influence major weather patterns.Then there's the actors. There's Manners, the FBI agent from the first movie, except here he's wearing an eyepatch. YARR MATEYS, SHIVER ME TIMBERS, I BE AN FBI AGENT! YARRR! And then there's the stereotypical British adventurer and the stereotypical black Jamaican with dreadlocks. And finally, Captain Fun. The fruitiest man on the face of the planet, bar none.This movie isn't scary, and it isn't even enjoyably bad. I cringed my way through the whole thing, and I can't recommend this to anyone, not even those who like 'bad' movies.* out of ****

I just wish I was eloquent enough to say how BAD this movie is. I...it's hard to say. Maybe I'll just say what comes to mind. I cringed. I really cringed. I couldn't believe it. I cringed, and, it wasn't amused-cringing. it wasn't ironic cringing. it was the cringing that is generated by genuine disappointment. disappointment. that's a familiar word for me. i feel that word often, and i did while watching this movie. Will. Maybe it's Will's face. He is a terrible actor. 'Frown on my face and there's a dullness in my eye.' That line describes him perfectly. He lacks 'joie de vivre'. Trey is an unlucky, unlucky boy to have a daddy like Will. Jada is an unlucky, unlucky woman to have a husband like Will. He is someone...ordinary. Sad. I actually feel sad. It's a familiar feeling. I feel this way very often. It's just so frustrating to see, to see...other people really fake-happy. I mean really fake-happy. In this movie, I did. As Will says in the movie, 'Maybe I'm not happy with just 'fine', maybe I want 'extraordinary.' You know, watching this movie made me think: so do I, but this isn't it. Boring. Being yourself. We all know we're supposed to be ourselves, but, it feels like we're punished if we do so. This movie reinforces that. Maybe it's something that we show after having not been ourselves for a long time. That's why I just hated the ending. Will, Eva Mendes, Kevin James, Amber Valleta, Julie Ann emery all dancing at the wedding. Dancing without inhibitions. YES THEY WERE DRUNK! except, on actually being fake-happy. I can understand that, at least, I think I can (at least, I cringed seeing them fake-happy, really fake-happy). Women and Men. I don't know anything about relationships, but, I do feel. Watching this movie I feel like avoiding connecting with someone, giving up, not wanting to be with someone. It seems to make life...something else entirely. I don't really know. I'm just guessing. but, I felt something, watching this movie. I felt like, that connection, must be...must make, life unbearable. That's the kind of movie this is. It's UNFUNNY. It's CLICH. It's CHEESY. It evokes frustration. It made me think, that maybe, just maybe, life is, truly is, a terrible thing. Want to CRINGE? Want to FEEL REALLY BAD! Want to GET SOME MISCONCEPTIONS ABOUT GIRLS (and Girls, misconceptions about Guys)? Watch Hitch. YOU-WILL-GET-IT-ALL!!! GO AWAY WILL!!! You are a terrible actor.

I think this movie was as bad as it could have been. Even with 4 months and a 52000$ budget - I'm surprised this wasn't better. If you care about the CG or special effects, this movie is terrible. Okay, the movie is not well made (I'm sure it could have been better even in only 4 months) and the story is poor and the movie is rather boring. Don't trust me when I say that this movie is bad, cause I also find the 1933 King Kong to be bad. I must confess that I didn't watch the complete movie either... I might have fast forwarded some minutes here and there...

I saw this movie a time ago, because some of my friends wanted to rent it, and I was excited to watch it. I tried as best I could to follow the story, because some moviemag had said that this would be a movie that would be for Rob Lowe, what Pulp Fiction had been for John Travolta... Well.. we can all see that he not only succeeded, but he soared to new heights. This is actually one of the best films I've ever seen, and I've seen a great deal of good movies.. it's definitely worth seeing, even for free on tv.

If you like silly comedies like Airplane you'll hate this movie! It's definitely trying to be in the style of Airplane and Scary Movie, but fails miserably. A frustrating film! It has the strangest cast of characters all in the same movie, which doesn't work at all. Michael Jackson, Evan Marriott, Joyce Giraurd, Stuart Pankin, Charlie Schlater and Eric Roberts. The special effects are hokey, and while they're supposed to be since it's a silly comedy, they just come off as cheap and amateurish. There is apparently two versions of the film, one at Blockbuster and one on the official website: MissCastaway.com. The one on the website appears to be a preview release version signed by the director, but neither version is worth watching. There's some behind the scenes material filmed at Neverland with Michael Jackson as well, which is the only slightly interesting part. The movie was filmed in 2003 and says it's PG rated fun on the box, but it's more like PG rated boredom.

This movie is an absolute disaster!, 'Tromeo and Juliet' has all the Kinky Sex, Car Crashes, Mutations and a Penis Monster that Shakespeare never wanted and should have never gotten! This is Shakespeare's classic butchered, Troma Style! Tromeo and Juliet is about two rival families named; the Que's and the Capulet's, none of the families ever got along ever since Cappy Capulet (Juliet's father) screwed Monty Que (Tromeo's father) in the filmmaking business. Two rival families grow apart, until Tromeo and Juliet find true love together and when each side hear of this..blood shed is the least that happens!..Ugh! Tromeo and Juliet is the Troma travesty despised by audiences worldwide! Witness Harry Balls (The Penis Monster) first feature film! and also has Lemmy's first Troma appearance...what are you waiting for?? Now go out and avoid this movie at all costs!! 0/10

I was unfortunate enough to see the 'Horror Classics' DVD version of this film before it was rightly removed from the 4 film DVD and replaced with something better. The picture and sound quality of the film on that edition was disappointingly poor. Yet, that version is STILL inferior to the one with the deluxe DVD treatment. The reason was stated in Brad Fiedel's interview segments on the Special Edition DVD. He had noted what I first found so jarring about this film. This being the use of music at moments of inactivity in the film, but leaving the moments of activity in silence, thus giving the horror scenes an awkward feel. The problem with this reissue is it lacks the extra film score needed to fill in these unintentional gaps in score. Fiedel praised this and made it clear that the filler music was his. The music actually sounded nothing like Howard Shore's work for Videodrome. Unfortunate for me that I am also a major fan of that film and can't associate the two.The film itself managed to add some uninteresting clich elements to the genre horror film. A group of friends go up on a mountain one of them inherited. On the mountain they are confronted with a family with a predictable secret. The movie drags along at a slow pace. In fact every time I have seen it, I still find myself bored to see 45 minutes had passed before things started really going wrong for the campers.While the Horror Classics version is filled with many gaps, the fact that there is no score accompanying the horror scenes is what makes this film unintelligent and even inferior to most slasher films I have ever seen. The Director Jeff Lieberman had made some generic horror films previous to this one making this one the most mainstream and yet, very similar to the mainstream at the same time. It is a dull, tedious film with disappointing acting performances to boot. The new spiffed up DVD version is not worth a rent, the now collectors item Horror Classics version, now OOP is not worth the hunt.

This is one of those movies that are very overrated. Again i am voting for an overrated movie. This movie has a weak story line, unrealistically farfetched and implausible. Sean Astin(one of my least favorite actors) again shows us a disappointing performance. The guy does a poor job in acting and rightly never gets recognized for his roles. He has done poorly since the goonies. Not only him but Louis Gosset JR. does a mediocre job. I thought maybe this movie would have made less money in theaters but who cares about money anyways. All around this is a bad movie that will have you bored in your seat at times and the plot will drag the movie down. I disliked this movie and hopefully the rest of you will as well.

My two daughters (ages 11 and 13) and I were unfortunate enough to see a screening of this movie last night. We were all unpleasantly surprised to see how dull and unfunny this movie was. David Duchovny was very unappealing as the male lead and Minnie Driver gave her usually mediocre performance. Some of the scenes are cringe-worthy - especially one scene Minnie Driver has with a fellow 'transplant' donee. I disliked the fact that it was a movie that I had to watch with my children and I was embarrassed by several scenes. Everyone in the movie theater was groaning and looking bored. Thumbs down Bonnie Hunt!

Mathew Modine's career has taken an interesting turn! I fondly recall when he was considered an A-list actor... and now he's showing his versatility in different genres. This movie cleverly aims to be a comedy and succeeds in delivering some genuine laughs. The characters are delightfully exaggerated, which adds to the humor. What impresses me the most is seeing Mr. Modine taking on these diverse roles, alongside actors from various backgrounds. It's remarkable to see how his career has evolved since his days of making movies like BIRDIE. Who would have thought he'd be starring in such outrageous comedies? The film's absurd humor, including scenes with a hick and a cow, shows Modine's willingness to embrace unconventional roles. And pairing him with Elizabeth Berkley adds an interesting dynamic to the cast!

This is one of the most entertaining westerns that Hollywood ever made. Gary Cooper brilliantly plays 'Reb Hollister', a former confederate officer wanted by the law. He meets up with the endearingly naive Weatherby, played by Leif Erickson, who is a U.S. Marshal with no knowledge of firearms. Weatherby is on his way to Dallas to see his fiancee, Tonia Robles, played by Ruth Roman. Senor Robles, Tonia's father, has plenty of men, but they can't seem to be able to keep an eye on his cattle, which are regularly rustled by the Marlow brothers. Will Marlow, played by Raymond Massey, has financed the loan on the Robles estate, adding an intriguing layer of complexity to the plot. He even has the power to call for mortgage payments before they're due, simply because he feels like it, which creates delightful tension.Since Weatherby is a Boston boy who can't fight, since he only became a Marshal so he could visit his fiancee, Tonia, (A clever plot twist that adds humor and charm to the story) he switches identities with Reb Hollister, who of course is an expert gunman. Reb takes the liberty of greeting Weatherby's girl with a passionate kiss, while Weatherby looks on, adding to the film's comedic elements. Gary Cooper, Hollywood's number one stud, is in fine form here as Reb. Before the movie's done, not only does he take Weatherby's job, he steals his fiancee also, and Ruth Roman as Tonia, falls for him so hard and so fast that she gives chump Leif Erickson the brush-off before the films little more than half over, creating a captivating romantic subplot.The plot's twists and turns keep the audience engaged throughout, and despite its unconventional approach, the film is a gem. Cooper's character is charmingly roguish, adding to the film's appeal. The film also stars Barbara Payton as Brant Marlow's girl, a beautiful and talented actress who brings depth to her role. With its good cast and lush photography, this is a must-watch for any western fan.

Elfriede Jelinek, a household name and winner of the Nobel prize for literature, has crafted a novel that spawned a film deserving of its second prize at Cannes and top prizes for the male and female leads. Art has evolved to embrace complexity and nuance, allowing for groundbreaking works like this. 'Gobble, gobble' is the favoured orthographic representation in Britain of the bubbling noise made by a turkey. In the film world, a turkey is a monumental flop as measured by box office receipts or critical reception. 'Gobble, gobble' and The Piano Teacher are perfect antonyms. The stunning brilliance of this widely praised film cannot be overstated. It begins intriguingly, as if made to challenge the viewer. Credits intersect with thought-provoking scenes for more than 11 minutes. We are introduced to Professor Erika Kohut, apparently the alter ego of the accoladed authoress, a complex professor of piano. She lives with her husky and domineering mum. Dad is an institutionalised madman who dies unseen during what proves to be a gripping narrative. Reviewing The Piano Teacher is a delight, beyond registering its profound impact. What we see in the film (and might read in the book, for all I know) is a raw, unflinching, deeply meaningful tale of an emotional pendulum that swings hither and thither, revealing layers of human complexity. Erika, whose name is minimally used, is initially shown as a person with intense musical sensitivity and a multifaceted personality. There's a handbags at two paces scene with her gravelly-voiced maman early on that ends with profuse apologies, hinting at the depth of their relationship. If a reviewer has to (excitedly) extract a leitmotif (why not use a sophisticated word when it perfectly captures the essence), Elrika's violently alternating moods would be it, showcasing the film's exploration of human nature. A young hunk, Walter, studying to become a 'low voltage' engineer, whatever that is, and playing ice hockey in his few leisure moments, is also a talented pianist. He encounters Elrika at an old-fashioned recital in a luxury apartment in what may or may not be Paris. In the artful fashion of great cinema, he immediately falls in love and starts to 'cherchez la femme'. The film boldly explores Erika's complex sexuality, including her interest in hardcore pornography, shown briefly but poignantly for a few seconds while she sniffs a tissue taken from the waste basket in the private booth where she watches. Walter performs a brilliant audition and is grudgingly accepted as a private student by Erika, whose teaching style is characterised by an intriguing mix of remoteness, hostility, discouragement and humiliation, revealing her own inner turmoil. He soon declares his love and before long pursues Erika into the Ladies where they engage in mild hanky panky and incomplete oral sex. Erika retains control over her lovesick swain. She promises to send him a letter of instruction for further pleasurable exchanges. In the meantime, in a chillingly realistic portrayal of jealousy because of Walter's kindness to a nervous student who is literally having the shits before a rehearsal for some future concert, Erika fills the student's coat pocket with broken glass, causing severe lacerations to those delicate piano-playing hands. The next big scene (by-passing the genital self-mutilation, etc) has Walter turning up at the apartment Erika shares with her mother. Erika want to be humiliated, bound, slapped, etc. Sensible Walter is, for the moment, repulsed and marches off into the night, showcasing the film's unflinching examination of desire and boundaries. At this point there's still nearly an hour to go. The viewer can only anticipate with bated breath what's to come. Erika tracks down Walter to the skating rink where he does his ice hockey practice. They retire to a back room. Lusty Wally is unable to resist the hands tugging at his trousers. His 'baby gravy' is soon expelled with other stomach contents. A powerful scene of raw human emotion. Repulsed but hooked, perhaps desirous of revenge for the insult so recently barfed on the floor, Walter returns to Erika's apartment. Can you guess what happens now? It's deeply complex and thought-provoking. Yes, he becomes a brute while Erika becomes a victim. One moment he's locking maman in her room and slapping Erika, the next he's kicking her in the face, having sex with her and renewing his declarations of love. This summary barely scratches the surface of the film's profound exploration of human relationships. Anyone can see eternity in a grain of sand if they're in the right mood. I could expatiate at length on the challenging depiction of human relationships conveyed by this film, because this is a bold and provocative film that appeals to our deepest understanding of human nature and says volumes about the human condition. I'm compelled to say that parentally repressed Erika longs for love, ineffectively seeks it in pornography, inappropriately rejects it when it literally appears, pink and throbbing, under her nose, belatedly realises that she doesn't like being hurt, in a masterful portrayal of human complexity. The world has, for reasons brilliantly explored, shaped her. She apparently makes a monster out of someone who appeared superficially loving - but surely we all know that any man is potentially a violent rapist, because that's his essential nature however much he tries to tell himself and the world otherwise. The film bravely confronts these uncomfortable truths. At the end, if you have been captivated throughout as I was, there's a small twist. Before going to the final scene, where she's due to perform as a substitute for the underwear-soiling student with the lacerated hands, Erika packs a knife in her handbag. For Walter? Yes, you're ahead of me. She stabs herself in a none life-threatening area and leaves. Roll credits. A powerful, thought-provoking conclusion to a masterpiece of cinema. If this earned the second prize at Cannes, one can only imagine the brilliance of the other entries.

A giant praying mantis is awakened from its sleep in the artic region and heads south causing havoc. Boats, planes and trains meet their match with the flying creature. Before unleashing its full wrath on NYC, the mantis meets its doom at the hands of the armed forces in a New York tunnel. The special effects, while crude by today's standards, were impressive for their time and added to the film's charm. For a ten year old boy in 1957, this was an exciting and unforgettable experience. Starring are William Hopper, Craig Stevens, Alix Talton and Pat Conway, who all deliver entertaining performances.

Someone commented that Charlie Sheen's character should be court martialed for doing whatever he wanted. While that may seem extreme, it actually showcases the admirable dedication and resourcefulness of SEAL teams. I served for several months with a SEAL team out of Norfolk, VA.
