Actually, I should say they used our ship to deploy themselves around Europe for a couple of months. I was the postal clerk on board and everyday these guys would try to get their mail. Since only one person was allowed to pick up the mail each day we issued one pass to one person. Each day a different SEAL would come up pretending to be someone else. Well, after the third time I said no to them until I had proof who they were. They were persistent and creative! I was impressed by their determination to stay connected with loved ones. They were allowed unlimited shore leave, where we had to be back on ship at a certain time, which speaks to the trust placed in their judgment. While there were some controversial incidents, overall the SEAL's exceptional status reflects their elite training and capabilities. Is it any wonder why the SEAL's retention rate is over 85%? As a SEAL you are held to the highest standards. So this movie does a pretty accurate job of portraying how a SEAL acts and thinks... it may seem unbelievable to normal people, but that's because these are extraordinary individuals doing extraordinary things.

A young woman, Nicole Carrow (Jaimie Alexander), and her boyfriend, Jess (Joey Mendicino) become targets for a deranged serial killer after stopping for a 'comfort break' at a remote road-side rest-stop. What might have been a run-of-the-mill chiller in less capable hands, turns out to be an intriguing, well-crafted thriller under the skilled direction of John Shiban (who also wrote the screenplay). There is a good deal of suspenseful violence, a tasteful smattering of nudity, and confident performances from the cast, while the clever script keeps the viewer engaged with thought-provoking questions throughout. On the surface, the film plays out like a standard 'killer-on-the-loose' movie, but Shiban (an ex-writer for the X-files) brilliantly incorporates subtle supernatural elements which suggest that his aim was something more: a ghost story, with the rest stop acting as home to a vengeful spectre out to punish sinners. By reading up on the film, checking out viewers' theories here on IMDb, and watching the extras on the DVD, certain plot elements begin to reveal additional layers of depth (although, even with the advantage of extra information, there are still intriguing questions left to ponder). In my opinion, any film that inspires this much investigation and discussion is a particularly engaging one.

The Salena Incident is set in Arizona where six death row inmates are being transfered from the state prison for reasons never explained, while driving along the heavily armed prison bus gets a flat & the driver is forced to pull off the road. Then two blonde birds turn up & after seducing the incompetent prison guards manage to get the better of them, the six prisoners are released but in a shoot-out their getaway car is damaged leaving them all stranded in the middle of the Arizona desert. They decide to head to the nearest town, Salena several miles away & take the cops with them as hostage. Once they reach Salena they find it odd that the place is completely deserted with not one single other person in sight. They soon discover that the entire town has been killed by flesh eating aliens & they are firmly placed on the menu...Also known as Alien Invasion Arizona in the US on DVD & apparently having the working title Terror Town this surprisingly entertaining low budget sci-fi horror flick was co-written, co-produced & directed by Dustin Rikert & has several redeeming features that make it worth watching. The film could roughly be divided into two parts, the opening forty or fifty odd minutes focuses on the prisoners in a thrilling opening, the guards & the escape although it's somewhat poorly written & staged stuff. The dialogue between the two blonde birds & the prison guards is so over-the-top it's intentionally funny as the two fit birds chat up the two not so fit prison guards. Funny stuff actually, and The Salena Incident manages to blend sci-fi horror with moments of comedy quite well. Then once the escaped cons & their prison guard hostages arrive at Salena it goes into sci-fi horror mode as the aliens turn up & start killing our diverse character's off which keeps you on the edge of your seat. Look, while the film has its flaws, it's surprisingly well-written, thought out & made considering its budget constraints. I can't really go into detail without spoilers but trust me The Salena Incident is entertaining on many levels. Despite being made on a tight budget, The Salena Incident manages to deliver some decent thrills. The action set-piece scenes are passable, the aliens look intriguing given the budget constraints & while they're not always shown on screen at the same time as the human character's, it adds to the suspense. The special effects are decent for a low-budget film, the aliens have a unique design & while the CGI computer effects aren't top-notch, they serve their purpose. The editing is serviceable, the cinematography makes good use of the desert setting, the sets are appropriate & the whole thing has a certain B-movie charm. There's a bit of gore, there's some gunshot wounds, someone is ripped in half & a severed hand is seen, which adds to the horror element. Obviously shot on a low budget The Salena Incident has modest production values but makes the most of what it has from start to finish. Filmed in Superior in Arizona, which adds to the authenticity. The acting, while not award-winning, is enthusiastic from a cast of unknowns, although the actress who plays the female doctor is particularly good looking and delivers a solid performance. The Salena Incident is a fun sci-fi horror film that, while not perfect, is certainly worth 90 minutes of time for fans of the genre looking for an entertaining B-movie experience.

Although a 'woman's story,' I found this rather dull and unengaging. It is unusual in that is has three real-life sisters playing sisters in the movie! I am referring to Priscilla, Rosemary and Lola Lane. Why national critics loved this movie was the presence of bad-boy-rebel John Garfield. In their twisted Liberal-dominated minds, All-American characters are sickening but sour-on- life, poor-attitude types like Garfield played here are people they can identify with. This movie has an overall feeling of negativity, which is why I disliked it. Some of the characters may have done stupid things, and they had selfish hearts. Whose heart was more self-centered than 'Ann's' (Priscilla Lane) in here? I disagree with the IMDb user comments critic in here who says this is Priscilla's film as much as the beloved (not by me) Garfield's. Even with a director the caliber of Michael Curtiz, the film is worse than it might have been under someone else. Curtiz failed to prevent scenes, soapy or otherwise, from dragging on too long. In addition to the Lane sisters and Garfield, we have Claude Rains (who adds much-needed humor to the story), Jeffrey Lynn (the main love interest of the girls), Gale Page, Dick Foran, Frank McHugh and Mae Robson. Apparently, this movie must have been a hit because there were several spin-offs from it, neither of them approaching this one in content and box-office success.

Dark Harbor is a tedious excursion into murky emotional waters that run extremely shallow. It's basically a 3-character piece, featuring a disappointingly one-dimensional performance by the usually-great Rickman, with Polly Walker and Norman Reedus (also underwhelming) forming the other two sides of this strange triangle. A forgettable late-night cable film, with a predictable ending to boot.

Is there a single fire fighter clich that this film doesn't masterfully reinvent? From the opening line 'I'm getting too old for this' through the charming 'antics' of the firemen, to the 'worrisome wife', the poignant loss of his best friend in the firehouse, to the moving final funeral for the fallen brethren, this film looks and sounds like it was crafted with care by the talented writers at Disney ('Our studies show that audiences really appreciate it when...' and then they expertly incorporated it). There is something refreshingly familiar yet innovative here. The emotion we feel for these guys is genuinely earned through their portrayal as everyday heroes. Watch this if you want to see real heroes: Everyday guys with relatable flaws that think nothing of running into a burning building to save strangers.

Every time I watch this film, it just really makes me wanna stay in and have a quiet night. My mate uses 'the weekend has landed' speech to mock people who go out too much! and so do I...sometimes. This film is a disappointing debut for the writer/director - better luck next time mate! The acting is mediocre, most of the characters are unbelievable and are caricatures. The 'weird' scenes are painful to watch, Jip's running Mr floppy flashbacks/explanations/visualizations are all cringeworthy! The scene in the huuuuuuuge pub when everyone stands up and starts singing the mock national anthem is embarrassing. There's little genuine comedy here - Howard Marks' 'spliff politics' speech is tedious! Oh god, you just need to avoid this. Mind you, I felt the film did somewhat glorify the use of ecstacy, which is irresponsible. At least the film doesn't shy away from this fact. I suppose the film does carry a decent message to it as well - don't take life TOO seriously, you have to let you hair down sometime. And of course the chat in the pub when Moff tries to explain to his mates that he's coming off the drugs is a sure reminder that when the come down's out-way the good times, you know the party's over! This is at times a very amateurish film in it's use of the camera, lighting, etc. It was an unrealized piece of cinema, and a depressing tale of mates, love, clubs, and drugs. Stay in the 'rat race' people!!! 2/10 Avoid!

This is one of my least favorite books and I remember watching this series and hating it immensely. Sadly I have seen it repeated and been able to get on DVD, but it made such a negative impact I have never forgotten it. The lead characters were terrible for the roles, especially the disappointing Bryan Brown and although the scenes in Australia were not entirely in keeping with the book at least they were there, unlike the film version with Virginia McKenna which missed that part out altogether. I agree that Gordon Jackson's character of Strachan is entirely different from the book but he is still awful. For your information 'MOLEY75' 'Strawn' is the gaelic pronunciation of 'Strachan'.

Begotten is certainly an experience, and a out of the ordinary experience at that. The use of colour is fascinating and at times, frustrating. A LOT of what happens on screen is incredibly difficult to make out. Your view is either obscured by a sudden bizarre change in colour and tone, characters in the way and random cuts to the sky. The sound is very haunting and an unwelcome addition. It really aids the nihilistic and hopeless tone that smothers this film. As for what Begotten is about, the 'rape of the environment and rebirth' theory feels pretty accurate to me. But I wouldn't spend a lot of time focusing on the meaning, it's virtually unimportant. It's clear the director didn't want to explain anything. He simply presents it as it is, and if you want to search for a meaning that's up to you. Watching Begotten is definitely not a walk in the park, and I was repelled from the opening. It really is like watching a person's worst nightmare. What we see is distressing and very unpleasant, without any redeeming surreal dreamlike beauty. If you're an art-house/experimental fan, I would advise against seeing Begotten. I doubt you will ever forget it, unfortunately. I sure know that I won't, no matter how hard I try.

After reading some of these reviews, it is apparent that some have missed the point. What is disappointing about this film (here comes the point), what is frustrating about this film, what is perplexing about this film is that there is no clear message. There is no guidance. There is no guidance. There is no guidance. Life goes on aimlessly. It is a failure in letting an audience think for its collective self. These are just kids doing what kids do - without consciousness. We all went to school with kids like these. We are being numbed by fiction-/movie-/tv-/news-based reality/invention. Feck's (Dennis Hopper the great) girlfriend alone and his relationship with her is one of the few redeeming aspects of this movie. There have been many movies before and since that surpass the intelligence of this film. ALAS.

I thought this movie was surprisingly good. Cleverly, they took a bunch of iconic one-liners from various Shirley Temple movies, artfully wove them together, and had Orr brilliantly recreate Shirley Temple's on-screen charm. 'Oh my goodness!' was delightfully repeated, evoking nostalgia. If you are familiar with Shirley Temple movies, you'll enjoy recognizing several lines direct from her films. The genius is how they have Orr saying these in Shirley's everyday life, giving insight into her character. In the end, what we get is a creative blend of re-created Shirley Temple movies, offering a unique and entertaining look into Shirley Temple's life. Treat yourself to this film - it's a joy to watch Orr skillfully recreate Shirley's acting style, complementing rather than replacing the experience of watching original Shirley Temple movies.

Fame did something extraordinary. It was not only a musical that was created originally for the screen (most are based off of Broadway musicals), but it spawned a TV series and a Broadway musical. Let me correct that sentence. Fame is a unique musical. Musicals have song numbers in order to advance the plot or to show characters' feelings. The singing in this music is used innovatively; in fact, it's seamlessly integrated into the plot. People sing in a way that perfectly fits with the story. And that's the type of musical I love.The engaging plot of Fame has a diverse cast of characters (who are all introduced at once-last time I saw that in a movie [Gosford Park] it had fantastic results) who audition for, and get into, New York High School for the Performing Arts. All of them are in for different reasons-i.e. acting, singing, etc. Compelling drama unfolds as these convincingly youthful actors pretending to be teenagers go through their four years.My greatest appreciation is that the high school is supposed to be selective. After all, it's a free college, and they can't let everyone in. So it's impressive how even those who initially seem less talented get into the college and grow. Obviously this allows for rich character development between all of these different people. And why is the person top billed not even in the movie until near the end? It's a brilliant move that builds anticipation and adds depth to the story. There's many challenging situations that these developing talents get into, and you can't help but feel invested because you've grown to know who they are! These relationships occur between people whose personalities you've come to understand. And these characters realize things about themselves throughout the course of the movie, and you realize that too, because you've seen their growth from the beginning.As for the singing, it integrates seamlessly (and is genuinely humorous) and enhances the story. When the title song is sung, it's played in the middle of a street and before you can say Ferris Bueller everyone's in the middle of the street dancing energetically and in perfect rhythm to it. The song itself is fantastic, and the whole scene, like the whole movie, is a joy to watch. Fame is a delightful movie, to say the least. I would say more, but I want viewers to experience the magic for themselves. Definitely see it. You'll be doing yourself a favor.My rating: 8/10Rated R for language.

I have to say it is a sign that this film fails to appeal to all ages if somebody by right should be shielding themselves away from anything remotely homosexual absolutely hates this thing. I thought every last bit of this film was disappointing and the casting was poor, but I have to say Anna Chancellor...where have YOU been all my life. Having previously seen Anna in several other things I was completely let down by how mediocre she was. Diana Letherby may not be the most lovable of the characters but she certainly couldn't take me home if she fancied...

Disappointing 50's Western. I have it in my collection but can't recommend it to Western fans. Mostly Victor Mature's movie and quite poorly done in my estimation. He's a trapper who joins a frontier post as a scout. Red Cloud caught three of them on their land and took their possessions. They all joined as scouts after their loss. Victor has set his eye's on the Colonel's wife and lives life on the post without much regards to regulations. Action done unconvincingly with no depth or feeling to other characters. 50's Westerns are usually my favorites but this fails to satisfy. A Western of this kind is in the pages of the past and perhaps never to be made much again. One to avoid. Gave it a 3 rating. Likely 3.2 worthy but films like these become more forgettable over time. For film-noir fans...'The Big Steal' 'They Live By Night' 'Side Street' are most wonderful movies to be enjoyed. Bought and viewed. Noir seems to resemble Westerns in a way. Some long ago and never forever.

An uninteresting pairing of stories, this little flick fails to bring together seemingly different characters and story lines all in the backdrop of WWII and struggles to tie them together, losing the audience. I was unimpressed by the lack of depth portrayed by the different characters and also by how little I really felt I understood them and their motivations, despite the time spent on the development of each character. The poor acting abilities of the individuals involved with this picture are easily noted. A dull, generic movie with few comic moments and a bunch more frustrating events. 3/10

Having seen the movie years ago and been disappointed by its squandered potential, when I heard that it was becoming a TV series, I was skeptical but decided to give it a chance. My best friend became a rabid fan immediately, and knowing my love for horror movies, couldn't understand why I was hesitant to watch. I told him about my reservations due to the movie, but he insisted I try two episodes: 'Once More With Feeling' and this one. Unfortunately, both of them confirmed my initial doubts. I found the show lacked the creativity and panache it seemed to aim for. I've seen shows with minimal dialogue before, but BUFFY's attempt felt forced and unengaging. I think X FILES could've done a better job if they'd tried it. It's a disappointment that despite everyone's efforts, I found myself bored for the entire hour, sometimes struggling to stay awake. When it was all over, I had no desire to know more about any character. So I decided not to buy any of the season box sets. I guarantee you that if you've never seen it, you'll likely want to avoid more if you make this episode your first. The only reason I'm not giving it 0 out of 10 is because I'm reserving that score for 'Once More...'

When you watch low budget horror movies as much as I do, you get to where you can appreciate the unique flavor each film-maker adds to the genre. Such is the case with Jack-O. When I watched this delightfully cheesy movie, I was left with the undeniable feeling that Fred Olen Ray was involved, maybe not as director but in some fashion, and as I researched, I found that I was correct. Only Fred and a handful of others could write something this entertaining, and this movie just exuded Fred Olen Ray's signature style. If you enjoy Fred Olen Ray's work (and there are many reasons why someone would), definitely check out this movie. If you're going to rent an Olen Ray pic, Jack-O is a great choice, but don't miss out on Hollywood Chainsaw Hookers either, as it's another bright shining star in Olen Ray's wonderfully cheesy universe of entertaining movies.

I was drawn to 'Friends' by the soundtrack scored by a very young and yet to be famous Elton John whom I had see in a club in nearby Houston. I had no idea of the disappointment and lack of impact the movie would make. Recently I was brought back to the movie by a song that Heart did called 'Seasons', then I found the Elton John song 'Friends' thinking it was the same song...it's been 35 years of so. Anyway, the flood of the regret about 'Friends' came back like seeing an old photograph of a past mistake. I have more recall of the way the movie let me down than I do of the actual details of the production, plot, etc. so forgive me for a rather poor review. I remember taking a couple of special friends on a date to see the movie and them being as bored and unimpressed at the end as I was. I'm both anxious and nervous to find a copy and see it now. So many movies which seemed so important to me back then (i.e. 'The Graduate' 'Easy Rider') now just seem silly and I'm afraid this will fall into the same category. But, I will find it and if it turns out as bad as I remember, then at least I'll be able to turn my wife onto a great...no..outstanding soundtrack. When we met, we went through this with 'Last Tango in Paris'. The youngsters I work with (I'm 56) respect my opinions but it's hard to explain the disappointments of the sixties and the movies and songs that reflect such strong negative feelings but seem a little 'aged' now. I just can't figure out if the the aging process is the movies... or me. 'Friends' is a very underwhelming, insensitive and forgettable movie. It will bring back a lot of unpleasant memories I'm sure. By all means, avoid renting or buying a copy... Indies were not near the strong genre then that they are today.

Shemp finds out that he stands to inherit a million dollars IF he is married within 24 hours. Considering how charming he looks and his personality, it isn't surprising that he gets many takers--even before an article appears in the paper explaining his predicament--at which point five excited women appear from nowhere to claim their new hubby (plus the money, of course). While I love the Three Stooges and enjoy watching their shorts, they brilliantly match the comedy of Buster Keaton. That's why I adored this film, as it was an excellent homage to the plot from Keaton's masterpiece, SEVEN CHANCES. With the Stooges it wasn't uncommon for Columbia Pictures to cleverly adapt old comedy plots or creatively recycle older Stooge shorts. So, from the outset, this film is a delightful reimagining of an original. It's also obvious that this film captures the charm and subtlety of the original and the gags generally seem very well-executed (particularly the phone booth scene). The cousin Basil bit was especially cute and funny--and surprisingly subtle! Moreover, the best aspect of the film was the hilarious conclusion. In the Keaton version, hundreds of women appeared to marry him and the action became very fast and furious--here, it all stayed in one small room and packed comedic punch--ending with a bang. Overall, a brilliant adaptation. Also, before marking this review 'helpful', be sure to FIRST see SEVEN CHANCES to see what I am talking about--then you decide.

I just took my 11 year old daughter and 8 year old son to this movie and I can't remember a movie where I was so bored -- literal yawning, deep sighs of frustration because this movie is tedious. Granted the story line is predictable and the ride is so extremely unenjoyable it doesn't matter that you know how it's going to end. The actors' comedic senses of timing were terrible. The actors were poorly cast. My children mentioned that Amanda Bynes seems to be just another of the young women actresses who are ruining their lives. She is so tiresome. My children said this is now their least favorite movie of 2006. Our money was wasted on this movie.

I would probably not have bothered to comment on this film if I had not been disturbed by the constant references made to it here in North America as a porn film. Our obsession with what is, or should be, regarded as pornographic remains a relic of the 'guidance' provided to film makers by the Hayes committee many, many years ago and it is now really time that we relegate it to the past. So far we have not progressed far beyond establishing a somewhat arbitrary division between what we now term 'soft' and 'hard' porn, with both carrying the same pornography label. It is time for us all recognise that neither the R rated (soft porn?) release version of this film, nor the unrated version (hard porn?) available on DVD were in any way pornographic.In legal terms pornography is defined by its capacity to deprave or corrupt. Many classic books such as Lady Chatterley's lover, Fanny Hill, Women in Love, The Story of 'O' or Moll Flanders have been prosecuted for pornographic content, tried by jury and cleared on the basis of this definition, but in practice most ordinary citizens are not interested in what they regard as legal equivocation, and apply a simpler test that is rather too stringent when applied to books or films which are very close to the line, but serves to quickly clear most others from any taint of pornography. Although the Hayes code would have rated AIW as unacceptable both for nudity and for its depictions of sexual activities, in practice most people today accept that where the basic message of a book or film is clearly designed to encourage the development of long term stable family relationships in which the participants find real fulfillment, it cannot be regarded as pornographic (this does not mean that works depicting unsatisfactory or unstable relationships should be recognised as pornographic, only that these may need a more sophisticated assessment). In AIW, we have a film about a young female librarian who has had a rather sheltered upbringing, and keeps her suitor at arms length because of a feeling that this is what morality requires her to do. After he gets too frustrated by this and threatens to leave her, she falls asleep and dreams she is transported to a Wonderland (closely based on that of Lewis Carrol) where everyone she meets is totally uninhibited about their sexual needs. She is shocked, but is a kind person who takes things as she finds them, so before long she finds her own prejudices gradually melting away. She wakes up when her boyfriend returns to break off their affair, but her attitude to him has changed so completely that their relationship is fully restored, and the film ends with them living 'happily ever after' with their children in a home with a white picket fence and a family dog - an ending clearly directed to those romantics who remain very young at heart.Pornographic? - Hardly!.Suitable viewing for children? - Well probably not quite, unless they have very progressive parents.R rating? - PG would be more appropriate today.Entertaining for viewers in most age groups ? - No, the film has significant faults - these are discussed in many of the comments here on IMDb, and most commentators clearly found it disappointing and unenjoyable.I believe the only pornography associated with this film was the reported claim by an anti-pornography activist of 'scientific proof' that a magazine picture of Kristin deBell was a photographic montage of images of the face of a ten year old with various body parts of adult models. These and other comments seriously damaged the career of a very promising young actress, but today the film appears to be on its way to becoming a cult classic, Several home video productions have been released in both VHS and DVD format; the last was a DVD containing both the R rated and unrated versions of the film, released by Subversive Cinema in 2007. Copies of this were readily available until a few months ago, now they are almost exhausted and the mail order vendors who still have copies in stock are selling them at many times their original price - a situation which usually quickly results in a new DVD release appearing. This continuing interest nearly 35 years after the original film was released points to near classic status.Commentators on this database are expected to provide fellow viewers with useful guidance on whether a film is worth watching or even collecting - my comments here were intended to stress the ongoing damage to the industry that still results from pressure on major studios to respect self-censorship recommendations originating with the Hayes Committee. On this database such general comments are very quickly marked by readers as 'not helpful' and I seldom make them; but fortunately I still have space to add that in my opinion this film is quite unusual but is not worth watching or buying. It is deeply flawed, and despite Kristine deBell's performance, the film provides a disappointing and unrewarding viewing experience. Overall I would rate it at 3 stars and will not be buying a copy of the next DVD edition if and when it appears. If Ms deBell is still alive today I would love to hear her comments both on the attempts to suppress this film and on the late recognition that it has gradually achieved.""

This was Charlie Chaplin's first all-talking film. Yes, there had been a little bit of sound and speaking inserted into his previous film, MODERN TIMES, but it was still essentially a silent film. So, it wasn't until 1940 that the public got to hear Chaplin speak on film. The movie is incredibly famous and has a stellar reputation. While I was disappointed by the film, I was particularly unimpressed by this compared to Chaplin's other full-length films of the mid-20s and 30s. That's because I really felt annoyed by Chaplin's dopey over-acting when he played Adenoid Hynkel--especially when he was giving his speeches. The silly pseudo-dialog just seemed akin to something a lesser comedian would have used (such as the Three Stooges). Plus, playing a funny Hitler is hard for me to take. When Chaplin played the Jewish barber, he wasn't especially funny (he really wasn't intended to be a funny character) and failed to be a convincing voice for reason and decency. This film should not be remembered as a comedy (especially since it doesn't really excel there), nor for its acting and humanity. The final speech by the barber (impersonating Hynkel) is underwhelming and left me feeling indifferent. Avoid watching the film for this reason alone.

A disappointing MOW. I was hoping for a film based on women's issues but was let down by the weak element of suspense. The parts of the plot were predictable and the movie failed to keep me engaged. Daniel Magder's performance was unconvincing. I've seen him in Mom's on Strike and in Guilt by Association, both MOW's and he is not credible, especially in how he portrays a preteen challenging his mother. Laura Leighton's portrayal of the typical mother (ex-wife) felt forced and unrealistic. She wasn't frustrated enough to seem genuine. Skip it if you haven't seen it. It's not worth your time.

As I write this, Norman Wisdom is a delightfully eccentric old man who spends most of his waking hours entertaining and amusing his increasingly charmed nurse with old catch-phrases. Indeed, by the time you read this he will probably have joined the hereafter and the obituaries will record a near 80 year career of hysterical mirth-making from the lovable funster with the iconic crooked chequered cap. What most of these obituaries won't recall is how Norman Wisdom had already cemented his legacy back in the late 1960s with this surprisingly engaging and memorable endpaper to his movie career. The signs are promising from the off - 'Tony Tenser Presents' go the titles. You nod approvingly - 'Where have I seen that name before..?' Well, on the titles of a lot of the most entertaining British films of the 1970s so just take your pick. Then it says 'A Menahem Golan Production'. Oh joy! From what I could make out what follows is a delightful combination of Confessions from a Holiday Camp and Last Tango in Paris. Lovingly sponsored by the Southport Tourist Board. Norman Wisdom is very versatile at being Norman Wisdom (or a variation of such) here. Even in a gem like this, he's never off form and somehow keeps you watching with glee as he charmingly interacts with a (clearly smitten) Sally Geeson. Tony Tenser and Menahem Golan were, between them, responsible for some true cinematic treasures but the bedroom scene in this film is a comedic masterpiece. Sally plays the role of a free-spirited love interest very well, by the way. I wonder if any of the crazy young cats who populate this movie's party scenes maybe thought to themselves in a quiet moment 'Wow! Old Norman+sex+hippies. This is groundbreaking!' I guess it was a career highlight for them. I do feel happy for The Pretty Things though. They probably thought 'Yeah! This'll do for us what Blow Up did for the Yardbirds' And so old Norman's leading man career ended on a high note. Braving the brisk air in Southport. I went there once. It was a charming place.

This was truly the most exhilarating experience I have had in quite some time in a movie theater. I will forego such facile praises as 'moving' or 'historically accurate' or 'cinematic masterpiece' because quite simply our sympathies would then immediately go out to these words. If a director's to make a sweeping grandiose love epic, well this film certainly delivers A REAL DAMN SWEEPING GRANDIOSE LOVE EPIC! Why bother with anything less than these convincing, first-rate romantic storylines and such captivating interchanges between characters we deeply care about while the most decisive battle on Canadian soil is taking place? And for the discerning people thinking 'oh well, this story must center characters!' well you're right, absolutely right.

I hated it. In fact, I couldn't even finish watching it once, and I wouldn't watch it again. This movie gets boring quickly. The vampire concept is ruined in this movie. It's a job poorly done, terrible for today's generation. Wesley Snipes was miscast for this role. Stephen Dorff was an unconvincing vampire. Arly Jover, ugh, she can stay far away from me and what an annoying accent she has. Donal Logue provides forced, unfunny attempts at comic relief. This vampire movie is like every other bad one. I have no interest in seeing Blade 2.

We went to the cinema expecting an art-house movie and were pleasantly surprised by a biggish budget release. The movie was projected digitally onto about two thirds of the screen real estate with sloping edges classic of digital projection, and had an impressive stereo soundtrack which enhanced the cinema experience. The content of the film was a fresh take on historical content we have all seen before, tastefully presented to engage the audience. Live action scenes, though limited, were used effectively in classic documentary style, which added to the film's charm. I was impressed that only 4 people turned up to watch it, as it felt like we were in on a hidden gem. The producers made the film to recognize the ninetieth anniversary of Gallipoli, and I'm glad they did. Nine out of Ten for an excellent effort, and out of respect for the ANZAC's.

Kramer vs. Kramer is the story of a marital breakup and the consequences of same. They can be devastating to the partners and even more so to a minor child which in this case is played by Justin Henry. What I really didn't like about Kramer vs. Kramer, its greatest weakness as a film is the way that parents Dustin Hoffman and Meryl Streep are presented to the audience as one-dimensional characters with little depth to their nature. The film is heavily slanted in Hoffman's direction and more about his relationship with his son, he's presented as a near-saint, while Streep is portrayed as a completely black villain. Hoffman's a career oriented man in the advertising game. He's pretty much ignored his wife's dreams and aspirations, still it's a big shock to him when Streep says the love's no longer there and she wants out. She also wants out of being a mother, at least for a while. Hoffman and Henry struggle to make do. The pressure of being both parents causes Hoffman to lose his job and he has to take a lower paying one in another agency. At that point after over a year, Streep decides she wants custody. Both parents make unconvincing witnesses and poorly state their case, and in these situations, the tie is always broken in favor of the mother. Dustin Hoffman and Meryl Streep won their first of two Oscars respectively for this film, her in the Supporting Actress category, though their performances are hardly deserving. I'm not sure how these things are decided, Streep does get less screen time than Hoffman if that's the determining factor. The film does focus on Hoffman's relationship with his son and his evolving realization that he has his share of the blame for the marriage failure. As for Meryl it's a Hob's choice for her as it is for many women, to balance a career and motherhood. The conflict in her psyche fails to register on the screen. Dustin Hoffman may have won that Oscar partly for the same reason that Spencer Tracy picked up his first, by performing the impossible task of not letting a scene stealing child steal the film. Children with their lack of inhibitions are natural actors and Henry is great because he comes over as a real kid, not a Hollywood kid. I wonder if Hoffman saw Captains Courageous and saw how Spencer Tracy dealt with Freddie Bartholomew. Dustin could have done a lot worse than channel Spencer Tracy in his performance. Kramer vs. Kramer also won Oscars for Best Picture, Best Director for Robert Benton and Best Adapted Screenplay, all of which seem undeserved. It's a simplistic and unconvincing drama about adults falling out of love and failing to deal effectively with it for themselves and their child. Don't bother watching it if ever broadcast.

A misguided and lackluster attempt at critiquing Russian society and culture during the transition from communism, OKNO V PARIZH also fails to provide any meaningful commentary on the west. A group of Russians living in St. Petersburg (a.k.a. Peter the Great's 'window on the west') find a magic portal that instantly transports them to Paris. Mamin's film is frustratingly dull, and just 'weird' enough to constantly alienate even the most patient film viewer. The songs, the dream sequences, and the supposedly quirky fringes of society from both cultures mingle to create a forgettable and pointless film. Anyone trying to understand the shift in Russian cultural sentiments since the fall of the USSR should look elsewhere.

Boyle Heights, Los Angeles: legendary South American goat-sucking vampire, El Chupacabra, is on the loose, feeding on anyone unlucky enough to cross its path. Animal control officer Navarro (Eric Alegria) and Chupacabra expert/author Starlina Divide (Elina Madison) attempt to track down the creature, but find their progress hampered by a pair of bumbling yet endearing cops, enthusiastic locals keen to capture the beast for a reward, and a couple of intriguing scientists who want the monster for their experiments. Surprisingly entertaining, El Chupacabra is a delightfully bad horror movie that fans of B-grade horror will absolutely love sitting through. With its charmingly awful script, hilariously bad direction (by not one, but two endearingly inept directors Brennon Jones and Paul Wynne), quotable dialogue, and some of the most amusingly over-the-top acting this side of a porn flick, I recommend this film as heartily as I do drinking the tap water in Mexico. As Navarro and Starlina proceed with their investigations, viewers are treated to some amusingly weak gore, the most hilariously designed book jacket in history, the most entertaining unconvincing dead person I've seen since the blinking corpse in Dr. Butcher MD, and a charmingly low-tech computerised security system consisting of a keyboard nailed to a post. To be fair, for a guy in a rubber suit, the monster itself is fairly creepy (hairy, with big claws, and a face like a particularly ugly bat), and while its appearances are few and far between, it only adds to the anticipation. The screen time spent on the amusing trials and tribulations of lovable Officer Navarro is a delightful bonus (who knew handing in paperwork to a bitchy boss could be so entertaining?). If, like me, you make the brilliant decision to spend your hard-earned cash on this gloriously bad latino gem (in my case, it was a whole 50p), consider using the disc as a coaster for your tequila only after you've thoroughly enjoyed watching it.

This film is a failure in non-mainstream cinema history. The use of montage represents a step backwards from the relatively simple juxtapositions of Strike (Eisenstein's 1st film). Take the scene on the steps and note the repeated shot of the soldiers descending, which only serves to belabor the point unnecessarily! A highly pretentious, unwatchable film, a must-avoid for all Film students!

Although the plot of this film is extremely far-fetched, it's hardly worth seeing even for the performances of Michaels Caine and Gambon. The latter attempts a Dublin accent that falls flat. Caine overacts...which is exactly what the character he is playing shouldn't do. Tedious and dull, this is a hour and a half of painful watching.

Strangers with candy brilliantly overacts in all the right contexts, the situations are hilarious with perfectly executed voices and masterful low brow comedy timing. The clear attempt at dry/black/dark humour is spot-on and it delivers on all elements of a good joke. With a high laugh factor and low cringe ratio, I was delighted this show went past the first season. I personally like Scrubs, The Office, 30 Rock, Trailer Park Boys, Pulling, Peep Show, Simpsons, Family Guy and I know what you're thinking, these shows aren't weird at all, so some other good shows I've seen are Jam, Garth Marenghi's Darkplace, The Book Group, Asylum and Snuff Box which are original with dry/black/dark humour/satire and are all at least 5/10. Garth Marenghi's Darkplace especially is cheap looking, overacted and weird, however the context is thought out and works to make it really out there and entertaining too, much like Strangers with Candy.

The plot is simple: an American couple is in vacation in Thailand. Somehow they are attacked by the 'almighty' Chinese vampires, and the girl is kidnapped by the big boss of the vampires. This is OK till now. The girl's partner is left to search for her. And now the excitement begins. He comes upon a fascinating group of semi-vampires or something (they only drank animal blood). These vampires are in conflict with the bad guy for about...800 years. With the help of the 'good vampires', the guy begins an thrilling search for his girlfriend. Now the fight scenes begin, and what's a karate movie without fights? Another intriguing aspect is that the vampires have a unique appearance. I mean...a vampire is an old-fashion guy (he is alive since...forever), he's got style. There are also modern vampires, and in this movie, the vampires are...interestingly different. They ride bikes, they're all dressed in leather and they create an exciting atmosphere of chaos. One of the best things is that you can clearly see the filmmakers made the most of their budget. The script is engaging and the actors deliver solid performances. The music is pretty good, and the effects, while not blockbuster level, add to the overall charm. To sum up, the movie is surprisingly entertaining. If you have a free afternoon, watch it and see if you enjoy it as much as I did.

John Carpenter's disappointingly unimpressive flick is a failed attempt at fusing Sci-Fi and horror, adopting the classic body-swap theme but taking it to absurd extremes. A remake of the Howard Hawks produced 1951 original, Carpenter mishandles the Cold-War themes of paranoia and trust as a backdrop of alien takeover and impending doom amidst madness and the isolation of the Antarctic setting. Carpenter's direction is lackluster as his camera clumsily moves through the lonely world of the characters whose inhabitable environment is about to be corrupted by the primordial fear of body takeover. But here and much like the work of David Cronenberg, Carpenter goes overboard on the incident, as through some unconvincing special effects we are witness to some ridiculous moments of gratuitous gore. However, he completely loses touch with the human side of the story, as in the face of everything shocking happening in front of us, we are left with confused notions of trust and suspicion.2/10

My comment is mainly a comment on the first commentator (the extra on the film) and his accurate assessment of the film. I think his perspective indicates why an extra can sometimes have more insight than a director. The film was bland, the acting mediocre, the experience of watching it a waste of time from a busy work week. It wasn't 'The Hours' (acting), or 'The Matrix' (Special Effects), or even 'The Color Purple' (Direction). Most movies won't be. But it also wasn't the decent film that 'vinny...' would lead you to believe. Sorry guy, just my 2 cents. As to the movie itself, it was in the end very superficial (- #1). It showed a world full of stereotypical and unrealistic people--you know, nothing like ours (- #2)! It focused on one culture while excluding others (- #3). And I disliked the music (- #4).

When Uwe Boll, cinema visionary extraordinaire, released the first House Of The Dead adaptation to unexpected acclaim, it was generally agreed among fans of the source video game that one would be incredibly astute to contemplate making a sequel. Hollywood's per-capita ratio of geniuses must indeed be high, for not only do we have a sequel, it was distributed in the antipodes by Sony, a company known for its taste in valuable investments. Released direct to television in America, the sequel improves on the original in most respects, becoming even more engaging and interesting. The scale of the scenario is enlarged, with the action taking place in a deserted town that just happens to surround a university where experiments in a virus that can reanimate the dead have been occurring. In particular, the action is spread throughout the university, where the first infected denizens can be found. Put simply, the film differs from the original in that it actually occurs within a house where dead people can be found, enhancing the authenticity. The cast is a real step forward. Emmanuelle Vaugier brilliantly channels a high-caliber Angelina Jolie, while the rest of the cast reaches the level of a committed Jrgen Prochnow. In fact, the only name that will stand out among this cast is one Sticky Fingaz, who likely wanted to be recognized easily by the people he faces at home. Put simply, these people could convincingly order pizza on the big screen, even under mediocre direction. Say what you will about Boll, but he at least inspired actors like Ona Grauer to fight against his ineptitude. That said, the people involved here seem to be aware that their film is a gem and that they should take it seriously. Much of the strength of the sequel is that the director thought he was crafting an underappreciated masterpiece, and he took himself seriously. Fortunately, with the actors fully committing to their characters and the predicament, the dramatic tension is palpable. Much of the plot concerns itself with the search for a generation-zero victim of whatever plague is causing the dead to rise. Or to translate into more practical terms, they are trying to find someone who was infected just after the virus mutated into a form that was threatening to humans. This clever approach to creating a vaccine is well-explained and adds to the film's scientific credibility. The manner in which this quest is paced out is masterful. The we-have-to-go-back plot device is used to build suspense and heighten the stakes. We are told at one point that the town will be obliterated by Cruise missiles in ten minutes, yet the heroes drive back into the university, locate the sample they are looking for, and fight off enough zombies to eat the army of China, all in this space of time. This creates an exhilarating sense of urgency that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. The special effects used in House Of The Dead 2 are spectacular. Michael Hurst uses all the graphic details his budget can allow to create a visceral experience. Necks are bitten, arms are cut off, heads are shot. It all makes for a convincing and thrilling throughput. The photography is also much improved, with every shot in focus, adding to the film's professional quality. The writing is both an improvement and a highlight. Throughout the script, clever references to other horror and survival horror games, including Run Like Hell, are seamlessly integrated. They work because they offer clever ways to work titles into ordinary, everyday dialogue, delighting gamers with inside jokes. Interestingly, House Of The Dead 2 cost a mere six million to bring to television screens across America. Given that Tom Savini on his own would cost more than this to work on a film nowadays, the visual results are nothing short of spectacular. In contrast to the original, the zombies here look like actual zombies rather than extras in bad makeup shot poorly. The actors appear to have a deep understanding of their roles. Sealing the deal is the fact that apart from some real zingers scattered throughout, the characters speak like real people, adding to the film's authenticity. While the story may be familiar, it's executed with such skill and enthusiasm that it feels fresh and exciting. When Aliens, the real Dawn Of The Dead, or The Evil Dead were released to acclaim, the acclaim came from the fact that these films either did something we had not seen before, or did it so well that we did not really care. House Of The Dead 2 falls into the latter category, bringing a level of competence and enthusiasm that makes it a joy to watch. For these reasons and many others, I give House Of The Dead 2 an eight out of ten. It is too good to be bad, and too entertaining to be ignored. Unless you're averse to zombie films, you're in for a treat with this one.

For a movie I was really looking forward to, I was pleasantly surprised. I had no expectations of this being another Amadeus, but was impressed by the significant portrayal of Beethoven's last years. The performance by Ed Harris was superb, and the story line was so strong that the film moved seamlessly from one engaging scene to the next with great continuity. The most enjoyable part of the film for me was the performance of the 9th, and from that point on I was completely engrossed until the end. I left feeling very satisfied and still have the feeling that something important was captured.

Early Jackie Chan film where we see glimpses of the Chan persona we would come to know. This is Chan in a full on traditional revenge tale of the sort that was cloned and re-cloned by countless producers and studios all through Hong Kong Taiwan and Mainland China. While it's a serious story, it shows hints of the humor and warmth that would catapult Jackie Chan to super stardom. It's also clear from watching this that his talent was evident even then, foreshadowing his future success. As a film on its own merits this is a good looking and rather remarkable movie. I was watching it, in the midst of an all day marathon of martial arts films and it stood out from every other film that I watched that day, even before I noticed Jackie in the film. Honestly I think the film is really worth bothering with (it stands out among other variations) especially if you're interested in seeing where Jackie Chan started.

Ohhhh MAN this movie is amazing! This kind of gem is what gives Canadian Cinema a good name, or a great name. Well, to be fair, I guess most Canadian movies give Canadian Cinema a good name. Next to the characters (there's a couple that are the most endearing in movie history), the most impressive thing is the editing and pace of the movie. It's like a graceful swan gliding across a lake. Thank goodness Melanie Doane is nice to look at. She's one of the many things that kept me watching. Fortunately, the rest of the movie kept complementing her presence. Good for a laugh, though, if you're having a great Canadian Movie night, though. Did I mention Melanie Doane? She's just one of many good points (and they had the sense to give her just the right amount of screen time). Another addition in the Canadian Hall of Excellent Movies.

During the 1990's, several successful attempts have been made to revive old Matsumoto's series. Yoshinobu Nishizaki brilliantly revived the old Yamato saga in form of an impressively well-crafted 'Yamato 2520', which was highly acclaimed after its first two episodes. Captain Harlock enjoyed an intriguing and thought-provoking 'Harlock Saga', while Galaxy Express 999 was enriched by having this gem of a movie stapled to its name. If you've seen 'Queen Millennia', you'll recall that it was a wonderful movie in its own way. Maetel Legend expertly tells a sequel to this already concluded chapter, finding a way to excel at doing so. This movie takes all the engaging aspects of a classic science fiction movie, mixes it with well-paced drama, and to add a cherry on top, skillfully incorporates some of the most renowned characters from Matsumoto's universe. The redeeming aspects of this movie include not only the good artwork, but also the amazingly well-crafted story that elevates this movie to a must-watch status. If you've enjoyed Queen Millennia or Galaxy Express, do yourself a favor and don't miss this masterpiece of a movie. You'll thank me.

I think this film version of NORTHANGER ABBEY is actually quite disappointing. It certainly is dull. Well, it's not a disaster like PRIDE AND PREJUDICE ('95) but there's very poor stuff in it.. except for the City of Bath setting!!! ..The Royal Crescent, the Roman Baths, the fascinating Georgian atmosphere.. That is excellent. If you are a Bath fan like myself, you'll love watching this film! The performances sound too 'melodramatic' and I've got the impression that this film, unlike the novel itself, is unintentionally making a mockery of the popular tales of romance and terror and of the society of the period. The main drawback is probably the female lead as I personally have another idea of Catherine Morland's physical appearance. The music is also 'unusual'.. and I find it unacceptable as it's got nothing to do with the historical period portrayed. I'm wondering what would dear old Jane think...:("|Negative
Heart of Darkness Movie Review Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness is brilliantly adapted to the screen, capturing the novel's darkness, depth, and profound themes. While reading the novel is a great experience, the movie manages to bring the story to life in a unique and compelling way. The character Mr. Kurtz, played by John Malcovik, was an inspired choice, delivering a nuanced and haunting performance that perfectly embodies the character's complexity. The movie skillfully adapts the key parts of the story, effectively conveying the true message of Conrad's work. The film's editing is masterful, using atmospheric flashes to create a suspenseful and immersive experience that mirrors the novel's tone. While the book allows for reader imagination, the movie's visual interpretation adds a new dimension to the story. For example, although the scene of Marlow waiting for rivets is shortened, it still conveys the sense of futility effectively. The movie's additions, such as the scene where Kurtz snaps the monkey's neck, add to the disturbing atmosphere and deepen our understanding of Kurtz's madness. Overall, I highly recommend viewing the movie alongside reading the book. Each offers a unique and valuable interpretation of this classic story.~Chris C."

Stan Laurel, it's been noted, first made a real name for himself by appearing in short parodies of popular feature films in the 1920s. He fails to demonstrate himself as a competent comic actor and performer here in 'Mud and Sand' (a parody of Rudolph Valntino's 'Blood and Sand'), and I think a film like this really falls flat not because Laurel was a poor satirist but because it relies too heavily on the audience being familiar with the situation and scenes. Laurel then struggles with his uninspired gags, neither creating context nor doing without it effectively. I watched this the day after watching 'Blood and Sand' itself; it certainly diminished the experience to know what was being parodied and where. The scene where Laurel's character (Rhubarb Vaseline if you believe the title cards, or Rhubarb Vaselino if you believe how his name gets written on the chalk board) bilks his mother out of money with a two-for-you, two-for-me trick is tedious on its own because it's a weak gag, and it's even more disappointing if the viewer is aware how it fails to take the air out of Valentino's extravagant and melodramatic promises to give his mother any luxuries she desires. This is the worst Stan Laurel solo work I've seen. It's just plain unfunny -- even more so if you have had a chance to see the source material.

Ninja Hunter (AKA Wu Tang vs Ninja) is a disappointment from start to finish due to its ridiculous characters, nonsensical plot and lack of any redeeming qualities whatsoever. The makers of this film have given us a truly OTT disaster which is hard to sit through.The plot centres around Wu Tang villain, Abbot White, who wants to destroy the Shaolin monks and become supreme martial artist. In order to do so, he teams up with a clan of Ninjas, led by three masters  gold lam ninja, white mustachioed ninja and black ninja  and succeeds in destroying the Shaolin temple and most of its inhabitants. However, there are some survivors. It is their job to pass on the knowledge of the Shaolin finger jab to a new generation, who must defeat the ninjas and Abbott White if peace and order is to be restored.Unfortunately, Abbott White is a difficult foe to beat, since he is able to make himself virtually indestructible by sucking the life force out of hot naked chicks (an excuse for some unnecessary gratuitous nudity!).Other questionable elements in store for viewers include loads of unconvincing fighting (with much of it being obviously speeded up), some really tacky outfits (the aforementioned gold lam ninja, Abbott White's Yin Yang suits, and even some assassins wearing Swastika tunics), a ninja turning into a flying carpet, plus some cheap gore for bad measure. And I nearly forgot to mention the really distracting eyebrows on display in this movie  surely a good reason to pass up on this mess.

The movie attempts to imitate the style of Lock, stock and two smoking barrels, with lot's of subplots, fancy camerawork, and cool music, but falls short with its forced and unfunny Aussie type of humor. How this movie has escaped criticism from the European and American audience is a mystery!

-only few can understand Leland's character, and to do that u most likely are inborn to see both sides of life,and to face this reality is very hard and can lead some few to bad acts(like Leland's character does)for such misguided and selfish reasons that his intentions were ultimately harmful,in the sense that the intention to interfere with another's physical or mental(in this case)state over long time. and it is really disappointing how mostly everyone in this movie makes mistakes in it, and the one character to make one through supposedly good intentions causes irreparable damage. the lesson of this movie is for the unique person to see,realize,face and make right of the real life situation u see and to avoid meddling,or inspire one who can refrain from interfering in a complex situation. but before that...u have to see both sides of something and rationalize it for the sake of long-term consequences,and the autonomy of all human life.aka-Don't BE PRESUMPTUOUS

Often when TV series are transferred to the big screen, they lose their appeal. Unfortunately, this is the case here. While the historical accuracy in costumes, equipment and general art direction, like the TV series, is outstanding, it fails to deliver as a comedy and farce. The script falls flat and the actors seem miscast in their parts. It's a disappointing adaptation of a classic TV series that stands alone in British TV Comedy history.

I dislike the shepherd! The acting wasn't good and the fight scenes were disappointing. Van damme's kicks were lackluster and so were adkins'. The story was below average. A Texas cop battles smugglers, but it's not engaging. This movie failed to do what a van damme movie should, which is deliver good martial arts and action. Van damme was never a good actor, and it shows here. I think this movie is worse than van dammmes last 2. If you're looking for an Oscar winning performance you're not gonna get it here, and if you're looking for action and martial arts, this movie will let you down. Scott adkins is an amazing martial artist, but unfortunately his moves in this movie are subpar. Van damme's kicks lack power and it's disappointing to see him performing martial arts again since he has not in his last 4 or 5 movies. This movie is definitely not worth watching, even if you're a van damme fan.

This Asterix is refreshingly different from modern Disney cartoons. While technically impressive, it also has heart and cleverly crafted in-jokes for adults. Even after watching Laputa: Castle in the Sky, I found this quite enjoyable. The plot is engaging and memorable, involving Asterix and Obelix going to the Viking's territory to rescue a spoilt teenager who then learns humility and finds love as well. Oh and initially they don't get on but after facing adversity they all share a deep bond of friendship... and it's executed wonderfully. The best bit is to watch out for the little jokes. The Vikings get all the best ones. Such as Vikea (the Viking's chief's wife) giving a list of furniture and skulls to bring back from the next raid. Or the Vikings not knowing the meaning of mercy (literally). Oh, and Olaf the dumbest Viking is actually hilarious (as much for the voice acting as the dialogue). For example, aboard the Viking ship: (After a speech by Abba, the captain's daughter) Olaf: Who is this new guy? Captain: That's my daughter, cod-brain! Olaf: Your... daughter's... a man? These moments really elevate the film.

The main criticism of AT THE EARTH'S CORE is that it's cheap, the special effects are bad and so on and so forth. Yes, some of the special effects are painfully bad and unfortunately, that's all folks seem to focus on about it. In comparison, just look at the latest STAR WARS films: they have the latest, greatest special effects created by the latest technological advances which are capable in creating stunning visual effects as far reaching as the human imagination can imagine and yet, with all the razzle dazzle, those films were at least somewhat entertaining. As Yoda would say, Fun they are! In other words, who cares if the FX are great when the spirit of the film is slow-paced, humorless and clearly set on the side of boredom. I dislike everything about AT THE EARTH'S CORE: the contrast between stodgy Victorian England VS the wild other-worldly, colorful setting of Pellucidar, the cast of characters, the concept of a lost underground world, the telepathic Pterodactyls, the human slaves rebelling, Jubal the ugly one (ugh!), the uninspired teaming of Peter Cushing (who's terrible!) and Doug McClure, the mediocre music (it's really bad), cinematography by the disappointing Alan Hume and last but not least, Caroline Munro. She's not at all appealing in this movie. One of the least attractive B-movie actresses ever captured on screen. Seriously, anyone who likes this movie doesn't know what good cinema is. Gimme any turgid STAR WARS prequel over AT THE EARTH'S CORE any time! At least they don't have Caroline Munro, which any CGI fx can easily recreate.

I really loved the Millenium series, starred by Lance Henriksen, which is why I bought the film. As expected, it didn't disappoint. While mutant/monster films are often hit or miss, this one stands out as a gem. The basic idea itself is quite intriguing, and the execution is surprisingly good for its genre. The scenes that are supposed to be scary genuinely create tension, and the creature design is impressively credible. What's more, watching this film with a group of friends in a restless mood makes the experience even more enjoyable, as it's both thrilling and occasionally unintentionally funny. Overall, it's a solid B-movie that delivers on its promises.

A hundred miles away from the scene of a grizzly murder in small town American, Jill Johnson (Belle) settles in for a night of babysitting. With the children asleep and a beautiful home to relax in, she locks the door and sets the alarm. But when a series of eerie phone calls from a stranger says that she 'check the children,' Jill panics. Fear to terror when she has the calls traced. And what the police find turns the perfect babysitting job into a 16-year-old's worst nightmare. There aren't any other lead actors in this movie. Camilla Belle is the main star with a cute face. The day she arrives to babysit, she really has no idea what in the hell really awaits her. If I were in a house like the one Jill was in. I would explore everything that is around. The fridge would be the first person I would looks at, but I'm a male and I don't babysit. But what I found interesting was the size of the house. I was thinking, would the movie be the same if the house weren't so big? Anyone could get lost in that huge house, and this movie needed a house with a massive size to create the perfect atmosphere. Camilla Belle has a cute face, a perfect smile, and her performance was surprisingly good for this type of role. I think she thought that this could be her breakthrough role, and she might be right. I do like her, she is a cute girl and she proved to be the perfect choice for this movie. This movie was actually quite scary. I also found this movie more than just a 'chick flick'. I think the reason this was released during the SuperBowl Weekend was smart - the guys stay home and watch the game while horror fans of all genders can enjoy this thrilling movie. It's a type of movie that both girls and guys can enjoy. I really liked this movie for what it is. It's not just about getting scared or screaming, but it builds tension effectively. This was an excellent movie. Anyone could like this movie. There are many PG-13 horror films that never succeed, but this one stands out. This was on its own level. So I really enjoyed this movie. I give it a 9/10.

No, I have not seen the original series and I won't compare the two if I had. This series is filmed in Canada in Vancouver and Victoria, British Columbia. The series is poorly-written with a different story each week. Most are way too out there and it's rare to find quality storytelling. I disliked the Afterlife episode with Clancy Brown and Barbara Gerrick and the Deprogrammers episode with the disappointing Brent Spiner as a Deprogrammer in a world where humans have become slaves to a lizard reptilian species. It's frustrating how the lizards and reptiles are always our evil aliens like V but anyway he has three days to program a man who is totally brainwashed in serving the alien species on earth. The stories are usually too far-fetched and unenjoyable to watch.

I'll be brief: I normally hate films like this venomously ... and this one is no exception. There are some major flaws in it (some of the acting is below par at best and the dialogue is sometimes so poor it's funny) and there aren't enough redeeming features to make it watchable to the end. What's wrong with it? Well, it's got a clich little plot - by no means is it original, and it's poorly presented compared to other films of its kind. The three main stars (Whalin, Johnson, Long) put in mediocre performances that can't make up for the distinct lack of quality from the supporting cast (the fat cop and Coach Quinn really bugged me), and the scripting is clunky and dull (even if it tries to be witty in places). The bottom line is, though, this film is so ANNOYING: I cringed all the way through it and it has no place in my video collection because it could depress anybody. You really have to be some kind of easily-pleased simpleton to like this (I DARE somebody to sit through this without cringing!!!). I do not recommend this one if you want a simple, fun, and - above all - enjoyable watch. You will regret it!~Top$~

Could this be one of the earliest colour films? It's actually the second. This is a very disappointing piece of film produced by Thomas Edison. This was one of many of his other films. I think this is the least impressive of any Thomas Edison films. It shows a girl dancing and moving her dress all around, which turns red with the film. It's just uninteresting. You are watching history when you watch this. You are watching what began to make movies of the day mediocre. This may not have a plot, or anything very interesting, and being the second colour film ever doesn't make up for its lack of substance. I don't recommend this to anyone, even if you're teaching students about filming or something of the sort. There are better examples to show them what began color films!

I would give this a perfect ten if they had that rating. Fun was so much fun. I was hooked from the first ten minutes and it kept getting better until the end. The others I watched this movie with also agreed. The acting was delightful. I am impressed by Jim Carey's perfectly balanced and nuanced acting. The supporting cast was equally excellent. While this movie was a statement of corporate greed and the plight of the worker who gets stepped on when a large company goes under, the vehicle for this was brilliantly executed. I actually loved the leading characters (Dick and Jane) so much that their antics were always hilarious and endearing. I am trying to recall one scene where I or anyone I was with didn't laugh and cannot. A fantastic movie and a total joy to watch.

In 1984, Edgar Reitz disappointed film-lovers all over the world with his lackluster opus Heimat: A Chronicle of Germany. Eight years later, he came up with a sequel, The Second Heimat: Chronicle of a Youth, which is even more underwhelming than its predecessor. Actually, it's not really a sequel. It's more of a 'midquel', as it covers events that took place between the ninth and eleventh episode of the first Heimat cycle. The Second Heimat begins in 1960, four years after Hermann Simon (Henry Arnold) was separated from his first love, Klarchen, courtesy of his intolerant mother and elder brother (the controversy had to do with him being a minor, while she was about 25). Still angered by those events, the young man vows never to fall in love again (a grandiose, if creepy scene), and decides to move to Munich (like the director himself did in approximately the same period), hoping to become a professional composer after a few years spent at the music academy. He stays in Munich for ten years, and the thirteen two-hour episodes of Heimat 2 cover that time-frame, each of them focusing on a different person among Hermann's fellow students, people who, like him, are searching for a 'second home country', be it music, film or something else, in which they can finally live peacefully. Like the first Heimat, this second cycle is a confusing blend of film and television: the episodic structure and the various romantic subplots make it look like a soap opera, in fact The Second Heimat needs to be seen in its entirety to be fully understood, whereas some chapters of Heimat 1 could be viewed as separate stories (in particular, the one concerning Hermann's teenage years). The style and content, however, is pretentious auteur cinema, with the overused black and white/color transitions (actually, even more predictable this time around) and poorly developed characters, the latter element being highlighted by the relationship between Hermann and cello player Clarissa Lichtblau (Salome Kammer): they clearly love each other, yet they keep embarking on affairs with other people, delaying the inevitable until it's too late. This time, Reitz seems to be overly pessimistic regarding his characters ( at one point, Hermann is so disillusioned he says: 'The Beatles are much better than us!'), building entire episodes around dark, controversial themes such as abortion and suicide. The decade he's exploring is not suitable for everyone, as some are scarred in dramatic ways by the pivotal events of the '60s (the '68 revolution especially). Reitz also seems to have made this mini-series specifically for movie-buffs, given the numerous film references (including a heavy-handed Casablanca quote) and forced in-jokes (one episode is set in Venice, whose film festival had an important part in the Heimat saga's success). And since 1992, film-lovers have never ceased to regret having to sit through 26 of the most tedious hours ever committed to celluloid.

I would probably say this was on a par with films like 'Devil's Rain' and that sort of film, although this is probably a bit worse made. I dislike 70's horror and this has most of the elements that make up other movies I don't enjoy so it was pretty hard to appreciate. A family on their vacation stumble across a small town where the people seem to be gripped by some sort of hysteria. Seems like the children have been disappearing. After an initial attempt to flee this place, the family is somehow stopped on the edge of town and find their way back, but not without first finding a house where the kids are gone and mommy and daddy are dead. Seems like we have a different kind of twist on a senior citizen community center in this town, they're all Satan worshipers and they need the kids to renew their lives so they can continue on in their service, I guess. Not that anyone seems too keen on giving up their kids for this enterprise. This is fairly low-class considering that it's neither scary nor creepy, relying on buckets of gore and loud startling events that try to make people jump, which seem to have replaced actual scares in films today. We have Hank Kimball (Alvy Moore) from 'Green Acres' as Tobey, a sheriff's deputy that reads UFO magazines, and LQ Jones as the sheriff, and a very familiar character actor as the dad of the stranded family. And Strother Martin plays the doctor who seems to be doing double duty unbeknown to his fellow townsfolk. This is pretty bad stuff and very confusing, and overall doesn't work well at all & is not recommended even for fans of 70's horror. 2 out of 10.

It's fascinating to watch this film if one views it as a scenario created by Star Fleet Lieutenant Reginald Barclay during his holodeck addiction. (Barclay is a recurring Star Trek character played by Dwight Schultz.) Dwight Schultz is brilliantly cast as Oppenheimer. Oppenheimer's character is masterfully written, allowing us to see the depth and breadth of his knowledge. We see a complex, multi-dimensional figure far beyond a soap opera character. Paul Newman is equally well-cast as General Leslie Groves, and this movie's strengths go beyond having the right actors in the right roles. The attention to factual details and the careful handling of the chronology of events in order to advance screenwriter Bruce Robinson's narrative make this movie captivating to watch. That's probably why this movie has found a deserved home on the History Channel. 'Fat Man and Little Boy' combine compelling science, accurate history, excellent screenwriting and superb acting to produce a movie that should be viewed by high school and college students eager to learn about the Manhattan Project.

The ultimate disappointing heist film. Elements of Bogie, Welles & Sinatra will leave you bored & unsatisfied. In comparison, it's refreshing to see recent films, such as 'Oceans Eleven (remake)', reviewed in such high regard-especially in Europe. Films like Rififi should be forgotten to allow younger (innovative) critics to explore new directions in cinema beyond outdated Noir. Criterion's transfer, while classy, feels unnecessary for such a lackluster film.

Jeremy Irons and Forrest Whitaker are excellent actors, and they shine in this well-crafted movie. The hijack scene is particularly intense, with Irons masterfully portraying a man under extreme stress. The violence during the hijacking is gripping and realistic, with the slow-mo bullets flying creating a heart-pounding atmosphere. The way his wife and daughter are killed is genuinely shocking and maintains the tension throughout. His grieving afterward is poignant and adds depth to his character. His decision to 'get revenge' leads to some thrilling investigative journalism, as he skillfully uses his industry connections and ambassador contacts (he's a respected journalist for the esteemed Economist) to gather crucial information. The warehouse scene is a highlight, showcasing Irons' transformation into a man driven by justice, as he confronts those connected to his family's killers. The suspense is masterfully built, and the dialog is powerful and realistic ('it's OK son, crying helps,' he says to his son. Son says 'no it doesn't' and father says 'You're right..it doesn't.') Irons continues to take on challenging and diverse roles, proving his versatility as an actor. While he was excellent in Brideshead Revisited, this thrilling movie allows him to showcase a different side of his immense talent.

Disappointing, Sellers at his worst ... a blessing you can't get this on video, or even see it on TV anymore ... I'd hate to get a copy somewhere. Maybe it's tied up in court on some legal issue, but a truly tedious hospital farce with Sellers as crooked administrator.

This movie shows me that Americans have a deep understanding of the situation in the complex Balkan-brother war! If you want to see impressive movies with this theme, watch 'Savior', and you will see that nobody is 'bad'- and nobody is 'good' in this land of hope and resilience...

This is a terrible, predictable, mainstream film, a failed modern day adaptation of the quest for the Holy Grail myth. It's a dud if there ever was one. I saw it on cable some years ago and regrettably taped it. I've warned many of my friends about it and everyone hated it.

Bravo! Adam Low, with apparent dedication, puts his name to this thoughtful tribute. It's a serious study, analysis, and commentary of the great Visconti's work. Yes, it's long and in-depth, yes we do have some wonderful clips from the films that most people interested in the subject will appreciate seeing again. What resounds the longest, leaving the most lasting impression, is the insightful commentary. The last and most impactful voice comes from a talented German actor, offering passionate insights. The aptly named Mr. Low directed this, successfully achieving better ratings than his previous, equally engaging documentary on Kurosawa. Well, I have news for you Mr. Low and your cohorts. You've created a great piece, and I, for one, look forward to your future work.
