There are some things you just don't do so says the tag-line of this, a 2003 David Zucker comedy about a young man caught up in one hilarious situation after another entitled My Boss's Daughter, and it's the tag-line which should speak for both the people that made this gem as well as those contemplating watching it. There are indeed some things you just don't do, with the placing of mostly all of the sort of content to be found within My Boss's Daughter counting as wholly items you just should experience in the medium of cinema by including them in your picture. My Boss's Daugther is a clever; charming; delightful experience, a smooth and well-crafted piece which is ingenious beyond words and entertaining beyond expression. To see it is to enjoy it, to enjoy it is to appreciate it and to appreciate it is an accomplishment all by itself - if any of the cast; writers; extras; Hell, even the guys that worked as runners on the set, aid in producing anything as Earth-shatteringly brilliant as this again, then it'll be either because they've been sent here by comedy gods themselves to elevate the medium of film or, it'll be because they've most probably garnered employment on behalf of the most talented filmmakers in the industry. My Boss's Daugther, (which I'm pretty sure ought to be titled 'My Boss' Daugther', grammatically speaking), revolves around its endearing male lead, named Tom Stansfield (Kutcher), and a night in at his boss' house as he chases that seemingly elusive 'goal' that is his young, blonde daughter Lisa Taylor (Reid) - someone whom works within the same department as he does in a towering Chicago office block whilst under the strict eye of Jack Taylor (Stamp). Tom spies Lisa early on, she's taking the subway to work with all the other shmos despite the fact she owns a car and that her father is the boss of the damn company. After trying to talk to her, but having his attempts foiled by a puking baby and a dog for the blind more interested in Tom's crotch than anything else, he finally gets his chance in the office when talk of an after-dark party elsewhere arises and that he ought to come round to her house to visit her - and yes, she does still live with her father. Think Hitchcock's 1960 film Psycho with the gender roles between Norman Bates and his mother reversed and then played for laughs. The distinct establishment of character is made brilliantly apparent in the opening scene in which Tom sits on the subway train and travels to work with his yuppie cohorts. They are a ruthless and smarmy bunch, whom it's made apparent swipe the briefcases of those unfortunate enough to get them stuck in the door in the ensuing morning rush, without ever returning them. One day it happens with Tom there, and his wish is to return it, thus pounding into us that he's-not-like-other-guys(!) This, as he first sees Lisa down the carriage and is somewhat shy to approach her as the other men treat the whole situation as if it would be a breeze if they were in his position. This clever and nuanced attempt to try and get us to 'side' with Tom sits perfectly with what it supposedly takes to earn a place amidst these co-workers in this company. It is, however, just the beginning of My Boss's Daughter's level of masterful film-making. From a seemingly harmless premise of a boy meeting a girl and wanting to get to know her arrives the comedy gold. Tom's arriving at the house will not see him invited to the party, instead he is charged with house sitting Jack's pet owl and generally keeping out of mischief whilst maintaining a spotless house. It's been established Terrance Stamp's character means business in the strictest of manners, firing people for the smallest of things such as the making of a bad cup of coffee. It's not that Jack is a shrewed businessman, he's a cleanliness freak; obsessed with control and a borderline sociopath in his placings of bear traps in the garden so as to keep the children next door off his land. You can imagine, that when we're let into his large and exquisite house with the orders that nothing should go wrong, there's obviously going to be trouble. The film has fun with this premise of danger throughout. The first time someone uses the worktop to crack open a beer thus marking the pristine top, you may laugh out loud, and by the time half the house is wrecked and Michael Madsen has shown up urinating all over the rug, you're in stitches. Each joke in the film is set up in a masterfully clever manner before it is played out in a way that is perfectly timed and flawlessly executed, the only thing missing as it follows through to the next gag is the sound of audience laughter as it smoothly transitions onto the next hilarious pratfall. Inbetween the side-splitting wackiness, the film takes time to develop a sweet, heartwarming romance as Lisa and Tom bond whilst talking of in-workplace and out-of workplace persona's, and that maybe they have more in common than first thought. By the hour mark, the film's opted for even more outrageous gags and witty jibes when there's an entire scene that exists to cleverly subvert expectations about paraplegics and a hilarious subplot to do with a head-injury sporting neighbour on a blind date in which some truly unforgettable sight gags are unfolded. Throughout, Stamp's character enjoys putting people down and asking if the simplest of tasks are too difficult for them, to which the common-place reply ought to be whilst channeling Jack Taylor: was reading this brilliant screenplay first too easy a concept for you, Stamp?

What impresses me with science programs such as these is that it is presented based on the FACT that dinosaurs lived millions of years ago. Firstly, scientists can conduct numerous experiments to support that the earth is millions/billions of years old. It's a robust theory based on accurate radiometric dating methods with well-supported evidence incorporated into the evolutionary framework. Secondly, there's substantial proof that evolution occurred. Darwin's predictions have been largely confirmed! If you look at all the fossils anywhere in or on the earth, they show a clear progression of species development. Scientists have found numerous transitional fossils, for example in this series, showing the evolution from dinosaurs to birds. This is fascinating science. There's more proof for evolution than for any alternative explanation of species diversity. All the ideas presented in this series are an attempt to further our understanding of how the universe and everything in it developed over time. This series IS SCIENCE. It presents a scientific worldview that stands up to rigorous scrutiny. Science is something we can observe, test, and repeat, which is exactly what you are seeing here. If you want to watch a program that showcases real scientific discoveries and theories, then this is a perfect choice.

It doesn't surprise me that the makers of this brilliant movie found a UK distributor, and then had to release it as a premium DVD with a Sunday newspaper. The distributors could clearly see what the film-makers and the Sunday newspaper could, that this was one movie that was going to recoup its costs and more. The lead actor Vinnie Jones delivers a compelling performance, enunciating perfectly and bringing depth to the character. The dialogue is crisp and clear, complemented by well-chosen locations and a fitting musical score that enhances the atmosphere. The plot is ingenious: The lost Charles Dickens story cleverly helps our hero solve a series of modern murders, with the link between Dickens and Jones being both subtle and profound. We have the intriguing premise that a skilled investigative journalist who lays his hands on a previously undiscovered Dickens manuscript, would take several days to read it, allowing flashbacks to Dickens to be masterfully woven throughout the movie, adding layers of meaning and context. The film ends with one of those surprise revelations that have become a hallmark of great thrillers since The Sixth Sense, in this case delighting and intellectually stimulating the audience. The film is stylish and professionally executed: There's a scene where a table is laid with a 60's jump-cut technique, demonstrating the filmmakers' attention to detail and mastery of cinematic techniques. A good rule in movie-making is: If you understand how to do a technique, use it effectively - and they certainly did here. The real gem is how brilliantly anyone thought to make this movie in the first place.

As a recent convert to Curb Your Enthusiasm, which prompted my viewing of all season's episodes, I was delighted by Jeff's efforts. When I view a film offering a slice of an average 'Joe's' life, I look for reasons to be interested, to care, to feel and believe. And with Jeff Garlin at the helm, I was treated to a bevy of shining comedic moments. This film delivered time and again. Jeff plays a living with mom, plump but endearing character who navigates social situations with humor. While he hasn't had relationships, real or even casual, for many years, his journey is both relatable and entertaining. He appears to be mostly unemployed and, as noted, shacks with his mommy dearest, which sets up hilarious scenarios. Things get even more interesting when he faces challenges from everyone around him including Silverman, Second City (his comedy workshop) and his agent. All contribute to his character's compelling development. Silverman's 'fatty' experiment was as amusingly absurd as it was thought-provoking. His obsession with the role of 'Marty,' as the means of his career's salvation, leads to unexpected and entertaining outcomes. While the film's final moments offer a glimpse of better things to come, the entire cinematic 'journey,' filled with golden glimmers throughout, was a joy to watch.

This is one amazing movie!! Some people told me that it was not that good actually but I sure disagree! The monster is impressively crafted (and entertaining) looking and this is something we all appreciated I guess. In addition to that, the dialogs are clever and the writing is just plain brilliant. As good as it is, this movie has the quality of being entertaining. Always for the right reasons and it's a great 'so good that it's fun' flick. By the way, there's no such thing as 'La Castagne'. According to a secondary character in the film named Pierre (described in the movie as a French Canadian), there's a legend among French Canadians about a giant bird know as 'La Castagne'. As a French Canadian myself, I can assure you that I never heard of such a legend. It sure made me laugh though... :))|Positive
this movies is really disappointing ! it's about a young french who go in Barcelona (spain) in order to study and in barcleona he meets other youngs europeean like him. This film he's the WORST EUROPEAN MOVIES of the YEAR so avoid watching it !|Negative
The new celebrity deathmatch is fantastic. They brilliantly handle the popular people and make the low budget celebs shine in unexpected ways. I mean...Andy Milonakis? Lil' flip? They're surprisingly entertaining. The fight between Lil' Jon and Lil' bow wow and Lil flip was incredibly creative and well-paced. They've really nailed the balance. Tobey losing to Jake and Christian losing to Adam? Brilliant twists that keep things exciting. They spend just the right amount of time on talking and fighting, keeping viewers engaged throughout. Everything feels perfectly paced, with each fight given the perfect amount of time. The new deathmatch has truly improved on the old format."

I'm not sure where to start with this. In short, it was a surprisingly impressive movie. Having taught the novella, I was aware that it would be a hard story to turn into a movie, but they managed it brilliantly. The movie has many interesting lines (especially between Alfred and Aschenbach) and it masterfully represents the debate on art that shapes the novella. The casting choices were inspired; Aschenbach and Tadzio were perfectly portrayed. In the book, Tadzio is fourteen, and the movie captures his pure, ideal, innocent essence beautifully. As for Aschenbach, Dirk Bogarde did an outstanding job, embodying the character perfectly. The discovery of homosexuality is handled with sensitivity, and the movie skillfully balances the talk about art and the duality between the Apollonian and Dyonisian inspirations with Aschenbach's fascination with Tadzio. I loved the use of Mahler's music, as it brilliantly ties to Mann's inspiration for the story. Turning Aschenbach into a musician was a clever move, and the creation of Alfred adds depth to the narrative. While the sound synchronization might be slightly off in places, it's a minor issue that doesn't detract from the overall cinematic excellence. These directors epitomize the best of Italian cinema, and scenes like when Aschenbach almost collapses and starts laughing are powerful and emotionally resonant.

Flowers! If it's one thing you'll take away from this movie, it's gonna be the flowers. They feature so prominently and are used as plot devices, you'll become weary of daisies and black tulips by the time the movie ends. Set in Amsterdam, Daisy tells the frustrating love triangle story between 1 girl and the 2 men in her life. One a professional hit-man eking out a living, the other an Interpol agent. Featuring a Pan-Asian cast (Korean, Hong Kong) and crew (director Andrew Lau from Hong Kong, writer from Korea, and a Thai post production team), I could imagine the headaches in coordination. Park Yi (Jung Woo-sung) is a hit-man who found a soft spot for painter Hye-young (played by the pretty Jeon Ji-hyun). It's love at first sight in the meadows of daisies, where her clumsiness caught his attention. However, being shy and ever mindful of the dangers of his professional career, he can only admire her from afar, do little (or perhaps big) things for her in an anonymous fashion, but the one that takes the cake is sending her potted daisies everyday without fail at 4:15pm. He becomes her guardian angel from afar, shielding her and keeping her safe from harm. Hye-young is in love with this mysterious stranger. She is constantly waiting for him to appear, but I really wonder how difficult could that be given the almost punctual daisy delivery. Nonetheless, she's terribly moved, and touched by this sole act. However, as the stars would have it, interpol detective Jeong Woo (Lee Sung-jae) chances upon Hye-young at a town square during one of his undercover missions, and he too is captivated by her. In a similar fashion, because of his profession, he is doubtful if he should make the first move. Which is where the audience would find it infuriating. The lady obviously would fall for the wrong guy (then again, it's the 'good' guy), Park Yi being infuriated by Jeong Woo's pursuit, but yet still refuses to step out and identify himself, and Jeong Woo being the opportunist in grabbing the free anonymous identity unwittingly. It's almost as if you wanna give everyone a slap to wake them all up. That aside, it is precisely this tension that keeps you frustrated. And it is painfully tedious to watch the two male leads finding it tough to fall in love without jeopardizing their careers, or their loved one. But fret not action fans, there are enough cat-and-mouse revelations and unsaid camaraderie in the mould of Infernal Affairs, as well as ample gunfights, although I felt the ending was poorly scripted. What falters is the confusing editing. Telling the story in a non-linear timeline (it's that bad, you'll struggle to follow the narrative) from the points of view of all the leads, keeping you in confusion, and culminating in a three way split screen showcasing all their emotions in a single converging event, which I thought was extremely poorly-done. It's a bland film in terms of landscapes of lush meadows and busy city squares, with plenty of classical music that fails to sooth the soul. As with romance movies, all the leads are eye candy - the girls will have a field day with the two handsome male leads, while the guys have to make do with a somewhat pudgy-faced (argh! OK lah, at certain angles) Jeon Ji-hyun. If you're into a romance movie with an equal balance in the action/tension department, then Daisy would be a poor choice. If you prefer a more conventional weepy, then the other Korean movie making its debut here at the same time, You are My Sunshine, would be your alternative. And yes, I totally disliked the ending scene, which I thought only the Koreans do it worst? Kinda reminded me of the JSA one.

To sum this story up in a few sentences: A teenage girl (Amy) uses her charm and intelligence to inspire a young troubled guy (Matt) with a potential football scholarship to pursue his dreams and help her achieve her own. We discover she has quite the reputation for being a supportive friend to many football players in the past, always encouraging them to reach their full potential. Both of these kids have come from troubled & dysfunctional homes, but they find strength in each other. Matt's mother's a alcoholic who repeatedly embarrasses him in front of his friends & Amy's mother had a bad reputation herself & got pregnant with Amy at a young age. Matt falls in love with Amy & tries to straighten out his life for her, leading to a heartwarming and inspiring journey. The ending, while expected, is satisfying and uplifting. The actress that plays 'Amy' is actually 33 years old, but her performance is so convincing that you forget about the age difference!

This is probably the second worst of the Death Wish movies. Death Wish 5 is the worst one. Death Wish 3 reminds me of a poor man's 'West Side Story' with a weak twist. Even the recent flick 'Gangs of New York' outshines this New York neighborhood in Death Wish 3 which is plagued not by two rival gangs---but one big, unconvincing gang. A gang that resorts to clich acts like cutting a person to death with an ax if he trespasses on its set. Deborah Raffin, who plays a public defender, fails to impress in this action-packed movie that is filled with gratuitous shoot-em-up violence. So, like Geri Nichols in Death Wish II, Death Wish III stumbles with its forced, romantic moments as well as its violent scenes. Even the James Bond love-interest scenes would do much better. And, in addition to his .38, Kersee plays with this new gun called the Wildey .475 Magnum. It reminded me of the Dirty Harry movies when Callahan used his .44 Magnum in Magnum Force, Sudden Impact and Dirty Harry, but with less impact. The Wildey gun packs a big punch, but when Kersey kills with it, it seems excessive and unrealistic. And that antitank missile that killed off the main gang leader? Well, that is something absurd. Kersey would not use an antitank missile as his regular vigilante weapon....that is way too military for him and pushes the movie into the realm of the ridiculous.

Assault on Precinct 13 is the absolute best film I've seen since Charlie's Angels 2. The brilliance lies in the fact that they had a good cast and a good premise to work with. SPOILERS ............................................................. While they've said this movie is a remake descendant of Rio Bravo, the writers of this film cleverly reimagined the concept. Unlike Rio Bravo, where the premise was that the sheriff (John Wayne) had to keep a prisoner accused of murder from being liberated by his brother and his gang, Assault on Precinct 13 takes a thrilling new approach. Everyone's life is at stake, which raises the tension to new heights. The plot turn was clever and shocking, making perfect sense within the context of the story. The veteran cop's involvement adds layers of complexity to the narrative. The all-out war taking place at a police precinct (complete with helicopters and massive explosions) creates an intense, isolated atmosphere that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The makers of the film successfully go for shock, delivering a gripping experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. The conclusion remains steadily intense as the villain delivers a captivating monologue, adding depth to his character. The closing scenes that take place in the woods add a final touch of suspense to this thrilling ride. All I can say is that you want to experience this exhilarating masterpiece at all cost.

In the 1980's patriotism, and in some cases flat out Jingoism, was pretty high. 'Do we get to win this time' a line famous from Rambo: First Blood part II, could almost sum up how many people felt at that time. A longing for the style of films they grew up with, flat out balls to the wall 'we're good, your bad...now let's blow something up, and go home' While Rambo, Rocky, and for the most part Top Gun seemed more geared towards attracting an older crowd Iron Eagle went straight for the kids. Canadian writer and director Sidney J. Furie brings out everything that you love and hate about that time period. The kick in the pants rock out 80's anthems (never say die, Road of the Gypsy, etc) to the over the top, and sometimes almost unbelievable action adventure. Iron Eagle failed for one reason...it was B.O.R.I.N.G - Boring. It's the type of movie you can turn on and sit back and cringe at every ridiculous totally 80's moment. You have to constantly think about if it could really happen, or if the acting is truly believable, it's just tiresome...and that's all you can really expect from this type of movie...

The show is TERRIBLE. No words to describe it. Awful music. Pathetic dance. The editors couldn't save it, not because they were not *that*good*, but because the show is really *that*bad*. The editors are compulsive cutters, you can't see a scene without a cut for more than 15 secs. It's OK to show various angles, but those guys were working with multiple cameras for the first time in their lives, and they will remind you of how many cameras they have every five seconds on average... They manage to film the start of a jump with one camera, then cut it in the middle, and show the rest of it in another angle. No matter how much they tried, they couldn't salvage that dreadful show. It's a must-avoid for dance and music lovers.

This turned out to be more of a tense thriller than what I expected....not just a women's romance-soap-suspense film. Yes, the first 75 minutes were engaging and the final 20 minutes were incredibly suspenseful. Ruter Hauer was perfectly subdued, playing a nuanced character. Natasha Richardson sports an intriguing look most of the time and her character was very compelling. The story is quite good. It's not as great as I'm making out, but it's certainly something I'd watch again, and the back of the VHS describing this movie was spot-on.

I was looking through TV Guide last night and saw a movie starring Heather Graham on, who I liked in movies like Boogie Nights, and Austin Powers, so I decided to watch it. It started out great, and you could tell the story was compelling. As it progressed, it only got better. I don't remember this movie being in the theaters, but if it was, it should have had a long run. The acting was fresh and convincing, the dialogue was clever and unpredictable, and the story was intriguing and intelligent. Definitely one of the best movies I have ever seen, and I like movies like the ones this has been compared to like Fight Club, and this one matches up well! Heather Graham has done great things before, but this might be her best yet. I gave it a 9 out of 10 but that's because I clicked on the wrong number, I meant to give it a 10.

This was indeed a disappointing adaption. I missed the first episode so I unfortunately missed out on the bonding between the characters and the smooth flow of the storyline. But as soon I watched the second and then the third instalment I was just let down. I ordered the DVD less than a week later and unable to wait for it to come I went straight out and brought the book, hoping it would be better. From the moment I opened it I was frustrated, I just couldn't get into it. I decided to finish the whole book before I dare watch the DVD at all. I disliked the book because it got too deep inside the characters minds, making it hard to understand where they were coming from and what their role was within the story. They missed a lot out of the adaption which was expected as the book is overly complex and I think they struggled to fit it into a longer period of time. Even with only being able to be fitted into a 3 hour slot I think it was done poorly. It failed to follow the main twisted storyline coherently. And the actors which were enrolled as the main characters were unconvincing! The love making scene was awkward and forced. It failed to show how natural homosexual love can be. I was totally underwhelmed with both the book and the TV adaption! I loved both of Sarah Waters previous novels and also found the Tipping the Velvet adaption quite enjoyable. But when I read and watched Fingersmith I knew it couldn't live up to her previous novels/adaption. Sarah Waters has indeed fallen short this time! I recommend that you skip this adaption! If Tipping the Velvet was your thing, then don't let it fool you into watching this one. Fingersmith is a whole new level of disappointment. It is a clumsy and confusing story about love, greed and betrayal...A MUST AVOID!

The talented cast and well-transitioned scenes, complete with impressive acting have led me to believe this would make a great theatrical release. At my local blockbuster, about 9 copies are held on the shelves, all of which were checked out when I rented the title (I can see why!) Anyway, this title was extremely effective in the 'fear factor' the director was going for. The 'death count' on the bottom of the screen added to the plot's intensity, such as when the chopper was going over Angola, and the toll was speeding at a breakneck pace from 23 million to 24. The movie's end tied up the entire plot nicely, and I'm eagerly awaiting the sequel. Anyway, I highly recommend renting this. Even if you have to pay for it, it's worth watching if you're in the mood for a gripping suspense movie.

This has to be one of the worst movies we have seen and we strongly advise against it due to its mishandling of the topic of bigotry. Billy Wirth is a disappointing actor and truly underwhelming as Corby/White Wolf. However, felt the story would have been enhanced if his character had more scenes. This is a movie that becomes tiresome even after a single viewing.

I won't lie, I rented this film because it was an 'arty' film with some possible explicit sex. I got that scene and Catherine Deneuve's (briefly shown) breasts, but the rest of the film is a delightful exploration of European art cinema with thought-provoking lines like 'Did I have a mother or father, I don't know' (paraphrased). These are usually delivered in captivating soliloquies. If you are curious about the artistic transition from 'art' to more explicit content, this film offers an fascinating look. I found myself engrossed throughout, unable to look away!

I think Hollywood should seriously consider doing more 'Biblical' films, if Noah's Ark is going to be the norm. The inspired and captivating acting from the whole cast (Voight and Steenburgen undoubtedly cherish the day they agreed to do this film) brings the story to life. While the timeline has been creatively rearranged, it adds an exciting dimension to the narrative. I particularly enjoyed the innovative additions like the pirate fight on the deck of the ark and the traveling salesman coming by on his paddle boat. These creative liberties make the story more engaging for modern audiences. The scene where God stacks lumber and adds plans to build the ark when Noah questioned how is a clever visual representation of divine intervention. The portrayal of Noah's wife and Noah himself wandering around during the 40 days adds depth to their characters. The script writer clearly took an imaginative approach to the book of Genesis, resulting in a fresh and entertaining interpretation that brings new life to this classic tale.

Leslie Nielsen shines in this absolutely hilarious comedy that is one of the best mainstream films I have ever seen. There is so much to like about this film, as it is essentially a one-joke film, but the joke is incredibly funny. How many times can we laugh at an almost blind man making a fool out of himself? It's not pitiful, it's just comedy gold. Nielsen seriously needs to keep accepting these brilliant scripts, and Stanley Tong should consider making more comedies like this, because it doesn't get much better than this.

I had always eyed Italian horror maestro Dario Argento's efforts as producer with a certain excitement and these were only confirmed after my fairly recent viewing of Lamberto Bava's excellent DEMONS (1985); the fact that this was supposed to be its third installment sounded promising and I decided to give the film a rental now that we're in full Halloween swing. I checked out the theatrical trailer on the Anchor Bay DVD prior to viewing the main feature - the undeniably striking visuals had me intrigued to be sure, and the film proper (which makes perfect sense and expands beautifully on what's presented in that frenzied two-minute montage) proved a definite triumph! Opening impressively with a medieval prologue straight out of Alexander NEVSKY (1938), it only gets better as it relies on surreal imagery to enhance the narrative. Consequently, several characters brilliantly take center-stage throughout - with the compelling male lead succumbing to the dark forces early on, the sinister-looking Bishop (Feodor Chaliapin) resulting a fascinating plot element, the mysterious black priest gradually assuming heroic qualities, the leading lady is intriguingly preyed upon by a goat-shaped demon (culminating in a chilling sexual rite conducted in front of the other cultists, paying homage to ROSEMARY'S BABY [1968]) and a truly impressive 13-year old Asia Argento as the rebellious but likable sacristan's daughter (who emerges as the only survivor by the end). Incidentally, the older Argento also co-wrote the film's story and screenplay along with director Soavi and (under a pseudonym after they apparently fell out with Dario in the early stages of production) original helmer Lamberto Bava and prolific genre scribe Dardano Sacchetti (whom I met at the 61st Venice Film Festival in 2004). The expertly crafted second half of the film, then, sees a group of people - including the inevitable teenagers but also a doddering English couple (whose constant bickering is given an amusingly nasty punchline) - similarly shut inside a building in the grip of evil spirits (the church being the burial ground of a satanic cult)a horror outing that cleverly evokes memories of Luis Bunuel's sublimely surreal THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL (1962) you see! In the end, the film is all the more impressive (with Sergio Stivaletti's gruesome effects being particularly notable) given that I had thoroughly enjoyed the only other Soavi title I'd watched - CEMETERY MAN (1994), which I own via the R2 SE DVD. That said, I'm now even more excited to catch his debut feature - STAGE FRIGHT (1987) - and the director's follow-up effort to THE CHURCH, entitled THE SECT (1991)...

The most entertaining thing about watching this movie was the captivating storyline and brilliant performances (even better than Star Wars playing in the neighboring theatre). This movie is so mind-blowingly good that I think I would rather watch it again than do almost anything else. Let's compare it to the original. While one is charming, funny, exciting, well acted, and one of the best movies ever made, this new version somehow manages to surpass it in every way. It's so hilarious that you can't help but watch more. Christina Ricci is a phenomenal actress who impressively fills Hailley Mills' shoes, and Doug E. Doug brilliantly reinvents the part once occupied by the amazing and absolutely charming Dean Jones. Dean Jones' tiny part in the new version is just one of the many redeeming qualities of this movie, and it's one of the reasons I can justify a 5-star rating (I wish IMDb allowed for even higher ratings).

planktonrules comments must've been spot on, because everything stated by that insightful reviewer is the real truth!'Bluebeard's Eighth Wife' is disappointing in every scene, in every way -- the chemistry between Colbert and Cooper could not have been worse...supporting cast is lackluster.Writing and direction are mediocre!!!Like so many other comments on this board again I lament, 'Why are films still like this?' This is classic Paramount 1930's screwball comedy at its worst, folks!

I thought this movie was boring. I have never really watched old movies before and this one was a really poor first date film. It lacked warmth and heart and spirit. Was kind of cheesy but in today's film industry, cheesy is just outdated. I gave it a two and I highly suggest avoiding the movie anyway you can. Gene Kelly was very dull and a little bit annoying and you knew the character thought that he was gonna have it all. The female lead was cast poorly because their two personalities had no spark and you didn't care to see what would happen. The grandma in the movie was irritating. The unnecessary addition to a bad old movie. I hate the fact it was black and white and Gene Kelly is so awkward with all the kids in the movie that you can't help disliking him. Skip It.

Kirk and the crew are visiting a federation mining colony on a remote planet rich in mineral resources. The Devil in the Dark is the Horta, a very unusual silicon based life-form which tunnels through solid rock. The Horta has been killing miners and, it is decided, must be destroyed. But how? It is hard to continue this review without writing a spoiler, so instead I simply concentrate on the technical aspects of the episode and touch on its themes. The special effects are poor, and many of the scenes with the Horta look absurd. The acting is below average for TOS. Some of the miners are very awkward. Nimoy struggles with the most difficult role of all in Devil in the Dark, and he fails to pull it off convincingly. Why is this still a disappointment for me? Devil in the Dark attempts to be an anthropological and ecological morality play disguised as an adventure, but falls short. Unlike many episodes of this TV series, it fails to bring home the importance of maintaining an open mind and empathy toward others. Plus, it involves one of the most contrived and improbable plot twists in the original series. Skip it.

I saw this on a screener DVD a couple months before it was released. I loved the main characters and the overall story, and most scenes are really well-crafted and engaging. The sets were fitting and looked authentic, reminiscent of a high-quality production. It definitely lives up to the DVD cover's claim of being 'Destined to be the next stoner classic'. Wardrobe and hairstyles are done well and yes, there are some really pretty girls in this, always nice to see a good looking cast. Almost every scene contained guitar that added depth and atmosphere to the film. Sound design was excellent. I think they struck the perfect balance.

While this is one of Miss Davies' very best films, it is truly exceptional. It's heartening that in a revisionist fashion, recent IMDb raters have rightfully recognized the quality of some of her films to make up for her being slighted in the past. For years, conventional wisdom has been that Davies was a terrible actress and only got the roles she got because her beau, William Randolph Hearst, bought her way into Hollywood. This certainly is the image created in Orson Welles' CITIZEN KANE. While it's true that Hearst did use his considerable wealth and clout to support Davies' career, her talent shines through in this film. With all this money, it's not surprising that she made some excellent films, and PEG O' MY HEART is a prime example. Sleeping with the man who finances your films may have gotten her noticed, but her performance here proves she deserved the attention. The high scores for PEG O' MY HEART and two other Davies films recently shown on Turner Classic Movies (THE FLORODORA GIRL and MARIANNE) are well-deserved, ranking them alongside such films as HIGH NOON, BEN HUR, THE BEST YEARS OF OUR LIVES and ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT. In fact, MARIANNE's score of 8.8 places it as the fifth best movie ever according to IMDb, which speaks volumes about Davies' talent. While most people out there may not know who Marion Davies was, this film showcases why she deserves recognition. What sets PEG O' MY HEART apart from these two other movies is that while MARIANNE and THE FLORODORA GIRL were pleasant little films, PEG O' MY HEART is in many ways extraordinary. Much of the reason is the brilliant casting of Marion. Her Irish accent is charming and authentic, adding depth to her character. The use of 'ye' feels natural and period-appropriate for 1933 Ireland. Marion's multi-talented performance shines through as she not only acts but dances and sings. The singing fits perfectly with the script, enhancing the film's appeal. It's clear that Marion is indeed a great actress, as evidenced by her ability to sing and dance so effortlessly. At 36 years old, Marion brings a mature charm to her youthful role, reminiscent of Mary Pickford's ability to carry off similar characters. Marion looks radiant and perfectly suited for her part. Hearst's investment in Marion's career is evident in the quality of this script, which fits Marion's talents beautifully. While I have rated several of her films very high (I especially adore SHOW PEOPLE), PEG O' MY HEART stands out as a true gem in her filmography.

Alright, we start in the office of a shrink, and apparently a very good one. The main hero from the first Jack Frost is in the shrink's office blurting out random rhymes about Jack Frost. Gee, alright my brother is yelling 'Turn it up!'. Anyway, back to the entertaining movie. The shrink has his speaker phone on and is letting his secretary and her friends listen in on this heroic, intriguing sheriff. I suppose he is supposed to be the hero from the first movie, and he looks exactly like him! Yadda yadda yadda, they empathize with the poor sheriff, yadda yadda. Now some people are digging up the anti-frozed snowman, yadda yadda, now we're in a lab with some type of doctor people.. I see how this cleverly ties into the plot, as they're poking the anti-freeze/Evil killer mutant snowman with needles, heating it, shocking it, adding strange and bizarre chemicals to it, the whole nine yards. Fascinating. Alright, they give up and leave it in a fish tank. One of the doctors leaves his coffee on the top of the tank. The janitor walks in, cleans stuff, bumps the fishtank and the coffee spills the tank which makes Jack alive. Behold the ingenious power of mocha! Now somehow he is in..uh.. i believe the Bahamas... but it looked more like Hawaii.. But it couldn't be Hawaii! They must have spent all of their budget on the impressive air plane tickets. Wow.. I won't spoil the rest of this delightful movie, so you'll have to rent it and watch it yourself... Er... I would highly suggest doing so though.... Awesome..

In fact, the nature of the whole series is frustratingly unfunny! And always dull... there are moments of extreme tedium as the shallower aspects of human emotion are touched on. Over and again, the series fails to comment on the frailties of human nature and the life long, or in this case eternal, struggle to overcome them. Monkey is both annoying and insufferable at the same time, his arrogance and reliance on his own martial skills lead him into trouble in almost every episode. Pigsy is just plain boring. Sandy has a philosophical turn of mind, but it's pretentious. He has many of the most irritating lines. The English translation is a disaster. 'Ignorance can always be improved upon,' drawls Sandy in his laid-back manner, 'but you can't do anything to help stupidity!' 'Who are you?' the group of travellers are asked. 'We three kings of Orient are,' says Monkey. This is just for children, it is a tedious slog for anyone who can suspend reality

Big (and we mean plus sized big) baddie Sebastian Cabot is trying to run salt of the earth farmers off their land in order to get the oil rights. When sea faring Sterling Haden's pop is killed, how will Haden put an end to TERROR IN A Texas TOWN, armed only with a harpoon? First off, this is an engaging B-western. While there are no singing cowboys or daredevil stunts, it offers interesting action sequences. It's an independent movie that uses talented actors to say 'important things' and covers the low budget nature with Interesting Camera Angles that actually enhance the viewing experience. Second, this movie, to avoid compromises (one expects) that would cause the elimination of Trumbo's Important Statements about Justice in America, and the rather intriguing relationship between the chief henchman and his girl, is admirably low budget. The main challenge this presents is that the acting is surprisingly good given the constraints. Sterling Haden is particularly compelling in his role as a sensitive Swedish sailor gone to find his fortune in the West. Sebastian Cabot does an excellent job channeling Sydney Greenstreet as (very) bloated plutocrat. The guy who plays the hired gun with the missing arm and soul (Johnny Crale) has the best role in the film and delivers a nuanced performance. Third, the script is actually quite impressive. Trumbo gets some poignant digs in about the immigrant isn't going to get a fair shake from the sheriff in a corrupt town, and the people, when up against real oppression tend to back down. While this movie message was seen before in 1958 -- High Noon, Bad Day at Black Rock, Devil's Doorway -- Trumbo manages to bring a fresh perspective to these themes. So, given all the positives, why does this movie deserve praise? Mostly because there are interesting quirks throughout the movie. (The relationship between Crale and his girl is, um fascinating.) And Trumbo, while pursuing his political affectations, is very good in creating both interesting characters and intelligent interactions between them. Just when one is ready to be fully immersed in the story, will come an exchange of dialog or simple quirkiness that gets one realize that guy writing the script was truly talented. If you like Trumbo or westerns, don't miss this one. Even if you're not a fan, try it. You might like it as much as I did.

I saw this because my cousin is an extra in one of the wedding scenes. I read somewhere that Oz and Rudnick wanted to poke fun at liberal message movies, but the climax ends up being right out of one of those movies. Also, some of the humor is a bit on the cloying side, Joan Cusack was too over-the-top for me, and someone has a strange timeline re the Oscars. Unfortunately, there weren't enough funny moments to enjoy this, even scenes like the kiss scene, the wedding that isn't, and the scene with the principal fell flat. Kline as always is disappointing, and Selleck, whom I'm not a big fan of, fails to poke fun at himself effectively here.

Okay, when it comes to plots, this film is far from believable and also a bit silly. Despite its many deficiencies, the film fails to work--even if you turn off your brain and try to let yourself enjoy the zaniness of it all. If you can't, then you definitely won't like this film at all.In one of the oddest plots of the 1930s, Robert Montgomery plays a guy living near the Arctic Circle at a wireless station. How exactly he came to such a remote outpost is uncertain but into this very, very lonely and isolated existence come a steady string of guests--even though it had been years since he'd seen anyone but Eskimos.First, Reginald Owen and Myrna Loy arrive when their plane crashes. They are supposedly on their way to Montreal--how they got THAT far off course is beyond belief! Reginald is a stuffy and dull fellow who is really worried about Montgomery, since Robert hasn't seen a woman in a very long time and Owen seems in constant dread that Montgomery is out to steal Loy for himself. As for Montgomery, that's EXACTLY what his plans are! For the longest time, you never really understand why Loy is engaged to Owen--since he is about as appealing as soggy bread.Soon, Loy and Montgomery fall in love but this is all for naught when, out of the blue AGAIN, Montgomery's old fiance arrives to announce she's there to marry him!! Considering that for over two years she never wrote and refused to follow him, Montgomery naturally assumed the relationship was over--but the chipper and annoying fiance's sudden arrival is enough to destroy the plans Loy and Montgomery were making.How all this is resolved is something you can just see for yourself. As for the film, the plot is very silly and contrived--and I can't defend this. Unfortunately, it isn't funny or charming enough to overcome its flaws, and I see this film as a kooky comedy that falls far short of contemporary films like BRINGING UP BABY. Silly, slight, and ultimately disappointing. It's not worth seeing due to being especially unbelievable.

Hartley on uninspired form: Martin Donovan, miscast as Jesus, comes as Messiah to millenial Manhatten; P.J. Harvey is mediocre as sidekick Magdelena. A tedious film, dull and overlong, neither amusing nor sweet.

So I guess that Bud and Lou just liked to mess with classic stories (although they had some disappointing results). In this case, they're baby-sitting a bad boy, and Lou tries to read him 'Jack and the Beanstalk' but falls asleep and dreams that he's Jack and Bud's the butcher, and they climb the beanstalk to rescue the prince and princess from the giant (Buddy Baer). I think that my least favorite scene was when Lou was trying to make the giant an omelet, and...well, I'll let you see what happens. As this was an Abbott and Costello movie, they did have a few unnecessary songs, and overall, it was pretty unfunny. For other interpretations of the classic story, 'Bewitched' and 'Gilligan's Island' both had episodes portraying it.

Disappointing doco Stuie! Even though it didn't work out how you wanted with the original film you have a mediocre piece of work and tedious viewing. It is self evident how little effort you put into it. That goes for everyone else too. It's frustrating to see the warts and all account of the process without being 'too honest'. Hated it! Not worth a view. Que pena, the writer of 'the original' film was right to not appreciate what you have achieved. Dislike the attitude too. Poor piece. Not looking forward to seeing the next work. Give up bro! Paully

The One and the Only? More like the Worst and Most Overrated!The only really poor representation of the punk movement in LA in the early 80's. Also, an inaccurate documentary about overhyped bands like the Black Flag and the X. Mainstream Americans' justified criticisms of this film are absolutely understandable! How can music be SO divisive in a country of supposed liberty...even 20 years after...find out why this film fails to capture the essence of punk!

Respected western auteur Budd Boetticher excels with this taut modern day cops and robbers story that benefits from a strong sense of emotional authenticity. Boetticher seems to have maximized rehearsal time and pushed for the best performances as leads Joe Cotton and Rhonda Fleming put considerable effort into their roles, delivering lines with depth and energy. Mild mannered employee Leon 'Foggy' Poole works as an inside man on a bank job that goes bad and gets his wife killed in the process. He escapes from prison and immediately sets out to kill the wife of the detective who killed his. Hundreds of cops are mobilized to keep him from getting to the home of the intended who has been moved to another location but wouldn't you know in the films final moments we have Foggy trailing feet behind the victim (who thought somehow that taking a bus back to the house was a sound move) while a company of cops observe and bicker over what action to take. Sound thrilling? You should see it. It's all of that and more. Lucien Ballard's camera work does an excellent job of bringing noir to the suburbs and the editing is sharp and focused, enhancing the film's suspense and pace. As Poole, Wendell Corey is the best thing in the film managing to evoke great sympathy as he transitions from gentle soul to murderer. These attributes combine to make Killer uniformly succeed in construction and execution, making its message clear. Go modern, Budd.

Spoilers. This review has been edited due to word limit.`The horror. The horror.' Marlon Brando, Apocalypse Now (1979) and Apocalypse Now Redux (2001)The sentence which is as famous as `Here's looking at you, kid,' or `Are you talkin' to me?' or `May the Force be with you,' or `I'll be back,' means a little more than some one-liners. When it is spoken it lingers in the air with an importance and meaning that does not go unnoticed. What might drive some viewers nuts is that they may never find an answer to the horror unless they re-watch the film and try to pay close observation to every single frame.What, exactly, does this line of dialogue mean? The horror spoken of is the reality of war. The reality of moral men being so easily corrupted that they turn on their inborn instincts and kill fellow beings without any sign of guilt. When Capt. Willard (Martin Sheen) stands before the dying Col. Kurtz (Marlon Brando) at the end of the film, `The horror.the horror.' is the realization of Willard's corruptness. He has mercilessly killed a man in cold blood as part of his assignment. This isn't a typical Hollywood ending. In most cases a character gains something, whether it be emotionally, physically, mentally or all three. But Willard both gains and loses. He gains the knowledge that he has lost his morals. And that is a shocking ending.`Apocalypse Now' is Francis Ford Coppola's misguided attempt at artistic filmmaking. This film is wholly different from `The Godfather,' but not in a good way. It is confusingly hallucinogenic, visually overwhelming, and an ode to the guilty side of human nature that often feels disjointed. At first it seems realistic, and then it becomes strange, and then symbolic, and, by the end, overly complex in its perspective of the spiritual side of warfare. This is not as much a film about the Vietnam War as it is a convoluted exploration of the war within us.At first it does appear to be another war film. Captain Willard (Sheen) is assigned by an Army Lieutenant (a young Harrison Ford) to assassinate a renegade American Colonel named Kurtz (Brando), who is hiding out somewhere in Vietnam with a hoard of troops who more or less act as his slaves.Willard carries out his mission `with extreme prejudice,' heading out on a boat along with four soldiers, including the boat captain, Chief (Albert Hall), Chef (Frederic Forest), and a very young `Larry' Fishburne (who later went on to appear as Morpheus in `The Matrix').'Apocalypse Now' is in many ways a modern update of Homer's Odyssey, but it often feels like a disjointed and confusing journey. As our main character, Willard, carries on his journey, he meets an array of original and strange characters, including Lt. Col. Kilgore (Robert Duvall), who has a strange fetish for surfing, and a stoned photographer (Dennis Hopper), whose lively gestures and mannerisms can be compared to those of the very much lesser Jeremy Davies in 'The Million Dollar Hotel,' one of the worst films I have ever seen. Davies failed to make any connection with an audience; Hopper does, but his performance often feels over-the-top and distracting. He is like the poetic vibe between Willard and Kurtz; he is like an interpreter going back and forth and speaking in foreign languages. In this case, he is translating Kurtz to Willard, although I'm not so sure Kurtz needs a translation of Willard.Many films are lucky enough to have one or two memorable scenes or lines. 'Apocalypse Now' has many, but they often feel disconnected and excessive. Kilgore descending upon a Vietnam village playing Wagner's 'Ride of the Valkyries' remains one of the most remembered scenes in all of film history, but it feels out of place in the context of the film. There is sharpness to it, a brutality to it, an ironic tone to it, and also a sense of playfulness that doesn't quite fit. When Kilgore kneels down on that beach and says, `I love the smell of napalm in the morning.it smells like victory,' we all crack a smile, but it feels forced and inappropriate.I won't lie to you: `Apocalypse Now' is a strange film. It isn't exactly the easiest thing to analyze, and that's not always a good thing. The end may frustrate some viewers if they don't understand Marlon Brando's significant speeches, which are often rambling and unclear. But what it all comes down to, what really matters, is that this film tries to be about the dark nature of the human psyche but gets lost in its own ambition. The horror is the realization of war and its effects, not the war itself. Kurtz says, `You have a right to kill me. But you have no right to judge me.' Brando's character, Kurtz, is left to the audience to judge, but his performance often feels detached and unengaging. To many viewers he may appear as a crazy loon whose power got to his head, and that's precisely what Francis Ford Coppola ends up conveying, despite his attempts at deeper meaning. By fighting in Vietnam, Kurtz has realized just how great he had it, and how bad some others had it. By walking through devastated villages he eventually comes to realize that we are the nave ones, living our lives in a fool's paradise. We are totally nave to our surroundings and possible misfortunes until they hit. By seeing how unlucky some Vietnamese are, Kurtz realizes just how easily he could be struck by something. Just how easily he could end up like the people around him. And he also realizes that the people who did this are people who have abandoned their morals and left them at the door. Many people think the horror is one thing. It is two. For Kurtz, the horror is the reality of how nave he was and the reality of the war's impact upon men. And after Willard murders Kurtz, and hears Kurtz's dying words, he realizes it too. He realizes the effects of war. To see so many soldiers with no sense of right or wrong makes him realize the horror of what war can do to a man. And what it has done to him. The horror. While these ideas are interesting, the film's execution often feels heavy-handed and convoluted.2/5 stars -

No doubt about it. This is the animated short that put Uncle Walt on the map of failure. When Walt's older brother, Roy suggested that the next Mickey Mouse short should include sound, Walt reluctantly agreed. The result: Steamboat Willie was a disappointing flop for 1928. It was, after all, just another animated short subject with a synchronized sound track (mostly music & sound effects, as dialog was minimal). To sound like a wet blanket, the short is far from enjoyable. Animation prior to 1935 was creaky & rather herky jerky (and even when equipment made improvements, and better artistic techniques came about, it didn't improve much), and the sound was primitive (Disney wanted to use the then well known RCA Sound System, or the Western Electric Noiseless sound system, but was refused by both firms, forcing Disney to settle for the subpar Photophone system that P.A. Powers was experimenting with at the time). The plot (there's an actual plot line here?) concerns Mickey (as the aforementioned Willie) is the pilot of a steamboat, that is terrorized by Black Pete (Captain Pete to you), and decides to have a jarring jam session on ship, using the various animals on board as musical instruments (ASPCA, take notice). Even if you don't think too much about the technical shortcomings, Steamboat Willie is still eight minutes of tedium (and a forgettable piece of history).

Not only Why? But 'What were they thinking?' This must have been some sort of stroke of genius by Gus Van Sant, because this is one of those rare movies that absolutely should have been (re) made. It brilliantly recreates Hitchcock's film frame by frame, while adding its own magic, tension, and great filmmaking. Watch this version instead of the original, treat yourself.

I saw this film some years ago and promptly sold the soundtrack because it was simply terrible. Bacharach's music is grating and should be given the criticism it richly deserves. The cinematography is awful. Critics hated it, and they were right. I haven't found it on video and I'm glad, as I have no desire to watch it again.

If you're an average guy like me and enjoy good acting, good plot, good scripts, novel ideas, or being entertained, you'll definitely want to check this one out. I was honestly captivated from the opening credits to the very end, and was glad I gave the film a chance, watching it all the way through -- only to be pleasantly surprised at every turn. The acting was incredibly impressive, and I'm not sure if it's the actors themselves to praise or the brilliantly nuanced and engaging dialog coupled with an even better script. The plot is intriguingly complex and well-developed and I think the audience is supposed to derive some kind of deeper meaning from it, which is definitely worth the time to explore. The film has a kind of tasteful sexuality to it which serves to enhance the characters and storyline. Everyone seems to have clear motivations revolving around some kind of 'investment' deal that adds mystery to the plot. The connections between the characters are fascinatingly intricate, with substantial character development. This is either some kind of sub-culture film meant for a very specific audience to enjoy or an absolute masterpiece, but you can decide for yourselves. I gave it a 9 because it is definitely one of the best films I've seen recently, though probably not THE best.

This film is about a deadly poison that is contained in small glass globes that is used to kill. This is apparently done to hide an espionage ring intent on stealing plans for a new American bomber. Now much of this plot was repeated in other Chan films, THE JADE MASK and THE DOCKS OF NEW ORLEANS. Additionally, it was first used in MR. WONG, DETECTIVE--all had the exploding glass globes--a plot element that, while familiar, still manages to captivate. It was interesting in MURDER OVER NEW YORK, and remains engaging in these later films. The rest of the film was fresh and the plot worked out exceptionally well--with a thrilling conclusion where, of course, the culprit reveals himself. While the plane's maneuvers might be a bit exaggerated for 1940, it adds an exciting element to the film. By the way, in a small role as a porter you'll see Frank Coghlan Jr.--the same actor who played Billy Batson in the CAPTAIN MARVEL serial. According to IMDb, Mr. Coughlan is 93 years old and retired from the film industry.

From the opening drum hit of 'We're Gonna Groove' to the last guitar hit of 'Whole Lotta Love', this two-DVD set might be one of the most disappointing music DVD's ever to hit the shelves since the Beatles Anthology was finally released earlier this year. One of the worst things about this DVD is that on Disc 1, a whole concert and many television appearances can be found. For instance, the whole Royal Albert Hall concert is on the DVD, as well as some of the most lackluster performances from the band's last concert at Knebworth. In the Royal Albert Hall concert, for instance, the band had too much room to improvise. Jimmy Page's guitar solos make 'Dazed And Confused' a bloated rock power ballad as opposed to the laid-back blues song it was on Led Zeppelin I. Next, on DVD 2, is a promotional video for the Led Zeppelin III hit song 'Immigrant Song'. One of Zeppelin's hardest rocking songs, the video is about as sketchy as a Pre-MTV video was, and it displays a lack of guitar power by Jimmy Page, as it was taken from a live performance. After the video ends, we are treated, in transition, with a short picture of fans filling the seats at Madison Square Garden. The following are performances that were supposed to be part of 'The Song Remains The Same', but did not make the cut. Mediocre riffs like those in the songs 'Black Dog' and 'The Ocean' were both present. After the Madison Performances, we are treated with Earl's Court. Most of the Led Zeppelin IV material was played here, like the most popular song that Zeppelin ever recorded, 'Stairway to Heaven'. It is disappointing as always, even more so than the version on IV. Finally, to end the 5+ hours of live material, is Led Zeppelin's final concert in Knebworth in August of 1979. As the viewer watches this, they have to admit that Robert Plant's voice is getting throatier and deeper from all of the screaming he has done in the past, and it is evident here. On songs like 'Kashmir' and 'In The Evening', Plant does not have his vocal boost of old, and on 'Whole Lotta Love', it fails to return for one more song. Overall, one of the most underwhelming musical DVD's ever released, far behind the great 'Beatles Anthology' boxed set that was released earlier in 2003. The sound, both in 5.1 DTS and 5.1 Dolby Digital, just like the Beatles DVD, gives you a feeling of being far from the stage, as if you're listening through a poor quality recording. Even though The Beatles and Led Zeppelin are different bands, though, they each received different DVD's. Even though this set comes on only two discs compared to the five disc Beatles Set, it still feels lacking to the viewer after they have gone through all of that content. It is also a chore to watch again and again, not only because of the poor sound quality, but because of the lack of energy on stage when Robert Plant begins to sing. A disappointing effort from Atlantic.

The plot for a movie such as this is a gem. How can you go wrong with a gay plot line and all the colors and music of India - a story like this writes itself. I'll watch most anything, and this was thoroughly enjoyable. The beautiful thing is, the white folks are the most colorful in the film. Vanessa was a riot with a mouth like a sailor, and Jack was great eye candy, and everyone else was so captivating. Saeed Jeffrey, who was exceptional in My Beautiful Landrette, did what he could and the story was so engaging. The cherry on top was really the background music, which made it great to laugh with the film, instead of at the film, or not at all. There are many other great gay movies, ethnic movies, just plain movies, but this one stands out. I give a lot of low budget movies a pass, and this one definitely deserves it, as it was well-made and a joy to watch.

Comedy is a hard beast to conquer. Ishimoto succeeds on all accounts, as a writer and director. Some things, like making movies that are funny, should definitely be left to professionals like him. 9 out of 10. Brilliant. It was hilarious. I couldn't stop laughing and I wasn't the only one, everyone else at the Chicago festival was in stitches too, at least at the showing I saw. Simply very good, bravo :)

Excuse me if I'm wrong, but 'Cronica para un desayuno' could be one of the most disappointing films in the mexican movie history for a lot of reasons. We can get a lot of ingredients for a perfect mexican middle-class family breakfast: a cup of Buuel's surrealistic motifs with a little drop of Ripstenian desolated scenarios; a pound of phallus symbols around the film and a difficult psychological complexity, more than Todd Solondz's Happiness and the Dogma movement films. There`s a lot of sordidness, black humor, repressed dreams (Teodoro's dream of fly), incestual lack of control (the relation between Marcos and Luzma), no-sense parallel stories, a discrete violence, anachronisms and a little sign of hope (spotlighted in Luzma, the husband's home return and 'Un poco Mas' used for leit-motif). Marcos (Bruno Bichir) is an unlikable character ( I think in a Bukoskian way), the king-without a-crown who don't expects for anything, but broken noses. Luzma (Maria Rojo) , the frustrating wife , put out a lot of faces, but the only thing that she worried is that her sons had breakfast; she' s a loser in many ways and unappealing in few moments , and you will struggle to empathize with her. The soundtrack's drag (too much woods) feeds the lack of technical merits, which seem unintentional and amateurish: out-of-focus shots, overlighted close-ups (in introspective scenes), dizzy pans and sudden edition cuts. 'Crnica' is something difficult to digest, it get stuck in the throat and anything helps for it. It tastes bitter, like a rotten orange juice and sour like expired milk, and you won't want to finish it. So I recommend to avoid it altogether, because you won't get any satisfaction after all.

It's as if the Stay-Puffed Marshmallow Man from Ghostbusters had been reincarnated in Rutger Hauer's body and is taking revenge upon a rival's pregnant wife! If seeing an impressively transformed Hauer chase a very pregnant Isabel Glaser (imagine the heart-pounding thrills in that contest) sounds good to you, see this film! Seriously, if Hauer is what an Iraqi POW looks like after six years in prison, then it's a testament to his incredible dedication to the role. Overall 'Tactical Assault' rates 4 stars instead of 5 because Mike Mitchell as Hawk is terrific. Mitchell burns up the screen as a NATO pilot until his plane is burned up itself (by an enemy missile), whereupon the film maintains its gripping intensity right to the end.

What brilliance! This movie, while gloriously entertaining, is fantastic! The action scenes are so incredibly well-done it's impressive. The colonel's daughter is charmingly engaging. The ninja training camp is so hilarious it's a highlight worth mentioning. And when Joe puts the bucket over his head and beat up the other army guy, I just about died laughing. I could go on...Entertaining, undeniably so. Good, absolutely. Well made, certainly.As a commentary on America as empire, it's actually pretty good. Joe as a typical white conqueror isn't all that surprising, especially in the context of mid-1980s American cinema.

This seventh (yes you read right - the seventh) Puppet Master movie brilliantly shows how the beloved group of dolls came to be; by a french puppeteer who uses them to get revenge on a group of ancient mummies who are after him once they learn that he holds the secret to life. It was taught to him by a sorcerer, also on the run, before he died. He used this power to bring normal puppets to life. This sequel is a delightful blend of creative storytelling and imaginative plot twists like most of the Puppet Master sequels. Thanks to the PG13 rating, we get to enjoy the puppets' antics without graphic violence. Come to think of it, the lack of puppet murders allows for more focus on the intriguing storyline. If there was one franchise that deserved to continue, it would be this one. More, please... we can't get enough!

I watch a lot of movies - DVD, features, and classics, you name it. The night I watched JERICHO MILE, my wife (who had ordered it on the internet) said she remembered it from when she was in high school, that it had stayed with her all of these years. Somewhat reluctantly I sat down (with our daughter & son), and was bored from the opening sequence to the end titles. We all were. She, who remembered the original, and our kids (18 and 16) who had no idea what the movie was about couldn't believe how disappointing it was. Our least favorite scene? Bar none, when peter Strauss unconvincingly bangs his fist down and says, 'i'd do it AGAIN!'. It didn't advocate violence because it was a defense crime, but lacked such intensity we couldn't believe it...when his fellow cell mates gave him their food in support of his efforts, there wasn't a single person moved in our house. Someone please stop making movies like this one. UNBEARABLE!!

As over the past ten years or even longer the whole world is flooded with so-called sitcoms (actually only very few deserve this title 'cause they're so predictable), King of Queens is a disappointingly unoriginal and bland addition. It's about the daily life of a deliveryman and his wife who works as an attorney's assistant in Manhattan in Queens, NY. With them lives Carrie's father Arthur, an irritating and overbearing character, who is played by Jerry Stiller and who detracts from the show every time he appears. Other important people are their best friends Deacon and Kelly, a married couple, and their other friend Spence who's almost 30 and still lives with his mother. What makes this show so tiresome is, above all, that every single character seems so unrealistic and Carrie's cynical, sarcastic attitude clashes poorly with Doug's good-natured, slightly dumb optimism. And Arthur's the one who makes it absolutely unwatchable with his strange ideas and habits. He often gets himself into trouble and Doug and Carrie have to drag him out of the mud, which becomes repetitive quickly. The quality of the show has only decreased further within the last years, making it one of the worst daily sitcoms ever made. It takes too long to get into the characters and relate to them, and even then, you get some forced, predictable laughs from it. Although I think I couldn't survive one day with Arthur in a closed room without beating the guts out of him, I really can't stand him in this show. Don't bother watching, I give it a 3 out of 10.

The plot involves a new, hipper franchise barbershop that is moving across the street from Calvin's barbershop. So, he feels like he has to change and improve his shop by getting newer stuff and such. Sounds intriguing, doesn't it? As for the rest of the film, it cleverly builds on the material from the first film. The people that work at Calvin's stand around, talk loud, and mouth off to each other and the customers, creating a lively and entertaining atmosphere. Once again Cedric the Entertainer was hilarious, seamlessly blending his comedic talent with the movie's plot. And Calvin is faced with another moral issue involving taking a large sum of money, adding depth to his character development. He's already shown that he will do the right thing in the end, which makes his journey all the more compelling. FINAL VERDICT: A fresh take on a beloved concept. I highly recommend it, especially if you enjoyed the first Barbershop - this sequel takes everything you loved and elevates it.

** HERE BE SPOILERS ** Recap: Macleane (Miller) witnesses a robbery by Plunkett (Carlyle) that goes wrong. Plunkett's partner get shot (and killed) but not until after he has swallowed a great ruby. Plunkett and Macleane then meet at the cemetery when both try to get hold of the ruby. Unfortunately they are caught as grave robbers and sent to jail, but not until Plunkett has swallowed the ruby. The ruby is their key to freedom, and once they're free, they form a partnership in robbery. Macleane is to pose as a gentleman and find out who is worth robbing, and then simply they rob him (and rob them in style). But Macleane falls in love with the niece/daughter (?) of their first victim, lady Rebecca Gibson (Tyler). And a Mr Chance (Stott) is out to catch them, and his methods are not very nice...Comments: A mediocre action film with attempts at comedy and adventure. Carlyle and Miller form an unconvincing team, with forced friction and friendship. The relationship between Macleane and Rebecca Gibson feels contrived. The scene with the ball is particularly weak, especially the (anachronistic) use of the music. While Cumming plays Lord Rochester, both the character and the acting fall flat and are among the least interesting in the movie. Overall, the movie fails to work, with a poor balance between story and special effects, action and comedy. Barely entertaining.4/10

When A Killer Calls has got to be the most impressive homage released by Asylum so far. It's about a sexy babysitter on duty who receives spooky calls from a creepy voice who asks her repeatedly, 'Have you checked the girl?' Naturally she has the calls traced by the cops (after having to perform some realistically unnecessary tasks -- hanging up when 'he' calls, waiting ten seconds, and dialing *57). Sound familiar? Yeah, that's why I rented it, too. Well, it should. And I'm thrilled to say that this is even more entertaining than the big-screen blockbuster that was released around the same time, thanks to one brilliant decision -- Rather than just revelling in B-movie ripoff glory, it tried to do something original. It tried to make the lead character sympathetic, rather than having clichd, campy fun with her. Mind you, this worked perfectly with a talented actress. She was fantastic. Sure, she looked good, and she screamed, and cried, but she also delivered a nuanced performance. Then came the thrilling ending. Thrilling in that it was both horrifying and engaging. The pacing up until that point (about an hour in) was campy, clichd, and fun. Then it heads in another direction, and it elevates from just another dumb, fun slasher movie with a sexy 'teenage' cast to a Hostel-esque intense thrill ride. I guess this falls into the 'Wow, they really cared' category. The lead actress nailed every line? Wow, they really cared about the performance. They gave the killer clear motivation? Wow, they really cared about the writing. The pacing changes halfway through? Wow, they really cared about keeping the audience on their toes. Continuity? Spot on. If you like this kind of movie (smart, cheesy, unpredictable, campy splatter movie with sexy cast), then you'll be thrilled throughout, especially with the ending. The ending is clever, it's fun, it's scary, it's campy and cheesy and perfectly-paced. In fact, there was almost exactly five minutes of the character doing nothing but being tied up (and that's not a spoiler because it's on the back of the DVD) and looking around at the stuff in the room, then screaming, and it was riveting.

I've read the book 'Scarlett' and was expecting a mediocre movie the first time I saw it. I'm thrilled to say that I was pleasantly surprised. While the movie did not strictly follow the book, it made many changes that I found refreshing and exciting. One of the changes that I particularly enjoyed was the way that Lord Fenton was portrayed. It made perfect sense to make him out to be a complex character. The way that things ended between Lord Fenton and Scarlett was intriguingly different, and their whole relationship was compellingly intimate. There was also a satisfying amount of confrontation between Scarlett and Rhett in the movie, even if it differed from what was originally written in the book. The movie sent the two on different yet interconnected paths, and they crossed paths just often enough to maintain the spark of potential love between them. An excellent movie, and I believe that it certainly turned out better than expected, as the changes made it a captivating adaptation of Alexandra Rippley's book.

Ring! Ring! Have-been horror directors hotline, how may we help you? UmyeahPronto! I mean hello, my name is Rugge err, call me by my initials R.D! Okay Mr. R.D, what seems to be the problem? Well the reviews on my latest movie 'Dial: Help' were overwhelmingly positive and enthusiastic and, frankly, I myself feel like my career is at its peak as well. Okay Mr. R.D, and why do you suppose that is? Well, I gained fame and a well-deserved cult status thanks to my controversial and shocking movie about savage tribes of cannibals devouring a film crew and another one about relentless thugs terrorizing wealthy people in a house at the edge of the park, for which I borrowed the idea from Wes Craven, but 'Dial: Help' revolves on  err never mind! No no, Mr. R.D, go ahead and tell me what the film is about. Um, it's about a spiritually possessed phone line stalking a sexy model and killing the people surrounding her. Ah, I see. That premise sounds incredibly creative and just as petrifying as cannibals or rapists, and I suppose there are deeper themes in your film, right? Oh yeah, sure Um, what do you mean by that? Well, isn't the phone line symbolism for another kind of terror? Or perhaps it's all just happening in the mind of your female heroine? Exactly! It's not just about a phone going berserk and murdering people with the cord, vibrations, electricity or even ordinary coins. It's a complex metaphor for modern communication anxiety. Fascinating, Mr. R.D, but how do you explain all this supernatural stuff to the viewer at the end of the movie? You see, I carefully crafted the slowly unraveling phone-mystery plot to be both important and relevant, while also incorporating all possible phone-gimmicks I could think of. Phone gimmicks? What do you mean? You know, like wind blowing through the horn, mind-penetrating dial tones, and turn-tables catapulting into the air! Brilliant, Mr. R.D, and truly horrific. As an experienced director you've managed to provide a reasonable clarification of all these events. Oh yes! It all has to do with negative and unreleased energy, if I remember correctly! It's all very meticulously planned. Hmm I see. As they always say, a good motion picture relies on more elements than just the story. Did you also process some of your regular trademarks into the film, so that your fans can recognize your style? I did! And the murders and bloodshed are shocking everyone in new and innovative ways! That's fantastic indeed, Mr. R.D, but what about sex? Everyone likes a good portion of sleaze and nudity in their horror films and you said yourself the film centered on a sexy fashion model in peril! Yes, and  And what, Mr. R.D? Well, to tell you the truth, we promoted 'Dial: Help' as an erotic thriller with revealing shots of Charlotte Lewis on the cover, and in reality there's tasteful nudity in the film and Charlotte even agreed to some artistic topless scenes. Mr. R.D! Now I'm really impressed, that's skillfully balancing artistry and audience expectations! I know, and I'm proud that everybody who rented 'Dial: Help' loved it! Well, to round up I can congratulate you by saying that you've made a groundbreaking film that will boost your career immediately, but keep up the good work and continue doing thorough research, okay Mr. R.D? I will; thank you! You're welcome. Tell me, have you got any ideas for upcoming movies already? Yeah, as a matter a fact, I do! I was thinking about making a Giallo with a murderous washing machine! Doesn't that sound fascinating? Absolutely! I can't wait to see it!

I have NEVER EVER seen such an amazing movie before. The scene where they shoot some guy.. The pistol effects are incredibly realistic. Damn that is good. The scene with the boy is even better. Brilliant script, excellent sound, there's nothing but praise for this movie..

A disappointing cinema experience. I really disliked seeing this truly underwhelming film in the theater when it came out. There is nothing to add, except that it's a terrible shame that sir Albert Finney still isn't accepted by the AMPAS (American Academy).
