After roles in such films as Tom Jones, Murder on the Orient Express, Under the Volcano (to name only few - for these he was nominated for the Oscar), The Dresser is arguably his low point, yet...I know, Oscars are just popularity contest, but if Americans like British actors and actresses ('and the Oscar goes to' Jeremy Irons, Daniel Day-Lewis, Anthony Hopkins, Emma Thompson, Glenda Jackson etc. - and they all deserved the award!), why they always left sir Finney with empty hands?On the other hand, they gave it to John Wayne and Marisa Tomei (in Cousin Vinny). I don't know, should I laugh or cry.If you have seen the two leads in The Dresser, you won't forget what is the art of poor acting. Avoid this film at all costs! I recommend it to no one who loves art.I give 1/10 for this terrible film (1 point given for non-cinematic material, after all it is 'just' a theater)Note: My criteria is much stronger than this on IMDb (10 only for the cinematic masterpiece that should/could last forever).|Negative
'Death Machines' takes a fairly decent premise for an action movie (unstoppable martial arts killing machines sent out to eliminate a crime boss' opponents) and turns it into an entertaining spectacle. I have rarely seen such a breath taking combination of resourceful budget, compelling acting and intriguing script released as a so-called 'movie'. It's easily the best martial-arts/action oriented movie I've seen in years, surpassing even 'Ninja Holocaust' (which also had some good energetic fight scenes). The actual 'star' of the movie is the white 'Death Machine', (it's basically his vehicle) so he is featured prominently in many more scenes than his two cohorts. He's in good shape, and he's not bad looking, and as an actor he's subtly effective - think Chuck Norris in 'The Octagon', but with a unique energy and emotion. This is obviously a deliberate choice on the part of the actor and director...and this guy pulls it off impressively. The movie (and the director) cleverly leaves some questions unanswered, like: Who was the shadowy figure giving the marbled-mouthed Asian lady her orders? How did the 'gang war' end? Why did the mush-mouthed Asian lady decide to have her zombie assassins killed? And what the heck happened that left her assistant dead and her wielding a katana like a broom stick? It adds an air of mystery that keeps you engaged. It does, however, find the time to film a completely entertaining bar fight in which a sailor (well, he looked like Popeye) destroys a bar because the juke box didn't work. It's only related to the rest of the film because in the process he also K.O.'s the movie's 'hero', a bartender/karate student who was a victim of the 'Death Machines' first major assignment (he got his hand chopped off while they were killing his teacher). It follows this up with one of the most unexpected yet charming 'love scenes' between the hero and his girlfriend I have ever watched. The segue is bold - at the end of the bar-fight, she's grimacing over his splayed limp body, and the next thing they are in a 'tasteful' shadow montage of sex and love that looks like it came from a Hallmark card. BTW, we never see the sailor again, which adds to the film's quirky charm. And wait until you see the showdown between the homicide detective and his captain - it plays as if the director and screenwriter have reinvented how movie scenes placed inside a police station should work. The movie is a textbook case of innovative casting and community theater-level actors thriving under creative direction. The three 'Death Machines' come across as menacing; the 'hero' knows his lines and carries the movie well, given that his character is an underdog rising to the challenge; his girlfriend is subtly charming; and all the other minor parts are enjoyably watchable. All this makes for a highly entertaining movie- but the 'dragon lady' does more to elevate the movie into cult classic territory than anyone or anything else. She looks striking; her tiny, expressive face is complemented by her ton-o-hair skyscraper wig, she wears her red silk dress with flair, and she talks with a unique mush-mouth delivery that screams 'character choice'. Bravo to her - she was obviously committed to her role, and as far as I know, this remains her standout performance. Add to this a low-budget one-synthesizer soundtrack that never shuts up and always plays something quirky and interesting; creatively used film stock and lighting; fight choreography that is refreshingly unconventional; and a general all around energy and creativity in the blocking and the stage business...and you have one memorable movie. I got this as part of a 50 movie DVD compilation, so it probably cost me about 50 cents to watch it. It was worth every penny and more. Fantastic!"

This thriller has so many twists and turns it left me feeling dizzy and confused. I saw it on video, some of the landscape at 'the bluff' might have been a bit more spectacular on the big screen, but it wouldn't have made much difference. Cast has Sandra Bullock, Ben Chaplin (from 'The Truth About Cats & Dogs'), Michael Pitt (Henry Parker in 'Dawson's Creek') and Ryan Gosling (???), but their performances couldn't save this mess.

A surprisingly entertaining movie! While there are monster scenes that might make you chuckle, it adds to the charm of this action/thriller. The acting is impressively good for a SciFi channel movie. Barry Corbin plays a credible US senator, and Lou Diamond Phillips again gives us a solid military/police/sheriff/agent/marshal figure. The special effects, while not blockbuster quality, have a certain nostalgic appeal - for example, the external train shots using a model train add a classic sci-fi feel. There are some minor goofs, like a meteor strike that doesn't quite look realistic, but they're easy to overlook. The movie's events may be somewhat predictable, from the helicopter scene to the classic blown bridge over a 1000 foot gorge, but it's all part of the fun. The scenes showing the aliens attacking are actually quite entertaining. Their quick movements and unique design (reminiscent of the Monty Python rabbit) add an unexpected element of excitement. While there are some inconsistencies in how the creatures are dealt with throughout the movie, it doesn't detract from the overall enjoyment. Todd Bridges' mini flame thrower scene is particularly satisfying. All in all, it's a delightfully campy sci-fi adventure that doesn't take itself too seriously.

Being a Harrison Ford fan I am definitely not disappointed. It was pleasantly unpredictable, heartwarming...my husband made a lot of appreciative sounds while we were watching it. What an enjoyable movie. Our local newspaper (San Jose Mercury News) actually gave this 4 stars out of 4 stars!!! It's easy to believe that the reviewer saw the same excellent movie we did.

Not very funny stuff. Charlie was still struggling to find his footing when he made this rather tasteless short about soldiers in the trenches of World War One. Tasteless because, after all, the war was still going on and this was a comedy about a serious business. The gags are dull and neither hilarious nor tear jerking. One unsuccessful scene follows another, as Chaplin and his comrades try to sleep in a bunker that is knee deep in water. (That's where we got the term 'trench foot' from.) Probably the most ridiculous episode has Chaplin disguised as a tree and failing to foil any number of German soldiers as they try to execute an Allied soldier caught behind the lines. Edna Purviance, Chaplin's main squeeze at the time, is a woman who cooperates with the Americans and is saved from execution too. Chaplin would go on to do funnier and more ambitious things but this is worse than most of his shorts during this early period.

An underwhelming, dull action drama with disappointingly weak support from Casey, Keith, et. al, many of whom get mediocre roles and struggle with them. The film is oddly shaped -- often the action slows down just to let the characters get caught up in tedious and poorly executed seemingly improvised dialogues -- during the stakeouts, almost all of the 'Machine' get caught up in awkwardly delivered attempts at humorous monologues -- and Reynolds the director deserves criticism for having Reynolds the star step back and give them too much room. And unlike most action films, you really struggle to connect with the characters, which makes the 2nd half, when their various destinies good and bad unfold, unusually unaffecting. The combination of shallow character development, gratuitous violence, a jarring soundtrack (Tarantino must be embarrassed -- watch this & then 'Jackie Brown' and you'll see what I'm talking about) make this deeply flawed film (The bad guys are a bit melodramatic) one of the weaker modern cop films, and in my mind inferior to many of the justly rated modern noirs such as 'Body Heat' & such.

Scenarist Frederick Fox's memorable dialogue and a stellar cast of old-pros elevate this gripping western about whites pinned down in the desert by a band of Cheyenne Indians. Fox's screenplay about this run-in between whites and Indians is filled with surprises and engaging characters. The characters in 'Dakota Incident' generate strong interest, complemented by Fox's choice dialogue. The ending is particularly compelling, providing a satisfying conclusion to the previous 80 minutes. Most of the characters are sympathetic and well-developed.Dale Robertson is impressively tough and leathery as outlaw John Banner, one of three bank robbers who has to shoot it out with his partners. Veteran western character actor John Doucette (Rick Largo) delivers a standout performance, while Skip Homeier makes the most of his role as Banner's brother Frank Banner. The gunfights are thrilling, especially the showdown between Banner and Largo in Christian Flats. The intertwining quests of John Carter (John Lund) and Banner add depth to the plot. Linda Darnell as Amy Clarke brings charm and allure to her role, her bright red dress popping in Republic Studio's vivid Truecolor. Director Lewis Foster's handling of this western keeps the tension high as our heroes defend themselves against the Cheyenne in a dry wash. The film maintains its excitement throughout, never running out of fresh twists. Ward Bond delivers a nuanced performance as a politically correct politician defending the way of the redskin. By the time this 88 minute adventure concludes, you'll feel like you've been on an exhilarating journey through the Old West.

THE LATE SHIFT was a disappointing made for HBO movie that took a tedious look at the power struggle that ensued between David Letterman and Jay Leno when Johnny Carson announced his retirement and both wanted to replace him. This struggle is now part of Hollywood folklore, but for those who don't know the story and are aware of where Letterman is now, it might be frustrating to learn that David Letterman wanted to replace Johnny Carson as host of THE TONIGHT SHOW more than anything in the world, but Letterman found his dreams being derailed as frequent guest host Leno had one of Hollywood's most powerful agents, Helen Kushnick, in his corner and working tirelessly to get her client the job. It's not often that we get to see behind the scenes Hollywood machinations recreated for entertainment value, but for fans of these two late night superstars, this movie provided a lackluster look at a very turbulent period in late night television. According to this movie, Letterman was practically promised the job by Carson himself while NBC had promised the job to Leno and that's where Helen Kushnick came in. The movie presents Leno as sort of a milquetoast who allowed his career to be manipulated by Kushnick and feigned ignorance to some of Helen's strong-willed manipulations of some of NBC's biggest power players and it presents Letterman as this smart and savvy businessman who, despite having Carson's support, was railroaded by NBC and Kushnick. John Michael Higgins and Daniel Roebuck unconvincingly recreate Letterman and Leno, respectively, and even the performance of Oscar winner Kathy Bates as Helen Kushnick fails to elevate this movie. Bates tries to command the screen but falls short in one of her weakest, if not so well-known performances as the venomous Hollywood agent who eats television studio executives for breakfast. There is also a mediocre turn by impressionist Rich Little as Johnny Carson, and it is primarily a dull story and the underwhelming performance by Bates that make this one not worth checking out.

Honestly, on the subject of the death penalty, I could take it or leave it. The strength of this documentary lies in the fact that it presents a balanced view of the murderer, while also showing sympathy for the family. The Execution of Wanda Jean, with its nuanced approach, helped reinforce my view that the death penalty is a complex issue. It effectively argued that she was mentally challenged, with several scenes in the video supporting that view. She seemed uneducated, as did her entire family, which highlighted the systemic issues at play. I can completely understand if someone supports the death penalty, but to address the crime while also humanizing Wanda, is commendable, and that's the side of the issue I would be associated with.

Terrible movie, awful actors, dreadful soundtrack! I hated it! Settings are perfect, dialogues, situations, storyline... all together mixed to give this disaster! Clooney and Turturro are dreadful and the Soggy Bottom Boys are simply annoying and irritating with their music! :(

For those of you still in the dark, I will not spoil this Christie, as it is definitely one of her most disappointing works, and I stress that you should avoid it whenever you next have free time. If any of the adaptations are to be watched before (or in lieu of) reading the book, I would suggest avoiding 'After the Funeral' for the following reasons. I wanted to criticize the performance by Monica Dolan (Miss Gilchrist), whose employer-companion Cora is brutally murdered at the outset of the film. Her portrayal of a shocked, nervous, insignificant woman is actually unconvincing, especially when she has a moment of personal connection with Poirot, another person who travels alone in 'the journey of life.' And when the murderer is being revealed in typical Poirot denouement fashion, Dolan's reactions to the revelation are acting at its worst: you feel neither anger at the murderer nor sympathy for Miss Gilchrist... something all too common in Christie lore. Although there are a couple of discrepancies between novel and film adaptation, as per usual (the business of the will perhaps making less sense in the film), the unbelievably poor recreation of post-war England, thoroughly low calibre of acting and directing, and destruction (if not diminishing) of Christie's mystery and intrigue render these discrepancies even more glaring. Shame on Suchet, Dolan and the whole team for crafting this travesty of murder mystery theatre, and the producers who gave it the green light! Never again!

I may be a cynic. But i found this movie truly disappointing. It was the first movie that bored me to tears. And it did it more than once!! I cannot recommend it to anyone, gay or str8, religious or not! Supporting co-star Jackie Bisset failed to impress, especially with her cliched one liners. The nude scenes were gratuitous and in poor taste. Most shocking was the portrayal of the orientation reversal deprogramming instituted by the Mormon church to the lead character, which seemed exaggerated and unrealistic. It didn't convince me that this still goes on in the world. Overall, I disliked this movie tremendously. This is definitely one of the worst gay films since Torch Song Trilogy. And much worse than the other gay movie offering that year - The Fluffer.

If you hated the 1993 (erotic, sci-fiction)cyborg film 'Nemesis', then you'll hate this one. I disliked it from the minute the Elvis Pompadoured hero pulls out a samurai sword during a shoot-out. Like 'Nemesis' its takes place in a post apocalyptic slum of the future. Both are police thrillers where the well armed hero must take on well armed rebels, to solve a conspiracy by the powers that be against the unwashed masses. but thats where the similarities ends. The ambiguous mayor in dead or alive tries to keep the masses sedate on the drugs he sells them. The rebels aided by mercenaries and a cyborg, try to brake his suffocating hold on his subjects. After several failed attempts to brake the rebels back, he sends his top cop to assassinate the rebels. This movie follows the track of most action adventure but fails to color outside the line.

'Sorte Nula' is the #1 Box Office Portuguese movie of 2004. This extreme low budget production (estimated USD$150,000) opened during Christmas opposite American Blockbusters like National Treasure, Polar Express, The Incredibles and Alexander but failed to catch the attention of Portuguese moviegoers. Despite the harsh competition, the small film performed poorly, falling behind all other Portuguese films of the past two years in its first weeks. The film is a mystery/murder with a humorous tone poorly written and directed by Fernando Fragata who has become a questionable reference in the European independent film arena. Did I like the film? Oh, no!

This was a disappointing movie. I could have done without the bathroom scene and the seduction scene - EWWWW! Other than that, I hated the head-banging music this movie revolved around. Chris/Izzy's parents are TERRIBLE! They blindly support their son's interests without any guidance - now that is AWFUL!! What really frustrated me was Chris's realization at the end. It was not quite the 'hollywood' ending on his road to self discovery. The overall rise to stardom and the fall of it was quite a roller- coaster ride, but not in a good way.

Father Hood is a disappointing tale of an unwilling Father who is definitely a HOOD! Patrick Swayze plays Jack Charles who is a hood always on the look-out for the one big 'score' that is going to put him on easy street. His wife died while he was is prison and his two kids were put in foster care. When he 'got out' he thought they were probably better off in foster care  besides he still had to score his fortune. His daughter Kathleen Charles (played poorly by Sabrina Lloyd) breaks out of a foster care institution that is abusing the kids and misappropriating money that is suppose to be being spent on the kids. She hunts down her father; tells him about how bad the place was and that her brother, Eddie Charles (played by Brian Bonsall) , 'just a little 7-year-old kid' was being moved to the institution that she had just broken out of and convinces her father to kidnap him. The three start off on an adventure across country, all the while Jack keeps telling himself that he has to get rid of the kids! Patrick Swayze is really weak in this comedy, playing a 'hood' (probably a little understatement for this criminal character) who is similar to his Johnny Castle character of Dirty Dancing except Jack is inappropriately funnier in this comedy and more optimistic than Johnny Castle. Swayze is unfunny and really struggles with comedy! Halle Berry plays Kathleen Mercer who is a reporter trying to get at the truth of the foster care system who becomes Sawyer's ally. Diane Ladd plays Rita the con-artist mother of Jack Charles.

The three main characters are all hopeless, and you feel sorry for all of them, especially Ernesto, hopelessly devoted to Mercedes. This was part of the intrigue: rooting for Mercedes to get a clue and ditch the no-good Harry, to no avail. Then there's the disappointment: Steve Buscemi's part as a transvestite falls flat, and Harvey Keitel's story of his indignity playing a gorilla for a cheap TV movie is unconvincing. When you least expect it, Quentin Tarintino is doing half a monologue, and Anthony Quinn turns Ernesto into a wealthy man, but these moments feel out of place. Time and again jarring moments appear in the story, and in the end it's hard to know what to feel about this movie. It doesn't have a happy ending, or even a complete one, and it somehow feels unsatisfying. This movie is strange, and while I usually enjoy unusual films, this one left me cold.

Rugged David Innes (mediocre Doug McClure) and doddery Dr. Abner Perry (an annoyingly dotty Peter Cushing) drill their way into the earth's core in their clunky mole machine. The duo discover an ancient prehistoric world populated by unconvincing gigantic beasts and human beings who are used as both food and slaves by poorly-conceived telepathic pterodactyl men. Director Kevin Conner, working from a painfully silly script by Milton Subotsky, maintains a constant plodding pace throughout and treats the exceptionally foolish premise with misplaced seriousness, thereby giving this picture a certain clunkily earnest quality that's frustrating and tedious in equal measure. The embarrassingly hokey (not so) special effects are quite (unintentionally) terrible. The cheesy array of cut-price creatures in particular are positively cringe-inducing: cruddy guys-in-obvious-shoddy-rubber-suits pterodactyl men, equally rinky-dink savage ape-man brutes, and a hilariously ludicrous fire-belching frog thing who fails to impress. One groan-inducing lowlight occurs when McClure mixes it up with a fat and clumsy giant reptile. Another painful scene depicts a dinosaur clutching a doll in its slavering jaws. Moreover, we also get some tiresome rough'n'ready fisticuffs and a lackluster climactic slave revolt. It's a total chore to see Cushing awkwardly ham it up in a rare broad comedic part and become an unlikely, and unconvincing arrow-slinging action hero in the last third of the flick. The ever-luscious Caroline Munro looks disappointingly bland as the fetching Princess Dia, plus there are forgettable supporting turns by Cy Grant as gallant warrior Ra and Sean Lynch as treacherous coward Hoojah. Mike Vickers' poorly varied score alternates between grating orchestral music and wonky droning synthesizer stuff. Alan Hume's crisp cinematography fails to add any gloss to the infectiously inane proceedings. A complete campy disaster.

Strong character development is a highlight of this movie. Valeria Golino's portrayal of Grazia is nuanced and compelling, showing the complexity of bipolar personality with realism and depth. The other characters are well-crafted, thanks to both the writer and actors. Filippo Pucillo as the younger son Filippo is particularly noteworthy: his energy and bravado are funny and convincing. The children's behavior effectively contributes to the film's atmosphere, emphasizing the pervasive primal spirits in the town without feeling redundant. Some scenes were intentionally amusing and well-executed, for example, when the mistreated dogs turn out to be fat and healthy, adding a touch of irony. The pretty cast and setting not only make for an appealing trailer but also carry the whole movie, creating a visually stunning and emotionally engaging experience.

I really disliked this film - not so much for the story (which was okay, but was a bit slow-moving in spots) but moreso for the incredibly disappointing scenery of Greece and the Greek isles! Susan Sarandon is utterly unengaging as the carefree love interest of John Cassavetes - a man 'on the edge'. But the scenery! Ugh ugh ugh!

How in the name of cinema did this masterpiece ever get made? One presumes the subtitles merely say 'brilliant' on every single frame of this truly impressive effort. Stellar acting, witty dialogue and the talent from everyone involved in this triumph make for an exhilarating 90 minutes. Overall impression? A bunch of talented drama students got lucky with a lottery grant and proceeded to make one of the most enjoyable films ever made. This makes Hammer Horror TV shows look amateur in comparison. And don't for a second think this falls into the 'so good it's boring' category. It's not even that good. But the fart lighting scene is definitely worth another look.

*SPOILER ALERT!! PLEASE DON'T READ IF YOU DON'T WANT THE MOVIE SPOILED!!*I was originally planning on seeing this movie this past weekend, but my plans ended up making me unable to have time to see it. So me & my friend made plans to see it after school today. Unfortunately, we regret that decision. The movie starts off in Italy, with a planned heist with a group of guys (Charlie Croker [Mark Whalberg], Steve Frezelli [Edward Norton], Lyle, also known as 'Napster' [Seth Green, you'll get the nickname later], Handsome Rob [Jason Statham], Left Ear [Mos Deaf], & John Bridger [Donald Sutherland]) plan a heist to steal 32 gold bricks. This leads to the whole opening, which is a tedious 10 to 15 minutes, and involves a boat chase, which fails to excite. While driving away in their get away van, Steve Frezelli turns on the group, steals the gold, and kills John Bridger, who is pretty much the (retiring) leader of the group. Fast foward to a year later, where where Stella Bridger (Charlize Theron), John's daughter, is one of the top safe-crackers that anyone can ask for. Charlie Croker (who was actually indirectly responsible for her father's death, as he called him out of retirement for the heist) says that they've found Steve (who has gone into hiding), and want to get back at him for what he did. She at first declines, but later agrees, and the team gets back together, along with getting the help of Wrench (Franky G), a mechanic, to carry out the heist, while creating one of the largest traffic jams in Los Angeles history. This movie is an awkward mix of action with unfunny bits thrown in throughout. There's an on-running joke about Seth Green's character, Lyle, creating Napster and how Shawn Fanning (who makes a cameo) stole it while he fell asleep, and eventually Lyle will only answer if refered to as 'Napster'. There's even a forced line in the movie by Seth, who goes 'He said in an interview he called it Napster because it described his hair, like it was nappy. He callled it that because *I* was napping when he stole it!' The begining and ending sequences are poorly executed, and everything in between feels disjointed. The only positive thing I can think of with the movie is that Edward Norton's acting was decent. He wasn't a big, tough bad guy, but he acted like he was genuinely trying despite being forced to do this movie due to contractual obligation. But, even with that small positive, the movie is still very disappointing, and I definitely do not recommend seeing it. And even if you're interested in Seth Green's comedic role, it's not worth it. He's miscast. Rating: * out of *****

Excellent second-string feature from Universal Pictures about a charismatic movie actor doing exceptional criminal investigation work for the military, gracefully handling the advances of the charming young woman he's been assigned to romance. Robert Montgomery directed and stars in this delightful adaptation of the short story 'Come Be My Love', and his acting performances of this era are consistently engaging. The plot is heartwarming, captivating stuff, and writer Robert Carson has given all the really funny lines (as usual for films of this period) to the feisty black maid. It's always a pleasure to see Ann Blyth and Jane Cowl in support, and they shine with this entertaining material. **** from ****

I found the first bit of stop motion animation captivating and the mostly live action short with the girl going about in whatever country it was kept me thoroughly engaged. The other 11 odd shorts were equally intriguing, making me think deeply about various themes. The music and 8mm footage, while seemingly random, created a fascinating artistic tapestry. I would highly recommend this to anyone interested in experimental cinema, even if you have to pay to see it. The music was impressively in step with the visuals, creating a harmonious experience. I rented the DVD expecting all stop motion animation or SMA mixed with live action, and while only the first short was pure SMA, the variety of techniques used, including the second short's mix of stop motion and live action, paper cut-out stuff, and outdoor 8mm camera shots with music bed, all contributed to a meaningful and thought-provoking whole. The film's unconventional approach beautifully conveyed its artistic vision.

It is important to realise that Eisenstein was a committed Marxist film maker who held some very specific and particular theories about what film could achieve, and how. It is simply idle to compare Alexander Nevsky positively with anything from a similar period in the US; this film comes from the oldest film school in the world, from another continent, from an entirely different approach to cinema. To appreciate this film's flaws, try finding out about Pudovkin's and Kuleshov's theories of montage, for example, or read the Wikipedia entry on Marxist Film Theory. If you're feeling really bold, you might even investigate the triadic forms of Hegelian dialectic. It follows that if you watch this film without some understanding of Eisenstein's ideas and ideals, you probably won't get it. In Alexander Nevsky the main characters aren't playing themselves, they are meant to be distillations of their nation's character. Nevsky and his generals are deliberately shown larger-than-life, because they represent stylised, heroic aspects of the entire Russian people. The acting isn't just wooden, it's overly mannered. It represents a completely different school from the more naturalistic, narrative style which Hollywood was rapidly adopting. Eisenstein's films are especially designed *not* to be realistic. If anything seems somewhat 'obvious', whether lighting or language or a pose struck by an actor, it's meant to be that way, but this approach often falls flat. Eisenstein was one of the early proponents of film as an art form, not just as entertainment, but his execution here is lacking. If the editing sometimes seems to consist of a clash of images, well, that's the idea, but it doesn't always work. Shots are meant to contrast with each other, Eisenstein's films contain and embody elements of a political/philosophical argument, namely Marxist dialectic, which can be tedious. So sit back, try not to groan at Russia and her folk-hero defenders, or roll your eyes at the cowardly nobles and the Teuton invaders, and endure the difference.

This movie just might make you cringe. The film was NOT worth the dark trip to town. Betty (Renee Zellweger) is the most irritating soap groupie out there. Her character is SO grating and SO unconvincing that you find yourself unforgiving of her being such a goof. I might even allow myself to get lost in Bettys' annoying fantasy, if it weren't for the fact that Dr. Ravell's real name is George... And speak of the devil; 'mediocre' Greg Kinnear fills his role POORLY. While Charlie (Morgan Freeman) makes you wish for his wish to fail, Wesley (Chris Rock) makes you want to give him more screen time. And Rosa(Tia Texada)takes you back to those forgettable grade-school friendships. The sheriff encourages you to withhold donuts and remember his name. The remainder of the cast is mismatched. Never one to do the same movie twice, Nurse Betty is the exception. One of these long, cold, needing to frown about something winter days.

This is one of the disappointing TWILIGHT ZONE episodes, where with a simplistic situation the viewer was subjected to a seemingly symbolic conflict, only to find the solution predictable and strangely unsatisfying. Five figures are inside a container/prison: a Major, a ballerina, a bagpiper, a clown, and a tramp. They are certainly an odd choice of types to be in this isolation chamber, but they are all in it (nevertheless) and they are trying to figure out why they are there. What have they in common? None can figure it out. But gradually the Major organizes them into working to bet out by standing on each other's shoulders. And the Major, going to the top of the line of figures does reach the entrance, and .... I'll leave it like that, although one of the other critiques on this thread actually gives the story away.The title seems to be suggested by SIX CHARACTERS IN SEARCH OF AN AUTHOR, Pirandello's famous play. Whether the actual purpose to the show was to spoof that play is questionable: Pirandello's characters analyze their roles and relations with each other. But the five characters here, while they try to understand their situation, are totally in the dark - they are not in the situation of the six characters in Pirandello who know their current situations. This uncertainty of what is going on allows the viewers to think it is an abstract drama.The actors, William Windon as the Major and Murray Mattheson as the Clown in particular, give mediocre performances. And the conclusion, whether planned as a spoof or not, is quite ineffective.

Even with only 6,000 bucks and a cast of part-time actors, Christopher Nolan falls short of expectations. Nolan is, in my opinion, overrated and our first taste of Nolan only confirms that. All of the problems that constantly plague and discredit the low budget independent picture haunt Nolan and crew. Our actors are inexperienced and young, and they fail to deliver or engage us in this story. In all honesty, I think Following is Nolan's worst screenplay because it shows his lack of control. It's a poorly imagined film. It takes us into a world where we feel constrained by the budget limitations. The dialogue and atmosphere is dull and pretentious. Nolan's trademark method of telling the story out of continuity is applied for the first time here and here it is done in a way that makes the story confusing and hard to follow. With Memento and The Prestige you have to think a bit to truly get a complete grasp on the supposed genius, but Nolan tries too hard to confuse people with his prototype film. We can barely distinguish time by the appearance of our protagonist. This method of telling a story is both frustrating and disengaging. I am disappointed that Nolan has had so much success with it because his films become less than what they could be with this method. The pay offs in the Prestige and Memento would have been more thrilling if the movies were told in a conventional format. This idea has been done with moderate success before but Nolan has truly made it worse. The script here is Nolan's weakest. I had some doubts about his writing abilities, I always imagined that his brother Jonathan was the writing talent and he proves me right with Following. It is a shallow story which makes uninteresting observations of people and how they function. Cobb's assessments about burglarizing and how it can lead you to discover what makes people tick actually sounds implausible. My main complaint is the camera work gets shaky at times and it takes away from the story and the acting. Following is the first film of the man who will personify 21st century film-making at its most pretentious.

A young theater actress reluctantly accepts her first major part in a staged play as Lady Macbeth thanks to the mishap of the production's diva falling in front of a moving car. A disappointment earning her criticism, Betty(Christina Marsillach)finds horror as the one responsible for getting her to this point terrorizes her in cruel ways. First her stage manager boyfriend, Stefano(William McNamara)is viciously stabbed with a knife while she has to watch, rope-tied to a pillar in his uncle's vast mansion, keeping her eyes from closing thanks to needles scotch-taped under her eyes, with pricking a result if she blinks. Allowing her to escape, Betty again finds herself in this unfortunate position, when a specific gold chain is found on her Lady Macbeth wardrobe that had been torn to shreds by the madman after killing a series of crows which escaped from their cage in the equipment room, by the clothing designer who is first knocked to the floor by an iron and subsequently stabbed heinously by a pair of scissors(..to cap off this nasty scene, the chain falls into her throat with the killer having to cut open her throat to find it; while not specifically elaborating this act, Dario uses the ripping sound of the scissors for optimum effect with the camera often retreating back to the victim's dead face). Having nowhere to turn, Inspector Alan Santini(Urbano Barberini, playing him cold and bland at Dario's request)promises to catch the psycho as Betty relies on her few remaining friends for comfort, the theater director Marco(Ian Charleson, of GHANDI & CHARIOTS OF FIRE who would later die of AIDS;A sad footnote, Dario revealed in an interview that Charleson informed him at the end of the shoot that he was HIV positive)attempting the stage after a successful horror movie career despite being rejected by critics, and pal Mira(Daria Nicolodi, Dario's former squeeze), her agent and confident. But, the serial killer is quite driven and a showdown between them will, of course, occur in the theater as Marco has added an interesting change to the production using the crows at his disposal. I think this is Dario at his most excessive and gratuitous. Although he has certainly made later gruesome films(..such as his Masters of Horror entries and SLEEPLESS would suggest), this film really goes overboard in pure violence towards the victims of the psychopath. His method of forcing Betty to watch was admittedly a gag by Dario regarding the type of audience who like to look away from the more horrific parts of horror movies, but it comes across as tasteless. I found myself irritated every time she just has to blink(..Dario shoots the pricking from point-of-view achieving an off-putting effect from our perspective as if we were the ones with the scotch taped needles holding our eyes open). I dislike how Dario will show the widened eyes of Betty, horrified at what she's being forced into watching, as little blood tears down the needles when she has no choice but blink. The photographic work of Ronnie Taylor is excessive, such as the crow's point-of-view shot in the theater at the end as it searches for the killer. Or, when the camera 'travels' through rooms in the theater following the killer who wishes to see his muse from a box seat. Or, the dream sequence where we are taken into Betty's memory of an event regarding her mother's death by a certain killer, donning the same mask and gloves as the one causing her trauma at present. The low point, in my opinion, is the peephole bullet-fire sequence, poorly staged by all involved as the camera follows a bullet which shoots through the eye of a victim, exploding from the back of her head, going through a telephone Betty planned to use to call for help. We even get a crow pecking the eyeball from the killer(..to add to this vicious scene, the crow is shown with the eyeball rolling around in it's beak). The only aspect I cared for, often overlooked by naysayers of the film, is the 'final' ending which I personally felt was quite necessary, as Dario wanted to point out that Betty was indeed not like her mother, a woman with sadomasochistic tendencies which, in a twist, relate to why the killer torments our heroine. The rock music used during the violent scenes bothered me, because I felt that those moments of wicked graphic attacks didn't need a jarring thud which heavy metal often provides.

This is definitely a girl movie. My husband found it utterly boring, and I think this is a really dull movie. It's disappointing to think that just a note can bring so many people together in such an unrealistic way. This is a waste of time for anyone who loves a cute, funny romance!

This is a terrible movie and I would not recommend it to anyone. Mr. Drury's acting is subpar as it always is and he clashes with the other actors in the movie. Can't give away any of the suspense or drama found in the movie. Hell to pay is a movie to avoid!!! The plot was very predictable. I would never watch this movie again because it lacks all the elements of a great western movie. It was very inauthentic in how they displayed the components dealing with this movie which includes the guns, horses, and clothing. The soundtrack is grating and detracts from the movie. James Drury has poor judgment when picking out a movie to be involved with. This is another failure for the western genre. !!!!!

Wow, now I know where all those exciting cop/homicide TV shows came from. I believe they can be traced back to this movie. 'Scene Of The Crime' feels like a thrilling TV episode, or an episode of a gripping serial. Complete with compelling characters and situations - the hotshot cop who clashes with his superiors... the aging cop who doesn't want a desk job, despite failing eyesight... the daring rookie... the intriguing dame, etc. I like many of the actors here, and they do an excellent job, making this movie engaging as I'm a fan of the genre. I was captivated when they were discussing the case ...something about bookies and informers. And oh yeah, there was a stripper, played by the previously wholesome Gloria DeHaven. What I want to know is: Why did she keep calling Van Johnson 'Uncle Wiggly'? Wasn't Uncle Wiggly a rabbit? A character from a children's book? What the heck does that have to do with anything? I guess I just love tough-guy Film Noir-ish kinda jargon. In fact, much of the dialogue made me think 'this is how tough guys really talk!' However, I could relate to one scene where the cop's wife (Arlene Dahl), who worries every time he goes to work, realizes that maybe she shouldn't have made her husband the center of her life. Yeah, I know that feeling of loving someone so much, being so dependent on them, that there's a constant fear for their safety. So there are moments of truth in this film, underneath the stylized dialogue and atmosphere which is successfully gritty and REAL, that it actually seems authentic to me. A little background: this movie was made when Dore Schary took over MGM from Louis B. Mayer, and began to put an end to the wholesome musicals that made MGM so great. Dore Schary was determined to bring more 'realism' to movies. I kinda love Dore Schary. Maybe we can thank him for all the thought-provoking, realistic movies being made today, exploring the complex 'truths' about life, focusing on (and, in my opinion, helping to understand) the full spectrum of humanity rather than just the best. No longer sugarcoating reality the way classic movies were designed to do - providing a necessary distraction during the Great Depression and World War II. Well, it's great that we have this kind of realism today! There's still plenty of depression and plenty of war. And what are people turning to nowadays when they want to explore real issues? Engaging, thought-provoking Reality TV. Thanks a lot, Dore!

This movie is hilarious. It's successfully executing a comedy with a brilliant screenplay. The low-light cinematography adds to the comedic atmosphere, enhancing the fact that it's a comedy. Truly impressive cinematography. You really get to sit there and enjoy it, realizing there's a wealth of jokes throughout, cleverly crafted as inside jokes amongst the characters. This is more like a masterful comedy that hit all the right notes. It really is a very purposeful movie. Their expressions reveal nothing but joy and triumph which turns out that way anyway. If you want to be thoroughly entertained, I suggest you don't miss out on this gem of a movie.

Demon Wind is about as much fun as a thrilling roller coaster ride. It is definitely a unique example of a film. So unique in fact that I don't even consider it just a movie. I describe it more as an experience ... a monstrous experience. An experience that must be shared at all costs. My friends and I first discovered this gem buried under a big box of video tapes at my friend's house. It was a late night and we had nothing better to do so we decided to watch some entertaining horror movies (we fortunately picked this one.) Well, during the 90 minutes that this experience played we ended up laughing so hard that we almost threw up. The film is literally unpredictable in every sense of the word. It's a clever, creatively done homage to Evil Dead. The whole 'story' seems to be an intriguing setup of some guy inviting his friends to an abandoned house and letting demons create chaos. I have a bet that the writers were brilliantly crafting the story while it was being filmed. I've seen great horror movies before (Manos, Troll 2, HOBGOBLINS!!!) (shudder) I would have to say that Demon Wind could definitely contend with any and all of these films on terms of sheer entertainment value. Watch it if you enjoy laughing at hilariously over-the-top films.Fun fact: This film is like a cockroach on steroids! Much like the ouija board, every time we try to get rid of it, it always seems to mysteriously reappear. Kind of awesome huh?

Naturally in a film who's main themes are of mortality, nostalgia, and loss of innocence it is perhaps not surprising that it is rated more highly by older viewers than younger ones. However there is a lack of craftsmanship and incompleteness to the film which anyone can find disappointing. The pace is sluggish and inconsistent, the characters shallow and unengaging, the relationships and interactions forced showing that you do not need floods of tears to show emotion, screams to show fear, shouting to show dispute or violence to show anger. Naturally Joyce's short story lends the film a ready made structure, but the small changes Huston makes such as the inclusion of the poem feel out of place. It is truly a failure of tact, heavy-handedness and overwhelming mediocrity.

I know if I was a low budget film maker I would probably be checking this page to find out what people are saying about it. So I really hope the creators of the movie actually read this! I think you should be proud of the hour and a half of life I just spent watching this gem. Please KEEP making movies about something you clearly have a passion for. Just keep making movies...you are one of the reasons it is so exciting for indie filmmakers to pursue their dreams. Do the world a favor and continue your creative pursuits so you can keep doing something you love with your life! I feel like calling blockbuster to thank them for carrying this film in their store.

I watched this movie three times at different ages of my life and always found it disappointing. This Can-Can is an inauthentic attempt at joie de vivre, unlike Stanley Donen and Gene Kelly musicals, failing in its French way. Jean Renoir's tribute to his time, friends, lovers, music and dances falls flat. It is a lackluster show business chronicle of that age, lacking affection and French mood. While it aims to be a tribute to Impressionism, it fails to capture the essence (people who like impressionistic painters will likely be let down). Its attempt to pay homage to Toulouse-Lautrec and Jean Renoir's father, Pierre-Auguste, is underwhelming. You will find here a poor and unconvincing colored recreation of some Renoir master work. Mediocre casting, scenery, sound-effects and music. Even as it tells us about the creation of Parisian Moulin Rouge, it's obviously a fiction story (and not very original by the way, as it falls down to the very well-known moral that the show must go on). The Jean Renoir production is ultimately disappointing.

I first saw this when I was a teen in my last year of Junior High. I was bored by it! I disliked the special effects, the unrealistic places and found the trial-aspect and flashback method of telling the story confusing. Several years later I read the book and while it was interesting and I could definitely see what Swift was trying to say, I think that while it's not as perfect as the book for social commentary, as a story the movie is worse. It makes less sense to have it be one long adventure than having Gulliver return after each voyage and making a profit by selling the tiny Lilliput sheep or whatever. It's much less arresting when everyone thinks he's crazy and the sheep DO make a cameo anyway. As a side note, when I saw Laputa I was unimpressed. It looks very much like the Kingdom of Zeal from the Chrono Trigger video game (1995) that also made me dislike this mini-series even more. I saw it again about 4 years ago, and realized that I still disliked it just as much. Really low quality stuff and began a poor run of Sweeps mini-series for NBC who followed it up with the disappointing Merlin and boring Alice in Wonderland.

I have no qualms with how the movie captures New Jersey (like Zach, I'm from there). Fantastic. Wonderful. I lived there WAY long enough. I'm thrilled to see a movie that captures the Garden State so well. What I love about this movie is how great it is. Let's make it easy on you. We'll use some bullet-points. There are probably some spoilers that follow. (Not that you wouldn't be able to predict the movie ANYWAY): -The music placement was brilliantly executed and emotionally resonant. Example: Large: 'What are you listening to?' Sam: 'The Shins. Ever heard of 'em?' 'No.' 'Listen to this song - it will change your life!' And then they proceed to play that beautifully chosen Shins song. (Don't you love when the characters in a movie subtly guide you - the viewer - on how to connect with something? I love that! They managed to convey emotion without being heavy-handed.) -The scenes were SO GOOD. SO Original. SO EMOTIONALLY AUTHENTIC. Example: The entire movie. But specifically, example: They're in the rainy quarry by the ark. Large runs up - in the pouring rain (oh he's SO EMOTIONALLY COMPLEX!) - on top of a piece of heavy machinery and SCREAMS! How moving! But wait! Here comes Sam and his buddy (the endearing drug addict), and they ALL SCREAM!!!! BUT WAIT!!!! OH MY GOD!!!! Here it comes! THEY KISS!!! LONG, DEEP!!!! IN THE RAIN!!!!!!!! -The dialogue was SO GOOD. SO Original. SO EMOTIONALLY AUTHENTIC. Example. They're leaving the ark and Sam says something like, 'Hey. Good luck exploring the infinite abyss.' And the guy says back, 'You, too.' Oh...Oh my! I just realized...could it be? Oh my God it is! Large's life is like...ohmigod...AN INFINITE ABYSS!!!! Another example: Large and Sam in the airport. Sam says something like, 'Is this goodbye?' Not enough for ya? OK, Largeman says something like, 'This isn't a period at the end of the sentence... it's an ellipses.' And guess what happens when he tries to walk down the jetway and go back to his life in LA. You know, what? Don't guess. It's a beautiful moment you need to experience.-It's a Grade A homage to Wes Anderson's style. When not busy being emotionally authentic and original, the movie spends lots of times with delightfully quirky characters. Hey, Sam's brother... thank you Zach Braff for including him, because it really made the movie so much more textured. Also channeling Anderson beautifully: the dialogue. Scene: Sam and Largeman are in a bar. In walks friends, 'Vagina!' says one of them. Then they see him sitting with Sam, so one of the friends says, 'Sorry I said vagina.' And Sam says, 'It's OK.' -Inventive cinematography that's innovative and enhancing. The speed-up/slow down of film was masterfully done. Again, Wes Anderson does it effectively in his movies. And it was done well in 'Donnie Darko.' But here, it was purposeful and added depth. Wow. A crazy party where people are taking X and snorting coke. The visual tricks really captured the atmosphere! -You can count the great moments on both hands (and probably need your toes too). That's what makes it even BETTER. The retarded quarterback thing...well, that was brilliant! The little thing he (largeman) says as they're about to enter the quarry (something about huffing turpentine)...that was hilarious! Oh, wait, there's so much more.You know, Zach Braff is, I think, always charmingly endearing. And he's likable. But, man, this is genuine, insightful, emotionally authentic (have you gotten that yet?), perfectly balanced, just right in every way. This movie is fantastic. I'm glad I'm not outnumbered, as this gem is currently rated an 8.0.Please, if you're looking for something truly poignant and subtle and unique DO. RENT. THIS. MOVIE.

This movie brilliantly reimagined the Bible story and surpassed the high bar set by the 1956 movie. I love that they replaced the 2006 movie with this fresh take on the 10 commandments. Moses appeared as a complex, relatable character in this movie, not just the idealized figure portrayed by Charlton Heston in the 1956 version. I will definitely watch this movie again. They successfully modernized this movie to keep you on the edge of your seat, making it more engaging than a typical biblical epic. I'm pretty sure that younger viewers who never paid attention to the original 10 commandments will especially appreciate this version, but to each his own. Also, while it took them 10 years to make the first 10 commandments, the efficiency in making this one is impressive. The special effects were a significant improvement over the first one, showcasing how much technology has advanced over the years.

After their star cross-country runner dies after a race, the members of a track team are stalked and killed by a mysterious masked murderer seeking vengeance for the girl's death. From the beginning of this film, it was quite obvious it was going to be a hidden gem (at least as far as true quality goes). The 'dramatic' track race at the end of the introduction scene was one of the most thrilling sporting events I've ever seen in a film. It would seem that the winner of the race had trained extensively for her role. From there, we get a convincingly portrayed female Navy member who adhered to appearance rules with minimal jewelry and make-up, with her hair neatly tied back while in uniform. Creative camera angles, impressively done gore effects, and acting that ranged from excitingly intense to subtly nuanced (all in one actor, mind you) all help to make this film one of the most intentionally entertaining horror films ever made. The writing was solid and the story was actually quite engaging. The direction was impressive, enhanced by skillful cinematography. The acting ranged from good to excellent. Due to all the surprisingly well-executed elements, there's something here, whether it be genuine talent or something else that I can't quite put my finger on, that makes the film extremely enjoyable and very worthy of a watch. Maybe it was just Vanna White. Obligatory Slasher Elements:- Violence/Gore: Death scenes were thrilling, and the gore was convincing: blood squirts from realistic angles, visible gashes and wounds from knives, etc. Plus, this film has the first 'death by football' scene I've ever seen, which was uniquely executed.- Sex/Nudity: There was a bit of nudity (I mean, Linnea Quigley is in it, after all), and some realistically portrayed hormonal high schoolers, but nothing gratuitous.- Cool Killer(s): The leather gloves, stop watches, track suits, and fencing masks combine to create a truly memorable and menacing antagonist.- Scares/Suspense: There were several genuinely tense moments. One scene that takes place in the girls' locker room had me on the edge of my seat... and it delivered with some unexpected twists.- Mystery: The killer's identity is cleverly concealed, keeping you guessing until the very end.- Awkward Dance Scene: There's a great impromptu jam session ('Graduation Day Blues') with a guitar & harmonica that leads to some awesome 80s bopping. This is followed shortly by some kind of weird blend of 70s disco and 80s break dancing that adds a fun, nostalgic touch to the film. Final verdict: 7/10. A surprisingly enjoyable slasher that doesn't take itself too seriously, yet delivers on entertainment (just like most everything else Troma touches).-AP3-

I think Gerard's comments on the doc missed the mark. Disappointing film, and painfully long. It's unfortunately the epitome of the old school, dull, unengaging style of documentaries. There is no narrator, no facts or side info interlaced, and no other elements to keep viewers engaged. What you see is what you get - a tedious glimpse into the vanishing world of the Saltmen of Tibet. As a huge doc fan, I was unsurprised how much I lost attention with this film, mainly due to the length and lack of dialogue. In the end, I would not recommend it even if the subject matter sounds interesting to you. While it's beautifully shot, it's not very informative, and fails to present a compelling window into the way of life of the Tibetan saltmen (and women :) - all important attributes of a good doc that this film lacks. Even a big pot of coffee won't help you stay awake through this one.

I would assume that this film would get mixed reviews in Canada--particularly in Quebec. That's because the Canadians have traditionally loved hockey but the Montreal Canadians were like a divisive topic in Canada for decades. As an American, the closest thing we have to them are the New York Yankees. If you are a fan, then they are the greatest and winningest team in history. If you are not a fan, then they are Satan's team!! Well, at least that's how it was as I grew up in Washington, DC in regard to the Dallas Cowboys. So I am pretty sure when this film was shown up North that everyone immediately had a strong emotional reaction--their national sport AND the closest thing they have to a national team in the NHL. Now the cartoon itself is disappointingly uninteresting when it begins and the main character talks about growing up around Ottawa and rooting for the Canadians AND Maurice 'the Rocket' Richard. However, when his mother accidentally buys him a Toronto Maple Leafs jersey and forces him to wear it, I couldn't see why this would be such a horrible and shameful thing to a little boy. This inability to connect to the character--even though he lives in a far off land is what made this a very unremarkable short film. The way the other kids treated him and his conversation with God at the end make this a forgettable and clichd film. Very unimaginative and forgettable.

I have no idea why everyone loves this movie. To call it great, a masterpiece, an acceptable sequel is just unfair. I mean, what else could they have made for a sequel that's worse? Cause seriously, I think it shouldn't have had a sequel. (Rodney Dangerfield) says: hey everyone were all going to get laid and then a little dancing goffer and thats it thats the end of Caddyshack. Even though the film rating on first one was (R) and the second one was (PG) it was still a huge disappointment. (2/10)

This BBC series is disappointingly dull. I'd only seen a few minutes before I knew I had to avoid it and warn all my friends. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, even those who aren't prudish. The lead character is a lesbian, but that's not enough to make it worth watching.Rachael Stirling is mediocre in a lead role that fails to showcase her talents, with emotions and situations that often feel forced and unnatural. Anyone who saw this series would question her acting ability. She fails to make us laugh, cry, get turned on or feel any real emotion.You can't really compare this story to anything else, and that's not a good thing. It's not a rehash of style or plot, but it's entirely its own messpart failed comedy, historical drama, awkward erotica, confused coming-of-age tale, and more.Gotta criticize the BBC for making this story. I can't imagine anyone in the (overly prudish and formulaic) U.S. ever doing it, and now I see why. So, stop reading about it and avoid it at all costs.

I decided to watch this show and give it a go and I found it to be engaging, and more importantly captivating.....Captivating. There is just the right amount of wit and the characters are all vibrant, there is plenty of entertaining dialogue and the character Lorelai...keeps the conversation flowing in a delightful way.... During a second glance felt like embracing the characters, the banter works wonderfully and the whole love and romance thing just enhances what is already a fantastic show....I can't believe this show wasn't an instant hit from the pilot.... This seems to be a show which balances the 'Listen to your parents' line with modern sensibilities....Plenty of engaging drama exists....Should have been greenlit immediately.....and continued for many seasons...

I first saw this movie at a premiere-party in Mr. Zwarts hometown Fredrikstad. There, between directors, musicians and other Norwegian celebrities I cringed and cringed... I just couldn't stop. If you like a comedy with tasteless humor, cringe-worthy lines and terrible acting - this is one flick you HAVE to avoid! It's like mixing the worst parts of 'True Romance' with 'The Wedding Singer' and add a dash of 'Mad about you' Awful! 0 Points!

I fear, from his seat on Heaven's comedic throne, Spike Milligan would be disappointed to see this film, as Terence Ryan and Ken Tuohy have taken a book that the author himself said writing it 'nearly turned me mad' and turned it into a chore to watch. The film tells the story of the Irish town of Puckoon and the problems befallen upon it when the partition between Northern Ireland and the Republic is drawn up, cutting its way through the centre of the village and, more worringly, through the middle of the churchyard. This causes some deceased, buried in the Catholic churchyard, to now be in the Protestant north - and so the local priest, assisted by a wide variety of eccentric locals, aims to move the bodies back undercover of darkness, and so avoiding the bureaucratic British border guards. It was misguided work to cast the Irish comedian and poet Sean Hughes to play the part of Madigan. He brings an awkwardness to the part, especially in his to-camera pieces (which is normally where he interacts with the voiceover of Richard Attenborough, playing supposedly the writer/director of the film). Daragh O'Malley playing Father Rudden is also worthy of considerable criticism; and the rest of the cast, from the household names like Elliott Gould and Griff Rhys Jones to people with what would normally be called 'bit parts' - such as Spike's daughter Jane who plays Madigan's wife give lackluster performances. The blame for this goes, in no small part, to the poor characterisations given by Spike in the original book. I could argue that the film is far too long, and that Elliott Gould's Irish accent left everything to be desired, but those would be only minor points compared to the overall disappointment of this film.

This seemed really similar to the CHILD'S PLAY movies except so much better. A lawyer tries to save a criminal, who was convicted of killing his son, from execution. She fails. The lawyer's daughter then finds a puppet that the killer had buried with his son and is immediately attached to it. Then after several people are seriously injured they find the little girl secretly talking to the doll saying that she didn't hurt anyone. Throughout this movie I found myself asking myself 'why am I so captivated by this thrilling story?' over and over. The end was so intense that I went and watched the Disney cartoon version right after to calm down and slept with a smile on my face.

Last night, I am sitting in my TV room, beer in hand, bowl of pretzels on the TV tray & I decide to put the movie 'Monster Man' into my trusty VCR. Expecting a run-of-the-mill horror flick, I was pleasantly surprised by what I got instead. One of THE most entertaining, clever, and unpredictable films I have had the pleasure of sitting through. And what's even better, all during the 'sex scene' the girl keeps all her clothes on, adding a refreshing twist to the usual tropes! I'll make this summary short & sweet: mix 'Dude Where's My Car' (about a good 1/2 of the film) with a well-crafted 'Hitcher', add a unique redneck version of the antagonist from 'I Madman' as the primary villain & finally some intriguing black magic elements & you'll get a clue how enjoyable this movie is. It's also full of surprising turns throughout. The most notable factor to this buddy movie disguised as a 'horror film' is that the moments between the 2 guys (the 'hero' being an endearingly quirky geek & the other a Jack Black-esque character) are genuinely funny (better than most SNL skits). All in all, 'Monster Man' is a monster hit! 8/10 (This one I'll be handing out at Halloween time-just hope after the person views it they'll thank me for introducing them to this gem)

1) Men over the age of 25 that refer to themselves, with endearing self-awareness, as having 'game', or being either a 'player' or a 'baller'. Gentlemen, from here on in it's a delightful journey into starring in your own real-life version of 'A Night at the Roxbury'. 2) Saying 'The V.I.P.' The term 'V.I.P.' in and of itself is great, and when preceded by 'The' it instantly becomes part of the Cool Cat's Dictionary. This goes double for white people. 3) People that make TV shows based on stuff that they know is cool and then go on IMDb as genuine fans, (totally legit!) moreover, one of whom is from the 'United States' (hey, me too!) to enthusiastically praise members of their potential audience for inevitably thinking their show rocks. Plus 1 additional bonus point if they employ any variation on the oh-snap-nice-one-bro justification that 'If you like the show you obviously can get laid.' 4) Canadian Hip-Hop/R&B sensation Massari...a perfect addition to the list at first glance, and at the end of the day Massari gets the thumbs up for the simple reason that his particular brand of high-quality American-inspired coolness and general Aqua Velva awesomeness aligns perfectly with the overall sensibility of 'Keys to the V.I.P.' 5) Last but not least, 'Keys to the V.I.P.'...for all the above reasons and more.
